7,11 G#cell_line|15,23 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

We now demonstrate that B7 , but not LFA-3 , strongly costimulated IL-2 transcription and mRNA expression in CD4+ T cells .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line

Maximal increase in IL-2 transcription was recorded with CHO-DR/ B7 / LFA-3 , suggesting a cooperative effect of B7 and LFA-3 at the transcriptional level .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Gel-shift analysis demonstrated that stimulation of CD4+ T cells with CHO-DR and staphylococcal enterotoxin A was sufficient to induce significant amounts of NF-kappa B binding proteins , whereas induction of AP-1 binding proteins required costimulation .
6,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|30,33 G#protein

LFA-3 induced moderate levels of AP-1 , but did not influence the levels of NF-kappa B , while B7 costimulation strongly induced both AP-1 and substantially enhanced NF-kappa B binding proteins .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|27,31 G#protein

The CHO-DR/ B7 / LFA-3 triple transfectant induced a further increase in AP-1 and NF-kappa B binding proteins compared with the double transfectants .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|1,7 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_line

The level of Oct-1 binding proteins remained similar in all samples .
3,6 G#protein

Super-shift analysis revealed that the NF-kappa B complex of costimulated CD4+ T cells contained large amounts of p50 , substantial amounts of p65 , and marginal levels of c-Rel proteins .
5,7 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line|9,13 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Our results indicate distinct effects of B7 and LFA-3 costimulation on the activity of AP-1 and NF-kappa B .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

These may partly account for the differential effects of B7 and LFA-3 costimulation on IL-2 expression .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The Ah receptor recognizes DNA binding sites for the B cell transcription factor , BSAP : a possible mechanism for dioxin-mediated alteration of CD19 gene expression in human B lymphocytes .
1,3 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|27,30 G#cell_type

2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin ( TCDD ) inhibits murine and human B lymphocyte immunoglobulin production through an unknown mechanism .


This study investigated the effect of TCDD on expression of the CD19 gene in a human B lymphocyte cell line .
11,13 G#DNA|15,20 G#cell_line

Northern blot analysis showed that TCDD treatment decreased steady state levels of CD19 mRNA by 67 % in the IM-9 cell line .
12,14 G#RNA|19,22 G#cell_line

Using a gel mobility shift assay , we identified a DNA-binding complex in IM-9 nuclear extracts that by several criteria appears to be the Ah receptor .
10,12 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

In addition , the Ah receptor complex recognized a DNA binding site for B cell lineage-specific activator protein ( BSAP ) in the promoter region of the human CD19 gene which is similar to the consensus Ah receptor DNA binding site .
4,6 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|13,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|36,38 G#protein|38,41 G#DNA|35,41 G#DNA

These results suggest that the AhR could interfere with BSAP -stimulated CD19 gene transcription by competition for a common DNA binding site .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA

Inhibitory action of nm23 proteins on induction of erythroid differentiation of human leukemia cells .
3,5 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

We recently identified a differentiation inhibitory factor ( I-factor ) in mouse myeloid leukemia M1 cells as a murine homolog of the human nm23-H2 gene product .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,16 G#cell_line|18,20 G#protein|22,26 G#protein

nm23 genes encode proteins that participate in tumor metastasis regulation and in various fundamental cellular processes , although their mechanisms of action are still unknown .
0,2 G#DNA

Although all nm23 proteins contain nucleoside diphosphate ( NDP ) kinase activity , it has not been established that the enzyme activity mediated the various functions of nm23 proteins .
2,4 G#protein|5,11 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

In the present experiment , we examined the effect of nm23 proteins on various differentiation induction systems of human leukemic cells including HL-60 , U937 , HEL/S , KU812F , K562 , and HEL cells .
10,12 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_line|24,25 G#cell_line|26,27 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_line|33,34 G#cell_line|22,35 G#cell_line

Native human erythrocyte NDP kinase protein inhibited the induction of erythroid differentiation of HEL , KU812 and K562 cells , but not the induction of monocytic or granulocytic differentiation of HL-60 , U937 and HEL/S cells .
0,6 G#protein|13,19 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_line|32,33 G#cell_line|34,35 G#cell_line|30,36 G#cell_line

The erythroid differentiation of HEL cells was inhibited by recombinant human nm23 -H1 , -H2 , mouse nm23 -M1 , and -M2 proteins .
4,6 G#cell_line|10,15 G#protein|16,22 G#protein|9,23 G#protein

Moreover , both the mutant nm23-H2His protein and truncated nm23-H2 protein containing N-terminal ( 1-60 ) peptide , which do not have NDP kinase activity , also inhibited erythroid differentiation of HEL cells .
4,7 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_line

These results suggest that ( 1 ) the differentiation inhibitory activity of I-factor /nm23 protein is not restricted to monocytic differentiation of M1 cells , ( 2 ) the inhibitory activity is exhibited without species specificity , and ( 3 ) the differentiation inhibitory activity of the nm23/NDP kinase protein is independent of its enzyme activity and requires the presence of N-terminal peptides .
12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_line|47,50 G#protein

Lipopolysaccharide -induced E-selectin expression requires continuous presence of LPS and is inhibited by bactericidal/permeability-increasing protein .
2,3 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

Endothelial cells stimulated by LPS express E-selectin , which plays an important role in mediating neutrophil adhesion during inflammation .
0,2 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

E-selectin is induced within 1-2 h , peaks at 4-6 h , and gradually returns to basal level by 24 h .
0,1 G#protein

rBPI21 , a recombinant N-terminal fragment of human bactericidal/permeability-increasing protein ( BPI ) , inhibited LPS -induced E-selectin expression when added at the same time as , and up to 6 h after , LPS .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Delayed administration of rBPI21 also affected LPS -mediated activation of the nuclear factor , NF-kappa B .
3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Two to 4 h following LPS addition to endothelial cells , when NF-kappa B was already activated , addition of rBPI21 resulted in marked reduction of NF-kappa B detectable at 4 or 6 h .
8,10 G#cell_type|12,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

These results indicate that endothelial activation requires continuous presence of LPS , and rBPI21 acts to reverse LPS -mediated endothelial activation by interrupting the on-going LPS signal .
13,14 G#protein

GM-CSF and IL-2 share common control mechanisms in response to costimulatory signals in T cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Antigen complexed with major histocompatibility complex class I or II molecules on the surface of antigen presenting cells interacts with the T cell receptor ( TCR ) on the surface of T cells and initiates an activation cascade .
3,11 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

So called costimulatory signals , mediated by other cell surface interactions or soluble cytokines produced by antigen presenting cells , are also required for complete T cell activation .
12,14 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

High levels of cytokine gene expression in T cells also required both TCR and costimulatory signals .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein

The granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor requires sequences in the promoter as well as a powerful enhancer located 3kb upstream to respond to TCR -like signals .
1,4 G#protein|8,9 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

These promoter and enhancer regions are mainly activated by the transcription factor nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) .
1,5 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|10,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The activation of NFAT by TCR signals has been well described for interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) and IL-4 gene transcription in T cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

Costimulatory signals , such as activation of the CD28 cell surface molecule on T cells , lead to activation through a distinct region of the granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) promoter .
8,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|25,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|25,32 G#DNA

This region is termed the CK-1 or CD28RE and appears to bind specific members of the NF-kappa B family of transcription factors .
5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Human T leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) infects T cells and can lead to increase GM-CSF expression .
10,12 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

We have found that the HTLV-1 transactivator protein , tax , acts as a costimulatory signal for GM-CSF and IL-2 gene transcription , in that it can cooperate with TCR signals to mediate high level gene expression .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Tax activates the GM-CSF promoter through the CK-1 /CD28RE region and also activates nuclear factor-kappa B binding to this region .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|13,16 G#protein

However , other transcription factors or coactivators of NF-kappa B are required for tax activation but these remain to be identified .
3,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

The CK-1 /CD28RE of GM-CSF shows a high degree of similarity to the IL-2 CD28RE and the IL-3 gene also contains a related region .
1,2 G#DNA|2,3 G#DNA|4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA

This observation , together with the fact that both GM-CSF and IL-2 respond to TCR signals via NFAT , implies a high degree of conservation in the regulation of cytokine gene expression in T cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type

Danazol decreases transcription of estrogen receptor gene in human monocytes .
4,6 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_type

1. Administration of danazol for over one month reduced the levels of estrogen receptor ( ER ) and its mRNA to approximately 50 and 20 % , respectively in monocytes .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#RNA|29,30 G#cell_type

2. Danazol did not alter the degradation rate of ER mRNA in monocytes .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#RNA|12,13 G#cell_type

3. Danazol decreased the transcription rate of ER gene to approximately 50 % in monocytes in a run-on assay .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|14,15 G#cell_type

4. Danazol may release estrogen predominance via the reduction of transcription for ER gene , which leads to the reduction of ER mRNA and ER expressions in monocytes .
12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#RNA|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type

Functional characterization of novel IL-2 transcriptional inhibitors .
4,5 G#protein

IL-2 -mediated T cell proliferation is a critical early event in the inflammatory process .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#cell_type

Formation of the NFAT -1 transcriptional complex on the IL-2 promoter is essential for IL-2 transcription .
3,4 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein

Using a cell line that is stably transfected with a trimer of the NFAT -1 regulatory element linked to a lac-Z reporter gene , we screened for inhibitors of NFAT -1-mediated beta-galactosidase activity .
13,14 G#protein|13,17 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

WIN 61058 and WIN 53071 were identified as microM inhibitors .


These compounds also inhibited beta-galactosidase mRNA levels .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#RNA

Similar inhibition of NFAT -1-mediated gene expression was observed in a second cell line , which is stably transfected with NFAT -1 regulatory elements linked to the reporter gene for sCD8 .
3,4 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein|20,24 G#DNA|27,31 G#DNA

At 10 microM , both compounds inhibited IL-2 mRNA and protein levels in the NFAT -1-linked lac-Z transfectants , and in human lymphocytes .
14,15 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line|21,23 G#cell_type

Both compounds inhibited the mixed lymphocyte reaction , and this inhibition was reversed by exogenous IL-2 .
15,16 G#protein

WIN 53071 inhibited IL-2 production induced in the calcium-dependent PMA and ionomycin pathway .
3,4 G#protein

Conversely , calcium-independent anti-CD28 Ab and PMA-induced IL-2 production was resistant .
2,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Both compounds altered the NFAT -1 transcriptional complex , causing its retarded mobility on gels .
4,5 G#protein|4,8 G#protein

By these functional criteria , we believe we have identified two structurally distinct , novel inhibitors of NFAT -1-mediated transcription .
17,18 G#protein

Transcriptional regulation of the vacuolar H(+)-ATPase B2 subunit gene in differentiating THP-1 cells .
4,8 G#protein|4,9 G#DNA|10,13 G#cell_line

Monocyte-macrophage differentiation was used as a model system for studying gene regulation of the human vacuolar H(+)-ATPase ( V-ATPase ) .
14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

We examined mRNA levels of various V-ATPase subunits during differentiation of both native monocytes and the cell line THP-1 , and found that transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms could account for increases in cell V-ATPase content .
2,3 G#RNA|6,7 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_line|18,19 G#cell_line|33,34 G#protein

From nuclear runoff experiments , we found that one subunit in particular , the B2 isoform ( Mr = 56,000 ) , was amplified primarily by transcriptional means .
14,16 G#protein

We have begun to examine the structure of the B2 subunit promoter region .
9,11 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|9,13 G#DNA

Isolation and sequencing of the first exon and 5'-flanking region of this gene reveal a TATA-less promoter with a high G + C content .
5,7 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA

Primer extension and ribonuclease protection analyses indicate a single major transcriptional start site .
3,4 G#protein|9,13 G#DNA

We transfected promoter-luciferase reporter plasmids into THP-1 cells to define sequences that mediate transcriptional control during monocyte differentiation .
2,5 G#DNA|6,8 G#cell_line

We found that sequences downstream from the transcriptional start site were sufficient to confer increased expression during THP-1 differentiation .
17,18 G#cell_line

DNase I footprinting and sequence analysis revealed the existence of multiple AP2 and Sp1 binding sites in the 5'-untranslated and proximal coding regions .
0,2 G#protein|11,16 G#DNA|18,23 G#DNA

Synergy between signal transduction pathways is obligatory for expression of c-fos in B and T cell lines : implication for c-fos control via surface immunoglobulin and T cell antigen receptors .
10,11 G#DNA|12,17 G#cell_line|20,21 G#DNA|23,25 G#protein|26,30 G#protein

Expression of the protooncogene c-fos is controlled by three main regulatory pathways involving kinase C , cAMP , and calcium .
4,5 G#DNA|3,5 G#DNA|13,15 G#protein

Kinase C mediates its effects via phosphorylation of serum response factor ( SRF ) which interacts with the serum response element ( SRE ) ; cAMP and calcium mediate their effects via phosphorylation of CREB ( cAMP regulatory element binding protein ) presumably by activation of a protein kinase A or calmodulin-regulated kinase .
0,2 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|34,35 G#protein|36,41 G#protein|47,50 G#protein|51,53 G#protein

We have examined the function of these elements in Burkitt 's lymphoma cells ( Ramos and Daudi ) as well as a T lymphocytic cell line ( Jurkat ) .
9,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line|22,26 G#cell_line|27,28 G#cell_line

We have found that stimulation of any one of these pathways alone has little or no effect on c-fos induction .
18,19 G#DNA

However , kinase C activation ( PMA stimulation ) combined with either cAMP ( forskolin plus MIX ) or calcium stimulation ( ionophore ) leads to greatly enhanced c-fos induction .
2,4 G#protein|28,29 G#DNA

By contrast , cAMP in the presence of calcium shows no synergy in c-fos induction .
13,14 G#DNA

Okadaic acid augments PMA- as well as calcium- mediated activation of c-fos , and has little or no effect when combined with cAMP .
11,12 G#DNA

The main difference between Ramos ( B cells ) and Jurkat ( T cells ) in the regulation of c-fos is that cAMP plus calcium is strongly synergistic in Jurkat and is without effect in Ramos .
4,5 G#cell_line|6,8 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_line|12,14 G#cell_type|19,20 G#DNA|29,30 G#cell_line|35,36 G#cell_line

Analysis of AP-1 activity using gel mobility shift assays confirms that the requirements for synergy in c-fos mRNA induction are paralleled by requirements for synergy in induction of AP-1 activity .
2,3 G#protein|16,17 G#DNA|16,18 G#RNA|28,29 G#protein

Signaling in B cells due to anti-Ig stimulation involves both kinase C activation and release of intracellular calcium , and results in c-fos mRNA induction .
2,4 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|22,23 G#DNA|22,24 G#RNA

Our results indicate that synergy between the kinase C activation and calcium is needed for efficient c-fos induction since neither of these two alone induces c-fos well .
7,9 G#protein|16,17 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA

That synergy of signaling pathways is relevant for the anti-Ig induction of c-fos is supported by the fact that cAMP -inducing agents and okadaic acid further enhance anti-Ig induction of c-fos .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#DNA

These results suggest that cell-specific patterns of synergy are an essential feature for c-fos induction and may be relevant for c-fos control through B and T cell antigen receptors .
13,14 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|23,29 G#protein

Multiple signals are required for function of the human granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor gene promoter in T cells .
8,12 G#protein|8,14 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type

The human granulocyte-macrophage CSF ( GM-CSF ) gene is expressed in T cells in response to TCR activation that can be mimicked by treatment of the cells with PMA and Ca2+ ionophore .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|1,8 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

The gene contains a proximal functional promoter region ( -620 to +34 ) , as well as a powerful enhancer located 3 kb upstream , both of which are involved in the response of the gene to TCR activation .
4,8 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein

The proximal promoter contains a region termed CLEO ( -54 to -31 ) that consists of a purine -rich element abutting an activator protein-1 ( AP-1 ) -like site , as well as an upstream nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) site ( -85 to -76 ) and a CK-1 element ( -101 to -92 ) .
1,3 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|22,29 G#DNA|35,38 G#protein|39,41 G#protein|34,43 G#DNA|44,47 G#DNA|50,52 G#DNA|53,56 G#DNA

We show in this work that mutations in either the purine -rich region of the CLEO element or the NF-kappa B site result in reduced PMA / Ca2+ activation of a 620-bp human GM-CSF promoter- luciferase reporter construct in Jurkat T cells by 65 % and 50 % , respectively .
10,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|31,38 G#DNA|40,42 G#cell_type|39,42 G#cell_line

The major inducible protein complex that binds to the human CLEO ( hCLEO ) element is an AP-1 -like complex that is inducible by PMA alone , but shows increased binding in response to PMA together with Ca2+ ionophore .
2,5 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|9,15 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

Although the binding of this complex is not cyclosporin -sensitive , promoter induction is inhibited by cyclosporin treatment .


A second weak inducible complex resembling nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NF-AT ) was also observed binding to the hCLEO region .
6,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

By using recombinant proteins , we confirmed that AP-1 , NF-ATp , and a higher order NF-ATp / AP-1 complex could all form with the hCLEO element , and we have also defined the sequence requirements for binding of each of these complexes .
2,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|25,26 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA

We found that expression of a constitutively active form of calcineurin could substitute for Ca2+ ionophore and synergize with PMA to activate the GM-CSF promoter , and conversely that mutant-activated Ras could substitute for PMA and cooperate with Ca2+ ionophore .
10,11 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein

Co-expression of Ras and calcineurin , however , did not activate the GM-CSF promoter , but required the additional expression of NF-kappa B p65 .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|21,23 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

These results imply that at least three signals are required to activate the GM-CSF proximal promoter , and that the signals impinge on distinct transcription factors that bind to the hCLEO and NF-kappa B regions of the promoter .
13,14 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein|30,31 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA|32,34 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA|30,35 G#DNA|37,38 G#DNA

IL-10 induces the tyrosine phosphorylation of tyk2 and Jak1 and the differential assembly of STAT1 alpha and STAT3 complexes in human T cells and monocytes .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,23 G#cell_type|24,25 G#cell_type

IL-10 affects monocytes and T cells by driving the progression of immune responsiveness such that Th2 lymphocyte-mediated effects predominate .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#cell_type|4,6 G#cell_type

In this report , we show that in monocytes and T cells IL-10 stimulates tyrosine phosphorylation of the signal transducers and activators of transcription , STAT1 alpha and STAT3 , in a differential manner such that the relative formation of homo- and hetero dimers varies between the two cell types .
8,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|40,44 G#protein

Moreover , monocytes express a novel IL-10 -stimulated STAT protein with an M(r) of 70 kDa that is recognized by the anti- STAT3 Ab but is not observed in T cells .
2,3 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type

IL-10 treatment of both T cells and monocytes results in the ligand-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of tyk2 and Jak1 , but not Jak2 or Jak3 .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Selective modulation of immune responsiveness by IL-10 in cells such as monocytes and T cells may result in part from the differential activation of STAT protein pairs .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type|24,27 G#protein

Use of new biologic markers in the ovulation induction .


Biological markers of ovulation , after a great in the past , have been fallen into disuse for the large diffusion of biochemical and biophysical ones .


However , the real effect of hormones involved in ovulation is expressed by biological modifications on target tissues .
16,18 G#cell_type

To explore the modifications of not reproductive target tissues as ovulation markers we studied the behaviour of Albuminemia , Platelet Factor IV ( as indicator of Platelet Aggregation ) , Type II estrogenic receptors in 42 ovulation induced women , undergoing our observation .
19,22 G#protein|30,34 G#protein

33 of them had ovulation and 9 developed a LUF syndrome , constituting two biological models of an opposite situation for the three markers observed .


All the markers considered were sufficiently sensitive , but among them , Platelet Factor IV was the most reliable to the hormonal ovulatory situation .
12,15 G#protein

Abnormal regulation of the IL-2 promoter in lpr CD4-CD8-Â T lymphocytes results in constitutive expression of a novel nuclear factor of activated T cells -binding factor .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_line|21,23 G#cell_type|17,23 G#protein|16,25 G#protein

The inert quality of MRL-Ipr/Ipr ( Ipr ) peripheral CD4-CD8- ( CD4-8- ) T cells manifests primarily as an inability to proliferate or produce IL-2 in response to TCR or mitogenic stimulation .
13,15 G#cell_type|4,15 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Yet these same cells do initiate early TCR -mediated signaling events , such as generation of inositol phosphates and increased intracellular calcium .
7,8 G#protein

They also display constitutively high levels of p59fyn and CD3 zeta tyrosine phosphorylation .
7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

The generation of second messengers in T cells normally leads to downstream signaling that results in transcriptional activation of the IL-2 gene .
6,8 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

We , therefore , compared the activation state of the IL-2 gene promoter region in freshly isolated and stimulated Ipr CD4-8- T cells with that of normal T lymphocytes .
10,11 G#protein|10,14 G#DNA|21,23 G#cell_type|19,23 G#cell_line|26,29 G#cell_type

Levels of the octamer , NF-kappa B ( p50-p65 heterodimer ) , and AP-1 transcriptional factors are constitutively elevated in freshly isolated Ipr CD4-8- T cells , consistent with the activated phenotype of these cells .
5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|22,26 G#cell_line

Upon stimulation with mitogens , formation of the transactivating complex , nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NF-AT ) , occurs with normal kinetics in Ipr CD4-8- T cells .
15,17 G#cell_type|11,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|26,30 G#cell_line

Yet , the levels of the activating NF-AT complex never reach those observed in similarly stimulated normal T cells .
7,9 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type

Furthermore , nuclear extracts from Ipr CD4-8- T cells display high levels of a novel specific binding activity at the NF-AT site , which is present at much lower levels in freshly isolated normal T lymphocytes .
7,9 G#cell_type|5,9 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|33,36 G#cell_type

Upon mitogenic stimulation , the binding activity of the novel NF-AT -binding factor is rapidly down-regulated in normal T cells , but persists at high levels in Ipr CD4-8- T cells .
10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type|27,31 G#cell_line

These two abnormalities at the NF-AT site provide a potential mechanism to account for the defect in IL-2 production from Ipr CD4-8- T cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type|20,24 G#cell_line

Cross-linking of CD30 induces HIV expression in chronically infected T cells .
2,3 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

CD30 , a member of the tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) receptor family , is expressed constitutively on the surface of the human T cell line ACH-2 , which is chronically infected with human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV ) -1 .
0,1 G#protein

We demonstrate that cross-linking CD30 with an anti- CD30 -specific monoclonal antibody , which mimics the described biological activities of the CD30 ligand ( CD30L ) , results in HIV expression .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

CD30 cross-linking does not alter proliferation of ACH-2 cells and the induction of HIV expression is not mediated by endogenous TNF alpha/beta .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|20,22 G#protein

Furthermore , cross-linking of CD30 leads to NF-kappa B activation and enhanced HIV transcription .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

Thus , CD30 -CD30L interactions mediate the induction of HIV expression by a kappa B-dependent pathway that is independent of TNF .
2,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

This mechanism may be important in the activation of HIV expression from latently infected CD4+ T cells , especially in lymphoid organs where cell to cell contact is conducive to receptor-ligand interactions .
15,17 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_line

Human MHC class II gene transcription directed by the carboxyl terminus of CIITA , one of the defective genes in type II MHC combined immune deficiency .
1,5 G#DNA|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein

Type II major histocompatibility complex combined immune deficiency ( type II MHC CID or bare lymphocyte syndrome ) is a congenital immunodeficiency disease characterized by absent MHC class II expression .
0,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

Four distinct complementation groups have been identified .


Recently , the defective gene in group II type II MHC CID has been isolated and termed CIITA .
3,5 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA

Here , we demonstrate that CIITA is an MHC class II gene-specific transcription activator .
5,6 G#DNA|8,11 G#protein|8,14 G#DNA

The transcription activation function is provided by the N-terminal acidic domain ( amino acids 26-137 ) , which is experimentally exchangeable with a heterologous viral transcription-activating domain .
8,11 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|23,27 G#protein

The specificity of CIITA for three major MHC class II genes , DR , DQ and DP , is mediated by its remaining C-terminal residues ( amino acids 317-1130 ) .
3,4 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|7,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|23,25 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

The transactivation of multiple cis elements , especially S and X2 , of the DR alpha proximal promoter in group II CID cells is CIITA dependent .
3,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|19,23 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein

Since CIITA overexpression in normal cells did not increase class II expression , we propose that initiation of CIITA expression serves as the on-off switch , while availability of downstream interactor ( s ) limits transcription .
1,2 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Monocyte tethering by P-selectin regulates monocyte chemotactic protein-1 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha secretion .
3,4 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

Signal integration and NF-kappa B translocation [ see comments ]
3,5 G#protein

Adhesion molecules that tether circulating leukocytes to endothelial cells may also transduce or modulate outside-in signals for cellular activation , providing an initial regulatory point in the inflammatory response .
0,2 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type

Adhesion of human monocytes to P-selectin , the most rapidly expressed endothelial tethering factor , increased the secretion of monocyte chemotactic protein-1 ( MCP-1 ) and tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) by the leukocytes when they were stimulated with platelet-activating factor .
3,4 G#cell_type|2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,35 G#cell_type|40,42 G#protein

Increased cytokine secretion was specifically inhibited by G1 , an anti- P-selectin mAb that prevents P-selectin from binding to its ligand ( P-selectin glycoprotein ligand-1 ) on myeloid cells .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

Moreover , tethering by P-selectin specifically enhanced nuclear translocation of nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) , a transcription factor required for expression of MCP-1 , TNF-alpha , and other immediate-early genes .
4,5 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|31,33 G#DNA

These results demonstrate that P-selectin , through its ligands on monocytes , may locally regulate cytokine secretion in inflamed tissues .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

Functional roles of in vivo footprinted DNA motifs within an alpha-globin enhancer .
3,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA

Erythroid lineage and developmental stage specificities .


Transcriptional regulation of the human alpha-like globin genes , embryonic zeta 2 and adult alpha , during erythroid development is mediated by a distal enhancer , HS-40 .
4,8 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA

Previous protein-DNA binding studies have shown that HS-40 consists of multiple nuclear factor binding motifs that are occupied in vivo in an erythroid lineage- and developmental stage- specific manner .
7,8 G#DNA|11,15 G#DNA

We have systematically analyzed the functional roles of these factor binding motifs of HS-40 by site-directed mutagenesis and transient expression assay in erythroid cell cultures .
9,12 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|22,25 G#cell_line

Three of these HS-40 enhancer motifs , 5'NF-E2/AP1 , GT II , and GATA-1(c) , positively regulate the zeta 2-globin promoter activity in embryonic/fetal erythroid K562 cells and the adult alpha -globin promoter activity in adult erythroid MEL cells .
3,4 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|18,21 G#DNA|23,27 G#cell_line|29,31 G#DNA|29,33 G#DNA|35,39 G#cell_line

On the other hand , the 3'NF-E2/AP1 motif is able to exert both positive and negative regulatory effects on the zeta 2-globin promoter activity in K562 cells , and this dual function appears to be modulated through differential binding of the ubiquitous AP1 factors and the erythroid-enriched NF-E2 factor .
6,8 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|25,27 G#cell_line|41,44 G#protein|46,49 G#protein

Mutation in the GATA-1(d) motif , which exhibits an adult erythroid-specific genomic footprint , decreases the HS-40 enhancer function in dimethyl sulfoxide-induced MEL cells but not in K562 cells .
3,5 G#DNA|9,13 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|20,24 G#cell_line|27,29 G#cell_line

These studies have defined the regulatory roles of the different HS-40 motifs .
10,11 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA

The remarkable correlation between genomic footprinting data and the mutagenesis results also suggests that the erythroid lineage- and developmental stage- specific regulation of human alpha-like globin promoters is indeed modulated by stable binding of specific nuclear factors in vivo .
23,27 G#DNA|34,37 G#protein

Nitric oxide -stimulated guanine nucleotide exchange on p21ras .
7,8 G#protein

The protooncogene p21ras , a monomeric G protein family member , plays a critical role in converting extracellular signals into intracellular biochemical events .
1,3 G#DNA|5,10 G#protein

Here , we report that nitric oxide ( NO ) activates p21ras in human T cells as evidenced by an increase in GTP -bound p21ras .
11,12 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_type|22,25 G#protein

In vitro studies using pure recombinant p21ras demonstrate that the activation is direct and reversible .
4,7 G#protein

Circular dichroism analysis reveals that NO induces a profound conformational change in p21ras in association with GDP /GTP exchange .
12,13 G#DNA

The mechanism of activation is due to S-nitrosylation of a critical cysteine residue which stimulates guanine nucleotide exchange .


Furthermore , we demonstrate that p21ras is essential for NO -induced downstream signaling , such as NF-kappa B activation , and that endogenous NO can activate p21ras in the same cell .
5,6 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

These studies identify p21ras as a target of the same cell .
3,4 G#protein|3,4 G#DNA

These studies identify p21ras as a target of NO in T cells and suggest that NO activates p21ras by an action which mimics that of guanine nucleotide exchange factors .
3,4 G#protein|3,4 G#DNA|10,12 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA|25,29 G#protein

Interleukin-2 promoter activity in Epstein-Barr virus -transformed B lymphocytes is controlled by nuclear factor-chi B .
0,2 G#DNA|4,9 G#cell_line|12,15 G#protein

The regulation of interleukin ( IL ) -2 gene expression has been investigated mainly in T lymphocytes , the predominant producers of IL-2 .
3,9 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein

However , B cells can also synthesize IL-2 .
2,4 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein

In the present study we analyzed the control of IL-2 promoter activity in Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) -transformed B cell clones which are capable of secreting IL-2 at a low level after stimulation with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate and the Ca2+ ionophore ionomycin .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|13,22 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein

Transient transfections using reporter constructs with multiples of transcription factor binding sites from the IL-2 promoter [ distal nuclear factor ( NF ) -AT , proximal NF-AT , AP-1/Octamer ( UPS ) or NF-chi B ( TCEd ) sites ] were performed .
3,5 G#DNA|8,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|17,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

In EBV-transformed B clones , the chi B site exerted the strongest inducible activity ; the NF-AT binding sites showed either no or only weak activity compared to Jurkat T cells .
1,4 G#cell_line|6,9 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA|28,31 G#cell_line

An IL-2 promoter bearing a defective NF- chi B site was completely inactive in EBV-transformed B cells , while it still had activity in Jurkat T cells .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|6,9 G#protein|6,10 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_line|24,27 G#cell_line

In seven EBV-B cell clones or lines differing in their capacity to secrete IL-2 , the activity of the IL-2 promoter correlated well with the status of IL-2 secretion .
2,5 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

Similarly , a human immunodeficiency virus promoter , whose activity is controlled through chi B factors , was found to be active in the IL-2 producing EBV- B cells , but inactive in the non- IL-2 -producing cells .
3,7 G#DNA|13,16 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|24,29 G#cell_line|35,36 G#protein|34,38 G#cell_line

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays using protein extracts from EBV- B cells and the IL-2 NF-chi B probe revealed the constitutive generation of chi B complexes in IL-2 -secreting cells consisting mainly of heterodimeric p50/p65 complexes .
5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|8,11 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_line|32,35 G#protein

A weaker chi B complex formation and faster-migrating complexes were detected in non- IL-2 -secreting cells .
2,4 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_line

These results demonstrate that the IL-2 NF-chi B site is indispensable for the activity of the IL-2 promoter in EBV-transformed B cells , whereas other transcription factors appear to be less important for IL-2 expression in these cells .
5,6 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_line|25,27 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Latent membrane protein-1 induces cyclin D2 expression , pRb hyperphosphorylation , and loss of TGF-beta 1 -mediated growth inhibition in EBV-positive B cells .
0,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|20,23 G#cell_type

The normal cell cycle is regulated by several molecules , such as the tumor-suppressor protein pRb , the G1 cyclins , the cyclin-dependent kinases , and their inhibitors .
15,16 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

These regulators are targeted by negative growth regulatory signals , such as that provided by TGF-beta .
15,16 G#protein

Here , we show that the presence of either wild-type EBV or its transforming latent membrane protein-1 ( LMP-1 ) results in the loss of TGF-beta 1 -mediated growth inhibition in human B cells .
13,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_type

Chemical cross-linking with 125I-labeled TGF-beta 1 showed an essentially normal TGF-beta receptor profile in EBV-positive and EBV-negative Burkitt 's lymphoma cell lines , and these receptors were shown to be functional in transducing signals , as evidenced by the TGF-beta 1 -mediated modulation of junB gene expression .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|14,22 G#cell_line|39,41 G#protein|44,46 G#DNA

However , TGF-beta 1 did not induce dephosphorylation of pRb in EBV ( or LMP-1 ) -positive cells as opposed to EBV -negative cells , suggesting a dichotomy in the TGF-beta 1 signaling pathway leading to separable gene regulatory and growth inhibitory responses .
2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|11,18 G#cell_line|21,24 G#cell_line|30,32 G#protein

Furthermore , LMP-1 was found to induce the expression of cyclin D2 ; normal B cells or EBV -negative Burkitt 's lymphoma cells do not express D-type cyclins .
2,3 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|17,23 G#cell_line|26,28 G#protein

Taken together , these data point to a potential mechanism underlying EBV -mediated B cell transformation whereby constitutive induction of key cell cycle regulators by LMP-1 can lead to pRb hyperphosphorylation and uncontrolled cell proliferation .
20,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Does thyroidectomy , radioactive iodine therapy , or antithyroid drug treatment alter reactivity of patients ' T cells to epitopes of thyrotropin receptor in autoimmune thyroid diseases ?
16,18 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein

The effect of treatment on thyroid antibody production and T cell reactivity to thyroid antigens was studied in 15 patients with Graves ' disease ( GD ) before and after thyroidectomy , 19 patients with GD before and after radioactive iodine ( RAI ) therapy , and 9 patients maintained euthyroid on antithyroid drugs ( ATD ) .


Twenty subjects matched for age and sex without known thyroid disease served as controls .


In GD patients , the responses of peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) and TSH receptor ( TSHR ) -specific T cell lines to recombinant human TSHR extracellular domain , thyroglobulin , and TSHR peptides were examined on the day of surgery or RAI therapy ( day 0 ) and also 6-8 weeks and 3-6 months thereafter .
7,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|15,24 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein|25,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

Reactivity to TSHR peptides before surgery was heterogeneous and spanned the entire extracellular domain .
2,3 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Six to 8 weeks after subtotal thyroidectomy , the number of patients ' PBMC responding to any peptide and the average number of recognized peptides decreased .
13,14 G#cell_type

A further decrease in the T cell reactivity to TSHR peptides was observed 3-6 months after surgery .
9,10 G#protein

The responses of PBMC from Graves ' patients before RAI therapy were less than those in the presurgical group .
3,4 G#cell_type

Six to 8 weeks after RAI therapy , the number of patients responding to any peptide and the average number of recognized peptides increased .


Three to 6 months after RAI , T cell responses to TSHR peptides were less than those 6-8 weeks after RAI therapy , but still higher than the values on day 0 .
11,12 G#protein

Responses of PBMC from patients with GD , maintained euthyroid on ATD , were lower than those before surgery or RAI therapy .
2,3 G#cell_type

The reactivity of T cell lines in different groups reflected a pattern similar to PBMC after treatment .
3,6 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_type

TSHR antibody and microsomal antibody levels decreased after surgery , but increased after RAI therapy .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|3,5 G#protein

The difference in the number of recognized peptides by patients ' PBMC before RAI and surgery may reflect the effect of long term therapy with ATD in the patients before RAI vs. the shorter period in patients before surgery .
11,12 G#cell_type

The decreased T cell reactivity to thyroid antigens after thyroidectomy could be the result of removal of a major part of the thyroid gland or redistribution of suppressor-inducer T cells .
6,8 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

The increased T cell response after RAI therapy is probably epitope specific , rather than a response to the whole TSHR molecule .
20,21 G#protein

Synchronous recognition of peptides 158-176 and 248-263 is important for the development of GD , and the loss of recognition of one of these epitopes may be an early sign of immune remission and a predictor of euthyroidism .
24,25 G#protein

Circumvention of tolerance for the nuclear T cell protein TCF-1 by immunization of TCF-1 knock-out mice .
5,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Molecular events that underlie the well-defined phenotypic changes of the differentiating thymocyte are poorly understood .
10,12 G#cell_type

A candidate gene to control thymocyte differentiation , T cell factor-1 ( TCF-1 ) * encodes a DNA-binding protein .
5,6 G#cell_type|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Its mRNA expression pattern is complex during embryogenesis , yet restricted to lymphocytes postnatally .
12,13 G#cell_type

Expression studies on TCF-1 protein have been hampered by the difficulty to raise antibodies due to extreme evolutionary conservation .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

TCF-1 knock-out mice , generated recently in our laboratory , have strongly decreased numbers of thymocytes , but are otherwise normal .
0,1 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

We have used these mice to generate anti- TCF-1 antibodies .
8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein

By immunization with a recombinant fusion protein , we show that TCF-1 knock-out mice readily yield antiserum titers against human and mouse TCF-1 protein .
4,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,24 G#protein

Wild-type littermates remain unresponsive to TCF-1 while they mount a high-titer antibody response to the fusion protein , Maltose Binding Protein ( MBP ) .
5,6 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Subsequently , TCF-1 -specific hybridomas could be prepared from the spleens of immunized knock-out mice .
2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#cell_line

This study illustrates the almost complete tolerance of mice for human TCF-1 and demonstrates that this tolerance is readily broken by gene knock-out .
11,12 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Furthermore , the usefulness of knock-out mice for the generation of monoclonal antibodies against the gene product of interest is underscored .
11,13 G#protein

The transcription factor , Nm23H2 , binds to and activates the translocated c-myc allele in Burkitt 's lymphoma .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

We have identified an in vivo footprint over the PuF site on the translocated c-myc allele in Burkitt 's lymphoma cells .
9,11 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA

The PuF site on the silent normal c-myc allele was unoccupied .
1,3 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|5,9 G#DNA

We demonstrated by electrophoretic mobility shift assay , electrophoretic mobility shift assay with antibody , UV cross-linking followed by SDS-gel electrophoresis , and Western analysis that Nm23H2 in B cell nuclear extracts bound to the c-myc PuF site .
26,27 G#protein|36,38 G#DNA

Transfection experiments with c-myc promoter constructs in both DHL-9 and Raji cells revealed that the PuF site functioned as a positive regulatory element in B cells with a drop in activity with mutation of this site .
3,5 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#cell_line|10,12 G#cell_line|15,17 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_type

Access to this site is blocked in the normal silent c-myc allele ; these data suggest that the Nm23H2 protein is involved in deregulation of the translocated c-myc allele in Burkitt 's lymphoma cells .
10,12 G#DNA|8,12 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|30,34 G#cell_line

Identification of two novel regulatory elements within the 5'-untranslated region of the human A gamma-globin gene .
4,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|12,16 G#DNA

Interaction between the stage selector element ( SSE ) in the proximal gamma-globin promoter and hypersensitivity site 2 in the locus control region partly mediates the competitive silencing of the beta-globin promoter in the fetal developmental stage .
3,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|30,32 G#DNA

We have now demonstrated that a second SSE-like element in the 5'-untranslated region of the gamma-gene also contributes to this competitive silencing of the beta-gene .
7,9 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA

Utilizing transient transfection assays in the fetal erythroid cell line , K562 , we have shown that the core enhancer of hypersensitivity site 2 can preferentially interact with the proximal gamma-promoter in the absence of the SSE , completely silencing a linked beta-promoter .
6,10 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_line|18,20 G#DNA|21,24 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA|36,37 G#DNA|41,43 G#DNA

Mutation of a 20-base pair sequence of the gamma-gene 5'-untranslated region ( UTR ) led to derepression of beta-promoter activity .
8,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA

A marked activation of gamma-promoter activity was also observed with this mutation , suggesting the presence of a repressor .
4,5 G#DNA

Fine mutagenesis dissected these activities to different regions of the 5'-UTR .
10,11 G#DNA

The stage selector activity was localized to a region centered on nucleotides +13 to +15 .
11,15 G#DNA

Electromobility shift assays utilizing this sequence demonstrated binding of a fetal and erythroid -specific protein .
10,15 G#protein

The repressor activity of the 5'-UTR was localized to tandem GATA-like sites , which appear to bind a complex of two proteins , one of which is the erythroid transcription factor GATA-1 .
5,6 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

These results indicate that the 5'-UTR of the gamma-gene contains sequences that may be important for its transcriptional and developmental regulation .
5,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA

Coupling of a signal response domain in I kappa B alpha to multiple pathways for NF-kappa B activation .
3,6 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

The eukaryotic transcription factor NF-kappa B plays a central role in the induced expression of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 and in many aspects of the genetic program mediating normal T-cell activation and growth .
1,4 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

The nuclear activity of NF-kappa B is tightly regulated from the cytoplasmic compartment by an inhibitory subunit called I kappa B alpha .
4,6 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,22 G#protein

This cytoplasmic inhibitor is rapidly phosphorylated and degraded in response to a diverse set of NF-kappa B -inducing agents , including T-cell mitogens , proinflammatory cytokines , and viral transactivators such as the Tax protein of human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 .
15,17 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|33,35 G#protein

To explore these I kappa B alpha -dependent mechanisms for NF-kappa B induction , we identified novel mutants of I kappa B alpha that uncouple its inhibitory and signal-transducing functions in human T lymphocytes .
3,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_type

Specifically , removal of the N-terminal 36 amino acids of I kappa B alpha failed to disrupt its ability to form latent complexes with NF-kappa B in the cytoplasm .
5,9 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

However , this deletion mutation prevented the induced phosphorylation , degradative loss , and functional release of I kappa B alpha from NF-kappa B in Tax -expressing cells .
17,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_line

Alanine substitutions introduced at two serine residues positioned within this N-terminal regulatory region of I kappa B alpha also yielded constitutive repressors that escaped from Tax -induced turnover and that potently inhibited immune activation pathways for NF-kappa B induction , including those initiated from antigen and cytokine receptors .
10,13 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|44,48 G#protein

In contrast , introduction of a phosphoserine mimetic at these sites rectified this functional defect , a finding consistent with a causal linkage between the phosphorylation status and proteolytic stability of this cytoplasmic inhibitor .
32,34 G#protein

Together , these in vivo studies define a critical signal response domain in I kappa B alpha that coordinately controls the biologic activities of I kappa B alpha and NF-kappa B in response to viral and immune stimuli .
13,17 G#protein|24,28 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

Growth regulation and cellular changes during differentiation of human prostatic cancer LNCaP cells as induced by T lymphocyte -conditioned medium .
11,13 G#cell_line|8,13 G#cell_line

Human prostatic epithelial cells from an androgen-dependent LNCaP cell line were examined in response to conditioned medium ( CM ) derived from phytohemagglutinin ( PHA ) -stimulated lymphocytes .
0,4 G#cell_line|6,10 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type|22,28 G#cell_line

Addition of CM caused a greater than 70 % reduction of cell proliferation by cell counting and cell cycle .


These cells showed G1 phase arrest and the clonogenicity was reduced .


The growth-modulating effect was dose-dependent and not due to cell lysis or apoptosis .


The binding of androgen to androgen receptor on these cells showed approximately 50 % reduction , underlining a proliferation reduction mechanism .
5,7 G#protein

The prostate-specific antigen ( PSA ) was downregulated to approximately 75 % during the process .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

Cell morphology showed dendritic processes extending from cytoplasm and other neuroendocrine cell characteristics .
10,12 G#cell_type

The expression of several cytoskeleton and intracellular proteins increased as determined by immunostaining on slides and by ELISA procedures .
4,8 G#protein

These included vimentin , correlating to cell shape changes , cytokeratins 8 and 18 , associated with differentiated cell types of prostate epithelia , and neuron-specific enolase and serotonin , associated with neuroendocrine cells .
2,3 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

From these cellular changes , we can infer that the cell growth was modulated along with induction of terminal differentiation .


Activated T cells were demonstrated to be important in providing the modulating activity .
1,3 G#cell_type

This growth modulator was semipurified and had an estimated molecular weight 13,000 to 24,000 Da .
1,3 G#protein

The activity was determined to be distinct from TGF , TNF , and some commonly known lymphokines .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

The interaction between lymphoid and prostatic cells in growth and development is described .
3,7 G#cell_type

Platelet-activating factor stimulates transcription of the heparin-binding epidermal growth factor-like growth factor in monocytes .
0,2 G#protein|6,12 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

Correlation with an increased kappa B binding activity .


Human peripheral blood monocytes responded to stimulation of platelet-activating factor ( PAF ) with up-regulation of the transcript for heparin-binding epidermal growth factor-like growth factor ( HB-EGF ) , a potent mitogen for vascular smooth muscle cells .
3,4 G#cell_type|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|33,37 G#cell_type

This function of PAF was observed at nanomolar concentrations of the ligand , starting at 30 min after stimulation .
3,4 G#protein

The PAF -induced up-regulation of HB-EGF mRNA was accompanied by an increase in kappa B binding activity .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA

These functions of PAF appeared to be mediated through the cell surface PAF receptors , as two PAF receptor antagonists , WEB 2086 and L-659 , 989 , blocked both the up-regulation of HB-EGF mRNA and kappa B binding activity induced by PAF .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|33,35 G#RNA|42,43 G#protein

The antagonists , however , had no effect on phorbol ester -induced up-regulation of HB-EGF mRNA and kappa B binding activity .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA

Pretreatment of monocytes with pertussis toxin inhibited these functions of PAF , whereas cholera toxin had no inhibitory effect .
2,3 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein

Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate , an inhibitor for NF-kappa B activation , markedly reduced PAF -stimulated kappa B binding activity as well as up-regulation of HB-EGF mRNA .
6,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#RNA

These results suggest a potential role of PAF in HB-EGF expression and provide evidence that this stimulation may occur through increased kappa B binding activity .
7,8 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Mapping of the interaction site of the defective transcription factor in the class II major histocompatibility complex mutant cell line clone-13 to the divergent X2-box .
3,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|12,21 G#cell_line|23,25 G#DNA

We have previously described a mutant B lymphoblastoid cell line , Clone-13 , that expresses HLA-DQ in the absence of HLA -DR and -DP .
5,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|20,24 G#protein

Several criteria indicated that the defect in this cell line influences the activity of an isotype-specific transcription factor .
15,18 G#protein

Indeed , transient transfection of HLA-DRA and DQB reporter constructs indicated that the affected factor operates via cis-elements located between -141 base pairs and the transcription initiation site .
5,10 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA

A series of hybrid DRA/DQB reporter constructs was generated to further map the relevant cis-elements in this system .
5,7 G#DNA|3,7 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA

Insertion of oligonucleotides spanning the DQB X-box ( but not the DQB-W region or the DQB Y-box ) upstream of -141 in a DRA reporter plasmid rescued expression to nearly wild-type levels .
5,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|18,21 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA

Substitution promoters were then generated where the entire X-box , or only the X1- or X2- boxes of HLA-DRA were replaced with the analogous regions of HLA-DQB .
8,9 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA

The DQB X2-box was able to restore expression to the silent DRA reporter construct .
1,3 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA

Moreover , replacement of the DQB X2-box with the DRA X2-box markedly diminished the activity of the DQB promoter in the mutant cell .
5,7 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|21,23 G#cell_line

None of the hybrid reporter constructs were defective when transfected into the wild-type , HLA-DR/-DQ positive parental cell line , Jijoye .
4,6 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|14,19 G#cell_line|20,21 G#cell_line

These studies suggest that the divergent X2-box of the class II major histocompatibility complex promoters plays an important role in influencing differential expression of the human class II isotypes .
5,7 G#DNA|9,14 G#protein|9,15 G#DNA|25,29 G#DNA

Restoration of the Epstein-Barr virus ZEBRA protein 's capacity to disrupt latency by the addition of heterologous activation regions .
3,7 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

The ZEBRA protein has a unique biological function among herpesviral proteins .
1,3 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

It is responsible for the disruption of Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) latency and the induction of the lytic cycle .


ZEBRA is a bZIP transcriptional activator which binds as a dimer to 7-bp response elements within EBV promoters and is directly involved in the stimulation of virus replication at the EBV lytic origin .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|30,33 G#DNA

We have employed the ZEBRA /EBV biological system to test whether a heterologous activation domain can substitute for another activation domain ( the ZEBRA domain ) .
4,5 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

The ZEBRA activation region was replaced with the potent acid activation region from the herpes simplex virus VP16 protein or with the activation region of the EBV R protein .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,19 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

Both chimeras were found to transactivate model and native promoters at equivalent or better levels than ZEBRA itself .
16,17 G#protein

Activation was not target- or cell-type dependent , nor was it dependent on the presence of virus .


These activation domains restored ZEBRA 's ability to induce early antigen and to stimulate origin replication to levels that were equal to or greater than those of wild type .
4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

These studies suggest that the specificities of some of the known biological functions of ZEBRA are not dependent upon the nature of the activation domain present within ZEBRA .
14,15 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Interleukin 4 activates a signal transducer and activator of transcription ( Stat ) protein which interacts with an interferon-gamma activation site-like sequence upstream of the I epsilon exon in a human B cell line .
0,2 G#protein|9,14 G#protein|18,22 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|30,34 G#cell_line

Evidence for the involvement of Janus kinase 3 and interleukin-4 Stat .
5,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

Germ line C transcripts can be induced by IL-4 in the human B cell line , BL-2 .
0,4 G#RNA|8,9 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line

Utilizing a IFN-gamma activation site-like DNA sequence element located upstream of the I epsilon exon , we demonstrated by gel mobility shift assays that IL-4 induced a binding activity in the cytosol and nucleus of BL-2 cells .
2,8 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|35,37 G#cell_line

This factor was designated IL-4 NAF ( IL-4 -induced nuclear-activating factors ) and was identified as a tyrosine phosphoprotein , which translocates from the cytosol to the nucleus upon IL-4 treatment .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Because these are the characteristics of a signal transducer and activator of transcription ( Stat ) protein , we determined whether antibodies to Stat proteins will interfere with gel mobility shift and found that antibodies to IL-4 Stat , also known as Stat6 , but not antibodies to other Stat proteins , interfere with the formation of the IL-4 NAF complex .
7,17 G#protein|21,25 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|34,38 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|49,51 G#protein|58,59 G#protein|58,61 G#protein

Congruous with the involvement of a Stat protein , IL-4 induced robust Janus kinase 3 ( JAK3 ) activity in BL-2 cells .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_line

Cotransfection of JAK3 with IL-4 Stat into COS-7 cells produced an intracellular activity which bound the same IFN-gamma activation site-like sequence and comigrated with IL-4 NAF in electrophoretic mobility shift assay .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|17,21 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

These results show that IL-4 NAF is IL-4 Stat , which is activated by JAK3 in response to IL-4 receptor engagement .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Does activation of the TAL1 gene occur in a majority of patients with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia ? A pediatric oncology group study .
4,6 G#DNA

Almost 25 % of patients with T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( T-ALL ) have tumor-specific rearrangements of the TAL1 gene .
18,20 G#DNA

Although TAL1 expression has not been observed in normal lymphocytes , TAL1 gene products are readily detected in leukemic cells that harbor a rearranged TAL1 allele .
1,2 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|11,13 G#DNA|11,14 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|23,26 G#DNA

Hence , it has been proposed that ectopic expression of TAL1 promotes the development of T-ALL .
10,11 G#protein

In this report , we show that TAL1 is expressed in the leukemic cells of most patients with T-ALL , including many that do not display an apparent TAL1 gene alteration .
7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA

A polymorphic dinucleotide repeat in the transcribed sequences of TAL1 was used to determine the allele specificity of TAL1 transcription in primary T-ALL cells .
9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type

Monoallelic expression of TAL1 was observed in the leukemic cells of all patients ( 8 of 8 ) bearing a TAL1 gene rearrangement .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

In the leukemic cells of patients without detectable TAL1 rearrangements , TAL1 transcription occurred in either a monoallelic ( 3 of 7 patients ) or a biallelic ( 4 of 7 patients ) fashion .
2,4 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Thus , TAL1 activation in these patients may result from subtle alterations in cis-acting regulatory sequences ( affecting expression of a single TAL1 allele ) or changes in trans-acting factors that control TAL1 transcription ( affecting expression of both TAL1 alleles ) .
2,3 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|21,24 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|39,41 G#DNA

Expression of erythroid-specific genes in acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia and transient myeloproliferative disorder in Down 's syndrome .
2,4 G#DNA

Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia ( M7 ) and transient myeloproliferative disorder in Down 's syndrome ( TMD ) are characterized by rapid growth of abnormal blast cells which express megakaryocytic markers .
23,26 G#cell_type|28,30 G#protein

To clarify properties of the blast cells in M7 and TMD cases , we examined erythroid markers expression in blasts from six cases with M7 and seven cases with TMD in this study .
5,7 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

Erythroid-specific mRNAs encoding gamma-globin and erythroid delta-aminolevulinate synthase were found to be expressed in blasts from most of these cases , indicating that majorities of the blasts in M7 and TMD cases have erythroid and megakaryocytic phenotypes .
0,2 G#RNA|3,4 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type

We also found that mRNAs encoding GATA-1 and GATA-2 are expressed in all these cases .
4,5 G#RNA|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

These results suggest that M7 blasts and TMD blasts correspond to the erythroid/megakaryocytic bipotential progenitor cells .
4,6 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|12,16 G#cell_type

Expression of Ah receptor ( TCDD receptor ) during human monocytic differentiation .
2,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

We have previously found a high expression of human Ah receptor ( TCDD receptor ) mRNA in peripheral blood cells of individuals .
9,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|8,16 G#RNA|17,20 G#cell_type

In this paper , the expression of this gene in blood cells was first investigated in fractions of nucleated cells , revealing predominant expression of the Ah receptor gene in the monocyte fraction .
10,12 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type|26,28 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA|31,33 G#cell_type

Then the expression levels of AhR mRNA in various hematopoietic cell lines were examined together with those of Arnt and P450IA1 .
5,7 G#RNA|9,12 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

AhR was expressed at high levels in monocytoid U937 , THP1 , and HEL/S cells , and at moderate levels in promyelocytic HL60 cells and erythroblastic HEL cells .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line|13,15 G#cell_line|21,24 G#cell_line|25,28 G#cell_line

However , it was not detected in lymphoid cells MOLT4 ( T cell ) and BALL1 ( B cell ) , nor in K562 erythroblasts .
7,9 G#cell_type|9,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_line|17,19 G#cell_type|23,25 G#cell_line

Furthermore , a specific induction of AhR during monocytic differentiation was investigated in HL60 and HEL cells .
6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_line|15,17 G#cell_line

HL60 cells were induced to differentiate toward monocytes-macrophages by incubation with phorbol ester , showing a 5- to 2-fold increase of AhR mRNA .
0,2 G#cell_line|7,8 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#RNA

The incubation with transforming growth factor beta 1 and 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 resulted in a 5- to 7-fold increase of AhR mRNA .
3,8 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#RNA

The HEL cells also exhibited a similar elevation of AhR mRNA level , when they had differentiated toward monocyte-macrophage cells by these combined inducers , but little change in the mRNA level was observed when the cells were induced to differentiate into other cell types .
1,3 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#RNA|18,20 G#cell_type

Treatment of the differentiated HL60 cells with 3-methylcholanthrene , a ligand of AhR , induced the expression of the P450IA1 gene .
4,5 G#cell_line|3,6 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

These results indicated that expression of AhR mRNA was significantly induced during monocytic differentiation and that the differentiated cells were responsive to xenobiotics .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#RNA|17,19 G#cell_type

Our results suggest that AhR may play an important role in the function of monocytes and also in the eventual activation of environmental carcinogens .
4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type

Neutrophils and monocytes express high levels of PU.1 ( Spi-1 ) but not Spi-B .
0,1 G#cell_type|2,3 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

PU.1 ( the Spi-1 oncogene ) and Spi-B are closely related members of the ets transcription factor family , sharing similar DNA binding specificities mediated by similar DNA binding domains .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|27,30 G#protein

PU.1 and Spi-B have been previously described as being predominantly expressed coordinately in macrophages and B cells , but their expression in early hematopoietic stages and during the course of myeloid differentiation to monocytes and macrophages or to neutrophils has not been extensively investigated .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type|33,34 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type|38,39 G#cell_type

Here , we report that PU.1 mRNA is upregulated during myeloid differentiation of human purified CD34+ cells and murine multipotential FDCP-mix A4 cells , suggesting that PU.1 is upregulated as an early event during differentiation of multipotential progenitor cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|13,17 G#cell_line|18,23 G#cell_line|26,27 G#protein|36,39 G#cell_type

PU.1 expression is maintained at stable levels during differentiation of myeloid cell lines U937 and HL-60 to monocytic and neutrophilic cells .
0,1 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line|13,14 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line|17,21 G#cell_type

PU.1 is expressed at highest levels in mature human monocytes and human peripheral blood neutrophils .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|7,10 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|11,15 G#cell_type

In contrast to PU.1 , significant levels of Spi-B mRNA and protein are found only in some B-cell lines and spleen but are not found in myeloid cell lines , neutrophils , or macrophages .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|17,19 G#cell_line|26,29 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_type|33,34 G#cell_type

In vitro translated Spi-B protein can bind to PU.1 binding sites in myeloid promoters and transactivate these promoters in nonmyeloid cells .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|19,21 G#cell_type

Therefore , although PU.1 and Spi-B may bind to similar DNA control elements and have redundancy of transactivation function in vitro , the lack of significant levels of Spi-B in myeloid cells makes it unlikely that Spi-B plays a significant role in myeloid lineage development and gene expression .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein

In contrast , PU.1 is expressed at high levels not only in monocytes and macrophages but also in neutrophils , indicating that PU.1 can activate gene expression in both major myeloid lineages .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|29,32 G#cell_type

Identification of a major positive regulatory element located 5' to the human zeta-globin gene .
4,7 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA

The function of the zeta-globin promoter was studied using a series of zeta-globin promoter deletion constructs to drive luciferase expression in transiently transfected human erythroleukemia cells .
4,6 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|12,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_line

The promoters were used without enhancers , or with enhancers derived from the beta-globin locus control region and the alpha-globin HS-40 enhancer .
1,2 G#DNA|5,6 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA

When transfected into K562 cells , which express zeta-globin , comparable amounts of activity were obtained from the -557 and -417 zeta- luciferase constructs and the alpha- luciferase constructs when no enhancers or the alpha-globin locus enhancers were used .
3,5 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|18,24 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA|36,37 G#DNA|34,37 G#DNA

When the constructs were transfected into OCIM1 cells , which do not express zeta-globin , the zeta-globin promoters were at best 20 % as active as the alpha-globin promoters .
6,8 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

When sequences from -417 to -207 5' to the zeta-globin mRNA cap site were deleted , up to 95 % of the zeta-globin promoter activity was lost in K562 cells .
1,7 G#DNA|9,11 G#RNA|9,13 G#RNA|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA|28,30 G#cell_line

Reinsertion of these sequences into zeta- luciferase constructs missing the -417 to -207 region showed that the sequences lack classical enhancer activity .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA

Point mutation of a GATA-1 site at -230 reduced promoter activity by 37 % .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA

Point mutation of a CCACC site at -240 had no effect .
4,6 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays indicated that the -230 GATA-1 site has a relatively low affinity for GATA-1 .
8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

These experiments show the presence of a strong positive-acting element , located between -417 and -207 bp 5' to the zeta-globin mRNA cap site , is necessary for high-level promoter activity in K562 cells .
8,10 G#DNA|13,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#RNA|20,24 G#DNA|32,34 G#cell_line

This element requires GATA-1 and additional unknown factors for maximal activity .
3,4 G#protein|5,8 G#protein

Analysis of the role of protein kinase C -alpha , -epsilon , and -zeta in T cell activation .
5,14 G#protein

T cells express multiple isotypes of protein kinase C ( PKC ) and although it is well accepted that PKCs have an important role in T cell activation , little is known about the function of individual PKC isotypes .
0,2 G#cell_type|6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

To address this issue , mutationally active PKC -alpha , -epsilon , or -zeta have been transfected into T cells and the consequences for T cell activation determined .
7,14 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

p21ras plays an essential role in T cell activation .
0,1 G#protein

Accordingly , the effects of the constitutively active PKCs were compared to the effects of mutationally activated p21ras .
6,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

The data indicate that PKC-epsilon and , to a lesser extent PKC-alpha but not -zeta , can regulate the transcription factors AP-1 and nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NF-AT-1 ) .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|24,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

The ability of PKC-epsilon to induce transactivation of NF-AT-1 and AP-1 was similar to the stimulatory effect of a constitutively activated p21ras .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

PKC-epsilon , but not PKC-alpha nor activated p21ras , was able to induce NF-KB activity .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Phorbol esters induce expression of CD69 whereas none of the activated PKC isotypes tested were able to have this effect .
5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|10,13 G#protein

Activated Src and p21ras were able to induce CD69 expression .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

These results indicate selective functions for different PKC isotypes in T cells .
7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

Moreover , the data comparing the effects of activated Ras and PKC mutants suggest that PKC-alpha , p21ras , and PKC-epsilon are not positioned linearly on a single signal transduction pathway .
8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Differences in binding of glucocorticoid receptor to DNA in steroid-resistant asthma .
4,6 G#protein

Although glucocorticosteroids are a very effective treatment for asthma and other chronic inflammatory diseases , a small proportion of patients are resistant to their therapeutic effects .


The molecular mechanism for this steroid resistance is unclear .


Steroid resistance can not be explained by pharmacokinetic mechanisms , by a defect in the binding of steroids to glucocorticoid receptors , nor by defective nuclear translocation of this receptor , thereby suggesting that the molecular abnormality lies distal to nuclear translocation .
19,21 G#protein

We examined the ability of nuclear translocated glucocorticoid receptors to bind to their DNA binding sites ( GRE ) using electrophoretic mobility shift assays in PBMC from patients with steroid-sensitive and steroid-resistant asthma .
7,9 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|25,26 G#cell_type

The binding of the glucocorticoid receptor to DNA in these patients was also studied using Scatchard analysis .
4,6 G#protein

Dexamethasone induced a significant rapid and sustained twofold increase in GRE binding in PBMCs from steroid-sensitive asthmatic patients and nonasthmatic individuals , but this was markedly reduced in steroid-resistant asthmatic patients .
10,11 G#DNA|13,14 G#cell_type

Scatchard analysis of glucocorticoid receptor - GRE binding showed no change in binding affinity but did show a reduced number of receptors available for DNA binding in the steroid-resistant patients .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

These results suggest that the ability of the glucocorticoid receptor to bind to GRE is impaired in steroid-resistant patients because of a reduced number of receptors available for binding to DNA .
8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein

Interleukin-5 signaling in human eosinophils involves JAK2 tyrosine kinase and Stat1 alpha .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Signaling by a wide variety of cytokines , including interferons , interleukins , and growth factors , involves activation of JAK kinases and Stat ( Signal transducers and activators of transcription ) proteins .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,31 G#protein|23,33 G#protein

At present , not much is known about the molecular mechanisms by which interleukin-5 ( IL-5 ) exerts its diverse biologic effects .
13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Human eosinophils are one of the most important target cells for IL-5 and were used here to study IL-5 signaling in a primary human cell .
0,2 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_type

IL-5 induced rapid and transient tyrosine phosphorylation of JAK2 .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein
