Inducible binding to the c-fos serum response element during T cell activation is regulated by a phosphotyrosine-containing protein .
16,18 G#protein

The proto-oncogene c-fos is an immediate-early gene , and one of the first genes transcribed after stimulation of most cells with a variety of ligands .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA

Fos expression may be a pivotal event in converting ligand-receptor interactions at the membrane into functional modulation of cell phenotype .


The serum response element ( SRE ) in the c-fos regulatory region participates in induction of transcription by various growth factors and by phorbol esters and subsequent squelching of transcription .
1,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein

We show that an inducible protein complex ( Band A ) binds to SRE DNA within 10 min after mitogenic stimulation of human PBL-T , and becomes nondetectable by 60 min .
5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|22,24 G#cell_line

0,2 G#protein|4,7 G#protein

10,12 G#cell_line|18,20 G#protein|22,23 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA

Upon stimulation of the cells , this protein no longer prevents binding of DNA by Band A , and suppression of binding is restored within 30 min .
15,17 G#protein

The phosphorylated tyrosine residue itself is important for the protein-protein interaction .


In vivo modification of major histocompatibility complex class II DRA promoter occupancy mediated by the AIR-1 trans-activator .
4,9 G#protein|4,11 G#DNA|15,17 G#protein

RJ 2.2.5 is a human B cell mutant derived from the Burkitt lymphoma Raji cell which is defective in the AIR-1 locus function .
0,2 G#cell_line|4,8 G#cell_line|11,15 G#cell_line

12,21 G#DNA

4,9 G#DNA|10,17 G#cell_line|23,25 G#DNA

0,2 G#DNA|5,10 G#cell_line|27,29 G#cell_line|30,32 G#cell_line

6,8 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_line|27,29 G#DNA

3,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,24 G#protein

The interleukin 2 receptor alpha-chain ( IL-2R alpha ) gene is rapidly and potently induced in T cells in response to mitogenic stimuli .
1,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|1,10 G#DNA|16,18 G#cell_type

Previously , an inducible enhancer between nucleotides -299 and -228 that contains NF-kappa B and CArG motifs was identified .
3,5 G#DNA|6,10 G#DNA|12,17 G#DNA

We now report the characterization of a second essential positive regulatory element located between nucleotides -137 and -64 that binds Elf-1 and HMG-I(Y) .
8,12 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

This element had maximal activity in lymphoid cells , paralleling the cell type specificity of Elf-1 expression .
6,8 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

Transcription from the IL-2R alpha promoter was inhibited when either the Elf-1 or the HMG-I(Y) binding site was mutated .
3,5 G#protein|3,6 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|11,17 G#DNA

Coexpression of both proteins activated transcription of the -137 to -64 element in COS-7 cells .
8,12 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_line

Elf-1 physically associated with HMG-I and with NF-kappa B p50 and c-Rel in vitro , suggesting that protein-protein interactions might functionally coordinate the actions of the upstream and downstream positive regulatory elements .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|26,32 G#DNA

This is the first report of a physical interaction between an Ets family member and NF-kappa B family proteins .
15,17 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

These findings provide significant new insights into the protein-protein and protein-DNA interactions that regulate cell-type-specific and inducible IL-2R alpha gene expression and also have implications for other genes regulated by Elf-1 and NF-kappa B family proteins .

Isolation of cDNA clones for 42 different Kruppel-related zinc finger proteins expressed in the human monoblast cell line U-937 .
2,4 G#DNA|7,11 G#protein|14,19 G#cell_line

To study the complexity and structural characteristics of zinc finger proteins expressed during human hematopoiesis and to isolate novel regulators of blood cell development , a degenerate oligonucleotide probe specific for a consensus zinc finger peptide domain was used to isolate 63 cDNA clones for Kruppel-related zinc finger genes from the human monoblast cell line U-937 .
8,11 G#protein|32,37 G#protein|42,44 G#DNA|45,49 G#DNA|51,56 G#cell_line

By extensive nucleotide sequence and Northern blot analysis , these cDNA clones were found to originate from approximately 42 different genes ( HZF 1-42 ) of which only 8 have previously been described .
10,12 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA

Northern blot analysis showed that a majority of these genes were expressed at comparable levels in U-937 and HeLa cells .
16,17 G#cell_line|18,20 G#cell_line

The large number of individual genes represented among the 63 clones and their apparent non-cell-type-specific expression suggest that the majority of the Kruppel-related zinc finger genes are likely to be expressed in most human tissues .
22,26 G#DNA

In contrast , some of the genes displayed a restricted expression pattern , indicating that they represent potential regulators of monocyte differentiation or proliferation .


Detailed structural analysis of the first 12 cDNAs ( HZF 1-10 ) and a partial characterization of HZF 11-42 revealed that a common feature of human Kruppel-related zinc finger proteins is the presence of tandem arrays of zinc fingers ranging in number from 3 to over 20 that are preferentially located in the carboxy-terminal regions of the proteins .
7,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|27,30 G#protein|26,30 G#protein|25,30 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|53,55 G#protein

In addition , several novel KRAB-containing zinc finger genes and a novel conserved sequence element were identified .

CAG repeat length variation in sperm from a patient with Kennedy 's disease .
0,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#cell_type

Using a modified sperm typing protocol , the mutation frequency of the CAG repeat region at the androgen receptor locus has been measured using a rare semen sample from an individual with spinal and bulbar muscular atrophy ( SBMA ) .
3,4 G#cell_type|12,15 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA

Among 258 X chromosome-containing sperm , 19 % had a repeat number equal to the donor 's somatic DNA ( 47 repeats ) , 66 % were expansions and 15 % were contractions .
4,5 G#cell_type|2,5 G#cell_type|15,19 G#DNA

The average expansion was 2.7 repeats .


More than half of the expansions involved one or two repeats ; the largest was 11 repeats .


68 % of the contractions were also one or two repeats but six ( 16 % ) were very large ( 12-25 repeats ) .


One contraction generated an allele in an intermediate size range ( 33-39 repeats ) .


Such alleles have not been observed among more than 900 normal and SBMA X-chromosomes that have been examined .
12,14 G#DNA

Comparison of the SBMA sperm typing results with mutation frequency data on normal alleles supports the hypothesis that trinucleotide repeat expansions may have a different molecular origin than contractions .

Aspirin-like drugs can protect human T lymphocytes against benzoquinone cytotoxicity : evidence for a NAD(P)H:quinone reductase -dependent mechanism .
4,7 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein

Benzene toxicity towards lymphocytes is thought to be mediated by metabolites of benzene including benzoquinone ( BQ ) .
3,4 G#cell_type

NAD(P)H:quinone reductase ( QR ) is known to protect against BQ toxicity .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

The expression of the QR gene is regulated by the transcription factor AP-1 .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

We had previously found that aspirin-like drugs ( ALD ) induce AP-1 in human T lymphocytes .
11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_type

It was therefore hypothesized that ALD would protect lymphocytes against BQ toxicity by inducing QR .
8,9 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

Molt-4 cells ( M4 ) , a human T lymphocyte cell line , were incubated with different concentrations of two ALD , flurbiprofen and sodium diclofenac , and then exposed to BQ .
0,2 G#cell_line|3,4 G#cell_line|7,12 G#cell_line

Toxicity was measured by viability ( trypan blue exclusion ) .


Both drugs protected the cells against BQ cytotoxicity in a dose-dependent manner , e.g. , sodium diclofenac at 15 microM reduced the fraction of BQ -treated dead cells by 70 % .


ALDs induced QR activity in the M4 cells in the same range of concentrations that protected the cells against BQ toxicity .
2,3 G#protein

The protective effect of ALD was significantly reduced by dicoumarol , a QR -specific inhibitor .
12,13 G#protein

Since human T cells and T cell lines do not metabolize arachidonic acid , our data suggest that ALD can protect human T lymphocytes against a metabolite of benzene by induction of QR activity .
1,4 G#cell_type|5,8 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein

The human platelet-activating factor receptor ( PAFR ) gene is transcribed by two distinct promoters ( promoter 1 and promoter 2 ) to generate two transcripts ( designated as PAFR transcript 1 and PAFR transcript 2 ) , though their open reading frames are identical .

15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#RNA|24,25 G#protein|24,27 G#RNA|34,35 G#protein|45,50 G#cell_line|51,53 G#cell_line|58,59 G#protein|58,61 G#RNA|62,63 G#protein|62,65 G#RNA

4,6 G#DNA|12,18 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA|34,36 G#DNA|39,42 G#DNA|43,45 G#protein

One gene , two transcripts : isolation of an alternative transcript encoding for the autoantigen La/SS-B from a cDNA library of a patient with primary Sjogrens ' syndrome .
4,5 G#RNA|14,16 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

A cDNA library was prepared from peripheral blood lymphocytes of an autoimmune patient with primary Sjogrens ' syndrome .
1,3 G#DNA|8,9 G#cell_type

The cDNA library was screened with the patients own autoimmune serum being monospecific for the nuclear autoantigen La/SS-B .
1,3 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

Thereby an alternative type of La mRNA was identified that differed from the known La mRNA due to an exchange of the exon 1 .
5,7 G#RNA|14,16 G#RNA|22,24 G#DNA

Sequencing of the genomic region between the exons 1 and 2 showed that the alternative 5'-end is a part of the intron .
7,11 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA

In addition , the presence of an alternative promoter site , which exists within the intron downstream of the exon 1 , became evident .
7,10 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA

In consequence , the alternative La mRNA is the result of a promoter switching combined with an alternative splicing mechanism .
5,7 G#RNA|4,7 G#RNA

In the intron , further transcription factor binding sites , including a NF-kappa B element , were identified leading to the suggestion that the expression of the gene encoding for the nuclear autoantigen La/SS-B alters in dependence on disease conditions .

Cross-linking CD40 on B cells rapidly activates nuclear factor-kappa B .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|7,10 G#protein

The B cell-associated surface molecule CD40 functions to regulate B cell responses .
5,6 G#protein|1,6 G#protein

Cross-linking CD40 on B cells can lead to homotypic cell adhesion , IL-6 production , and , in combination with cytokines , to Ig isotype switching .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Tyrosine kinase activity is increased shortly after engagement of this receptor .


Little is known about how the very early events induced by CD40 cross-linking link to cellular responses .
11,12 G#protein

In this study , we demonstrate that nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappa B and NF-kappa B-like transcription factors are activated after cross-linking CD40 on resting human tonsillar B cells and on B cell lines .
7,14 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|26,30 G#cell_type|32,35 G#cell_line

The activation is rapid and is mediated through a tyrosine kinase-dependent pathway .

9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

By using transient transfection assays , we found that cross-linking CD40 supports NF-kappa B -dependent gene expression .
10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Our results define the NF-kappa B system as an intermediate event in CD40 signaling and suggest that the CD40 pathway can influence the expression of B cell-associated genes with NF-kappa B consensus sites .
4,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein|29,33 G#DNA

Protease inhibitors block lipopolysaccharide induction of tissue factor gene expression in human monocytic cells by preventing activation of c-Rel/ p65 heterodimers .
11,14 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Tissue factor ( TF ) is expressed rapidly by human monocytes exposed to bacterial endotoxin ( lipopolysaccharide , or LPS ) .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#protein

Transcriptional regulation is mediated by binding of c-Rel /p65 heterodimers to a kappa B-like site in the TF promoter .
7,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

Nuclear translocation of cytosolic c-Rel/ p65 heterodimers and other members of the NF-kappa B /Rel family requires dissociation and proteolytic degradation of the inhibitor protein , I kappa B alpha .
5,6 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|26,30 G#protein

The protease inhibitors N alpha-tosylphenylalanyl chloromethyl ketone ( TPCK ) and N alpha-tosyl-L-lysine chloromethyl ketone ( TLCK ) block activation of NF-kappa B /Rel proteins by preventing degradation of I kappa B alpha .
21,23 G#protein|21,25 G#protein|29,33 G#protein

To determine if TPCK and TLCK inhibited LPS induction of TF expression , freshly isolated human monocytes and monocytic THP-1 cells were pretreated with these inhibitors for 30 min before LPS stimulation .
10,11 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|18,21 G#cell_line

Both TPCK and TLCK inhibited LPS induction of TF protein , TF mRNA and TF promoter activity in a dose-dependent manner .
8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#RNA|14,15 G#protein

These inhibitors specifically prevented degradation of I kappa B alpha and nuclear translocation of c-Rel /p65 heterodimers .
6,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

In contrast , TPCK and TLCK did not block induction of an immediate-early gene encoding the transcription factor , Egr-1 .
12,14 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Taken together , these data indicated that inhibiting nuclear translocation of c-Rel /p65 heterodimers prevented LPS induction of TF gene transcription in monocytic cells .

1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D3 receptors in peripheral blood mononuclear cells from patients with primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism .
0,3 G#protein|4,8 G#cell_type

A decreased number of calcitriol ( 1,25(OH)2D3 ) receptors has been observed in parathyroid glands of uremic animals .
4,9 G#protein

In humans , studies carried out in surgically removed parathyroid glands have shown that calcitriol binding is higher in primary than in secondary hyperparathyroidism .


Since specific receptors for calcitriol have been described in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) , we have investigated the specific uptake of 3H-labelled 1,25(OH)2D3 in PBMC of 12 women with primary hyperparathyroidism ( PHP ) , 8 women with hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic renal failure ( SH ) , 9 women with renal transplant ( RT ) , and 23 healthy women .
9,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|27,28 G#cell_type

The median dissociation constant ( Kd ) was similar in all three groups of patients and in healthy women ( mean +/- S.D. ( range ) : PHP , 1.2 +/- 1.0 ( 0.2-4 ) x 10(-10) M ; SH , 0.6 +/- 0.4 ( 0.2-1.2 ) x 10(-10) M ; RT , 1.1 +/- 0.5 ( 0.4-1.9 ) x 10(-10) M ; controls , 1.0 +/- 0.6 ( 0.3-2.6 ) x 10(-10) M ) . However , the maximal binding capacity ( Nmax ) was significantly enhanced in PHP ( 3.9 +/- 1.9 ( 1.3-7.6 ) fmol/10(7) cells vs. 2.3 +/- 0.9 ( 1.1-4.4 ) fmol/10(7) cells in controls ; P = 0.0006 ) and decreased in SH ( 0.8 +/- 0.5 ( 0.2-1.6 ) fmol/10(7) cells vs. 2.3 +/- 0.9 ( 1.1-4.4 ) fmol/10(7) cells in controls ; P = 0.0001 ) , whereas no changes were seen in RT ( 2.3 +/- 0.7 ( 1.2-3.3 ) fmol/10(7) cells vs. 2.3 +/- 0.9 ( 1.1-4.4 ) fmol/10(7) cells in controls ) .


In three patients with PHP who were subjected to parathyroidectomy , the calcitriol number came down to normal .


Changes of calcitriol receptors in primary and secondary hyperparathyroidism could magnify the consequences of disturbances in serum concentration of calcitriol itself and might play an important role in the development of secondary hyperparathyroidism in uremia .
2,4 G#protein

The severe phenotype of females with tiny ring X chromosomes is associated with inability of these chromosomes to undergo X inactivation .
8,10 G#DNA|6,10 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA

Mental retardation and a constellation of congenital malformations not usually associated with Turner syndrome are seen in some females with a mosaic 45,X/46,X,r(X) karyotype .
21,24 G#DNA

Studies of these females show that the XIST locus on their tiny ring X chromosomes is either not present or not expressed .
7,9 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|11,15 G#DNA

As XIST transcription is well correlated with inactivation of the X chromosome in female somatic cells and spermatogonia , nonexpression of the locus even when it is present suggests that these chromosomes are transcriptionally active .
1,2 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|13,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type|31,32 G#DNA

We examined the transcriptional activity of ring X chromosomes lacking XIST expression ( XISTE- ) , from three females with severe phenotypes .
7,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA

The two tiny ring X chromosomes studied with an antibody specific for the acetylated isoforms of histone H4 marking transcribed chromatin domains were labeled at a level consistent with their being active .
4,6 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA

We also examined tow of the XISTE- ring chromosomes to determine whether genes that are normally silent on an inactive X are expressed from these chromosomes .
6,9 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA

Analyses of hybrid cells show that TIMP , ZXDA , and ZXDB loci on the proximal short arm , and AR and PHKA1 loci on the long arm , are well expressed from the tiny ring X chromosome lacking XIST DNA .

Studies of the ring chromosome that has XIST DNA but does not transcribe it show that its AR allele is transcribed along with the one on the normal X allele .

Inhibition of activation of transcription factor AP-1 by CD28 signalling in human T-cells .
6,7 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Co-stimulation of T-lymphocytes by T-cell receptor ( TcR ) occupancy and activation of the CD28 surface molecule results in enhanced proliferation and interleukin 2 ( IL-2 ) production .
2,3 G#cell_type|4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

The increase in IL-2 gene expression triggered by CD28 involves a kappa B-like sequence in the 5'-regulatory region of the IL-2 promoter , called CD28 -responsive element .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA

Stimulation of T-cells by agonistic anti- CD28 antibodies in conjunction with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) - or TcR -derived signals induces the enhanced activation of the transcription factor NF-kappa B .
2,3 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

Here we report that CD28 engagement , however , exerts opposite effects on the transcription factor AP-1 .
4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

Whereas anti- CD28 together with PMA increased the DNA binding and trans-activation activity of NF-kappa B , PMA -induced activation of AP-1 was significantly suppressed .
2,3 G#protein|1,3 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The inhibitory effect exerted by anti- CD28 was observed at the level of DNA binding as well as in functional reporter-gene assays .
6,7 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

These results suggest that the two transcription factors are independently regulated and may perform different functions during T-cell activation .
6,8 G#protein

HIV-1 Nef leads to inhibition or activation of T cells depending on its intracellular localization .
0,2 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

Nef of primate lentiviruses is required for viremia and progression to AIDS in monkeys .
0,1 G#protein

Negative , positive , and no effects of Nef have also been reported on viral replication in cells .
8,9 G#protein

To reconcile these observations , we expressed a hybrid CD8- Nef protein in Jurkat cells .
10,11 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_line

Two opposite phenotypes were found , which depended on the intracellular localization of Nef .
13,14 G#protein

Expressed in the cytoplasm or on the cell surface , the chimera inhibited or activated early signaling events from the T cell antigen receptor .
11,12 G#protein|20,24 G#protein

Activated Jurkat cells died by apoptosis , and only cells with mutated nef genes expressing truncated Nefs survived , which rendered Nef nonfunctional .
1,3 G#cell_line|12,14 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

These mutations paralleled those in other viral strains passaged in vitro .


Not only do these positional effects of Nef reconcile diverse phenotypes of Nef and suggest a role for its N-terminal myristylation , but they also explain effects of Nef in HIV infection and progression to AIDS .
7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

An intricate arrangement of binding sites for the Ets family of transcription factors regulates activity of the alpha 4 integrin gene promoter .
8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|17,22 G#DNA

alpha 4 integrins mediate cell-cell and cell-extracellular matrix interactions that are critical for maturation and function of the immune system as well as differentiation of skeletal muscle .
0,3 G#protein

Here we examine molecular mechanisms controlling the pattern of alpha 4 expression .
9,11 G#protein

The activity of constructs containing 5' deletion mutants of the alpha 4 gene promoter was compared in transfection assays into cell lines that express alpha 4 and cell lines that do not .
5,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein|10,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_line|24,26 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_line

The sequence between position -42 and -76 base pairs ( bp ) was required for efficient transcription in cells that express alpha 4 , but it showed no activity in HeLa cells , which do not express alpha 4 .
4,9 G#DNA|21,23 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line|37,39 G#protein

Three binding sites for the Ets family of transcription factors are found in this region : two adjacent sites at positions -50 and -54 bp and a more 5' site at position -67 bp .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|21,25 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|32,34 G#DNA

Using a series of constructs containing deletions and mutations in this region , we found that the 3'-most site alone was sufficient for binding GA-binding protein alpha ( GABP alpha ) / GABP beta and for a low level of transcriptional activation .
17,19 G#DNA|24,27 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|28,34 G#protein

When all three sites were present , a second complex " a " was detected , which contains an unknown member of the Ets family .
23,25 G#protein

Formation of complex a was cell-type specific and correlated with a high level of transcription .


Deletion of the 5'-most Ets site had no effect on binding to GABP alpha/GABP beta , but it eliminated a .
3,6 G#DNA|12,15 G#protein

Concomitant with this loss of a , a new Ets-1-containing complex " c " appeared .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Complex c substituted efficiently for complex a in transcriptional activation .


We conclude that although neither of the two 5'-most Ets sites alone binds nuclear protein , they appear to act as modulators which control the pattern of Ets proteins that bind the alpha 4 gene promoter .
8,11 G#DNA|13,15 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|32,36 G#DNA

This arrangement of Ets sites , coupled with the tissue- and developmental- specific expression of Ets members , likely play a key role in defining the pattern of alpha 4 integrin .
3,5 G#DNA|15,17 G#protein|28,31 G#protein

Mechanism of antiandrogen action : conformational changes of the receptor .


Androgen receptor mRNA was translated in vitro , and androgen- and antiandrogen- bound receptor complexes were studied using limited proteolytic digestion by trypsin .
0,2 G#protein|0,3 G#RNA|9,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Partial proteolysis of androgen -bound receptor protein resulted in a 29-kDa proteolysis-resisting fragment , whereas antiandrogen binding stabilised a 35-kDa fragment .
3,7 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Both fragments contain the entire ligand binding domain , and the 35-kDa fragment extended into the hinge region of the receptor .
5,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Several antiandrogens show agonistic properties for a mutated androgen receptor ( LNCaP cell variant ) ; trypsin digestion of antiandrogen -bound mutated receptor also resulted in a 29-kDa fragment .
7,10 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Our results point to an important difference between antiandrogens and antagonists of other steroid hormone receptors .
13,16 G#protein

Antiandrogens result in protection of both the hinge region and C-terminus of the androgen receptor agonist proteolytic attack , whereas other studies showed that antiestrogens and antiprogestagens expose the C-terminal end of the ligand binding domain of their respective receptors to protease .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

Differences in conformation of the hinge region distinguish androgen -bound from antiandrogen -bound receptor complexes , which represents an important feature of antiandrogen action .
5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,15 G#protein

Activation of nuclear factor kappa B in human neuroblastoma cell lines .
2,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line|7,11 G#cell_line

The nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) is a eukaryotic transcription factor .
1,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

In B cells and macrophages it is constitutively present in cell nuclei , whereas in many other cell types , NF-kappa B translocates from cytosol to nucleus as a result of transduction by tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF alpha ) , phorbol ester , and other polyclonal signals .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#cell_type|20,22 G#protein|33,37 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

Using neuroblastoma cell lines as models , we have shown that in neural cells NF-kappa B was present in the cytosol and translocated into nuclei as a result of TNF alpha treatment .
1,4 G#cell_line|12,14 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

The TNF alpha -activated NF-kappa B was transcriptionally functional .
1,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

NF-kappa B activation by TNF alpha was not correlated with cell differentiation or proliferation .
0,2 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

However , reagents such as nerve growth factor ( NGF ) and the phorbol ester phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) , which induce phenotypical differentiation of the SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cell line , activated NF-kappa B , but only in that particular cell line .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_line|34,36 G#protein|42,44 G#cell_line

In a NGF -responsive rat pheochromocytoma cell line , PC12 , PMA activated NF-kappa B , whereas NGF did not .
2,3 G#protein|2,8 G#cell_line|9,10 G#cell_line|13,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

In other neuroblastoma cell lines , such as SK-N-Be(2) , the lack of PMA induction of differentiation was correlated with the lack of NF-kappa B activation .
2,5 G#cell_line|8,9 G#cell_line|23,25 G#protein

We found , moreover , that in SK-N-Be(2) cells protein kinase C ( PKC ) enzymatic activity was much lower compared with that in a control cell line and that the low PKC enzymatic activity was due to low PKC protein expression .
7,9 G#cell_line|9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_line|32,33 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

NF-kappa B was not activated by retinoic acid , which induced morphological differentiation of all the neuroblastoma cell lines used in the present study .
0,2 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line

Thus , NF-kappa B activation was not required for neuroblastoma cell differentiation .
2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type

Furthermore , the results obtained with TNF alpha proved that NF-kappa B activation was not sufficient for induction of neuroblastoma differentiation .
6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

ERP , a new member of the ets transcription factor/oncoprotein family : cloning , characterization , and differential expression during B-lymphocyte development .
0,1 G#protein|7,11 G#protein

The ets gene family encodes a group of proteins which function as transcription factors under physiological conditions and , if aberrantly expressed , can cause cellular transformation .
1,4 G#DNA|12,14 G#protein

We have recently identified two regulatory elements in the murine immunoglobulin heavy-chain ( IgH ) enhancer , pi and microB , which exhibit striking similarity to binding sites for ets-related proteins .
9,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

To identify ets-related transcriptional regulators expressed in pre-B lymphocytes that may interact with either the pi or the microB site , we have used a PCR approach with degenerate oligonucleotides encoding conserved sequences in all members of the ets family .
2,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|15,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|38,40 G#DNA

We have cloned the gene for a new ets-related transcription factor , ERP ( ets-related protein ) , from the murine pre-B cell line BASC 6C2 and from mouse lung tissue .
9,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_line|24,26 G#cell_line

The ERP protein contains a region of high homology with the ETS DNA-binding domain common to all members of the ets transcription factor/oncoprotein family .
1,2 G#protein|20,24 G#protein

Three additional smaller regions show homology to the ELK-1 and SAP-1 genes , a subgroup of the ets gene family that interacts with the serum response factor .
10,11 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA|24,27 G#protein

Full-length ERP expresses only negligible DNA-binding activity by itself .
1,2 G#protein

Removal of the carboxy terminus enables ERP to interact with a variety of ets-binding sites including the E74 site , the IgH enhancer pi site , and the lck promoter ets site , suggesting a carboxy-terminal negative regulatory domain .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|21,25 G#DNA|28,32 G#DNA|35,39 G#protein

At least three ERP -related transcripts are expressed in a variety of tissues .
3,4 G#protein|3,6 G#protein

However , within the B-cell lineage , ERP is highly expressed primarily at early stages of B-lymphocyte development , and expression declines drastically upon B-cell maturation , correlating with the enhancer activity of the IgH pi site .
4,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|34,37 G#DNA

These data suggest that ERP might play a role in B-cell development and in IgH gene regulation .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|14,16 G#DNA

Gene for a tissue-specific transcriptional activator ( EBF or Olf-1 ) , expressed in early B lymphocytes , adipocytes , and olfactory neurons , is located on human chromosome 5 , band q34 , and proximal mouse chromosome 11 .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type|27,30 G#DNA|31,33 G#DNA|35,39 G#DNA

Murine B lymphocytes , adipocytes , and olfactory neurons contain a DNA-binding protein that participates in the regulation of genes encoding tissue-specific components of signal transduction .
0,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|11,13 G#protein|19,20 G#DNA

Purification and cloning of this protein , termed early B-cell factor ( EBF ) , from murine B lymphocytes and independent cloning of a protein , termed Olf-1 , from olfactory neuronal cells revealed virtual complete amino acid sequence identity between these proteins .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_type|36,39 G#protein

As a first step towards identifying a human genetic disorder or mouse mutation for which EBF could be a candidate gene , we have chromosomally mapped the corresponding locus in both species .
15,16 G#protein

By Southern hybridization analyses of somatic cell hybrid panels with murine cDNA probe , fluorescence chromosomal in situ hybridization ( FISH ) of human genomic clones , and analysis of recombinant inbred mouse strains , we have found single sites for EBF homologous sequences on human Chromosome ( Chr ) 5 , band q34 , and on proximal mouse Chr 11 , in an evolutionarily conserved region .
10,13 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA|30,34 G#cell_line|41,42 G#protein|41,44 G#DNA|52,54 G#DNA|57,61 G#DNA|64,67 G#DNA

Calcineurin activates transcription from the GM-CSF promoter in synergy with either protein kinase C or NF-kappa B /AP-1 in T cells .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|11,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

Two cis-acting elements GM-kappa B/GC-box and CLE0 , of the granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) gene are required for maximal induction in Jurkat T cells by costimulation with phorbol-12-myristate acetate ( PMA ) and Ca2+ ionophore ( A23187 ) .
1,3 G#DNA|3,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|10,17 G#DNA|23,26 G#cell_line

The GM-kappa B sequence is recognized by NF-kappa B , which is mainly induced by PMA .
1,4 G#DNA|7,9 G#protein

The CLE0 sequence interacts with factors , related to a PMA -induced AP-1 and a PMA / A23187 -induced NF- AT .
1,3 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,21 G#protein

We examined whether signal transducing components in T cells can activate transcription of the GM-CSF gene .
7,9 G#cell_type|14,16 G#DNA

Cotransfection of NF-kappa B ( p50/p65 ) - or AP-1 ( c-Jun/c-Fos ) - expression vectors into Jurkat cells with a luciferase reporter containing the GM-CSF promoter did not stimulate transcription from the GM-CSF promoter .
2,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_line|21,23 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA

In contrast , cotransfection with a combination of NF-kappa B and AP-1 significantly augmented transcription from the GM-CSF promoter containing the GM-kappa B/GC-box and the CLE0 ( AP-1 /NF-AT ) .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Expression of a constitutively active calcineurin ( CN ) , a Ca2+ /calmodulin-dependent protein phosphatase , potentiated by two fold the transcriptional activation by NF-kappa B /AP-1 .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Both constitutively active forms of CN and protein kinase C ( PKC ) synergistically activated transcription from the GM-CSF promoter .
5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

These results suggest that cooperation among NF-kappa B- , AP-1- and NF-AT- binding sequences is required for induction of the GM-CSF gene through PKC- and Ca2+- signaling pathways downstream of T cell activation .
6,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

Nonpituitary human prolactin gene transcription is independent of Pit-1 and differentially controlled in lymphocytes and in endometrial stroma .
0,4 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

Expression of the human PRL ( hPRL ) gene in extrapituitary sites such as the uterus ( decidualized endometrial stroma and myometrium ) and cells of the hematopoietic lineage is directed by an alternative promoter which is located approximately 6 kilobases ( kb ) upstream of the pituitary-specific start site .
3,9 G#DNA|27,29 G#cell_type|33,35 G#DNA|39,45 G#DNA|47,50 G#DNA

In order to delineate the tissue-specific mechanisms governing the control of nonpituitary PRL gene expression , we have cloned and sequenced 3 kb 5'-flanking DNA of the upstream decidual/lymphoid ( dPRL ) promoter .
12,14 G#DNA|21,25 G#DNA|28,33 G#DNA

Based on sequence homology we identified two binding motifs for Pit-1 and seven half-sites for glucocorticoid receptor/progesterone receptor ( PR ) binding .
7,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

We focused our studies on the role of Pit-1 and of PR as potential transcriptional regulators , since the POU domain protein Pit-1 is essential in the control of pituitary PRL expression , and progesterone induces decidual transformation of the endometrial stroma , a differentiation process during which the decidual PRL gene is activated .
8,9 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|50,52 G#DNA

We demonstrate in a variety of cell types , including lymphocytes and endometrial stroma , that Pit-1 is not involved in the regulation of dPRL promoter/reporter gene constructs carrying 3 kb 5'-flanking DNA .
10,11 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|24,28 G#DNA|29,33 G#DNA

Our experiments also show that activated PR does not confer direct transcriptional control on the dPRL promoter .
6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

When we compared the activity of the transfected dPRL promoter in PRL- secreting and nonsecreting lymphoid cells , we found that the 3 kb 5'-flanking region of the dPRL promoter did not contain elements restricting expression to only those lymphocytes that produce PRL but allowed expression of fusion reporter genes irrespective of the status of the endogenous PRL gene .
8,10 G#DNA|11,17 G#cell_type|22,26 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|39,40 G#cell_type|57,58 G#protein|57,59 G#DNA

This was in sharp contrast to endometrial cells where 3 kb 5'-flanking DNA conferred strong transcriptional activation on the dPRL promoter in decidualized endometrial stromal cells actively secreting PRL , but did not allow transcription in undifferentiated non-PRL-secreting endometrial stromal cells .
19,21 G#DNA|23,26 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|37,41 G#cell_type

Activation of the dPRL promoter construct in these undifferentiated cells could however be induced by the addition of cAMP , in the absence of progesterone , suggesting that a signal transduced through the cAMP signaling pathway is a primary inducer of decidual PRL gene expression .
3,5 G#DNA|42,44 G#DNA

Signals and nuclear factors that regulate the expression of interleukin-4 and interleukin-5 genes in helper T cells .
2,4 G#protein|9,13 G#DNA|14,17 G#cell_type

Mouse thymoma line EL-4 cells produce cytokines such as interleukin ( IL ) -2 , IL-3 , IL-4 , IL-10 , and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor in response to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) .
3,5 G#cell_line|0,5 G#cell_line|6,7 G#protein|9,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

EL-4 cells also produce low levels of IL-5 when stimulated by PMA alone ; however , cAMP greatly augments PMA -dependent IL-5 production .
0,2 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

A transient transfection assay revealed that two signals , PMA and cAMP , are required for optimal activation of the IL-5 promoter .
20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

In contrast , cAMP almost completely inhibited the PMA -dependent activation of the endogenous IL-2 gene , as well as the transfected IL-2 promoter .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA

These results indicate that the IL-5 gene is positively regulated by cAMP in a manner opposite to that for the IL-2 gene .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

One of the nuclear factors ( NFs ) that regulates the response of the IL-5 promoter to cAMP and PMA has properties similar to NF for activated t cell .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_type

The P sequence of the IL-4 gene , defined as a responsive element for PMA and calcium ionophore ( A23187 ) , shares sequence similarity with the NF kappa B and the NF-activated T cell binding sites .
1,3 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|27,37 G#DNA

We attempted to determine whether NF(P) , a nuclear factor specific for the P sequence , is related to NF-kappa B and nuclear factor for activated T cell ( NF-AT ) .
5,6 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein|22,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

In electromobility shift assays both NF-kappa B ( P65 or P65/P50 heterodimer ) and NF-AT bound to the P sequence .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

However , sequence specificity of NF-AT was more similar to that of NF(P) , and only a small amount of P65 was detected in NF(P) .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

These results indicate that a component or components of NF-AT have the potential to reconstitute NF(P) , whereas NF-kappa B alone does not account for NF(P) in Jurkat crude extract .
9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Taken together , these results suggest that NF-AT-like factors are involved in the regulation of IL-4 and IL-5 genes .
7,9 G#protein|15,19 G#DNA

Solution structure of a POU-specific homeodomain : 3D-NMR studies of human B-cell transcription factor Oct-2 .
4,6 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The POU DNA-binding motif defines a conserved family of eukaryotic transcription factors involved in regulation of gene expression .
1,4 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

This bipartite motif consists of an N-terminal POU-specific domain ( POUs ) , a flexible linker , and a C-terminal POU-specific homeodomain ( POUHD ) .
1,3 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Here we describe the solution structure of a POU-specific homeodomain .
8,10 G#protein

An NMR model is obtained from Oct-2 , a human B-cell specific transcription factor which participates in the regulation of immunoglobulin genes .
6,7 G#protein|9,14 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

A fragment of Oct-2 containing POUHD and an adjoining linker was expressed in Escherichia coli and characterized by three-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance ( 3D-NMR ) spectroscopy .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Complete 1H and 15N resonance assignment of the POUHD moiety is presented .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

The POUHD solution structure , as calculated by distance geometry and simulated annealing ( DG/SA ) , is similar to that of canonical homeodomains .
1,2 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

A salient difference between solution and crystal structures is observed in the C-terminal segment of alpha-helix 3 ( the HTH recognition helix ) , which is not well ordered in solution .
4,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

Because this segment presumably folds upon specific DNA binding , its flexibility in solution may reduce the intrinsic DNA affinity of POUHD in the absence of POUs .
21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

NF-kappa B -dependent and -independent pathways of HIV activation in a chronically infected T cell line .
11,16 G#cell_line

J delta K cells were isolated as a chronically infected survivor cell line , following infection of Jurkat CD4+ T cells with dl-NF , a mutated strain of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) containing a deletion of the long terminal repeat ( LTR ) NF-kappa B sites .
0,4 G#cell_line|8,13 G#cell_line|17,21 G#cell_line|41,44 G#DNA|45,46 G#DNA|47,49 G#protein

J delta K cells exhibited very low levels of constitutive HIV production .
0,4 G#cell_line

HIV-1 expression was activated from J delta K cells by treatment with phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) , sodium butyrate ( NaB ) , or hexamethylene bisacetamide ( HMBA ) , but not tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) , confirming the role of NF-kappa B in mediating TNF-alpha induction of HIV transcription .
5,9 G#cell_line|34,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|46,48 G#protein|50,51 G#protein

The strong induction of HIV expression by NaB or HMBA in J delta K cells clearly demonstrates the existence of NF-kappa B -independent mechanisms of HIV activation in chronically infected cells .
11,15 G#cell_line|20,22 G#protein|28,31 G#cell_type

J delta K cells may provide a useful model for characterizing NF-kappa B -independent transcriptional activation of the HIV LTR .
0,4 G#cell_line|11,13 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

JNK is involved in signal integration during costimulation of T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

T lymphocyte activation and interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) production require at least two signals , generated by phorbol ester ( TPA ) and Ca2+ ionophore or costimulation of the T cell receptor ( TCR ) and the CD28 auxiliary receptor .
0,2 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|37,40 G#protein

We investigated how these stimuli affect mitogen activated protein ( MAP ) kinases .
6,13 G#protein

Full activation of the MAP kinases that phosphorylate the Jun activation domain , JNK1 and JNK2 , required costimulation of T cells with either TPA and Ca2+ ionophore or antibodies to TCR and CD28 .
4,6 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Alone , each stimulus resulted in little or no activation .


Similar to its effect on IL-2 induction , cyclosporin A ( CsA ) inhibited the synergistic activation of JNK , and a competitive inhibitor of Jun phosphorylation by JNK inhibited IL-2 promoter activation .
5,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|30,32 G#DNA

By contrast , the MAP kinases ERK1 and ERK2 were fully activated by TPA or TCR stimulation and were not affected by Ca2+ , CD28 , or CsA .
4,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Hence , integration of signals that lead to T cell activation occurs at the level of JNK activation .
16,17 G#protein

Inhibition of rat splenocyte proliferation with methylprednisolone : in vivo effect of liposomal formulation .
2,4 G#cell_type

The effect of a liposomal formulation of methylprednisolone ( MPL ) on the inhibition of lymphocyte proliferation in spleen cells was investigated following IV dosing in rats .
18,20 G#cell_type

Liposomes do not alter the suppressive action of MPL when placed in lymphocyte culture .
12,14 G#cell_line

Rat splenocytes were found to have greater sensitivity to MPL ( EC50 = 7.9 nM ) than do human peripheral blood lymphocytes ( EC50 = 28 nM ) .
0,2 G#cell_type|18,22 G#cell_type

In vivo studies in rats utilized 2 mg/kg IV bolus doses of liposomal MPL compared to drug in solution .


Animals were sacrificed at various times post-dosing until 120 h , spleen was excised and , after incubation of lymphocytes with PHA , splenocyte blastogenic responses were assessed by measuring cellular incorporation of 3H-thymidine .
19,20 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein

The suppressive effect of liposomal MPL in comparison with free drug was significantly prolonged ( &gt; 120 h vs &lt; 18 h ) .


Inhibition effects versus time were described by a pharmacodynamic model using MPL concentrations in plasma as an input function .
14,15 G#cell_type

A nonlinear relationship was found between suppression of splenocyte proliferation and the concentration of bound glucocorticoid receptors in spleen .
8,9 G#cell_type|15,17 G#protein

Only partial receptor occupancy accompanied complete lymphocyte suppression .


The suppression of endogenous corticosterone in plasma for both treatments was similar with values from L- MPL rats returning to baseline after 24 h .
6,7 G#cell_type

These results demonstrate enhanced efficacy of local immunosuppression by targeting spleen with liposomal MPL .


Function of NF-kappa B /Rel binding sites in the major histocompatibility complex class II invariant chain promoter is dependent on cell-specific binding of different NF-kappa B /Rel subunits .
2,4 G#protein|2,7 G#DNA|9,17 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein|24,28 G#protein

The promoter of the human major histocompatibility complex class II-associated invariant-chain gene ( Ii ) contains two NF-kappa B /Rel binding sites located at -109 to -118 ( Ii kappa B-1 ) and -163 to -172 ( Ii kappa B-2 ) from the transcription start site .
1,2 G#DNA|6,12 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|17,22 G#DNA|24,27 G#DNA|28,31 G#DNA|33,36 G#DNA|37,40 G#DNA

We report here that the differential function of each of these NF-kappa B /Rel sites in several distinct cell types depends on cell-specific binding of NF-kappa B /Rel transcription factors .
11,13 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|25,30 G#protein

Ii kappa B-1 is a positive regulatory element in B-cell lines and in the Ii-expressing T-cell line , H9 , but acts as a negative regulatory element in myelomonocytic and glia cell lines .
0,3 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#cell_line|14,17 G#cell_line|18,19 G#cell_line|24,27 G#DNA|28,33 G#cell_line

In vivo protein-DNA contacts are detectable at Ii kappa B-1 in cell lines in which this site is functional as either a positive or negative regulator .
7,10 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_line|22,26 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility supershift assays determine that members of the NF-kappa B /Rel family of transcription factors can bind to this site in vitro and that DNA-binding complexes that contain p50 , p52 , p65 , and cRel correlate with positive regulation whereas the presence of p50 correlates with negative regulation .
9,11 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|45,46 G#protein

Ii kappa B-2 is a site of positive regulation in B-cell lines and a site of negative regulation in H9 T cells , myelomonocytic , and glial cell lines .
0,3 G#DNA|10,12 G#cell_line|19,22 G#cell_line|23,29 G#cell_line

In vivo occupancy of this site is observed only in the H9 T-cell line .
11,14 G#cell_line

Again , in vitro supershift studies indicate that the presence of p50 , p52 , p65 , and cRel correlates with positive function whereas the presence of only p50 and p52 correlates with negative function .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

This differential binding of specific NF-kappa B /Rel subunits is likely to mediate the disparate functions of these two NF-kappa B /Rel binding sites .
5,7 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|19,24 G#DNA

Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) replicative gene expression in tumour cells of AIDS-related non-Hodgkin 's lymphoma in relation to CD4 cell number and antibody titres to EBV .
9,11 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

OBJECTIVE : To determine whether activation of Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) replication in tumour cells of AIDS-related non-Hodgkin 's lymphoma ( ARNHL ) is correlated with CD4+ cell counts and influences antibody response to EBV [ anti-Z Epstein-Barr replicative activator ( ZEBRA ) , anti-early antigen ( EA ) , anti-viral capsid antigen ( VCA ) ] .
14,16 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|37,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|45,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|51,54 G#protein|55,56 G#protein

DESIGN : Retrospective study based on immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization to detect EBV replicative gene products in tissue samples from patients affected by ARNHL and correlation with CD4+ cell counts and results of EBV serology ( including anti- ZEBRA activity ) in sera from the same patients .
28,29 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

METHODS : Seventeen out of 22 cases of ARNHL were selected for the presence of EBV [ Epstein-Barr early region ( EBER ) RNA-positive ] .


Immunohistochemistry was performed with anti- ZEBRA , anti- EA -restricted , anti- VCA antibodies and in situ hybridization with BHLF1/NotI oligoprobes on tumour samples .
5,6 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|7,14 G#protein

Results were statistically correlated with those of CD4+ cell counts ( 17 out of 17 ) and with anti- EBV antibody titres ( 13 out of 17 ) assessed using standard immunofluorescence method and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay procedure using recombinant ZEBRA protein and synthetic peptides as antigens .
7,8 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|39,42 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

RESULTS : BZLF1 ( ZEBRA ) or early gene products ( EA-R and EA-D/BHLF1/NotI ) were detected in a small proportion ( &lt; 0.01-5 % ) of tumour cells in eight of these 17 cases by immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|27,29 G#cell_type

Demonstration of replicative gene expression did not correlate with either low CD4+ cell counts ( P &gt; 0.05 ) or anti- EBV antibody titres ( P &gt; 0.05 ) .
11,12 G#protein

Anti- ZEBRA activity was not significantly increased in patients affected with ARNHL , the cells of which expressed replicative gene products ( P &gt; 0.05 ) .
1,2 G#protein

CONCLUSION : The degree of immunodeficiency does not clearly enhance replicative gene expression in tumour cells of ARNHL .
14,16 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

EBV serology , including anti- ZEBRA activity , is not a reliable tool for predicting the occurrence of such proliferations .

Effects of prostaglandin E2 on Th0-type human T cell clones : modulation of functions of nuclear proteins involved in cytokine production .
2,4 G#protein|5,10 G#cell_line|15,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The effects of prostaglandin E2 ( PGE2 ) on cytokine production and proliferation of the CD4+ human helper T cell clone SP-B21 were investigated .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,22 G#cell_line

In cells stimulated with anti-CD3 mAb , PGE2 inhibited cell proliferation and the production of all the cytokines examined .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Addition of rIL-2 fully restored the proliferative response and partially restored the production of IL-4 and IL-5 , but not that of other cytokines .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

In contrast , in cells stimulated with phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) / A23187 , PGE2 enhanced the production of IL-4 and IL-5 , and only partially inhibited the production of other cytokines .
16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Therefore , the effects of PGE2 vary depending on the mode of T cell activation , and the IL-4 and IL-5 are regulated differently from other cytokines .
5,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

In a mobility shift assay , only the NF-kappa B ( p50 /p50 ) homodimer was observed in a complex formed with the kappa B sequence in unstimulated SP-B21 cells .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|8,15 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA

When cells were stimulated with anti-CD3 mAb or PMA /A23187 , a complex formation of NF-kappa B ( p50 /p65 ) heterodimer with the kappa B sequence was induced .
5,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA

Interestingly , PGE2 or di-butyryl ( Bt2 ) cAMP abolished the binding of NF-kappa B ( p50 /p65 ) heterodimer to the kappa B sequence in cells stimulated with anti-CD3 mAb but not with PMA /A23187 .
2,3 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|13,20 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein

Our results suggest that the target of PGE2 action is a component in the signal transduction pathway leading to the activation of protein kinase C .
7,8 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

However , the inhibition of the T cell activation signals by PGE2 is selective .
11,12 G#protein

PGE2 enhanced the complex formation with NF-AT , AP-1 and CLE0 sequences when the cells were activated by either anti-CD3 mAb or PMA /A23187 stimulation .
0,1 G#protein|6,12 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein

It seems therefore that PGE2 , by elevating cAMP levels , interferes with the activation pathway for NF-kappa B but not for NF-AT , AP-1 or CLE0 binding protein .
4,5 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The P sequence of the human interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) gene , which was defined as a responsive element for phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate and calcium ionophore ( A23187 ) in Jurkat T cells , shares sequence similarity with the NF-kappa B and the NF-AT binding sites .

3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

NF-kappa B ( P65 or P65/P50 heterodimer ) bound to the P sequence in electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSA ) and activated transcription through the P sequence when expression plasmids were cotransfected with P sequence -driven reporter plasmids in Jurkat T cells .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA|34,36 G#DNA|34,39 G#DNA|40,43 G#cell_line

3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|9,13 G#DNA|17,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|31,33 G#DNA

Both mobility shift and sequence specificity of NF-AT were similar to those of NF(P) and only a small amount of P65 was detected in NF(P) in crude nuclear extracts .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

These results indicate that the component ( s ) of NF-AT has the potential to reconstitute NF(P) whereas NF-kappa B alone can not account for NF(P) in crude extracts .
10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Unlike NF-AT , NF(P) does not contain AP1 as its DNA binding component .

Activation of early growth response 1 gene transcription and pp90rsk during induction of monocytic differentiation .
2,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein

The present work has studied mechanisms responsible for induction of early growth response 1 ( EGR-1 ) gene expression during monocytic differentiation of U-937 myeloid leukemia cells .
10,18 G#DNA|23,27 G#cell_line

Differentiation of U-937 cells with 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate ( TPA ) , an activator of the serine/threonine protein kinase C , was associated with transcriptional activation of EGR-1 promoter-reporter constructs .
2,4 G#cell_line|15,18 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA

The EGR-1 promoter contains six CC(A/T)6GG ( CArG ) motifs .
1,3 G#DNA|5,10 G#DNA

The two 5'-most distal CArG sequences conferred TPA inducibility .
2,6 G#DNA

In contrast , there was little effect of TPA on EGR-1 transcription in a TPA -resistant U-937 cell variant , designated TUR .
10,11 G#DNA|14,19 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_line

Treatment of both U-937 and TUR cells with okadaic acid , an inhibitor of serine/threonine protein phosphatases 1 and 2A , was associated with induction of monocytic differentiation and EGR-1 transcription through the 5'-most CArG element .
3,4 G#cell_line|5,7 G#cell_line|14,20 G#protein|29,30 G#DNA|33,36 G#DNA

15,16 G#DNA|23,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#DNA

Antioxidants inhibit monocyte adhesion by suppressing nuclear factor-kappa B mobilization and induction of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 in endothelial cells stimulated to generate radicals .
2,3 G#cell_type|6,9 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Cell adhesion to endothelial cells stimulated by tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF ) is due to induction of surface receptors , such as vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 ( VCAM-1 ) .
3,5 G#cell_type|5,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The antioxidant pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ( PDTC ) specifically inhibits activation of nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) .
11,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Since kappa B motifs are present in VCAM-1 and intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) promoters , we used PDTC to study the regulatory mechanisms of VCAM-1 and ICAM-1 induction and subsequent monocyte adhesion in TNF-treated human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVECs ) .
1,4 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|9,16 G#DNA|7,16 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|32,33 G#cell_type|39,41 G#cell_type|35,41 G#cell_line|42,43 G#cell_line

7,8 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|16,21 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_line

3,4 G#cell_line|8,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Since HUVECs released superoxide anions in response to TNF , and H2O2 induces VCAM-1 , PDTC may act as a radical scavenger .
1,2 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein

1,2 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

9,12 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|13,15 G#cell_line

Displacement of an E-box-binding repressor by basic helix-loop-helix proteins : implications for B-cell specificity of the immunoglobulin heavy-chain enhancer .
3,5 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|16,19 G#DNA

The activity of the immunoglobulin heavy-chain ( IgH ) enhancer is restricted to B cells , although it binds both B-cell-restricted and ubiquitous transcription factors .
4,10 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_type|20,25 G#protein

Activation of the enhancer in non- B cells upon overexpression of the basic helix-loop-helix ( bHLH ) protein E2A appears to be mediated not only by the binding of E2A to its cognate E box but also by the resulting displacement of a repressor from that same site .
3,4 G#DNA|6,8 G#cell_type|5,8 G#cell_type|12,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA|43,44 G#protein

We have identified a " two-handed " zinc finger protein , denoted ZEB , the DNA-binding specificity of which mimics that of the cellular repressor .
4,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

By employing a derivative E box that binds ZEB but not E2A , we have shown that the repressor is active in B cells and the IgH enhancer is silenced in the absence of binding competition by bHLH proteins .
4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type|26,28 G#DNA|37,39 G#protein

Hence , we propose that a necessary prerequisite of enhancer activity is the B-cell-specific displacement of a ZEB -like repressor by bHLH proteins .

Inhibition of NF-kappa B by sodium salicylate and aspirin [ see comments ]
2,4 G#protein

The transcription factor nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) is critical for the inducible expression of multiple cellular and viral genes involved in inflammation and infection including interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) , IL-6 , and adhesion molecules .
1,3 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|18,22 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

The anti-inflammatory drugs sodium salicylate and aspirin inhibited the activation of NF-kappa B , which further explains the mechanism of action of these drugs .
11,13 G#protein

This inhibition prevented the degradation of the NF-kappa B inhibitor , I kappa B , and therefore NF-kappa B was retained in the cytosol .
7,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Sodium salicylate and aspirin also inhibited NF-kappa B -dependent transcription from the Ig kappa enhancer and the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) long terminal repeat ( LTR ) in transfected T cells .
6,8 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|17,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA|30,33 G#cell_line

Effects of the antisense myb expression on hemin- and erythropoietin- induced erythroid differentiation of K562 cells .
14,16 G#cell_line

In order to elucidate the role of c-myb gene in erythroid differentiation of K562 cell induced by hemin ( Hm ) and erythropoietin ( Epo ) , we constructed recombinant plasmid that could produce antisense myb RNA after induction with dexamethasone .
7,9 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA|34,37 G#RNA

During treatment with Hm , K562 cells constitutively expressed c-myb mRNA , and 50 % of them began to synthesize hemoglobin ( Hb ) .
3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_line|9,11 G#RNA|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Expression of antisense myb RNA reduced the amount of c-myb mRNA , and the percentage of Hb -synthesizing cells was decreased to 20 % .
2,5 G#RNA|9,11 G#RNA|16,17 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line

In the presence of Epo , c-myb mRNA declined and 20 % of K562 cells synthesized Hb regardless of antisense myb RNA expression .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#RNA|13,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|19,22 G#RNA

It is suggested that constitutive expression of c-myb mRNA is necessary for Hm -induced differentiation , and that a decrease in the amount of c-myb mRNA induced by antisense myb RNA expression suppresses Hm -induced differentiation .
7,9 G#RNA|12,13 G#protein|24,26 G#RNA|28,31 G#RNA|33,34 G#protein

The amount of c-myb mRNA in K562 cells was reduced during the differentiation induced by Epo .
3,5 G#RNA|6,8 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein

Expression of GATA-1 mRNA was almost constant during Hm -induced differentiation , but increased during Epo treatment .
2,4 G#RNA|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

It is supposed that the mechanism of Hm -induced differentiation is distinguished from that of Epo -induced differentiation in K562 cells .

Prenatal immune challenge alters the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenocortical axis in adult rats .


We investigated whether non-abortive maternal infections would compromise fetal brain development and alter hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenocortical ( HPA ) axis functioning when adult .


To study putative teratogenic effects of a T cell-mediated immune response versus an endotoxic challenge , 10-d-pregnant rats received a single intraperitoneal injection of 5 x 10 ( 8 ) human red blood cells ( HRBC ) or gram-negative bacterial endotoxin ( Escherichia coli LPS : 30 micrograms/kg ) .
30,34 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type

The adult male progeny ( 3 mo old ) of both experimental groups showed increased basal plasma corticosterone levels .


In addition , after novelty stress the HRBC group , but not the LPS group , showed increased ACTH and corticosterone levels .
7,8 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_line

Both groups showed substantial decreases in mineralocorticoid ( MR ) and glucocorticoid receptor ( GR ) levels in the hippocampus , a limbic brain structure critical for HPA axis regulation , whereas GR concentrations in the hypothalamus were unchanged and in anterior pituitary were slightly increased .
32,33 G#protein

HRBC and LPS indeed stimulated the maternal immune system as revealed by specific anti- HRBC antibody production and enhanced IL-1 beta mRNA expression in splenocytes , respectively .
0,1 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|13,16 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type

This study demonstrates that a T cell-mediated immune response as well as an endotoxic challenge during pregnancy can induce anomalies in HPA axis function in adulthood .


Clinically , it may be postulated that disturbed fetal brain development due to prenatal immune challenge increases the vulnerability to develop mental illness involving inadequate responses to stress .


A low NM23.H1 gene expression identifying high malignancy human melanomas .
2,4 G#DNA

The NM23 gene has been proposed as a metastasis-suppressor gene , and its use has been suggested as prognostic factor .
1,3 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA

NM23 was identified in a system of murine melanoma cell lines , in which an inverse relationship was found between NM23 expression and metastatic ability .
0,1 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein

In a human malignant melanoma study NM23 expression was found to be significantly lower in metastases that developed less than 24 months after diagnosis of the primary tumours .
6,7 G#protein

The present paper studies the expression of the NM23 .H1 gene in cell lines which derive from primary or metastatic human malignant melanomas in relation to staging , infiltration degree , lymphocytic infiltration , cell morphology , cell pigmentation , karyotype , and disease-free survival .
8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_line

The level of mRNA expression of the NM23 gene is significantly lower in cell lines that derive from more infiltrating primary melanomas than in cell lines obtained from less infiltrating tumours .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_line|24,26 G#cell_line

Moreover , cell lines derived from tumours of patients with a disease-free survival of more than 24 months ( 24-58 months ) express the NM23 gene at higher levels than cell lines obtained from melanomas of patients with a disease-free survival of less than 24 months ( 6-15 months ) .
2,4 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|30,32 G#cell_line

Activation of a novel serine /threonine kinase that phosphorylates c-Fos upon stimulation of T and B lymphocytes via antigen and cytokine receptors .
4,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type|20,22 G#protein

Ligation of Ag receptors in T and B lymphocytes initiates signal transduction cascades which alter the expression of genes that regulate cellular proliferation and differentiation .
2,4 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_type

The transmission of signals from the membrane to the nucleus is mediated principally through the action of protein tyrosine and serine/threonine kinases .
17,22 G#protein

We have identified and characterized a novel serine /threonine kinase that phosphorylated the proto-oncogene product , c-Fos , and is termed Fos kinase .
7,10 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

Fos kinase was rapidly activated after ligation of the CD3 and CD2 receptors in Jurkat and normal human T lymphocytes and in response to IL-6 and anti-IgM in the human B cell lines AF10 and Ramos , respectively .
0,2 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_line|16,20 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_line|29,33 G#cell_line|33,34 G#cell_line|35,36 G#cell_line

The phorbol ester , PMA , was also a potent inducer of Fos kinase activity in all of the above populations , suggesting that PKC plays a role in the regulation of this enzyme .
12,14 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Fos kinase phosphorylates c-Fos at a site near the C-terminus , as well as a peptide derived from this region ( residues 359-370 , RKGSSSNEPSSD ) , and Fos peptide competitively inhibited c-Fos phosphorylation .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Fos kinase was shown to be distinct from other identified serine /threonine kinases , including protein kinase A , protein kinase C , casein kinase II , MAP kinases , p70S6K and p90RSK .
0,2 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Fos kinase was purified by anion exchange chromatography and exhibited an apparent M(r) = 65,000 and isoelectric point = 6.1 .
0,2 G#protein

Fos kinase may play a role in transcriptional regulation through its capacity to phosphorylate c-Fos at a site required for expression of the transcriptional transrepressive activity of this molecule .
0,2 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Moreover , its rapid activation suggests it may have a wider role within signal transduction cascades in lymphocytes .
17,18 G#cell_type

Antigenic specificities of human CD4+ T-cell clones recovered from recurrent genital herpes simplex virus type 2 lesions .
3,7 G#cell_line

Lesions resulting from recurrent genital herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) infection are characterized by infiltration of CD4+ lymphocytes .
17,19 G#cell_type

We have investigated the antigenic specificity of 47 HSV-specific CD4+ T-cell clones recovered from the HSV-2 buttock and thigh lesions of five patients .
8,12 G#cell_line

Clones with proliferative responses to recombinant truncated glycoprotein B ( gB ) or gD of HSV-2 or purified natural gC of HSV-2 comprised a minority of the total number of HSV-specific clones isolated from lesions .
5,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line

The gC2- and gD2- specific CD4+ clones had cytotoxic activity .
1,7 G#cell_line

The approximate locations of the HSV-2 genes encoding HSV-2 type-specific CD4+ antigens have been determined by using HSV-1 x HSV-2 intertypic recombinant virus and include the approximate map regions 0.30 to 0.46 , 0.59 to 0.67 , 0.67 to 0.73 , and 0.82 to 1.0 units .
10,12 G#protein

The antigenic specificity of an HLA DQ2-restricted , HSV-2 type-specific T-cell clone was mapped to amino acids 425 to 444 of VP16 of HSV-2 by sequential use of an intertypic recombinant virus containing VP16 of HSV-2 in an HSV-1 background , recombinant VP16 fusion proteins , and synthetic peptides .
5,12 G#cell_line|15,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|41,45 G#protein

Each of the remaining four patients also yielded at least one type-specific T-cell clone reactive with an HSV-2 epitope mapping to approximately 0.67 to 0.73 map units .
11,14 G#cell_line

The antigenic specificities of lesion-derived CD4+ T-cell clones are quite diverse and include at least 10 epitopes .
4,8 G#cell_line

Human T-cell clones reactive with gC and VP16 are reported here for the first time .

Marked basophilia in acute promyelocytic leukaemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid : molecular analysis of the cell origin of the basophils .
20,21 G#cell_type

We report a patient with acute promyelocytic leukaemia who developed marked basophilia during all-trans retinoic acid treatment .


We studied genomic DNA and RNA extracted from the patient 's peripheral leucocytes in order to determine the origin of the basophils .
2,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#RNA|11,13 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type

The RAR alpha rearranged band in the Southern blot analysis and a chimaeric product of PML-RAR alpha by polymerase chain reaction were strongly visible before ATRA treatment , but at the time of maximal basophilia both of them were markedly diminished .
1,3 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

These findings suggest that the basophils which appeared during the ATRA treatment are reactive in nature rather than a leukaemic clone .
