Activation of the interleukin 6 gene by Mycobacterium tuberculosis or lipopolysaccharide is mediated by nuclear factors NF-IL6 and NF-kappa B [ published erratum appears in Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A 1995 Apr 11 ; 92 ( 8 ) : 3632 ]
3,6 G#DNA|14,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

The host response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis includes granuloma formation at sites of infection and systemic symptoms .


Cytokines have been identified by immunohistochemistry in granulomas in animal models of bacillus Calmette-Guerin ( BCG ) infection and are released by mononuclear phagocytes upon stimulation by mycobacterial proteins .
0,1 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type

In this regard , the cytokine interleukin 6 ( IL-6 ) may play a role in the clinical manifestations and pathological events of tuberculosis infection .
5,6 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

We have demonstrated that lipoarabinomannan ( LAM ) from the mycobacterial cell wall , which was virtually devoid of lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) , stimulated mononuclear phagocytes to release IL-6 in a dose-response manner .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein

LAM and LPS were potent inducers of IL-6 gene expression in peripheral blood monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|11,14 G#cell_type

Both LAM - and LPS -inducible IL-6 promoter activity was localized to a DNA fragment , positions -158 to -49 , by deletion analysis and chloramphenicol acetyltransferase assay .
1,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|4,8 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein

Two nuclear factor NF-IL6 ( positions -153 to -145 and -83 to -75 ) and one nuclear factor NF-kappa B ( positions -72 to -63 ) motifs are present within this fragment .
3,4 G#DNA|1,4 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|18,20 G#protein|16,27 G#DNA

Site-directed mutagenesis of one or more of these motifs within the IL-6 promoter demonstrated that each has positive regulatory activity and that they could act in a function- and orientation-independent manner .
11,12 G#protein

Deletion of all three elements abolished inducibility of IL-6 promoter activity by both LAM and LPS .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein

We conclude that the NF-IL6 and NF-kappa B sites mediate IL-6 induction in response to both LPS and LAM , acting as bacterial or mycobacterial response elements .
4,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,27 G#DNA

Regulation of CD14 expression during monocytic differentiation induced with 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 .
2,3 G#protein

CD14 , a monocyte/macrophage receptor for the complex of LPS and LPS binding protein , is a differentiation marker for the monocyte/macrophage lineage .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

We have analyzed the regulation of CD14 expression during 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( VitD3 ) -induced monocytic differentiation .
6,7 G#protein

Using FACS , Northern blotting , and nuclear run-on analyses , we demonstrate that the up-regulation of CD14 expression during monocytic cell maturation is regulated mainly at the level of gene transcription , and that new protein synthesis is required for CD14 induction .
17,18 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

We have recently cloned the CD14 5' upstream sequence and demonstrated its tissue-specific promoter activity .
5,6 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

Using stable transfection of the monocytoid U937 cell line with a series of deletion mutants of the CD14 5' upstream sequence coupled to a reporter gene construct , we show that bp -128 to -70 is the critical region for the induction of CD14 expression .
5,9 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|17,21 G#DNA|31,35 G#DNA|43,44 G#protein

This region contains two binding sites for the Sp1 transcription factor .
4,6 G#DNA|8,11 G#protein

A 3-bp mutation at the distal Sp1-binding site not only eliminates Sp1 interaction , but also abolishes most of the VitD3 induction of CD14 expression .
6,8 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility shift analysis does not detect a direct interaction of the CD14 distal Sp1-binding site with the vitamin D3 receptor and its partner , the retinoid X receptor .
12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|18,21 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

These data demonstrate that VitD3 induces CD14 indirectly through some intermediary factor , and suggest a critical role for Sp1 in this process .
6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

DNA-binding and transcriptional regulatory properties of hepatic leukemia factor ( HLF ) and the t(17;19) acute lymphoblastic leukemia chimera E2A- HLF .
6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|15,21 G#protein

The t(17;19) translocation in acute lymphoblastic leukemias results in creation of E2A- hepatic leukemia factor ( HLF ) chimeric proteins that contain the DNA-binding and protein dimerization domains of the basic leucine zipper ( bZIP ) protein HLF fused to a portion of E2A proteins with transcriptional activation properties .
1,2 G#DNA|12,15 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|23,28 G#protein|30,37 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|43,45 G#protein

An in vitro binding site selection procedure was used to determine DNA sequences preferentially bound by wild-type HLF and chimeric E2A- HLF proteins isolated from various t(17;19)-bearing leukemias .
17,18 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_line

All were found to selectively bind the consensus sequence 5'-GTTACGTAAT-3' with high affinity .
7,9 G#DNA

Wild-type and chimeric HLF proteins also bound closely related sites identified previously for bZIP proteins of both the proline - and acidic amino acid-rich ( PAR ) and C/EBP subfamilies ; however , E2A- HLF proteins were significantly less tolerant of certain deviations from the HLF consensus binding site .
3,4 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|45,49 G#DNA

These differences were directly attributable to loss of an HLF ancillary DNA-binding domain in all E2A- HLF chimeras and were further exacerbated by a zipper mutation in one isolate .
9,10 G#protein|9,13 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

Both wild-type and chimeric HLF proteins displayed transcriptional activator properties in lymphoid and nonlymphoid cells on reporter genes containing HLF or C/EBP consensus binding sites .
1,2 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_type|16,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|19,25 G#DNA

But on reporter genes with nonoptimal binding sites , their transcriptional properties diverged and E2A- HLF competitively inhibited activation by wild-type PAR proteins .
2,4 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

These findings establish a spectrum of binding site-specific transcriptional properties for E2A- HLF which may preferentially activate expression of select subordinate genes as a homodimer and potentially antagonize expression of others through heteromeric interactions .
12,13 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

ZAP-70 tyrosine kinase , CD45 , and T cell receptor involvement in UV- and H2O2- induced T cell signal transduction .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,10 G#protein

Several mammalian responses to UV irradiation , including the activation of NF-kappa B , are believed to involve tyrosine phosphorylation .
11,13 G#protein

UV irradiation and H2O2 treatment of T lymphocytes induce protein tyrosine phosphorylation and Ca2+ signals similar to those observed following biological stimulation .
6,8 G#cell_type

We have examined the role of cell surface molecules in these responses .


Normal T lymphocytes whose surface expression of CD3 was depleted showed impaired UV-induced tyrosine phosphorylation and Ca2+ signals .
1,3 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein

Similarly , Jurkat T cell lines deficient in CD3 or CD45 expression also gave impaired UV responses .
2,6 G#cell_line

However , all these cell types still gave strong Ca2+ and tyrosine phosphorylation responses to H2O2 .


The T cell tyrosine kinase ZAP-70 was found to be highly responsive to UV and H2O2 treatment .
4,6 G#protein

ZAP-70 responsiveness to UV required expression of both CD3 and CD45 , whereas only CD3 was required for the response to H2O2 .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

UV -induced activation of NF-kappa B was blocked by CD3 depletion , indicating the importance of such cell surface molecules in biological responses to UV .
4,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

In nonlymphoid cells , the epidermal growth factor receptor displayed increased tyrosine phosphorylation within seconds of UV irradiation .
1,3 G#cell_type|5,9 G#protein

These results suggest that UV -induced signal transduction is mediated via cell surface receptors that normally respond to biological stimulation , whereas H2O2 is able to partially bypass this requirement .
11,14 G#protein

Inhibition of the differentiation of human myeloid cell lines by redox changes induced through glutathione depletion .
5,9 G#cell_line

We have investigated the effect of redox changes in vivo on the differentiation of two human myeloid cell lines , HL-60 and KG-1 .
15,19 G#cell_line|20,21 G#cell_line|22,23 G#cell_line

The glutathione -depleting agent diethyl maleate ( DEM ) prevented the development of differentiated features in response to phorbol esters , including adherence of the cells to plastic surfaces and repression of the myeloperoxidase and CD34 genes .
33,37 G#DNA

Moreover , DEM abolished phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate -induced activation of the transcription factors AP-1 and Egr-1 , suggesting that inhibition of differentiation may be due , at least in part , to redox modifications of these proteins .
11,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Lipopolysaccharide induction of tissue factor gene expression in monocytic cells is mediated by binding of c-Rel/p65 heterodimers to a kappa B-like site .
3,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_type|15,17 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA

Exposure of monocytic cells to bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) activates the NF-kappa B /Rel family of proteins and leads to the rapid induction of inflammatory gene products , including tissue factor ( TF ) .
2,4 G#cell_type|12,14 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

TF is the primary cellular initiator of the coagulation protease cascades .
0,1 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Here we report the characterization of a nuclear complex from human monocytic cells that bound to a kappa B-like site , 5'-CGGAGTTTCC-3' , in the 5'-flanking region of the human TF gene .
7,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|17,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein|29,32 G#DNA

This nuclear complex was activated by LPS with kinetics that preceded induction of the TF gene .
1,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA

In vitro binding studies demonstrated that the TF site bound translated c- Rel and p65 homodimers but not p50/p65 heterodimers or p50 homodimers .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|11,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

Base-pair substitutions in the TF site indicated that the presence of a cytosine at position 1 precluded binding of NF-kappa B .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

In fact , under low-ionic-strength conditions , the TF complex did not migrate with translated p50/p65 dimers but instead comigrated with c-Rel /p65 dimers .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Antibodies against the NF-kappa B and Rel proteins and UV cross-linking studies revealed the presence of c-Rel and p65 and the absence of p50 in the TF complex and further showed that c-Rel/ p65 heterodimers selectively bound to the TF kappa B-like site .
3,5 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|32,35 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|39,43 G#DNA

Functional studies indicated that the TF site conferred LPS inducibility on a heterologous promoter and was transactivated by c-Rel or p65 .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Taken together , our results demonstrated that binding of c-Rel/ p65 heterodimers to a novel kappa B-like site mediated LPS induction of TF gene expression in monocytic cells .
10,11 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type

Inhibition of T cell activation by the extracellular matrix protein tenascin .
7,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Tenascin ( TN ) is an extracellular matrix protein that is expressed widely in the fetus and sparingly in the adult , but reappears at high levels in certain areas of tissue insult such as tumor matrices and sites of wound healing .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|6,9 G#protein

We show here that soluble TN inhibits proliferation of human T cells in response to alpha CD3 Ab co- immobilized with the extracellular matrix protein fibronectin ( FN ) .
5,6 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

TN also inhibits proliferation driven by alpha CD3 /IL-2 or by phorbol ester/IL-2 , and it prevents high level induction of IL-2R .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The presence of TN in culture medium does not detectably alter the pattern of tyrosine phosphorylation resulting from T cell triggering with alpha CD3 , but at later time points prevents the appearance of functional NF-AT1 transcription factor complexes in T cell nuclear extracts .
3,4 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|35,39 G#protein|40,44 G#protein

These findings are consistent with the postulated role for TN as a natural antagonist to FN action , and suggest that T cell responses occurring at tissue sites in which TN is expressed could be influenced by its presence .
9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 Nef protein down-regulates transcription factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 in human T cells in vitro after T-cell receptor stimulation .
0,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type

Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) negative factor ( Nef ) has been shown to down-regulate the transcription factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 in vitro .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

To define the mechanism of action of the Nef protein , the signal transduction pathways which may be affected in T cells by constitutive expression of the nef gene were examined .
8,9 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

Stimulation of T cells with tumor necrosis factor , interleukin-1 , or lipopolysaccharide resulted in the recruitment of transcriptional factors to a similar level whether or not the cells expressed the nef gene .
2,4 G#cell_type

On the other hand , stimulation of T cells by mitogens or antibodies to the T-cell receptor ( TCR ) - CD3 complex resulted in the down-regulation of transcriptional factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 in cells expressing the nef gene compared with cells not expressing the nef gene .
7,9 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Because the Nef protein does not affect the surface expression of the CD3 -TCR complex , we conclude that the Nef protein down-regulates the transcriptional factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 in T cells in vitro through an effect on the TCR-dependent signal transduction pathway .
2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

Effects of alpha-lipoic acid and dihydrolipoic acid on expression of proto-oncogene c-fos .
10,12 G#DNA

The transcription factor AP-1 is an important human mediator of the cellular response to serum , growth factors , and phorbol esters such as 12-O-tetradecanoyl-phorbol-13 acetate ( TPA ) .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

The AP-1 complex consists of distinct protein heterodimers encoded by the proto-oncogene c-fos and c-jun mRNA whose gene expression can be induced by TPA , cyclic AMP and growth factors .
1,2 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|14,16 G#RNA|28,30 G#protein

Recent findings suggest an involvement of reactive oxygen species in the pathway of TPA and protein kinase C leading to expression of c-fos and c-jun mRNA .
15,18 G#protein|22,26 G#RNA

To investigate the role of reactive oxygen species we studied the effects of alpha-lipoic acid and dihydrolipoic acid ( natural thiol antioxidants ) on the expression of c-fos mRNA in human Jurkat T cells .
27,29 G#RNA|30,34 G#cell_line

When cells were preincubated with dihydrolipoic acid ( 0.2 mM ) the expression of c-fos mRNA was suppressed at 30 min after stimulation of TPA ( 0.5 microM ) whereas in the case of preincubation of alpha-lipoic acid ( 0.2 microM ) , the expression was enhanced at 30 min .
14,15 G#DNA|14,16 G#RNA

These studies support the idea that superoxide anion radical plays a role in the expression of c-fos mRNA .
16,17 G#DNA|16,18 G#RNA

Appraisal of potential therapeutic index of antioxidants on the basis of their in vitro effects on HIV replication in monocytes and interleukin 2 -induced lymphocyte proliferation .
19,20 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein

Antioxidant molecules have been suggested to be of therapeutic value in the treatment of HIV -infected patients .


To evaluate this possibility , we examined in vitro the effects of two types of antioxidant molecules in terms of inhibition of HIV replication in monocytes , one of the main reservoirs of HIV , and also in terms of modulation of the immune competence as measured by PBMC proliferation .
25,26 G#cell_type|48,49 G#cell_type

We tested the effects of BHA , a phenolic , lipid-soluble , chain-breaking antioxidant , and NAC , a known glutathione precursor with some direct free-radical scavenging properties as well , on the regulation of HIV -1 expression in latently infected U1 cells and in productively and chronically infected U937 cells .
41,43 G#cell_line|49,51 G#cell_line

Both antioxidants inhibited TNF - or PMA- induced NF-kappa B activity in U1 cells , as well as the sustained NF-kappa B activity permanently induced by the virus itself in chronically HIV -infected U937 cells .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|20,22 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_line

This resulted in only a partial inhibition of TNF - or PMA- induced HIV replication in U1 cells , and no detectable effect on HIV replication in chronically infected U937 cells .
8,9 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_line|29,31 G#cell_line|27,31 G#cell_line

This may be the first limitation to potential antiviral effects of antioxidant therapies .


Another limitation is that antioxidant concentrations high enough to block NK-kappa B activation were shown to have a suppressive effect on immune functions in vitro , because NAC and BHA blocked IL-2 -induced PBMC proliferation .
10,12 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|31,34 G#cell_type

These data warrant prudence in the design of antioxidant-based therapies aimed at suppressing HIV replication .


Isolation and characterization of gelatinase granules from human neutrophils .
7,9 G#cell_type

We recently confirmed the existence of gelatinase granules as a subpopulation of peroxidase-negative granules by double-labeling immunogold electron microscopy on intact cells and by subcellular fractionation .


Further characterization of gelatinase granules has been hampered by poor separation of specific and gelatinase granules on both two-layer Percoll gradients and sucrose gradients .


We have developed a three-layer Percoll density gradient that allows separation of the different granules and vesicles from human neutrophils ; in particular , it allows separation of specific and gelatinase granules .
18,20 G#cell_type

This allows us to characterize these two granule populations with regard to their content of membrane proteins , which become incorporated into the plasma membrane during exocytosis .
15,17 G#protein

We found that gelatinase granules , defined as peroxidase-negative granules containing gelatinase but lacking lactoferrin , contain 50 % of total cell gelatinase , with the remaining residing in specific granules .
11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Furthermore , we found that 20 % to 25 % of both the adhesion protein Mac-1 and the NADPH-oxidase component cytochrome b558 is localized in gelatinase granules .
15,16 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Although no qualitative difference was observed between specific granules and gelatinase granules with respect to cytochrome b558 and Mac-1 , stimulation of the neutrophil with FMLP resulted in a selective mobilization of the least dense peroxidase-negative granules , ie , gelatinase granules , which , in concert with secretory vesicles , furnish the plasma membrane with Mac-1 and cytochrome b558 .
10,11 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|56,57 G#protein|58,60 G#protein

This shows that gelatinase granules are functionally important relative to specific granules in mediating early inflammatory responses .
3,4 G#protein

Regulation of interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain expression and nuclear factor.kappa B activation by protein kinase C in T lymphocytes .
2,6 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type

Autocrine role of tumor necrosis factor alpha .
3,7 G#protein

The regulation of interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain ( IL-2R alpha ) expression and nuclear factor ( NF ) activation by protein kinase C ( PKC ) in resting T cells , has been studied .
3,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,30 G#cell_type

Treatment of human resting T cells with phorbol esters strongly induced the expression of IL-2R alpha and the activation of NF.kappa B .
3,6 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

This activation was due to the translocation of p65 and c-Rel NF.kappa B proteins from cytoplasmic stores to the nucleus , where they bound the kappa B sequence of the IL-2R alpha promoter either as p50.p65 or as p50. c-Rel heterodimers .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA|30,33 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

Interestingly , all of those events were largely indirect and mediated by endogenously secreted tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF alpha ) , as they were strongly inhibited by a neutralizing anti- TNF alpha monoclonal antibody .
14,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|30,36 G#protein

Furthermore , cyclosporin A , which blocked TNF alpha production induced by PKC , strongly inhibited IL-2R alpha and NF.kappa B activation .
7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

The addition of either TNF alpha or IL-2 partially recovered cyclosporin A -induced IL-2R alpha inhibition , but only TNF alpha completely recovered NF.kappa B activation .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Those results indicate that , in resting T cells , PKC activation has only a triggering role , whereas the endogenously secreted TNF alpha plays an essential role in the quantitative control of the expression of IL-2R alpha chain or NF.kappa B activation .
6,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|40,42 G#protein

Superantigens activate HIV-1 gene expression in monocytic cells .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

Binding of superantigens to MHC class II molecules results in transduction of biochemical signals leading to cellular activation and gene expression .
4,8 G#protein

We demonstrate that the staphylococcal superantigens toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 ( TSST-1 ) and staphylococcal enterotoxin A ( SEA ) activate HIV-1 -LTR -driven transcription of chloramphenicol acetyl transferase in the human monocytic cell line THP-1 .
4,6 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA|26,29 G#protein|31,35 G#cell_line|35,36 G#cell_line

Induction of HIV-1 - LTR -driven transcription in THP-1 cells by superantigens was associated with the induction of nuclear factor-kappa B DNA-binding activity .
4,5 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Superantigens also increased viral protein secretion from the granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor -pretreated chronically infected human monocytic cell line U1 .
0,1 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|8,19 G#cell_line

Induction of HIV-1 gene expression in monocytic cells by superantigens occurred via tumor necrosis factor-alpha -dependent and -independent mechanisms .
6,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein

Our results suggest that superantigens and other MHC class II ligands may activate HIV-1 gene expression in monocytes/macrophages .
4,5 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

Mitogen activation of human peripheral T lymphocytes induces the formation of new cyclic AMP response element-binding protein nuclear complexes .
5,7 G#cell_type|3,7 G#cell_type|12,19 G#protein

A large body of evidence indicates that experimental agents which raise cellular cAMP levels inhibit T cell growth and division .


By contrast , many studies have reported that mitogen activation of T cells increases cAMP levels , implying a positive physiological role for cAMP in the activation process .
8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

In the present study we demonstrate that mitogen activation of human peripheral T lymphocytes induces nuclear factors that form complexes with cyclic AMP response element-binding protein ( CREB ) .
7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|10,14 G#cell_type|21,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Four complexes are identified by the electrophoretic mobility shift assay , two of which are induced by mitogen activation .
17,18 G#protein

All four complexes contain CREB and are bound to the cAMP response element ( CRE ) core sequence ( TGACGTCA ) , as indicated by antibody and oligonucleotide competition experiments .
4,5 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|10,18 G#DNA

Binding of the four complexes to CRE is prevented by dephosphorylation of nuclear extracts and is restored by rephosphorylation with cAMP -dependent protein kinase or endogenous kinases .
6,7 G#DNA|20,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Similar complexes are detected in nuclear extracts of Jurkat cells .
8,10 G#cell_line

Mitogen induction of the electrophoretic mobility shift assay complexes is not accounted for by protein phosphorylation or by induction of CREB .
4,9 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Rather , the data indicate that mitogen increases the levels of a nuclear factor ( s ) that dimerizes with CREB .
20,21 G#protein

Induction of new CREB complexes implies a physiological role for cAMP in mitogen activation of T lymphocytes .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

Alpha-tocopherol inhibits agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion to cultured human endothelial cells .
7,11 G#cell_line

Antioxidants have been proposed to be anti-atherosclerotic agents ; however , the mechanisms underlying their beneficial effects are poorly understood .


We have examined the effect of alpha-tocopherol ( alpha-tcp ) on one cellular event in atherosclerotic plaque development , monocyte adhesion to stimulated endothelial cells ( ECs ) .
22,25 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type

Human umbilical vein ECs were pretreated with alpha-tcp before stimulation with known agonists of monocyte adhesion : IL-1 ( 10 ng/ml ) , LPS ( 10 ng/ml ) , thrombin ( 30 U/ml ) , or PMA ( 10 nM ) .
3,4 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion , but not basal adhesion , was inhibited in a time- and concentration-dependent manner by alpha-tcp .


The IC50 of alpha-tcp on an IL-1 -induced response was 45 microM .
6,7 G#protein

The inhibition correlated with a decrease in steady state levels of E-selectin mRNA and cell surface expression of E-selectin which is consistent with the ability of a monoclonal antibody to E-selectin to inhibit monocytic cell adhesion in this system .
11,13 G#RNA|18,19 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Probucol ( 50 microM ) and N-acetylcysteine ( 20 mM ) also inhibited agonist-induced monocytic cell adhesion ; whereas , several other antioxidants had no significant effect .


Protein kinase C ( PKC ) does not appear to play a role in the alpha-tcp effect since no suppression of phosphorylation of PKC substrates was observed .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Activation of the transcription factor NF-kappa B is reported to be necessary but not sufficient for E-selectin expression in EC .
3,5 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_line

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays failed to show an alpha-tcp -induced decrease in activation of this transcription factor after cytokine stimulation .
15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

It has been hypothesized that alpha-tcp acts as an anti-atherosclerotic molecule by inhibiting generation of oxidized LDL -- a putative triggering molecule in the atherosclerotic process .


Our results point to a novel alternative mechanism of action of alpha-tcp .


Central nervous system -derived cells express a kappa B-binding activity that enhances human immunodeficiency virus type 1 transcription in vitro and facilitates TAR -independent transactivation by Tat .
0,5 G#cell_type|22,23 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein

The Tat protein of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) is a potent activator of long terminal repeat -directed transcription .
1,3 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

While in most cell types , activation requires interaction of Tat with the unusual transcription element TAR , astrocytic glial cells support TAR -independent transactivation of HIV-1 transcription by Tat .
14,16 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|18,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#DNA

This alternative pathway of Tat activation is mediated by the viral enhancer , a kappa B domain capable of binding the prototypical form of the transcription factor nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) present in many cell types , including T lymphocytes .
4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|42,44 G#cell_type

Tat transactivation mediated by the kappa B domain is sufficient to allow replication of TAR -deleted mutant HIV-1 in astrocytes .
0,1 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|19,20 G#cell_type

The present study demonstrates the existence of kappa B-specific binding factors present in human glial astrocytes that differ from prototypical NF-kappa B .
7,11 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_type|20,22 G#protein

The novel astrocyte-derived kappa B-binding activity is retained on an HIV-1 Tat affinity column , while prototypical NF-kappa B from Jurkat T cells is not .
11,12 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,23 G#cell_line

In vitro transcription studies demonstrate that astrocyte-derived kappa B-binding factors activate transcription of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat and that this activation is dependent on the kappa B domain .
6,10 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA

Moreover , TAR -independent transactivation of HIV-1 transcription is reproduced in vitro in an astrocyte factor-dependent manner which correlates with kappa B-binding activity .
2,3 G#DNA

The importance of the central nervous system -enriched kappa B transcription factor in the regulation of HIV-1 expression is discussed .
4,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Human interleukin-13 activates the interleukin-4-dependent transcription factor NF-IL4 sharing a DNA binding motif with an interferon-gamma-induced nuclear binding factor .
0,2 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

The effects of interleukin-13 ( IL-13 ) and interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) on cellular functions were shown to be quite similar .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

We provide evidence that in monocytes as well as in T lymphocytes both IL-4 and IL-13 activate the same recently identified transcription factor NF-IL4 which binds to the specific responsive element IL-4RE .
10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,32 G#DNA

In addition , we show that a nuclear factor activated by interferon-gamma also interacts with the IL-4RE .
7,9 G#protein|16,17 G#DNA

It differs from NF-IL4 in the electrophoretic mobility of the complex with DNA , in its DNA-binding specificity and in the proteins interacting with the DNA sequence .
3,4 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA

Sensitivity against various enzyme inhibitors suggests that components of the signal transduction pathway are shared by all three cytokines .
18,19 G#protein

Encephalomyocarditis virus internal ribosomal entry site RNA-protein interactions .


Translational initiation of encephalomyocarditis virus ( EMCV ) mRNA occurs by ribosomal entry into the 5' nontranslated region of the EMCV mRNA , rather than by ribosomal scanning .
3,9 G#RNA|15,18 G#DNA|20,22 G#RNA

Internal ribosomal binding requires a cis-acting element termed the internal ribosomal entry site ( IRES ) .
5,7 G#DNA|9,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA

IRES elements have been proposed to be involved in the translation of picornavirus mRNAs and some cellular mRNAs .
0,1 G#DNA|0,2 G#DNA|12,14 G#RNA|16,18 G#RNA

Internal ribosome binding likely requires the interaction of trans-acting factors that recognize both the mRNA and the ribosomal complex .
8,10 G#protein|14,15 G#RNA|17,19 G#protein

Five cellular proteins ( p52 , p57 , p70 , p72 , and p100 ) cross-link the EMCV IRES or fragments of the IRES .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA

For one of these proteins , p57 , binding to the IRES correlates with translation .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#DNA

Recently , p57 was identified to be very similar , if not identical , to polypyrimidine tract-binding protein .
2,3 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

On the basis of cross-linking results with 21 different EMCV IRES fragments and cytoplasmic HeLa extract or rabbit reticulocyte lysate as the source of polypeptides , consensus binding sites for p52 , p57 , p70 , and p100 are proposed .
10,11 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

It is suggested that each of these proteins recognizes primarily a structural feature of the RNA rather than a specific sequence .
15,16 G#RNA

A novel heterodimerization partner for thyroid hormone receptor .
2,4 G#protein|5,8 G#protein

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor .
0,3 G#protein

Retinoid-like receptors play a central role in hormonal responses by forming heterodimers with other nuclear hormone receptors .
0,2 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

In this study we have identified the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor ( PPAR ) as a new thyroid hormone receptor ( THR ) auxiliary nuclear protein , heterodimerizing with THR in solution .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|16,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Although these heterodimers do not recognize a classical thyroid hormone response element ( TRE ) characterized by direct repeat separated by four nucleotides ( DR+4 ) , PPAR behaves as a dominant negative regulator of thyroid hormone ( TH ) action .
2,3 G#protein|8,12 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

However , a TH -dependent positive effect is elicited by selective interaction of the THR beta- PPAR but not the THR alpha- PPAR heterodimer with a novel TRE ( DR+2 ) .
14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|27,28 G#DNA|29,30 G#DNA

The critical region of THR beta was mapped to 3 amino acids in the distal box of the DNA binding domain .
4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Hence , PPAR can positively or negatively influence TH action depending on TRE structure and THR isotype .
2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Comparison of retinoic acid and phorbol myristate acetate as inducers of monocytic differentiation .


Several human myeloid leukemia cell lines growing in vitro can be induced to differentiate to more mature monocyte/macrophage-like cells by treatment with protein kinase C -activating phorbol esters , such as PMA .
1,6 G#cell_line|17,19 G#cell_type|22,25 G#protein

In addition to PMA , cells of the THP-1 myeloid leukemia cell line acquire macrophage-like characteristics after treatment with all-trans retinoic acid ( RA ) .
8,13 G#cell_line

To analyze the signal transduction mechanisms induced by RA , we first compared the effects of PMA and RA on the expression of genes which are known to be regulated during monocytic differentiation .


Both RA and PMA effectively down-regulated c-myc expression , while c-myb expression decreased only after PMA treatment .
6,7 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA

Expression of the beta 2-integrin genes , CD11a and CD11b , was clearly increased after both of these treatments .
3,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA

Their effects on the src-family tyrosine kinase genes were different : hck expression was similarly induced by these agents but lyn expression was stronger and more rapid after RA treatment .
4,8 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA

RA also enhanced lyn mRNA production rapidly in HL-60 , indicating that the activation of lyn gene expression is common in monocytic and granulocytic maturation of myeloid leukemia cells .
3,5 G#RNA|8,9 G#cell_line|15,17 G#DNA|26,29 G#cell_type

To examine whether the AP-1 enhancer activity is involved in RA -induced monocytic differentiation , THP-1 cells were transiently transfected with a chloramphenicol acetyl transferase ( CAT ) -reporter gene containing 5 copies of the AP-1 binding sites .
4,6 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_line|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|22,30 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|35,38 G#DNA

In contrast to PMA , RA did not induce any CAT activity in these cells , thus suggesting that the RA -induced changes in the expression of those genes described above were not dependent on the AP-1 enhancer activity .
10,11 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|36,38 G#DNA

An active v-abl protein tyrosine kinase blocks immunoglobulin light-chain gene rearrangement .
2,6 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA

Lymphoid cells transformed by Abelson murine leukemia virus have provided one of the classic models for study of early B-cell development and immunoglobulin rearrangement .
0,2 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein

Most of these cells have rearranged their heavy-chain locus but not their light chain genes , suggesting that an active v-abl protein interferes with this differentiation step .
7,9 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein

To test this hypothesis , light-chain gene structure was examined in pre-B cells transformed by temperature-sensitive mutants of the Abelson virus and in derivatives that survive at the nonpermissive temperature because they express a human BCL-2 gene .
5,8 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_line|34,37 G#DNA

Our studies reveal that inactivation of the v-abl protein tyrosine kinase triggers high-frequency rearrangement of kappa and lambda light-chain genes .
7,9 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|15,20 G#DNA

These events are accompanied by marked increases in the expression of RAG-1 and RAG-2 RNAs .
11,12 G#RNA|13,15 G#RNA|11,15 G#RNA

These increases occur in the absence of protein synthesis but are dependent on inactivation of the v-abl protein tyrosine kinase .
16,18 G#protein|16,20 G#protein

As documented in the accompanying paper ( Klug et al. , this issue ) , an active v-abl protein also suppresses the activity of NF-kappa B /rel and expression controlled by the kappa intron enhancer .
17,19 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA

Together these data demonstrate that the v-abl protein specifically interferes with light-chain gene rearrangement by suppressing at least two pathways essential for this stage of B-cell differentiation and suggest that tyrosine phosphorylation is important in regulating RAG gene expression .
6,8 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|25,26 G#cell_type|36,38 G#DNA

Calcium signalling in T cells stimulated by a cyclophilin B-binding protein .
3,5 G#cell_type|8,11 G#protein

The immunosuppressant drug cyclosporin A blocks a calcium -dependent signal from the T-cell receptor ( TCR ) that normally leads to T-cell activation .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

When bound to cyclophilin , cyclosporin A binds and inactivates the key signalling intermediate calcineurin .
3,4 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

To identify potential cellular homologues of cyclosporin A that might regulate calcium signalling , we have cloned human genes encoding cyclophilin B-binding-proteins using the yeast two-hybrid system .
20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

One gene product , when overexpressed in Jurkat T cells , specifically induced transcription from the interleukin-2 enhancer , by activating the T-cell-specific transcription factors NF-AT and NF-IL2A .
7,10 G#cell_line|16,18 G#DNA|22,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

This protein , termed calcium -signal modulating cyclophilin ligand ( CAML ) , acts downstream of the TCR and upstream of calcineurin by causing an influx of calcium .
7,8 G#protein|4,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

CAML appears to be a new participant in the calcium -signal transduction pathway , implicating cyclophilin B in calcium signalling , even in the absence of cyclosporin .
0,1 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Expression and genomic configuration of GM-CSF , IL-3 , M-CSF receptor ( C-FMS ) , early growth response gene-1 ( EGR-1 ) and M-CSF genes in primary myelodysplastic syndromes .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA

Peripheral blood mononuclear cells from seventeen patients with primary myelodysplastic syndromes ( MDS ) in advanced stage were enriched for blasts and tested for ( 1 ) karyotype , ( 2 ) genomic configuration and ( 3 ) expression of IL-3 , GM-CSF , FMS and EGR-1 genes which are all located on the long arm of chromosome 5 .
20,21 G#cell_type|40,48 G#DNA|57,59 G#DNA|54,59 G#DNA

The expression of the M-CSF gene , that has been recently reassigned to the short arm of chromosome 1 ( lp ) , was also investigated .
4,6 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|14,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA

Aims of the study were to ( 1 ) assess the potential role of the expression of these genes in the maintenance and expansion of the neoplastic clones and ( 2 ) search for constitutional losses or rearrangements of one allele followed by a deletion of the second allele of the same genes in the leukemic cells .
26,28 G#cell_line|40,41 G#DNA|48,49 G#DNA|55,57 G#cell_type

The latter issue was investigated by comparing , in 8 cases , constitutive DNA from skin fibroblasts with leukemic DNA .
12,14 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#DNA

Eleven of the 17 patients had abnormal karyotypes .


The M-CSF gene was expressed in 6 cases and the FMS and the EGR-1 genes were expressed in 2 of the latter cases .
1,3 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA

An autocrine mechanism of growth could be hypothesized only for the 2 patients whose cells expressed both the M-CSF and FMS genes .
18,22 G#DNA

No germline changes or rearrangements were observed in any of the genes studied .


Thus , deregulation of genes encoding for certain hemopoietic growth factors or receptors does not seem to represent a major mechanism of MDS progression .
8,11 G#protein

A novel human homeobox gene distantly related to proboscipedia is expressed in lymphoid and pancreatic tissues .
2,5 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA

A novel human homeobox gene , HB9 , was isolated from a cDNA library prepared from in vitro stimulated human tonsil B lymphocytes and from a human genomic library .
2,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|17,23 G#cell_type|26,29 G#DNA

The HB9 gene is composed of 3 exons spread over 6 kilobases of DNA .
1,2 G#DNA|1,3 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA

An open reading frame of 1206 nucleotides is in frame with a diverged homeodomain .
1,4 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

The predicted HB9 protein has a molecular mass of 41 kilodaltons and is enriched for alanine , glycine , and leucine .
2,3 G#DNA|2,4 G#protein

The HB9 homeodomain is most similar to that of the Drosophila melanogaster homeobox gene proboscipedia .
1,2 G#DNA|1,3 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA

Northern blot analysis of poly(A) RNA purified from the human B cell line RPMI 8226 and from activated T cells revealed a major mRNA transcript of 2.2 kilobases .
4,6 G#RNA|9,15 G#cell_line|17,20 G#cell_type|22,25 G#RNA

Similar analysis of poly(A) RNA from a variety of adult tissues demonstrated HB9 transcripts in pancreas , small intestine , and colon .
3,5 G#RNA|12,13 G#DNA

Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction was used to examine HB9 RNA transcripts in hematopoietic cell lines .
8,9 G#DNA|8,11 G#RNA|12,15 G#cell_line

HB9 RNA transcripts were most prevalent in several human B cell lines and K562 cells .
0,1 G#DNA|0,3 G#RNA|8,12 G#cell_line|13,15 G#cell_line

In addition , transcripts were detected in RNA prepared from tonsil B cells and in situ hybridization studies localized them in the germinal center region of adult tonsil .
10,13 G#cell_type

These findings suggest the involvement of HB9 in regulating gene transcription in lymphoid and pancreatic tissues .
6,7 G#DNA

Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 Tat upregulates interleukin-2 secretion in activated T cells .
0,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

Dysregulation of cytokines secreted by T cells may play an important role in the pathogenesis of AIDS .
2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type

To investigate the effects of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) Tat on interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) expression , we used IL-2 promoter -chloramphenicol acetyltransferase constructs and IL-2 -secreting Jurkat T cells as a model system .
5,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|23,28 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|31,34 G#cell_line|29,34 G#cell_line

Transient expression of HIV-1 Tat induced a five- to eightfold increase in IL-2 promoter activity in Jurkat T cells stimulated with phytohemagglutinin and phorbol myristate acetate .
3,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|16,19 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

IL-2 secretion was increased more than twofold in both Jurkat T cells and primary T cells stimulated by extracellular HIV-1 Tat protein .
0,1 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_line|13,16 G#cell_line|19,21 G#protein|18,22 G#protein

Analysis of mRNA suggested that Tat exerts its effect on IL-2 primarily at the transcriptional level .
2,3 G#RNA|10,11 G#protein

The NF-kappa B site at positions -206 to -195 of the IL-2 promoter was required but not sufficient for the Tat effect .
1,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

The Tat -mediated increase in IL-2 promoter activity could selectively be blocked by antisense tat or - unlike the analogous effect of human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 Tax - by cyclosporin A .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|22,29 G#protein

The observed increase in IL-2 levels might facilitate virus spread from or to T cells .
4,5 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Furthermore , it might contribute to the hypergammaglobulinemia or , together with other cytokines found to be dysregulated , the T-helper cell dysfunctions observed in AIDS patients .
13,14 G#protein

Activation of nuclear factor kappa B in human lymphoblastoid cells by low-dose ionizing radiation .
2,6 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type

Nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) is a pleiotropic transcription factor which is involved in the transcriptional regulation of several specific genes .
0,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|10,13 G#protein

Recent reports demonstrated that ionizing radiation in the dose range of 2-50 Gy results in expression of NF-kappa B in human KG-1 myeloid leukemia cells and human B-lymphocyte precursor cells ; the precise mechanism involved and the significance are not yet known .
17,19 G#protein|20,25 G#cell_line|26,30 G#cell_type

The present report demonstrates that even lower doses of ionizing radiation , 0.25-2.0 Gy , are capable of inducing expression of NF-kappa B in EBV-transformed 244B human lymphoblastoid cells .
21,23 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_type|24,29 G#cell_line

These results are in a dose range where the viability of the cells remains very high .


After exposure to 137Cs gamma rays at a dose rate of 1.17 Gy/min , a maximum in expression of NF-kappa B was seen at 8 h after a 0.5-Gy exposure .
19,21 G#protein

Time-course studies revealed a biphasic time-dependent expression after 0.5- , 1- and 2-Gy exposures .


However , for each time examined , the expression of NF-kappa B was maximum after the 0.5-Gy exposure .
10,12 G#protein

The expression of the p50 and p65 NF-kappa B subunits was also shown to be regulated differentially after exposures to 1.0 and 2.0 Gy .
4,10 G#protein

Alternative splicing of RNA transcripts encoded by the murine p105 NF-kappa B gene generates I kappa B gamma isoforms with different inhibitory activities .
3,5 G#RNA|8,13 G#DNA|14,19 G#protein

The gene encoding the 105-kDa protein ( p105 ) precursor of the p50 subunit of transcription factor NF-kappa B also encodes a p70 I kappa B protein , I kappa B gamma , which is identical to the C-terminal 607 amino acids of p105 .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|4,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|22,27 G#protein|28,32 G#protein|38,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein

Here we show that alternative RNA splicing generates I kappa B gamma isoforms with properties different from those of p70 .
8,12 G#protein|8,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

One 63-kDa isoform , termed I kappa B gamma-1 , which lacks 59 amino acids C-terminal to ankyrin repeat 7 , has a novel 35-amino acid C terminus encoded by an alternative reading frame of the p105 gene .
1,3 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|24,28 G#protein|31,34 G#DNA|36,37 G#protein|36,38 G#DNA

A 55-kDa isoform , I kappa B gamma-2 , lacks the 190 C-terminal amino acids of p70 I kappa B gamma .
1,3 G#protein|4,8 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

In contrast to p70 I kappa B gamma , which is a cytoplasmic protein , I kappa B gamma-1 is found in both the cytoplasm and nucleus , whereas I kappa B gamma-2 is predominantly nuclear .
3,4 G#protein|4,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|29,33 G#protein

The I kappa B gamma isoforms also display differences in specificity and affinity for Rel/ NF-kappa B proteins .
1,5 G#protein|1,6 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|14,18 G#protein

While p70 I kappa B gamma inhibits p50- , p65- , and c-Rel- mediated transactivation and/or DNA binding , both I kappa B gamma-1 and I kappa B gamma-2 are specific for p50 and have different affinities for this subunit .
1,2 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|25,29 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

The absence in I kappa B gamma-1 and I kappa B gamma-2 of a protein kinase A site whose phosphorylation modulates p70 I kappa B gamma inhibitory activity suggests that alternative RNA splicing may be used to generate I kappa B gamma isoforms that respond differently to intracellular signals .
3,7 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|38,42 G#protein|38,43 G#protein

Structure and expression of the human GATA3 gene .
5,8 G#DNA

GATA3 , a member of the GATA family that is abundantly expressed in the T-lymphocyte lineage , is thought to participate in T-cell receptor gene activation through binding to enhancers .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein|29,30 G#DNA

To understand GATA3 gene regulation , we cloned the human gene and the 5' end of the mouse GATA3 gene .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

We show that the human GATA3 gene contains six exons distributed over 17 kb of DNA .
5,6 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA

The two human GATA3 zinc fingers are encoded by two separate exons highly conserved with those of GATA1 , but no other structural homologies between these two genes can be found .
3,4 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|11,12 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein

The human and mouse GATA3 transcription units start at a major initiation site .
1,7 G#DNA|10,13 G#DNA

The promoter sequence analysis of these two genes revealed that they are embedded within a CpG island and share structural features often found in the promoters of housekeeping genes .
15,17 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

Finally , we show that a DNA fragment containing the human GATA3 transcription unit , 3 kb upstream from the initiation site and 4 kb downstream from the polyadenylation site , displays T-cell specificity .
6,8 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|10,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA

Characterization of the human gene encoding LBR , an integral protein of the nuclear envelope inner membrane .
3,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

We have characterized the human gene encoding LBR , an integral protein of the nuclear envelope inner membrane .
4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Restriction mapping shows that the transcription unit spans approximately 35 kilobases .
5,7 G#DNA

A transcription start site is located approximately 4 kilobases 5' to the translation initiation codon , and an RNA splice of 3863 bases occurs in the 5'-untranslated region to generate mature HeLa cell mRNA .
12,15 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|31,33 G#cell_line|30,34 G#RNA

5' to the identified transcription start site are two CCAAT sequences and potential recognition sites for several transcription factors including Sp1 , AP-1 , AP-2 , and NF-kB .
4,7 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

There are 13 protein coding exons in the LBR gene .
5,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA

LBR 's nucleoplasmic domain is encoded by exons 1-4 , and its hydrophobic domain , with eight putative transmembrane segments , is encoded by exons 5-13 .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|12,14 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|24,25 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA

The hydrophobic domain is homologous to three yeast polypeptides , suggesting that this higher eukaryotic gene could have evolved from recombination between a gene that encoded a soluble nuclear protein and a membrane protein gene similar to those in yeast .
1,3 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|27,30 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA

These results are the first to demonstrate the structural organization of a vertebrate gene encoding an integral membrane protein of the nuclear envelope that may be a member of a family of polypeptides conserved in evolution .
12,14 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

Retinoic acid-induced expression of CD38 antigen in myeloid cells is mediated through retinoic acid receptor-alpha .
4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|12,15 G#protein

CD38 is a leukocyte differentiation antigen that has been thought to be a phenotypic marker of different subpopulations of T- and B- lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_type

In myeloid cells , CD38 is expressed during early stages of differentiation .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein

Virtually no information is available on regulation and functions of CD38 .
10,11 G#protein

Recently we reported that all-trans-retinoic acid ( ATRA ) is a potent and highly specific inducer of CD38 expression in human promyelocytic leukemia cells .
17,18 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_type

Here we report that ATRA -induced expression of CD38 antigen in myeloid cells is mediated through retinoic acid-alpha receptor ( RAR alpha ) .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|16,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

ATRA failed to induce CD38 expression in a mutant subclone of the HL-60 myeloid leukemia cell line ( designated HL-60R ) that is relatively resistant to ATRA -induced granulocytic differentiation .
4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_line|12,17 G#cell_line|19,20 G#cell_line

Retroviral vector-mediated transduction of RA receptor ( RAR alpha ) into this HL-60R subclone completely restored the sensitivity of these cells to ATRA in terms of their ability to express CD38 .
4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|30,31 G#protein

In contrast , CD38 expression was not inducible by ATRA in HL-60R cells , transfected with a functional RAR beta , RAR gamma , or RXR alpha receptor .
3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line|18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,28 G#protein

Induction of CD38 in acute promyelocytic and acute myeloblastic leukemia cells was independent of ATRA -induced cytodifferentiation .
2,3 G#protein|4,11 G#cell_type

Following culture with ATRA , increased CD38 protein levels were also observed in normal CD34+ bone marrow cells , but not on normal circulating granulocytes .
6,7 G#protein|13,18 G#cell_type|22,25 G#cell_type

From these results , we conclude that CD38 is ATRA inducible in myeloid leukemia cells and normal CD34+ bone marrow cells .
7,8 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type|16,21 G#cell_type

This effect is independent of differentiation and is mediated by RAR alpha in HL-60 cells , suggesting a similar role for RAR alpha in CD38 expression in other hematopoietic cells .
10,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

Some antioxidants inhibit , in a co-ordinate fashion , the production of tumor necrosis factor-alpha , IL-beta , and IL-6 by human peripheral blood mononuclear cells .
12,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_type

Some antioxidants , including butylated hydroxyanisole ( BHA ) , tetrahydropapaveroline ( THP ) , nordihydroguiauretic acid , and 10,11-dihydroxyaporphine ( DHA ) , were found to be potent inhibitors of the production of tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) -alpha , IL-1 beta , and IL-6 by human peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) stimulated by lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) ( IC50s in the low micromolar range ) .
34,41 G#protein|42,44 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|48,53 G#cell_type|54,55 G#cell_type

Inhibition of cytokine production was gene selective and not due to general effects on protein synthesis .
2,3 G#protein

Inhibition of cytokine production by PBMC was observed also when other inducers were used ( staphylococci , silica , zymosan ) .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type

Much higher concentrations of other antioxidants -- including ascorbic acid , trolox , alpha-tocopherol , butylated hydroxytoluene , and the 5-lipoxygenase inhibitor zileuton -- did not affect the production of these cytokines .
31,32 G#protein

The active compounds did not inhibit IL-1 -induced production of IL-6 in fibroblasts , showing the cell selectivity of the effect .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type

Antioxidant-mediated inhibition of cytokine production was correlated with low levels of the corresponding messenger RNAs .
3,4 G#protein|13,15 G#RNA

Nuclear run-on experiments showed that THP inhibited transcription of the IL-1 beta gene .
10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA

THP decreased the concentration of the transcription factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 detected in nuclear extracts of PBMC cultured in the presence or absence of LPS .
6,8 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

THP and DHA markedly decreased the levels of TNF-alpha and IL-1 beta in the circulation of mice following LPS injection .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Thus antioxidants vary widely in potency as inhibitors of the activation of transcription factors and of the transcription of genes for pro-inflammatory cytokines .
12,14 G#protein|19,20 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

Coordinate inhibition of the transcription of genes for inflammatory cytokines could provide a strategy for therapy of diseases with inflammatory pathogenesis and for septic shock .
9,10 G#protein

An interleukin-4-induced transcription factor : IL-4 Stat .
1,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

Interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) is an immunomodulatory cytokine secreted by activated T lymphocytes , basophils , and mast cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

It plays an important role in modulating the balance of T helper ( Th ) cell subsets , favoring expansion of the Th2 lineage relative to Th1 .
10,17 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type

Imbalance of these T lymphocyte subsets has been implicated in immunological diseases including allergy , inflammation , and autoimmune disease .
3,6 G#cell_type

IL-4 may mediate its biological effects , at least in part , by activating a tyrosine-phosphorylated DNA binding protein .
0,1 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

This protein has now been purified and its encoding gene cloned .


Examination of the primary amino acid sequence of this protein indicates that it is a member of the signal transducers and activators of transcription ( Stat ) family of DNA binding proteins , hereby designated IL-4 Stat .
3,7 G#protein|18,28 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

Study of the inhibitory activities of phosphotyrosine-containing peptides derived from the intracellular domain of the IL-4 receptor provided evidence for direct coupling of receptor and transcription factor during the IL-4 Stat activation cycle .
15,16 G#protein|11,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

Such observations indicate that IL-4 Stat has the same functional domain for both receptor coupling and dimerization .
4,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

Evaluation of the respiratory epithelium of normals and individuals with cystic fibrosis for the presence of adenovirus E1a sequences relevant to the use of E1a-Â adenovirus vectors for gene therapy for the respiratory manifestations of cystic fibrosis .
16,19 G#DNA

Lung disease associated with disorders such as cystic fibrosis ( CF ) may be amenable to somatic gene therapy in which there is delivery of the normal gene directly to the respiratory epithelium using E1a-Â adenovirus ( Ad ) type 2- or 5-based vectors .
26,28 G#DNA

For safety reasons , the Ad vectors are rendered replication deficient by deletion of the E1a region .
15,17 G#DNA

Because there is the theoretical possibility of an E1a-Â replication-deficient vector replicating as a result of recombination or complementation with Ad 2/5 E1a sequences present in the target cell , this study is directed toward evaluating respiratory epithelium of normals and individuals with CF for the presence of E1a sequences .
19,23 G#DNA

Using Ad 2/5 E1a-specific primers and the polymerase chain reaction to evaluate DNA recovered from freshly isolated nasal and bronchial epithelium recovered by brushing , E1a sequences were detected in respiratory epithelium of 19 of 91 normals ( 21 % ) .
1,5 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA

In the E1a-positive samples , the average of E1a copy number was 55 +/- 18/10(3) recovered cells .


In CF individuals , 7 of 52 ( 13 % ) had detectable E1a sequences in the respiratory epithelium , with E1a copy number in the positive samples of 80 +/- 21/10(3) recovered cells .
13,15 G#DNA

These results demonstrate that there are detectable Ad 2/5 E1a sequences in the respiratory epithelium of a small percentage of normals and individuals with CF .
9,11 G#DNA|7,11 G#DNA

Because of the theoretical potential of such sequences supporting replication of E1a- Ad vectors , human gene therapy protocols for CF utilizing such vectors should consider evaluating study individuals for the presence of Ad 2/5 E1a sequences in the respiratory epithelium .
35,37 G#DNA|33,37 G#DNA

Leiomyosarcoma of the vulva : report of a case .


A 52-year-old female presented with a progressively enlarging vulvar mass .


Pathological evaluation revealed a high-grade vulvar leiomyosarcoma .


Immunohistochemical and ultrastructural studies were performed to support the diagnosis .


In an effort to better understand the biology of this tumor additional immunohistochemical studies for the protein product of p53 tumor suppressor gene and estrogen receptor expression by tumor cells , as well as the type of immune cells infiltrating the tumor were performed .
16,18 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|37,39 G#cell_type

Tumor cells showed an overexpression of p53 protein and were estrogen receptor -positive .
0,2 G#cell_type|6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Macrophages and T and B lymphocytes infiltrated the tumor in moderate numbers with occasional lymphoid aggregate formation .
0,1 G#cell_type|2,6 G#cell_type

This study is the first attempt to better understand the biology of these tumors .


Stimulation of HIV replication in mononuclear phagocytes by leukemia inhibitory factor .
5,7 G#cell_type|8,11 G#protein

This study examined the effects of leukemia inhibitory factor ( LIF ) on human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) replication in mononuclear phagocytes ( MNP ) .
6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|24,25 G#cell_type

LIF induced a dose-dependent increase in p24 antigen production in the chronically infected promonocytic cell line U1 .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,17 G#cell_line

The magnitude and time kinetics of the LIF effects were similar to interleukin 1 ( IL-1 ) , IL-6 , and tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) , other cytokines known to induce HIV replication in this cell line .
7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

To characterize mechanisms responsible for these LIF effects , levels of HIV mRNA , activation of the DNA binding protein nuclear factor ( NF ) -kB , signal transduction pathways , and potential interactions with other cytokines were analyzed .
6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#RNA|17,22 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

LIF increased steady-state levels of HIV mRNA at 2.0 , 4.3 , and 9.2 kB .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA

This was detectable by 24 h and persisted until 72 h .


The DNA binding protein NF-kB is a central mediator in cytokine activation of HIV transcription .
1,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

NF-kB levels were higher in unstimulated U1 cells as compared to the parent cell line U937 .
0,1 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_line|12,15 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line

In both cell lines LIF increased NF-kB activity .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Induction of NF-kB and HIV replication by cytokines are at least in part dependent on reactive oxygen intermediates .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

The oxygen radical scavenger N-acetyl-L-cysteine , but not an inhibitor of nitric oxide synthase , inhibited LIF -induced HIV replication .
11,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

LIF induces the production of other cytokines in monocytes but its effects on HIV replication were not inhibited by antibodies to IL-1 , TNF , or IL-6 .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

These results identify LIF as a stimulus of HIV replication .

Mechanisms involved in the inhibition of growth of a human B lymphoma cell line , B104 , by anti-MHC class II antibodies .
9,14 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line|18,22 G#protein

The mechanisms involved in the inhibition of growth of a human B lymphoma cell line , B104 , by anti-MHC class II antibodies ( Ab ) were compared with those in anti-IgM Ab -induced B104 growth inhibition .
10,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line|19,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

Two anti-MHC class II Ab , L227 and 2.06 , inhibited the growth of B104 cells , although 2.06 , but not L227 , needed to be further cross-linked with a goat anti-mouse IgG Ab ( GAM ) to show the effect .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|31,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

L227 induced an increase in intracellular free Ca2+ concentration ( [ Ca2+ ]i ) from the intracellular pool and little or no protein tyrosine phosphorylation , phosphatidyl inositol turnover , or expression of Egr-1 mRNA , whereas 2.06 plus GAM induced an increase in [ Ca2+ ]i from both the intracellular and , in particular , the extracellular pools .
0,1 G#protein|33,35 G#RNA|37,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

The inhibition of B104 cell growth induced by anti-MHC class II Ab was Ca(2+) -independent and not inhibited by actinomycin D or cyclosporin A , and cell cycle arrest at the G2/M interphase was not observed .
3,5 G#cell_line|8,12 G#protein

These features are very different from those observed in B104 cell death induced by anti-IgM Ab .
9,11 G#cell_line|14,16 G#protein

Neither DNA fragmentation nor the morphology of apoptosis was observed .


These findings demonstrate that cross-linking of MHC class II molecules transduced the negative signals through intracellular mechanisms different from those present in the cross-linking of surface IgM .
6,10 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Functional block for 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 -mediated gene regulation in human B lymphocytes .
10,13 G#cell_type

Elements necessary for the steroid hormone 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( 1 alpha,25-(OH)2D3 ) to induce a biological response include the presence of specific intracellular receptors ( vitamin D3 receptors ( VDR ) ) and modulation of gene expression via hormone-activated receptor binding to regulatory regions of target genes .
23,25 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|43,45 G#protein|46,48 G#DNA

These parameters were examined in normal and Epstein-Barr virus-immortalized human B cells and compared with 1 alpha,25-(OH)2D3 -responsive cells of the T and monocytic lineages .
7,12 G#cell_line|15,19 G#cell_line|21,25 G#cell_type

Although resting tonsillar B cells did not express VDR mRNA , activation of these cells with interleukin-4 induced VDR in the absence of exogenously supplemented 1 alpha,25-(OH)2D3 .
8,10 G#RNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

As indicators of hormone-mediated gene regulation we analyzed modulation of CD23 , a common B cell/monocyte surface antigen , and 24-hydroxylase .
10,11 G#protein|13,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

1 alpha,25-(OH)2D3 inhibited CD23 expression in U937 cells , yet failed to modulate CD23 expression in B cells .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

5,6 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_line|16,19 G#cell_type|24,26 G#RNA|31,33 G#cell_type

These findings suggest that although human B lymphocytes can express VDR mRNA and protein , they exhibit a functional block for vitamin D -dependent gene regulation .
