Positive and negative regulation of IL-2 gene expression : role of multiple regulatory sites .
5,6 G#protein

Interleukin 2 ( IL-2 ) is an important lymphokine required in the process of T cell activation , proliferation , clonal expansion and differentiation .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

The IL-2 gene displays both T cell specific and inducible expression : it is only expressed in CD4+ T cells after antigenic or mitogenic stimulation .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|17,20 G#cell_type

Several cis-acting regulatory sites are required for induction of the IL-2 gene after stimulation .
1,4 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

In this study , we have analysed the function of these cis-acting regulatory sites in the context of the native IL-2 enhancer and promoter sequence .
11,14 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA

The results of this study suggest that the NFAT ( -276 to -261 ) , the distal octamer ( -256 to -248 ) and the proximal octamer ( -75 to -66 ) sites not only act as enhancers of IL-2 gene transcription in the presence of cellular stimulation , but also have a silencing effect on IL-2 gene expression in resting cells .
8,9 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA|28,31 G#DNA|39,40 G#protein|39,41 G#DNA|56,57 G#protein|56,58 G#DNA

Two other sites display disparate effects on IL-2 gene expression in different T leukemia cell lines : the distal purine box ( -291 to -277 ) and the proximal purine box sites ( -145 to -128 ) .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|12,16 G#cell_line|18,21 G#DNA|22,25 G#DNA|28,32 G#DNA|33,36 G#DNA

Finally , the AP-1 ( -186 to -176 ) and the kappa B sites ( -206 to -195 ) respond to different cellular activation in EL4 cells .
3,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|25,27 G#cell_line

The AP-1 site mediated the response to PMA stimulation while the kappa B site responded to IL-1 stimulation .
1,3 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

These data suggest that the regulation of IL-2 gene expression is a complex process and multiple cis-acting regulatory sites interact to exert different effects in T cells representative of alternative stages of differentiation .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA|25,27 G#cell_type

Sp1 is a critical factor for the monocytic specific expression of human CD14 .
0,1 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

CD14 is a membrane glycoprotein expressed specifically on monocytes and macrophages , and its expression is markedly increased during the process of monocyte differentiation .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type

In order to study CD14 gene regulation , the human CD14 gene was cloned from a partial EcoRI digested chromosome 5 library .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|17,22 G#DNA

A 5.5-kilobase genomic clone contained the full-length CD14 coding sequence and 4.2 kilobases of 5'-upstream sequence .
1,4 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|11,16 G#DNA

One major and one minor transcription start site were identified 101 and 130 base pairs ( bp ) upstream , respectively , from the protein translation start ATG .
1,8 G#DNA|10,19 G#DNA|24,28 G#DNA

A DNA fragment containing 128 bp of upstream sequence had strong , monocyte-specific promoter activity in the CD14 positive monocytic cell line Mono Mac 6 as compared to the nonmonocytic cell lines HeLa and REX .
1,3 G#DNA|4,9 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,22 G#cell_line|22,25 G#cell_line|29,32 G#cell_line|32,33 G#cell_line|34,35 G#cell_line

Four regions in this DNA fragment interact with nuclear proteins isolated from monocytic cells .
4,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

The Sp1 transcription factor bound to three different regions in the CD14 promoter .
1,2 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA

Mutation of the major Sp1 binding site ( -110 bp ) decreased tissue-specific promoter activity , and these results , together with transactivation experiments , demonstrate that Sp1 plays a critical role in the tissue-specific expression of CD14 in monocytic cells .
4,5 G#protein|3,7 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,41 G#cell_type

CD14 Sp1 site oligonucleotides bound preferentially to a 105-kDa Sp1 species , which is present in higher relative levels in monocytic than non-monocytic cells , suggesting that modification of Sp1 , such as phosphorylation , may explain how the Sp1 site mediates monocytic specific promoter activity .
0,1 G#protein|1,2 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

The interleukin-8 AP-1 and kappa B-like sites are genetic end targets of FK506-sensitive pathway accompanied by calcium mobilization .
1,7 G#DNA

FK506 , an immunosuppressant , inhibits the production of several cytokines in T lymphocytes .
10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

We observed that FK506 suppressed the transcription of a chemotactic cytokine , interleukin-8 ( IL-8 ) in a human T cell line , Jurkat cells , activated by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) and calcium ( Ca2+ ) ionophore ( ionomycin ) .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_line|23,25 G#cell_line

By deleted and mutated analysis of the IL-8 promoters , the AP-1 and kappa B-like sites were identified as the responsive elements for PMA and ionomycin .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|11,16 G#DNA

FK506 suppressed the transcriptions through the AP-1 or kappa B-like sites induced by PMA plus Ca(2+)-mobilizing agents , but not those induced by Ca(2+)-independent stimuli .
6,7 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA

In gel retardation analysis , FK506 had little effect on the binding to the AP-1 site of PMA / ionomycin -induced nuclear factors , which were recognized with anti-JunD or c-Fos antibody .
14,16 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

In contrast , FK506 or EGTA ( Ca2+ chelator ) similarly affected the formation of kappa B-like site binding complexes , which were not recognized by any antibodies against the human Rel family proteins ( c-Rel , p65 , p50 , and p49 ) .
15,20 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

Furthermore , we confirmed the previous report that FK506 suppressed the PMA / ionomycin -induced activation through authentic kappa B site of immunoglobulin ( Ig ) gene , to which NF-kappa B binding was also decreased by FK506 , indicating that both IL-8 kappa B-like site and Ig kappa B site are FK506 -sensitive in spite of the difference of binding factors .
18,21 G#DNA|22,27 G#DNA|30,32 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|42,46 G#DNA|48,51 G#DNA|60,62 G#protein

Our results indicate that not only the reported IL-2 NF-AT and NFIL-2A sites and Ig kappa B site , but also the IL-8 AP-1 and kappa B-like sites are terminals of FK506 -sensitive pathway involving Ca2+ mobilization .
8,13 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|23,24 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA

Androgen binding sites in peripheral human mononuclear leukocytes of healthy males and females .
0,3 G#protein|4,8 G#cell_type

Androgen binding sites have been identified in circulating human mononuclear leukocytes of healthy donors of both sexes .
0,3 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_type

Cells were separated from blood samples on a Ficoll gradient and incubated with different concentrations of [3H]testosterone in the presence or absence of a 400-fold excess of unlabelled testosterone .


Binding data were derived from Scatchard analysis .


The binding sites fulfil the required criteria for specific steroid binding sites however differ somewhat from the classic androgen receptors from genital skin fibroblast : in fertile adult males ( n = 20 ) the binding sites showed ( 1 ) a high affinity for testosterone ( 1.32 +/- 0.49 nM ; mean +/- SD ) , ( 2 ) a saturable capacity ( 184 +/- 52 binding sites per cell ; mean +/- SD ) , and ( 3 ) a characteristic competitive binding profile for other steroid hormones ( relative binding affinities : testosterone = dihydrotestosterone &gt; 17 beta-estradiol &gt; progesterone , whereas aldosterone , 17-hydroxy-progesterone and cortisol did not compete appreciably ) .
1,3 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type|35,37 G#protein|67,69 G#protein

Furthermore the number of binding sites determined using [3H]dihydrotestosterone , [3H]RU-1881 , or [3H] testosterone were comparable .
4,6 G#protein

This raises the possibility that androgen receptors in peripheral mononuclear leukocytes differ from those in genital skin fibroblasts .
5,7 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type

There was no apparent correlation between serum testosterone concentrations and androgen binding sites .
10,13 G#protein

In fertile women remarkable changes in androgen binding sites were seen in the course of the menstrual cycle , with a significant increase in the immediate preovulatory period .
6,9 G#protein

The presence of androgen receptors in peripheral mononuclear leukocytes provides for the first time the experimental basis for an hypothesis of direct , receptor-mediated effects of androgens on mature immunocompetent cells .
3,5 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_type|28,31 G#cell_type

The immunological implications of these results are discussed .


Induction of IL-8 expression in T cells uses the CD28 costimulatory pathway .
2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein

IL-8 , a potent chemotactic factor for neutrophil granulocytes and lymphocytes , is a proinflammatory cytokine secreted by a variety of cell types , including T cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|25,27 G#cell_type

Stimulation of the CD28 cell surface molecule delivers costimulatory signals essential for lymphokine production in activated T cells via a conserved sequence element found in the promoter of several lymphokine genes .
3,4 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|20,23 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA

Anti- CD28 -stimulated T cells produced significant amounts of IL-8 ; additionally , costimulation with anti-CD3 and anti- CD28 Abs resulted in a synergistic induction of IL-8 secretion .
1,2 G#protein|0,5 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Sequence homology , single nucleotide mutations , and anti- CD28 Ab stimulation studies established that the NF-kappa B -like sequence in the promoter of the IL-8 gene functioned as a CD28 response element .
9,10 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|16,20 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein|30,33 G#DNA

Furthermore , cyclosporin A , but not rapamycin , blocked the synergistic induction of IL-8 expression achieved with anti-CD3 and anti- CD28 costimulation .
14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The involvement of a CD28 response element in the induction of IL-8 expression in activated T cells may provide new insights into the pathogenesis and persistence of immune disorders characterized by increased levels of IL-8 , such as psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|34,35 G#protein

MHC class II signaling in B-cell activation [ see comments ]
0,3 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type

The cognate interaction between T cells and antigen-presenting cells ( APCs ) , mediated by major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class II molecules , results in the delivery of activation signals to the APC .
4,6 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|15,24 G#protein|34,35 G#cell_type

These signals contribute to the expression of co-stimulatory activity by APCs and have important consequences for cell effector function .
10,11 G#cell_type

MHC class II molecules also serve as receptors for B-cell stimulation by microbial superantigens .
0,3 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|12,14 G#protein

In this review , Paul Scholl and Raif Geha discuss recent advances in our understanding of mechanisms of MHC class II signaling and analyse their role in human B-cell activation .
18,21 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type

Effects of glucocorticoids in rheumatoid arthritis .


Diminished glucocorticoid receptors do not result in glucocorticoid resistance .
1,3 G#protein

OBJECTIVE .


Lymphocytes of patients with rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) have diminished receptor density ; thus , patients with RA should show partial resistance to glucocorticoids .


We investigated the glucocorticoid sensitivity of lymphocytes in RA patients compared with healthy subjects .
6,7 G#cell_type

METHODS .


We determined the effects of glucocorticoids on lymphocyte proliferation and cytokine release .
7,8 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein

RESULTS .


Proliferation and cytokine release were inhibited in RA patients to the same extent as in healthy controls .
2,3 G#protein

CONCLUSION .


Diminished receptor density in RA patients does not result in glucocorticoid resistance .


Arrested development : understanding v-abl .
4,5 G#DNA

The protein tyrosine kinase activity of the v-abl oncogene has been demonstrated to subvert the normal second messenger systems used by lymphoid cells for growth and differentiation .
1,4 G#protein|7,8 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|21,23 G#cell_type

Transformation of bone marrow with the Abelson murine leukemia virus results in the appearance of B cell lineage cells arrested at the pre-B cell stage .
15,19 G#cell_type

Recent reports have characterized these cells expressing high v-abl kinase activity as deficient in detectable NF-kappaB DNA binding activity and low level RAG gene expression .
8,9 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA

These observations suggest that v-abl may be inhibiting the differentiation of B cells by blocking these two crucial elements in the maturation pathway .
4,5 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_type

Corticosteroid receptors in lymphocytes : a possible marker of brain involution ?
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#cell_type

A similarity has recently been found between the regulation of corticosteroid receptors in brain and in lymphoid tissue .
10,12 G#protein

We have studied the regulation of corticosteroid receptors in human mononuclear leukocytes as a possible marker of brain involution .
6,8 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

Type I corticosteroid receptors are down regulated by excess of mineralocorticoids ( primary and secondary hyperaldosteronism , pseudohyperaldosteronism ) and of glucocorticoids ( Cushing 's syndrome ) . Type II corticosteroid receptors are not reduced by excess of endogenous corticosteroids ( Cushing 's syndrome ) .
2,4 G#protein|0,4 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|28,32 G#protein

In normal adults there is a direct significant correlation between plasma cortisol and Type I and between plasma cortisol and Type II receptors in mononuclear leukocytes , while in Cushing 's syndrome the correlation is inverse between plasma cortisol at 8 a.m. and Type II receptors .
13,15 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|43,46 G#protein

In an aged population the mean numbers of Type I and of Type II receptors are lower and plasma cortisol is higher than in adult controls , but the increase of plasma cortisol is not followed by a clinical picture of hypercorticism .
8,10 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

Corticosteroid Type I and Type II receptors are inversely correlated with age .
0,7 G#protein

After dexamethasone suppression ( 1 mg at 11 p.m. ) Type I receptors always decrease in controls while the response of Type II is not homogeneous .
10,13 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

In an aged group of patients , both receptors are reduced by dexamethasone .


We conclude that the decrease with age of corticosteroid receptors is possibly related to a physiological involution of corticosteroid receptors and that this reduction does increase plasma cortisol concentration , without affecting the glucocorticoid effector mechanism .
8,10 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

All-trans retinoic acid and 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 co-operate to promote differentiation of the human promyeloid leukemia cell line HL60 to monocytes .
13,18 G#cell_line|18,19 G#cell_line|20,21 G#cell_type

A basis for differentiation therapy of leukemias is provided by knowledge of agents which induce specific lineage maturation .


All-trans retinoic acid ( RA ) induces differentiation of HL60 cells to neutrophils and is used to treat acute promyelocytic leukemia .
9,11 G#cell_line|12,13 G#cell_type

We observed that RA did not induced neutrophil differentiation in serum-free grown HL60 cells whereas 50 nM 1 alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( D3 ) induced maximal monocyte differentiation .
12,14 G#cell_line|10,14 G#cell_line

Increasing RA concentrations reduced the D3 concentration required for monocyte differentiation .


Cells treated with 5 nM D3 showed little response , but differentiated maximally with 5 nM D3 and 10 nM RA .


The D3 analogs MC903 , EB1089 and KH1060 were more potent inducers of monocyte differentiation .


The extent to which analog activity was increased after cotreatment with RA was inversely related to potency .


Twenty-four hour treatment with 10 nM RA primed cells for response to 5 nM D3 ; the reverse sequence being ineffective .
6,9 G#cell_line

Priming with 10 nM RA , or subsequent treatment with D3 ( 5 nM ) , did not alter expression of mRNAs encoding receptors for D3 ( VDR ) , RA ( RAR alpha ) or 9-CIS RA ( RXR alpha , beta , gamma ) .
21,22 G#RNA|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|39,45 G#protein

That RA promotes both neutrophil and monocyte differentiation has implications for the use of RA and D3 in treatment of leukemias and provides insight into mechanisms whereby RAR , VDR and RXR facilitate monocyte differentiation .
29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

[ An overexpression of retinoic acid receptor alpha blocks myeloid cell differentiation at the promyelocyte stage ]
4,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Retinoic acid ( RA ) , a vitamin A derivative , exerts a wide range of biological effects related to cell proliferation and differentiation .


The pleiotropic effects of RA are thought to be mediated through specific nuclear RA receptors ( RARs ) .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

RARs are members of the steroid/thyroid hormone receptor superfamily and exhibit a molecular structure that possess discrete DNA-binding and RA ( ligand ) -binding domains .
0,1 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|19,25 G#protein

In hematopoietic system , RA and RARs , predominantly RAR alpha may play key roles for the proliferation and differentiation of hematopoietic progenitors .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

However , it is currently unknown how RA and RARs are involved in regulating normal hematopoietic differentiation .
9,10 G#protein

To make clear the roles of RA and RAR alpha in the normal hematopoiesis , I have introduced the construct of human RAR alpha ( hRAR alpha ) into murine bone marrow cells with retroviral vector , and selected infected cells with drug resistant marker ( Neo(r) ) cultured on the stroma cell line ( PA6-neo ) , and analyzed the behavior of infected cells .
8,10 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|29,33 G#cell_type|42,45 G#DNA|46,47 G#DNA|51,54 G#cell_line|55,56 G#cell_line|63,65 G#cell_type

All of procedure were done in vitro .


Most cells infected with hRAR alpha exhibited promyelocytic morphology and were thought to be blocked at the promyelocytic stage in their myeloid differentiation .
4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Furthermore , these immature cells differentiated terminally into mature granulocytes by adding with RA ( 10 ( -6 ) M ) .
3,5 G#cell_type

RAR alpha infected cells were also able to differentiate into mature macrophages in the both of long term culture and IL3 colony .
0,2 G#protein|2,4 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_line

These observations suggest that an overexpression of RAR alpha alone is effective to suppress myeloid cell differentiation and RAR alpha plays a crucial role in the terminal differentiation of myeloid precursors .
7,9 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein

The system described here may serve as a model for studying the the essential genes for differentiation of normal bone marrow cells .
13,15 G#DNA|18,22 G#cell_type

Hypoxic induction of interleukin-8 gene expression in human endothelial cells .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|7,10 G#cell_type

Because leukocyte-mediated tissue damage is an important component of the pathologic picture in ischemia/reperfusion , we have sought mechanisms by which PMNs are directed into hypoxic tissue .
21,22 G#cell_type

Incubation of human endothelial cells ( ECs ) in hypoxia , PO2 approximately 14-18 Torr , led to time-dependent release of IL-8 antigen into the conditioned medium ; this was accompanied by increased chemotactic activity for PMNs , blocked by antibody to IL-8 .
2,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|36,37 G#cell_type|42,43 G#protein

Production of IL-8 by hypoxic ECs occurred concomitantly with both increased levels of IL-8 mRNA , based on polymerase chain reaction analysis , and increased IL-8 transcription , based on nuclear run-on assays .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|13,15 G#RNA|25,26 G#protein

Northern analysis of mRNA from hypoxic ECs also demonstrated increased levels of mRNA for macrophage chemotactic protein-1 , another member of the chemokine superfamily of proinflammatory cytokines .
6,7 G#cell_type|12,13 G#RNA|14,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

IL-8 gene induction was associated with the presence of increased binding activity in nuclear extracts from hypoxic ECs for the NF-kB site .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#DNA|17,18 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type

Studies with human umbilical vein segments exposed to hypoxia also demonstrated increased elaboration of IL-8 antigen compared with normoxic controls .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

In mice exposed to hypoxia ( PO2 approximately 30-40 Torr ) , there was increased pulmonary leukostasis , as evidenced by increased myeloperoxidase activity in tissue homogenates .
22,23 G#protein

In parallel , increased levels of transcripts for IP-10 , a murine homologue in the chemokine family related to IL-8 , were observed in hypoxic lung tissue .
8,9 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Taken together , these data suggest that hypoxia constitutes a stimulus for leukocyte chemotaxis and tissue leukostasis .


Thrombin and thrombin receptor agonist peptide induce early events of T cell activation and synergize with TCR cross-linking for CD69 expression and interleukin 2 production .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Thrombin stimulation of the T leukemic cell line Jurkat induced a transient increase in [ Ca2+ ]i .
0,1 G#protein|4,9 G#cell_line

Proteolytic activity of the enzyme was required for this effect since diisopropyl fluorophosphate-thrombin failed to increase [ Ca2+ ]i .
4,5 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

Furthermore , hirudin and anti-thrombin III inhibited the thrombin-induced [ Ca2+ ]i rise in Jurkat T cells .
4,6 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_line

A synthetic thrombin receptor agonist peptide ( TRP ) of 7 residues ( SFLLRNP ) was found to be as effective as thrombin for [ Ca2+ ]i mobilization , and both agonists induced Ca2+ release exclusively from internal stores .
2,4 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Thrombin stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of several proteins of molecular mass 40 , 42 , 70 , 120 , and 130 kDa .
0,1 G#protein|8,21 G#protein

There was a good correlation between thrombin -induced tyrosine phosphorylation of the latter three proteins and Ca2+ mobilization .
6,7 G#protein

Thrombin and TRP also caused translocation of protein kinase C from the cytosol to the plasma membrane .
0,1 G#protein|7,10 G#protein

As a likely consequence of these events , thrombin activated the nuclear factor NF-kB .
8,9 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

Several cell lines of hematopoietic origin including the leukemic T cell line HPB.ALL and the erythroleukemic cell line K562 were responsive to thrombin , whereas others such as THP1 , a myelomonocytic cell line , and BL2 , a Burkitt lymphoma were refractory to thrombin or TRP stimulation .
8,13 G#cell_line|15,19 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_line|31,34 G#cell_line|36,38 G#cell_line|39,41 G#cell_line|44,45 G#protein

The magnitude of the thrombin response in the different cell types paralleled the expression of the thrombin receptor mRNA .
4,5 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|16,19 G#RNA

We found that activation of Jurkat T cells by a combination of phytohemagglutinin and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate led to a dramatic inhibition of thrombin receptor mRNA expression and to a concomitant loss of the thrombin response .
5,8 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|23,26 G#RNA|34,35 G#protein

Finally , we demonstrate that thrombin and TRP enhanced CD69 expression and interleukin 2 production induced by T cell receptor cross-linking in both Jurkat T cells and peripheral blood lymphocytes .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|23,26 G#cell_line|29,30 G#cell_type

These findings highlight the role of thrombin as a potential regulator of T lymphocyte activation .
6,7 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

Stress response of senescent T lymphocytes : reduced hsp70 is independent of the proliferative block .
3,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein

Senescent human T lymphocyte cultures are unable to undergo proliferation , but show no difference from early passage cells in cytotoxic function or surface antigenic profile .
0,5 G#cell_line|16,19 G#cell_line

A second feature of senescent T cells is the dramatic reduction in hsp70 production in response to heat shock .
4,7 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein

This decline is associated with a decrease in binding of nuclear extracts to the consensus heat shock element .
14,18 G#DNA

Interestingly , the progressive decline in the heat shock response of cultured T cells correlates with the percent proliferative life span completed rather than with the actual proliferative activity at the time of heat shock .
11,14 G#cell_line

This suggests that for senescent T cells the reduced ability to respond to heat shock by producing hsp70 , although possibly lying at the level of transcriptional control , may nevertheless be unrelated to the reduced DNA synthesis or the diminished proliferative activity also manifested by these cells .
4,7 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|36,37 G#DNA

Involvement of phospholipase D in the activation of transcription factor AP-1 in human T lymphoid Jurkat cells .
2,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_line|12,17 G#cell_line

The induction of the AP-1 transcription factor has been ascribed to the early events leading to T lymphocyte activation .
4,5 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

We have examined the possibility that stimulation of phospholipase D ( PLD ) may regulate activation of transcription factor AP-1 in human T cells by transfecting human T lymphocyte Jurkat cells with a plasmid containing an AP-1 enhancer element and a chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter gene .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_line|27,31 G#cell_line|36,38 G#DNA|36,39 G#DNA|41,43 G#protein|41,45 G#DNA

We have detected activatable PLD in Jurkat cells , and we have found that addition of phosphatidic acid ( PA ) , the physiologic product of PLD action on phospholipids , is rapidly incorporated into Jurkat cells and leads to activation of transcription factor AP-1 .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|26,27 G#protein|35,37 G#cell_line|44,45 G#protein|42,45 G#protein

Treatment of Jurkat cells with anti-CD3 mAb activated both PLD and transcription factor AP-1 .
2,4 G#cell_line|5,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

Wortmannin , an inhibitor of receptor-coupled PLD activation , blocked the anti-CD3 -induced increases in both PLD activity and AP-1 enhancer activity .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

We found a good correlation in the transfected cells between PLD activation and induction of AP-1 enhancer activity under different experimental conditions .
7,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

Furthermore , ethanol , an inhibitor of the PLD pathway , blocked the anti-CD3-stimulated AP-1 enhancer activity .
8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA

However , this anti-CD3 -mediated response was not inhibited by neomycin , an inhibitor of phosphoinositide hydrolysis .
3,4 G#protein

The increases in AP-1 enhancer activity induced by PA or anti-CD3 mAb were efficiently abrogated by the presence of propranolol , an inhibitor of PA phosphohydrolase and protein kinase C ( PKC ) .
3,5 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Furthermore , the PA - and the anti-CD3 -induced increases in AP-1 enhancer activity were blocked by the presence of PKC inhibitors or by PKC down-regulation .
7,8 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

These data indicate that PLD stimulation can activate the transcription factor AP-1 in T lymphocytes , and suggest that the induction of AP-1 enhancer factor activity by PA is mediated via PKC stimulation , either through a direct activating effect of PA or through PA -derived diacylglycerol formation .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|22,24 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein

These data also provide evidence for a role of PLD -derived lipids in the induction of AP-1 enhancer activity resulting from stimulation of the TCR/CD3 complex , suggesting that increased PLD activity can play an important role in T lymphocyte activation .
9,10 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|38,40 G#cell_type

Upregulation of bcl-2 by the Epstein-Barr virus latent membrane protein LMP1 : a B-cell-specific response that is delayed relative to NF-kappa B activation and to induction of cell surface markers .
2,3 G#DNA|5,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|27,30 G#protein

An ability of the Epstein-Barr virus latent membrane protein LMP1 to enhance the survival of infected B cells through upregulation of the bcl-2 oncogene was first suggested by experiments involving gene transfection and the selection of stable LMP1 + clones ( S.Henderson , M. Rowe , C.Gregory , F.Wang , E.Kieff , and A.Rickinson , Cell 65 : 1107-1115 , 1991 ) .
4,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|22,23 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,40 G#cell_line

However , it was not possible to ascertain whether Bcl-2 upregulation was a specific consequence of LMP1 expression or an artifact of the selection procedure whereby rare Bcl-2 + cells already present in the starting population might best be able to tolerate the potentially toxic effects of LMP1 .
9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#cell_line|47,48 G#protein

We therefore reexamined this issue by using two different experimental approaches that allowed LMP1 -induced effects to be monitored immediately following expression of the viral protein and in the absence of selective pressures ; activation of the NF-kappa B transcription factor and upregulation of the cell adhesion molecule ICAM-1 were used as early indices of LMP1 function .
13,14 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|39,41 G#protein|45,48 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|55,56 G#protein

In the first approach , stable clones of two B-cell lines carrying an LMP1 gene under the control of an inducible metallothionein promoter were induced to express LMP1 in all cells .
9,11 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

Activation of NK-kappa B and upregulation of ICAM-1 occurred within 24 h and were followed at 48 to 72 h by upregulation of Bcl-2 .
2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

In the second approach , we tested the generality of this phenomenon by transiently expressing LMP1 from a strong constitutively active promoter in a range of different cell types .
15,16 G#protein

All six B-cell lines tested showed NF-kappa B activation in response to LMP1 expression , and this was followed in five of six lines by expression of ICAM-1 and Bcl-2 .
2,4 G#cell_line|6,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

In the same experiments , all three non- B-cell lines showed NF-kappa B activation and ICAM-1 upregulation but never any effect upon Bcl-2 .
8,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We therefore conclude that Bcl-2 upregulation is part of the panoply of cellular changes induced by LMP1 but that the effect is cell type specific .
4,5 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Our data also suggest that whilst NF-kappa B may be an essential component of LMP1 signal transduction , other cell-specific factors may be required to effect some functions of the viral protein .
6,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

Long-term inositol phosphate release , but not tyrosine kinase activity , correlates with IL-2 secretion and NF-AT induction in anti-CD3-activated peripheral human T lymphocytes .
7,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,24 G#cell_line

The cascade of events within the first few minutes of T cell stimulation has been well characterized .
10,12 G#cell_type

Although many second messengers have been shown to be necessary and sufficient for T cell activation in a number of model systems , the rate-limiting step in peripheral T cells has not been demonstrated .
13,15 G#cell_type|27,30 G#cell_type

To model effective versus ineffective CD3 -mediated stimulation in peripheral T cells , we used two anti-CD3 mAbs that differ in their ability to stimulate purified T cells : OKT3 , which causes early second messenger generation but is unable to activate T cells without a second signal , and 64.1 , which stimulates T cell proliferation on its own .
5,6 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type|16,18 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|42,44 G#cell_type|50,51 G#protein|54,56 G#cell_type

We found that tyrosine kinase activity was similar for both mAbs over a period of hours .
3,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

However , the inositol phosphate response was stronger for 64.1 than for OKT3 .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

To tie these events to gene activation , we measured NF-kappa B and NF-AT activity in the nucleus after anti-CD3 stimulation .
10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Both stimuli induced the appearance of the NF-kappa B components ( c-Rel , p65 ( RelA ) , and p50 ( NF-kappa B1 ) ) and NF-kappa B DNA binding activity in the nucleus .
7,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

However , only 64.1 induced NF-AT in the nucleus , correlating with its ability to activate T cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

Thus , NF-AT induction and IL-2 secretion were correlated with the levels of inositol phosphate release but not with gross levels of tyrosine kinase activity induced late following the response .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

On the other hand , NF-kappa B induction and IL-2 receptor expression occurred even with the smaller second messenger response generated by OKT3 .
5,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

HLA-DR- , CD33+ , CD56+ , CD16- myeloid/natural killer cell acute leukemia : a previously unrecognized form of acute leukemia potentially misdiagnosed as French-American-British acute myeloid leukemia-M3 [ see comments ]


We have identified and characterized a previously unrecognized form of acute leukemia that shares features of both myeloid and natural killer ( NK ) cells .
17,25 G#cell_type

From a consecutive series of 350 cases of adult de novo acute myeloid leukemia ( AML ) , we identified 20 cases ( 6 % ) with a unique immunophenotype : CD33+ , CD56+ , CD11a+ , CD13lo , CD15lo , CD34+/- , HLA-DR - , CD16 - .
43,44 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

Multicolor flow cytometric assays confirmed the coexpression of myeloid ( CD33 , CD13 , CD15 ) and NK cell-associated ( CD56 ) antigens in each case , whereas reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) assays confirmed the identity of CD56 ( neural cell adhesion molecule ) in leukemic blasts .
8,23 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|43,47 G#protein|49,51 G#cell_type

Although two cases expressed CD4 , no case expressed CD2 , CD3 , or CD8 and no case showed clonal rearrangement of genes encoding the T-cell receptor ( TCR beta , gamma , delta ) .
4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,34 G#protein

Leukemic blasts in the majority of cases shared unique morphologic features ( deeply invaginated nuclear membranes , scant cytoplasm with fine azurophilic granularity , and finely granular Sudan black B and myeloperoxidase cytochemical reactivity ) that were remarkably similar to those of acute promyelocytic leukemia ( APL ) ; particularly the microgranular variant ( FAB AML -M3v ) .
31,32 G#protein|51,53 G#protein|54,57 G#protein

However , all 20 cases lacked the t(15;17) and 17 cases tested lacked the promyelocytic/retinoic acid receptor alpha ( RAR alpha ) fusion transcript in RT-PCR assays ; 12 cases had 46,XX or 46,XY karyotypes , whereas 2 cases had abnormalities of chromosome 17q : 1 with del(17)(q25) and the other with t(11;17)(q23;q21) and the promyelocytic leukemia zinc finger/ RAR alpha fusion transcript .
14,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|14,24 G#RNA|42,44 G#DNA|47,48 G#DNA|52,53 G#DNA|59,61 G#protein|55,63 G#RNA

All cases tested ( 6/20 ) , including the case with t(11;17) , failed to differentiate in vitro in response to all-trans retinoic acid ( ATRA ) , suggesting that these cases may account for some APLs that have not shown a clinical response to ATRA .
11,12 G#DNA

Four of 6 cases tested showed functional NK cell-mediated cytotoxicity , suggesting a relationship between these unique CD33+ , CD56+ , CD16 - acute leukemias and normal CD56+ , CD16- NK precursor cells .
21,22 G#protein|26,33 G#cell_type

Using a combination of panning and multiparameter flow cytometric sorting , we identified a normal CD56+ , CD33+ , CD16- counterpart cell at a frequency of 1 % to 2 % in the peripheral blood of healthy individuals .
14,22 G#cell_type

Our studies suggest that this form of acute leukemia may arise from transformation of a precursor cell common to both the myeloid and NK cell lineages ; thus we propose the designation myeloid/NK acute leukemia .
21,26 G#cell_type

Recognition of this new leukemic entity will be important in distinguishing these ATRA -nonresponsive cases from ATRA -responsive true APL .


IL-4 down-regulates IL-2 - , IL-3 - , and GM-CSF -induced cytokine gene expression in peripheral blood monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

IL-4 , a product of the T-helper 0 ( Th0 ) and 2 ( Th2 ) subset , was originally described as a B-cell stimulatory factor and has subsequently been found to suppress IL-1 alpha , IL-1 beta , IL-6 , IL-8 , and TNF-alpha gene expression in monocytes stimulated with LPS , and to upregulate IL-1 receptor antagonist ( IL1-RA ) gene expression .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|6,17 G#cell_type|23,26 G#protein|48,49 G#cell_type|56,63 G#DNA

In this study we investigated the effect of IL-4 on the expression of cytokine genes in monocytes evoked by other T-helper cell cytokines : IL-2 , IL-3 , and GM-CSF .
8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#cell_type|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

IL-4 down-regulated mRNA accumulation of the proinflammatory cytokines IL-1 beta , IL-8 , and TNF-alpha in monocytes stimulated with IL-2 , IL-3 , and GM-CSF .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

IL-4 also suppressed the IL-2 -induced IL-6 mRNA expression .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Temporal analysis of the IL-4 down-regulatory effect on the IL-2- , IL-3- , or GM-CSF- induced proinflammatory cytokine gene expression in monocytes provided evidence that IL-4 acts predominantly on the post-transcriptional level .
4,5 G#protein|21,22 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

This was supported by the observation that the down-regulatory capacity of IL-4 appeared to be dependent on de novo protein synthesis .
11,12 G#protein

IL-4 did not exert significant influence on the induction of expression of IL-1-RA or various CSFs by IL-2 , IL-3 , and GM-CSF .
0,1 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Induction of proto-oncogene and cytokine expression in human peripheral blood monocytes and the monocytic cell line THP-1 after stimulation with mycoplasma-derived material MDHM .
2,3 G#DNA|4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line

Mycoplasma fermentans-derived high-molecular-weight material ( MDHM ) was originally described to induce differentiation of murine thymocytes to cytolytic effector T-cells by stimulating IL-6 release from adherent cells .
14,16 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type

This study shows that human peripheral blood monocytes ( PBMo ) also respond to MDHM with increases in IL-1 beta , IL-6 and TNF alpha expression , both at the mRNA and protein level .
7,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

The induced expression of IL-1 beta and TNF alpha mRNA in the monocytic THP-1 cell line increased as quickly as in primary cells .
4,10 G#RNA|13,16 G#cell_line|21,23 G#cell_type

In contrast to PBMo , THP-1 and 14 other monocytic/myeloid leukemia-derived cell lines did not secrete measurable amounts of the cytokines upon treatment with MDHM .
3,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#cell_line|9,13 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein

IL-1 beta and IL-6 genes contain AP-1 binding sites as regulatory elements , the AP-1 protein being composed of c-jun and c-fos gene products .
0,2 G#DNA|0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|0,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|19,24 G#protein

In THP-1 cells c-jun mRNA expression increased after incubation with MDHM while positive c-fos expression remained unaffected .
1,3 G#cell_line|3,5 G#RNA|13,14 G#DNA

Although these data suggest AP-1 regulated cytokine mRNA expression , results from PBMo are not in accordance with this notion .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type

In the primary cells MDHM -induced elevation of cytokine mRNA levels was preceded by a downregulation of c-fos expression while positive c-jun expression was not modulated .
2,4 G#cell_type|8,10 G#RNA|17,18 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA

c-myc mRNA expression , constitutively high in THP-1 cells , was induced in MDHM -stimulated PBMo .
0,2 G#RNA|7,9 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_type

In conclusion , MDHM -stimulated induction of cytokine mRNA expression was accompanied by different proto-oncogene responses in PBMo and THP-1 cells .
7,9 G#RNA|14,15 G#DNA|17,18 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_line

These differences may represent different regulatory pathways of the two cell systems .


Alternatively , these data support the notion that neither AP-1 nor the c-myc protein are involved in the MDHM -induced increase in IL-1 beta , IL-6 or TNF alpha mRNA levels .
9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Furthermore , the present results demonstrate clearly that mycoplasma products can have a profound impact on the activation status of eukaryotic cells .
8,10 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

Novel membrane receptors for aldosterone in human lymphocytes : a 50 kDa protein on SDS-PAGE .
0,3 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|10,13 G#protein

Fast in vitro effects of aldosterone on the Na+/H(+)-exchanger , inositoltrisphosphate generation and corresponding specific binding to plasma membranes at Kd-values of approximately 0.1 nM have been found in human mononuclear leukocytes and vascular smooth muscle cells .
8,9 G#protein|29,32 G#cell_type|33,37 G#cell_type

The novel aldosterone membrane receptor was analyzed on SDS-PAGE after labeling of microsomal membranes from human mononuclear leukocytes with a [125I]- aldosterone -derivative by use of BASED as a photoactivatable crosslinker .
15,18 G#cell_type

Binding of 1 nM [125I]- aldosterone was found at a molecular weight of approximately 50 kDa which was absent with 1 microM cold aldosterone , but not cortisol in the binding media .


This aldosterone -selectivity is typical and discriminatory for the new aldosterone membrane receptor .
10,13 G#protein

Solubilization of the receptor protein from membranes by high salt concentrations ( 1 M NaCl , 1 mM EDTA ) was not achieved .
3,5 G#protein

It , thus , appears as an integral membrane protein .
7,10 G#protein

Dithiothreitol , a sulfhydryl agent , does not reduce specific aldosterone binding indicating the absence of SH-groups in the binding domain or sensitive structures of the receptors .
16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

The results are the first to characterize the novel membrane receptor for aldosterone with regard to molecular weight and basic properties .
8,11 G#protein

These findings and other related results are reviewed here .


A transcriptional regulatory element is associated with a nuclease-hypersensitive site in the pol gene of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 .
1,4 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

Analysis of the chromatin organization of the integrated human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) genome has previously revealed a major constitutive DNase I-hypersensitive site associated with the pol gene ( E . Verdin , J . Virol . 65 : 6790-6799 , 1991 ) .
8,17 G#DNA|21,26 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

In the present report , high-resolution mapping of this site with DNase I and micrococcal nuclease identified a nucleosome-free region centered around nucleotides ( nt ) 4490 to 4766 .
11,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|22,29 G#DNA

A 500-bp fragment encompassing this hypersensitive site ( nt 4481 to 4982 ) exhibited transcription-enhancing activity ( two- to threefold ) when it was cloned in its natural position with respect to the HIV-1 promoter after transient transfection in U937 and CEM cells .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|8,12 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA|39,40 G#cell_line|41,43 G#cell_line

Using in vitro footprinting and gel shift assays , we have identified four distinct binding sites for nuclear proteins within this positive regulatory element .
14,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|21,24 G#DNA

Site B ( nt 4519 to 4545 ) specifically bound four distinct nuclear protein complexes : a ubiquitous factor , a T-cell-specific factor , a B-cell-specific factor , and the monocyte/macrophage- and B-cell-specific transcription factor PU.1/Spi-1 .
0,2 G#DNA|3,7 G#DNA|12,15 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|30,35 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

In most HIV-1 isolates in which this PU box was not conserved , it was replaced by a binding site for the related factor Ets1 .
7,9 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein

Factors binding to site C ( nt 4681 to 4701 ) had a DNA-binding specificity similar to that of factors binding to site B , except for PU.1/Spi-1 .
3,5 G#DNA|6,10 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

A GC box containing a binding site for Sp1 was identified ( nt 4623 to 4631 ) .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|12,16 G#DNA

Site D ( nt 4816 to 4851 ) specifically bound a ubiquitously expressed factor .
0,2 G#DNA|3,7 G#DNA|11,14 G#protein

These results identify a transcriptional regulatory element associated with a nuclease- hypersensitive site in the pol gene of HIV-1 and suggest that its activity may be controlled by a complex interplay of cis- regulatory elements .
4,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|10,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA

Expression of v-src in T cells correlates with nuclear expression of NF-kappa B .
2,3 G#DNA|4,6 G#cell_type|11,13 G#protein

NF-kappa B is a rapidly inducible transcriptional activator that responds to a variety of signals and influences the expression of many genes involved in the immune response .
0,2 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA

Protein tyrosine kinases transmit signals from cytokine and immune receptors .
1,3 G#protein|6,10 G#protein

Very little information exists linking these two important classes of signaling molecules .
10,12 G#protein

We now demonstrate that v-src expression correlates with nuclear expression of a kappa B binding complex similar to that induced by phorbol ester and ionomycin , as detected by electrophoretic mobility shift assay using a variety of kappa B sites .
4,5 G#DNA|12,16 G#protein|37,40 G#DNA

This complex was blocked by the tyrosine kinase inhibitor , herbimycin A .
6,8 G#protein

The v-src -induced complex comprised the p50 and p65 components of NF-kappa B , as determined by supershift and immunoblot analysis .
1,2 G#DNA|1,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

As a functional correlate of this finding , transient co-transfection of HIV-1 LTR reporter constructs in a different T cell line demonstrated that v-src activated this promoter in a kappa B-dependent manner .
11,13 G#DNA|11,15 G#DNA|18,21 G#cell_line|23,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein

We found that transactivation of the HIV-1 LTR by v-src was more sensitive to mutations of the proximal , rather than the distal , kappa B element .
6,8 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|24,27 G#DNA

The implications for T cell receptor signaling and HIV-1 gene expression are considered .
3,6 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA

trans-activation of the HIV promoter by a cDNA and its genomic clones of human herpesvirus-6 .
3,5 G#DNA

Human herpesvirus 6 ( HHV-6 ) is a lymphotropic herpesvirus , and in vitro , it can productively infect human CD4+ T cells as HIV-1 .
20,23 G#cell_line

Co-infection of T cells by HIV-1 and HHV-6 can lead to both activation of the HIV-1 promoter and acceleration of the cytopathic effects .
2,4 G#cell_type|15,17 G#DNA

An HHV-6 ( GS ) cDNA clone , pCD41 , encoding for a 41-kDa nuclear protein was identified and characterized previously ( Chang and Balachandran , J. Virol . 65 , 2884-2894 and 7085 , 1991 ) .
1,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|13,16 G#protein

Sequence analyses show that this protein has significant homology with the human cytomegalovirus UL44 gene coding for the ICP36 family of early-late-class phosphoprotein .
11,15 G#DNA|18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

Using this cDNA as the probe , a 3.8-kb EcoRI genomic fragment encoding the HHV-6 ( GS ) P41 was cloned and designated as pGD41 .
2,3 G#DNA|8,12 G#DNA|14,19 G#protein|24,25 G#DNA

When cotransfected with the HIV LTR CAT into CV-1 cells , both the pCD41 and pGD41 clones trans-activated the HIV LTR .
4,7 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_line|13,14 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA

Sequence analyses of pCD41 indicate that there are two potential open reading frames ( ORFs ) , A and B , which are homologous to the ORFs found in the genomic clone pGD41 .
3,4 G#DNA|10,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|32,33 G#DNA

Deletion constructs of the pCD41 clone demonstrated that ORF-A was critical for the HIV LTR activation .
4,5 G#DNA|4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

Deletion analyses of the pCD41 ORF-A and the use of promoter constructs further mapped an internal functional promoter within the pCD41 sequence that can direct the synthesis of the trans-activating protein .
4,5 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein

By using HIV LTR deletion mutants , the NF-kappa B binding sites were found to be critical for response to the pCD41 trans-activation .
2,4 G#DNA|2,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA

CD14 -mediated translocation of nuclear factor-kappa B induced by lipopolysaccharide does not require tyrosine kinase activity .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

During the course of serious bacterial infections , lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) is believed to interact with macrophage receptors , resulting in the generation of inflammatory mediators and systemic symptoms including hemodynamic instability and shock .
17,19 G#protein

CD14 , a glycosylphosphatidylinositol-linked antigen , functions as an LPS signaling receptor .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

A critical issue concerns the mechanism by which CD14 , which has no transmembrane domain , transduces its signal following LPS binding .
8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

Recently , investigators have hypothesized that CD14 -mediated signaling is effected through a receptor-associated tyrosine kinase ( TK ) , suggesting a multicomponent receptor model of LPS signaling .
6,7 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Wild-type Chinese hamster ovary ( CHO ) -K1 cells can be activated by endotoxin to release arachidonate following transfection with human CD14 ( CHO/ CD14 ) .
1,9 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Nuclear translocation of cytosolic NF-kappa B is correlated with a number of LPS -inducible responses .


We sought to determine if this pathway were present in CHO/ CD14 cells and to elucidate the relationship of NF-kappa B activation to the CD14 receptor system .
11,12 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line|19,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

LPS -stimulated translocation of NF-kappa B in CHO/ CD14 cells resembled the same response in the murine macrophage-like cell line RAW 264.7 .
4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_line|16,20 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_line

Protein synthesis inhibitors and corticosteroids , which suppress arachidonate release and the synthesis of proinflammatory cytokines , had no effect on translocation of NF-kappa B in CHO/ CD14 or RAW 264.7 cells , demonstrating that NF-kappa B translocation is an early event .
14,16 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,32 G#cell_line|35,37 G#protein

Although TK activity was consistently observed by immunoblotting extracts from activated RAW 264.7 cells , LPS-induced phosphotyrosine residues were not observed from similarly treated CHO/CD14 cells .
11,14 G#cell_line|24,26 G#cell_line

Furthermore , the TK inhibitors herbimycin A and genistein failed to inhibit translocation of NF-kappa B in CHO/CD14 or RAW 264.7 cells , although both of these agents inhibited LPS -induced TK activity in RAW 264.7 cells .
14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_line|19,22 G#cell_line|34,37 G#cell_line

These results imply that TK activity is not obligatory for CD14 -mediated signal transduction to occur in response to LPS .
10,11 G#protein

Signals transduced through the CD4 molecule on T lymphocytes activate NF-kappa B .
4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#protein

We have demonstrated that native envelope glycoproteins of HIV-1 , gp160 can induce activation of the transcription factor , NF-kappa B .
4,7 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

The stimulatory effects of gp160 are mediated through the CD4 molecule , since pretreatment with soluble CD4 abrogates its activity .
9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

The gp160 -induced NF-kappa B complex consists of p65 , p50 and c-rel proteins .
3,5 G#protein|1,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

The stimulatory effect of gp160 on NF-kappa B activation is protein synthesis independent , is dependent upon protein tyrosine phosphorylation , and abrogated by inhibitors of protein kinase C .
6,8 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

The gp160 -mediated activation of NF-kappa B in CD4 positive T cells may be involved in biological effects , e.g. , enhanced HIV replication , hypergammaglobulinemia , increased cytokine secretion , hypercellularity in bone marrow and apoptosis .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,12 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

No evidence for the expression of the progesterone receptor on peripheral blood lymphocytes during pregnancy [ see comments ]
7,9 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

The expression of the progesterone receptor in human peripheral blood lymphocytes was analysed , using an enzyme linked immunosorbent assay ( Abbott PgR-EIA monoclonal ) , in order to evaluate its prognostic character in the context of spontaneous abortion .
4,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|7,11 G#cell_type

Cytosols were prepared from lymphocytes of 24 healthy pregnant women ( 11 first , 10 second and three third trimester ) , seven healthy non-pregnant women , nine women with recurrent spontaneous abortion , and six healthy men .


In addition , a human breast carcinoma cell line ( ZR-75-1 ) , which expresses the progesterone receptor , was analysed throughout .
4,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line|16,18 G#protein

The ZR-75-1 cell line showed an expression of 642 fmol/mg whereas lymphocytes of pregnant women showed an expression &lt; or = 4 fmol/mg .
1,4 G#cell_line

Lymphocytes of non-pregnant women , women with threatened pre-term delivery , and men showed equivalent levels : 3 +/- 1 , 3 +/- 2 and 5 +/- 4 fmol/mg respectively .
0,1 G#cell_type

These results show that there is no evidence of specific expression of the progesterone receptor in pregnancy and exclude any prognostic character in spontaneous abortion .
13,15 G#protein

A role for the progesterone receptor in the mechanism of the known effect of progesterone on peripheral blood lymphocytes is also excluded .
4,6 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

Tolerance to lipopolysaccharide involves mobilization of nuclear factor kappa B with predominance of p50 homodimers .
6,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Stimulation of the human monocytic cell line Mono Mac 6 with lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) leads to rapid and transient expression of cytokines like tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) .
3,7 G#cell_line|7,10 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

When such cells are precultured for 2 days with a low dose of LPS ( 20 ng/ml ) followed by stimulation with a high dose of LPS ( 1 microgram/ml ) , expression of the TNF gene is minimal , i.e. the cells are tolerant .
35,36 G#protein|35,37 G#DNA

In nuclear run-on analysis , such tolerant cells show only a low degree of transcription , indicating that tolerance operates at or upstream of the transcription level .
6,8 G#cell_type

The CD14 LPS receptor is , however , up-regulated ( not down-regulated ) in tolerant cells , and LPS can , in fact , still lead to activation of tolerant cells as evidenced by mobilization of the transcription factor nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) .
1,2 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line|29,31 G#cell_line|37,39 G#protein|39,43 G#protein|44,46 G#protein

Resolution of the NF-kappa B complex in gel shift analysis shows that the binding protein , mobilized in naive Mono Mac 6 cells , consists mainly of p50 -p65 heterodimers , while in tolerant cells , the p50 homodimer is predominant .
3,5 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|18,23 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_line|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

This increase in p50 homodimers coincides with an increase in p105 mRNA , suggestive of a transcriptional up-regulation of p50 .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|10,12 G#RNA|19,20 G#protein

Reporter gene analysis reveals that the NF-kappa B complex mobilized in tolerant cells is functionally inactive in that NF-kappa B -dependent luciferase constructs containing the human immunodeficiency virus long terminal repeat or the TNF 5'-region show only minimal transactivation after LPS stimulation .
6,8 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line|18,20 G#protein|18,23 G#DNA|25,31 G#DNA|33,34 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA

Similar to Mono Mac 6 cells , primary blood monocytes , when precultured with a low dose of LPS , also become tolerant and produce little TNF after LPS stimulation .
2,6 G#cell_line|7,10 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein

The tolerant blood monocytes also up-regulate CD14 , and they mobilize NF-kappa B with a predominance of p50 homodimers .
1,4 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Taken together , these results demonstrate that tolerance to LPS is determined by post-receptor mechanisms that involve an altered composition of the NF-kappa B complex .
22,24 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Analysis of Oct2-isoform expression in lipopolysaccharide -stimulated B lymphocytes .
2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_line

Oct2-isoform expression in splenic B cells stimulated with lipopolysaccharide or lipopolysaccharide plus phorbol-di-butyrate was analysed by cDNA cloning .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#cell_type

The frequency of Oct2-positive clones was 1/15,000 in both libraries .
3,5 G#cell_line

Two new isoforms were found that generate novel amino- or carboxy- terminal sequences .
8,13 G#protein

An isoform lacking exon 11 destroyed the carboxy-terminal leucin-zipper region and introduced a frame shift creating a novel , proline -rich carboxy terminus .
3,5 G#DNA|7,10 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

A new exon containing a highly basic region ( 4c ) was characterized , between exons 4 and 5 .
2,3 G#DNA|14,19 G#DNA

This exon was inserted between glutamine-rich regions 2 and 3 , carboxy terminal of a tentative leucine-zipper structure .
5,10 G#DNA|4,10 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

In addition , a new combination isoform containing Oct2a 's amino terminal insert ( exon 7a ) and Oct2b 's carboxy terminal insert ( exon 13 ) was found that created a novel large isoform , Oct2ab .
8,9 G#protein|8,13 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|18,23 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|36,37 G#protein

More frequent use of the classical Oct2a and Oct2b isoforms was observed in the lipopolysaccharide -stimulated B cells , while a preference for the Oct2ab and Oct2ba isoforms was observed in lipopolysaccharide plus phorbol-di-butyrate -treated cells .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|31,36 G#cell_line

Positive regulators of the lineage-specific transcription factor GATA-1 in differentiating erythroid cells .
5,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

The zinc finger transcription factor GATA-1 is a major regulator of gene expression in erythroid , megakaryocyte , and mast cell lineages .
3,5 G#protein|1,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,22 G#cell_type

GATA-1 binds to WGATAR consensus motifs in the regulatory regions of virtually all erythroid cell-specific genes .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

Analyses with cultured cells and cell-free systems have provided strong evidence that GATA-1 is involved in control of globin gene expression during erythroid differentiation .
2,4 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

Targeted mutagenesis of the GATA-1 gene in embryonic stem cells has demonstrated its requirement in normal erythroid development .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|7,10 G#cell_type

Efficient rescue of the defect requires an intact GATA element in the distal promoter , suggesting autoregulatory control of GATA-1 transcription .
8,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein

To examine whether GATA-1 expression involves additional regulatory factors or is maintained entirely by an autoregulatory loop , we have used a transient heterokaryon system to test the ability of erythroid factors to activate the GATA-1 gene in nonerythroid nuclei .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|35,37 G#DNA

We show here that proerythroblasts and mature erythroid cells contain a diffusible activity ( TAG ) capable of transcriptional activation of GATA-1 and that this activity decreases during the terminal differentiation of erythroid cells .
4,5 G#cell_type|6,9 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

Nuclei from GATA-1 -mutant embryonic stem cells can still be reprogrammed to express their globin genes in erythroid heterokaryons , indicating that de novo induction of GATA-1 is not required for globin gene activation following cell fusion .
2,3 G#protein|4,7 G#cell_type|2,7 G#cell_line|14,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|31,33 G#DNA

Role of HIV-1 Nef expression in activation pathways in CD4 + T cells .
2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

The role of the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV-1 ) Nef protein in T cell activation pathways was investigated using a Jurkat CD4 + cell line stably transfected with a Nef expression vector .
10,12 G#protein|4,12 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_line

Secretion of IL-2 and TNF-alpha , surface expression of IL-2R , and DNA-binding activity of NF-kappa B and AP-1 ( Fos/Jun ) complex in response to phorbol myristate acetate , TNF-alpha , or immobilized antibodies to CD3 were monitored .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

These parameters were not modified by Nef expression in Jurkat cells , whereas stimulation with the same stimuli resulted in partial inhibition of LTR activation in Nef + Jurkat cells .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_line|23,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_line|26,30 G#cell_line

This inhibition was not mediated through Nef phosphorylation on Thr-15 or GTP -binding activity because mutations in critical sites did not alter this inhibition .
6,7 G#protein

Analysis of truncated LTRs confirmed that inhibition of LTR activation was not mediated through NF-kappa B -binding activity but through the region containing the negative responding elements ( NREs ) .
3,4 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA

These results suggest that Nef downmodulates LTR activation without significantly inhibiting the capacity of T cells to respond to immunological activations .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type

Tat-binding protein 7 is a subunit of the 26S protease .
0,3 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Subunit 6 ( S6 ) , an integral component of the 26S protease from human erythrocytes , has been studied by SDS-PAGE , peptide mapping and sequence analysis .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

S6 was cleaved with CNBr and three internal peptides were sequenced .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

A comparison with known proteins in Genbank revealed that all three S6 peptides match the predicted sequence of TBP7 , Tat-binding protein 7 .
11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

Based on peptide matches covering more than 10 % of the TBP7 sequence , and the fact that the migration of S6 on SDS-PAGE is consistent with the estimated molecular mass for TBP7 , we conclude that subunit 6 of the 26S protease is TBP7 .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|41,43 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

Hypoxia causes the activation of nuclear factor kappa B through the phosphorylation of I kappa B alpha on tyrosine residues .
5,9 G#protein|13,17 G#protein

The response of mammalian cells to stress is controlled by transcriptional regulatory proteins such as nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) to induce a wide variety of early response genes .
3,5 G#cell_type|10,13 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|29,32 G#DNA

In this report , we show that exposure of cells to hypoxia ( 0.02 % O2 ) results in I kappa B alpha degradation , increased NF-kappa B DNA binding activity , and transactivation of a reporter gene construct containing two NF-kappa B DNA binding sites .
19,23 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|36,39 G#DNA|41,43 G#protein|41,46 G#DNA

Pretreatment of cells with protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors and the dominant negative allele of c-Raf-1 ( Raf 301 ) inhibited I kappa B alpha degradation , NF-kappa B binding , and transactivation of kappa B reporter constructs by hypoxia .
5,7 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|33,37 G#DNA

To demonstrate a direct link between changes in the phosphorylation pattern of I kappa B alpha with NF-kappa B activation , we immunoprecipitated I kappa B alpha after varying times of hypoxic exposure and found that its tyrosine phosphorylation status increased during hypoxic exposure .
12,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|23,27 G#protein

Inhibition of the transfer of tyrosine phosphoryl groups onto I kappa B alpha prevented I kappa B alpha degradation and NF-kappa B binding .
9,13 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

In comparison to other activators of NF-kappa B such as phorbol myristate acetate or tumor necrosis factor , we did not detect changes in the tyrosine phosphorylation status of I kappa B alpha following treatment with either of these agents .
6,8 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|29,33 G#protein

These results suggest that tyrosine phosphorylation of I kappa B alpha during hypoxia is an important proximal step which precedes its dissociation and degradation from NF-kappa B .
7,11 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Overproduction of NFKB2 ( lyt-10 ) and c-Rel : a mechanism for HTLV-I Tax -mediated trans-activation via the NF-kappa B signalling pathway .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Molecular , biochemical and epidemiological evidence implicate HTLV-I as an etiologic agent of adult T cell leukemia ( ATL ) .


The Tax protein of HTLV-I , a positive transcriptional activator of HTLV-I gene expression , is a viral oncogene that also increases transcription of cellular genes including GM-CSF , IL-2R alpha and IL-2 .
1,3 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

One of the cellular targets of the trans-activating effects of Tax is the NF-kappa B /Rel family of transcription factors , pleiotropic regulators of immunoregulatory , cytokine and viral gene expression .
13,15 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

In this report , we demonstrate that NFKB2 ( lyt-10 ) and c-Rel are overexpressed in HTLV-I infected and Tax-expressing cells and , together , account for the majority of the constitutive NF-kappa B binding activity in these cells before and after PMA stimulation .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|32,34 G#protein

Most importantly , we show a Tax -dependent correlation between expression of NFKB2 ( p100 ) and processing to the DNA binding NFKB2 ( p52 ) form , induction of c-Rel , and trans-activation of NF-kappa B -mediated gene expression .
6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

Furthermore , the NFKB2 precursor is physically associated with c-Rel and with Tax in HTLV-I infected cells .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

We propose that NFKB2 synthesis and processing allows continuous nuclear expression of an otherwise cytoplasmic protein and , in conjunction with overexpression of c-Rel , NFKB2 alters the NF-kappa B signalling pathway and contributes to leukemic transformation of T cells by HTLV-I .
3,4 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|38,40 G#cell_type

Retinoic acid downmodulates erythroid differentiation and GATA1 expression in purified adult-progenitor culture .
6,7 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_line

All-trans retinoic acid ( RA ) is an important morphogen in vertebrate development , a normal constituent in human adult blood and is also involved in the control of cell growth and differentiation in acute promyelocytic leukemia .


We have examined the effects of RA on normal hematopoiesis by using early hematopoietic progenitor cells ( HPC ) stringently purified from adult peripheral blood .
13,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type

In clonogenetic fetal calf serum -supplemented ( FCS+ ) or -nonsupplemented ( FCS- ) culture treated with saturating levels of interleukin-3 ( IL-3 ) granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) and erythropoietin ( Ep ) ( combined with c-kit ligand in FCS(-)-culture conditions ) , RA induces a dramatic dose-dependent shift from erythroid to granulomonocytic colony formation , the latter colonies being essentially represented by granulocytic clones .
1,15 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|65,67 G#cell_line

This shift is apparently not caused by a recruitment phenomenon , because in FCS+ culture , the total number of colonies is not significantly modified by RA addition .
13,15 G#cell_line

In FCS- liquid-suspension culture supplemented with saturating Ep level and low-dose IL-3 /GM-CSF , adult HPC undergo unilineage erythropoietic differentiation : Here again , treatment with high-dose RA induces a shift from the erythroid to granulocytic differentiation pathway .
1,4 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

Studies on RA time-response or pulse treatment in semisolid or liquid culture show that early RA addition is most effective , thus indicating that early but not late HPC are sensitive to its action .
28,29 G#cell_type

We then analyzed the expression of the master GATA1 gene , which encodes a finger transcription factor required for normal erythroid development ; addition of RA to HPC stimulated into unilineage erythropoietic differentiation in liquid culture caused a virtually complete inhibition of GATA1 mRNA induction .
7,10 G#DNA|14,17 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type|42,43 G#protein|42,44 G#RNA

These results indicate that RA directly inhibits the erythroid differentiation program at the level of early adult HPC , and may lead to a shift from the erythroid to granulocytic differentiation pathway .
17,18 G#cell_type

This phenomenon is correlated with inhibition of GATA1 induction in the early stages of erythropoietic differentiation .
7,8 G#protein

Induction of phosphatidylinositol turnover and EGR-1 mRNA expression by crosslinking of surface IgM and IgD in the human B cell line B104 .
5,7 G#RNA|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,22 G#cell_line

We have previously shown that a human B lymphoma cell line , B104 , expressed surface IgM ( sIgM ) and surface IgD ( sIgD ) , and that crosslinking of sIgM and sIgD by anti- IgM antibody ( Ab ) and anti- IgD Ab , respectively , induced Ca2+ influx to almost the same degree , whereas only sIgM -crosslinking caused B104 cell death .
6,13 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|35,41 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|42,45 G#protein|59,60 G#protein|62,64 G#cell_line

Here , we investigated the accumulation of cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) , the hydrolysis of inositol phosphates , protein kinase C ( PKC ) activity and the induction of Egr-1 and c-fos mRNA expression by sIgM- and sIgD- crosslinking to examine differences in the signals mediated through sIgM and sIgD in B104 cells .
19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|52,54 G#cell_line

Both sIgM- and sIgD- crosslinking with antibodies induced elevation of cAMP levels , phosphatidylinositol turnover , PKC activation and expression of Egr-1 and c-fos mRNA , although sIgM -crosslinking was more effective than sIgD -crosslinking , presumably due to the higher expression of sIgM than of sIgD .
16,17 G#protein|21,25 G#RNA|27,28 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

Egr-1 mRNA expression induced by sIgM- and sIgD- crosslinking was inhibited by H7 , erbstatin and genistein , but not by HA1004 .
0,1 G#DNA|0,2 G#RNA|12,13 G#protein

Erbstatin and genistein inhibited the sIg-crosslinking-induced Egr-1 mRNA expression in a dose-dependent manner parallel to that observed in the inhibition of sIg-crosslinking-induced protein tyrosine phosphorylation .
6,7 G#DNA|6,8 G#RNA

Phorbol myristate acetate induced Egr-1 mRNA expression but forskolin and dibutyryl cyclic AMP did not .
4,5 G#DNA|4,6 G#RNA

These findings suggest that the Egr-1 mRNA activating signals through sIgM and sIgD are protein tyrosine kinase- and PKC- dependent , but protein kinase A -independent .
5,6 G#DNA|5,7 G#RNA|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Cyclosporin A ( CsA ) and FK506 rescued B104 cells from death induced by anti-IgM Ab , but did not affect the expression of Egr-1 and c-fos mRNA , showing that CsA and FK506 affect signal transducers differently from or downstream to these molecules .
8,10 G#cell_line|14,16 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,28 G#RNA

The difference in signals transduced through sIgM and sIgD in B104 cells is discussed .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line

Direct exposure to 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin ( TCDD ) increases infectivity of human erythrocytes to a malarial parasite .
10,12 G#cell_type

Direct exposure to 10 nM 2,3,7,8-TCDD caused a 75 % increase and a 2-fold increase in the infectivity of isolated human erythrocytes to P. falciparum after 48 hours when the parasites were in an unsynchronized or synchronized state of growth , respectively .
20,22 G#cell_type

Treatment of human erythrocytes with 10 microM sodium orthovanadate ( NaOV ) , an inhibitor of plasma membrane Ca-ATPase and phosphotyrosine phosphatase , decreased parasitemia by 30 % .
2,4 G#cell_type|16,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Co-treatment of RBCs with TCDD and NaOV completely blocked the TCDD -induced increase in parasitemia .
2,3 G#cell_type

Because erythrocytes are anucleated , these results are discussed as evidence for biochemical changes by TCDD without requiring the activation of gene products .
1,2 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein

Evidence for a trans-acting activator function regulating the expression of the human CD5 antigen .
3,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

Interspecies somatic cell hybrids were generated by fusing the mouse T-lymphoma cell line , BW5147 , with normal human T lymphocytes at different stages of differentiation .
1,4 G#cell_line|9,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|17,21 G#cell_type

Thymocytes , activated peripheral T lymphocytes , or an activated T-cell clone were used as human partners , respectively , in three independent fusions .
0,1 G#cell_type|2,6 G#cell_type|9,12 G#cell_line

Irrespective of the human cell partner used for fusion , a certain number of hybrids lost CD5 surface expression over a period of time in culture .
14,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein

Analysis at the phenotype and genetic level showed that lack of CD5 expression was due neither to segregation of human autosome 11 , on which the CD5 gene has been mapped , nor to deletion of the CD5 structural gene .
11,12 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,40 G#DNA

Furthermore , loss of CD5 surface expression correlated with the absence of specific mRNA .
4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#RNA

Since these hybrids preferentially segregate human chromosomes , these results indicate the existence of a non-syntenic trans-active locus , or loci , positively controlling the expression of the human CD5 gene .
15,18 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|28,31 G#DNA

Induction of the CD11b gene during activation of the monocytic cell line U937 requires a novel nuclear factor MS-2 [ published erratum appears in J Immunol 1999 Jul 15 ; 163 ( 2 ) : 1091 ]
3,5 G#DNA|9,13 G#cell_line|16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The differentiation of myeloid precursors into mature myelomonocytic cells is characterized by the induction of the gene encoding the beta2 integrin CD11b .
3,5 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The transcription factors Sp1 and PU.1 prime the CD11b promoter , but the nature of the factors responsible for its inducible expression are unknown .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA

In addition to the CD11b gene , the homologous genes encoding CD11a and CD11c also exhibit inducible expression during myeloid differentiation .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Therefore , we compared the nucleotide sequences of the CD11a , CD11b , and CD11c gene promoters to identify common elements that might contribute to inducible expression .
5,7 G#DNA|9,17 G#DNA

This analysis identified one such element repeated four times within the CD11b promoter .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA

Mutation of these elements indicated that two , MS-2beta and MS-2gamma , are critical to the induction of the CD11b gene during differentiation of the pro-monocytic cell line U937 .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|25,29 G#cell_line

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays indicate that MS-2beta and MS-2gamma interact with nuclear factors that are induced during U937 differentiation .
