Biochemical analysis of the region -158/-90 revealed a binding site for transcription factors of the polyomavirus enhancer-binding protein 2/core-binding factor ( PEBP2/CBF ) family at position -103 .
5,6 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|15,24 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA

Disruption of the PEBP2/CBF site markedly diminished the role of the PEBP2/CBF factors in the constitutive transcription of the CD36 gene .
3,5 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

The involvement of members of the PEBP2/CBF family in chromosome translocations associated with acute myeloid leukemia , and in the transcriptional regulation of the myeloid-specific genes encoding for myeloperoxidase , elastase , and the colony-stimulating factor receptor , highlights the relevance of the regulation of the CD36 gene promoter in monocytic cells by members of the PEBP2/CBF family .
6,8 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|46,49 G#DNA|50,52 G#cell_type|56,58 G#protein

HLA-DQB1 codon 57 is critical for peptide binding and recognition .
0,3 G#DNA

The association of specific HLA-DQ alleles with autoimmunity is correlated with discrete polymorphisms in the HLA-DQ sequence that are localized within sites suitable for peptide recognition .
4,6 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA

The polymorphism at residue 57 of the DQB1 polypeptide is of particular interest since it may play a major structural role in the formation of a salt bridge structure at one end of the peptide-binding cleft of the DQ molecules .
26,29 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

This polymorphism at residue 57 is a recurrent feature of HLA-DQ evolution , occurring in multiple distinct allelic families , which implies a functional selection for maintaining variation at this position in the class II molecule .
33,36 G#protein

We directly tested the amino acid polymorphism at this site as a determinant for peptide binding and for antigen-specific T cell stimulation .


We found that a single Ala --&gt; Asp amino acid 57 substitution in an HLA-DQ3.2 molecule regulated binding of an HSV-2 VP-16-derived peptide .


A complementary single-residue substitution in the peptide abolished its binding to DQ3.2 and converted it to a peptide that can bind to DQ3.1 and DQ3.3 Asp -57-positive MHC molecules .
24,29 G#protein

These binding studies were paralleled by specific T cell recognition of the class II-peptide complex , in which the substituted peptide abolished T cell reactivity , which was directed to the DQ3.2 -peptide complex , whereas the same T cell clone recognized the substituted peptide presented by DQ3.3 , a class II restriction element differing from DQ3.2 only at residue 57 .
12,15 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|38,41 G#cell_line

This structural and functional complementarity for residue 57 and a specific peptide residue identifies this interaction as a key controlling determinant of restricted recognition in HLA-DQ -specific immune response .


Autocrine activation by interferon-gamma of STAT factors following T cell activation .
3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

The activation of T cells requires engagement of the T cell receptor/CD3 complex and co-stimulatory molecules , and results in the triggering of several signaling pathways which lead rapidly to the nuclear translocation of several transcription factors , such as nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappa B and NF-AT .
3,5 G#cell_type|9,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|35,37 G#protein|40,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein

A result of this activation process is the induction of a number of genes , including those encoding cytokines such as interleukin-2 , tumor necrosis factor-alpha , and interferon ( IFN ) -gamma which have important immunoregulatory effects .
18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|28,33 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

We report here that a DNA-binding factor containing STAT1 also becomes activated in human peripheral blood T lymphocytes or Jurkat cells , although not until 1-2 h after stimulation .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,18 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_line

Activation is delayed a further 1-2 hr when mononuclear cell cultures are stimulated by an antigen which requires processing .
8,11 G#cell_line

Appearance of the STAT1 factor is significantly reduced in the presence of cyclosporin A , and blocked by cycloheximide , indicating that its activation is dependent upon a protein ( s ) synthesized in response to initial signaling events .
3,4 G#protein

Neutralizing antiserum against IFN-gamma , but not other cytokines tested , blocked activation of the factor almost completely , and IFN-gamma was found in the culture supernatants of stimulated cells at levels at which recombinant IFN-gamma could activate the factor in naive cells .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_line|35,36 G#protein|41,43 G#cell_type

Therefore , a STAT1 transcription factor is activated by IFN-gamma synthesized and released upon stimulation of T lymphocyte populations .
3,4 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

While Jurkat cells both secrete and respond to IFN-gamma in an autocrine loop , it seems likely that the responding cells may differ from those synthesizing this cytokine in the mononuclear cell cultures in the light of the recent report that Th1 cells lack the IFN-gamma receptor chain necessary for activation of STAT1 ( Pernis , A. , Gupta , S. , Gollob , K.J. , Garfein , E. , Coffman , R.L. , Schindler , C. , and Rothman , P. , Science 1995 . 269 : 245 ) .
1,3 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_line|41,43 G#cell_line|45,46 G#protein|52,53 G#protein

Absence of T-cell- and B-cell- specific transcription factors TCF-1 , GATA-3 , and BSAP in Hodgkin 's Reed-Sternberg cells .
2,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_line

Based on the presence of T cell receptor-beta ( TcR-beta ) gene rearrangements in L428 and HDLM-1 cells , the expression of CD2 in HDLM-1 cells , and the presence of immunoglobulin heavy-chain ( IgH ) gene rearrangement in KM-H2 cells , some researchers have concluded that these long-term cell lines derived from patients with Hodgkin 's disease are lymphoid in nature .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|5,13 G#DNA|14,18 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_line|31,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|31,38 G#DNA|39,41 G#cell_line|48,51 G#cell_line

The information obtained from these cell lines has also been used in arguments for a lymphoid origin of H-RS cells in tissue despite the frequent absence of lymphoid markers and Ig/TcR gene rearrangements in these cells .
5,7 G#cell_line|18,20 G#cell_line|27,29 G#protein|30,33 G#DNA

We questioned whether one can use the limited expression of lymphoid markers or the limited gene rearrangement to conclude that H-RS cells have a lymphoid origin , because these markers may be aberrant in tumor cells .
10,12 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_line|34,36 G#cell_type

In this study , we examined the expression of two T-cell-specific transcription factors ( TCF-1 and GATA-3 ) and one B-cell-specific transcription factor ( BSAP ) in cultured H-RS cells by using a gel mobility shift assay .
11,13 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_line|27,30 G#cell_line

The sensitivity and specificity of this assay for determination of cell lineage have been established in a large number of cultured human and murine cell lines .
10,12 G#cell_line|20,26 G#cell_line

All three types of H-RS cell lines were consistently negative for BSAP , TCF-1 , and GATA-3 .
4,7 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

The absence of GATA-3 was confirmed in H-RS cells in tissues by an in situ hybridization technique .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line

Virtually all B-cell lines , with the exception of some myeloma cell lines , are positive for BSAP , which is the transcription factor for promoters for several B-cell markers , including VpreB1 , lambda 5 , CD19 , and CD20 .
2,4 G#cell_line|10,13 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#DNA|28,30 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

All T-cell lines tested were positive for TCF-1 and GATA-3 , which are the transcription factors for promoters for several T-cell-restricted markers , including CD2 , CD3 , TcR , and lck .
1,3 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

The absence of BSAP , TCF-1 , and GATA-3 clearly indicates an underlying difference between H-RS cells and lymphoid cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_line|18,20 G#cell_type

MEK1 and the extracellular signal-regulated kinases are required for the stimulation of IL-2 gene transcription in T cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|16,18 G#cell_type

TCR engagement stimulates the activation of the protein kinase Raf-1 .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Active Raf-1 phosphorylates and activates the mitogen-activated protein ( MAP ) kinase /extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase 1 ( MEK1 ) , which in turn phosphorylates and activates the MAP kinases/extracellular signal regulated kinases , ERK1 and ERK2 .
1,2 G#protein|6,12 G#protein|6,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|28,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Raf-1 activity promotes IL-2 production in activated T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Therefore , we sought to determine whether MEK1 and ERK activities also stimulate IL-2 gene transcription .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

Expression of constitutively active Raf-1 or MEK1 in Jurkat T cells enhanced the stimulation of IL-2 promoter -driven transcription stimulated by a calcium ionophore and PMA , and together with a calcium ionophore the expression of each protein was sufficient to stimulate NF-AT activity .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|8,11 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|42,43 G#protein

Expression of MEK1 -interfering mutants inhibited the stimulation of IL-2 promoter -driven transcription and blocked the ability of constitutively active Ras and Raf-1 to costimulate NF-AT activity with a calcium ionophore .
2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Expression of the MAP kinase-specific phosphatase , MKP-1 , which blocks ERK activation , inhibited IL-2 promoter and NF-AT -driven transcription stimulated by a calcium ionophore and PMA , and in addition , MKP-1 neutralized the transcriptional enhancement caused by active Raf-1 and MEK1 expression .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

We conclude that the MAP kinase signal transduction pathway consisting of Raf-1 , MEK1 , and ERK1 and ERK2 functions in the stimulation IL-2 gene transcription in activated T lymphocytes .
4,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|28,30 G#cell_type

Multiple transcription factors are required for activation of human interleukin 9 gene in T cells .
1,3 G#protein|8,12 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_type

The genetic elements and regulatory mechanisms responsible for human interleukin 9 ( IL-9 ) gene expression in a human T cell leukemia virus type I-transformed human T cell line , C5MJ2 , were investigated .
12,13 G#protein|8,15 G#DNA|18,29 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_line

We demonstrated that IL-9 gene expression is controlled , at least in part , by transcriptional activation .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA

Transient expression of the luciferase reporter gene linked to serially deleted sequences of the 5'-flanking region of the IL-9 gene has revealed several positive and negative regulatory elements involved in the basal and inducible expression of the IL-9 gene in C5MJ2 cells .
4,7 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#DNA|40,42 G#cell_line

An AP-1 site at -146 to -140 was shown to be involved in the expression of the IL-9 gene .
17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

A proximal region between -46 and -80 was identified as the minimum sequence for the basal and inducible expression of the IL-9 gene in C5MJ2 cells .
1,3 G#DNA|4,7 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_line

Within this region , an NF-kappaB site at -59 to -50 and its adjacent 20-base pair upstream sequence were demonstrated to play a critical role for the IL-9 promoter activity .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA

DNA-protein binding studies indicated that NF-kappaB , c-Jun , and potentially novel proteins ( around 35 kDa ) can bind to this important sequence .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Mutations at different sites within this proximal promoter region abolished the promoter activity as well as the DNA binding .
6,9 G#DNA

Taken together , these results suggest that the cooperation of different transcription factors is essential for IL-9 gene expression in T cells .
11,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type

DNA triplex formation selectively inhibits granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor gene expression in human T cells .
5,8 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA

Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) is a hemopoietic growth factor that is expressed in activated T cells , fibroblasts , macrophages , and endothelial cells .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

Although GM-CSF does not appear to be essential for normal hemopoiesis , overexpression of GM-CSF has been implicated in the pathogenesis of some diseases such as myeloid leukemia and chronic inflammation .
1,2 G#protein

An NF-kappaB /Rel binding site within the GM-CSF promoter , termed the kappaB element appears to be important for controlling expression in reporter gene assays in response to a number of stimuli in T cells .
1,2 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|33,35 G#cell_type

We investigated oligonucleotide -directed triple helix formation across this regulatory sequence as a potential tool to inhibit GM-CSF gene transcription .
9,11 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein

A 15-base oligonucleotide , GM3 , was targeted to a purine-rich region in the GM-CSF proximal promoter , which overlaps the kappaB element .
10,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

Gel mobility shift assays and DNase I footprinting demonstrated that GM3 formed a sequence-specific collinear triplex with its double-stranded DNA target .
5,7 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|18,21 G#DNA

Triplex formation by GM3 blocked recombinant and nuclear NF-kappaB proteins binding to the GM-CSF element .
5,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

GM3 also caused selective inhibition of the human T-cell lymphotrophic virus-1 Tax transactivator-induced luciferase activity from a reporter construct driven by the GM-CSF promoter in Jurkat T cells .
7,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA|25,28 G#cell_line

Finally , GM3 greatly reduced the concentration of endogenous GM-CSF mRNA induced by different stimuli in Jurkat T cells but did not affect interleukin 3 mRNA levels in the same cells .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#RNA|16,19 G#cell_line|23,25 G#protein|23,26 G#RNA

We conclude that the kappaB element in the GM-CSF promoter plays a central role in the transcriptional activation of the endogenous GM-CSF gene .
4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

Colinear triplex formation acts as a selective transcriptional repressor of the GM-CSF gene and may have potential therapeutic application in cases of undesirable overexpression of this protein .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA

Reversible differentiation of human monoblastic leukemia U937 cells by ML-9 , an inhibitor of myosin light chain kinase .
3,8 G#cell_line|14,18 G#protein

Human monoblastic leukemia U937 cells are induced to differentiate into monocytes and macrophages by various agents .
0,5 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type

We have shown that 1-(5-chloronaphthalene-1-sulfonyl)-1H-hexahydro-1,4-diazepine hydrochloride ( ML-9 ) , an inhibitor of myosin light chain kinase , induces differentiation of monocytoid leukemia cell lines U937 and THP-1 but not of myeloblastic leukemic ML-1 cell or erythroleukemia K562 cells .
13,17 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_line|25,26 G#cell_line|27,28 G#cell_line|31,35 G#cell_line|36,39 G#cell_line

In the present study , we further analyzed the effect of ML-9 in comparison with that of 1 alpha,Â 25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( VD3 ) a typical inducer of monocytic differentiation .


ML-9 induced nitroblue tetrazolium ( NBT ) -reducing activity of U937 cell more rapidly than VD3 : This differentiation marker was induced significantly after incubation with ML-9 and VD3 for 4 hours and 1 day , respectively .
10,12 G#cell_line

ML-9 also induced alpha-naphthyl acetate esterase ( ANAE ) activity , another monocytic differentiation marker , more rapidly than VD3 .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

The maximum levels of these markers induced by ML-9 were comparable to those induced by VD3 , but after removal of ML-9 from the medium by washing the cells , the expressions of theses markers decreased within 4 hours and reached basal levels in 1 day , indicating that ML-9 's induction of expression of differentiation-associated phenotypes was reversible .


The growth inhibition of U937 cells by ML-9 was also reversible .
4,6 G#cell_line

Similar effects were observed in another line of human monoblastic cells , THP-1 .
8,11 G#cell_line|12,13 G#cell_line

ML-9 had little or no effect on the morphology of U937 cells but increased the expression of monocyte-macrophage lineage-associated surface antigen , CD14 , to some extent .
10,12 G#cell_line|17,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Irreversible terminal differentiation induced by VD3 is associated with down regulation of the expression of c-myc and upregulation of the expression of c-fos and c-jun , but ML-9 did not affect the expression of these oncogenes appreciably .


ML-9 -induced differentiation was also reversible when the cells were cultured with cultured with ML-9 plus an anti-cancer drug such as 1-beta-D-arabino-furanosylcytosine or daunomycin .


it became irreversible , however , upon simultaneous treatment with dexamethasone and transforming growth factor-beta 1 ( TGF-beta 1 ) , which did not induce differentiation of U937 cells but caused growth arrest of the cells in the G0/G1 phase of the cell cycle .
12,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_line

These results suggest that ML-9 should be useful for studying the mechanisms of monocytic differentiation .


Modulation of endogenous IL-1 beta and IL-1 receptor antagonist results in opposing effects on HIV expression in chronically infected monocytic cells .
3,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_line

A proportion of HIV -infected individuals experience episodes of localized or systemic bacterial infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria .


Many of the clinical side effects of these infections are associated with the production of proinflammatory cytokines , which are induced primarily by LPS , a constituent of the bacterial cell wall of Gram-negative bacteria .
15,17 G#protein

The present study examines the mechanisms involved in LPS -mediated induction of HIV expression in U1 cells , a promonocytic cell line chronically infected with HIV .
15,17 G#cell_line|19,22 G#cell_line

Stimulation of U1 cells by LPS alone induced minimal levels of HIV expression , which was significantly enhanced by granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) .
2,4 G#cell_line|19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Costimulation of U1 cells with LPS plus GM-CSF resulted in the accumulation of steady-state levels of HIV RNA ; however , only a weak induction of HIV long terminal repeat -driven transcription , which was not associated with the activation of the cellular transcription factor nuclear factor-kappa B , was noted .
2,4 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|16,18 G#RNA|26,30 G#DNA|42,45 G#protein|45,48 G#protein

Costimulation of cells with LPS plus GM-CSF induced the production of proinflammatory cytokines , IL-8 , IL-1 beta and IL-6 , but not TNF-alpha .
6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

IL-1 receptor antagonist ( ra ) inhibited LPS enhancement of HIV expression in GM-CSF -stimulated cells , suggesting that endogenous IL-1 was involved in LPS -mediated viral production .
0,2 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_line|19,21 G#protein

In this regard , anti-inflammatory cytokines inhibited LPS plus GM-CSF -stimulated HIV expression , and this effect closely correlated with inhibition of IL-1 beta release and , in particular , with up-regulation of endogenous IL-1ra production .
4,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Thus , the balance between an endogenously produced viral inducer ( IL-1 beta ) and an inhibitor ( IL-1ra ) may represent an important pathway leading to modulation of HIV expression from monocytic cells .
6,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

Herpesvirus saimiri immortalized gamma delta T cell line activated by IL-12 .
0,8 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein

IL-12 is a novel heterodimeric cytokine important for the regulation and differentiation of lymphocytes and NK cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

Like other cytokines , IL-12 mediates its biologic activity through high-affinity receptors expressed on responsive cells .
4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

To date , a large number of receptors for IL-12 have been found only on PBMC following activation with PHA or IL-2 .
9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

To gain further knowledge of the IL-12R complex and the IL-12 signal transduction pathway in cytotoxic T cells , we studied a number of human T cell lines that had been transformed to permanent growth with Herpesvirus saimiri , an oncogenic virus of nonhuman primates .
6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|24,28 G#cell_line

This paper reports the expression of IL-12R on a human gamma delta T cell line that responds to IL-12 with enhanced cytolytic activity and increased expression of cytolytic effector molecules granzyme B and perforin .
6,7 G#protein|9,15 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Using these T cells as a model of IL-12 signal transduction , we confirmed that these events involve members of the Janus kinase family of nonreceptor tyrosine kinases JAK2 , TYK2 , and signal transducer and activator of transcription 4 .
2,4 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,40 G#protein

Regulation of gene expression at early stages of B-cell and T-cell differentiation .


The expression of distinct sets of genes at different stages of B-lymphocyte and T-lymphocyte differentiation is controlled at the level of transcription .


A number of recent studies have described interactions between transcription factors in lymphocytes that provide new insights into mechanisms regulating gene expression .
9,11 G#protein

These mechanisms include the assembly of higher order nucleoprotein complexes and other protein-protein interactions that enhance the functional specificity of transcriptional regulators in lymphocytes .
6,10 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Identification of a human LIM-Hox gene , hLH-2 , aberrantly expressed in chronic myelogenous leukaemia and located on 9q33-34.1 .
3,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA

We describe the isolation of human LH-2 , a putative transcription factor containing two cysteine -rich regions ( LIM domains ) and a homeobox ( Hox ) DNA-binding domain .
5,7 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|23,29 G#protein

High levels of hLH-2 expression were observed in all cases of chronic myelogenous leukaemia ( CML ) tested , regardless of disease status .
3,4 G#DNA

hLH-2 was mapped to chromosome 9Q33-34.1 , in the same region as the reciprocal translocation that creates the BCR-ABL chimera of the Philadelphia chromosome ( Ph ' ) , the hallmark of CML ; hLH-2 was retained on the derivative 9 chromosome and is therefore centromeric of c-ABL .
0,1 G#DNA|4,6 G#DNA|18,20 G#protein|34,35 G#DNA|39,42 G#DNA|47,48 G#DNA

The proximity of hLH-2 to the breakpoint on chromosome 9 raises the possibility of cis-activation by the t(9;22)(q34;q11) translocation .
3,4 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA

In addition to finding hLH-2 expression in all cases of CML , expression was observed in lymphoid malignancies and myeloid cell lines , but not in primary cases of acute myelogenous leukaemia .
4,5 G#DNA|19,22 G#cell_line

The role of hLH-2 in the development or progression of leukaemia is not known .
3,4 G#DNA

However , hLH-2 may prove useful as a marker of CML for monitoring residual disease .
2,3 G#DNA

Lymphoid cell resistance to glucocorticoids in HIV infection .


In humans infected with the HIV-1 virus there may be a disproportionate severity of signs and symptoms of illness compared to the fraction of CD4+ infected T-lymphoid cells .
24,28 G#cell_line

In part , this may be due to altered intercellular signalling systems and intracellular signal transduction .


Glucocorticoids are well known for their effects on the vitality and function of lymphoid cells .
13,15 G#cell_type

Patients with HIV infections often show elevated circulating levels of cortisol , suggesting some misfunction in the regulatory systems that maintain the levels of this critical hormone .


At the cellular level , it is known that both acute HIV infection and glucocorticoids can cause apoptotic cell death in thymic lymphocytes .
21,23 G#cell_type

However , chronically HIV -infected cells appear to be resistant to glucocorticoid-evoked cell death .
2,6 G#cell_type

Glucocorticoid receptor -ligand binding studies on patients ' cells have shown reduced affinity between the receptor binding sites and test steroids .
0,2 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

In vitro , chronically HIV -infected cells of the lymphoid CEM line displayed resistance to glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis .
3,7 G#cell_line|9,12 G#cell_line

These cells showed reduced numbers of binding sites with little alteration in apparent affinity between ligand and receptor .
6,8 G#protein

Thus it appears that there may often be malfunction of the normal glucocorticoid response in HIV -infected cells probably due to altered interactions between the glucocorticoid receptor and its hormone .
15,18 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein

Such alterations may have clinical consequences , including the possibility of a relatively longer life span of infected CD4+ T-lymphocytes , as well as systemic effects of chronically elevated cortisol level .
17,20 G#cell_type

Abundant expression of erythroid transcription factor P45 NF-E2 mRNA in human peripheral granurocytes .
3,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|3,9 G#RNA|10,13 G#cell_type

Transcription factor NF-E2 is crucial for regulation of erythroid-specific gene expression .
0,3 G#protein

p45 subunit of NF-E2 contains a basic-leucine zipper domain and dimerizes with the small Maf family protein to form functional NF-E2 complex .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

While p45 expression was shown to be restricted to erythroid cells , megakaryocytes and mast cells in hematopoietic lineage , we found in this study that p45 mRNA is abundantly transcribed in the granulocyte fraction of human peripheral blood cells .
1,2 G#protein|1,2 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#RNA|33,35 G#cell_type|36,40 G#cell_type

As neutrophils occupy approximately 92 % of the cells in granulocyte fraction of human peripheral blood cells .
1,2 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|13,17 G#cell_type

As neutrophils occupy approximately 92 % of the cells in this fraction , the cells expressing p45 is most likely to be neutrophils .
1,2 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#cell_type

p45 mRNA is also expressed in HL-60 promyelocytes , albeit the expression level is much lower than that of the granulocyte fraction .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#RNA|6,8 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_type

HL-60 cells were found to express mafK mRNA , indicating the presence of genuine NF-E2 complex in the cells .
0,2 G#cell_line|6,8 G#RNA|14,16 G#protein

Although p45 mRNA is transcribed from two different promoters , aNF-E2 promoter and fNF-E2 promoter , in erythroid and megakaryocytic lineage cells , p45 mRNA is transcribed only from aNF-E2 promoter .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#RNA|10,12 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|17,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#RNA|29,31 G#DNA

The expression of p45 megakaryocytic lineage cells , p45 mRNA is transcribed only from aNF-E2 promoter .
3,4 G#protein|4,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|14,16 G#DNA

The expression of p45 mRNA in the neutrophils declined rapidly after transfer of the cells to in vitro culture and G-CSF could not sustain the expression from the down-regulation , suggesting the E2 may also participate in the regulation of neutrophil-specific gene expression .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#RNA|7,8 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Expression of c-fos and c-jun proteins and AP-1 binding activity during cell cycle progression of HL60 cells and phytohemagglutinin -stimulated lymphocytes .
2,3 G#protein|2,3 G#DNA|4,5 G#DNA|4,6 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line

The protein products of the c-fos ( p62c-fos ) and c-jun ( p39c-jun ) genes are members of the AP-1 transcription factor family and are thought to play important roles in the regulation of gene expression during the cell cycle .
5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

Most studies on the expression of these proteins in relation to the cell cycle have been performed at the mRNA level , and therefore do not give direct information about the presence of the proteins during the cell cycle .


We have used Western blotting to investigate the presence of these proteins during the cell cycles of two different cellular systems : a continuously growing myeloid leukemic cell line , HL60 , and normal cells stimulated into cycle , phyto-Â hemagglutinin ( PHA ) -stimulated normal human peripheral blood lymphocytes ( PBL ) .
19,21 G#cell_line|23,29 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_line|33,35 G#cell_type|41,42 G#protein|39,49 G#cell_line|50,51 G#cell_type

The binding activity of transcription factor AP-1 , which consists of dimers of Fos and Jun family proteins , was also studied using a gel shift assay .
6,7 G#protein|13,18 G#protein

We found nuclear p62c-fos , p39c-jun , and AP-1 binding activity throughout the cell cycle both in HL60 cells and in PHA -stimulated PBL , and we postulate that these proteins are required throughout the cell cycle and not transiently in the G0 to G1 transition as previous mRNA studies have indicated .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_line

We demonstrated an uncoupling of AP-1 binding activity from p62c-fos , and p39c-jun AP-1 activity was expressed more strongly in the G1- and G2/M- phase enriched samples than in the S-phase enriched samples of HL60 cells , while levels of nuclear p62c-fos and p39c-jun were constant .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|34,36 G#cell_line|40,44 G#protein

Nuclei of unstimulated PBL from different donors expressed p62c-fos and p39c-jun , but AP-1 was not detected in the majority of samples .
2,4 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Following PHA stimulation of PBL , the increase in AP-1 activity was delayed with respect to the augmentation of p39c-jun expression .
1,2 G#protein|4,5 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

We also observed that cytoplasmic p62c-fos and p39c-jun were present in HL60 cells and PHA -stimulated PBL .
4,8 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_line

However , no cytoplasmic p62c-fos was detected in unstimulated PBL , although in some cases cytoplasmic p39c-jun was detected , suggesting that subcellular compartmentalization of these proteins may occur under certain circumstances .
4,5 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Octamer binding factors and their coactivator can activate the murine PU.1 ( spi-1 ) promoter .
0,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,15 G#DNA

PU.1 ( spi-1 ) , a member of the Ets transcription factor family , is predominantly expressed in myeloid and B cells , activates many B cell and myeloid genes , and is critical for development of both of these lineages .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_type|25,30 G#DNA

Our previous studies ( Chen , H.M. , Ray-Gallet , D. , Zhang , P. , Hetherington , C.J. , Gonzalez , D.A. , Zhang , D.-E. , Moreau-Gachelin , F. , and Tenen , D.G. ( 1995 ) Oncogene 11 , 1549-1560 ) demonstrate that the PU.1 promoter directs cell type-specific reporter gene expression in myeloid cell lines , and that PU.1 activates its own promoter in an autoregulatory loop .
47,48 G#protein|47,49 G#DNA|50,54 G#DNA|62,63 G#protein

Here we show that the murine PU.1 promoter is also specifically and highly functional in B cell lines as well .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|15,18 G#cell_line

Oct-1 and Oct-2 can bind specifically to a site at base pair -55 in vitro , and this site is specifically protected in B cells in vivo .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

We also demonstrate that two other sites contribute to promoter activity in B cells ; an Sp1 binding site adjacent to the octamer site , and the PU.1 autoregulatory site .
12,14 G#cell_type|16,19 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#DNA

Finally , we show that the B cell coactivator OBF-1/Bob1/OCA-B is only expressed in B cells and not in myeloid cells , and that OBF-1/Bob1/OCA-B can transactivate the PU.1 promoter in HeLa and myeloid cells .
8,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#cell_line|33,35 G#cell_type

This B cell restricted coactivator may be responsible for the B cell specific expression of PU.1 mediated by the octamer site .
4,5 G#protein|1,5 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

Inhibition of p105 processing by NF-kappaB proteins in transiently transfected cells .
2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line

Regulation of the transcription factor NF-kappaB involves proteasome-mediated processing of the NF-kappaB1 p105 precursor protein , which generates the p50 subunit of NF-kappaB .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

The processing of p105 occurs constitutively in vivo but can be markedly enhanced by various cellular activation agents , although the underlying regulatory mechanism is not yet clear .
3,4 G#protein

In the present study , we demonstrate that signal-mediated induction of p105 processing in human T cells is associated with de novo synthesis of this precursor protein .
11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein

Transient transfection studies performed in COS7 cells revealed that the newly synthesized p105 protein appears to be more rapidly processed compared to its accumulated form that is already associated with the processed product p50 .
5,7 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Interestingly , the processing rate of p105 is markedly inhibited in cells co-transfected with p50 or other NF-kappaB subunits , including RelA and c-Rel , that physically interact with p105 .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

These findings suggest that the processing of p105 is subject to negative regulation by the various NF-kappaB subunits .
7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

We further demonstrate that p105 undergoes degradation in lipopolysaccharide -stimulated human monocytic cells .
4,5 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_line

However , the inducible degradation of p105 is not coupled with the generation of p50 .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Together , these studies demonstrate that the processing and inducible degradation of p105 are differentially regulated .
12,13 G#protein

Identification of an inducible regulator of c-myb expression during T-cell activation .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#cell_type

Resting T cells express very low levels of c-Myb protein .
0,3 G#cell_type|8,10 G#protein

During T-cell activation , c-myb expression is induced and much of the increase in expression occurs at the transcriptional level .
4,5 G#DNA

We identified a region of the c-myb 5' flanking sequence that increased c-myb expression during T-cell activation .
6,10 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA

In vivo footprinting by ligation-mediated PCR was performed to correlate in vivo protein binding with functional activity .


A protein footprint was visible over this region of the c-myb 5' flanking sequence in activated T cells but not in unactivated T cells .
10,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type

An electrophoretic mobility shift assay ( EMSA ) with nuclear extract from activated T cells and an oligonucleotide of this binding site demonstrated a new protein-DNA complex , referred to as CMAT for c-myb in activated T cells ; this complex was not present in unactivated T cells .
12,15 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|35,38 G#cell_type|33,38 G#protein|45,48 G#cell_type

Because the binding site showed some sequence similarity with the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) binding site , we compared the kinetics of induction of the two binding complexes and the molecular masses of the two proteins .
2,4 G#DNA|13,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|10,21 G#DNA

Studies of the kinetics of induction showed that the NFAT EMSA binding complex appeared earlier than the CMAT complex .
9,10 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

The NFAT protein migrated more slowly in a sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel than the CMAT protein did .
1,2 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

In addition , an antibody against NFAT did not cross-react with the CMAT protein .
6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

The appearance of the CMAT binding complex was inhibited by both cyclosporin A and rapamycin .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#protein

The CMAT protein appears to be a novel inducible protein involved in the regulation of c-myb expression during T-cell activation .
1,2 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA

CNI-1493 inhibits monocyte/macrophage tumor necrosis factor by suppression of translation efficiency .
2,6 G#protein

Tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) mediates a wide variety of disease states including septic shock , acute and chronic inflammation , and cachexia .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

Recently , a multivalent guanylhydrazone ( CNI-1493 ) developed as an inhibitor of macrophage activation was shown to suppress TNF production and protect against tissue inflammation and endotoxin lethality [ Bianchi , M. , Ulrich , P. , Bloom , O. , Meistrell , M. , Zimmerman , G.A. , Schmidtmayerova , H. , Bukrinsky , M. , Donnelley , T. , Bucala , R. , Sherry , B. , Manogue , K.R. , Tortolani , A.J. , Cerami , A. &amp; Tracey , K.J. ( 1995 ) Mol.Med.1 , 254-266 , and Bianchi , M. , Bloom , O. , Raabe , T. , Cohen , P. S. , Chesney , J. , Sherry , B. , Schmidtmayerova , H. , Zhang , X. , Bukrinsky , M. , Ulrich , P. , Cerami , A. &amp; Tracey , J. ( 1996 ) J.Exp.Med. , in press ] .
19,20 G#protein

We have now elucidated the mechanism by which CNI-1493 inhibits macrophage TNF synthesis and show here that it acts through suppression of TNF translation efficiency .
11,12 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

CNI-1493 blocked neither the lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) -induced increases in the expression of TNF mRNA nor the translocation of nuclear factor NF-kappa B to the nucleus in macrophages activated by 15 min of LPS stimulation , indicating that CNI-1493 does not interfere with early NF-kappa B -mediated transcriptional regulation of TNF .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA|20,24 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type|45,47 G#protein|51,52 G#protein

However , synthesis of the 26-kDa membrane form of TNF was effectively blocked by CNI-1493 .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Further evidence for the translational suppression of TNF is given by experiments using chloram-phenicol acetyltransferase ( CAT ) constructs containing elements of the TNF gene that are involved in TNF translational regulation .
7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|13,19 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein

Both the 5' and 3' untranslated regions of the TNF gene were required to elicit maximal translational suppression by CNI-1493 .
2,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA

Identification of the molecular target through which CNI-Â 1493 inhibits TNF translation should provide insight into the regulation of macrophage activation and mechanisms of inflammation .
9,10 G#protein

Soluble tumor necrosis factor receptors inhibit phorbol myristate acetate and cytokine-induced HIV-1 expression chronically infected U1 cells .
0,5 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Recombinant human tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) binding protein-1 ( r-h TBP-1 ) and recombinant human soluble dimeric TNF receptor ( rhu TNFR : Fc ) were used to determine the relative contributions of TNF to phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) and cytokine-induced human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) replication in chronically infected cell lines .
6,7 G#protein|0,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

Treatment of HIV-1 -infected promonocytic U1 cells with r-h-TBP-1 or rhu TNFR : Fc reduced PMA -induced HIV-1 p24 antigen production in a concentration-dependent manner , with a maximal inhibition of approximately 90 % .
2,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

Maximal inhibition of p24 antigen production in T-lymphocytic ACH-2 cells was 47 % with r-hTBP-1 and 42 % with rhu TNFR : Fc .
3,5 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

r-hTBP-1 and rhu TNFR : Fc also decreased p24 antigen synthesized by U1 cells in response to other stimuli , including phytohemagglutinin ( PHA ) -induced supernatant , granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor , interleukin-6 , and TNF .
0,1 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|21,27 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

Addition of r-hTBP-1 to U1 cells during the last 4 h of a 24 h incubation with PMA still inhibited p24 antigen production by 15 % .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_line|20,22 G#protein

U1 cells stimulated with 10 ( -7 ) M PMA released approximately 1 ng/ml endogenous TBP-1 with an initial peak observed at 1 h and a second peak at 24 h after PMA stimulation .
0,2 G#cell_line|14,16 G#protein

r-hTBP-1 also partially reversed inhibition of U1 cellular proliferation caused by PMA .
0,1 G#protein

Both r-hTBP-1 and rhu TNFR : Fc blocked PMA induction of nuclear factor ( NK ) -Â kappa B DNA-binding activity in U1 cells in association with decreases in HIV-1 replication .
1,2 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|11,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_line

We conclude that soluble TNF receptors can inhibit stimuli-induced HIV-1 expression and NK-Â kappa B DNA-binding activity in chronically infected U1 cells .
