HIV glycoprotein 120 enhances intercellular adhesion molecule-1 gene expression in glial cells .
0,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

Involvement of Janus kinase /signal transducer and activator of transcription and protein kinase C signaling pathways .
2,4 G#protein|4,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

It is well established that the two major glial cells in the central nervous system ( CNS ) , astrocytes and microglia , are key participants in mediating the neurologic dysfunction associated with HIV infection of the CNS .
8,10 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type

In this study , we investigated the ability of the major envelope glycoprotein of HIV , glycoprotein 120 ( gp120 ) , to regulate intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) expression in glial cells , because ICAM-1 is important in mediating immune responsiveness in the CNS , facilitating entry of HIV -infected cells into the CNS , and promoting syncytia formation .
10,13 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein|50,53 G#cell_type

Our results indicate that gp120 enhances ICAM-1 gene expression in primary rat astrocytes , primary human astrocytes , a human astroglioma cell line CRT , and primary rat microglia .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|10,13 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_type|19,24 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_type|26,29 G#cell_type

The signal transduction events involved in gp120 -mediated enhancement of ICAM-1 appear to involve activation of both protein kinase C and tyrosine kinase , because inhibitors of protein kinase C and tyrosine kinase abrogate gp120 -mediated ICAM-1 expression in both astrocytes and microglia .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|40,41 G#cell_type|42,43 G#cell_type

Moreover , gp120 induces tyrosine phosphorylation of signal transducer and activator of transcription ( STAT-1 alpha ) as well as the Janus kinase ( JAK2 ) in glial cells .
2,3 G#protein|7,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

We also demonstrate that gp120 -mediated ICAM-1 expression has functional significance , as it enhances the ability of monocytic cells to bind to gp120 -stimulated human astrocytes in an ICAM-1 /beta 2 integrin -dependent fashion .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#cell_type|23,27 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

These results provide new insights into how gp120 can influence the involvement of glial cells in the pathogenesis of AIDS dementia complex .
7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

IL-10 cooperates with TNF-alpha to activate HIV-1 from latently and acutely infected cells of monocyte/macrophage lineage .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

IL-10 is elevated in HIV-1 -infected individuals and has been implicated in disease progression .
0,1 G#protein

In this study , we investigated the effects of IL-10 on the activation of HIV-1 from infected monocytes and macrophages .
9,10 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

Although IL-10 alone did not induce HIV-1 replication , in the presence of TNF-alpha , IL-10 markedly enhanced virion production from a chronically infected promonocytic cell line ( U1 ) and in acutely infected monocyte-derived macrophages .
1,2 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_line|34,36 G#cell_type

Neutralizing mAbs to IL-10 and TNF-alpha indicated that both cytokines were essential for the induction and were required to generate a synergistic increase in virus expression .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

The effects of the two cytokines were distinguishable functionally since pretreatment with TNF-alpha attenuated the cytokine cooperativity , while pretreatment with IL-10 potentiated their cooperativity , suggesting that IL-10 and TNF-alpha play different roles in the activation of virus .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Northern blot analysis as well as Ab blocking and cytokine secretion studies indicated that the induction of either endogenous TNF-alpha or IL-10 was not involved in the cooperativity , nor was an up-regulation of TNF-alpha receptors .
9,10 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

In combination with TNF-alpha , IL-10 stimulated activating protein-1 ( AP-1 ) and nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappa B binding activities and cooperated to increase HIV-1 steady-state mRNA levels and enhance long terminal repeat -directed transcription through activation of the NF-kappa B binding sites , suggesting the IL-10 effect occurs at least in part at the transcriptional level .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,20 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA|41,43 G#protein|41,45 G#DNA|48,49 G#protein

These results indicate that IL-10 , in addition to down-regulating the cellular immune response to HIV-1 , may also play a role in TNF-alpha -mediated activation of HIV-1 replication in the monocyte/macrophage lineage .
4,5 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

Interaction of HTLV-I Tax with the human proteasome : implications for NF-kappa B induction .
2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

The human T-cell leukemia virus type I ( HTLV-I ) has been etiologically associated with the development of the adult T-cell leukemia ( ATL ) as well as degenerative neurologic syndrome termed tropical spastic paraparesis ( TSP ) .


HTLV-I encodes a potent transactivator protein termed Tax that appears to play an important role in the process of T-cell immortalization .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Even though the mechanisms by which Tax induces transformation are still unknown , it seems likely that the ability of Tax to alter the expression of many cellular genes plays an important part in this process .
6,7 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA

Tax does not bind directly to DNA but rather deregulates the activity of cellular transcription factors .
0,1 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

One family of host transcription factors whose activity is altered by Tax includes NF-kappa B/Rel .
4,6 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

These transcription factors are post-transcriptionally regulated by their assembly with a second family of inhibitory proteins termed I kappa B that serve to sequester the NF-kappa B/Rel complexes in the cytoplasm .
1,3 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|25,28 G#protein

Upon cellular activation , I kappa B alpha is phosphorylated , polyubiquitinated , and degraded in the proteasome .
4,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

This proteolytic event liberates NF-kappa B , permitting its rapid translocation into the nucleus where it binds to its cognate enhancer elements .
4,6 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA

Similarly , the p105 precursor of the NF-kappa B p50 subunit is also post-translationally processed in the proteasome .
3,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

The mechanisms by which Tax activates NF-kappa B remain unclear , and findings presented in the literature are often controversial .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein

We identified a physical interaction between Tax and the HsN3 subunit of the human proteasome .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

This raises the intriguing possibility that physical association of the HsN3 proteasome subunit with HTLV-I Tax coupled with the independent interaction of Tax with either p100 or p65- I kappa B alpha targets these cytoplasmic NF-kappa B/Rel complexes to the proteasome for processing .
11,12 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,32 G#protein|35,37 G#protein|34,38 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

Immunophenotype of intraductal carcinoma .


OBJECTIVE -- Mammography and breast-conserving therapy have focused attention on the classification of intraductal carcinoma ( IDC ) and emphasized the prognostic importance of comedo versus noncomedo variants .


We used histochemical markers to define the immunophenotype of 43 IDCs with respect to comedo versus noncomedo status and patterns of angiogenesis .


RESULTS -- Reactions in comedo carcinomas were significantly negative for estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor , and positive for p53 and HER-2/neu more often than the noncomedo variant .
10,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

All seven IDCs associated with Paget 's disease showed positive reactions for HER-2/neu .
12,13 G#protein

Basement membrane immunoreactivity for type IV collagen and laminin was discontinuous in most examples of IDC regardless of type , with a trend toward more intense staining in comedo than in noncomedo carcinomas .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Periductal angiogenesis was not significantly related to the type of IDC but was more pronounced with comedo carcinomas .


CONCLUSIONS -- These observations indicate that there are immunophenotypic correlates to the current structural classification of IDC .


The immunophenotype of IDC is helpful in subclassifying an IDC and could prove useful as a prognostic indicator for local control in patients treated by breast-conserving therapy .


Inhibition of protein phosphatase 2A induces serine /threonine phosphorylation , subcellular redistribution , and functional inhibition of STAT3 .
2,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STATs ) are rapidly phosphorylated on tyrosine residues in response to cytokine and growth factor stimulation of cell surface receptors .
0,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

STATs hereafter are translocated to the nucleus where they act as transcription factors .
0,1 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

Recent reports suggest that serine phosphorylation of STATs also is involved in the regulation of STAT -mediated gene transcription .
7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Here , we studied the role of serine /threonine phosphatases in STAT3 signaling in human antigen-specific CD4(+) T cell lines and cutaneous T cell lymphoma lines , expressing a constitutively activated STAT3 .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,20 G#cell_line|21,26 G#cell_line|31,32 G#protein

We show that an inhibitor of protein phosphatases ( PPs ) PP1/PP2A , calyculin A , induces ( i ) phosphorylation of STAT3 on serine and threonine residues , ( ii ) inhibition of STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation and DNA binding activity , and ( iii ) relocation of STAT3 from the nucleus to the cytoplasm .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|48,49 G#protein

Similar results were obtained with other PP2A inhibitors ( okadaic acid , endothall thioanhydride ) but not with inhibitors of PP1 ( tautomycin ) or PP2B ( cyclosporine A ) .
20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Pretreatment with the broad serine /threonine kinase inhibitor staurosporine partly blocked the calyculin A -induced STAT3 phosphorylation , whereas inhibitors of serine /threonine kinases , such as mitogen-activated protein kinase-1 extracellular-regulated kinase-kinase , mitogen-activated protein p38 kinase , and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase , did not .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|27,32 G#protein|33,37 G#protein|39,41 G#protein

In conclusion , we provide evidence that PP2A plays a crucial role in the regulation of STAT3 phosphorylation and subcellular distribution in T cells .
7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type

Moreover , our findings suggest that the level of STAT3 phosphorylation is balanced between a staurosporine -sensitive kinase ( s ) and PP2A .
9,10 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Polyamines in human breast cancer and its relations to classical prognostic features : clinical implications .


Experimental evidence suggest an important role of polyamines in breast cancer development .


Polyamines have been determined in tissue and erythrocyte samples from 100 patients with primary invasive breast cancer and 30 patients with fibroadenomas .


Statistical analysis was performed in order to determine the prognostic value of the polyamine patterns of tumor tissues and erythrocytes in comparison with clinical and histological prognostic factors .


In malignant tissues , polyamine levels were significantly higher than in benign tissues .


They correlated with markers of tumor aggressivity ( axillary node involvement and especially with markers of high mitotic rate as Ki-67 staining , histological grade ) .


No correlation was found between estrogen and progesterone status , tumor size and polyamine concentrations .


Erythrocyte polyamines levels were identical between cancer patients and controls .


The knowledge of the polyamine pattern in breast cancer could become useful in clinical practice particularly if polyamine metabolism is targeted as a therapeutic approach .


Signal transduction pathways triggered by the FcepsilonRIIb receptor ( CD23 ) in human monocytes lead to nuclear factor-kappaB activation .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|16,18 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Alveolar macrophages play a key role in the initiation of the inflammatory reaction of allergic asthma .
2,4 G#cell_type

Alveolar macrophages and peripheral blood monocytes are activated when IgE/allergen immune complexes bind to the CD23 receptor , which leads to the production of inflammatory cytokines .
0,2 G#cell_type|3,6 G#cell_type|9,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

OBJECTIVE : We sought to investigate the molecular mechanisms regulating this early inflammatory response .


We have focused on the study of the signal transduction pathways triggered by CD23 in human monocytes and the promonocytic cell line U937 .
13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|19,23 G#cell_line

METHODS : CD23 was cross-linked in human monocytes and U937 cells with IgE immune complexes .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_line|12,15 G#protein

Surface expression of CD23 was determined by FACS analysis .
3,4 G#protein

Transcription factor activation and gene transcription were studied by gel-shift assays and Northern blot analysis , respectively .
0,2 G#protein

IkappaBalpha phosphorylation and degradation was analyzed by Western blot .
0,1 G#protein

RESULTS : Nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappaB is the main transcription factor involved in the gene activation that follows CD23 cross-linking in monocytes .
2,8 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type

CD23 -induced NF-kappaB is a heterodimer composed of p65/p50 subunits .
0,1 G#protein|0,3 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

NF-kappaB nuclear translocation is secondary to the phosphorylation and subsequent degradation of the NF-kappaB inhibitory molecule IkappaBalpha .
13,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Tyrosine kinase -dependent , and not protein kinase C -dependent , pathways mediate CD23 -triggered NF-kappaB activation but do not participate in the direct phosphorylation of IkappaBalpha .
0,2 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

IkappaBalpha degradation and NF-kappaB nuclear translocation correlate with transcriptional activation of the inflammatory cytokines TNF-alpha and IL-1beta .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : NF-kappaB is the main transcription factor involved in the signal transduction pathway of CD23 in monocytes .
2,3 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

Suppression of TNFalpha -mediated NFkappaB activity by myricetin and other flavonoids through downregulating the activity of IKK in ECV304 cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line

Flavonoids are a group of naturally-occurring phenolic compounds in the plant kingdom , and many flavonoids are found with vascular protective properties .


Nevertheless how the protective response is exerted by flavonoids is not well characterized .


In view of the nuclear factor-kappaB ( NFkappaB ) may play a central role in the initiation of atherosclerosis , prevention of the activation of NFkappaB represents an important role in protecting vascular injury .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

In this study , the effects of flavonoids on NFkappaB /inhibitor-kappaB ( IkappaB ) system in ECV304 cells activated with tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNFalpha ) were examined .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_line|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

We investigated the inhibitory action of six flavonoids on IkappaB kinase ( IKK ) activity , an enzyme recently found to phosphorylate critical serine residues of IkappaB for degradation .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Of six flavonoids tested , myricetin was found to strongly inhibit IKK kinase activity , and prevent the degradation of IkappaBalpha and IkappaBbeta in activated endothelial cells .
11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Furthermore , myricetin was also found to inhibit NFkappaB activity correlated with suppression of monocyte adhesion to ECV304 cells .
8,9 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line

Therefore we conclude that flavonoids may be of therapeutic value for vascular disease through down regulation of NFkappaB /IkappaB system .
17,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Wiley-Liss , Inc .


Bcl-2 -mediated drug resistance : inhibition of apoptosis by blocking nuclear factor of activated T lymphocytes ( NFAT ) -induced Fas ligand transcription .
0,1 G#protein|10,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Bcl-2 inhibits apoptosis induced by a variety of stimuli , including chemotherapy drugs and glucocorticoids .
0,1 G#protein

It is generally accepted that Bcl-2 exerts its antiapoptotic effects mainly by dimerizing with proapoptotic members of the Bcl-2 family such as Bax and Bad .
5,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

However , the mechanism of the antiapoptotic effects is unclear .


Paclitaxel and other drugs that disturb microtubule dynamics kill cells in a Fas /Fas ligand ( FasL ) -dependent manner ; antibody to FasL inhibits paclitaxel-induced apoptosis .
6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

We have found that Bcl-2 overexpression leads to the prevention of chemotherapy ( paclitaxel ) -induced expression of FasL and blocks paclitaxel -induced apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The mechanism of this effect is that Bcl-2 prevents the nuclear translocation of NFAT ( nuclear factor of activated T lymphocytes , a transcription factor activated by microtubule damage ) by binding and sequestering calcineurin , a calcium-dependent phosphatase that must dephosphorylate NFAT to move to the nucleus .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

Without NFAT nuclear translocation , the FasL gene is not transcribed .
1,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Thus , it appears that paclitaxel and other drugs that disturb microtubule function kill cells at least in part through the induction of FasL .
11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Furthermore , Bcl-2 antagonizes drug-induced apoptosis by inhibiting calcineurin activation , blocking NFAT nuclear translocation , and preventing FasL expression .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The effects of Bcl-2 can be overcome , at least partially , through phosphorylation of Bcl-2 .
3,4 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Phosphorylated Bcl-2 can not bind calcineurin , and NFAT activation , FasL expression , and apoptosis can occur after Bcl-2 phosphorylation .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

MHC-peptide ligand interactions establish a functional threshold for antigen-specific T cell recognition .


Antigen-specific T cell recognition is dependent on the functional density of the TCR -ligand , which consists of specific MHC molecules and a specifically bound peptide .
12,13 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

We have examined the influence of the affinity and concentration of exogenous peptide and the density of specific MHC molecules on the proliferation of a CD4+ , DQA1*0501/DQB1*0201 ( DQ2.1 ) -restricted , HSV-2 -specific T cell clone .
18,20 G#protein|25,38 G#cell_line

Using antigen peptide analogs with different mutations of known DQ2-anchor residues , T cell response was reduced in an peptide-affinity and -Â concentration specific manner .


The decrease using weaker binding peptides was gradual as stimulation with a peptide with intermediate affinity yielded intermediate T cell proliferation and the poorest binding peptide induced an even weaker T cell response .
18,20 G#cell_type|30,32 G#cell_type

MHC class II density on the APC was modified using DQ2 homo - and hetero zygous B- LCLs as APCs , however this variation of MHC concentration had no effect on T cell proliferation .
0,3 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|10,18 G#cell_line|19,20 G#cell_type|31,33 G#cell_type

We interpret this as a reflection of a low threshold for activation of the T cell clone , in which peptide- MHC avidity is the over-riding determinant of the strength of ligand signal .
14,16 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

Regulatory effects of interleukin-11 during acute lung inflammatory injury .
3,4 G#protein

The role of interleukin-11 ( IL-11 ) was evaluated in the IgG immune complex model of acute lung injury in rats .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

IL-11 mRNA and protein were both up-regulated during the course of this inflammatory response .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#RNA

Exogenously administered IL-11 substantially reduced , in a dose-dependent manner , the intrapulmonary accumulation of neutrophils and the lung vascular leak of albumin .
2,3 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein

These in vivo anti-inflammatory effects of IL-11 were associated with reduced NF-kappaB activation in lung , reduced levels of tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) in bronchoalveolar lavage ( BAL ) fluids , and diminished up-regulation of lung vascular ICAM-1 .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|38,41 G#protein

It is interesting that IL-11 did not affect BAL fluid content of the CXC chemokines , macrophage inflammatory protein-2 ( MIP-2 ) and cytokine -inducible neutrophil chemoattractant ( CINC ) ; the presence of IL-11 did not affect these chemokines .
4,5 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

However , BAL content of C5a was reduced by IL-11 .
9,10 G#protein

These data indicate that IL-11 is a regulatory cytokine in the lung and that , like other members of this family , its anti-inflammatory properties appear to be linked to its suppression of NF-kappaB activation , diminished production of TNF-alpha , and reduced up-regulation of lung vascular ICAM-1 .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|45,48 G#protein

Thrombopoietin induces tyrosine phosphorylation of Stat3 and Stat5 in human blood platelets .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

Thrombopoietin is known to be essential for megakaryocytopoiesis and thrombopoiesis .
0,1 G#protein

Recently , we and others have shown that thrombopoietin induces rapid tyrosine phosphorylation of Jak2 and other proteins in human platelets and BaF3 cells , genetically engineered to express c-Mpl , a receptor for thrombopoietin .
8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_line|29,30 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

The Jak family of tyrosine kinases are known to mediate some of the effects of cytokines or hematopoietic growth factors by recruitment and tyrosine phosphorylation of a variety of Stat ( signal transducers and activators of transcription ) proteins .
4,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,37 G#protein

Hence , we have investigated whether Stat proteins are present in platelets and , if so , whether they become tyrosine phosphorylated in response to thrombopoietin .
6,8 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

We immunologically identified Stat1 , Stat2 , Stat3 , and Stat5 in human platelet lysates .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Thrombopoietin induced tyrosine phosphorylation of Stat3 and Stat5 in these cells .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Thrombopoietin also induced tyrosine phosphorylation of Stat3 and Stat5 in FDCP-2 cells genetically engineered to constitutively express human c-Mpl .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line|17,19 G#protein

Thus , our data indicate that Stat3 and Stat5 may be involved in signal transduction after ligand binding to c-Mpl and that this event may have a role in megakaryopoiesis/ thrombopoiesis or possibly a mature platelet function such as aggregation .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Mechanisms that contribute to the development of lymphoid malignancies : roles for genetic alterations and cytokine production .
15,16 G#protein

Recent studies have defined genetic alterations commonly associated with transformed lymphocytes .
9,11 G#cell_line

This review suggests roles for these alterations in the development of lymphoid neoplasms .


Damage to the genes encoding proteins that function in intracellular signaling , transcription , or regulation of the cell cycle has been identified and linked at varying degrees to the progression of certain lymphoid malignancies .


An understanding of the mechanistic consequences following such genetic alterations is essential to an understanding of the development of these lymphoid neoplasms .


In contrast , it is also becoming clear that the dysregulated expression of proteins that are not genetically altered can also contribute to the progression of lymphoid malignancies .


One such example is the excessive expression of " normal " lymphokines of cytokines which accompanies many lymphoproliferative diseases .
8,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

The dysregulated expression of cytokines during malignancy can result in the augmentation of growth of transformed lymphocytes , as well as an alteration of the anti-tumor immune response .
4,5 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_line

The latter mechanism is especially important because evasion of the impending immune response is a prerequisite for the progression of lymphoproliferative diseases .


Taken together , this review supports the notion that the development of lymphoid malignancies is multifactorial , involving genetic alterations as well as dysregulated cytokine expression .
24,25 G#protein

Dehydroepiandrosterone modulation of lipopolysaccharide -stimulated monocyte cytotoxicity .


Dehydroepiandrosterone ( DHEA ) , the predominant androgen secreted by the adrenal cortex , can be converted to both potent androgens and estrogens .


In addition to its role as a precursor for other steroid hormones , DHEA has been proposed to play an important role in immunity .


This study has investigated DHEA modulation of LPS -induced monocyte cytotoxicity .


Cytotoxicity markers assessed include tumor cell killing , IL-1 secretion , reactive oxygen intermediate release , nitric oxide synthetase activity as measured by the release of reactive nitrogen intermediates , complement receptor-1 cell surface protein , and TNF-alpha protein presence .
0,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|30,35 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

Monocytes stimulated with LPS concentrations of 1.0 micrograms/ml displayed the above cytotoxic markers , whereas monocytes stimulated with DHEA alone or with LPS at a lower concentration of 0.2 ng/ml did not .
0,1 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type

However , when used simultaneously , DHEA and LPS 0.2 ng/ml displayed a synergistic effect on monocyte cytotoxicity against cancerous cell lines , IL-1 secretion , reactive nitrogen intermediate release , complement receptor-1 cell-surface protein , and TNF-alpha protein to levels comparable with levels obtained using LPS 1.0 microgram/ml .
19,22 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein|31,35 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

Finally , Scatchard plot analysis demonstrated the presence of a DHEA receptor in monocytes , suggesting that DHEA effects on LPS -stimulated monocytes are mediated through a receptor-dependent process .
13,14 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type|20,23 G#cell_line

Interferons inhibit activation of STAT6 by interleukin 4 in human monocytes by inducing SOCS-1 gene expression .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#DNA

Interferons ( IFNs ) inhibit induction by IL-4 of multiple genes in human monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

However , the mechanism by which IFNs mediate this inhibition has not been defined .
6,7 G#protein

IL-4 activates gene expression by inducing tyrosine phosphorylation , homodimerization , and nuclear translocation of the latent transcription factor , STAT6 ( signal transducer and activator of transcription-6 ) .
0,1 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,28 G#protein

STAT6 -responsive elements are characteristically present in the promoters of IL-4 -inducible genes .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA

Because STAT6 activation is essential for IL-4 -induced gene expression , we examined the ability of type I and type II IFNs to regulate activation of STAT6 by IL-4 in primary human monocytes .
1,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_type

Pretreatment of monocytes with IFN-beta or IFN-gamma , but not IL-1 , IL-2 , macrophage colony-stimulating factor , granulocyte/macrophage colony-stimulating factor , IL-6 , or transforming growth factor beta suppressed activation of STAT6 by IL-4 .
2,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

This inhibition was associated with decreased tyrosine phosphorylation and nuclear translocation of STAT6 and was not evident unless the cells were preincubated with IFN for at least 1 hr before IL-4 stimulation .
12,13 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Furthermore , inhibition by IFN could be blocked by cotreatment with actinomycin D and correlated temporally with induction of the JAK/STAT inhibitory gene , SOCS-1 .
4,5 G#protein|20,23 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA

Forced expression of SOCS-1 in a macrophage cell line , RAW264 , markedly suppressed trans-activation of an IL-4 -inducible reporter as well as IL-6- and IFN-gamma- induced reporter gene activity .
3,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

These findings demonstrate that IFNs inhibit IL-4 -induced activation of STAT6 and STAT6 -dependent gene expression , at least in part , by inducing expression of SOCS-1 .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|26,27 G#DNA

An activation-responsive element in single C motif-1/lymphotactin promoter is a site of constitutive and inducible DNA-protein interactions involving nuclear factor of activated T cell .
5,8 G#DNA|18,24 G#protein

Single C motif-1 ( SCM-1 ) /lymphotactin is a C-type chemokine whose expression is activation dependent , cyclosporin A sensitive and restricted to CD8+ T cells , double-negative thymocytes , gammadelta-type T cells , and NK cells .
0,3 G#protein|0,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|23,26 G#cell_type|27,29 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_type|35,37 G#cell_type

In humans , there are two highly homologous genes encoding SCM-1alpha and SCM-1beta .
7,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Here we examined the regulatory mechanism of the SCM-1 genes .
8,10 G#DNA

The luciferase reporter gene under the control of the 5' flanking region of 0.7 kb was strongly induced upon activation with anti-CD3 or PHA plus PMA only in SCM-1-producer T cell lines through a cyclosporin A-sensitive mechanism .
1,4 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_line

An element termed E1 located at -108 to -95 nt relative to the major transcription start site was found to be critical for the promoter activity .
3,4 G#DNA|6,10 G#DNA

In electrophoretic mobility shift assays using the E1 oligonucleotide as probe , nuclear extracts from unstimulated T and B cell lines formed a constitutive complex termed complex I , while nuclear extracts from stimulated SCM-1-producer T cell lines formed a higher mobility complex termed complex II with a concomitant decrease in complex I .
7,8 G#DNA|18,21 G#cell_line|23,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|34,38 G#cell_line|40,43 G#protein|44,46 G#protein|51,53 G#protein

The shift from complex I to complex II seen only in SCM-1-producer T cell lines upon activation was completely suppressed by cyclosporin A .
3,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_line

Both complexes were critically dependent on the NF-AT core sequence TTTCC in the E1 element and were partially supershifted by anti-NF-ATp .
7,10 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

One-hybrid assays in yeast isolated NF-ATp as an E1 binding protein , and transfection of NF-ATp into T and B cell lines strongly enhanced the activation-dependent SCM-1 promoter activity .
3,6 G#protein|8,9 G#DNA|8,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,22 G#cell_line|25,27 G#protein

Collectively , a unique mechanism involving NF-ATp appears to regulate the cell type-specific and activation-dependent expression of the SCM-1 genes .
6,7 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

Dopamine stimulates expression of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 via NF-kappaB in cells of the immune system .
11,12 G#protein

Recent studies have reported that lymphocytes produce , transport and bind dopamine present in plasma .
5,6 G#cell_type

However , the action of dopamine on HIV-1 gene expression in cells of the immune system has not yet been examined .


Here , we have investigated the regulation of HIV-1 expression by dopamine in Jurkat T cells and in primary blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) .
13,16 G#cell_line|18,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type

HIV-1 replication was increased by dopamine , which correlated with the increased levels of HIV-1 transactivation .


Our transient expression data revealed that dopamine stimulated transcription through the NF-kappaB element present in the long terminal repeat .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA

The importance of NF-kappaB sites was confirmed by using vectors containing wild-type or mutant kappaB sites in a heterologous promoter .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|11,16 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA

Consistent with the role of NF-kappaB in mediating dopamine responsiveness , the proteasome inhibitor MG132 abolished dopamine -induced transcriptional activation .
5,6 G#protein

We further explored the effect of dopamine in the presence of phorbol esters or tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) known to activate NF-kappaB .
14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

The combination of dopamine and TNF-alpha led to a stimulation of HIV-1 transcription and replication .
5,6 G#protein

However , in contrast with TNF-alpha , dopamine treatment did not affect NF-kappaB DNA binding activity nor the concentrations of p50 , p65 and IkappaB-alpha proteins , which suggests a distinct NF-kappaB activation mechanism .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

These results reveal a new link between the dopamine system , cytokine signaling pathway and regulation of gene expression via the involvement of NF-kappaB in T cells and PBMC .
11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_type

[ Hormonal metabolic status in breast cancer patients after conservative surgery : comparison with known prognostic criteria ]


Body weight , body mass index , body fat , lean body mass , blood-glucose , cholesterol , HDL-cholesterol , triglyceride , beta-lipoproteins , insulin , gonadotropin , estradiol , testosterone , SHBG , T3 , T4 and TSH levels as well as estradiol and progesterone receptor levels in excised tumor were studied in 40 patients with breast cancer prior to conservative treatment .
18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Said anthropometric , metabolic and hormonal parameters were compared with the index of lymphocytic infiltration of tumor selected as a prognostic factor .


A significant correlation between high lymphocytic infiltration ( 2.5 points ) , low body mass and fat was identified .


Also , smoking contributed to loss of body mass and fat ; however , it caused lymphocytic infiltration to rise .


Moderate body mass , relatively low fat level and positive receptor status are among factors of good prognosis in breast cancer of early stages .


Selective DNA-binding activity of interleukin-10 -stimulated STAT molecules in human monocytes .
4,5 G#protein|4,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

It has been demonstrated that interferon-gamma ( IFN-gamma ) and interleukin-10 ( IL-10 ) have various reverse effects on macrophages ; however , the molecular mechanism of this difference has not been fully understood .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

In this study , we analyzed the binding activity of IL-10- and IFN-gamma- activated STAT molecules to two kinds of GAS -motif sequences .
10,16 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA

IL-10 -activated STAT1 could bind to the GAS-motif sequence in the promoter region of the Fcgamma receptor , but not to that in the promoter region of the COX-2 gene , whereas IFN-gamma -activated STAT1 and STAT5 could bind to both sequences .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|0,3 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|15,17 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|32,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

IL-10 inhibited IFN-gamma -induced STAT activation without newly synthesized protein .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,10 G#protein

We further demonstrated that aspirin , but not dexamethasone , suppressed IFN-gamma -induced STAT activation .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Taken together , these results suggest that IL-10-activated STAT1 has a specificity in binding to the GAS-motif sequences , whereas IFN-gamma -activated STAT1 and STAT5 have a broader spectrum in binding to the GAS-motif sequences .
8,9 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA

This may explain the difference between IL-10 and IFN-gamma in biological activity , and the inhibitory effect of IL-10 on IFN-gamma activities .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Peptide binding affinity and pH variation establish functional thresholds for activation of HLA-DQ -restricted T cell recognition .
12,13 G#DNA

Peptides derived from the HSV-2 VP16 protein were utilized for studies of peptide binding to DQ0302 molecules and T cell activation at both neutral and acidic pH .
4,7 G#protein

The native peptide VP16 430-444 contains an Asp at position 442 , binds to DQ0302 strongly , with a Kd value of 50nM at acidic pH and very weakly , with a Kd value of greater than 10 microM at neutral pH .
9,11 G#protein

A truncated version of 430-444 , i.e. , VP16 433-442 , binds with an affinity 10-fold lower compared to 430-444 at acidic pH , and binding at neutral pH was barely detectable .


The homologous peptide 430-444,442A has an Asp to Ala substitution at position 442 and binds to DQ0302 with a Kd similar to 433-442 .


The short truncated analog 433-442A binds very poorly at both acidic and neutral pH .


Both the wild type 430-444 and 433-442 peptides stimulated a HSV-specific T cell clone after a brief incubation with antigen presenting cells ( APC ) expressing DQ0302 at acidic pH .
19,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type

Much higher concentrations of wild type peptides were needed to activate T cells at neutral pH .
11,13 G#cell_type

In contrast , APC pulsed with Ala -substituted peptides 430-444 , 442A or 433-442A at neutral pH failed to stimulate the T cell clone , while APC pulsed at acidic pH and subsequently washed led to successful T cell activation .
3,4 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_line|26,27 G#cell_type

The Ala -substituted peptide was recognized by the T cell clone at neutral pH only when it was present in the APC culture throughout the stimulation process .
8,11 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_line

While the MHC-peptide complexes formed with the native peptide are stable , complexes formed with the Ala -substituted peptide had a functional t1/2 of less than 4 hr at neutral pH .
2,4 G#protein

ETS transcription factors regulate an enhancer activity in the third intron of TNF-alpha .
0,3 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein

We describe an enhancer site in the third intron of tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) .
7,9 G#DNA|10,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

A reporter construct containing the 5'-flanking region of the mouse TNF-alpha gene displayed weak activity when transfected into RAW264.7 macrophage-like cells .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|18,21 G#cell_line

The addition of the third intron of TNF-alpha to this construct resulted in an enhancement of CAT protein .
4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

This enhancement was eliminated if a conserved 20-bp sequence was removed from the intron or if a dominant-negative ets-binding factor was co-transfected with the reporter gene .
6,9 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|17,20 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA

Mutations of this site that destroyed potential ets transcription factor binding sites had reduced transcriptional activity .
7,10 G#protein|7,12 G#DNA

The major transcription factor that bound to the oligonucleotide was confirmed to be GABP by supershift and competition analysis .
13,14 G#protein

In RAW264.7 cells , the binding was constitutive , however , in bone marrow-derived macrophages binding activity was shown to be interferon-gamma inducible .
1,3 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

This may imply a role for ets transcription factors in the production of TNF-alpha .

E2F-1 blocks terminal differentiation and causes proliferation in transgenic megakaryocytes .
0,1 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

The transcription factor E2F-1 plays a central role in the cell cycle through its ability to activate genes involved in cell division .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA

E2F-1 activity is regulated by a number of proteins , including the retinoblastoma susceptibility gene product , cyclin-dependent kinases , and their inhibitors , proteins that have been implicated in the control of certain developmental processes .
0,1 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein

To investigate a potential role of E2F-1 in differentiation , we assayed the ability of megakaryocytes to form platelets in an in vivo transgenic model .
6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type

E2F-1 expression in megakaryocytes blocked differentiation during maturation , resulting in severe thrombocytopenia .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#cell_type

Ultrastructural analysis of megakaryocytes revealed abnormal development characterized by hyperdemarcation of cytoplasmic membranes and reduced numbers of alpha granules .
3,4 G#cell_type

Administration of megakaryocyte growth and development factor or interleukin 6 could not overcome the differentiation block .
2,3 G#cell_type|2,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Additionally , E2F-1 caused massive megakaryocyte accumulation in both normal and ectopic sites , first evident in E15 embryonic liver .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type

Furthermore , significant apoptosis was observed in transgenic megakaryocytes .
8,9 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type

These data indicate that E2F-1 can prevent terminal differentiation , probably through its cell cycle -stimulatory activity .
4,5 G#protein

Polymorphic nucleotides within the human IL-4 promoter that mediate overexpression of the gene .
5,6 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA

Atopy , which predisposes individuals to develop asthma , severe systemic anaphylaxis , and atopic dermatitis , is usually associated with dramatically elevated total serum IgE levels and is thought to be controlled by a major susceptibility gene and multiple minor susceptibility genes .
25,26 G#protein|36,38 G#DNA|41,43 G#DNA

A recent sib-pair analysis revealed a tight linkage between markers on 5q31.1 and a major susceptibility gene controlling total serum IgE levels .
11,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

Due to its location within this cluster and its biologic role in Ig class switching and Th2 cell differentiation , the IL-4 gene has emerged as one major candidate for the atopy gene .
16,18 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA|31,33 G#DNA

In one model , polymorphisms within IL-4 regulatory elements might result in overexpression of the gene , amplifying Th2 cell differentiation and class switching to IgE .
6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein

In support of this model , we report that the human IL-4 promoter exists in multiple allelic forms that exhibit distinct transcriptional activities in IL-4 -positive T cells .
11,12 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|24,28 G#cell_type

A particular allele has an unusually high transcriptional activity .


A nucleotide substitution within a recently described OAP40 element located just upstream of an NF-AT site ( P sequence ) appears to be largely responsible for the increased promotor strength of this particular allelic form of the IL-4 promoter .
7,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#DNA

In EMSAs , this substitution results in a markedly enhanced affinity for sequence-specific complexes exhibiting an AP-1 specificity .
16,17 G#protein

The identification of allelic nucleotides , which results in overexpression of the IL-4 gene , provides specific targets for a comprehensive screening of atopic and nonatopic individuals and may provide a clue for genetic predisposition for atopy .
12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

Evidence for lowered induction of nuclear factor kappa B in activated human T lymphocytes during aging .
5,9 G#protein|10,14 G#cell_type

Transcription factor NF kappa B ( nuclear factor kappa B ) is induced in T lymphocytes from young individuals following activation with a variety of stimuli including anti-CD3 , phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) , and tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) .
2,5 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|37,40 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

In contrast , activated T lymphocytes from older individuals show a significant reduction in the induction of NF kappa B in response to the same stimuli .
4,6 G#cell_type|17,20 G#protein

The age-related decline in induction of NF kappa B could not be attributed to alteration in the composition of subunits , p50 and p65 were found to be the predominant subunits of induced NF kappa B in T cells from young as well as elderly donors .
6,9 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type

Furthermore , similar levels of NF kappa B were found in the cytosols of unactivated T cells from both young and elderly donors suggesting that precursor levels of NF kappa B remain unaltered during aging .
5,8 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|28,31 G#protein

These results suggest that an age-associated decline in the induction of NF kappa B in activated T cells from elderly individuals may be attributable to altered regulation of the inhibitor , I kappa B , and may play an important role in immune dysregulation accompanying aging .
11,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|31,34 G#protein

Inhibition of lipopolysaccharide -induced monocyte interleukin-1 receptor antagonist synthesis by cortisol : involvement of the mineralocorticoid receptor .
4,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Glucocorticoids , as a part of their physiological role in the control of inflammatory and immune processes , suppress the expression of interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) and other cytokines .
22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Human monocyte IL-1 receptor antagonist ( IL-1ra ) messenger ribonucleic acid ( mRNA ) expression and protein secretion are inhibited by dexamethasone .
2,3 G#protein|0,5 G#protein|0,11 G#RNA

We have now further studied the regulation of IL-1ra by the major physiological human glucocorticoid , cortisol .
8,9 G#protein

We found that cortisol incubation induced a decrease in IL-1ra mRNA expression and a significant inhibition of IL-1ra protein secretion in cell cultures of human peripheral monocytes stimulated with the bacterial endotoxin lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#RNA|17,19 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_type

Oral administration of 276 mumol cortisol to normal subjects also decreased LPS -induced IL-1ra synthesis in cultured monocytes .
13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_line

By coincubating the monocytes with either the mineralocorticoid antagonist spironolactone or the glucocorticoid receptor antagonist RU 38486 , the in vitro cortisol -induced inhibition of LPS -stimulated IL-1ra secretion was partially reversed .
3,4 G#cell_type|12,14 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The mineralocorticoid aldosterone exerted a significant decrease in LPS -induced monocyte IL-1ra secretion in vitro , which was blocked by coincubation with spironolactone .
11,12 G#protein

In addition , the expression of mineralocorticoid receptor mRNA in human monocytes was observed by PCR of reversed transcribed RNA .
6,8 G#protein|6,9 G#RNA|11,12 G#cell_type|17,20 G#RNA

Our results further indicate that corticosteroids physiologically control the IL-1/ IL-1ra system during inflammatory or immune processes .
10,11 G#protein

Moreover , we provide evidence that , in addition to a glucocorticoid receptor -mediated effect , the mineralocorticoid receptor is involved in the inhibition of monocyte IL-1ra secretion by cortisol .
11,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Target structures of the CD8(+)-T-cell response to human cytomegalovirus : the 72-kilodalton major immediate-early protein revisited .
11,15 G#protein

Cell-mediated immunity plays an essential role in the control of infection with the human cytomegalovirus ( HCMV ) .


However , only a few CD8(+)-T-cell epitopes are known , with the majority being contained in the pp65 phosphoprotein , which is believed to dominate the CD8(+)-T-cell response to HCMV .
5,7 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Here , we have readdressed the issue of CD8(+) T cells specific for the 72-kDa major immediate-early protein ( IE-1 ) , which is nonstructural but is found very early and throughout the replicative cycle .
8,11 G#cell_type|14,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Using a novel flow-cytometric assay , we were able to identify CD8(+)-T-cell epitopes ( by IE-1 peptide-specific induction of cytokine synthesis ) and simultaneously measure the frequency of cells directed against them .
11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

For this purpose , 81 pentadecamer peptides covering the complete 491-amino-acid sequence of IE-1 were tested on peripheral blood mononuclear cells of anti- HCMV immunoglobulin G-seropositive donors .
10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_type

At least 10 new epitopes were identified , and the fine specificity and presenting HLA molecule of the first of them was determined .
4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

The frequencies of CD8(+) T cells directed against IE-1 were similar to those directed against pp65 in donors tested with known pp65 -derived peptides .
3,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Importantly , additional testing of a corresponding set of peptides covering the complete sequence of pp65 on 10 of these donors identified individuals whose CD8(+) T cells recognized IE-1 but not pp65 and vice versa , clearly illustrating that either protein may be a major target .
15,16 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

In summary , our results suggest that IE-1 is far more important as a CD8(+)-T-cell target than current opinion suggests .
7,8 G#protein

E1A oncogene induction of cellular susceptibility to killing by cytolytic lymphocytes through target cell sensitization to apoptotic injury .
0,2 G#DNA|9,11 G#cell_type

E1A oncogene expression increases mammalian cell susceptibility to lysis by cytolytic lymphocytes ( CLs ) at a stage in this intercellular interaction that is independent of cell surface recognition events .
0,2 G#DNA|10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

Since CLs can induce either apoptotic or necrotic cell death , we asked whether E1A sensitization to injury-induced apoptosis is sufficient to explain E1A -induced cytolytic susceptibility .
1,2 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Mouse , rat , hamster , and human cells that were rendered cytolytic susceptible by E1A were also sensitized to CL-induced and chemically induced apoptosis .
0,9 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

In contrast , E1A -positive cells were no more susceptible to injury-induced necrosis than E1A -negative cells .
3,4 G#protein|3,6 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Similar to induction of cytolytic susceptibility and in contrast to other E1A activities , cellular sensitization to chemically induced apoptosis depended on high-level E1A oncoprotein expression .
11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Loss of both cytolytic susceptibility and sensitization to chemically induced apoptosis was coselected during in vivo selection of E1A -positive sarcoma cells for increased tumorigenicity .
18,19 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_type

Furthermore , E1A mutant proteins that can not bind the cellular transcriptional coactivator , p300 , and that fail to induce cytolytic susceptibility also failed to sensitize cells to injury-induced apoptosis .
2,3 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

These data indicate that E1A induces susceptibility to killer cell-induced lysis through sensitization of cells to injury-induced apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein

TCL1 oncogene expression in AIDS-related lymphomas and lymphoid tissues .
0,2 G#DNA

AIDS-related non-Hodgkin 's lymphoma ( AIDS NHL ) comprises a diverse and heterogeneous group of high-grade B cell tumors .


Certain classes of AIDS NHL are associated with alterations in oncogenes or tumor-suppressor genes or infections by oncogenic herpesviruses .
10,11 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

However , the clinically significant class of AIDS NHL designated immunoblastic lymphoma plasmacytoid ( AIDS IBLP ) lacks any consistent genetic alterations .


We identified the TCL1 oncogene from a set of AIDS IBLP -associated cDNA fragments generated by subtractive hybridization with non- AIDS IBLP .
3,5 G#DNA|9,14 G#DNA

Aberrant TCL1 expression has been implicated in T cell leukemia/lymphoma development , and its expression also has been seen in many established B cell tumor lines .
1,2 G#protein|22,26 G#cell_line

However , TCL1 expression has not been reported in AIDS NHL .
2,3 G#protein

We find that TCL1 is expressed in the majority of AIDS IBLP tumors examined .
3,4 G#protein

TCL1 protein expression is restricted to tumor cells in AIDS IBLP tissue samples analyzed with immunohistochemical staining .
0,1 G#protein

Hyperplastic lymph node and tonsil also exhibit strong TCL1 protein expression in mantle zone B cells and in rare interfollicular zone cells , whereas follicle-center B cells ( centroblasts and centrocytes ) show weaker expression .
8,9 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_type|24,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_type|30,31 G#cell_type

These results establish TCL1 as the most prevalent of all of the surveyed oncogenes associated with AIDS IBLP .
3,4 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA

They also indicate that abundant TCL1 expression in quiescent mantle zone B cells is down-regulated in activated germinal center follicular B cells in parallel to the known expression pattern of BCL-2 .
5,6 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type|8,13 G#cell_type|17,22 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein

High-level expression in nonproliferating B cells suggests that TCL1 may function in protecting naive preactivated B cells from apoptosis .
3,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type

IL-2 -independent activation and proliferation in human T cells induced by CD28 .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein

Although the role of CD28 in T cell costimulation is firmly established , the mechanisms by which it exerts its costimulatory actions are less clear .
4,5 G#protein

In many circumstances it is difficult to distinguish the effects of CD28 from subsequent actions of cytokines , such as IL-2 , on T cell proliferation .
11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Here , we report a model of CD28 costimulation using PMA plus the natural ligand CD80 that resulted in very limited stimulation of IL-2 , as evidenced by both cytokine production and IL-2 promoter stimulation .
7,8 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|32,34 G#DNA

Promoter assays revealed CD28 -dependent effects on both NF-kappaB and AP-1 , but not on NF-AT or the intact IL-2 promoter .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

In addition , T cell proliferation was completely resistant to the actions of the immunosuppressant cyclosporin A ( CsA ) .


Moreover T cell proliferation was unaffected by the addition of blocking Abs to both IL-2 and the IL-2 receptor , demonstrating that this form of costimulation by CD28 was independent of IL-2 .
11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

We also investigated the effects of stimulating T cell blasts with CD80 alone and found that there was a limited requirement for IL-2 in this system .
7,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We conclude that CD28 costimulation can cause substantial T cell proliferation in the absence of IL-2 , which is driven by a soluble factor independent of NF-AT transactivation .
3,4 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

The Epstein-Barr virus latency BamHI-Q promoter is positively regulated by STATs and Zta interference with JAK /STAT activation leads to loss of BamHI-Q promoter activity .
1,6 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA

In Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) -associated tumors in nonimmunocompromised patients , EBV gene expression is highly restricted .


EBV-encoded nuclear antigen ( EBNA ) -1 is expressed , whereas the immunogenic and proliferative EBNAs are not .
4,5 G#protein|0,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

This pattern of EBNA expression is generated by usage of the BamHI-Q promoter ( Qp ) .
3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA

We have determined that the JAK /STAT pathway positively regulates Qp activity .
5,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA

In transient-transfection assays , a Qp -CAT reporter was activated by cotransfected JAK-1 and by treatment of cells with the cytokine IL-6 .
5,6 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The ability of Qp to bind signal transducer and activator of transcription ( STAT ) proteins was directly demonstrated by electrophoretic mobility-shift assay , and mutation of potential STAT-binding sites reduced Qp responsiveness to Janus kinase ( JAK ) -1 .
3,4 G#DNA|6,16 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA|34,40 G#protein

Consistent with a role for STATs in Qp function , Qp using Burkitt 's lymphoma Rael cells and cultured nasopharyngeal carcinoma ( NPC ) cells contained nuclear STAT protein .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|12,17 G#cell_line|18,25 G#cell_type|27,29 G#protein

We investigated whether the inability to maintain EBV-positive NPC cell lines in culture was related to Qp activity .
7,11 G#cell_line|16,17 G#DNA

Passaging of the NPC cell line HK666 led to activation of expression of BZLF1 , which encodes Zta and loss of Qp function .
3,7 G#cell_line|13,14 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA

Transient expression assays linked Zta expression to the down-regulation of Qp .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA

Cotransfection of Zta reduced Qp activity in reporter assays .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#DNA

This negative regulation required Zta DNA-binding activity .
4,5 G#protein

We provide evidence that Zta up-regulation of p53 leads to p53 -mediated interference with JAK /STAT activation of Qp .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#DNA

The data imply that JAK /STAT signaling has a role in EBV-associated malignancies .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Reactive oxygen intermediate -release of fibre -exposed monocytes increases inflammatory cytokine -mRNA level , protein tyrosine kinase and NF-kappaB activity in co-cultured bronchial epithelial cells ( BEAS-2B ) .
5,8 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#RNA|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_line|26,27 G#cell_line

Some pulmonary diseases like bronchitis or asthma bronchiale are mediated by inflammatory mechanisms in bronchial epithelial cells .
14,17 G#cell_type

Alveolar macrophages are located directly in the surrounding of these cells , so that we suppose an interaction between epithelial cells and macrophages regarding to the release of inflammatory mediators .
0,2 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type|28,30 G#protein

For measuring the contribution of macrophages to the release of inflammatory mediators by bronchial epithelial cells , we established an in vitro model of co-cultured blood monocytes ( BM ) and BEAS-2B cells in a transwell system ( Costar ) .

BM were exposed to Chrysotile B and soot particle FR 101 in a concentration of 100 microg/10 ( 6 ) cells .
0,1 G#cell_type

After up to 90 min exposure time ELISA , EMSA ( electromobility shift assay ) and RT- PCR were used to measure protein tyrosine kinase activity , protein activity of NF-kappaB and cytokine ( IL-1beta , IL-6 , TNF-alpha ) specific mRNA levels in BEAS-2B cells .
22,25 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|41,42 G#RNA|44,46 G#cell_type

We observed an increase in protein tyrosine kinase activity ( up to 1.8 +/- 0.5-fold ) and NF-kappaB protein activity in BEAS-2B cells after particle or fibre exposure of co-cultured BM .
5,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|30,31 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_line

Consecutive IL-1beta- , IL-6- and TNF-alpha- mRNA were elevated ( up to 1.9 +/- 0.58-fold ) .
1,7 G#RNA

Protein tyrosine kinase activity , NF-kappaB activity , and the synthesis of cytokine -specific mRNA were inhibited by antioxidants .
0,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#RNA

These data suggest a ROI-dependent NF-kappaB mediated transcription of inflammatory cytokines in bronchial epithelial cells .

Suppression of the human immunodeficiency virus long terminal repeat by CD8+ T cells is dependent on the NFAT-1 element .
3,9 G#DNA|10,13 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

CD8+ T lymphocytes of HIV-1 infected individuals produce a soluble factor that efficiently suppresses HIV-1 replication at the transcriptional level .
0,3 G#cell_type|9,11 G#protein

We show here that the response of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) to mitogenic or Tat -mediated activation is sensitive to the suppressive action of a Herpesvirus saimiri ( HVS ) -transformed CD8+ T cell clone from an HIV-infected individual and supernatants from CD8+ T cells of HIV-1 -infected asymptomatic subjects ( CD4+ &gt; 350/microliters ) .
13,14 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|29,39 G#cell_line|46,49 G#cell_type|55,56 G#protein

Mutagenesis of NF kappa B or Sp-1 elements within the LTR resulted in no change in the ability of CD8+ T cell supernatants to inhibit Tat- or mitogen- mediated LTR transcription .
2,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|19,22 G#cell_type

However , the response to HIV-1 Tat by a LTR in which the interleukin ( IL ) -2 homology NFAT-1 region was mutated resulted in almost complete elimination of suppression by CD8+ T cells .
6,7 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|13,21 G#DNA|31,34 G#cell_type

This was not observed when the NFAT-1 mutant LTR was activated by mitogen .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein

We have previously shown that gene expression directed by the HIV-1 NF kappa B elements is inhibited by CD8 + cell- derived supernatants ( Copeland et al. , AIDS Res Hum Retroviruses , 1995 ; 11 : 1321-1326 ) .
11,14 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein

Taken together , these observations suggest that mitogenic activation , mediated primarily through the NF kappa B enhancer , is susceptible to CD8 -mediated inhibition , however , inhibition of Tat -mediated activation may rely upon a different pathway that is NFAT-1 dependent .
14,17 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

Inhibition of NF-kappa B activation in human T-cell lines by anetholdithiolthione .
2,4 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_line

Nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappa B is a redox sensitive cytosolic transcription factor .
0,7 G#protein|9,14 G#protein

Redox regulation of NF-kappa B has been implicated in the activation of the human immuno-deficiency virus ( HIV ) .
3,5 G#protein

Therefore , inhibition of NF-kappa B activation may be an effective strategy for acquired immunodeficiency syndrome therapy .
4,6 G#protein

Anetholdithiolthione ( ADT , 5-[p-methoxyphenyl]-3H-1,2-dithiol-3-thione ) is an antioxidant which has been used to protect against acetaminophen- and CCl4- induced hepatotoxicity , lipid peroxidation , radiation injury , and also has been used clinically as an anti-choleretic agent .


The present study examined the effect of ADT pretreatment on NF-kappa B activation in response to a variety of stimuli such as H2O2 , phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) or tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF alpha ) .
10,12 G#protein|31,35 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

PMA and TNF alpha induced activation of ( NF ) -kappa B in human Jurkat T-cells was partially inhibited by ADT ( 0.1 mM ) pretreatment .
2,4 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line

ADT ( 0.1 mM ) also inhibited H2O2 induced activation of the transcription factor in the peroxide sensitive human Wurzburg T-cells .
12,14 G#protein|16,21 G#cell_line

Furthermore , ADT treated Wurzburg cells had significantly higher glutathione levels as compared with untreated cells .
4,6 G#cell_line|14,16 G#cell_type

H2O2 induced lipid peroxidation in Wurzburg cells was remarkably inhibited by ADT pretreatment .
5,7 G#cell_line

ADT , a pro- glutathione antioxidant , was observed to be capable of modulating NF-kappa B activation .
14,16 G#protein

Involvement of tyrosine phosphorylation in endothelial adhesion molecule induction .
5,8 G#protein

Induction of endothelial adhesion molecules by the cytokine tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF ) can occur independently of protein kinase C and activation of a protein tyrosine kinase ( PTK ) has recently been implicated in the upregulation of vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 ( VCAM-1 ) by interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) on endothelial cells .
2,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|39,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|53,55 G#cell_type

We demonstrate that the PTK inhibitors herbimycin A or genistein suppress induction of endothelial VCAM-1 and E-selectin , as well as subsequent monocytic cell adhesion to endothelial cells stimulated by TNF .
4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein

Inhibition studies indicate that specific tyrosine phosphorylation following PTK activation is involved in the mobilization of the transcription factor , nuclear factor kappa B , and VCAM-1 mRNA expression .
8,9 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#RNA

This may have implications for pathophysiological conditions that involve the upregulation of these molecules ( e.g. inflammation and atherosclerosis ) .


Protein kinase C-zeta mediates NF-kappa B activation in human immunodeficiency virus -infected monocytes .
0,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_type

The molecular mechanisms regulating human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) persistence in a major cell reservoir such as the macrophage remain unknown .
19,20 G#cell_type

NF-kappa B is a transcription factor involved in the regulation of the HIV long terminal repeat and is selectively activated following HIV infection of human macrophages .
0,2 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|12,16 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_type

Although little information as to what signal transduction pathways mediate NF-kappa B activation in monocytes-macrophages is available , our previous work indicated that classical protein kinase C ( PKC ) isoenzymes were not involved in the HIV -mediated NF-kappa B activation .
10,12 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|24,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|24,31 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

In this study , we have focused on atypical PKC isoenzymes .
9,11 G#protein

PKC-zeta belongs to this family and is known to be an important step in NF-kappa B activation in other cell systems .
0,1 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Immunoblotting experiments with U937 cells demonstrate that PKC-zeta is present in these cells , and its expression can be downmodulated by antisense oligonucleotides ( AO ) .
3,5 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein

The HIV -mediated NF-kappa B activation is selectively reduced by AO to PKC-zeta .
3,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In addition , cotransfection of a negative dominant molecule of PKC-zeta ( PKC-zeta mut ) with NF-kappa B -dependent reporter genes selectively inhibits the HIV - but not phorbol myristate acetate- or lipopolysaccharide- mediated activation of NF-kappa B .
10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

That PKC-zeta is specific in regulating NF-kappa B is concluded from the inability of PKC-zeta ( mut ) to interfere with the basal or phorbol myristate acetate -inducible CREB - or AP1 -dependent transcriptional activity .
1,2 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Lastly , we demonstrate a selective inhibition of p24 production by HIV -infected human macrophages when treated with AO to PKC-zeta .
8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|11,15 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein

Altogether , these results suggest that atypical PKC isoenzymes , including PKC-zeta , participate in the signal transduction pathways by which HIV infection results in the activation of NF-kappa B in human monocytic cells and macrophages .
6,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|31,34 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type

Induction of Bcl-x ( L ) expression by human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 Tax through NF-kappaB in apoptosis-resistant T-cell transfectants with Tax .
2,6 G#protein|8,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein

Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) Tax is thought to play a pivotal role in immortalization of T cells .
9,10 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

We have recently shown that the expression of Tax protected the mouse T-cell line CTLL-2 against apoptosis induced by interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) deprivation and converted its growth from being IL-2 dependent to being IL-2 independent .
8,9 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

In this study , we demonstrate that constitutive expression of bcl-xl but not bcl-2 , bcl-xs , bak , bad , or bax was associated with apoptosis resistance after IL-2 deprivation in CTLL-2 cells that expressed Tax .
10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_line|36,37 G#protein

Transient-transfection assays showed that bcl-x promoter was transactivated by wild-type Tax .
4,6 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

Similar effects were observed in mutant Tax retaining transactivating ability through NF-kappaB .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Deletion or substitution of a putative NF-kappaB binding site identified in the bcl-x promoter significantly decreased Tax -induced transactivation .
6,7 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

This NF-kappaB -like element was able to form a complex with NF-kappaB family proteins in vitro .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

Furthermore , Tax -induced transactivation of the bcl-x promoter was also diminished by the mutant IkappaBalpha , which specifically inhibits NF-kappaB activity .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Our findings suggest that constitutive expression of Bcl-x ( L ) induced by Tax through the NF-kappaB pathway contributes to the inhibition of apoptosis in CTLL-2 cells after IL-2 deprivation .
7,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_line|28,29 G#protein

The beta-globin promoter is important for recruitment of erythroid Kruppel-like factor to the locus control region in erythroid cells .
1,3 G#DNA|8,11 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_type

Erythroid Kruppel-like factor ( EKLF ) , which binds to the CACCC box in the beta-globin promoter , is required for the expression of the beta-globin gene in adult erythroid cells .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA|28,31 G#cell_type

It was recently demonstrated that EKLF is also required for the activity of the beta-globin locus control region ( LCR ) 5'HS3 .
5,6 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA

Some evidence suggests that the LCR and the beta-globin promoter interact in adult erythroid cells , and the network of protein-protein interactions that exists between these two elements may regulate how EKLF is recruited to the LCR .
5,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#cell_type|31,32 G#protein|36,37 G#DNA

In this report , we use the PIN*POINT assay to study the role of the promoter on the recruitment of EKLF to 5'HS2 and 5'HS3 of the LCR .
20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA

We find that recruitment of EKLF to 5'HS2 requires the TATA box , but recruitment to 5'HS3 depends on the CACCC and TATA boxes of the beta-globin promoter .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA

Furthermore , recruitment of EKLF to 5'HS3 only occurred in beta-globin-expressing murine erythroid leukemia cells , whereas recruitment of EKLF to 5'HS2 occurred in both gamma-globin-expressing K562 cells and murine erythroid leukemia cells .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#DNA|10,15 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA|25,28 G#cell_line|29,33 G#cell_type

Unlike EKLF , Sp1 , which also binds to CACCC boxes , is not recruited to 5'HS3 .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|16,17 G#DNA

We have also examined how one 5'HS affects the recruitment of EKLF to another 5'HS .
6,7 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA

We have found that the recruitment of EKLF to 5'HS3 depends on the presence of 5'HS2 in cis , but the recruitment to 5'HS2 does not depend on 5'HS3 .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA

Based on these results , we present a model that illustrates how EKLF may be recruited to the beta-globin locus .
12,13 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

Estrogen decreases TNF gene expression by blocking JNK activity and the resulting production of c-Jun and JunD .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Central to the bone-sparing effect of estrogen ( E ( 2 ) ) is its ability to block the monocytic production of the osteoclastogenic cytokine TNF-alpha ( TNF ) .
23,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

However , the mechanism by which E ( 2 ) downregulates TNF production is presently unknown .
11,12 G#protein

Transient transfection studies in HeLa cells , an E ( 2 ) receptor-negative line , suggest that E ( 2 ) inhibits TNF gene expression through an effect mediated by estrogen receptor beta ( ERbeta ) .
4,6 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|30,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

We also report that in RAW 264.7 cells , an E ( 2 ) receptor-positive murine monocytic line , E ( 2 ) downregulates cytokine-induced TNF gene expression by decreasing the activity of the Jun NH(2)-terminal kinase ( JNK ) .
5,8 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

The resulting diminished phosphorylation of c-Jun and JunD at their NH(2)-termini decreases the ability of these nuclear proteins to autostimulate the expression of the c-Jun and JunD genes , thus leading to lower production of c-Jun and JunD .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|24,28 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

The consequent decrease in the nuclear levels of c-Jun and JunD leads to diminished binding of c-Jun /c-Fos and JunD /c-Fos heterodimers to the AP-1 consensus sequence in the TNF promoter and , thus , to decreased transactivation of the TNF gene .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA|40,41 G#protein|40,42 G#DNA

Cutting edge : TCR stimulation by antibody and bacterial superantigen induces Stat3 activation in human T cells .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Recent data show that TCR/CD3 stimulation induces activation of Stat5 in murine T cells .
4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

Here , we show that CD3 ligation by mAb and Staphylococcal enterotoxin ( SE ) induce a rapid , gradually accumulating , long-lasting tyrosine , and serine phosphorylation of Stat3 ( but not Stat5 ) in allogen-specific human CD4+ T cell lines .
29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,42 G#cell_line

In contrast , IL-2 induces a rapid and transient tyrosine and serine phosphorylation of Stat3 .
3,4 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Compared with IL-2 , CD3 ligation induces a delayed Stat3 binding to oligonucleotide probes from the ICAM-1 and IL-2R alpha promoter .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

CD3 -mediated activation of Stat3 is almost completely inhibited by a Src kinase inhibitor ( PP1 ) , whereas IL-2 -induced Stat3 activation is unaffected .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

In conclusion , we show that CD3 ligation by mAb and SE triggers a rapid , PP1 -sensitive tyrosine and serine phosphorylation of Stat3 in human CD4+ T cells .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|25,29 G#cell_type

Moreover , we provide evidence that TCR/ CD3 and IL-2 induce Stat3 activation via distinct signaling pathways .
7,8 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Distinctive gene expression patterns in human mammary epithelial cells and breast cancers .
5,9 G#cell_type

cDNA microarrays and a clustering algorithm were used to identify patterns of gene expression in human mammary epithelial cells growing in culture and in primary human breast tumors .
0,2 G#DNA|15,19 G#cell_type

Clusters of coexpressed genes identified through manipulations of mammary epithelial cells in vitro also showed consistent patterns of variation in expression among breast tumor samples .
2,4 G#DNA|8,11 G#cell_type

By using immunohistochemistry with antibodies against proteins encoded by a particular gene in a cluster , the identity of the cell type within the tumor specimen that contributed the observed gene expression pattern could be determined .


Clusters of genes with coherent expression patterns in cultured cells and in the breast tumors samples could be related to specific features of biological variation among the samples .
2,3 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_type

Two such clusters were found to have patterns that correlated with variation in cell proliferation rates and with activation of the IFN -regulated signal transduction pathway , respectively .
21,22 G#protein

Clusters of genes expressed by stromal cells and lymphocytes in the breast tumors also were identified in this analysis .
2,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#cell_type
