These results support the feasibility and usefulness of this systematic approach to studying variation in gene expression patterns in human cancers as a means to dissect and classify solid tumors .


PPARgamma activation induces the expression of the adipocyte fatty acid binding protein gene in human monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|7,13 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type

The peroxisome-proliferator activated receptor gamma ( PPARgamma ) , a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily of ligand activated transcription factors , plays a key role in the anti-diabetic actions of the thiazolidinediones ( TZDs ) .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

PPARgamma induces the expression of many genes involved in lipid anabolism , including the adipocyte fatty acid binding protein ( aP2 ) , and is a key regulator of adipocyte differentiation .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#DNA|14,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

PPARgamma is also expressed in hematopoietic cells and is up-regulated in activated monocytes/ macrophages .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|12,14 G#cell_type

Activation of PPARgamma may play a role in the induction of differentiation of macrophages to foam cells that are associated with atherosclerotic lesions .
2,3 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type

We report that both natural and synthetic PPARgamma agonists induce time- and dose-dependent increases in aP2 mRNA in both primary human monocytes and the monocytic cell line , THP-1 .
15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#RNA|20,22 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_type|24,27 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_line

These data suggest that PPARgamma activation may play a role in monocyte differentiation and function analogous to its well-characterized role in adipocytes .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

Identification of a physical interaction between calcineurin and nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFATp ) .
6,7 G#protein|8,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

In T lymphocytes , the calcium/calmodulin-dependent serine/threonine phosphatase , calcineurin , plays a pivotal role in transducing membrane-associated signals to the nucleus .
1,3 G#cell_type|5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

One of the putative targets of calcineurin is the pre-existing , cytosolic component of the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFATp ; also referred to as NFAT1 ) , which is one of several transcription factors required for the expression of interleukin 2 .
6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|43,45 G#protein

Inhibition of calcineurin by the immunosuppressive drugs cyclosporin A and FK506 prevents dephosphorylation of NFATp and its translocation to the nucleus .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

However , a physical interaction between calcineurin and NFATp has not been demonstrated .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Here we demonstrate the binding of NFATp from lysates of T cells to immobilized calcineurin .
6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

Stimulation of T cells with calcium ionophore induced a shift in the molecular weight of NFATp that is due to its dephosphorylation .
2,4 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

This dephosphorylation was inhibited by treatment of T cells with cyclosporin A or FK506 prior to stimulation .
7,9 G#cell_type

Of note , both the phosphorylated and the dephosphorylated form of NFATp bound to calcineurin .
11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Furthermore , the binding of both forms of NFATp to calcineurin was inhibited by pretreatment of calcineurin with a complex of FK506 and its ligand FKBP12 .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Taken together these data strongly suggest a direct interaction of calcineurin with NFATp and that this interaction does not depend upon the phosphorylation sites of NFATp affected by activation .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein

Cross-linking CD40 on B cells preferentially induces stress-activated protein kinases rather than mitogen-activated protein kinases .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|7,10 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

The B cell-associated surface molecule CD40 plays a key role in T cell-dependent B cell maturation , as individuals with defects in either CD40 or its ligand are impaired in immunoglobulin isotype class switching and germinal center formation .
1,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

CD40 signaling activates downstream effectors , including the tyrosine protein kinase , Lyn , the phosphatidylinositol-3-kinase ( PI-3 kinase ) , and the transcription factor , NF-kappa B .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

In this study , we demonstrate that stress-activated protein kinases ( SAPK ) are activated after CD40 cross-linking on various B cell lines or human tonsillar B cells .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,23 G#cell_line|26,28 G#cell_type|24,28 G#cell_type

The activation is rapid and transient and is mediated through a cyclosporin A -insensitive pathway .


Furthermore , this signaling pathway appears not to rely on protein kinase C .
10,13 G#protein

While CD40 ligation strongly activates the SAPKs ( up to 25-fold ) , it does not affect members of the mitogen-activated protein kinase family ( MAPK ; ERK1 and ERK2 ) .
1,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Consistent with these data , CD40 signals up-regulate c-jun but not c-fos mRNA and alter the transcription factor ATF2 but not the Raf-1 protein .
5,6 G#protein|8,13 G#RNA|16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

In summary , CD40 signaling preferentially induces SAPK but not MAPK .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Stimulation of the T-cell antigen receptor-CD3 complex signaling pathway by the tyrosine phosphatase inhibitor pervanadate is mediated by inhibition of CD45 : evidence for two interconnected Lck/Fyn- or zap-70- dependent signaling pathways .
3,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

The tyrosine phosphatase specific inhibitor pervanadate is a potent activator of T lymphocytes through induction of tyrosine phosphorylation and downstream events of the activation cascade .
1,3 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|16,18 G#protein

Using CD45- or CD3- negative variants of the Jurkat leukemic T-cell line we show that the different biochemical events induced by pervanadate appeared to be dependent on the presence at the cell surface of either CD45 or CD3 .
1,6 G#cell_line|8,12 G#cell_line|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

CD45 -dependent events such as tyrosine phosphorylation of Shc , activation of nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) , activator protein-1 ( AP-1 ) , transcription factors , and stimulation of interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) promoter and of CD69 and CD25 surface expression paralleled activation of the tyrosine kinases lck and fyn .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|32,37 G#DNA|39,40 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|48,50 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|52,53 G#protein

By contrast , stimulation of calcium influx , a CD3 -dependent event , paralleled zap-70 activation .
9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The data demonstrate that the T-cell antigen receptor -CD3 ( TcR- CD3 ) complex is functionally linked to two different protein tyrosine kinase ( PTK ) modules with separate specific functions and that CD45 may be an important regulator of this coupling .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|8,14 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Vitamin D analogs , 20-Epi-22-oxa-24a,26a,27a,-trihomo-1alpha,25(OH)2- vitamin D3 , 1,24(OH)2-22-ene-24-cyclopropyl-vitamin D3 and 1alpha,25(OH)2-lumisterol3 prime NB4 leukemia cells for monocytic differentiation via nongenomic signaling pathways , involving calcium and calpain .
13,16 G#cell_line

Side-chain modified vitamin D analogs including 20-Epi-22-oxa-24a,26a,27a-trihomo-1alpha,2 5-dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( KH1060 ) , and 1,24-dihydroxy-22-ene-24-cyclopropyl-vitamin D3 ( MC903 ) were originally designed to aid in the treatment of hyperproliferative disorders including psoriasis and cancer .


Here we demonstrate that these analogs , as well as the 6-cis-locked conformer , 1alpha,25-dihydroxy-lumisterol3 ( JN ) prime NB4 cells for monocytic differentiation .
14,21 G#cell_line

Previously , the action of MC903 and KH1060 was presumed to be mediated by the nuclear vitamin D receptor ( VDRnuc ) .
15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Differentiation in response to all analogs was shown to be inhibited by 1beta,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( HL ) , the antagonist to the nongenomic activities of 1,25D3 .


These data suggest that although MC903 and KH1060 may bind the VDRnuc , that the differentiative activities of these agents requires nongenomic signaling pathways .
11,12 G#protein

Here we show that 1alpha,25(OH)2-d5-previtamin D3 ( HF ) , JN , KH1060 , and MC903 induce expression of PKC alpha and PKC delta and translocation of both isoforms to the particulate fraction , and PKC alpha to the nuclear fraction .
19,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

The full differentiation response with combinations of analogs and TPA was inhibited 50 % by the membrane permeable Ca2+ chelator , 1,2-bis(o-aminophenoxy)-ethane-N,N,N',N'-tetraacetic acid ( BAPTA-AM ) or calpain inhibitor I .
27,28 G#protein

These data demonstrate that intracellular free calcium and the calcium -dependent protease , calpain play critical roles in monocytic differentiation .
9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Intracellular calcium appears to be most critical in the 1,25D3 -priming stage of differentiation , while calpain is essential in the TPA maturation response .
16,17 G#protein

Neutrophil maturation and the role of retinoic acid .
0,1 G#cell_type

Neutrophil maturation occurs in well defined morphological stages that correlate with the acquisition of molecular markers associated with neutrophil function .
0,1 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein

A variety of factors are known to play a role in terminal neutrophil maturation , including the vitamin A derivative , retinoic acid .
12,13 G#cell_type

Retinoic acid can directly modulate gene expression via binding to its nuclear receptors , which can , in turn , activate transcription of target genes .
11,13 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA

A role for retinoic acid during neutrophil maturation has been suggested from a variety of sources . Here we present a review of the mechanism of retinoic acid receptor action and the major evidence showing that normal retinoid signaling is required for neutrophil maturation .
6,7 G#cell_type|26,29 G#protein|42,43 G#cell_type

Human T-cell lymphotrophic virus type-I tax gene induces secretion of human macrophage inflammatory protein-1alpha .
0,7 G#DNA|10,14 G#protein

Human T-cell lymphotropic virus I ( HTLV-I ) encodes for a 40-kDa protein , Tax , which is important for the immortalization of T cells .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

Tax has been shown to transactivate several cellular genes .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA

In this study , we show that MIP-1alpha is selectively expressed and secreted in the tax transfected Jurkat cell line upon mitogen stimulation .
7,8 G#protein|15,20 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

Expression of MIP-1alpha-R mRNA in these cells suggests an autocrine role for this chemokine in HTLV-I infected T-cells .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#RNA|13,14 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type

Induced MIP-1alpha expression and secretion in PMA/PHA stimulated tax transfected cells correlate with the noninduction of MNP-1 transcription factor , which is intimately involved in downmodulating the MIP-1alpha gene .
1,2 G#protein|6,11 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Dendritic cells and the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis .
0,2 G#cell_type

Rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) is a chronic autoimmune inflammatory disease in which unknown arthrogenic autoantigen is presented to CD4 + T cells .
14,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_type

The strong association of the disease with an epitope within the HLA-DR chain shared between various alleles of HLA-DR4 and DR1 emphasizes the importance of antigen presentation .
8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

This immune response predominantly occurs in the synovial tissue and fluid of the joints and autoreactive T cells are readily demonstrable in both the synovial compartment and blood .
16,18 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type

Circulating dendritic cells ( DC ) are phenotypically and functionally identical with normal peripheral blood ( PB ) DC .
0,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|12,19 G#cell_type

In the synovial tissue , fully differentiated perivascular DC are found in close association with T cells and with B cell follicles , sometimes containing follicular DC .
7,9 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_type|25,27 G#cell_type

These perivascular DC migrate across the activated endothelium from blood and receive differentiative signals within the joint from monocyte-derived cytokines and CD40 -ligand+ T cells .
1,3 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|21,25 G#cell_type

In the SF , DC manifest an intermediate phenotype , similar to that of monocyte-derived DC in vitro .
4,5 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

Like a delayed-type hypersensitivity response , the rheumatoid synovium represents an effector site .


DC at many effector sites have a characteristic pattern of infiltration and differentiation .


It is important to note that the effector response is not self-limiting in RA autoimmune inflammation .


In this article , we argue that the presentation of self-antigen by DC and by autoantibody-producing B cells is critical for the perpetuation of the autoimmune response .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type

Permanently arresting this ongoing immune response with either pharmaceutical agents or immunotherapy is a major challenge for immunology .


Thymocyte-thymic epithelial cell interaction leads to high-level replication of human immunodeficiency virus exclusively in mature CD4 (+) CD8(-) CD3 (+) thymocytes : a critical role for tumor necrosis factor and interleukin-7 .
1,3 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|14,21 G#cell_type|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

This work aims at identifying the thymocyte subpopulation able to support human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) replication under the biological stimuli of the thymic microenvironment .


In this report we demonstrate that interaction with thymic epithelial cells ( TEC ) induces a high-level replication of the T-tropic primary isolate HIV-1 ( B-LAIp ) exclusively in the mature CD4 (+) CD8(-) CD3 (+) thymocytes .
8,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|20,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|31,37 G#cell_type

Tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) and interleukin-7 ( IL-7 ) , secreted during this interaction , are critical cytokines for HIV long terminal repeat transactivation through NF-kappaB -dependent activation .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|21,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

TNF is the major inducer of NF-kappaB and particularly of the p50-p65 complex , whereas IL-7 acts as a cofactor by sustaining the expression of the p75 TNF receptor .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

The requirement for TNF is further confirmed by the observation that the inability of the intermediate CD4 (+) CD8(-) CD3 (-) thymocytes to replicate the virus is associated with a defect in TNF production during their interaction with TEC and correlates with the absence of nuclear NF-kappaB activity in these freshly isolated thymocytes .
3,4 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|15,22 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein|38,39 G#cell_type|46,47 G#protein|50,53 G#cell_type

Addition of exogenous TNF to the intermediate thymocyte cultures induces NF-kappaB activity and is sufficient to promote HIV replication in the cocultures with TEC .
3,4 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type

The other major subpopulation expressing the CD4 receptor , namely , the double-positive ( DP ) CD4 (+) CD8(+) CD3 (+/-) thymocytes , despite the entry of the virus , do not produce a significant level of virus , presumably because they are unresponsive to TNF and IL-7 .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|12,22 G#cell_type|45,46 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

Together , these data suggest that in vivo , despite an efficient entry of the virus in all the CD4 (+) subpopulations , a high viral load may be generated exclusively within the mature CD4 (+) CD8(-) CD3 (+) subset of thymocytes .
19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type|34,35 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|33,42 G#cell_type

However , under conditions of inflammatory response after infection , TNF might also be present in the intermediate thymocyte compartment , leading to efficient HIV replication in these cells .
10,11 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type

NF-kappaB -mediated up-regulation of Bcl-x and Bfl-1/A1 is required for CD40 survival signaling in B lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|0,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

Activation of CD40 is essential for thymus-dependent humoral immune responses and rescuing B cells from apoptosis .
2,3 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

Many of the effects of CD40 are believed to be achieved through altered gene expression .
5,6 G#protein

In addition to Bcl-x , a known CD40 -regulated antiapoptotic molecule , we identified a related antiapoptotic molecule , A1/Bfl-1 , as a CD40 -inducible gene .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA

Inhibition of the NF-kappaB pathway by overexpression of a dominant-active inhibitor of NF-kappaB abolished CD40 -induced up-regulation of both the Bfl-1 and Bcl-x genes and also eliminated the ability of CD40 to rescue Fas -induced cell death .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Within the upstream promoter region of Bcl-x , a potential NF-kappaB -binding sequence was found to support NF-kappaB -dependent transcriptional activation .
2,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein

Furthermore , expression of physiological levels of Bcl-x protected B cells from Fas-mediated apoptosis in the absence of NF-kappaB signaling .
7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|7,11 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Thus , our results suggest that CD40 -mediated cell survival proceeds through NF-kappaB -dependent up-regulation of Bcl-2 family members .
6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

Stimulation of neutrophil interleukin-8 production by eosinophil granule major basic protein .
2,3 G#cell_type|3,4 G#protein|6,11 G#protein

We evaluated the ability of eosinophil granule major basic protein ( MBP ) to stimulate interleukin ( IL ) -8 production by neutrophils .
5,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,20 G#protein|22,23 G#cell_type

MBP over the concentration range of 0.1 to 10 microM stimulated the release of up to approximately 8 ng/ml IL-8 .
0,1 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Incubation with 2 microM MBP showed that , after a 1 h lag , the level of IL-8 release increased with time for approximately 10 h .
4,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

At the 2 microM concentration , eosinophil cationic protein , eosinophil-derived neurotoxin , and eosinophil peroxidase did not stimulate significant levels of IL-8 production .
6,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

MBP stimulated 2-fold increases in IL-8 messenger RNA ( mRNA ) after 1 and 3 h of incubation , which were blocked by pretreatment with actinomycin D .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#RNA|9,10 G#RNA

However , stimulation with MBP did not produce an increase in the binding activity of nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappaB or activator protein-1 .
4,5 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

No NF-IL-6 binding activity was detected in the same nuclear extracts .
1,2 G#protein

In addition , stimulation with MBP prolonged the stability of IL-8 mRNA .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#RNA

MBP also induced transient increases in mRNA for macrophage inflammatory protein ( MIP ) -1alpha and MIP-1beta , but did not stimulate the release of either chemokine .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#RNA|8,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

These findings indicate that MBP is selective among the eosinophil granule proteins as a stimulus for neutrophil IL-8 release and , further , that stimulation of neutrophil IL-8 release by MBP involves both transcriptional and posttranscriptional regulation .
4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|26,27 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

We postulate that MBP -induced release of IL-8 by neutrophils may contribute to the pathophysiology of acute asthma and other inflammatory lung diseases .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type

Expression of either the TCL1 oncogene , or transcripts from its homologue MTCP1/c6.1B , in leukaemic and non-leukaemic T cells from ataxia telangiectasia patients .
4,6 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|17,20 G#cell_type

Patients with the recessively inherited disorder ataxia telangiectasia ( A-T ) have a high level of specific chromosome translocations which can be easily observed in peripheral T cells and show a greatly increased predisposition to leukaemia/lymphoma , mainly of T cell origin .
17,19 G#DNA|25,28 G#cell_type|39,41 G#cell_type

Some translocation cells proliferate into a large clone and may develop into T cell prolymphocytic leukaemia ( T-PLL ) .
1,3 G#cell_type

By the time of diagnosis of T-PLL , the clone contains many more genetic changes in the form of additional translocations .


T-PLL is also seen in non- A-T individuals where expression of either TCL1 ( at 14q32 ) or the c6.1B/MTCP1 A1 transcript ( at-Xq28 ) has been demonstrated in just a few instances .
12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA|19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#DNA

We show here , that expression of TCL1 occurs in leukaemic T cells from A-T patients with chromosome 14 rearrangements .
7,8 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type|17,19 G#DNA

Expression of TCL1 also occurs in the preleukaemic clone cells of A-T patients containing the primary translocation alone .
2,3 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type

Some expression of TCL1 could also be detected in randomly selected A-T patients without large cytogenetic clones and without any evidence of leukaemic change .
3,4 G#protein

We also show that expression of the B1 transcript from a second gene , MTCP1 , occurred at a relatively high level only in two T-PLL tumours from A-T patients with t(X;14) translocations whereas the MTCP1 /A1 transcript is much more widely expressed in both tumour and non tumour cells of A-T and non- A-T individuals .
7,9 G#RNA|14,15 G#DNA|35,36 G#DNA|35,38 G#RNA|45,50 G#cell_type

[ Correlation of lymphocytic infiltration of tumor tissue with the hormonal and metabolic state in patients with breast cancer ]


Lymphocyte infiltration of tumor was studied vis-a-vis hormone metabolic status , tumor tissue hormone sensitivity and tobacco smoking , in 113 breast cancer patients , aged 25-77 .


On the average , no correlation was established between degree of lymphocyte infiltration in breast tumor and age and menopause onset .


In smoking menopausal patients , lymphocyte infiltration was found to be higher than in non-smokers ( p &lt; 0.05 ) .


There was a direct correlation between the rate of lymphocyte infiltration and the level of progesterone receptors in tumor .
15,17 G#protein

Some subgroups displayed a direct correlation between infiltration and sex-binding globulin , cholesterol , luteinizing hormone in blood , and lean body mass .
9,11 G#protein

It was matched by an inverse correlation between lymphocyte infiltration and blood-thyroid hormone concentration , urine catecholamines and free cortisol excretion and fat/lean body mass ratio .


Considering the abovesaid as well as the lymphocyte ability to perform the dual function of immunocytes and hormonocytes , it is suggested that the results may be used in both the study of lymphocyte infiltration and research in means of its control .
15,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type

Gene transcription through activation of G-protein-coupled chemoattractant receptors .
5,8 G#protein

Receptors for leukocyte chemoattractants , including chemokines , are traditionally considered to be responsible for the activation of special leukocyte functions such as chemotaxis , degranulation , and the release of superoxide anions .
2,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Recently , these G-protein-coupled serpentine receptors have been found to transduce signals leading to gene transcription and translation in leukocytes .
3,6 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

Transcription factors , such as NF kappa B and AP-1 , are activated upon stimulation of the cells with several chemoattractants at physiologically relevant concentrations .
0,2 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Activation of transcription factors through these receptors involves G-protein coupling and the activation of protein kinases .
8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

The underlying signaling pathways appear to be different from those utilized by TNF-alpha , a better characterized cytokine that induces the transcription of immediate-early genes .
12,13 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA

Chemoattractants stimulate the expression of several inflammatory cytokines and chemokines , which in turn may activate their respective receptors and initiate an autocrine regulatory mechanism for persistent cytokine and chemokine gene expression .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Affinity-driven peptide selection of an NFAT inhibitor more selective than cyclosporin A [ see comments ]


The flow of information from calcium-mobilizing receptors to nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) -dependent genes is critically dependent on interaction between the phosphatase calcineurin and the transcription factor NFAT .
5,7 G#protein|8,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|8,19 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

A high-affinity calcineurin -binding peptide was selected from combinatorial peptide libraries based on the calcineurin docking motif of NFAT .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

This peptide potently inhibited NFAT activation and NFAT -dependent expression of endogenous cytokine genes in T cells , without affecting the expression of other cytokines that require calcineurin but not NFAT .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Substitution of the optimized peptide sequence into the natural calcineurin docking site increased the calcineurin responsiveness of NFAT .
9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Compounds that interfere selectively with the calcineurin -NFAT interaction without affecting calcineurin phosphatase activity may be useful as therapeutic agents that are less toxic than current drugs .
6,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

9-cis retinoic acid induces monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 secretion in human monocytic THP-1 cells .
4,7 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|9,13 G#cell_type

Monocyte migration and activation are regulated by monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 ( MCP-1 ) .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Prior studies have shown MCP-1 expression is modulated by a variety of ligands that act through extracellular receptors .
4,5 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

In the current study , we show 9-cis retinoic acid ( RA ) , a ligand for the nuclear hormone receptor retinoid X receptor ( RXR ) and retinoic acid receptor ( RAR ) , markedly induces the expression of MCP-1 .
18,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

In human THP-1 monocytic leukemia cells cultured with RA ( 0.05 to 500 nmol/L ) , MCP-1 expression was induced rapidly , significantly , and dose-dependently by as much as 165-fold .
1,6 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein

MCP-1 RNA level was also increased in RA -treated cells .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#RNA

Expression of PPARgamma , a heterodimer partner of RXR , is also markedly induced by RA in THP-1 cells .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type

However , BRL49653 , a PPARgamma ligand , failed to induce MCP-1 secretion either alone or to modify the expression level induced by RA .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

In contrast , BRL49653 significantly increased MCP-1 ( biotinylated MCP-1 ) binding to THP-1 cells , whereas RA had no effect .
6,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Other peroxisome proliferator activated receptor ( PPAR ) ligands , 15d-PGJ ( 2 ) and troglitazone ( PPARgamma ) , Wy14 , 643 ( PPARalpha ) , and PD195599 ( PPARbeta ) inhibited the induction of MCP-1 by RA .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

RA 's effect on MCP-1 expression in human elutriated monocytes were similar to that observed in the THP-1 cells .
4,5 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line

These studies identify RA as a nuclear signal for MCP-1 induction in undifferentiated human monocytic cells .
9,10 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type

These studies also suggest monocyte MCP-1 expression induced through RA may modulate cell migration .
5,6 G#protein

Classification of IVS1-10T --&gt; C as a polymorphism of BRCA1 .
9,10 G#DNA

Mutations inactivating the tumor suppressor gene BRCA1 may be responsible for disease for up to 80 % of familial ovarian cancer cases .
3,6 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA

In this syndrome , tumorigenesis classically initiates from an inherited mutation in one allele followed by somatic deletion of the normal allele .
13,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

Sequencing of BRCA1 amplified from genomic DNA of lymphocytes and microdissected ovarian tumor cells of a familial ovarian cancer patient revealed three , rare heterozygous DNA variations ( 2418delA , 233G --&gt; A , and IVS1-10T --&gt; C ) in both tumor and constitutional ( lymphocyte ) DNA .
2,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#cell_type|10,14 G#cell_type|41,48 G#DNA

Thus , both copies of BRCA1 were retained in tumor .
5,6 G#DNA

Haplotype analysis of the patient and four siblings assigned 2418delA to one copy of BRCA1 and 233G --&gt; A and IVS1-10T --&gt; C to the other .
14,15 G#DNA

The DNA change , 2418delA , is considered a mutation that inactivated one BRCA1 allele because it caused a frameshift and generation of a premature stop codon , resulting in synthesis of a truncated peptide as evidenced by an in vitro protein truncation test .
13,14 G#DNA|24,27 G#DNA

The DNA variation , 233G --&gt; A , does not result in an amino acid change , and is considered a benign polymorphism .


IVS1-10T --&gt; C is a unique BRCA1 change that occurs in the last nucleotide of a consensus sequence for a branch site critical for RNA splicing .
6,7 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

Therefore , we investigated whether IVS1-10T --&gt; C deleteriously affected BRCA1 splicing or expression , and thereby inactivated the other BRCA1 allele .
10,11 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

Using the technique of reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) with RNA isolated from lymphoid cell lines of the patient and of controls , no evidence was found that IVS1-10TC abnormally disrupted mRNA splicing or caused the absence of BRCA1 mRNA .
15,18 G#cell_line|33,34 G#RNA|40,41 G#DNA|40,42 G#RNA

Thus , IVS1-10T --&gt; C is not harmful to BRCA1 function , and is classified a benign polymorphism .
9,10 G#DNA

Retention of the normal BRCA1 allele in the tumor with the heterozygous germline BRCA1 mutation , 2418delA , indicated that mutational inactivation of both BRCA1 alleles was not required for tumorigenesis .
4,5 G#DNA|4,6 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA

It is possible that the normal allele may be functionally inactivated by a nonmutational mechanism .
5,7 G#DNA

Myb-transformed hematopoietic cells as a model for monocyte differentiation into dendritic cells and macrophages .
1,3 G#cell_type|0,3 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

Immune induction is effected through the interaction of antigen-presenting cells with specific receptors on the surface of thymus-derived lymphocytes .
8,10 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

Cells most able to ingest , process , and present antigen appear to be related to the mononuclear phagocyte/neutrophil series .
17,20 G#cell_type

For example dendritic cells ( DC ) can be found in colonies of GM-CSF-responsive bone marrow cells , and under experimental conditions are routinely expanded as a population in vitro from GM-CSF-responsive progenitor cells .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#cell_type|13,17 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_type

To address the question of DC lineage and to determine what genes are involved in lineage commitment , we have generated a series of GM-CSF-responsive cell lines that can be induced to differentiate in a homogeneous manner in vitro .
5,6 G#cell_type|5,7 G#cell_type|24,27 G#cell_line

The cloned cell lines are derived from 12-day fetal liver and are transformed with a truncated form of c-myb , which lacks the normal autoregulatory sequences .
1,4 G#cell_line|18,19 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA

As far as we know , these myb-transformed hemopoi-etic cells ( MTHC ) differ from normal only in the unregulated expression of myb , a gene whose expression is obligatory for proliferation of hemopoietic cells .
7,10 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_line

MTHC in the presence of TNF-alpha and IL-4 will differentiate into cells that have many of the properties of macrophages .
0,1 G#cell_line|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

When the same MTHC lines are exposed to TNF-alpha in combination with IFN-gamma , the cells instead become DC .
3,4 G#cell_line|3,5 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type

The differentiated DC are potent presenters of antigen in mixed lymphocyte reactions and of soluble antigen to specific T cell lines .
2,3 G#cell_type|18,21 G#cell_line

Thus , cells with the properties of both macrophages and DC can be derived from a single type of GM-CSF-responsive progenitor cell .
8,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_type

We have used this MTHC system to analyze differences in gene expression as the cells mature along the DC and macrophage pathways .
4,5 G#cell_line|4,6 G#cell_line|18,19 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type

A distinctive pattern of differentially expressed cDNAs is evident where macrophage-specific cDNAs are homologous to genes encoding cytoskeletal and cell-surface proteins , whereas the DC -specific cDNAs are homologous to signaling , chemokine , and IFN-gamma-inducible genes .
6,7 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|17,21 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type|26,27 G#DNA|30,37 G#DNA

We discuss the utility of MTHC in analyzing the relationships between DC and macrophages , and suggest that DC and macrophages represent extreme phenotypes in a spectrum of antigen handling cells that are somewhat interchangeable , depending on their immediate environment .
5,6 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type|28,31 G#cell_type

The Legionella pneumophila rpoS gene is required for growth within Acanthamoeba castellanii .
3,5 G#DNA

To investigate regulatory networks in Legionella pneumophila , the gene encoding the homolog of the Escherichia coli stress and stationary-phase sigma factor RpoS was identified by complementation of an E. coli rpoS mutation .
15,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|31,32 G#DNA

An open reading frame that is approximately 60 % identical to the E. coli rpoS gene was identified .
1,4 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|12,16 G#DNA

Western blot analysis showed that the level of L. pneumophila RpoS increased in stationary phase .
10,11 G#protein

An insertion mutation was constructed in the rpoS gene on the chromosome of L. pneumophila , and the ability of this mutant strain to survive various stress conditions was assayed and compared with results for the wild-type strain .
7,9 G#DNA

Both the mutant and wild-type strains were more resistant to stress when in stationary phase than when in the logarithmic phase of growth .


This finding indicates that L. pneumophila RpoS is not required for a stationary-phase-dependent resistance to stress .
6,7 G#protein

Although the mutant strain was able to kill HL-60- and THP-1- derived macrophages , it could not replicate within a protozoan host , Acanthamoeba castellanii .
8,13 G#cell_type

These data suggest that L. pneumophila possesses a growth phase-dependent resistance to stress that is independent of RpoS control and that RpoS likely regulates genes that enable it to survive in the environment within protozoa .
17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Our data indicate that the role of rpoS in L. pneumophila is very different from what has previously been reported for E. coli rpoS .
7,8 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA

Monoallelic expression of Pax5 : a paradigm for the haploinsufficiency of mammalian Pax genes ?
3,4 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA

It is generally assumed that most mammalian genes are transcribed from both alleles .
6,8 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA

Hence , the diploid state of the genome offers the advantage that a loss-of-function mutation in one allele can be compensated for by the remaining wild-type allele of the same gene .
17,18 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA

Indeed , the vast majority of human disease syndromes and engineered mutations in the mouse genome are recessive , indicating that recessiveness is the ' default ' state .
14,16 G#DNA

However , a minority of genes are semi-dominant , as heterozygous loss-of-function mutation in these genes leads to phenotypic abnormalities .


This condition , known as haploinsufficiency , has been described for five of the nine mammalian Pax genes , which are associated with mouse developmental mutants and human disease syndromes .
15,18 G#DNA

Recently we have reported that the Pax5 gene is subject to allele -specific regulation during B cell development .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA

Pax5 is predominantly transcribed from only one of its two alleles in early B-lymphoid progenitors and mature B cells , while it transiently switches to a biallelic mode of transcription in pre-B and immature B cells .
0,1 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA|12,15 G#cell_type|16,19 G#cell_type|31,36 G#cell_type

As a consequence , B-lymphoid tissues are mosaic with regard to the transcribed allele , and heterozygous mutation of Pax5 therefore results in deletion of B lymphocytes expressing only the mutant allele .
13,14 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type|31,32 G#DNA|30,32 G#DNA

The allele -specific regulation of Pax5 raises the intriguing possibility that monoallelic expression may also be the mechanism causing the haploinsufficiency of other Pax genes .
1,2 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA

In this review , we discuss different models accounting for the haploinsufficiency of mammalian Pax genes , provide further evidence in support of the allele -specific regulation of Pax5 and discuss the implication of these findings in the context of the recent literature describing the stochastic and monoallelic activation of other hematopoietic genes .
14,16 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|51,53 G#DNA

Activation of STAT5 by IL-4 relies on Janus kinase function but not on receptor tyrosine phosphorylation , and can contribute to both cell proliferation and gene regulation .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

We have investigated mechanisms and consequences of STAT5 activation through the human IL-4 receptor ( IL-4R ) .
7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

By functionally expressing receptor mutants in the murine pro-B cell line Ba/F3 , we could show that phosphorylated tyrosine residues within the IL-4R alpha chain are dispensable for IL-4 -induced STAT5 activity .
3,5 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_line|22,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

However , disruption of a membrane-proximal proline-rich sequence motif ( ' box1 ' ) in either subunit of the bipartite IL-4R abolished not only ligand-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of Janus kinases JAK1 and JAK3 , but also IL-4 -triggered activation of STAT5 and concomitant cell proliferation .
5,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

A dominant-negative version of STAT5b , but not of STAT5a , interfered with IL-4 -induced DNA synthesis in Ba/F3 cells , suggesting an involvement of STAT5b in the control of cell proliferation through IL-4R .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Reporter gene experiments finally showed that transcription from promoters of STAT5 target genes can be specifically induced by challenging cells with IL-4 , and that both STAT5a and STAT5b can contribute to IL-4 -triggered transcriptional control .
10,11 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Inhibition of NF-AT signal transduction events by a dominant-negative form of calcineurin .
2,3 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

An inhibitory , " dominant-negative , " form of the calcineurin catalytic ( A ) subunit was prepared , which lacks the calmodulin -binding domain , autoinhibitory domain and most of its catalytic core but possesses the regulatory ( B ) subunit binding domain .
10,11 G#protein|10,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|37,42 G#protein

When tested for its ability to block calcineurin -dependent signaling in Jurkat cells , expression of this " B-subunit knock-out " ( BKO ) construct suppressed reporter gene activity driven by NF-AT , the pivotal promoter element for interleukin ( IL ) -2 gene induction .
7,8 G#protein|17,25 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein|35,37 G#DNA|38,43 G#protein|38,44 G#DNA

Immunoprecipitation of epitope-labeled BKO demonstrated for the formation of a tight complex with endogenous B subunit in Jurkat cells , consistent with an inhibitory mechanism that involves the sequestration of the B subunit .
2,4 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line|31,33 G#protein

Furthermore , the sharply reduced NF-AT activity produced by co-transfecting BKO could be " rescued " by overexpression of transfected B subunit , suggesting that depletion of this subunit was responsible for the inhibition .
5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein

These data suggest the potential utility of agents that disrupt calcineurin -mediated signal transduction pathways by blocking formation of the catalytically active dimer of calcineurin A and B subunits .
10,11 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,29 G#protein

Evaluation of monoclonal anti-D reagents using D variant cells .
6,9 G#cell_line

Monoclonal anti-D antibodies submitted to the Third Monoclonal International Workshop were evaluated against a number of D variant cells using standard serological techniques .
0,3 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line

The monoclonal antibodies were able to discriminate between the cells of Categories Va , VI and DFR but not Category III cells .
1,3 G#protein|11,22 G#cell_line

Cells within each category did not give any aberrant results .


The Rh : 33 cells behaved as normal Rh ( D ) positive cells .
1,5 G#cell_line|7,14 G#cell_type

Interleukin 10 induced c-fos expression in human B cells by activation of divergent protein kinases .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#cell_type|12,15 G#protein

IL-10 is a potent mediator of human B cell growth and plasma cell formation .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_type

However , signal transduction of IL-10 in B cells is poorly understood .
5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

In this study the effect of IL-10 on the expression of the protooncogene c-fos was investigated , because Fos plays a potential role in the regulation of B cell proliferation and differentiation .
6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

B cells were purified from buffy coat preparations of healthy blood donors by positive selection using an anti CD20 monoclonal antibody and a MiniMACS separation unit .
0,2 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

B cells were prestimulated with SAC for 48 hrs .
0,2 G#cell_type

Then , cells were incubated with medium or IL-10 ( 100 ng/ml ) for 10 to 120 min .
8,9 G#protein

RNA was extracted by phenol/chloroform and c-fos expression was analyzed by PCR assisted mRNA assay .
0,1 G#RNA|6,7 G#DNA

A significant 2-4 fold increase of c-fos expression was observed within 30 min of stimulation with IL-10 ( p &lt; 0.01 ) .
6,7 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

After 2 hrs c-fos expression declined to basal levels .
3,4 G#DNA

The effect of IL-10 was dose-dependent with a maximum stimulation using 100 ng/ml of IL-10 .
3,4 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The IL-10 effect on c-fos expression was not blocked by polymyxin B .
1,2 G#protein|4,5 G#DNA

Using the tyrosine kinase inhibitor genistein ( 10 microM ) a complete inhibition of IL-10 induced c-fos expression was observed .
14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#DNA

In addition , H-7 ( 10 microM ) , a specific inhibitor of serine /threonine kinases , significantly blocked IL-10 mediated c-fos expression ( p &lt; 0.05 ) .
13,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA

In conclusion , these data show that IL-10 induces c-fos expression in human B-cells by activation of tyrosine and serine /threonine kinases .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_type|19,22 G#protein

Since this is the first report on IL-10 induced signal transduction , these data may help to identify the intracellular mechanisms by which IL-10 stimulates human B-cells .
7,8 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type

Immunocytochemical analysis of MNDA in tissue sections and sorted normal bone marrow cells documents expression only in maturing normal and neoplastic myelomonocytic cells and a subset of normal and neoplastic B lymphocytes .
3,4 G#protein

The human myeloid cell nuclear differentiation antigen ( MNDA ) is a nuclear antigen known to be expressed in mature myelomonocytic cell lines .
8,9 G#protein

An extensive immunocytochemical evaluation of fixed tissues confirmed MNDA expression in normal maturing granulocytes and monocytes and in acute nonlymphocytic leukemias and chronic myelogenous leukemia .
8,9 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type

MNDA was not detected in normal tissue histiocytes but was found in activated macrophages and foreign body giant cells associated with inflammation .
0,1 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|15,19 G#cell_type

Flow cytometric cell sorting of normal bone marrow established that MNDA is initially expressed in myeloid blast cells .
10,11 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type

Examination of lymphoid tissues showed a low level of expression in a population of normal mande B lymphocytes but not in germinal center cells or plasma cells .
15,18 G#cell_line|21,24 G#cell_type|25,27 G#cell_type

A subset of B cell neoplasms expressing MNDA included hairy cell leukemia , parafollicular ( monocytoid ) B cell lymphoma , mantle cell lymphoma , and small lymphocytic lymphoma .
3,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein

Cell sorting of normal bone marrow showed MNDA expression in CD20 +/CD10-/CD5- B cells .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

MNDA was not detected in other normal bone marrow or all other nonhematopoietic cells .
0,1 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

The hematopoietic cell-specific pattern of MNDA expression was elucidated through a comprehensive analysis of normal and neoplastic tissues , and the results provide further evidence of the coexpression of B- and myeloid cell markers in neoplastic B cells and identify a normal B cell population that might be related to the cell of origin of a subset of B cell neoplasms .
5,6 G#protein|29,34 G#protein|35,38 G#cell_type|41,45 G#cell_type|58,61 G#cell_type

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor activators target human endothelial cells to inhibit leukocyte -endothelial cell interaction .
0,4 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type

An early event in acute and chronic inflammation and associated diseases such as atherosclerosis and rheumatoid arthritis is the induced expression of specific adhesion molecules on the surface of endothelial cells ( ECs ) , which subsequently bind leukocytes .
23,25 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type|32,33 G#cell_type|38,39 G#cell_type

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors ( PPARs ) , members of the nuclear receptor superfamily of transcription factors , are activated by fatty acid metabolites , peroxisome proliferators , and thiazolidinediones and are now recognized as important mediators in the inflammatory response .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Whether PPAR activators influence the inflammatory responses of ECs is unknown .
8,9 G#cell_type

We show that the PPAR activators 15-deoxy-Delta ( 12 , 14 ) -prostaglandin J ( 2 ) ( 15d-PGJ ( 2 ) ) , Wyeth 14643 , ciglitazone , and troglitazone , but not BRL 49653 , partially inhibit the induced expression of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 ( VCAM-1 ) , as measured by ELISA , and monocyte binding to human aortic endothelial cells ( HAECs ) activated by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) or lipopolysaccharide .
43,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|60,64 G#cell_type|65,66 G#cell_type

The " natural " PPAR activator 15d-PGJ ( 2 ) had the greatest potency and was the only tested molecule capable of partially inhibiting the induced expression of E-selectin and neutrophil-like HL60 cell binding to PMA -activated HAECs .
28,29 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_line|37,38 G#cell_type

Intracellular adhesion molecule-1 induction by PMA was unaffected by any of the molecules tested .
0,3 G#protein

Both PPAR-alpha and PPAR-gamma mRNAs were detected in HAECs by using reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and a ribonuclease protection assay ; however , we have yet to determine which , if any , of the PPARs are mediating this process .
1,2 G#RNA|3,5 G#RNA|1,5 G#RNA|8,9 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

These results suggest that certain PPAR activators may help limit chronic inflammation mediated by VCAM-1 and monocytes without affecting acute inflammation mediated by E-selectin and neutrophil binding .
14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#cell_type

Dephosphorylation of ZAP-70 and inhibition of T cell activation by activated SHP1 .
2,3 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Studies with motheaten mice , which lack the SHP1 protein tyrosine phosphatase , indicate that this enzyme plays an important negative role in T cell antigen receptor ( TCR ) signaling .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The physiological substrates for SHP1 in T lymphocytes , however , have remained unclear or controversial .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

To define these targets for SHP1 we have compared the effects of constitutively active and inactive mutants of SHP1 on TCR signaling .
5,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Expression of wild-type SHP1 had a very small effect on the TCR-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of ZAP-70 and Syk , even when SHP1 was overexpressed 20Â -Â 100-fold over endogenous SHP1 .
3,4 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

Inactive SHP1 -D421A and wild-type SHP2 were without effects .
1,2 G#protein|0,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

Constitutively active SHP1 -DeltaSH2 had a more pronounced effect on ZAP-70 and Syk , even when expressed at near physiological levels .
2,3 G#protein|0,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

SHP1 -DeltaSH2 also inhibited events downstream of ZAP-70 and Syk , such as activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase Erk2 and the transcriptional activation of the interleukin-2 gene .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA

In contrast , a constitutively active SHP2-DeltaSH2 had no statistically significant effect ( although it caused a slight augmentation in some individual experiments ) .
6,7 G#protein

None of the constructs influenced the anti-CD3-induced tyrosine phosphorylation of the TCR zeta-chain or phospholipase Cgamma1 , indicating that Src family kinase function was intact .
11,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

Taken together , our findings support the notion that ZAP-70 and Syk can be direct substrates for SHP1 in intact cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

However , the two SH2 domains of SHP1 did not facilitate its recognition of ZAP-70 and Syk as substrates in intact cells .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Therefore , we suggest that SHP1 is not actively recruited to inhibit TCR signaling induced by ligation of this receptor alone .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Instead , we propose that ligation of a distinct inhibitory receptor leads to the recruitment of SHP1 via its SH2 domains , activation of SHP1 and subsequently inhibition of TCR signals if the inhibitory receptor is juxtaposed to the TCR .
9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Immune responses to adenoviruses : viral evasion mechanisms and their implications for the clinic .


Adenoviruses encode proteins that block responses to interferons , intrinsic cellular apoptosis , killing by CD8(+) cytotoxic T lymphocytes and killing by the death ligands TNF , Fas ligand and TRAIL .
7,8 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_type|23,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

The viral proteins are believed to prolong acute and persistent adenovirus infections .
1,3 G#protein

The proteins may prove useful in protecting adenovirus gene therapy vectors and transplanted cells from the immune system .
7,11 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_line

C/EBPbeta and GATA-1 synergistically regulate activity of the eosinophil granule major basic protein promoter : implication for C/EBPbeta activity in eosinophil gene expression .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|8,14 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein

Eosinophil granule major basic protein ( MBP ) is expressed exclusively in eosinophils and basophils in hematopoietic cells .
0,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type

In our previous study , we demonstrated a major positive regulatory role for GATA-1 and a negative regulatory role for GATA-2 in MBP gene transcription .
13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Further analysis of the MBP promoter region identified a C/EBP ( CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein ) consensus binding site 6 bp upstream of the functional GATA-binding site in the MBP gene .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|9,17 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA

In the cell line HT93A , which is capable of differentiating towards both the eosinophil and neutrophil lineages in response to retinoic acid ( RA ) , C/EBPalpha mRNA expression decreased significantly concomitant with eosinophilic and neutrophilic differentiation , whereas C/EBPbeta expression was markedly increased .
2,5 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#RNA|40,41 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSAs ) showed that recombinant C/EBPbeta protein could bind to the potential C/EBP-binding site ( bp -90 to -82 ) in the MBP promoter .
10,11 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|20,24 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

Furthermore , we have demonstrated that both C/EBPbeta and GATA-1 can bind simultaneously to the C/EBP- and GATA-binding sites in the MBP promoter .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

To determine the functionality of both the C/EBP- and GATA- binding sites , we analyzed whether C/EBPbeta and GATA-1 can stimulate the MBP promoter in the C/EBPbeta and GATA-1 negative Jurkat T-cell line .
7,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_line|26,33 G#cell_line

Cotransfection with C/EBPbeta and GATA-1 expression vectors produced a 5-fold increase compared with cotransfection with the C/EBPbeta or GATA-1 expression vectors individually .
2,7 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

In addition , GST pull-down experiments demonstrated a physical interaction between human GATA-1 and C/EBPbeta .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Expression of FOG ( riend ATA ) , which binds to GATA-1 and acts as a cofactor for GATA-binding proteins , decreased transactivation activity of GATA-1 for the MBP promoter in a dose-dependent manner .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA

Our results provide the first evidence that both GATA-1 and C/EBPbeta synergistically transactivate the promoter of an eosinophil-specific granule protein gene and that FOG may act as a negative cofactor for the eosinophil lineage , unlike its positively regulatory function for the erythroid and megakaryocyte lineages .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA|17,21 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|42,46 G#cell_type

Tissue-specific regulation of the ecto-5'-nucleotidase promoter .
4,6 G#DNA

Role of the camp response element site in mediating repression by the upstream regulatory region .
3,7 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA

We have isolated the 5' region of the ecto-5'-nucleotidase ( low K ( m ) 5'-NT ) gene and established that a 969-base pair ( bp ) fragment confers cell-specific expression of a CAT reporter gene that correlates with the expression of endogenous ecto-5'-NT mRNA and enzymatic activity .
4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|8,18 G#DNA|22,28 G#DNA|33,36 G#DNA|42,45 G#RNA

A 768-bp upstream negative regulatory region has been identified that conferred lymphocyte-specific negative regulation in a heterologous system with a 244-bp deoxycytidine kinase core promoter .
1,6 G#DNA|20,25 G#DNA

DNase I footprinting identified several protected areas including Sp1 , Sp1/AP-2 , and cAMP response element ( CRE ) binding sites within the 201-bp core promoter region and Sp1 , NRE-2a , TCF-1/LEF-1 , and Sp1/NF-AT binding sites in the upstream regulatory region .
0,2 G#protein|8,21 G#DNA|28,38 G#DNA|40,43 G#DNA

Whereas the CRE site was essential in mediating the negative activity of the upstream regulatory region in Jurkat but not in HeLa cells , mutation of the Sp1/AP-2 site decreased promoter activity in both cell lines .
2,4 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#cell_line|21,23 G#cell_line|27,29 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay analysis of proteins binding to the CRE site identified both ATF-1 and ATF-2 in Jurkat cells .
10,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line

Finally , phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate increased the activity of both the core and the 969-bp promoter fragments , and this increase was abrogated by mutations at the CRE site .
14,17 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

In summary , we have identified a tissue-specific regulatory region 5' of the ecto-5'-NT core promoter that requires the presence of a functional CRE site within the basal promoter for its suppressive activity .
7,10 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

Extracellular signal-regulated protein kinase ( ERK ) -dependent and ERK-independent pathways target STAT3 on serine-727 in human neutrophils stimulated by chemotactic factors and cytokines .
12,13 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

STAT3 ( signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 ) is a latent transcription factor that is activated by tyrosine phosphorylation ( Tyr-705 ) in cells stimulated with cytokines or growth factors .
0,1 G#protein|2,9 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

Recent studies suggest that one or more cytoplasmic serine kinases also phosphorylate STAT3 and are necessary for maximal gene activation .
7,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Here we demonstrate , with a site-specific antibody , that STAT3 is phosphorylated on Ser-727 in human neutrophils stimulated with chemotactic factors ( N-formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine and complement C5a ) , cytokines [ granulocyte/macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor ( G-CSF ) ] , or a protein kinase C activator ( PMA ) .
10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|20,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|38,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|48,51 G#protein

(2-Amino-3'-methoxyphenyl)oxanaphthalen-4-one ( PD 98059 ) , an inhibitor of extracellular signal-regulated protein kinase ( ERK ) activation , blocked the serine phosphorylation of STAT3 induced by chemotactic factors or PMA .
10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

The drug was less effective on cytokines : it virtually abolished the response to GM-CSF that occurred 5 min after stimulation but only partly decreased those at 15-30 min and did not appreciably alter responses to G-CSF regardless of incubation time .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

1-(5-Isoquinolinylsulphonyl)-2-methylpiperazine dihydrochloride ( H7 ) , an inhibitor of a putative STAT3 serine kinase , and 4-(4-fluorophenyl)-2-(4-methylsulphinylphenyl)-5-(4-pyridyl)Â 1H-imidazole ( SB 203580 ) , an inhibitor of p38 mitogen-activated protein ( MAP ) kinase , did not dampen any of these serine phosphorylation responses .
11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|25,32 G#protein

We propose that neutrophils use both ERK-dependent and ERK-independent pathways to phosphorylate Ser-727 on STAT3 .
3,4 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

The former pathway is recruited by all ERK -activating stimuli , whereas the latter pathway uses an undefined serine kinase and is recruited selectively by cytokines .
7,8 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

GATA transcription factors associate with a novel class of nuclear bodies in erythroblasts and megakaryocytes .
0,3 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type

The nuclear distribution of GATA transcription factors in murine haemopoietic cells was examined by indirect immunofluorescence .
4,7 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type

Specific bright foci of GATA-1 fluorescence were observed in erythroleukaemia cells and primary murine erythroblasts and megakaryocytes , in addition to diffuse nucleoplasmic localization .
4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type

These foci , which were preferentially found adjacent to nucleoli or at the nuclear periphery , did not represent sites of active transcription or binding of GATA-1 to consensus sites in the beta-globin loci .
26,27 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|32,34 G#DNA

Immunoelectron microscopy demonstrated the presence of intensely labelled structures likely to represent the GATA-1 foci seen by immunofluorescence .
13,14 G#protein

The GATA-1 nuclear bodies differed from previously described nuclear structures and there was no co-localization with nuclear antigens involved in RNA processing or other ubiquitous ( Spl , c-Jun and TBP ) or haemopoietic ( NF-E2 ) transcription factors .
1,2 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|24,39 G#protein

Interestingly , GATA-2 and GATA-3 proteins also localized to the same nuclear bodies in cell lines co-expressing GATA -1 and -2 or GATA -1 and -3 gene products .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|17,21 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|17,28 G#protein

This pattern of distribution is , thus far , unique to the GATA transcription factors and suggests a protein-protein interaction with other components of the nuclear bodies via the GATA zinc finger domain .
12,15 G#protein|29,33 G#protein

Energy substrates , hormone responses and glucocorticoid binding in lymphocytes during intense physical exercise in humans following phosphocreatine administration .
9,10 G#cell_type

Eight healthy untrained male volunteers pedalled a cycle ergometer according to two exercise protocols : the first involved step-wise increasing physical exercise to maximal ( MPE ) ; the second involved prolonged ( 35 min ) submaximal physical exercise ( PPE ) at 70 % of the individual 's maximal oxygen uptake .


Each volunteer performed these exercise twice , following either an intravenous injection of phosphocreatine ( PCr ) or a placebo of an isotonic NaCl solution .


Anaerobic threshold ( AT ) was determined from the point of departure of the ventilatory response from linearity and from the sudden increase in venous blood lactate concentrations during MPE .


After exercise following placebo administration we observed increases in concentrations of blood substrates , plasma adrenocorticotropin ( ACTH ) , growth hormone and cortisol and in the number of glucocorticoid receptors in lymphocytes without changes in the dissociation constant .
14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,33 G#cell_type

Intravenous administration of PCr ( starting 1 day before exercise ) led to an increase in the total workload ( on average by 5.8 % ) and in AT ( on average by 6.8 % ) during MPE and to a better tolerance of exercise during PPE .


Following PCr administration we observed lower blood lactate concentrations and different patterns of some enzyme activities , less pronounced changes in plasma ACTH and cortisol concentrations and in glucocorticoid binding in lymphocytes , but no changes in plasma growth hormone concentrations compared to the placebo .
22,23 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|31,32 G#cell_type

The results showed that intense physical exercise led not only to increases in blood hormone concentrations but also to an increase in the density of glucocorticoid receptors in lymphocytes .
25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type

Intravenous PCr injection led to smaller changes in ACTH and cortisol concentrations as well as to a lower activation of glucocorticoid binding in lymphocytes .
8,9 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type

Putative steroid binding domain of the human mineralocorticoid receptor , expressed in E. coli in the presence of heat shock proteins shows typical native receptor characteristics .
0,4 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Domain E , considered as the putative hormone binding domain ( HBD ) of the human mineralocorticoid receptor ( hMR ) was expressed in Escherichia coli as a fusion protein with either maltose binding protein ( MBP ) or glutathione S-transferase ( GST ) .
0,2 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|32,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|39,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

These bacterially-produced MR constructs had no steroid binding activity per se .
1,4 G#DNA

In fact , heat shock protein association ( hsp ) is required for high affinity ligand-binding of the MR .
3,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

After incubation of purified MBP- or GST- HBD with rabbit reticulocyte lysate , known to be rich in heat shock proteins , we obtained saturable binding of [3H]aldosterone .
4,8 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

The Kd value for aldosterone was 0.3 nM and the Bmax = 32 pmol/mg .


Hormone binding specificity was assessed by competition studies with various steroid ligands .


Sucrose gradient assays performed with [3H]aldosterone -MBP-HBD revealed complex sedimenting at 8.3S and 4.9S with [3H]progesterone-MBP-HBD .
5,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Western-blot analysis of the sedimentation peak showed the concomitant presence of MBP-HBD by a monoclonal anti-MBP antibody , and hsp90 by a monoclonal anti-hsp antibody .
11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Moreover , following incubation with the anti-rabbit hsp90 monoclonal antibody the sedimenting gradient showed a 10.4S sedimenting complex .
7,8 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

These analyses demonstrated that the [3H]aldosterone - MBP-HBD complex is at least associated with hsp90 in reticulocyte lysate and that the HBD of hMR is sufficient to bind hsp90 .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Deletions of a relatively short amino- ( 729-766 ) or carboxy- terminal ( 940-984 ) region of the HBD fragment eliminated all steroid-binding properties .
5,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Overall , these results indicate that the integrity of domain E is necessary and sufficient to bind steroid ligands , agonists or antagonists , with characteristics similar to the entire native MR .
9,11 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Renal cell carcinoma-derived gangliosides suppress nuclear factor-kappaB activation in T cells .
5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor-kappaB ( NFkappaB ) is impaired in T cells from patients with renal cell carcinomas ( RCCs ) .
3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

In circulating T cells from a subset of patients with RCCs , the suppression of NFkappaB binding activity is downstream from the stimulus-induced degradation of the cytoplasmic factor IkappaBalpha .
2,4 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Tumor-derived soluble products from cultured RCC explants inhibit NFkappaB activity in T cells from healthy volunteers , despite a normal level of stimulus-induced IkappaBalpha degradation in these cells .
0,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein

The inhibitory agent has several features characteristic of a ganglioside , including sensitivity to neuraminidase but not protease treatment ; hydrophobicity ; and molecular weight less than 3 kDa .
14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Indeed , we detected gangliosides in supernatants from RCC explants and not from adjacent normal kidney tissue .
8,10 G#cell_type

Gangliosides prepared from RCC supernatants , as well as the purified bovine gangliosides G ( m1 ) and G ( d1a ) , suppressed NFkappaB binding activity in T cells and reduced expression of the cytokines IL-2 and IFN-gamma .
24,25 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Taken together , our findings suggest that tumor-derived gangliosides may blunt antitumor immune responses in patients with RCCs .


Nuclear factor-kappaB -dependent induction of interleukin-8 gene expression by tumor necrosis factor alpha : evidence for an antioxidant sensitive activating pathway distinct from nuclear translocation .
0,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,13 G#protein

Tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNFalpha ) is a pluripotent activator of inflammation by inducing a proinflammatory cytokine cascade .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

This phenomenon is mediated , in part , through inducible expression of the CXC chemokine , interleukin-8 ( IL-8 ) .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In this study , we investigate the role of TNFalpha -inducible reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) in IL-8 expression by " monocyte-like " U937 histiocytic lymphoma cells .
9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,28 G#cell_line

TNFalpha is a rapid activator of IL-8 gene expression by U937 , producing a 50-fold induction of mRNA within 1 hour of treatment .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#cell_line|17,18 G#RNA

In gene transfection assays , the effect of TNFalpha requires the presence of an inducible nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) ( Rel A ) binding site in the IL-8 promoter .
8,9 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|14,26 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA

TNFalpha treatment induces a rapid translocation of the 65 kD transcriptional activator NF-kappaB subunit , Rel A , whose binding in the nucleus occurs before changes in intracellular ROS .
0,1 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Pretreatment ( or up to 15 minutes posttreatment ) relative to TNFalpha with the antioxidant dimethyl sulfoxide ( DMSO ) ( 2 % [ vol/vol ] ) blocks 80 % of NF-kappaB -dependent transcription .
11,12 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Surprisingly , however , DMSO has no effect on inducible Rel A binding .
10,12 G#protein

Similar selective effects on NF-kappaB transcription are seen with the unrelated antioxidants , N-acetylcysteine ( NAC ) and vitamin C .
4,5 G#protein

These data indicate that TNFalpha induces a delayed ROS-dependent signalling pathway that is required for NF-kappaB transcriptional activation and is separable from that required for its nuclear translocation .
4,5 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Further definition of this pathway will yield new insights into inflammation initiated by TNFalpha signalling .
13,14 G#protein

Gender and vascular reactivity .


Estrogen receptors are found on vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells ; their expression is influenced by exposure to the hormone .
0,2 G#protein|5,11 G#cell_type

Estrogen receptors influence non-genomic events , which are rapid in onset and genomic events , which are longer acting responses .
0,2 G#protein

Estrogens affect vascular tone indirectly by modulating release of endothelium-derived vasoactive factors and directly by modulating intracellular calcium in vascular smooth muscle cells .
9,12 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_type

Estrogens indirectly affect thrombotic events and inflammation by altering platelet aggregation and leukocyte adherence and migration , respectively .
9,10 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type

Estrogens also influence production of mitogens which , when released at sites of vascular injury , affect vascular remodeling .


Although estrogens initiate vascular responses , genomic sex may influence and/or limit expression of estrogen receptors and therefore actions of sex steroid hormones throughout the vasculature .


Induction of a functional vitamin D receptor in all-trans-retinoic acid -induced monocytic differentiation of M2-type leukemic blast cells .
4,7 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line

Different types of acute myeloid leukemia blast cells were induced to differentiate in vitro with all-trans-retinoic acid ( ATRA ) and vitamin D3 ( VD ) .
3,8 G#cell_type

M0/M1 leukemic cells are not sensitive to differentiating agents , whereas M3 leukemic cells are induced to undergo granulocytic differentiation after ATRA treatment but are not sensitive to VD .
0,3 G#cell_line|11,14 G#cell_line

M2 leukemic blast cells behave differently because they undergo monocytic differentiation with both the differentiation inducers .
0,4 G#cell_line

To gain some insight into the maturation of M2-type leukemic cells , we studied the molecular mechanisms underlying monocytic differentiation induced by ATRA and VD in spontaneous M2 blast cells as well as in Kasumi-1 cells ( an acute myeloid leukemia M2-type cell line ) .
8,11 G#cell_type|27,30 G#cell_line|34,36 G#cell_line|38,44 G#cell_line

Our results indicate that ATRA as well as VD efficiently increases the nuclear abundance of VD receptor ( VDR ) and promotes monocytic differentiation .
15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

VDR is functionally active in ATRA -treated Kasumi-1 cells because it efficiently heterodimerizes with retinoid X receptor , binds to a DR3-type vitamin D-responsive element , and activates the transcription of a vitamin D-responsive element-regulated reporter gene .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|14,17 G#protein|21,25 G#DNA|32,37 G#DNA

Consistent with these findings , VD -responsive genes are induced by ATRA treatment of Kasumi-1 cells , suggesting that the genetic program underlying monocytic differentiation is activated .
5,8 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_line

The molecular mechanism by which ATRA increases the nuclear abundance of a functional VDR is still unknown , but our data clearly indicate that the M2 leukemic cell context is only permissive of monocytic differentiation .
13,14 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_line

Protein kinase C and calcineurin synergize to activate IkappaB kinase and NF-kappaB in T lymphocytes .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

The nuclear factor of kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) is a ubiquitous transcription factor that is key in the regulation of the immune response and inflammation .
6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#protein

T cell receptor ( TCR ) cross-linking is in part required for activation of NF-kappaB , which is dependent on the phosphorylation and degradation of IkappaBalpha .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

By using Jurkat and primary human T lymphocytes , we demonstrate that the simultaneous activation of two second messengers of the TCR -initiated signal transduction , protein kinase C ( PKC ) and calcineurin , results in the synergistic activation of the IkappaBalpha kinase ( IKK ) complex but not of another putative IkappaBalpha kinase , p90 ( rsk ) .
2,3 G#cell_line|6,8 G#cell_type|4,8 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|42,48 G#protein|53,54 G#protein|52,55 G#protein|56,60 G#protein

We also demonstrate that the IKK complex , but not p90 ( rsk ) , is responsible for the in vivo phosphorylation of IkappaBalpha mediated by the co-activation of PKC and calcineurin .
5,7 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Each second messenger is necessary , as inhibition of either one reverses the activation of the IKK complex and IkappaBalpha phosphorylation in vivo .
16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Overexpression of dominant negative forms of IKK alpha and -beta demonstrates that only IKKbeta is the target for PKC and calcineurin .
6,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

These results indicate that within the TCR /CD3 signal transduction pathway both PKC and calcineurin are required for the effective activation of the IKK complex and NF-kappaB in T lymphocytes .
6,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

Diminished responses to IL-13 by human monocytes differentiated in vitro : role of the IL-13Ralpha1 chain and STAT6 .
3,4 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

The primary IL-13 receptor complex on human monocytes is believed to be a heterodimer comprised of the IL-4R alpha chain and the IL-2R gamma chain ( gamma(c) ) -like molecule , IL-13R alpha1 .
2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|17,20 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|25,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

mRNA levels for IL-13R alpha1 , but not IL-4R alpha , were markedly decreased in in vitro monocyte-derived macrophages ( MDMac ) , and with increasing time of monocytes in culture correlated with the loss of IL-13 regulation of lipopolysaccharide -induced TNF-alpha production .
0,1 G#RNA|3,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_line|20,21 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

Analysis of cell lines Daudi and THP-1 that differentially express gamma(c) and IL-13R alpha1 showed that IL-13 can activate STAT6 in IL-13R alpha1 -positive THP-1 cells but not in gamma(c)-positive , IL-13R alpha1 -negative Daudi cells .
2,4 G#cell_line|4,5 G#cell_line|6,7 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_line|31,33 G#protein|29,36 G#cell_line

IL-13 activation of STAT6 was reduced in MDMac which was associated with diminished IL-13 -induced expression of CD23 and MHC class II .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

However , with reduced IL-13R alpha1 expression and low nuclear STAT6 activity , some IL-13 -induced responses were unaltered in magnitude in MDMac .
4,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#cell_line

In the absence of functional IL-13R alpha1 and gamma(c) , IL-13 must signal through an alternative receptor complex on MDMac .
