5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_line

Experiments with a blocking antibody to IL-4R alpha showed that this chain remains an essential component of the IL-13 receptor complex on MDMac .
6,8 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#cell_line

The p53 paradox in the pathogenesis of tumor progression .
1,2 G#protein

Recent evidence suggests that the p53 molecule appears in two different forms : the mutant p53 that stimulates tumor progression , and wild type p53 that inhibits tumor progression .
5,7 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

In addition , it has been established that tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) can activate the expression of wild type p53 in concert with the nuclear transcription factor , NF-kappa B .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

Both TNF-alpha and NF-kappa B are also involved in the stimulation of the pathway that leads to the expression of major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class I molecules and , hence , antigen presentation to the T cells .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|20,29 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type

In this paper we shall advance the hypothesis that : ( i ) TNF-alpha indirectly controls immune surveillance ; and ( ii ) TNF-alpha controls DNA repair and tumor suppression through the regulation of wild type p53 .
13,14 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|34,37 G#protein

Thus , it is hypothesized that elevated TNF-alpha is primarily responsible for promoting tumor progression .
7,8 G#protein

The promoter and 5' flanking sequences controlling human B29 gene expression .
1,2 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA

The product of the B-cell-specific B29 gene ( B29 , Ig beta , CD79b ) is essential for Ig-mediated B-cell activation via the B-cell antigen receptor complex ( BCR ) on human and murine B lymphocytes .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|4,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,36 G#cell_type

To better understand the regulation of this pivotal gene , we have analyzed the human genomic DNA sequence upstream of the B29 ATG start codon for transcriptional control activity .
14,18 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA

The human B29 gene lacks either a TATA or a CAAT box and transcription is initiated at multiple sites .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|7,12 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA

The minimal promoter of the human B29 gene is contained within a 193-bp region 5' of these multiple start sites .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA

This minimal promoter exhibits B-cell-specific activity and contains SP1 , ETS , OCT , and IKAROS/LYF-1 transcription factor motifs .
1,3 G#DNA|8,19 G#DNA

All these motifs are strikingly conserved in sequence and placement relative to the previously characterized murine B29 promoter .
16,17 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA

Additional upstream gene segments dramatically affected B29 minimal promoter activity .
6,7 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA

A newly identified motif called the B29 conserved sequence ( BCS ) , found upstream of both human and murine B29 promoters , appears to stimulate B29 transcription through a novel mechanism .
6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|17,22 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein

A single BCS had little effect either on the minimal B29 promoter or on a heterologous promoter .
2,3 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

Instead , the BCS stimulated transcription by counteracting 5' negative regulatory DNA sequences that block the activity of the B29 minimal promoter in its absence .
3,4 G#DNA|8,13 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

These findings indicate that B29 gene expression is controlled by the complex interplay of positive and negative regulatory elements .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA

A novel immunosuppressive factor in bovine colostrum blocks activation of the interleukin 2 gene enhancer at the NFAT site .
2,4 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA

A factor in bovine colostrum ( colostrum inhibitory factor , CIF ) inhibits interleukin 2 ( IL2 ) production in activated T helper cells by blocking the accumulation of IL2 mRNA .
6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#RNA

To determine whether CIF blocks at the level of IL2 transcription , we introduced reporter plasmids into the human T leukemia cell line Jurkat by transient transfection .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|18,24 G#cell_line

These contained the luciferase gene under the control of either the human IL2 upstream enhancer region ( segments -326 to +45 ) or three repeats of the NFAT element contained within it ( segments -255 to -285 ) .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

Expression of luciferase in these cells was induced by phorbol myristate acetate plus a calcium ionophore .
2,3 G#protein

CIF inhibited induction of either construct as did cyclosporine , which is known to block activation of the NFAT element .
0,1 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

CIF failed to inhibit several other enhancer elements .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA

The NFAT-controlled luciferase gene system distinguishes CIF from other T cell inhibitory activities present in colostrum , in particular , TGF beta 1 and TGF beta 2 and the glucocorticoids .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|1,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

Stably transfected Jurkat cells behaved similarly to the transiently transfected ones with respect to inhibition by CIF and cyclosporine .
16,17 G#protein

The NFAT -luc assay is a useful technique for the rapid , sensitive measurement of CIF or other immunosuppressants with a similar mode of action .
1,2 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Heat shock induces HIV-1 replication in chronically infected promyelocyte cell line OM10.1 .
8,12 G#cell_line

A long period of clinical latency before development of symptoms is characteristic of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) infection .


OM10.1 , a promyelocyte cell line latently infected with HIV-1 , has been developed as a model for studying the mechanism of viral latency and the activation of virus expression .
0,1 G#cell_line|3,6 G#cell_line

We found that this latently infected cell line with heat shock at 42 degrees C for 2 h resulted in a high level of HIV-1 production without addition of any cytokines .
30,31 G#protein

The mechanism of activation was analyzed by using anti-TNF-alpha antibody and various inhibitors .
8,10 G#protein

Although the TNF-alpha level in culture supernatants was below the sensitivity of an ELISA assay system , addition of anti- TNF-alpha antibody in culture medium could partially suppress the heat shock induced HIV-1 production .
2,3 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Staurosporine ( PKC inhibitor ) , pentoxifylline ( NF-kappa B inhibitor ) , and Ro5-3335 ( HIV-1 Tat inhibitor ) also inhibited significantly the heat shock induced virus activation .
17,18 G#protein

In particular , staurosporine achieved approximately 90 % inhibition of the HIV-1 antigen expression in heat shock -treated OM10.1 at a non-toxic concentration .
15,19 G#cell_line

Although the mechanism of HIV-1 activation with heat shock has not been fully elucidated yet , it is presumed PKC plays an important role in HIV-1 activation .
19,20 G#protein

Thus , the present observations will provide a further insight into the pathogenesis of HIV-1 infections .


Activation of the CDC42 effector N-WASP by the Shigella flexneri IcsA protein promotes actin nucleation by Arp2/3 complex and bacterial actin -based motility .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

To propel itself in infected cells , the pathogen Shigella flexneri subverts the Cdc42 -controlled machinery responsible for actin assembly during filopodia formation .
4,6 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Using a combination of bacterial motility assays in platelet extracts with Escherichia coli expressing the Shigella IcsA protein and in vitro analysis of reconstituted systems from purified proteins , we show here that the bacterial protein IcsA binds N-WASP and activates it in a Cdc42 -like fashion .
15,18 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

Dramatic stimulation of actin assembly is linked to the formation of a ternary IcsA- N-WASP - Arp2/3 complex , which nucleates actin polymerization .
3,4 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|13,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The Arp2/3 complex is essential in initiation of actin assembly and Shigella movement , as previously observed for Listeria monocytogenes .
1,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Activation of N-WASP by IcsA unmasks two domains acting together in insertional actin polymerization .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The isolated COOH-terminal domain of N-WASP containing a verprolin-homology region , a cofilin-homology sequence , and an acidic terminal segment ( VCA ) interacts with G-actin in a unique profilin-like functional fashion .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Hence , when N-WASP is activated , its COOH-terminal domain feeds barbed end growth of filaments and lowers the critical concentration at the bacterial surface .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

On the other hand , the NH(2)-terminal domain of N-WASP interacts with F-actin , mediating the attachment of the actin tail to the bacterium surface .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

VASP is not involved in Shigella movement , and the function of profilin does not require its binding to proline -rich regions .
12,13 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

c-Maf induces monocytic differentiation and apoptosis in bipotent myeloid progenitors .
0,1 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type

The transcriptional mechanisms that drive colony-forming unit granulocyte-macrophage ( CFU-GM ) myeloid progenitors to differentiate into cells of either the granulocytic or monocytic lineage are not fully understood .
5,13 G#cell_line|20,24 G#cell_type

We have shown that the c-Maf and c-Myb transcription factors physically interact in myeloid cells to form inhibitory complexes that hinder transactivation of c-Myb target genes through direct binding to Myb consensus sites .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA|30,33 G#DNA

These complexes arise in a developmentally regulated pattern , peaking at the promyelocyte stage , or in cell model systems , appearing soon after the induction of monocytic differentiation .
12,14 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_line

We wished to determine if this developmentally related interaction is a consequence of myeloid differentiation or an intrinsic differentiating stimulus .


Because the elevated Myb : Maf status seen in differentiating cells can be recapitulated by overexpression of c-Maf in myeloid cell lines , we inducibly expressed the c-Maf cDNA in 2 bipotent human myeloid progenitor cells .
3,6 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|32,36 G#cell_type

Elevated levels of c-Maf protein led to marked increases in Myb : Maf complexes and the accumulation of monocyte/macrophage cells , followed by eventual programmed cell death .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Analysis of targets that could mediate these phenotypic changes indicated that c-Maf likely plays a key role in myeloid cell development through dual mechanisms ; inhibition of a select set of c-Myb regulated targets , such as Bcl-2 and CD13/APN , coupled with the activation of as yet undefined differentiation-promoting genes .
11,12 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|49,51 G#DNA

AML1 ( CBFalpha2 ) cooperates with B cell-specific activating protein ( BSAP/PAX5 ) in activation of the B cell-specific BLK gene promoter .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|0,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|6,13 G#protein|17,22 G#DNA

AML1 plays a critical role during hematopoiesis and chromosomal translocations involving AML1 are commonly associated with different forms of leukemia , including pre-B acute lymphoblastic leukemia .
0,1 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

To understand the function of AML1 during B cell differentiation , we analyzed regulatory regions of B cell-specific genes for potential AML1 -binding sites and have identified a putative AML1 -binding site in the promoter of the B cell-specific tyrosine kinase gene , blk .
5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|13,15 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|29,32 G#DNA|37,44 G#DNA

Gel mobility shift assays and transient transfection assays demonstrate that AML1 binds specifically to this site in the blk promoter and this binding site is important for blk promoter activity .
10,11 G#protein|18,19 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA

Furthermore , in vitro binding analysis revealed that the AML1 runt DNA-binding domain physically interacts with the paired DNA-binding domain of BSAP , a B cell -specific transcription factor .
9,10 G#protein|9,13 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|24,29 G#protein

BSAP has been shown previously to be important for B cell-specific regulation of the blk gene .
0,1 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA

Physical interaction of AML1 with BSAP correlates with functional cooperativity in transfection studies where AML1 and BSAP synergistically activate blk promoter transcription by more than 50-fold .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#DNA

These results demonstrate physical and functional interactions between AML1 and BSAP and suggest that AML1 is an important factor for regulating a critical B cell-specific gene , blk .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA

Transcriptional inhibition by interleukin-6 of the class A macrophage scavenger receptor in macrophages derived from human peripheral monocytes and the THP-1 monocytic cell line .
3,4 G#protein|6,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_line|20,24 G#cell_line

Expression of the class A macrophage scavenger receptor ( MSR ) contributes to the uptake of modified low density lipoproteins ( LDL ) by macrophages and transformation of these cells into lipid-laden foam cells , which characterize atherosclerosis .
9,10 G#protein|3,11 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|16,23 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_type

Many environmental factors , in particular , proinflammatory cytokines and growth factors , can exert regulatory effects on MSR expression , whereas intracellular accumulation of cholesterol itself does not influence MSR levels to any considerable extent .
7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

In the present study , by using an in vitro model , we examined whether stimulation with interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) , an immunoregulatory , multipotential cytokine , modulates the expression and activities of the MSR in macrophages .
17,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#cell_type

When treated with IL-6 , macrophages derived from peripheral monocytes and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) -differentiated THP-1 monocytic cells showed significantly reduced uptake and/or binding of the MSR ligand , acetylated LDL .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|11,21 G#cell_line|29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|32,34 G#protein

This effect was paralleled by a reduction in the expression of MSR protein and mRNA .
11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#RNA

Analysis of MSR promoter activity in THP-1 cells transfected with an MSR promoter-reporter gene construct demonstrated decreased activity of the MSR promoter in IL-6 -treated THP-1 macrophages .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|6,7 G#cell_line|6,8 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#cell_line|26,27 G#cell_type

Electrophoretic mobility gel shift assay also showed a reduction in the binding of a transcription factor to the MSR promoter AP-1/ets elements in IL-6 -treated cells .
14,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|18,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

Thus , exposure to IL-6 may inhibit expression of the class A MSR in differentiated macrophages at transcriptional levels .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

This result suggests that this cytokine may modulate foam cell formation during atherogenesis .
5,6 G#protein

Retinoblastoma protein expression leads to reduced Oct-1 DNA binding activity and enhances interleukin-8 expression .
0,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Tumor cell lines with a defective retinoblastoma gene are unable to transcribe the HLA class II genes in response to IFN-gamma treatment , and reconstitution of functional Rb rescues IFN-gamma-induced class II gene expression .
6,8 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,33 G#DNA

However , the molecular mechanism of Rb rescue of the class II genes is unknown .
6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA

We have examined the effect of Rb expression on the activation of the promoter for HLA-DRA , the prototype class II gene .
6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA|18,22 G#DNA

Oct-1 , a POU domain transcription factor , was identified as a repressor of HLA-DRA promoter activity in the Rb-defective cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA|19,21 G#cell_type

Rb expression led to phosphorylation of Oct-1 , thus relieving its repressive effect .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Oct-1 has also been shown to repress interleukin 8 promoter activity .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

Consistent with reduced levels of Oct-1 DNA binding activity in the Rb-transformed cell lines , interleukin 8 expression is higher in these cell lines .
5,6 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_line|15,17 G#protein

Cell activation and apoptosis by bacterial lipoproteins through toll-like receptor-2 .
5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Apoptosis is implicated in the generation and resolution of inflammation in response to bacterial pathogens .


All bacterial pathogens produce lipoproteins ( BLPs ) , which trigger the innate immune response .
6,7 G#protein|4,8 G#protein

BLPs were found to induce apoptosis in THP-1 monocytic cells through human Toll-like receptor-2 ( hTLR2 ) .
0,1 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|11,17 G#protein

BLPs also initiated apoptosis in an epithelial cell line transfected with hTLR2 .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

In addition , BLPs stimulated nuclear factor-kappaB , a transcriptional activator of multiple host defense genes , and activated the respiratory burst through hTLR2 .
3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,16 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

Thus , hTLR2 is a molecular link between microbial products , apoptosis , and host defense mechanisms .
2,3 G#protein

Possible differences in the mechanism ( s ) of action of different glucocorticoid hormone compounds .


Different glucocorticoid hormones ( GCH ) show differences in the intensity and in the kinetics of their immunomodulating activity .


The mechanism ( s ) of action of GCH is under investigation , but is has been noted that they exert immune activity via the genomic pathway .


We have studied the effects of prednisone ( PDN ) , deflazacort ( DFC ) , and dexamethasone ( DXM ) on the production of cytokines ( IL-2 , IL-6 , TNF-alpha , IL-10 ) by peripheral T lymphocytes , and the effects on the inhibition of NF-kB DNA binding activity by activated Jurkat cell line .
25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,39 G#cell_type|47,48 G#protein|52,56 G#cell_line

The data obtained show that the three GCH molecules exert an immunosuppression on cytokine production by T lymphocytes and a strong decrease in the nuclear translocation of NF-kB in Jurkat cells ; moreover , ( a ) not all the cytokines investigated were affected , and not with the same intensity , by the three GCH and ( b ) DXM inhibited the binding activity of NF-kB less than that of DFC and PDN .
13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_line|40,41 G#protein|66,67 G#protein

These data are in agreement with the concept that different GCH compounds might differ in their binding and affinity properties , tissue-specific metabolism , and interaction with transcription factor .
27,29 G#protein

Distinctive expression pattern of the BCL-6 protein in nodular lymphocyte predominance Hodgkin 's disease .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

The BCL-6 gene encoding a nuclear-located Kruppel-type zinc finger protein is rearranged in about 30 % diffuse large B-cell lymphomas and is expressed predominantly in normal germinal center B cells and related lymphomas .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#RNA|5,10 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|26,30 G#cell_type

These findings suggest that BCL-6 may play a role in regulating differentiation of normal germinal center B cells and that its deregulated expression caused by rearrangements may contribute to lymphomagenesis .
4,5 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_type

This prompted us to investigate the expression of the BCL-6 protein in Hodgkin 's disease ( HD ) , focusing on the nodular lymphocyte predominance subtype ( NLPHD ) , which differs from classical HD by virtue of the B-cell nature of the malignant cell population ( so-called L &amp; H cells ) and its relationship with germinal centers .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|43,46 G#cell_type|48,52 G#cell_type

Forty-one HD samples ( 19 NLPHD , 12 nodular sclerosis , and 10 mixed cellularity ) were immunostained with the monoclonal antibodies PG-B6 and PG-B6p that react with a fixative-sensitive and a formalin-resistant epitope on the aminoterminal region of the BCL-6 gene product , respectively .
20,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|40,43 G#protein

Strong nuclear positivity for the BCL-6 protein was detected in tumor ( L &amp; H ) cells in all cases of NLPHD .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|10,17 G#cell_type

In contrast , BCL-6 was expressed only in a small percentage of Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells in about 30 % of classical HD cases .
3,4 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_line

Notably , the nuclei of reactive CD3+/CD4+ T cells nearby to and rosetting around L &amp; H cells in NLPHD were also strongly BCL-6 + , but lacked CD40 ligand ( CD40L ) expression .
5,9 G#cell_type|14,18 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

This staining pattern clearly differed from that of classical HD , whose cellular background was made up of CD3+/CD4+ T cells showing the BCL-6 -/ CD40L + phenotype .
18,21 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

These results further support the concept that NLPHD is an histogenetically distinct , B-cell-derived subtype of HD and suggest a role for BCL-6 in its development .
22,23 G#protein

Selenium -mediated inhibition of transcription factor NF-kappa B and HIV-1 LTR promoter activity .
4,8 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA

The eukaryotic transcription factor NF-kappa B is involved in the inducible expression of various inflammatory genes as well as in HIV-1 replication .
2,6 G#protein|1,6 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA

Activation of NF-kappa B is induced by prooxidants and several stimuli eliciting oxidative stress , such as cytokines , lipopolysaccharide , UV irradiation and other mediators .
2,4 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Various antioxidants inhibit NF-kappa B activation in response to these stimuli .
3,5 G#protein

In this study , we have investigated the effects of selenium , an integral component of glutathione peroxidase ( GPX ) , on NF-kappa B activation .
16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

In selenium -deprived Jurkat and ESb-L T lymphocytes , supplementation of selenium led to a substantial increase of GPX activity .
1,4 G#cell_line|5,8 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein

Analysis of DNA binding revealed that NF-kappa B activation in response to TNF was significantly inhibited under these conditions .
6,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Likewise , reporter gene assays using luciferase constructs driven by the HIV-1 long terminal repeat showed a dose-dependent inhibition of NF-kappa B controlled gene expression by selenium .
11,15 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein

The effects of selenium were specific for NF-kappa B , since the activity of the transcription factor AP-1 was not suppressed .
7,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

These data suggest that selenium supplementation may be used to modulate the expression of NF-kappa B target genes and HIV-1 .
14,16 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA

The involvement of p23 , hsp90 , and immunophilins in the assembly of progesterone receptor complexes .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

To better understand the assembly mechanism for the progesterone receptor ( PR ) , we have developed cell-free systems for studying interactions of PR , hsp90 , and other associated proteins .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

When PR is incubated in rabbit reticulocyte lysate , its association with hsp90 , hsp70 , the three immunophilins FKBP54 , FKBP52 and CyP-40 , and with p23 is observed .
1,2 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

These interactions require ATP/Mg2+ and when ATP is limiting the PR complex is altered to one containing the proteins p60 and p48 , but lacking immunophilins and p23 .
10,11 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

We have studied two pre-formed hsp90 complexes that may participate in the assembly of PR complexes .
5,6 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

One contains hsp90 bound to hsp70 and p60 and this complex forms spontaneously in the absence of ATP .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

A second complex contains hsp90 bound to p23 plus the three immunophilins and some hsp70 .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The formation of this complex requires ATP .


In further studies we have shown that purified hsp90 can bind to purified p23 and this interaction requires both ATP and molybdate .
8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

This explains , in part , the known effects of ATP and molybdate on assembly of PR complexes .
16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Increased IkappaB expression and diminished nuclear NF-kappaB in human mononuclear cells following hydrocortisone injection .
1,2 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type

We have recently demonstrated that hydrocortisone and other glucocorticoids inhibit reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) generation by mononuclear ( MNC ) and polymorphonuclear leucocytes ( PMNL ) .
18,25 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type

Since NF-kappaB/ IkappaB system regulates the transcription of proinflammatory genes , including those responsible for ROS generation , we tested the hypothesis that hydrocortisone may stimulate IkappaB production thus inhibiting NF-kappaB translocation from the cytosol into the nucleus in MNC , in vivo .
2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|39,40 G#cell_type

One hundred milligram of hydrocortisone was injected intravenously into 4 normal subjects .


Blood samples were obtained prior to the injection and at 1 , 2 , 4 , 8 and 24 hr after the injection .


Nuclear extracts and total cell lysates were prepared from MNC by standard techniques .
9,10 G#cell_type

IkappaB levels in MNC homogenates increased at 1 hr , peaked at 2-4 hr , started to decrease at 8 hr , and returned to baseline levels at 24 hr .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#cell_type

NF-kappaB in MNC nuclear extracts decreased at 1 hr , reached a nadir at 4 hr , gradually increased at 8 hr and returned back to baseline levels at 24 hr .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#cell_type

The total protein content of NF-kappaB subunit ( P65 ) in MNC lysates also showed a decrease following hydrocortisone injection .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type

This decrease was observed at 2 hr , reached a nadir at 4 hr , and returned to baseline levels at 24 hr .


ROS generation inhibition paralleled NF-kappaB levels in the nucleus .
4,5 G#protein

It was inhibited at 1 hr , reached a nadir at 2-4 hr , started to increase at 8 hr , and returned to basal levels at 24 hr .


Our data demonstrate that hydrocortisone induces IkappaB and suppresses NF-kappaB expression in MNC in parallel .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type

IkappaB further reduces the translocation of NF-kappaB into the nucleus thus preventing the expression of proinflammatory genes .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

Glucocorticoids induce apoptosis in human monocytes : potential role of IL-1 beta .
4,6 G#cell_type|10,12 G#protein

Glucocorticoids ( GC ) are potent anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive agents that act on a variety of immune cells , including monocytes and macrophages .
16,18 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type

However , the exact cellular mechanisms underlying this anti-inflammatory capacity are still unknown .


In our study , we determined the induction of apoptosis by GC in human monocytes .
14,15 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type

Peripheral blood monocytes were isolated by density centrifugation methods with a purity of &gt; 90 % and were cultured in RPMI 1640 medium .
0,3 G#cell_type

Monocyte apoptosis was determined by four independent methods , including annexin-V staining , TUNEL , DNA-laddering , and typical morphology by means of transmission electron microscopy .


TNF-alpha and IL-1beta were measured by ELISA .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein

GC receptor was blocked with mifepristone .
0,2 G#protein

Caspase 3 was inhibited with caspase-3 inhibitor ( DEVD-CHO ) .


Stimulation with different GC at therapeutic concentrations resulted in monocyte apoptosis in a time- and dose- dependent manner .


Necrosis was excluded by propidium iodide staining .


Proinflammatory cytokines such as IL-1beta and TNF-alpha were down-regulated by GC treatment .
1,2 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Continuous treatment of monocytes with IL-1beta , but not with TNF-alpha , could almost completely prevent GC -induced cell death .
3,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

The addition of mifepristone or caspase-3 inhibitor could partially abrogate GC -induced apoptosis as well as GC -induced inhibition of IL-1beta .
20,21 G#protein

This is the first study to demonstrate induction of apoptosis by GC in human monocytes .
13,15 G#cell_type

GC -induced monocyte apoptosis may be partially mediated through effects on IL-1beta production .
11,12 G#protein

It is conceivable that GC exert their anti-inflammatory capacity in various diseases , at least in part , by the induction of apoptosis in monocytes .
24,25 G#cell_type

Differential effects of lipopolysaccharide and tumor necrosis factor on monocytic IkappaB kinase signalsome activation and IkappaB proteolysis .
5,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

The inflammatory mediators lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) and tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) are potent activators of NF-kappaB .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

This study compared the effect of these stimuli on endogenous IkappaB kinase ( IKK ) signalsome activation and IkappaB phosphorylation/proteolysis in human monocytic cells and investigated the role of the signalsome proteins IKK-alpha , IKK-beta , NF-kappaB -inducing kinase ( NIK ) , IKK-gamma ( NF-kappaB essential modulator ) , and IKK complex -associated protein .
10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type|30,32 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|36,39 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|51,53 G#protein|51,55 G#protein

Kinase assays showed that TNF elicited a rapid but short-lived induction of IKK activity with a 3-fold greater effect on IKK -alpha than on IKK-beta , peaking at 5 min .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

In contrast , LPS predominantly stimulated IKK-beta activity , which slowly increased , peaking at 30 min .
6,7 G#protein

A second peak was observed at a later time point following LPS stimulation , which consisted of both IKK -alpha and -beta activity .


The endogenous levels of the signalsome components were unaffected by stimulation .


Furthermore , our studies showed association of the IKK-alpha /beta heterodimer with NIK , IkappaB -alpha and -epsilon in unstimulated cells .
8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

Exposure to LPS or TNF led to differential patterns of IkappaB -alpha and IkappaB -epsilon disappearance from and reassembly with the signalsome , whereas IKK-alpha , IKK-beta , and NIK remained complex-associated .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

NIK can not phosphorylate IkappaB -alpha directly , but it appears to be a functionally important subunit , because mutated NIK inhibited stimulus-induced kappaB -dependent transcription more effectively than mutated IKK-alpha or -beta .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Overexpression of IKK complex -associated protein inhibited stimulus-mediated transcription , whereas NF-kappaB essential modulator enhanced it .
2,4 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

The understanding of LPS- and TNF- induced signaling may allow the development of specific strategies to treat sepsis-associated disease .


Tumor necrosis factor alpha decreases , and interleukin-10 increases , the sensitivity of human monocytes to dexamethasone : potential regulation of the glucocorticoid receptor .
0,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein

Resistance to glucocorticoid therapy has been observed in patients with autoimmune/inflammatory diseases and may be related to the inflammatory process itself .


The aim of this study was to examine the ability of tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNFalpha , a proinflammatory cytokine ) and interleukin ( IL ) -10 ( an anti-inflammatory cytokine ) to differentially regulate the sensitivity of human monocytes /macrophages to glucocorticoids .
11,14 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,28 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|39,41 G#cell_type|41,42 G#cell_type

To accomplish this , we first analyzed the pattern of TNFalpha and IL-10 inhibition by dexamethasone in LPS -stimulated whole-blood cell cultures .
10,11 G#protein|17,22 G#cell_line

Second , we studied the modulation of the sensitivity of these cells to dexamethasone by preincubation with TNFalpha or IL-10 and measurement of LPS -stimulated IL-6 secretion .
17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

In addition , we evaluated the effect of dexamethasone on phorbolmyristate-acetate -stimulated IL-1 receptor antagonist secretion by the human monocytic cell line U937 .
12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|18,23 G#cell_line

Finally , we investigated whether the modulation of corticosensitivity in TNFalpha- and IL-10- pretreated U937 cells was related to a change of the glucocorticoid receptor concentration and affinity .
10,16 G#cell_line|23,25 G#protein

Dexamethasone had different effects on LPS -induced TNFalpha and IL-10 secretion ; whereas it suppressed TNFalpha in a dose-dependent fashion , its effect on IL-10 secretion was biphasic , producing stimulation at lower , and inhibition at higher doses .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

The concentration of LPS employed influenced the effect of dexamethasone on IL-10 secretion ( P &lt; 0.001 ) .
11,12 G#protein

Pretreatment with TNFalpha diminished , and with IL-10 improved , the ability of dexamethasone to suppress IL-6 secretion in whole-blood cell cultures ( P &lt; 0.01 for both ) and to enhance IL-1 receptor antagonist secretion by U937 cells ( P &lt; 0.05 for both ) .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein

TNFalpha decreased ( P &lt; 0.001 ) , while IL-10 increased ( P &lt; 0.001 ) , the concentration of dexamethasone binding sites in these cells , with no discernible effect on their binding affinity .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

We conclude that glucocorticoids differentially modulate TNFalpha and IL-10 secretion by human monocytes in a LPS dose-dependent fashion and that the sensitivity of these cells to glucocorticoids is altered by TNFalpha or IL-10 pretreatment ; TNFalpha blocks their effects , whereas IL-10 acts synergistically with glucocorticoids .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

This is accompanied by opposite glucocorticoid receptor changes , respectively opposing and favoring glucocorticoid actions .
5,7 G#protein

This study suggests that the pattern of pro-/antiinflammatory cytokine secretion may alter the response of patients to glucocorticoid therapy .
8,9 G#protein

Block of granulocytic differentiation of 32Dcl3 cells by AML1/ETO ( MTG8 ) but not by highly expressed Bcl-2 .
5,7 G#cell_line|8,12 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein

The chimeric gene , AML1/ETO ( MTG8 ) , generated in t(8;21) acute myeloid leukemia enhances the expression of Bcl-2 .
1,4 G#DNA|4,8 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein

To evaluate whether this enhancement is the primary role of AML1/ETO in leukemogenesis , effects of over-expression of Bcl-2 in the murine myeloid precursor cell line , 32Dcl3 , were examined .
10,11 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_line|27,28 G#cell_line

When 32Dcl3 cells expressing exogenous Bcl-2 were induced to differentiate , the onset of morphological differentiation was delayed .
1,3 G#cell_line|5,6 G#protein

However , even the cells expressing very high levels of exogenous Bcl-2 eventually underwent differentiation without a significant decrease in the synthesis of Bcl-2 .
11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

On the contrary , 32Dcl3 cells stably expressing AML1/ETO were completely resistant to differentiation and continued to grow in the presence of G-CSF .
4,6 G#cell_line|8,9 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein

These results are consistent with the interpretation that stimulation of Bcl-2 expression is not the primary target of AML1/ETO .
10,11 G#protein|18,19 G#DNA

Host defense mechanisms triggered by microbial lipoproteins through toll-like receptors .
5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

The generation of cell-mediated immunity against many infectious pathogens involves the production of interleukin-12 ( IL-12 ) , a key signal of the innate immune system .
13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Yet , for many pathogens , the molecules that induce IL-12 production by macrophages and the mechanisms by which they do so remain undefined .
10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

Here it is shown that microbial lipoproteins are potent stimulators of IL-12 production by human macrophages , and that induction is mediated by Toll-like receptors ( TLRs ) .
5,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|23,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Several lipoproteins stimulated TLR-dependent transcription of inducible nitric oxide synthase and the production of nitric oxide , a powerful microbicidal pathway .
7,10 G#protein

Activation of TLRs by microbial lipoproteins may initiate innate defense mechanisms against infectious pathogens .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

Abnormal NF-kappa B activity in T lymphocytes from patients with systemic lupus erythematosus is associated with decreased p65-RelA protein expression .
1,3 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

Numerous cellular and biochemical abnormalities in immune regulation have been described in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE ) , including surface Ag receptor -initiated signaling events and lymphokine production .
23,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Because NF-kappa B contributes to the transcription of numerous inflammatory genes and has been shown to be a molecular target of antiinflammatory drugs , we sought to characterize the functional role of the NF-kappa B protein complex in lupus T cells .
1,3 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|33,35 G#protein|33,37 G#protein|38,41 G#cell_type

Freshly isolated T cells from lupus patients , rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) patients , and normal individuals were activated physiologically via the TCR with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 Abs to assess proximal membrane signaling , and with PMA and a calcium ionophore ( A23187 ) to bypass membrane-mediated signaling events .
2,4 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

We measured the NF-kappa B binding activity in nuclear extracts by gel shift analysis .
3,5 G#protein

When compared with normal cells , the activation of NF-kappa B activity in SLE patients was significantly decreased in SLE , but not in RA , patients .
3,5 G#cell_type|9,11 G#protein

NF-kappa B binding activity was absent in several SLE patients who were not receiving any medication , including corticosteroids .
0,2 G#protein

Also , NF-kappa B activity remained absent in follow-up studies .
2,4 G#protein

In supershift experiments using specific Abs , we showed that , in the group of SLE patients who displayed undetectable NF-kappa B activity , p65 complexes were not formed .
5,6 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

Finally , immunoblot analysis of nuclear extracts showed decreased or absent p65 protein levels .
11,13 G#protein

As p65 complexes are transcriptionally active in comparison to the p50 homodimer , this novel finding may provide insight on the origin of abnormal cytokine or other gene transcription in SLE patients .
1,3 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Signaling events induced by lipopolysaccharide-activated toll-like receptor 2 .
4,8 G#protein

Human Toll-like receptor 2 ( TLR2 ) is a signaling receptor that responds to LPS and activates NF-kappaB .
5,6 G#protein|0,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Here , we investigate further the events triggered by TLR2 in response to LPS .
9,10 G#protein

We show that TLR2 associates with the high-affinity LPS binding protein membrane CD14 to serve as an LPS receptor complex , and that LPS treatment enhances the oligomerization of TLR2 .
3,4 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Concomitant with receptor oligomerization , the IL-1R-associated kinase ( IRAK ) is recruited to the TLR2 complex .
9,10 G#protein|6,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Intracellular deletion variants of TLR2 lacking C-terminal 13 or 141 aa fail to recruit IRAK , which is consistent with the inability of these mutants to transmit LPS cellular signaling .
4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Moreover , both deletion mutants could still form complexes with wild-type TLR2 and act in a dominant-negative ( DN ) fashion to block TLR2 -mediated signal transduction .
11,12 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

DN constructs of myeloid differentiation protein , IRAK , TNF receptor-associated factor 6 , and NF-kappaB -inducing kinase , when coexpressed with TLR2 , abrogate TLR2 -mediated NF-kappaB activation .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

These results reveal a conserved signaling pathway for TLR2 and IL-1Rs and suggest a molecular mechanism for the inhibition of TLR2 by DN variants .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Tyrphostin AG-490 inhibits cytokine-mediated JAK3 /STAT5a/b signal transduction and cellular proliferation of antigen-activated human T cells .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

Janus kinase 3 ( JAK3 ) is a cytoplasmic tyrosine kinase required for T cell development and activated by cytokines that utilize the interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) receptor common gamma chain ( gamma(c) ) .
4,5 G#protein|0,6 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|23,34 G#protein

Genetic inactivation of JAK3 is manifested as severe combined immunodeficiency disease ( SCID ) in humans and mice .
3,4 G#protein

These findings have suggested that JAK3 represents a pharmacological target to control certain lymphoid-derived diseases .
5,6 G#protein

Here we provide novel evidence that AG-490 potently inhibits the autokinase activity of JAK3 and tyrosine phosphorylation and DNA binding of signal transducer and activator of transcription 5a and 5b ( STAT5a/b ) .
13,14 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|21,33 G#protein

Similar inhibitory effects were observed with other cytokines that use gamma(c) .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

AG-490 also inhibited IL-2 -mediated proliferative growth in human T cells with an IC50) = 25 microM that was partially recoverable .
3,4 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Moreover , we demonstrate that this inhibitor prevented tetanus toxoid antigen-specific T cell proliferation and expansion but failed to block activation of Zap70 or p56Lck after anti-CD3 stimulation of human T cells .
22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type

Taken together , these findings suggest that AG-490 inhibits the JAK3 -mediated Type II signaling pathway but not the T cell receptor-derived Type I pathway and possesses therapeutic potential for T cell -derived pathologies such as graft-versus-host disease , allergy , and autoimmune disorders .
10,11 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|30,32 G#cell_type

C/EBP beta in rheumatoid arthritis : correlation with inflammation , not disease specificity .
0,2 G#protein

Rheumatoid arthritis synovial tissue was examined and compared with osteoarthritis tissue for the presence of the nuclear transcription factor C/EBP beta ( NF-IL-6 ) .
19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|16,24 G#protein

The region ( lining or sublining ) , cell type , and subcellular distribution ( cytoplasmic or nuclear ) of the expression of C/EBP beta was characterized .
23,25 G#protein

Rheumatoid arthritis synovial fluid and blood and normal peripheral blood were also examined .


C/EBP beta was detected in the synovial lining and in sublining cells of synovial tissue from patients with both rheumatoid and osteoarthritis .
0,2 G#protein|10,15 G#cell_type

A significant ( P &lt; 0.001 and &lt; 0.05 , respectively ) increase in the percentage of cells with nuclear staining was seen in the lining layer , compared to cells in the sublining region , in rheumatoid and osteoarthritis .


In both diseases a strong correlation ( r = 0.79 , P &lt; 0.001 ) was observed between the percentage of cells in the synovial lining that were positive for nuclear C/EBP beta and lining cell depth .
30,33 G#protein

Two-color immunohistochemistry demonstrated that both macrophages and fibroblast-like synoviocytes were positive for nuclear C/EBP beta .
5,6 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|13,15 G#protein

The presence of C/EBP beta was confirmed by immunohistochemistry and Western blot analysis with isolated synovial fibroblasts .
3,5 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

Nuclear C/EBP beta was also detected in rheumatoid synovial fluid monocytes /macrophages , but not in lymphocytes or neutrophils .
1,3 G#protein|7,19 G#cell_type

Western blot analysis confirmed the presence of C/EBP beta in these cells .
7,9 G#protein

The intensity of C/EBP beta staining was greater ( P &lt; 0.001 ) in synovial fluid monocytes than in those from normal or rheumatoid peripheral blood .
3,5 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|21,26 G#cell_type

In conclusion , the enhanced nuclear staining for C/EBP beta in the synovial lining , compared to the sublining , suggesting activation in the lining , and the positive correlation of lining layer depth with the percentage of cells in the lining positive for nuclear C/EBP beta , suggest a potential role for C/EBP beta in chronic inflammation .
8,10 G#protein|45,47 G#protein|53,55 G#protein

The regulation of the production or activity of C/EBP beta , to inhibit inflammatory mediator expression by synovial macrophages and fibroblasts , offers a novel approach to therapeutic intervention .
8,10 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type

Direct interaction of hematopoietic transcription factors PU.1 and GATA-1 : functional antagonism in erythroid cells .
3,9 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Malignant transformation usually inhibits terminal cell differentiation but the precise mechanisms involved are not understood .


PU.1 is a hematopoietic-specific Ets family transcription factor that is required for development of some lymphoid and myeloid lineages .
0,1 G#protein|3,8 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_type

PU.1 can also act as an oncoprotein as activation of its expression in erythroid precursors by proviral insertion or transgenesis causes erythroleukemias in mice .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Restoration of terminal differentiation in the mouse erythroleukemia ( MEL ) cells requires a decline in the level of PU.1 , indicating that PU.1 can block erythroid differentiation .
9,10 G#cell_line|6,12 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Here we investigate the mechanism by which PU.1 interferes with erythroid differentiation .
7,8 G#protein

We find that PU.1 interacts directly with GATA-1 , a zinc finger transcription factor required for erythroid differentiation .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,14 G#protein

Interaction between PU.1 and GATA-1 requires intact DNA-binding domains in both proteins .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

PU.1 represses GATA-1 -mediated transcriptional activation .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein

Both the DNA binding and transactivation domains of PU.1 are required for repression and both domains are also needed to block terminal differentiation in MEL cells .
2,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_line

We also show that ectopic expression of PU.1 in Xenopus embryos is sufficient to block erythropoiesis during normal development .
7,8 G#protein

Furthermore , introduction of exogenous GATA-1 in both MEL cells and Xenopus embryos and explants relieves the block to erythroid differentiation imposed by PU.1 .
5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein

Our results indicate that the stoichiometry of directly interacting but opposing transcription factors may be a crucial determinant governing processes of normal differentiation and malignant transformation .
11,13 G#protein

IL-12 induces IFN regulating factor-1 ( IRF-1 ) gene expression in human NK and T cells .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|2,8 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

IL-12 is a critical immunoregulatory cytokine that promotes cell-mediated immune responses and the differentiation of naive CD4+ cells to Th1 cells ; however , relatively few IL-12 target genes have been identified .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein

To better clarify the molecular basis of IL-12 action , we set out to characterize genes up-regulated by IL-12 , first by contrasting IL-12 - and IFN -alpha-inducible genes .
7,8 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA

We identified several genes up-regulated by IL-12 , namely , MIP-1alpha , MIP-1beta , IL-1RA , and IFN regulatory factor-1 ( IRF-1 ) .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|17,23 G#protein

IRF-1 is a transcription factor regulated by IFNs that is also essential for Th1 responses .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

We demonstrated that IL-12 directly up-regulates IRF-1 to the same extent as IFN-alpha in normal human T cells and in NK cells .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type

We showed that IL-12 had a direct effect on IRF-1 , an effect not mediated indirectly by the induction of IFN-gamma production .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Furthermore , IL-2 and IL-12 synergistically induced IRF-1 , whereas IFN-alpha and IL-12 did not .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The participation of STAT4 in the regulation of IRF-1 was demonstrated in two ways .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

First , STAT4 was required for the IL-12 -dependent transactivation of an IRF-1 reporter construct , and second , STAT4 binding to the IRF-1 promoter was shown using EMSA .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA

In contrast to IL-12 , no up-regulation of IRF-1 was found in IL-4 -stimulated cells , and IL-4 did not block IL-12 -dependent up-regulation of IRF-1 .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Therefore , IRF-1 may be an important contributor to IL-12 signaling , and we speculate that the defective IL-12 responses seen in IRF -1-/- mice might be attributable , in part , to the absence of this transcription factor .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

Targeted remodeling of human beta-globin promoter chromatin structure produces increased expression and decreased silencing .
3,8 G#DNA

The chromatin structure of the human beta-globin gene locus assumes a transcriptionally-active conformation in erythroid cells .
1,3 G#DNA|5,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type

One feature of this chromatin reorganization is the formation of DNase 1 hypersensitive sites in the regions of active globin gene promoters .
10,14 G#DNA|18,22 G#DNA

This reorganization requires the globin locus control region and is associated with normal expression of the beta-like globin genes .
4,8 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA

To determine whether it is possible to artificially enhance the opening of the chromatin structure of a minimal beta-globin promoter , we placed a 101bp , erythroid-specific DNase 1 hypersensitive site-forming element ( HSFE ) immediately upstream of the beta-globin promoter and gene .
17,20 G#DNA|26,32 G#DNA|33,34 G#DNA|39,43 G#DNA

This element includes binding sites for NF-E2 , AP-1 , GATA-1 and Sp-1 .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Constructs were stably transfected into murine erythroleukemia cells and promoter chromatin structure and gene expression were analyzed .
5,8 G#cell_type|9,12 G#DNA

The HSFE induced an area of enhanced DNase 1 hypersensitivity extending from the transcriptional start site to -300bp of the artificial promoter and significantly increased the proportion of beta-globin promoters in an open chromatin configuration .
1,2 G#DNA|7,9 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|32,35 G#DNA

This remodeling of promoter chromatin structure resulted in 3-fold increases in beta-globin gene transcription and induction , and inhibited long-term beta-globin gene silencing .
3,6 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

These results indicate that a relatively small cis-acting element is able to enhance remodeling of promoter chromatin structure resulting in increased beta-globin gene expression .
7,9 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

Regulation of low shear flow-induced HAEC VCAM-1 expression and monocyte adhesion .
5,6 G#cell_line|6,7 G#protein

We recently reported that prolonged exposure of human aortic endothelial cells ( HAEC ) to low shear stress flow patterns is associated with a sustained increase in the activated form of the transcriptional regulator nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) .
7,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_line|34,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

Here we investigate the hypothesis that low shear-induced activation of NF-kappaB is responsible for enhanced expression of vascular cell adhesion molecule ( VCAM-1 ) resulting in augmented endothelial cell-monocyte ( EC-Mn ) adhesion and that this activation is dependent on intracellular oxidant activity .
10,11 G#protein|17,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Before exposure to low shear ( 2 dyn/cm2 ) for 6 h , HAEC were preincubated with or without the antioxidants pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ( PDTC ) or N-acetyl-L-cysteine ( NAC ) .
13,14 G#cell_line

PDTC strongly inhibited low shear-induced activation of NF-kappaB , expression of VCAM-1 , and EC-Mn adhesion .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Paradoxically , NAC exerted a positive effect on low shear-induced VCAM-1 expression and EC-Mn adhesion and only slightly downregulated NF-kappaB activation .
10,11 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

However , cytokine-induced NF-kappaB activation and VCAM-1 expression are blocked by both PDTC and NAC .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

These data suggest that NF-kappaB plays a key role in low shear-induced VCAM-1 expression and that pathways mediating low shear- and cytokine-induced EC-Mn adhesion may be differentially regulated .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Nuclear factor-90 of activated T-cells : A double-stranded RNA -binding protein and substrate for the double-stranded RNA-dependent protein kinase , PKR .
0,2 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|7,9 G#RNA|15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

NFAT transcription factors play a central role in initiating T-cell activation through the induction of immediate-early T-cell specific genes including interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) .
22,23 G#protein

NFAT transcription factors bind to a sequence in the IL-2 enhancer known as the antigen receptor response element 2 ( ARRE-2 ) .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|14,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA

Multiple proteins exhibiting ARRE-2 binding activity have been isolated , including a heterodimer from stimulated T-cell nuclear extracts consisting of Mr = 90 000 ( NF90 ) and Mr = 45 000 ( NF45 ) subunits .
3,4 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

The subunits of this heterodimer have been cloned , and NF90 was found to encode a protein containing two domains that are predicted to form motifs capable of binding to double-stranded RNA .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|30,32 G#RNA

Using in vitro translated polypeptides , we have demonstrated that NF90 specifically binds to double-stranded RNA .
10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA

Furthermore , NF90 was phosphorylated in a double-stranded RNA -dependent manner likely by the interferon-induced , double-stranded RNA -dependent protein kinase , PKR .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA|16,18 G#RNA|16,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

The NF90 protein was found to be expressed not only in T-cells , but also in nonimmune HeLa cells .
1,2 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|16,19 G#cell_line

In HeLa cells , the protein was almost exclusively localized to the ribosome salt wash fraction of cell lysates .
1,3 G#cell_line

NF-kappaB activation is required for C5a -induced interleukin-8 gene expression in mononuclear cells .
0,1 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_type

C5a , a potent peptide chemoattractant , stimulates interleukin-8 ( IL-8 ) secretion from peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|14,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

Experiments were conducted to understand the mechanisms for C5a -induced IL-8 production , which was 14-fold greater than that in unstimulated cells by 2 hours .
10,11 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

IL-8 secretion was accompanied by accumulation of IL-8 mRNA in the cytosol and by nuclear expression of a kappaB DNA binding activity within 30 minutes .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA|18,19 G#protein

AP-1 but not NF-IL-6 DNA binding activity was also detected in C5a -stimulated PBMC ; however , its delayed expression ( maximal at 4 hours ) suggested a less important role in the rapid production of IL-8 .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|11,14 G#cell_line|36,37 G#protein

The correlation between C5a -induced kappaB binding activity and IL-8 gene expression was examined in the RAW264.7 macrophage cells using reporter genes directed by the kappaB sequence from IkappaBalpha and IL-8 promoter regions .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line|25,27 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|30,33 G#DNA

C5a -induced reporter gene expression was abolished by introducing mutations into the kappaB sites and by coexpression of a dominant negative IkappaBalpha construct resistant to agonist-induced phosphorylation .
2,4 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA

Pertussis toxin , which ADP -ribosylates the Gi proteins known to couple to the C5a receptor , produced minimal inhibition of C5a -induced IL-8 expression and had little effect on C5a -induced calcium mobilization in RAW264.7 cells .
7,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|35,37 G#cell_line

These results suggest that NF-kappaB activation is required for C5a -induced IL-8 gene expression and that this response is mediated primarily through a pertussis toxin -insensitive pathway .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Increased glucocorticoid receptor beta in airway cells of glucocorticoid -insensitive asthma .
1,4 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type

Glucocorticoid ( GC ) -insensitive asthma is a challenging clinical problem that can be associated with life-threatening disease progression .


The molecular basis of GC insensitivity is unknown .


Alternative splicing of the GC receptor ( GCR ) pre-mRNA generates a second GCR , termed GCRbeta , which does not bind GC but antagonizes the transactivating activity of the classic GCR .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|4,10 G#RNA|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Thus increased expression of GCRbeta could account for glucocorticoid insensitivity .
4,5 G#protein

Bronchoalveolar lavage ( BAL ) cells and peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) were examined for GCRbeta immunoreactivity using a GCRbeta -specific antibody by immunohistochemical staining .
0,6 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Cell localization of GCRbeta expression was performed using a double immunostaining technique .
3,4 G#protein

Patients with GC -insensitive asthma expressed a significantly higher number of GCRbeta -immunoreactive cells in their BAL and peripheral blood than GC -sensitive asthmatics or normal control subjects .
11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

Furthermore , GCRbeta expression in GC-insensitive asthma was particularly high in airway T cells , which are thought to play a major role in the pathogenesis of asthma .
2,3 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

We also examined the expression of GCRbeta in specimens from the airways of patients with chronic bronchitis .
6,7 G#protein

In chronic bronchitis , few cells were GCRbeta -positive and their numbers did not differ significantly from normal control subjects .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

We conclude that GC -insensitive asthma is associated with increased expression of GCRbeta in airway T cells .
12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

Activation of the Janus kinase 3 -STAT5a pathway after CD40 triggering of human monocytes but not of resting B cells .
3,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type

CD40 /CD40 ligand interactions play a key role in the immune responses of B lymphocytes , monocytes , and dendritic cells .
0,1 G#protein|1,2 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type

The signal transduction events triggered by cross-linking of the CD40 receptor have been widely studied in B cell lines , but little is known about signaling following CD40 stimulation of monocytes and resting tonsillar B cells .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_type|32,36 G#cell_line

Therefore , we studied the CD40 pathway in highly purified human monocytes and resting B cells .
5,6 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_type

After CD40 triggering , a similar activation of the NF-kappaB ( but not of the AP-1 ) transcription factor complex occurred in both cell preparations .
1,2 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

However , the components of the NF-kappaB complexes were different in monocytes and B cells , because p50 is part of the NF-kappaB complex induced by CD40 triggering in both monocytes and B cells , whereas p65 was only induced in B cells . In contrast , although the Janus kinase 3 tyrosine kinase was associated with CD40 molecules in both monocytes and resting B cells , Janus kinase 3 phosphorylation induction was observed only in CD40 -activated monocytes , with subsequent induction of STAT5a DNA binding activity in the nucleus .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_type|32,34 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein|41,43 G#cell_type|49,52 G#protein|49,54 G#protein|57,58 G#protein|61,62 G#cell_type|63,66 G#cell_type|67,70 G#protein|76,77 G#protein|76,79 G#cell_line|84,85 G#protein

These results suggest that the activation signals in human B cells and monocytes differ following CD40 stimulation .
8,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

This observation is consistent with the detection of normal CD40 -induced monocyte activation in patients with CD40 ligand+ hyper IgM syndrome in whom a defect in CD40 -induced B cell activation has been reported .
9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Genetic evidence for an additional factor required for erythropoietin -induced signal transduction .
8,9 G#protein

Erythropoietin ( EPO ) and its receptor ( EPOR ) are required for the development of mature erythrocytes .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

After binding of ligand , the EPOR activates a variety of signaling pathways that ultimately control cellular proliferation , survival , and specific gene expression .
6,7 G#protein

Although erythroid progenitors appear to be the principal EPO -responsive cell type in vivo due to the restricted expression of the EPOR , many growth factor-dependent cell lines expressing the EPOR can respond to EPO by activating many or all of these pathways .
1,3 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|8,12 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|24,28 G#cell_line|30,31 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

In the present study , we have identified a cellular context ( the interleukin-2 [ IL-2 ] -dependent HT-2 line ) in which the EPO stimulation of the EPOR fails to support cellular proliferation , STAT-5 induction , or MAPK activation , despite efficient phosphorylation of the EPOR and JAK2 and inhibition of apoptosis after withdrawal of IL-2 .
13,20 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|47,48 G#protein|49,50 G#protein|57,58 G#protein

Interestingly , when we fused HT-2 cells expressing the EPOR with Ba/F3 cells in a complementation assay , the resulting hybridomas proliferated and potently activated STAT-5 and MAPK in response to EPO .
5,7 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line|20,21 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

These data indicate that an unidentified cellular factor is needed to mediate signaling by the EPOR .
5,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Moreover , Ba/F3 cells apparently express this factor ( s ) and somatic fusions can , therefore , confer EPO -responsiveness to HT-2 cells that lack this factor .
2,4 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_line

Novel therapies for inflammatory bowel disease .


Looking back at successes and failures in newer approaches to treating IBD , it is tempting -- although still difficult -- to draw conclusions about pathogenesis .


When a therapy proves effective , do clinicians truly know how it works ? Even with a therapy as specific as anti-TNF antibody , it is not clear if the benefit is attributable to simple binding and clearance of TNF-alpha or to binding on the cell surface and subsequent deletion of the activated macrophage .
21,23 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|52,54 G#cell_type

When a drug appears to be less effective than preclinical models suggest , can failures in effectiveness from delivery or dosing be differentiated ? The disappointing results of clinical trials with IL-10 -- so at odds with the prediction of benefit from animal models -- bring into question the validity of those models as well as the soundness of design of the clinical trials on which efficacy of IL-10 is judged .
31,32 G#protein|68,69 G#protein

The variability of response even to the most narrowly targeted agents suggests that these diseases are far more heterogeneous in humans than in their murine counterparts .


Clinicians are only just beginning to recognize subclinical markers of response , and it may soon be possible to predict response on the basis of genetic composition .


For the moment , however , the field of pharmacogenetics is embryonic .


Challenges in developing new therapeutic strategies include not only identifying novel agents , but also improving the definitions of clinical endpoints and defining efficacy at the biologic level .


Only through considered evaluation of clinical evidence may clinicians determine which therapies should remain novelties and which should become an accepted part of the armamentarium .


Potent and stable attenuation of live-HIV-1 by gain of a proteolysis-resistant inhibitor of NF-kappaB ( IkappaB-alphaS32/36A ) and the implications for vaccine development .
10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Live-attenuated human immunodeficiency viruses ( HIVs ) are candidates for Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome ( AIDS ) vaccine .


Based on the simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIV ) model for AIDS , loss-of-function ( e.g. deletion of accessory genes such as nef ) has been forwarded as a primary approach for creating enfeebled , but replication-competent , HIV-1/SIV .
22,23 G#DNA

Regrettably , recent evidence suggests that loss-of-function alone is not always sufficient to prevent the emergence of virulent mutants .


New strategies that attenuate via mechanisms distinct from loss-of-function are needed for enhancing the safety phenotype of viral genome .
17,19 G#DNA

Here , we propose gain-of-function to be used simultaneously with loss-of-function as a novel approach for attenuating HIV-1 .


We have constructed an HIV-1 genome carrying the cDNA of a proteolysis-resistant nuclear factor-kappaB inhibitor ( IkappaB-alphaS32/36A ) in the nef region .
4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

HIV-1 expressing IkappaB-alphaS32/36A down-regulates viral expression and is highly attenuated in both Jurkat and peripheral blood mononuclear cells .
2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_line|14,18 G#cell_type

We provide formal proof that the phenotypic and attenuating characteristics of IkappaB-alphaS32/36A permit its stable maintenance in a live , replicating HIV-1 despite 180 days of forced ex vivo passaging in tissue culture .
11,12 G#protein

As compared with other open-reading frames embedded into HIV/SIV genome , this degree of stability is unprecedented .
4,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA

Thus , IkappaB-alphaS32/36A offers proof-of-principle that artifactually gained functions , when used to attenuate the replication of live HIV-1 , can be stable .
2,3 G#protein

These findings illustrate gain-of-function as a feasible strategy for developing safer live-attenuated HIVs to be tested as candidates for AIDS vaccine .


Multiple NF-ATc isoforms with individual transcriptional properties are synthesized in T lymphocytes .
1,3 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

The transcription factor NF-ATc that controls gene expression in T lymphocytes and embryonic cardiac cells is expressed in three prominent isoforms .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_type

This is due to alternative splice/polyadenylation events that lead to the predominant synthesis of two long isoforms in naive T cells and a shorter NF-ATc isoform in effector T cells .
18,21 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,30 G#cell_type

Whereas the previously described isoform NF-ATc /A contains a relatively short C terminus , the longer isoforms , B and C , span extra C-terminal peptides of 128 and 246 aa , respectively .
5,6 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

We show here that in addition to the strong N-terminal trans-activation domain , TAD-A , which is common to all three NF-ATc isoforms , NF-ATc /C contains a second trans-activation domain , TAD-B , in its C-terminal peptide .
8,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Various stimuli of T cells that induce the activity of TAD-A also enhance the activity of TAD-B , but , unlike TAD-A , TAD-B remains unphosphorylated by protein from 12-O-tetradecanoyl 12-phorbol 13-acetate -stimulated T cells .
3,5 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type|29,35 G#cell_line

The shorter C-terminal peptide of isoform NF-ATc /B exerts a suppressive transcriptional effect .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein

These properties of NF-ATc / B and - C might be of importance for gene regulation in naive T lymphocytes in which NF-ATc / B and - C are predominantly synthesized .
3,9 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type|22,28 G#protein

Selection and long-term persistence of reactive CTL clones during an EBV chronic response are determined by avidity , CD8 variable contribution compensating for differences in TCR affinities .
6,8 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Recent studies have suggested that the diversity of TCR repertoire after primary immunization is conserved in memory T cells and that a progressive narrowing of this repertoire may take place during recall infections .
8,9 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

It now remains to be investigated which parameters determine the repertoire of the memory response and possibly restrict its diversity after subsequent antigenic challenges .


To address this question , we took advantage of a panel of CD8+ T cell clones from the joint of a rheumatoid arthritis patient and selected for their reactivity against a single MHC/peptide complex .
12,16 G#cell_line|31,34 G#protein

Characterization of both TCR chains documented a great diversity among those clones and the persistence of clonotypes over a 2-yr period .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein

Strikingly , despite the observed repertoire heterogeneity , all clones displayed a narrow range of MHC /peptide density requirements in cytotoxicity assays ( ED50 between 9 and 36 nM ) .
15,16 G#protein

TCR affinities were then indirectly estimated by blocking CD8 interaction with an anti-CD8 mAb .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

We found a wide range of TCR affinities among the different clonotypes that segregated with Vbeta usage .
6,7 G#protein

We thus propose that during an in vivo chronic response , a narrow range of avidity of the TCR -CD8 complex conditions long-term clonotype persistence , and that the level of CD8 contribution is adjusted to keep clonotypes with variable TCR affinities within this avidity window .
18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

Nuclear localization and formation of beta-catenin -lymphoid enhancer factor 1 complexes are not sufficient for activation of gene expression .
5,6 G#protein|5,11 G#protein

In response to activation of the Wnt signaling pathway , beta-catenin accumulates in the nucleus , where it cooperates with LEF/TCF ( for lymphoid enhancer factor and T-cell factor ) transcription factors to activate gene expression .
10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,29 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

The mechanisms by which beta-catenin undergoes this shift in location and participates in activation of gene transcription are unknown .
4,5 G#protein

We demonstrate here that beta-catenin can be imported into the nucleus independently of LEF/TCF binding , and it may also be exported from nuclei .
4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

We have introduced a small deletion within beta-catenin ( Delta19 ) that disrupts binding to LEF-1 , E-cadherin , and APC but not axin .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

This Delta19 beta-catenin mutant localizes to the nucleus because it may not be efficiently sequestered in the cytoplasm .
1,2 G#DNA|2,3 G#protein|1,4 G#protein

The nuclear localization of Delta19 definitively demonstrates that the mechanisms by which beta-catenin localizes in the nucleus are completely independent of LEF/TCF factors .
4,5 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

beta-Catenin and LEF-1 complexes can activate reporter gene expression in a transformed T-lymphocyte cell line ( Jurkat ) but not in normal T lymphocytes , even though both factors are nuclear .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line|22,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type

Thus , localization of both factors to the nucleus is not sufficient for activation of gene expression .


Excess beta-catenin can squelch reporter gene activation by LEF-1 -beta-catenin complexes but not activation by the transcription factor VP16 .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Taken together , these data suggest that a third component is necessary for gene activation and that this third component may vary with cell type .


Control of lymphocyte development by the Ikaros gene family .
6,9 G#DNA

Lymphoid cell differentiation relies on precisely orchestrated gene activation and repression events .


Gene targeting studies have demonstrated crucial roles for the transcription factors Ikaros and Aiolos in regulating multiple stages of B and T cell development .
9,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Recent experiments suggest that Ikaros and Aiolos set B cell antigen-receptor ( BCR ) - and TCR- mediated signaling thresholds and that the molecules exist within T cells in nuclear complexes that contain nucleosome remodeling and histone deacetylase activities .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type|29,31 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

Transcriptional targeting of retroviral vectors to the erythroblastic progeny of transduced hematopoietic stem cells .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,14 G#cell_line

Targeted expression to specific tissues or cell lineages is a necessary feature of a gene therapy vector for many clinical applications , such as correction of hemoglobinopathies or thalassemias by transplantation of genetically modified hematopoietic stem cells .
32,37 G#cell_type

We developed retroviral vectors in which the constitutive viral enhancer in the U3 region of the 3' LTR is replaced by an autoregulatory enhancer of the erythroid-specific GATA-1 transcription factor gene .
7,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|28,30 G#protein|26,31 G#DNA

The replaced enhancer is propagated to the 5' LTR upon integration into the target cell genome .
1,3 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

The modified vectors were used to transduce human hematopoietic cell lines , cord blood-derived CD34(+) stem/progenitor cells , and murine bone marrow repopulating stem cells .
7,11 G#cell_line|12,17 G#cell_type|19,25 G#cell_line

The expression of appropriate reporter genes ( triangle upLNGFR , EGFP ) was analyzed in the differentiated progeny of transduced stem cells in vitro , in liquid culture as well as in clonogenic assay , and in vivo , after bone marrow transplantation in lethally irradiated mice .
4,6 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|19,22 G#cell_line

The GATA-1 autoregulatory enhancer effectively restricts the expression of the LTR-driven proviral transcription unit to the erythroblastic progeny of both human progenitors and mouse-repopulating stem cells .
1,4 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA|16,18 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type|23,26 G#cell_line

Packaging of viral particles , integration into the target genome , and stability of the integrated provirus are not affected by the LTR modification .
22,23 G#DNA

Enhancer replacement is therefore an effective strategy to target expression of a retroviral transgene to a specific progeny of transduced hematopoietic stem cells .
12,14 G#DNA|19,23 G#cell_line

Regulation of Fas ligand expression and cell death by apoptosis-linked gene 4 .
2,4 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA
