Programmed cell death is a process required for the normal development of an organism .


One of the best understood apoptotic pathways occurs in T lymphocytes and is mediated by Fas /Fas ligand ( FasL ) interaction .
9,11 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

During studies of apoptosis induced by T cell-receptor engagement , we identified ALG-4F , a truncated transcript that prevents T cell-receptor-induced FasL upregulation and cell death .
12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Overexpression of full-length ALG-4 induced transcription of FasL and , consequently , apoptosis .
2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

These results indicate that ALG-4 is necessary and sufficient for FasL expression .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Fas/ FasL interaction initiates cell death in many other systems , and its dysregulation is a mechanism by which several pathologic conditions arise .
1,2 G#protein

Understanding the molecular mechanisms of FasL regulation could be very useful in elucidating how these diseases develop and in identifying potential therapeutic targets .
5,6 G#protein

The Epstein-Barr virus oncoprotein latent membrane protein 1 engages the tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated proteins TRADD and receptor-interacting protein ( RIP ) but does not induce apoptosis or require RIP for NF-kappaB activation .
1,4 G#protein|1,8 G#protein|10,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

A site in the Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) transforming protein LMP1 that constitutively associates with the tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 ( TNFR1 ) -associated death domain protein TRADD to mediate NF-kappaB and c-Jun N-terminal kinase activation is critical for long-term lymphoblastoid cell proliferation .
4,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|17,29 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,37 G#protein

We now find that LMP1 signaling through TRADD differs from TNFR1 signaling through TRADD .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

LMP1 needs only 11 amino acids to activate NF-kappaB or synergize with TRADD in NF-kappaB activation , while TNFR1 requires approximately 70 residues .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Further , LMP1 does not require TRADD residues 294 to 312 for NF-kappaB activation , while TNFR1 requires TRADD residues 296 to 302 .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

LMP1 is partially blocked for NF-kappaB activation by a TRADD mutant consisting of residues 122 to 293 .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,17 G#protein

Unlike TNFR1 , LMP1 can interact directly with receptor-interacting protein ( RIP ) and stably associates with RIP in EBV -transformed lymphoblastoid cell lines .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,24 G#cell_line

Surprisingly , LMP1 does not require RIP for NF-kappaB activation .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Despite constitutive association with TRADD or RIP , LMP1 does not induce apoptosis in EBV-negative Burkitt lymphoma or human embryonic kidney 293 cells .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,23 G#cell_line

These results add a different perspective to the molecular interactions through which LMP1 , TRADD , and RIP participate in B-lymphocyte activation and growth .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Inhibition of NF-kappa B activity in human T lymphocytes induces caspase-dependent apoptosis without detectable activation of caspase -1 and -3 .
2,4 G#protein|16,20 G#protein

NF-kappa B is involved in the transcriptional control of various genes that act as extrinsic and intrinsic survival factors for T cells .
0,2 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type

Our findings show that suppression of NF-kappa B activity with cell-permeable SN50 peptide , which masks the nuclear localization sequence of NF-kappa B1 dimers and prevents their nuclear localization , induces apoptosis in resting normal human PBL .
6,8 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|33,37 G#cell_type

Inhibition of NF-kappa B resulted in the externalization of phosphatidylserine , induction of DNA breaks , and morphological changes consistent with apoptosis .
2,4 G#protein

DNA fragmentation was efficiently blocked by the caspase inhibitor Z-VAD-fmk and partially blocked by Ac-DEVD-fmk , suggesting that SN50 -mediated apoptosis is caspase -dependent .
7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Interestingly , apoptosis induced by NF-kappa B suppression , in contrast to that induced by TPEN ( N,N,N',N'-tetrakis [2-pyridylmethyl]ethylenediamine ) or soluble Fas ligand ( CD95 ) , was observed in the absence of active death effector proteases caspase-1 -like ( IL-1 converting enzyme ) , caspase-3 -like ( CPP32/Yama/apopain ) , and caspase-6 -like and without cleavage of caspase-3 substrates poly( ADP -ribose) polymerase and DNA fragmentation factor-45 .
5,7 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|34,38 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|41,44 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|49,50 G#protein|53,54 G#protein|59,60 G#protein|59,61 G#protein|61,65 G#protein|66,69 G#protein

These findings suggest either low level of activation is required or that different caspases are involved .
13,14 G#protein

Preactivation of T cells resulting in NF-kappa B nuclear translocation protected cells from SN50 -induced apoptosis .
2,4 G#cell_type|6,8 G#protein

Our findings demonstrate an essential role of NF-kappa B in survival of naive PBL .
7,9 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

Signal transduction pathways in normal human monocytes stimulated by cytokines and mediators : comparative study with normal human neutrophils or transformed cells and the putative roles in functionality and cell biology .
4,7 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_line

Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( GM-CSF ) and interleukin ( IL ) -3 induced tyrosine phosphorylation of 92-kDa protein in normal human monocytes .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type

We identified this 92-kDa protein as STAT5 , but not as STATs 1 , 3 , and 6 nor c-fes and vav protooncogene products , and demonstrated its translocation to the nucleus , enhancement of specific DNA binding capacity , and potentiation of trancriptional activity by GM-CSF .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

N-formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine ( FMLP ) and phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) induced tyrosine phosphorylation of 42- and 44- kDa proteins , which were identified as extracellular signal-regulated kinase ( ERK ) , in human monocytes .
15,20 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type

In marked contrast to neutrophils and MO7e cells , GM-CSF did not induce tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of ERK in monocytes .
4,5 G#cell_type|6,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type

Among upstream signaling molecules of ERK , Shc was constitutively associated with Grb2 and was not tyrosine -phosphorylated by GM-CSF and FMLP , and Sos1 and c-Raf-1 were not phosphorylated by GM-CSF , IL-3 , TNF , and FMLP in monocytes , whereas all these signaling molecules were affected and/or utilized by GM-CSF in MO7e cells .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|40,41 G#cell_type|52,53 G#protein|54,56 G#cell_type

In contrast to neutrophils , p38 was constitutively phosphorylated and agonist-dependent phosphorylation and activation was not detected in human monocytes .
3,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type

Superoxide release stimulated by FMLP was inhibited partially by PD98059 or SB203580 , a specific inhibitor of ERK or p38 pathway , and was almost completely inhibited by the combination of both inhibitors , whereas PMA -induced superoxide release was resistant to these two inhibitors in monocytes .
46,47 G#cell_type

PD98059 inhibited GM-CSF -dependent proliferation of MO7e cells .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

Present results indicate trancriptional roles of STAT5 and functional roles of ERK and/or p38 in normal human monocytes stimulated by physiological receptor-mediated agonists GM-CSF and FMLP .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein

Possible roles of ERK in proliferation of transformed cells were also suggested .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line

Aiolos transcription factor controls cell death in T cells by regulating Bcl-2 expression and its cellular localization .
0,1 G#protein|1,3 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein

We searched for proteins that interact with Ras in interleukin ( IL ) -2-stimulated or IL-2-deprived cells , and found that the transcription factor Aiolos interacts with Ras .
7,8 G#protein|9,17 G#cell_line|22,24 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The Ras -Aiolos interaction was confirmed in vitro and in vivo by co-immunoprecipitation .
1,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein

Indirect immunofluorescence shows that IL-2 controls the cellular distribution of Aiolos and induces its tyrosine phosphorylation , required for dissociation from Ras .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

We also identified functional Aiolos -binding sites in the Bcl-2 promoter , which are able to activate the luciferase reporter gene .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

Mutation of Aiolos -binding sites within the Bcl-2 promoter inhibits transactivation of the reporter gene luciferase , suggesting direct control of Bcl-2 expression by Aiolos .
2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Co-transfection experiments confirm that Aiolos induces Bcl-2 expression and prevents apoptosis in IL-2 -deprived cells .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_line

We propose a model for the regulation of Bcl-2 expression via Aiolos .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Binding of YY1 and Oct1 to a novel element that downregulates expression of IL-5 in human T cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : IL-5 controls development of eosinophilia and has been shown to be involved in the pathogenesis of allergic diseases .
2,3 G#protein

In both atopic and nonatopic asthma , elevated IL-5 has been detected in peripheral blood and the airways .
8,9 G#protein

IL-5 is produced mainly by activated T cells , and its expression is regulated at the transcriptional level .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

OBJECTIVE : This study focuses on the functional analysis of the human IL-5 ( hIL-5 ) promoter and characterization of cisÂ -regulatory elements and transcription factors involved in the suppression of IL-5 transcription in T cells .
11,17 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type

METHODS : Methods used in this study include DNase I footprint assays , electrophoretic mobility shift assays , and functional analysis by mammalian cell transfection involving deletion analysis and site-directed mutagenesis .
8,10 G#protein

RESULTS : We identified 5 protein binding regions ( BRs ) located within the proximal hIL-5 promoter .
5,8 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

Functional analysis indicates that the BRs are involved in control of hIL-5 promoter activity .
5,6 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA

Two of these regions , BR3 and BR4 located at positions -102 to -73 , have not previously been described as regulators of IL-5 expression in T cells .
5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type

We show that the BR3 sequence contains a novel negative regulatory element located at positions -90 to -79 of the hIL-5 promoter , which binds Oct1 , octamer-like , and YY1 nuclear factors .
4,5 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|30,33 G#protein

Substitution mutations , which abolished binding of these proteins to the BR3 sequence , significantly increased hIL-5 promoter activity in activated T cells .
11,12 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|20,23 G#cell_type

CONCLUSION : We suggest that Oct1 , YY1 , and octamer-like factors binding to the -90/-79 sequence within the proximal IL-5 promoter are involved in suppression of IL-5 transcription in T cells .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type

New immunosuppressive drug PNU156804 blocks IL-2 -dependent proliferation and NF-kappa B and AP-1 activation .
5,6 G#protein

We had previously shown that the drug undecylprodigiosin ( UP ) blocks human lymphocyte proliferation in vitro .
12,14 G#cell_type

We have now investigated the mechanism of action of a new analogue of UP , PNU156804 , which shows a more favorable activity profile than UP in mice .


We demonstrate here that the biological effect of PNU156804 in vitro is indistinguishable from UP : PNU156804 blocks human T cell proliferation in mid-late G1 , as determined by cell cycle analysis , expression of cyclins , and cyclin-dependent kinases and retinoblastoma phosphorylation .
18,21 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

In addition , we show that PNU156804 does not block significantly the induction of either IL-2 or IL-2R alpha- and gamma- chains but inhibits IL-2 -dependent T cell proliferation .
15,16 G#protein|17,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

We have investigated several molecular pathways that are known to be activated by IL-2 in T cells .
13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

We show that PNU156804 does not inhibit c-myc and bcl-2 mRNA induction .


On the other hand , PNU156804 efficiently inhibits the activation of the NF-kappa B and AP-1 transcription factors .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

PNU156804 inhibition of NF-kappa B activation is due to the inhibition of the degradation of I kappa B-alpha and I kappa B-beta .
3,5 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

PNU156804 action is restricted to some signaling pathways ; it does not affect NF-kappa B activation by PMA in T cells but blocks that induced by CD40 cross-linking in B lymphocytes .
13,15 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type

We conclude that the prodigiosin family of immunosuppressants is a new family of molecules that show a novel target specificity clearly distinct from that of other immunosuppressive drugs such as cyclosporin A , FK506 , and rapamycin .


Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 Tax protein induces the expression of STAT1 and STAT5 genes in T-cells .
0,8 G#protein|12,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#cell_type

Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) Tax transforms normal T-cells in the presence of interleukin ( IL ) -2 in vitro .
0,10 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|17,22 G#protein

STAT is a family of transcription factors that play a pivotal role in cytokine-induced functions of a various type of cells .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

We investigated the involvement of STATs in the transformation of T-cells by HTLV-1 .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type

HTLV-1 -transformed T-cell lines expressed higher amounts of STAT1 , STAT3 and STAT5 RNA and proteins than virus-negative T cells .
0,4 G#cell_line|8,14 G#RNA|17,20 G#cell_type

The expression of STAT1 and STAT5 in a human T-cell line was induced by Tax .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein

IL-2 induced the DNA binding activity of STAT3 and STAT5 of a HTLV-1 -transformed cell line and then stimulated its proliferation .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

In contrast , IL-2 did neither in a cell line lacking STAT3 and STAT5 .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

The expression of STAT1 , STAT3 and STAT5 mRNAs were also induced by a T-cell mitogen in normal human peripheral blood mononuclear cells .
3,9 G#RNA|14,16 G#protein|18,23 G#cell_type

Our results suggest that the induction of STAT1 and STAT5 by Tax enhances cytokine -induced functions of virus-infected T-cells , hence the induction may play a role in IL-2 -dependent transformation steps of T-cells by HTLV-1 .

Transcriptional control of the IL-5 gene by human helper T cells : IL-5 synthesis is regulated independently from IL-2 or IL-4 synthesis .
4,5 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

BACKGROUND : IL-5 is fundamentally involved in eosinophilic inflammation .
2,3 G#protein

Control of IL-5 production may be effective for the management of allergic diseases .
2,3 G#protein

OBJECTIVE : We aimed to find the transcriptional mechanisms that regulate the IL-5 gene to selectively control IL-5 synthesis .
12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

METHODS : Allergen-specific T-cell clones and T-cell hybridomas were established from the peripheral blood lymphocytes of patients with asthma , and the transcriptional regulation of the IL-5 gene was investigated with transient transfection and electrophoretic mobility shift analysis .
2,5 G#cell_line|6,8 G#cell_line|12,15 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA

RESULTS : A human IL-5 promoter/enhancer- luciferase gene construct , pIL-5(-511) Luc , was transcribed on activation of IL-5 -producing T-cell clones , but not IL-5 -nonproducing clones .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|4,9 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_line

pIL-5(-511) Luc was transcribed by T-cell hybridomas derived from fusion between IL-5 -producing T-cell clones and an IL-5 gene-nonexpressing T-cell line , but not by hybridomas derived from IL-5 -nonproducing T-cell clones .
0,2 G#DNA|5,7 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_line|25,26 G#cell_line|28,29 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_line

IL-5 synthesis was not only induced by T-cell receptor stimulation but also by IL-2 receptor stimulation .
0,1 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Binding of NF-AT , NF-kappaB , and AP-1 was induced by T-cell receptor ( TcR ) stimulation , although there was no significant upregulation of binding by IL-2 stimulation .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

CONCLUSION : IL-5 synthesis by human helper T cells is regulated at the transcriptional level .
2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_type

A unique transcriptional mechanism distinct from those regulating the IL-2 or IL-4 genes seems to control the IL-5 gene .
9,13 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

Selective regulation of IL-5 gene transcription may be useful for treating eosinophlic inflammation .
3,4 G#protein

Defining therapeutic targets by using adenovirus : blocking NF-kappaB inhibits both inflammatory and destructive mechanisms in rheumatoid synovium but spares anti-inflammatory mediators .
8,9 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

The role of the transcription factor NF-kappaB in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis has long been a subject of controversy .
4,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

We used an adenoviral technique of blocking NF-kappaB through overexpression of the inhibitory subunit IkappaBalpha , which has the advantage that it can be used in the diseased tissue itself , with &gt; 90 % of the synovial macrophages , fibroblasts , and T cells infected .
7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type|40,41 G#cell_type|43,45 G#cell_type

We found that the spontaneous production of tumor necrosis factor alpha and other pro-inflammatory cytokines is NF-kappaB -dependent in rheumatoid synovial tissue , in contrast to the main anti-inflammatory mediators , like IL -10 and -11 , and the IL-1 receptor antagonist .
7,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|32,36 G#protein|39,42 G#protein

Of even more interest , IkappaBalpha overexpression inhibited the production of matrix metalloproteinases 1 and 3 while not affecting their tissue inhibitor .
5,6 G#protein|11,16 G#protein

Blocking NF-kappaB in the rheumatoid joint thus has a very beneficial profile , reducing both the inflammatory response and the tissue destruction .
1,2 G#protein

The adenoviral technique described here has widespread applicability , allowing rapid testing of the effects of blocking a potential therapeutic target in either cultures of normal cells or in the diseased tissue itself .
25,27 G#cell_type

Resistance to tumor necrosis factor induced apoptosis in vitro correlates with high metastatic capacity of cells in vivo .
2,5 G#protein

TNF is one of the cytokines secreted by the cells of the immune system .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Our data demonstrate that those cell lines lacking capability to form metastatic tumors in vivo are susceptible to TNF induced apoptosis in vitro .
5,7 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein

However , cell lines with high metastatic potential are resistant to TNF in vitro .
2,4 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

Furthermore , the same cell lines were resistant to cytolytic action of other cytotoxic proteins secreted by LAK cells .
4,6 G#cell_line|13,15 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line

Our data showed that TNF resistance in vitro correlates with the increased level of transcription factor NF-kappaB .
4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

This finding may provide a tool to improve current protocols of immunotherapy and insights to how tumor cells are or are not killed by LAK cells .

Clonality analysis of granulocytes and T lymphocytes in healthy females by the PCR-based HUMARA method .
3,4 G#cell_type|5,7 G#cell_type|13,14 G#DNA

Clonality analysis utilizing X-chromosome inactivation has been used in the study of various diseases , including hematological malignancies .
3,4 G#DNA

The human androgen receptor gene ( HUMARA ) assay is the newest of such methods , and the majority of the female population can be assessed by this relatively simple procedure .
1,4 G#protein|1,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA

One problem in using these clonality analysis methods , however , is that there may be significant variation in Lyonization in blood cells in normal individuals .
21,23 G#cell_type

To determine the diversity in X-chromosome methylation patterns , which reflect Lyonization , assessed by the HUMARA assay in the supposedly normal population , we analyzed granulocytes and T cells from 97 relatively young ( 18- to 35-year-old ) healthy female volunteers .
5,6 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|26,27 G#cell_type|28,30 G#cell_line

We found that the methylation patterns in the two HUMARA alleles were distributed even more widely , both in granuloctyes and in T cells , than previously reported with other methods .
9,11 G#DNA|19,20 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_line

We also found that the deviation of methylation in granulocytes and T cells was well correlated .
9,10 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_line

Thus , we conclude that appropriate controls from the same individuals , such as T cells in the case of stem cell disorders , should always be employed to conclusively determine whether certain cells of hematopoietic origin are clonal .
14,16 G#cell_line

Functional B-cell response in intrahepatic lymphoid follicles in chronic hepatitis C .


Intrahepatic lymphoid follicle ( ILF ) formation is one of the most characteristic and commonly observed histological features in patients with chronic hepatitis C .


However , little is known regarding whether follicles in the liver belong to functional lymphoid tissues , where B cells are activated , differentiated , and proliferated , or if the lymphocytes are merely infiltrated after recruitment from the secondary lymphoid organs .


To ascertain this possibility , we examined the expression of markers for B-cell activation , differentiation , and proliferation in ILFs in patients with chronic hepatitis C using surgically resected specimens , and compared them with specimens of perihepatic lymph nodes by an immunohistochemical technique .


Germinal center ( GC ) formation in the ILFs was frequently found in HCV-positive cases .


The distribution of immunoglobulin M ( IgM ) - , IgD- , and IgG-positive cells and the expression patterns of Ki-67 , CD23 , or bcl-2 and bcl-6 gene products in the follicles with GC formation in the liver of patients with chronic hepatitis C were similar to those of lymph nodes , indicating that B cells are activated , proliferated , and differentiated in the ILFs with GC formation in patients with chronic hepatitis C .
55,57 G#cell_type

Oligoclonal expansion of B cells in the livers with ILFs was confirmed by an analysis of immunoglobulin heavy chain ( IgH ) gene rearrangement determined by polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) .
3,5 G#cell_type|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|16,23 G#DNA

These data strongly suggest that ILFs with GC formation , which are frequently found in patients with chronic hepatitis C , may functionally be the same as those found in lymph nodes with respect to B-cell expansion and maturation .


Downregulation of Wilms ' tumor gene ( WT1 ) is not a prerequisite for erythroid or megakaryocytic differentiation of the leukemic cell line K562 .
2,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|20,24 G#cell_line

The Wilms ' tumor gene ( WT1 ) encodes a transcription factor of the zinc finger type .
1,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

A high expression of WT1 has been detected in a range of acute leukemias , and WT1 is downregulated during induced differentiation of some leukemic cell lines .
4,5 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|24,27 G#cell_line

Overexpression of WT1 in some myeloid cell lines confers resistance to differentiation induction .
2,3 G#DNA|5,8 G#cell_line

These observations suggest that a high WT1 expression in hematopoietic cells is incompatible with differentiation .
6,7 G#DNA|9,11 G#cell_type

In this study , each of the four different isoforms of WT1 was constitutively overexpressed in the leukemic cell line K562 .
11,12 G#DNA|17,21 G#cell_line

K562 cells express endogenous WT1 , which is downregulated as a response to induced differentiation along the erythroid and megakaryocytic pathways .
0,2 G#cell_line|4,5 G#DNA

We now demonstrate that a forced exogenous expression of the four different isoforms of WT1 in K562 does not affect the differentiation response , as judged by accumulation of hemoglobin in response to hemin or the expression of megakaryocytic cell surface markers in response to 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate ( TPA ) .
14,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#cell_line|29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|38,42 G#protein

We conclude that downregulation of WT1 during induced differentiation of K562 cells is not a prerequisite for erythroid or megakaryocytic differentiation of these cells .
5,6 G#DNA|10,12 G#cell_line

Association of the interleukin-4 receptor alpha chain with p47phox , an activator of the phagocyte NADPH oxidase in B cells .
3,7 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Interleukin ( IL ) -4 plays an important role in IgE synthesis in B cells and in Th2 differentiation in T cells .
0,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_line

IL-4 conducts its biological activities through binding to the IL-4 receptor ( IL-4R ) on the surface of target cells .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

IL-4R are thought to be composed of the IL-4R alpha chain ( IL-4R alpha ) and either the IL-2R gamma chain or the IL-13R alpha chain .
0,1 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|23,26 G#protein

We have previously shown that the membrane-proximal portion in the cytoplasmic domain of the human IL-4R alpha ( hIL-4R alpha ) is critical for proliferation , generation of germline epsilon transcript , and activation of STAT6 , based on analyses of truncated hIL-4R alphas .
6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|41,44 G#protein

In this study , we found that p47phox , an activator of the phagocyte NADPH oxidase , binds to this portion by the two-hybrid system .
13,16 G#protein

Furthermore , we observed the association of p47phox with the hIL-4R alpha in B cells derived from a normal donor .
10,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

These results suggest that p47phox is involved in the signal transduction of IL-4 in B cells .
12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

However , activation of STAT6 , CD23 expression , and IgE synthesis induced by IL-4 were not affected in p47phox -deficient patients , which raises the possibility that p47phox may be important in other signaling activities as well in B cells .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|39,41 G#cell_type

Effects of diesel organic extracts on chemokine production by peripheral blood mononuclear cells .
6,7 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Polyaromatic hydrocarbons ( PAHs ) associated with diesel exhaust particles ( DEPs ) are found in the atmospheric urban pollution .


Such compounds have been shown to favor IgE production , bronchial hyperresponsiveness , and airway inflammation .
7,8 G#protein

Chemokines are a group of chemotactic cytokines involved in the recruitment of inflammatory cells .
5,7 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

OBJECTIVE : We investigated the effect of DEP- PAHs on the release and mRNA expression of IL-8 , MCP-1 , and RANTES by PBMCs obtained from healthy subjects .
13,14 G#RNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type

METHODS : Protein production in supernatants was assessed by ELISA , and mRNA expression was evaluated by semiquantitative RT- PCR .
12,13 G#RNA

RESULTS : Secretion of IL-8 and RANTES increased in a dose-dependent manner with increasing concentrations of DEP- PAHs ( range , 0.5 ng to 50 ng/mL ) .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

On the contrary , the release of MCP-1 was significantly inhibited , also in a dose-dependent manner .
7,8 G#protein

Messenger RNA production coding for IL-8 , RANTES , and MCP-1 showed parallel variations to the production of the correspondent proteins .
0,2 G#RNA|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Effects of DEP- PAHs became significant at 7 hours and up to 48 hours time culture for MCP-1 , and up to 24 hours time culture for IL-8 and RANTES .
17,18 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Moreover , supernatants from DEP-PAH-activated cells , compared with those of controls , exhibited a significantly enhanced chemotactic activity for neutrophils and eosinophils , which was significantly inhibited by pretreatment with anti- IL-8 and anti- RANTES neutralizing antibodies , respectively .
4,6 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

CONCLUSION : These findings suggest that the chemokine pathways are modulated by DEP- PAHs at the transcriptional level , reinforcing the idea that the development of inflammatory reactions might be affected by diesel exhaust emission .
7,8 G#protein

20-Epi analogues of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 are highly potent inducers of DRIP coactivator complex binding to the vitamin D3 receptor .
10,13 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D3 ( 1,25(OH)2D3 ) plays a major role in the stimulation of bone growth , mineralization , and intestinal calcium and phosphate absorption ; it also acts as a general inhibitor of cellular proliferation .


Several new , clinically relevant compounds dissociate antiproliferative and calcemic activities of 1,25(OH)2D3 , but the molecular basis for this has not been clearly elucidated .


Here , we tested whether the potency of one class of compounds , 20-epi analogues , to induce myeloid cell differentiation , is because of direct molecular effects on vitamin D receptor ( VDR ) .
29,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

We report that two 20-epi analogues , MC1627 and MC1288 , induced differentiation and transcription of p21 ( Waf1 , Cip1 ) , a key VDR target gene involved in growth inhibition , at a concentration 100-fold lower than that of 1,25(OH)2D3 .
16,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA

We compared this sensitivity to analogue effects on VDR interacting proteins : RXR , GRIP-1 , and DRIP205 , a subunit of the DRIP coactivator complex .
8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|23,26 G#protein

Compared with the interaction of VDR with RXR or GRIP-1 , the differentiation dose-response most closely correlated to the ligand-dependent recruitment of the DRIP coactivator complex to VDR and to the ability of the receptor to activate transcription in a cell-free system .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

These results provide compelling links between the efficiency of the 20-epi analogue in inducing VDR /DRIP interactions , transactivation in vitro , and its enhanced ability to induce cellular differentiation .
14,15 G#protein

SLP-76 and Vav function in separate , but overlapping pathways to augment interleukin-2 promoter activity .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

SLP-76 and Vav , two hematopoietic cell specific molecules , are critical for T cell development and activation .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#protein

Following T cell antigen receptor stimulation , SLP-76 and Vav both undergo tyrosine phosphorylation and associate with each other via the SH2 domain of Vav and phosphorylated tyrosines of SLP-76 .
1,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Furthermore , SLP-76 and Vav have a synergistic effect on interleukin ( IL ) -2 promoter activity in T cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,16 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_line

In this report , we show that two tyrosines , Tyr-113 and Tyr-128 , of SLP-76 are required for its binding to Vav , both in vitro and in intact cells .
15,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type

Surprisingly , we find also that the interaction between SLP-76 and Vav is not required for their cooperation in augmenting IL-2 promoter activity , as the two molecules appear to function in different signaling pathways upstream of IL-2 gene expression .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#DNA

Overexpression of SLP-76 in the Jurkat T cell line potentiates the activities of both nuclear factor of activated T cells and AP-1 transcription factors .
2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_line|14,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

In contrast , overexpression of Vav leads to enhanced nuclear factor of activated T cells activity without affecting AP-1 .
5,6 G#protein|9,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Additionally , overexpression of Vav , but not SLP-76 , augments CD28-induced IL-2 promoter activity .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

These findings suggest that the synergy between SLP-76 and Vav in regulating IL-2 gene expression reflects the cooperation between different signaling pathways .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

Rel/NF-kappaB can trigger the Notch signaling pathway by inducing the expression of Jagged1 , a ligand for Notch receptors .
0,1 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Jagged1 belongs to the DSL family of ligands for Notch receptors that control the proliferation and differentiation of various cell lineages .
0,1 G#protein|4,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

However , little is known about the transcription factors that regulate its expression .
7,9 G#protein

Here , we show that Jagged1 is a Rel/NF-kappaB -responsive gene .
5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA

Both c-Rel and RelA induced jagged1 gene expression , whereas a mutant defective for transactivation did not .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

Importantly , jagged1 transcripts were also upregulated by endogenous NF-kappaB activation and this effect was inhibited by a dominant mutant of IkappaBalpha , a physiological inhibitor of NF-kappaB .
2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Cell surface expression of Jagged1 in c-Rel -expressing cell monolayers led to a functional interaction with lymphocytes expressing the Notch1/TAN-1 receptor .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,10 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein

This correlated with the initiation of signaling downstream of Notch , as evidenced by increased levels of HES-1 transcripts in co-cultivated T cells and of CD23 transcripts in co-cultivated B cells .
17,19 G#RNA|20,23 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#RNA|29,31 G#cell_type

Consistent with its Rel/NF-kappaB -dependent induction , Jagged1 was found to be highly expressed in splenic B cells where c-Rel is expressed constitutively .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

These results demonstrate that c-Rel can trigger the Notch signaling pathway in neighboring cells by inducing jagged1 gene expression , and suggest a role for Jagged1 in B-cell activation , differentiation or function .
4,5 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

These findings also highlight the potential for an interplay between the Notch and NF-kappaB signaling pathways in the immune system .


Bacterial peptidoglycan induces CD14 -dependent activation of transcription factors CREB/ATF and AP-1 .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Peptidoglycan ( PGN ) , the major cell wall component of Gram-positive bacteria , induces secretion of cytokines in macrophages through CD14 , the pattern recognition receptor that binds lipopolysaccharide and other microbial products .
17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein

To begin to elucidate the mechanisms that regulate the transcription of cytokine genes , we wanted to determine which transcription factors are activated by PGN in mouse RAW264.7 and human THP-1 macrophage cells .
11,13 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_line|29,33 G#cell_line

Our results demonstrated that : ( i ) PGN induced phosphorylation of the transcription factors ATF-1 and CREB ; ( ii ) ATF-1 and CREB bound DNA as a dimer and induced transcriptional activation of a CRE reporter plasmid , which was inhibited by dominant negative CREB and ATF-1 ; ( iii ) PGN induced phosphorylation of c-Jun , protein synthesis of JunB and c-Fos , and transcriptional activation of the AP-1 reporter plasmid , which was inhibited by dominant negative c-Fos ; and ( iv ) PGN -induced activation of CREB /ATF and AP-1 was mediated through CD14 .
13,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#DNA|36,39 G#DNA|46,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|57,58 G#protein|62,63 G#protein|64,65 G#protein|71,72 G#protein|71,74 G#DNA|81,82 G#protein|91,92 G#protein|91,93 G#protein|94,95 G#protein|98,99 G#protein

This is the first study to demonstrate activation of CREB /ATF and AP-1 transcription factors by PGN or by any other component of Gram-positive bacteria .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

Glucocorticoid receptors are down-regulated in inflamed colonic mucosa but not in peripheral blood mononuclear cells from patients with inflammatory bowel disease [ see comments ]
0,2 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Growing evidence indicates that the immune system and the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal system are linked by several mechanisms , for example intracellular glucocorticoid receptors ( hGR ) .
22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Glucocorticoids are the standard treatment of acute attacks of inflammatory bowel disease ( IBD ) .


Binding of glucocorticoids to hGR down-regulates the transcription of inflammatory genes that can propagate IBD .
4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA

PATIENTS AND METHODS : IBD patients were either treated with 5-60 mg of prednisolone for more than 1 week or were without glucocorticoid treatment for more than 4 weeks .


hGR levels were determined from isolated cytosol of peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMCs ) or mucosal biopsies using a radioassay with [3H]-dexamethasone .
0,1 G#protein|8,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

Interleukin ( IL ) 6 levels were determined by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay ( ELISA ) .


RESULTS : The systemic ( PBMC ) hGR levels of corticosteroid-treated IBD patients were significantly lower than those of control subjects ( 59.6 +/- 57.1 dpm mg-1 cytosol protein vs.
7,8 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

227.0 +/- 90.8 dpm mg-1 cytosol protein , P = 0.007 ) and IBD patients not receiving glucocorticoid treatment ( 179.7 +/- 171.3 dpm mg-1 cytosol protein , P = 0.002 ) .
5,7 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Systemic hGR levels in untreated IBD patients did not differ significantly from those in control subjects .
1,2 G#protein

In patients with connective tissue diseases , systemic hGR levels were also found to be decreased in the absence of glucocorticoid treatment .
8,9 G#protein

Systemic hGR levels in patients with Crohn 's disease ( CD ) treated with steroids ( 66.6 +/- 61.0 dpm mg-1 cytosol protein ) were not different from those in patients with ulcerative colitis ( UC ) ( 56.1 +/- 51.6 dpm mg-1 cytosol protein ) .
1,2 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|43,45 G#protein

In contrast to these findings , mucosal hGR levels were significantly decreased in both steroid-treated ( 18.0 +/- 15.5 ) and not steroid-treated ( 37.8 +/- 30.5 ) patients compared with control subjects ( 125.6 +/- 97.1 ; P = 0.00009 and P = 0.0008 respectively ) .
7,8 G#protein

IL-6 levels in all IBD groups with and without steroids were significantly different from those in control subjects .


CONCLUSION : In IBD there is no difference in systemic hGR levels between not steroid-treated patients and control subjects , in spite of inflammatory activity ( IL-6 ) .
10,11 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Mucosal hGR levels were decreased independently of treatment , probably leading to a decreased protection against NF-kappaB action in the intestinal mucosa .
1,2 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

ICSAT overexpression is not sufficient to cause adult T-cell leukemia or multiple myeloma .
0,1 G#protein

ICSAT ( Interferon Consensus Sequence binding protein for Activated T cells ) is a lymphocyte-specific member of the interferon regulatory factor ( IRF ) family of transcription factors , originally identified through Southwestern screening of the ATL ( Adult T-cell leukemia ) -16T expression library .
0,1 G#protein|2,11 G#protein|18,25 G#protein|36,45 G#DNA

In this study , we created transgenic mice overexpressing ICSAT in lymphocytes .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type

Although spontaneous tumorigenesis was not observed , IL-2 production with Concanavalin A stimulation was significantly increased in transgenic mice overexpressing ICSAT .
7,8 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

ICSAT overexpression in lymphocytes seems insufficient for the leukemogenesis of ATL or multiple myeloma ( MM ) , however , it may regulate T cell activation and its overexpression may lead to leukemogenesis via controlling IL-2 production .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Altered memory T cell differentiation in patients with early rheumatoid arthritis .
1,4 G#cell_type

The chronic immune response in rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) might be driven by activated Th1 cells without sufficient Th2 cell differentiation to down-modulate inflammation .


To test whether disordered memory T cell differentiation contributes to the typical Th1-dominated chronic inflammation in RA we investigated differentiation of resting CD4+ memory T cells in patients with early ( 6 wk to 12 mo ) untreated RA and in age- and sex-matched healthy controls in vitro .
4,7 G#cell_type|21,26 G#cell_type

No difference in cytokine secretion profiles of freshly isolated memory T cells was detected between patients and controls .
3,4 G#protein|7,12 G#cell_type

A cell culture system was then employed that permitted the differentiation of Th effectors from resting memory T cells by short term priming .
1,4 G#cell_line|12,14 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_type

Marked differences were found in response to priming .


Th2 cells could be induced in all healthy controls by priming with anti-CD28 in the absence of TCR ligation .
0,2 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

By contrast , priming under those conditions resulted in Th2 differentiation in only 9 of 24 RA patients .


Exogenous IL-4 could overcome the apparent Th2 differentiation defect in seven patients but was without effect in the remaining eight patients .
1,2 G#protein

In all patients a marked decrease in IL-2 -producing cells and a significant increase in well-differentiated Th1 cells that produced IFN-gamma but not IL-2 were evident after priming with anti-CD3 and anti-CD28 .
7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

The data suggest that CD4+ memory T cells from patients with early untreated RA manifest an intrinsic abnormality in their ability to differentiate into specific cytokine-producing effector cells that might contribute to the characteristic Th1-dominated chronic ( auto ) immune inflammation in RA .
4,8 G#cell_type|25,28 G#cell_type

The intracellular parasite Theileria parva protects infected T cells from apoptosis .
6,9 G#cell_type

Parasites have evolved a plethora of strategies to ensure their survival .


The intracellular parasite Theileria parva secures its propagation and spreads through the infected animal by infecting and transforming T cells , inducing their continuous proliferation and rendering them metastatic .
18,20 G#cell_type

In previous work , we have shown that the parasite induces constitutive activation of the transcription factor NF-kappaB , by inducing the constitutive degradation of its cytoplasmic inhibitors .
15,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

The biological significance of NF-kappaB activation in T. parva-infected cells , however , has not yet been defined .
4,5 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type

Cells that have been transformed by viruses or oncogenes can persist only if they manage to avoid destruction by the apoptotic mechanisms that are activated on transformation and that contribute to maintain cellular homeostasis .
8,9 G#DNA

We now demonstrate that parasite-induced NF-kappaB activation plays a crucial role in the survival of T. parva-transformed T cells by conveying protection against an apoptotic signal that accompanies parasite-mediated transformation .
5,6 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_type

Consequently , inhibition of NF-kappaB nuclear translocation and the expression of dominant negative mutant forms of components of the NF-kappaB activation pathway , such as IkappaBalpha or p65 , prompt rapid apoptosis of T. parva-transformed T cells .
4,5 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|33,37 G#cell_type

Our findings offer important insights into parasite survival strategies and demonstrate that parasite-induced constitutive NF-kappaB activation is an essential step in maintaining the transformed phenotype of the infected cells .
14,15 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

A polymorphism that affects OCT-1 binding to the TNF promoter region is associated with severe malaria [ see comments ]
4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA

Genetic variation in cytokine promoter regions is postulated to influence susceptibility to infection , but the molecular mechanisms by which such polymorphisms might affect gene regulation are unknown .
3,6 G#DNA

Through systematic DNA footprinting of the TNF ( encoding tumour necrosis factor , TNF ) promoter region , we have identified a single nucleotide polymorphism ( SNP ) that causes the helix-turn-helix transcription factor OCT-1 to bind to a novel region of complex protein-DNA interactions and alters gene expression in human monocytes .
32,34 G#protein|50,52 G#cell_type

The OCT-1-binding genotype , found in approximately 5 % of Africans , is associated with fourfold increased susceptibility to cerebral malaria in large case-control studies of West African and East African populations , after correction for other known TNF polymorphisms and linked HLA alleles .
42,44 G#DNA

UV-induced CYP1A1 gene expression in human cells is mediated by tryptophan .
1,2 G#protein

Induction of cytochrome P-4501A1 ( CYP1A1 ) activity by UV has been observed earlier in animal studies via a mechanism that has not yet been resolved .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Our previous data have indicated that formylated indolocarbazoles which are formed by UV irradiation of tryptophan solutions are very potent Ah-receptor agonists .


To evaluate the effect of UV light on cytochrome P4501A1 gene expression , we studied the induction of CYP1A1 mRNA by UV irradiation of cultured human keratinocytes ( HaCaT cell line ) , primary human blood lymphocytes and mouse Hepa-1 cells .
8,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#RNA|24,27 G#cell_line|28,31 G#cell_line|33,37 G#cell_type|38,41 G#cell_line

The cells were exposed to UV light delivered by a bank of 6 Philips TL20/12RS sun lamps emitting primarily in the UVB range in the absence and presence of tryptophan .


A semiquantitative reverse transcriptase -linked polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) was used for analysis of gene expression in the treated cells .
2,4 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

The results show that the CYP1A1 mRNA level induced by UV in the presence of tryptophan was higher than that induced by UV alone in both HaCaT cells and lymphocytes after 3 h of incubation post- UV irradiation .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|26,28 G#cell_line|29,30 G#cell_type

To find out if the induction by UV light is caused by the formation of an Ah receptor ligand , Hepa-1 wild-type and Ah receptor deficient c12 cell lines were applied .
20,29 G#cell_line

Wild-type ( wt ) cells were inducible either by the tryptophan photoproduct 6-formylindolo [ 3 , 2-b ] carbazole ( FICZ ) or by UV -irradiation but very low or undetectable levels were observed in the c12 cells .
0,5 G#cell_line|36,38 G#cell_type

This shows that the induction of gene expression by FICZ and UV is Ah receptor dependent .
13,15 G#protein

Together , these results indicate that UV -induced CYP1A1 gene expression in mammalian cells is mediated by an Ah receptor ligand formed from tryptophan .
8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein

Thus , the photoproducts of tryptophan are suggested to be mediators of light via binding to the Ah receptor and as such also could have a role in light-regulated biological rhythms .
17,19 G#protein

Repression by Ikaros and Aiolos is mediated through histone deacetylase complexes .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,11 G#protein

Here we show that the lymphoid lineage-determining factors Ikaros and Aiolos can function as strong transcriptional repressors .
5,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

This function is mediated through two repression domains and is dependent upon the promoter context and cell type .
6,8 G#protein

Repression by Ikaros proteins correlates with hypo-acetylation of core histones at promoter sites and is relieved by histone deacetylase inhibitors .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein

Consistent with these findings , Ikaros and its repression domains can interact in vivo and in vitro with the mSin3 family of co-repressors which bind to histone deacetylases .
5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

Based on these and our recent findings of associations between Ikaros and Mi-2-HDAC , we propose that Ikaros family members modulate gene expression during lymphocyte development by recruiting distinct histone deacetylase complexes to specific promoters .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA

Protein kinase B ( c-Akt ) , phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase , and STAT5 are activated by erythropoietin ( EPO ) in HCD57 erythroid cells but are constitutively active in an EPO -independent , apoptosis -resistant subclone ( HCD57-SREI cells ) .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,23 G#cell_line|29,30 G#protein|29,35 G#cell_line|36,38 G#cell_line

We found that erythropoietin ( EPO ) and stem cell factor ( SCF ) activated protein kinase B ( PKB/Akt ) in EPO -dependent HCD57 erythroid cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,27 G#cell_line

To better understand signals controlling proliferation and viability , erythroid cells that resist apoptosis in the absence of EPO were subcloned and characterized ( HCD57-SREI cells ) .
18,19 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_line

Constitutive activations of PKB/Akt , STAT5a , and STAT5b were noted in these EPO -independent cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_line

PI3-kinase activity was an upstream activator of PKB/Akt because the PI3-kinase inhibitor LY294002 blocked both constitutive PKB/Akt and factor-dependent PKB/Akt activity .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The LY294002 study showed that proliferation and viability of both HCD57-SREI and HCD57 cells correlated with the activity of PKB/Akt ; however , PKB/Akt activity alone did not protect these cells from apoptosis .
10,11 G#cell_line|12,14 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Treatment of HCD57 cells with SCF also activated PKB/Akt , but did not protect from apoptosis .
2,4 G#cell_line|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

This result suggested that PKB/PI3-kinase activity is necessary but not sufficient to promote viability and/or proliferation .
4,5 G#protein

Constitutive STAT5 activity , activated through an unknown pathway not including JAK2 or EPOR , may act in concert with the constitutive PI3-kinase /PKB/Akt pathway to protect the EPO -independent HCD57-SREI cells from apoptosis and promote limited proliferation .
1,2 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line|28,32 G#cell_line

Disruption of alpha beta but not of gamma delta T cell development by overexpression of the helix-loop-helix protein Id3 in committed T cell progenitors .
16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_type

Enforced expression of Id3 , which has the capacity to inhibit many basic helix-loop-helix ( bHLH ) transcription factors , in human CD34(+) hematopoietic progenitor cells that have not undergone T cell receptor ( TCR ) gene rearrangements inhibits development of the transduced cells into TCR alpha beta and gamma delta cells in a fetal thymic organ culture ( FTOC ) .
3,4 G#protein|12,19 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_type|30,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|30,38 G#DNA|42,44 G#cell_type|45,52 G#cell_line|54,58 G#cell_line|59,60 G#cell_line

Here we document that overexpression of Id3 , in progenitors that have initiated TCR gene rearrangements ( pre-T cells ) , inhibits development into TCRalpha beta but not into TCRgamma delta T cells .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_type|24,26 G#cell_line|29,33 G#cell_line

Furthermore , Id3 impedes expression of recombination activating genes and downregulates pre-Talpha mRNA .
2,3 G#protein|11,13 G#RNA

These observations suggest possible mechanisms by which Id3 overexpression can differentially affect development of pre-T cells into TCR alpha beta and gamma delta cells .
7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|17,24 G#cell_line

We also observed that cell surface CD4(-)CD8(-)CD3(-) cells with rearranged TCR genes developed from Id3 -transduced but not from control-transduced pre-T cells in an FTOC .
4,8 G#cell_type|9,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_line|24,25 G#cell_line

These cells had properties of both natural killer ( NK ) and pre-T cells .
6,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#cell_type|12,14 G#cell_type

These findings suggest that bHLH factors are required to control T cell development after the T/NK developmental checkpoint .
4,6 G#protein

HIV-1 reactivation in resting peripheral blood mononuclear cells of infected adults upon in vitro CD4 cross-linking by ligands of the CDR2-loop in extracellular domain 1 .
3,8 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

HIV-1 infects resting peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMCs ) but remains inactive state until subsequent cell activation .
2,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#cell_type

We have demonstrated that the cross-linking of cell surface CD4 by gp120-anti-gp120 immune complexes or heat-inactivated HIV-1 ( iHIV-1 ) is sufficient to trigger activation signals leading to virus reactivation ( 9 ) .
9,10 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

In this study , we demonstrate that NF-kappaB nuclear translocation and stimulation of virus production by iHIV-1 were strictly linked to the concentrations of viral proteins used as exogenous stimuli .
7,8 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

Moreover , we further investigated the physiologic relevance of these observations .


When submitted to an in vitro CD4 cross-linking by iHIV-1 , PBMCs from HIV-1 -infected patients were found to produce virus .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type

This viral reactivation was associated with increased NF-kappaB nuclear translocation in patients ' PBMCs .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

Additionally , virus reactivation in resting PBMCs infected in vitro with HIV-1 was found to be specifically induced by ligands of the CDR2-loop in domain 1 ( D1 ) of CD4 ( virus envelope and anti- CD4 monoclonal antibodies ) .
6,7 G#cell_type|5,7 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|32,39 G#protein

In contrast , virus reactivation was not observed following CD4 oligomerization by antibodies that bind other epitopes in D1 , including the D1/CDR3-loop .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Finally , soluble CD4 ( sCD4 ) prevented virus reactivation by D1/CDR2-loop ligands .
3,4 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

Our results indicate that the signaling events initiated in PBMCs by oligomerization of CD4 at the D1/ CDR2-loop can trigger HIV-1 upregulation in infected individuals .
9,10 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Signaling through the lymphotoxin-beta receptor stimulates HIV-1 replication alone and in cooperation with soluble or membrane-bound TNF-alpha .
3,5 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

The level of ongoing HIV-1 replication within an individual is critical to HIV-1 pathogenesis .


Among host immune factors , the cytokine TNF-alpha has previously been shown to increase HIV-1 replication in various monocyte and T cell model systems .
6,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Here , we demonstrate that signaling through the TNF receptor family member , the lymphotoxin-beta ( LT-beta ) receptor ( LT-betaR ) , also regulates HIV-1 replication .
8,9 G#protein|14,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Furthermore , HIV-1 replication is cooperatively stimulated when the distinct LT-betaR and TNF receptor systems are simultaneously engaged by their specific ligands .
10,11 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

Moreover , in a physiological coculture cellular assay system , we show that membrane-bound TNF-alpha and LT-alpha1beta2 act virtually identically to their soluble forms in the regulation of HIV-1 replication .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Thus , cosignaling via the LT-beta and TNF-alpha receptors is probably involved in the modulation of HIV-1 replication and the subsequent determination of HIV-1 viral burden in monocytes .
5,9 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type

Intriguingly , surface expression of LT-alpha1beta2 is up- regulated on a T cell line acutely infected with HIV-1 , suggesting a positive feedback loop between HIV-1 infection , LT-alpha1beta2 expression , and HIV-1 replication .
5,6 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_line|28,29 G#protein

Given the critical role that LT-alpha1beta2 plays in lymphoid architecture , we speculate that LT-alpha1beta2 may be involved in HIV -associated abnormalities of the lymphoid organs .
5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Monoclonal anti-endothelial cell antibodies from a patient with Takayasu arteritis activate endothelial cells from large vessels .
0,4 G#protein

OBJECTIVE : To create monoclonal anti-endothelial cell antibodies ( mAECA ) from a patient with Takayasu arteritis to evaluate their ability to activate human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVEC ) , and to characterize the mechanism of EC activation .
4,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|23,28 G#cell_line|29,30 G#cell_line

METHODS : A panel of mAECA was generated from peripheral blood lymphocytes of a patient with Takayasu arteritis , using Epstein-Barr virus transformation .
5,6 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

Activity against macrovascular EC ( HUVEC ) and microvascular EC ( human bone marrow EC immortalized by SV40 ) antigens was detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay .
2,4 G#cell_line|5,6 G#cell_line|8,10 G#cell_line|11,18 G#cell_line

Inhibition studies were used to select the monoclonal antibodies ( mAECA ) which share the same EC epitope binding specificity as the total IgG-AECA from the Takayasu arteritis patient .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

The binding of the mAECA to human aortic EC was studied by immunohistochemistry .
4,5 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_type

The secretion levels of interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) and von Willebrand factor ( vWF ) were determined , to serve as markers for EC activation .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

The activated EC were examined for the adherence of a monocytic cell line ( U937 ) , as well as for expression of vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 , intercellular adhesion molecule 1 , and E-selectin .
1,3 G#cell_line|10,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|23,28 G#protein|29,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

In addition , nuclear extracts of the mAECA -treated EC were analyzed for the induction of translocation of nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) , using a specific NF-kappaB oligoprobe in an electrophoretic mobility shift assay .
7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_line|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

RESULTS : Six mAECA were selected , the mixture of which produced 100 % inhibition of binding of the original IgG ( from the patient with Takayasu arteritis ) to HUVEC .
3,4 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_line

All mAECA possessed high activity against macrovascular EC , but none had significant antimicrovascular EC activity .
1,2 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line

The mAECA , but not normal human IgG , had anti-human aortic EC activity .
1,2 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|5,8 G#protein

Four of the 6 mAECA activated EC , manifested by increased IL-6 and vWF secretion .
4,5 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

The 4 mAECA induced EC expression of adhesion molecules and increased adhesion of U937 monocytic cells to EC .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_line|13,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type

In addition , these mAECA stimulated the nuclear translocation of the NF-kappaB transcription factor .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

CONCLUSION : Our findings suggest that AECA may directly stimulate EC in Takayasu arteritis through elevation of adhesion molecule expression associated with NF-kappaB activation and adhesion of monocytes , and may therefore play a pathogenic role in the development of the vasculopathy in Takayasu arteritis .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type

Cutting edge : expression of the NF of activated T cells in eosinophils : regulation by IL-4 and IL-5 .
6,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

We report that NF-AT1 and NF-AT4 are expressed cytoplasmically in resting eosinophils , whereas NF-AT2 and NF-AT3 have not been seen .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Likewise , NF-AT1 mRNA and NF-AT4 mRNA have been detected in resting eosinophils , and their levels can be significantly up-regulated by the Th2-associated cytokines IL-4 and IL-5 .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#RNA|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|12,13 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type|23,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

There is no detectable NF-AT protein expression in the nuclei of resting eosinophils .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type

However NF-ATs appear in the nuclei of IL-4- , IL-5- , or ionomycin- stimulated eosinophils .
1,2 G#protein|7,15 G#cell_line

Only NF-AT1 and NF-AT4 , but not NF-AT2 and NF-AT3 , have translocated into the nuclei in IL-4- or IL-5- stimulated eosinophils .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|17,22 G#cell_line

These findings delineate a novel pathway in the cytokine network in which Th2 lymphocytes " control " eosinophils via the release of IL-4 and IL-5 , and activation of NF-AT in eosinophils .
12,14 G#cell_line|17,18 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#cell_type

The findings also suggest that a later feedback " talking " may exist between eosinophils and Th2 lymphocytes .
14,15 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_line

PPARalpha activators inhibit cytokine-induced vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 expression in human endothelial cells .
4,8 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Adhesion molecule expression on the endothelial cell ( EC ) surface is critical for leukocyte recruitment to atherosclerotic lesions .


Better understanding of transcriptional regulation of adhesion molecules in ECs may provide important insight into plaque formation .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha ( PPARalpha ) , a member of the nuclear receptor family , regulates gene expression in response to certain fatty acids and fibric acid derivatives .
0,1 G#cell_type|0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

The present study investigated PPARalpha expression in human ECs and their regulation of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 ( VCAM-1 ) .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|13,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

METHODS AND RESULTS : Immunohistochemistry revealed that human carotid artery ECs express PPARalpha .
10,11 G#cell_type|7,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein

Pretreatment of cultured human ECs with the PPARalpha activators fenofibrate or WY14643 inhibited TNF-alpha-induced VCAM-1 in a time- and concentration-dependent manner , an effect not seen with PPARgamma activators .
4,5 G#cell_type|2,5 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Both PPARalpha activators decreased cytokine-induced VCAM-1 mRNA expression without altering its mRNA half-life .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Transient transfection of deletional VCAM-1 promoter constructs and electrophoretic mobility shift assays suggest that fenofibrate inhibits VCAM-1 transcription in part by inhibiting NF-kappaB .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Finally , PPARalpha activators significantly reduced adhesion of U937 cells to cultured human ECs .
2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_line|11,14 G#cell_type|11,14 G#cell_type

CONCLUSIONS : Human ECs express PPARalpha , a potentially important regulator of atherogenesis through its transcriptional control of VCAM-1 gene expression .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Such findings also have implications regarding the clinical use of lipid-lowering agents , like fibric acids , which can activate PPARalpha .
20,21 G#protein

CBP/p300 integrates Raf / Rac -signaling pathways in the transcriptional induction of NF-ATc during T cell activation .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

NF-ATc , an inducibly expressed transcription factor , controls gene expression in T lymphocytes and cardiomyocytes .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type

We show here that the transcriptional co-activators CBP/p300 bind to and control the activity of the inducible N-terminal transactivation domain of NF-ATc , TAD-A .
5,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Similar to the N terminal transactivation domain of c-Jun , TAD-A is inducibly phosphorylated , but this phosphorylation is dispensable for the interaction with CBP/p300 .
3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Constitutive active versions of c-Raf and Rac synergistically enhance the CBP/p300 -mediated increase of TAD-A activity , indicating the important role CBP/p300 plays in the integration of T cell activation signals .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Since a mutation of CBP abolishing HAT activity is almost as active as wild-type CBP in T cells , functions of CBP/p300 other than histone acetylation appear to control the NF-AT -dependent transcription in T cells .
4,5 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,36 G#cell_type

Immune functions , clinical parameters and hormone receptor status in breast cancer patients .


We have carried out a detailed analysis of the cellular immune functions of breast cancer patients in comparison with healthy controls .


A possible correlation between immune and clinical parameters was analysed in 50 breast cancer patients .


Immune parameters , natural killer cell and T lymphocyte functions and the numbers of circulating T lymphocytes were analysed against the clinical parameters comprising the tumour burden , the stage of the disease and the expression of hormone receptors on the tumour .
3,6 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_type|37,39 G#protein

In order to analyse the immune function data effectively , low responders were identified with stringent cut-off values .


Considerably higher proportions of low responders were found among the patient population .


Elevated numbers of circulating T lymphocytes and CD3 -directed cytolysis correlated with the expression of oestrogen receptors independently of the clinical/histological parameters .
3,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Latent membrane protein 1 of Epstein-Barr virus interacts with JAK3 and activates STAT proteins .
0,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Latent membrane protein 1 ( LMP1 ) acts like a permanently activated receptor of the tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) -receptor superfamily and is absolutely required for B cell immortalization by Epstein-Barr virus .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,23 G#protein

Molecular and biochemical approaches demonstrated that LMP1 usurps cellular signaling pathways resulting in the induction of NF-kappaB and AP-1 via two C-terminal activating regions .
6,7 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

We demonstrate here that a third region encompassing a proline rich sequence within the 33 bp repetitive stretch of LMP1 's C-terminus is required for the activation of Janus kinase 3 ( JAK3 ) .
9,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

The interaction of LMP1 and JAK3 leads to the enhanced tyrosine auto/transphosphorylation of JAK3 within minutes after crosslinking of a conditional NGF-R : LMP1 chimera and is a prerequisite for the activation of STAT transcription factors .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|21,25 G#protein|33,36 G#protein

These results reveal a novel activating region in the LMP1 C-terminus and identify the JAK /STAT pathway as a target of this viral integral membrane protein in B cells .
9,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

Monocyte arrest and transmigration on inflamed endothelium in shear flow is inhibited by adenovirus-mediated gene transfer of IkappaB-alpha .
17,18 G#protein

Mobilization of nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) activates transcription of genes encoding endothelial adhesion molecules and chemokines that contribute to monocyte infiltration critical in atherogenesis .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

Inhibition of NF-kappaB has been achieved by pharmacological and genetic approaches ; however , monocyte interactions with activated endothelium in shear flow following gene transfer of the NF-kappaB inhibitor IkappaB-alpha have not been studied .
2,3 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

We found that overexpression of IkappaB-alpha in endothelial cells using a recombinant adenovirus prevented tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) -induced degradation of IkappaB-alpha and suppressed the upregulation of vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 ( VCAM-1 ) , intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) , and E-selectin mRNA and surface protein expression and the upregulation of transcripts for the chemokines monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 ( MCP-1 ) and growth-related activity-alpha ( GRO-alpha ) by TNF-alpha .
5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|37,40 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|45,47 G#RNA|58,59 G#protein|59,63 G#protein|64,65 G#protein|67,69 G#protein|70,71 G#protein|73,74 G#protein

This was associated with a reduction in endothelial MCP-1 secretion and GRO-alpha immobilization .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Adhesion assays under physiological shear flow conditions showed that firm arrest , spreading , and transmigration of monocytes on TNF-alpha -activated endothelium was markedly inhibited by IkappaB-alpha overexpression .
17,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Inhibition with monoclonal antibodies and peptide antagonists inferred that this was due to reduced expression of Ig integrin ligand as well as of chemokines specifically involved in these events .
2,4 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

In contrast , rolling of monocytes was increased by IkappaB-alpha transfer and was partly mediated by P-selectin ; however , it appeared to be unaffected by the inhibition of E-selectin induction .
5,6 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Thus , our data provide novel evidence that selective modulation of NF-kappaB by adenoviral transfer of IkappaB-alpha impairs the expression of multiple endothelial gene products required for subsequent monocyte arrest and emigration in shear flow and thus for monocyte infiltration in atherosclerotic plaques .
11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Recognition of NFATp/AP-1 composite elements within genes induced upon the activation of immune cells .
2,5 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_type

Composite elements are regulatory modules of promoters or enhancers that consist of binding sites of two different but synergizing transcription factors .
0,2 G#DNA|3,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein

A well-studied example is nuclear factors of activated T-cell ( NFAT ) sites which are composite elements of a NFATp/c and an activating protein 1 ( AP-1 ) binding site .
4,13 G#DNA|19,30 G#DNA

We have developed a computational approach to identify potential NFAT target genes which ( a ) comprises an improved method to scan for individual NFAT composite elements ; ( b ) considers positional effects relative to transcription start sites ; and ( c ) involves cluster analysis of potential NFAT composite elements .
9,12 G#DNA|24,27 G#DNA|36,39 G#DNA|49,52 G#DNA

All three steps progressively helpX?ed to discriminate T-cell-specific promoter sequences against other functional regions ( coding and intronic sequences ) of the same genes , against promoters of muscle-specific genes or against random sequences .
7,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|15,19 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|32,34 G#DNA

Using this approach , we identified potential NFAT composite elements in promoters of cytokine genes and their receptors as well as in promoters of genes for AP-1 family members , Ca2+-binding proteins and some other components of the regulatory network operating in activated T-cells and other immune cells .
7,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|13,15 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|42,44 G#cell_type|46,48 G#cell_type

The method developed can be adapted to characterize and identify other composite elements as well .
11,13 G#DNA

The program for recognition NFAT composite elements is available through the World Wide Web ( http://compel.bionet.nsc.ru/FunSite/CompelScan.html and http://transfac.gbf.de/dbsearch/funsitep/s_comp.html ) .
5,7 G#DNA|4,7 G#DNA

The oestrogen receptor codon 10 polymorphism detected in breast cancer is also present in non-malignant cells .
1,3 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type

The effect of oestrogens on oestrogen -receptive organs and cells is mediated via intracellular receptors ( ERalpha and ERbeta ) .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Oestrogen receptor gene polymorphisms in the region encoding the N-terminal portion of the protein are reportedly associated with pathological conditions including breast cancer , hypertension , spontaneous abortion and coronary heart disease .
0,2 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

A silent mutation in codon 10 of exon 1 , detected in ER-negative and ER-positive human breast cancer cell lines , in breast tumors and blood DNA from breast cancer patients , has been recognized as a polymorphic site .
4,6 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|12,20 G#cell_line|25,27 G#DNA|37,39 G#DNA

In this study we examined , by denaturing gradient-gel electrophoresis and DNA sequence analysis , the possible presence of a codon 10 polymorphic site in normal oestrogen target organs and cells such as the uterus ( myometrium and endometrium ) , in the placenta and peripheral blood mononuclear cells and in a benign uterus tumour ( leiomyoma ) .
11,13 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|20,24 G#DNA|45,49 G#cell_type

We have detected ER codon 10 polymorphism in these samples and have compared them to those observed in breast cancer samples .
3,6 G#DNA

All tissues and cells studied were homozygous for the wild-type gene , and were heterozygous as well as homozygous for the codon-10-variant type .
9,11 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

These results indicate that the presence of the codon-10-variant type is not a characteristic of breast cancer .
8,10 G#DNA

Out current findings suggest that further investigations are warranted to elucidate the possible linkage of ER codon 10 polymorphism to physiological and pathological conditions .
15,18 G#DNA

0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Transcription factors USF1 and USF2 up-regulate gene expression ( i.e. , HIV-1 long terminal repeats ) via interaction with an E box on their target promoters , which is also a binding site for c-Myc .
0,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|31,33 G#DNA|34,35 G#protein

The c-Myc oncoprotein is important in control of cellular proliferation and differentiation , while Yin-Yang 1 ( YY1 ) has been shown to control the expression of a number of cellular and viral genes .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|30,34 G#DNA

These two proteins physically interact with each other and mutually inhibit their respective biological functions .


In this study , we show that USF/ c-Myc up-regulates , while YY1 down-regulates the promoter activity of CXCR4 , a coreceptor for T cell-tropic HIV-1 entry .
8,9 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

We have identified an E box around -260 and a YY1 binding site around -300 relative to the transcription start site .
4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|18,21 G#DNA

Mutation of the E box abolished USF/c-Myc - mediated up-regulation of CXCR4 promoter activity , and mutation of the YY1 binding site was associated with unresponsiveness to YY1 -mediated inhibition .
3,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein

These data suggest that USF/c-Myc and YY1 may play an important role in the HIV-1 -replicative cycle , by modulating both the viral fusion/entry process and viral expression .
