A series of 5' deletion derivatives of the upstream regulatory region were used in transient transfection assays to identify promoter elements required for basal and inducible gene expression .
3,6 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA

A PMA responsive element was localized to a region between -319 and -219 bp upstream of the initiation codon and co-transfections with transcription factor expression plasmids for AP-2 and Sp1 resulted in augmented ASM promoter activity , which was abolished when the binding sites for these two factors were deleted .
1,4 G#DNA|10,15 G#DNA|22,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|42,44 G#DNA

Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays and supershift assays we demonstrate that this region is specifically bound by Sp1 and AP-2 .
17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

These factors are present in nuclear extracts prepared from both induced and uninduced THP-1 cells .
13,15 G#cell_line

However , the intensity of the complex formed appeared to increase when nuclear extracts from PMA -treated cells were used .
15,18 G#cell_line

From these studies , we conclude that a concerted action of the transcription factors AP-2 and Sp1 is essential for the upÂ -regulation of ASM expression during the process of macrophage differentiation .
12,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

LPS -Induced NF-kappaB activation and TNF-alpha release in human monocytes are protein tyrosine kinase dependent and protein kinase C independent .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|11,14 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) is an important mediator of septic shock .
2,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Endotoxin ( LPS ) signal transduction in human monocytes leads to activation of nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappaB ) and TNF-alpha release .
7,9 G#cell_type|13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Previous studies have implicated activation of both protein kinase C ( PKC ) and protein tyrosine kinases ( PTK ) in LPS -induced NF-kappaB activation and TNF-alpha production .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

We hypothesized that inhibition of either PKC or PTK would decrease LPS -induced NF-kappaB DNA binding and TNF-alpha release in human monocytes .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

MATERIALS AND METHODS : Human monocytes were stimulated with PMA ( 50 ng/ml ) alone or LPS ( 100 ng/ml ) with and without a nonspecific serine /threonine protein kinase inhibitor staurosporine ( Stauro ) , a specific pan- PKC inhibitor bisindolylmaleimide ( Bis ) , or an inhibitor of PTK genistein ( Gen ) .
4,6 G#cell_type|26,30 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|50,51 G#protein

TNF-alpha release in culture supernatants was measured by an ELISA .
0,1 G#protein

NF-kappaB DNA binding was evaluated by electrophoretic mobility shift assay .
0,1 G#protein

RESULTS : LPS increased NF-kappaB DNA binding and TNF-alpha release in human monocytes .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Nonspecific protein kinase inhibition inhibited NF-kappaB activation and TNF-alpha release , while specific PKC inhibition with Bis had no effect on LPS -induced NF-kappaB DNA binding or TNF-alpha release .
1,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

PTK inhibition with Gen attenuated both LPS -induced NF-kappaB DNA binding and TNF-alpha production in human monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

Direct activation of PKC with PMA induced both NF-kappaB activation and TNF-alpha production by human monocytes .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

CONCLUSIONS : These results suggest that LPS -induced NF-kappaB activation and TNF-alpha release in human monocytes are independent of PKC activity .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

Furthermore , our results provide evidence that PTK plays a role in LPS -induced NF-kappaB activation and TNF-alpha release in human monocytes and thus could be a potential therapeutic target in inflammatory states .
7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Amelioration of rat cerulein pancreatitis by guamerin-derived peptide , a novel elastase inhibitor .
11,12 G#protein

Increased activity of various proteases is observed in both human and experimental pancreatitis ; however , the information on the effects of specific protease inhibitors on the disease is limited .
4,5 G#protein

In this study we show that a novel elastase inhibitor , guamerin-derived synthetic peptide ( GDSP ) , improves the parameters of cerulein-induced acute pancreatitis in the rat .


The effects of GDSP on pancreatic weight , serum amylase and lipase , morphologic changes in the pancreas , neutrophil infiltration , and nuclear factor KB ( NF-KB ) activation were measured in rats infused with supramaximal dose of cerulein ( 5 ( g/kg/h ) for 6 h .
8,12 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The effects of GDSP were also measured on superoxide formation by activated human neutrophils .
11,14 G#cell_type

The effects of GDSP were compared with those of another elastase inhibitor , elastatinal .


GDSP significantly inhibited edema formation , neutrophil infiltration , acinar cell damage , and plasma lipase and amylase increases caused by cerulein .
14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

GDSP also completely inhibited superoxide formation in the human neutrophils stimulated by N-formyl-methionine-leucine-phenyl-alanine ( fMLP ) or 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate ( TPA ) .
8,10 G#cell_type

Elastatinal had some of the same effects as GDSP but was less potent and effective .


These results demonstrate a beneficial effect of GDSP , a novel specific elastase inhibitor , on the development of rat cerulein pancreatitis .


A novel lipopolysaccharide-induced transcription factor regulating tumor necrosis factor alpha gene expression : molecular cloning , sequencing , characterization , and chromosomal assignment .
2,5 G#protein|6,10 G#protein

Lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) is a potent stimulator of monocytes and macrophages , causing secretion of tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) and other inflammatory mediators .
9,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#cell_type|16,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Given the deleterious effects to the host of TNF-alpha , it has been postulated that TNF-alpha gene expression must be tightly regulated .
8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

The nature of the nuclear factor ( s ) that control TNF-alpha gene transcription in humans remains obscure , although NF-kappaB has been suggested .
4,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Our previous studies pertaining to macrophage response to LPS identified a novel DNA-binding domain located from -550 to -487 in the human TNF-alpha promoter that contains transcriptional activity , but lacks any known NF-kappaB -binding sites .
12,14 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|21,24 G#DNA|33,34 G#protein|34,36 G#DNA

We have used this DNA fragment to isolate and purify a 60-kDa protein binding to this fragment and obtained its amino-terminal sequence , which was used to design degenerate probes to screen a cDNA library from THP-1 cells .
11,13 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|36,38 G#cell_line

A novel cDNA clone ( 1.8 kb ) was isolated and fully sequenced .
2,4 G#DNA

Characterization of this cDNA clone revealed that its induction was dependent on LPS activation of THP-1 cells ; hence , the name LPS -induced TNF-alpha factor ( LITAF ) .
3,5 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Inhibition of LITAF mRNA expression in THP-1 cells resulted in a reduction of TNF-alpha transcripts .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#RNA|6,8 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein

In addition , high level of expression of LITAF mRNA was observed predominantly in the placenta , peripheral blood leukocytes , lymph nodes , and the spleen .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|17,20 G#cell_type

Finally , chromosomal localization using fluorescence in situ hybridization revealed that LITAF mapped to chromosome 16p12-16p13.3 .
11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA

Together , these findings suggest that LITAF plays an important role in the activation of the human TNF-alpha gene and proposes a new mechanism to control TNF-alpha gene expression .
6,7 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|16,19 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein

A human IFNGR1 small deletion hotspot associated with dominant susceptibility to mycobacterial infection [ see comments ]
1,6 G#DNA

The immunogenetic basis of severe infections caused by bacille Calmette-Guerin vaccine and environmental mycobacteria in humans remains largely unknown .


We describe 18 patients from several generations of 12 unrelated families who were heterozygous for 1 to 5 overlapping IFNGR1 frameshift small deletions and a wild-type IFNGR1 allele .
18,23 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA

There were 12 independent mutation events at a single mutation site , defining a small deletion hotspot .
8,11 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

Neighbouring sequence analysis favours a small deletion model of slipped mispairing events during replication .


The mutant alleles encode cell-surface IFNgamma receptors that lack the intra-cytoplasmic domain , which , through a combination of impaired recycling , abrogated signalling and normal binding to IFNgamma exert a dominant-negative effect .
4,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

We thus report a hotspot for human IFNGR1 small deletions that confer dominant susceptibility to infections caused by poorly virulent mycobacteria .
6,10 G#DNA

Characterization of expression of the gene for human pterin carbinolamine dehydratase/dimerization cofactor of HNF1 .
7,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Pterin carbinolamine dehydratase/dimerization cofactor of HNF1 ( PCD/DCoH ) is a dual-function protein .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

In the cytoplasm it acts as a dehydratase in the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin , the cofactor for aromatic amino acid hydroxylases .
7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

In the nucleus , it functions as a dimerization cofactor of HNF1 and increases the transcriptional activity of HNF1 .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

To deepen our understanding of this protein , we characterized its expression in human tissues and cells .


Human PCD/DCoH was present predominantly in liver and kidney , with significant amounts in testis and ovary , trace amounts in lung , and undetectable levels in whole brain , heart , and spleen .
1,2 G#protein

It was expressed in all of the cells that were examined .


Importantly , it was also present in the nucleus of HeLa cells , which lack HNF1 , and in the cytoplasm of fibroblasts that have little or no tetrahydrobiopterin .
10,12 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|22,23 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

The expression of human PCD/DCoH in the liver and nonhepatic cells was compared at both the mRNA and protein levels .
4,5 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Although the mRNA level in liver was only fourfold higher than that in keratinocytes and fibroblasts , the hepatic PCD/DCoH protein level was 20-fold higher than that in normal human epidermal keratinocytes and dermal fibroblasts .
13,14 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_type|34,35 G#cell_type|33,35 G#cell_type

Cloning of the 5' and 3' untranslated region ( UTR ) of human keratinocyte PCD/DCoH revealed that it has 53 bp more of GC-rich 5' untranslated sequence than the published liver PCD/DCoH .
3,8 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|23,27 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

In vitro transcription and translation analysis showed that the longer 5' UTR resulted in about a 35 % decrease in translation efficiency .
11,12 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA

These data show that human PCD/DCoH is not only present in cells where tetrahydrobiopterin is synthesized or HNF1 is present but is a widely distributed protein .
5,6 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Its differential expression in different tissues and cells is regulated not only at the transcriptional level but also at the translational level .


NF-kappaB regulates Fas/APO-1/CD95- and TCR- mediated apoptosis of T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

The maintenance of lymphocyte homeostasis by apoptosis is a critical regulatory mechanism in the normal immune system .


The transcription factor NF-kappaB has been shown to play a role in protecting cells against death mediated by TNF We show here that NF-kappaB also has a role in regulating Fas / APO-1 / CD95 -mediated death , a major pathway of peripheral T cell death .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|42,45 G#cell_type

Transfection of Jurkat cells with the NF-kappaB subunits p50 and p65 confers resistance against Fas-mediated apoptosis .
2,4 G#cell_line|6,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Reciprocally , inhibition of NF-kappaB activation by a soluble peptide inhibitor or a dominant form of the NF-kappaB inhibitor , IkappaB , makes the cells more susceptible to Fas-mediated apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Furthermore , inhibition of NF-kappaB activation by a soluble peptide inhibitor rendered a T cell hybridoma more susceptible to TCR-mediated apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_line

Correspondingly , transfection of p50 and p65 provided considerable protection from TCR-mediated apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

These observations were corroborated by studies on Fas -mediated death in primary T cells .
7,8 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

Concanavalin A -activated cycling T cell blasts from mice that are transgenic for the dominant IkappaB molecule have increased sensitivity to Fas-mediated apoptosis , associated with a down-regulation of NF-kappaB complexes in the nucleus .
3,7 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

In addition , blocking TNF , itself a positive regulator of NF-kappaB , with neutralizing antibodies renders the cells more susceptible to anti-Fas-mediated apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

In summary , our results provide compelling evidence that NF-kappaB protects against Fas -mediated death and is likely to be an important regulator of T cell homeostasis and tolerance .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

T helper differentiation proceeds through Stat1-dependent , Stat4-dependent and Stat4-independent phases .


Much of our focus in understanding Th1/Th2 development has been on the signals delivered by IL-12 and IL-4 as final determinants of terminal T cell differentiation .
15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Because extinction of IL-12 signaling in early Th2 development could potentially be important in imprinting a more permanent Th2 phenotype on a population of T cells , we have also examined various parameters regulating the IL-12 signaling pathway .
3,4 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein

Whereas IL-4 appears to repress functional IL-12 signaling through inhibition of IL-12R beta 2 expression , IFN-gamma in the mouse , and IFN-alpha in the human appear to induce IL-12R beta 2 expression and promote IL-12 responsiveness .
1,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

We propose that Th1 development can be considered in two stages , capacitance and development .


Capacitance would simply involve expression of IL-12R beta 1 and beta 2 subunits , regulated by TCR , IL-4 and IFNs .
6,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

The second stage , development , we propose is the true IL-12 induced developmental stage , involving expression of Stat4 inducible proteins .
11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

In the human , this may also occur via IFN-alpha , which is able to activate Stat4 .
9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

It is perhaps possible that all of Stat4 actions on Th1 development may be exert directly by Stat4 at the IFN-gamma gene , however we suggest that , more likely , Stat4 may act to induce Th1 development through the induction of other non-cytokine genes , whose stable expression maintains the transcriptional state of a Th1 cell .
7,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein|43,45 G#DNA|55,57 G#cell_type

Lineage-specific activation of STAT3 by interferon-gamma in human neutrophils .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Binding of interferon-gamma ( IFN-gamma ) to its heterodimeric receptor induces activation of the tyrosine kinases JAK1 and JAK2 followed by tyrosine phosphorylation of STAT1alpha .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Selective activation of STAT1alpha at the IFN-gamma receptor is achieved by specific interaction between a cytosolic tyrosine motif including Y440 in the IFN-gamma receptor alpha-chain and the SH2 domain of STAT1alpha .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

We demonstrate that , in addition to STAT1alpha , STAT3 is also activated by IFN-gamma in human neutrophils .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

The activation of STAT3 was not found in human eosinophils , monocytes , and HL-60 cells , although the STAT3 protein was expressed in these cells .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

The cell type-specific activation of STAT3 by IFN-gamma was also observed in neutrophils that are differentiated in vitro from human CD34+ hematopoietic stem cells .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|19,24 G#cell_type

These results indicate that a single cytokine receptor can activate different STAT family members in a cell-specific manner , which might result in cell-specific gene transcription .
6,8 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

Alternative polyadenylation events contribute to the induction of NF-ATc in effector T cells .
8,9 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

The transcription factor NF-ATc is synthesized in three prominent isoforms .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

These differ in the length of their C terminal peptides and mode of synthesis .


Due to a switch from the use of a 3' polyA site to a more proximal polyA site , NF-ATc expression switches from the synthesis of the two longer isoforms in naive T cells to that of short isoform A in T effector cells .
9,12 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|31,34 G#cell_type|38,40 G#protein|41,44 G#cell_type

The relative low binding affinity of cleavage stimulation factor CstF-64 to the proximal polyA site seems to contribute to its neglect in naive T cells .
6,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|22,25 G#cell_type

These alternative polyadenylation events ensure the rapid accumulation of high concentrations of NF-ATc necessary to exceed critical threshold levels of NF-ATc for gene induction in effector T cells .
12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_type

Estrogen and progesterone induction of survival of monoblastoid cells undergoing TNF-alpha -induced apoptosis .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein

Induction of apoptosis of mononucleated cells is a physiological process for regulating the intensity of the immune response .
4,6 G#cell_type

The female steroid hormones estrogen ( E2 ) and progesterone ( Prog ) are known to modulate the reactivity of the immune system ; recently it has been demonstrated that they can regulate induction of apoptosis of endothelial cells and osteoblasts .
37,39 G#cell_type|40,41 G#cell_type

TNF-alpha -mediated induction of apoptosis has been well characterized in myeloid cells .
0,1 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

We investigated whether E2 and Prog could interfere with TNF-alpha -induced apoptosis of the monoblastoid U937 cell line .
9,10 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line

Treatment with E2 or Prog increased survival and prevented apoptosis induced by TNF-alpha in both undifferentiated and macrophage-like PMA-differentiated U937 cells , as assessed by trypan blue exclusion cell counting , thymidine incorporation , AnnexinV labeling , followed by flow cytometry and DNA fragmentation studies .
12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line

This effect can be associated with the activation of specific hormone receptors , since we observed the expression of the estrogen receptor alpha ( ER-alpha ) , ER-beta , and progesterone receptor ( PR ) mRNAs ; the ER-alpha protein expression was confirmed by immunocytochemical analysis .
20,36 G#RNA|38,39 G#protein

In addition , hormone-mediated survival against apoptosis was concentration dependent , reaching the half-maximal effect at 10 nM and blocked by the ER antagonist ICI 182 , 780 in undifferentiated cells , further supporting a receptor-mediated mechanism of cell survival .
29,31 G#cell_type

Other steroid receptor drugs such as Raloxifene , RU486 , or the ICI 182 , 780 in PMA-differentiated cells displayed agonist activity by preventing TNF-alpha -induced apoptosis as efficiently as the hormones alone , providing further evidence to the notion that steroid receptor drugs may manifest agonist or antagonist activities depending on the cellular context in which they are studied .
17,19 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein

Treatment with E2 was also associated with a time-dependent decrease in the mRNA level of the proapoptotic Nip-2 protein , supporting the hypothesis that hormone responsiveness of U937 cells is mediated by target gene transcription .
16,19 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_line

Together , these results demonstrate that ER and PR can be activated by endogenous or exogenous ligands to induce a genetic response that impairs TNF-alpha -induced apoptosis in U937 cells .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_line

The data presented here suggest that the female steroid receptors play a role in regulation of the immune response by preventing apoptosis of monoblastoid cells ; this effect might have important consequences in the clinical use of steroid receptor drugs .
7,10 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

-- Vegeto , E. , Pollio , G. , Pellicciari , C. , Maggi , A .


Estrogen and progesterone induction of survival of monoblastoid cells undergoing TNF-alpha -inuced apoptosis .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein

Dicarba-closo-dodecaboranes as a pharmacophore .


Retinoidal antagonists and potential agonists .


Synthesis and biological evaluation of the first dicarba-closo-dodecaborane ( carborane ) derivatives of retinoids are described .


Their retinoidal activity were examined in terms of the differentiation-inducing ability toward human promyelocytic leukemia HL-60 cells .
12,17 G#cell_line

High retinoidal activity ( agonist or antagonist for retinoic acid receptor ( RAR ) requires a carboxylic acid moiety and an appropriate hydrophobic group located at a suitable position on the molecule .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The 4-carboranyl-substituted compounds ( 7 ,Â  11 ) showed antagonistic activity but no agonistic activity even in the presence of the potent synergist HX630 .


On the other hand , the 3-carboranyl-substituted compounds ( 8 ,Â  12 ) showed potential agonistic activity , but no antagonistic activity .


The results indicates that carboranes are applicable as the hydrophobic moiety of biologically active molecules .


Inhibition of T cell signaling by mitogen-activated protein kinase -targeted hematopoietic tyrosine phosphatase ( HePTP ) .
6,9 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|6,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Activation of T lymphocytes to produce cytokines is regulated by the counterbalance of protein- tyrosine kinases and protein- tyrosine phosphatases , many of which have a high degree of substrate specificity because of physical association with their targets .
2,4 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

Overexpression of hematopoietic protein- tyrosine phosphatase ( HePTP ) results in suppression of T lymphocyte activation as measured by T cell antigen receptor -induced activation of transcription factors binding to the 5' promoter of the interleukin-2 gene .
2,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|31,33 G#DNA|35,37 G#DNA

Efforts to pinpoint the exact site of action and specificity of HePTP in the signaling cascade revealed that HePTP acts directly on the mitogen-activated protein ( MAP ) kinases Erk 1 and 2 and consequently reduces the magnitude and duration of their catalytic activation in intact T cells .
11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,29 G#protein|29,33 G#protein|45,48 G#cell_type

In contrast , HePTP had no effects on N-terminal c-Jun kinase or on events upstream of the MAP kinases .
3,4 G#protein|8,11 G#protein

The specificity of HePTP correlated with its physical association through its noncatalytic N terminus with Erk and another MAP kinase , p38 , but not Jnk or other proteins .
3,4 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

We propose that HePTP plays a negative role in antigen receptor signaling by specifically regulating MAP kinases in the cytosol and at early time points of T cell activation before the activation-induced expression of nuclear dual-specific MAP kinase phosphatases .
3,4 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|34,39 G#protein

p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase mediates signal integration of TCR /CD28 costimulation in primary murine T cells .
0,1 G#protein|0,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type

Optimal T cell activation requires two signals , one generated by TCR and another by the CD28 costimulatory receptor .
11,12 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

In this study , we investigated the regulation of costimulation-induced mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) activation in primary mouse T cells .
10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_type

In contrast to that reported for human Jurkat T cells , we found that p38 MAPK , but not Jun NH2-terminal kinase ( JNK ) , is weakly activated upon stimulation with either anti-CD3 or anti-CD28 in murine thymocytes and splenic T cells .
6,10 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type|40,43 G#cell_type

However , p38 MAPK is activated strongly and synergistically by either CD3/CD28 coligation or PMA/Ca2+ ionophore stimulation , which mimics TCR - CD3/CD28 -mediated signaling .
2,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Activation of p38 MAPK correlates closely with the stimulation of T cell proliferation .
2,4 G#protein

In contrast , PMA-induced JNK activation is inhibited by Ca2+ ionophore .
4,5 G#protein

T cell proliferation and production of IL-2 , IL-4 , and IFN-gamma induced by both CD3 and CD3 /CD28 ligation and the nuclear expression of the c-Jun and ATF-2 proteins are each blocked by the p38 MAPK inhibitor SB203580 .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|26,30 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

Our findings demonstrate that p38 MAPK 1 ) plays an important role in signal integration during costimulation of primary mouse T cells , 2 ) may be involved in the induction of c-Jun activation and augmentation of AP-1 transcriptional activity , and 3 ) regulates whether T cells enter a state of functional unresponsiveness .
4,6 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|46,48 G#cell_type

Erythroid gene expression is differentially regulated by erythropoietin , haemin and delta-aminolaevulinic acid in UT-7 cells .
7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line

Erythropoietin ( Epo ) is essential for the later stages of erythropoiesis , acting to promote cell survival and proliferation , but its role in differentiation remains to be defined .


The UT-7 cell line exhibits both erythroid and megakaryocytic characteristics and can be induced to differentiate along the erythroid pathway by Epo or the megakaryocytic pathway by phorbol myristic acetate .
1,4 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

We have compared the effects of Epo and the chemical inducers , delta-aminolaevulinic acid ( delta-ALA ) and haemin on the differentiation capacity of UT-7 cells .
6,7 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_line

Epo alone promoted relatively early events in erythroid maturation , without significant changes in haemoglobin production or morphology .
0,1 G#protein

GATA-2 and c-myb were down-regulated by Epo , and GATA-2 was further down-modulated by the inducers .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Conversely , SCL expression was up-regulated by Epo and further increased by haemin and delta-ALA .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Epo caused an increase in the proportion of cells expressing cell surface glycophorin A ( GPA ) and up-regulated beta- and gamma- globin by several fold .
0,1 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

Both haemin and delta-ALA caused a de novo increase in alpha-globin expression as well as enhancing Epo -induced beta-globin expression , leading to a marked increase in haemoglobin production .
10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

These results suggest that haemoglobin production in UT-7 cells is limited by a deficiency of erythroid-specific aminolaevulinic acid synthase ( ALAS-E ) activity or globin synthesis as a consequence of their immaturity as a multipotential cell line .
7,9 G#cell_line|15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|15,23 G#protein|34,37 G#cell_line

Essential role of alveolar macrophages in intrapulmonary activation of NF-kappaB .
3,5 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein

Acute inflammatory injury in rat lung induced by deposition of immunoglobulin G immune complexes requires expression of cytokines and chemokines as well as activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappaB .
10,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|28,34 G#protein

There is little direct evidence regarding the role of alveolar macrophages in these activation events .
9,11 G#cell_type

In the present studies , rat lungs were depleted of alveolar macrophages by airway instillation of liposome-encapsulated dichloromethylene diphosphonate .
10,12 G#cell_type

These procedures , which greatly reduced the number of retrievable alveolar macrophages , suppressed activation of lung NF-kappaB in the inflammatory model .
10,12 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

In addition , bronchoalveolar lavage levels of tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) and the CXC chemokine , macrophage inflammatory protein-2 , were substantially reduced .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

In parallel , upregulation of the lung vascular adhesion molecule , intercellular adhesion molecule-1 , was greatly reduced by intrapulmonary instillation of phosphonate-containing liposomes .
6,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

Neutrophil accumulation and development of lung injury were also substantially diminished .


Lung instillation of TNF-alpha in alveolar macrophage-depleted rats restored the NF-kappaB activation response in whole lung .
3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

These data suggest that , in this inflammatory model , initial activation of NF-kappaB occurs in alveolar macrophages and the ensuing production of TNF-alpha may propagate NF-kappaB activation to other cell types in the lung .
13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Interferon-beta mediates stromal cell rescue of T cells from apoptosis .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

The resolution of immune responses is characterized by extensive apoptosis of activated T cells .
12,14 G#cell_type

However , to generate and maintain immunological memory , some antigen-specific T cells must survive and revert to a resting G0/G1 state .
10,13 G#cell_type

Cytokines that bind to the common gamma chain of the IL-2 receptor promote the survival of T cell blasts , but also induce proliferation .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

In contrast , soluble factors secreted by stromal cells induce Tcell survival in a resting G0/G1 state .
3,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

We now report that interferon-beta is the principal mediator of stromal cell-mediated Tcell rescue from apoptosis .


Interferon -alpha and -beta promote the reversion of blast Tcells to a resting G0/G1 configuration with all the characteristic features of stromal cell rescue ; such as high Bcl-XL expression and low Bcl-2 .
0,4 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Type I interferons and stromal cells stimulate apparently identical signaling pathways , leading to STAT-1 activation .
0,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

We also show that this mechanism may play a fundamental role in the persistence of T cells at sites of chronic inflammation ; suggesting that chronic inflammation is an aberrant consequence of immunological memory .
15,17 G#cell_type

Reduction of tumour necrosis factor alpha expression and signalling in peripheral blood mononuclear cells from patients with thalassaemia or sickle cell anaemia upon treatment with desferrioxamine .
2,6 G#protein|10,14 G#cell_type

Recent evidence indicates that the rate of progression of the HIV-1 disease is significantly reduced in thalassaemia major patients upon treatment with high doses of desferrioxamine ( DFX ) .


The authors have previously demonstrated that in vitro exposure of mononuclear cells to DFX decreases the bioavailability of tumour necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) which has a stimulatory effect on HIV-1 replication .
10,12 G#cell_type|18,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

In this study , therefore , TNF-alpha bioavailability from mononuclear cells isolated from 10 patients with thalassaemia or sickle cell anaemia given DFX as compared to 10 untreated subjects has been evaluated .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Evidence is presented showing that DFX treatment reduces TNF-alpha bioavailability ( P &lt; 0.05 ) by inhibiting its steady state ( P &lt; 0.05 ) and by enhancing its inactivation through binding to soluble TNF-alpha receptor type II ( P &lt; 0.05 ) .
8,9 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

We also show that DFX treatment limits the in vivo activation of NF-kappaB , a transcription factor involved in both TNF-alpha gene transcription and TNF-alpha signalling ( P &lt; 0.005 ) .
12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

We conclude that TNF-alpha bioavailability and signalling are impaired in patients upon DFX treatment .
3,4 G#protein

This mechanism may contribute to delayed progression of the HIV-1 infection in vivo .


Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Involvement of NF-kappaB p50/p65 heterodimer in activation of the human pro-interleukin-1beta gene at two subregions of the upstream enhancer element .
2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA

A region between -3134 and -2729 bp upstream from the transcription site of the human pro-interleukin 1beta ( proIL-1beta ) gene was identified as an LPS-responsive enhancer element .
10,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|14,21 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA

In this study , the influence of the sequences located between -3134 and -2987 on the transcriptional activity of the proIL-1beta gene in LPS-stimulated Raw 264.7 cells was examined in detail .
10,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|23,27 G#cell_line

The results obtained by transient transfection of fosÂ  -CAT constructs that contained serial 5'-deletion mutations showed that the region between -3134 and -3059 appears to be required for the induction of transcription by LPS .
8,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA

Gel shift assay studies with synthetic oligonucleotides corresponding to partial sequences of the latter region and nuclear extracts from stimulated cells revealed specific protein binding sites between -3110 and -3090 and between -3079 and -3059 .
5,7 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA

These specific bindings were time and LPS dose dependent .


The results of supershift analysis using specific antibodies against transcription factors suggested that both binding complexes contained the NF-kappaB components p50 and p65 , and did not contain other NF-kappaB proteins ( p52 , c-Rel , Rel B ) , AP-1 proteins ( c-Fos , C-Jun ) , CREB or C/EBPbeta ( NF-IL6 ) .
9,11 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|40,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|52,53 G#protein

Mutation of either of the putative NF-kappaB-binding sites in the enhancer element decreased the LPS -stimulated transcriptional activity .
6,8 G#DNA

These data indicated that two NF-kappaB-binding sites , which are located between -3134 and -3059 , are critical for the activation of proIL-1beta gene transcription .
5,7 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


N-acetyl-L-cysteine inhibits primary human T cell responses at the dendritic cell level : association with NF-kappaB inhibition .
15,16 G#protein

N-acetyl-L-cysteine ( NAC ) is an antioxidant molecule endowed with immunomodulatory properties .


To investigate the effect of NAC on the induction phase of T cell responses , we analyzed its action on human dendritic cells ( DC ) derived from adherent PBMC cultured with IL-4 and granulocyte-macrophage CSF .
32,33 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

We first found that NAC inhibited the constitutive as well as the LPS -induced activity of the transcription factor NF-kappaB .
17,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

In parallel , NAC was shown to down-regulate the production of cytokines by DC as well as their surface expression of HLA-DR , CD86 ( B7-2 ) , and CD40 molecules both at the basal state and upon LPS activation .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

NAC also inhibited DC responses induced by CD40 engagement .
7,8 G#protein

The inhibitory effects of NAC were not due to nonspecific toxicity as neither the viability of DC nor their mannose receptor-mediated endocytosis were modified by NAC .
16,17 G#cell_type

Finally , we found that the addition of NAC to MLR between naive T cells and allogeneic DC resulted in a profound inhibition of alloreactive responses , which could be attributed to a defect of DC as APC-independent T cell responses were not inhibited by NAC .
12,15 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type

Altogether , our results suggest that NAC might impair the generation of primary immune responses in humans through its inhibitory action on DC .
22,23 G#cell_type

Thrombin -induced p65 homodimer binding to downstream NF-kappa B site of the promoter mediates endothelial ICAM-1 expression and neutrophil adhesion .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|0,4 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type

We investigated the mechanisms by which proinflammatory mediator , thrombin , released during intravascular coagulation and tissue injury , induces ICAM-1 ( CD54 ) expression in endothelial cells .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type

Stimulation of HUVEC with thrombin resulted in dose- and time-dependent increases in ICAM-1 mRNA and cell surface expression and in ICAM-1 -dependent endothelial adhesivity toward polymorphonuclear leukocytes .
2,3 G#cell_line|4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#RNA|20,21 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type

Transient transfection of endothelial cells with ICAM-1 promoter luciferase reporter gene ( ICAM-1LUC ) constructs indicated that deletion of upstream NF-kappa B site ( -533 bases from translation start site ) had no effect on thrombin responsiveness , whereas mutation/deletion of downstream NF-kappa B site ( -223 bases from the translation start site ) prevented the activation of ICAM-1 promoter , indicating that the downstream NF-kappa B site is critical for thrombin inducibility .
3,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|6,15 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein|20,23 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA|27,30 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|42,44 G#protein|42,45 G#DNA|46,48 G#DNA|50,53 G#DNA|58,59 G#protein|58,60 G#DNA|65,67 G#protein|65,68 G#DNA|71,72 G#protein

NF-kappa B -directed luciferase activity increased approximately 3-fold when cells transfected with the plasmid pNF-kappa BLUC containing five copies of consensus NF-kappa B site linked to a minimal adenovirus E1B promoter-luciferase gene were exposed to thrombin , indicating that activation of NF-kappa B was essential for thrombin response .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|21,23 G#protein|21,24 G#DNA|20,24 G#DNA|28,32 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|41,43 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

Gel supershift assays demonstrated that thrombin induced binding of NF-kappa Bp65 ( Rel A ) to downstream NF-kappa B site of the ICAM-1 promoter .
5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA

Thrombin receptor activation peptide , a 14-amino-acid peptide representing the new NH2 terminus of proteolytically activated receptor-1 , mimicked thrombin 's action in inducing ICAM-1 expression .
0,1 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

These data indicate that thrombin activates endothelial ICAM-1 expression and polymorphonuclear leukocyte adhesion by NF-kappa Bp65 binding to the downstream NF-kappa B site of ICAM-1 promoter after proteolytically activated receptor-1 activation .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|20,23 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA

Differential inhibition of Smad6 and Smad7 on bone morphogenetic protein- and activin- mediated growth arrest and apoptosis in B cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Smad6 and Smad7 prevent ligand-induced activation of signal-transducing Smad proteins in the transforming growth factor-beta family .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|12,16 G#protein

Here we demonstrate that both Smad6 and Smad7 are human bone morphogenetic protein-2 ( hBMP-2 ) -inducible antagonists of hBMP-2 -induced growth arrest and apoptosis in mouse B cell hybridoma HS-72 cells .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|26,30 G#cell_line|30,32 G#cell_line

Moreover , we confirmed that the ectopic expressions of Smad6 and Smad7 inhibited the hBMP-2 -induced Smad1/Smad5 phosphorylation .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

We previously reported that Smad7 is an activin A-inducible antagonist of activin A-induced growth arrest and apoptosis in HS-72 cells .
4,5 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line

Interestingly , although mRNA expression of Smad6 was induced by activin A in HS-72 cells , Smad6 showed no antagonistic effect on activin A -induced growth arrest and apoptosis .
6,7 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein

Moreover , we found that the ectopic expression of Smad7 , but not Smad6 , inhibited the activin A -induced Smad2 phosphorylation in HS-72 cells .
9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_line

Thus , Smad6 and Smad7 exhibit differential inhibitory effects in bone morphogenetic protein-2- and activin A- mediated signaling in B lineage cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type

Retinoic acid induces apoptosis of human CD34+ hematopoietic progenitor cells : involvement of retinoic acid receptors and retinoid X receptors depends on lineage commitment of the hematopoietic progenitor cells .
5,10 G#cell_type|13,16 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_type

Retinoids are bifunctional regulators of growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells .
9,11 G#cell_type

In this study we explored the effects of retinoic acid ( RA ) on apoptosis of human CD34+ hematopoietic progenitor cells isolated from normal bone marrow .
18,21 G#cell_type|16,21 G#cell_type

RA ( 100 nM ) induced an increase in the percentage of dead cells from 24 % to 44 % at day 6 ( p &lt; 0.05 , n = 6 ) as compared to control cells cultured in medium alone .
12,14 G#cell_type|35,37 G#cell_type

The effect was dose dependent and appeared relatively late .


Significant differences were observed from day 4 onward .


Apoptosis , or programmed cell death , was demonstrated as the mode of cell death by using the TUNEL assay , which detects single strand nicks in DNA , or by the Nicoletti technique demonstrating a subdiploid population by DNA staining .


RA previously was found to inhibit granulocyte colony-stimulating factor -- and not granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor -- stimulated proliferation of CD34+ cells .
6,9 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

However , we found that RA opposed anti-apoptotic effects of G-CSF and GM-CSF on CD34+ cells ( G-CSF : 8 % dead cells at day 6 ; G-CSF + RA : 20 % ; GM-CSF : 12 % ; GM-CSF + RA : 27 % ) .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Moreover , RA induced apoptosis of CD34+ cells and CD34+CD71+ cells stimulated with erythropoietin .
6,8 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

To explore the receptor signaling pathways involved in RA -induced apoptosis , we used selective ligands for retinoic acid receptors ( RARs ; RO13-7410 ) and retinoid X receptors ( RXRs ; RO 25-6603 ) .
17,20 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

We found that RARs were involved in RA -mediated apoptosis of myeloid progenitor cells , whereas RARs as well as RXRs were involved in RA -mediated apoptosis of erythroid progenitor cells .
3,4 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|28,31 G#cell_type

Suppressive effects of anti-inflammatory agents on human endothelial cell activation and induction of heat shock proteins .
6,9 G#cell_type|13,16 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Studies from our laboratory have shown that the earliest stages of atherosclerosis may be mediated by an autoimmune reaction against heat shock protein 60 ( Hsp60 ) .
22,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The interactions of Hsp60 -specific T cells with arterial endothelial cells ( EC ) require expression of both Hsp60 and certain adhesion molecules shown to be induced simultaneously in EC by mechanical and other types of stress .
3,4 G#protein|3,7 G#cell_line|9,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

Recently , it was shown that suppression of T cell-mediated immune responses by cyclosporin A ( CyA ) enhanced atherosclerotic lesion formation in mice .


In contrast , aspirin was found to lower the risk of myocardial infarction in men .


These conflicting observations may be due to different effects of anti-inflammatory agents on adhesion molecule and Hsp expression in EC , respectively .
19,20 G#cell_type

MATERIAL AND METHODS : In the present study , we analyzed the effects of CyA , aspirin , and indomethacin on T cell proliferation using a proliferation assay .


To explore the expression of adhesion molecules , monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 ( MCP-1 ) , and Hsp60 in human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVECs ) , Northern blot analyses were used .
5,7 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|18,23 G#cell_type|24,25 G#cell_type

To examine the activation status of the transcription factors nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) and heat shock factor-1 ( HSF-1 ) , electrophoretic mobility shift assays were performed .
7,9 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

RESULTS : With the exception of indomethacin , the used immunosuppressive and anti-inflammatory agents significantly inhibited T cell proliferation in response to influenza virus antigen in a dose-dependent manner .
22,25 G#protein

Interestingly , CyA and indomethacin did not suppress tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) -induced adhesion molecule expression on HUVECs , whereas aspirin had an inhibitory effect .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

These observations correlated with the modulation of NF-kappaB activity in EC .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type

All agents tested induced expression of Hsp60 6 hr after application .
6,7 G#protein

In addition , aspirin and indomethacin , but not CyA , induced Hsp70 expression in HUVECs that correlated with induction of HSF-1 activity .
12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein

CONCLUSION : Our results show that the tested agents ( except indomethacin ) are inhibitors of the T cell-mediated immune response , as expected , that aspirin is an effective suppressor of adhesion molecule expression , and that all three agents can induce Hsp60 in HUVECs .
32,34 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#cell_type

These data provide the molecular basis for the notion that ( 1 ) part of the anti-atherogenic effect of aspirin may be due to the prevention of the adhesion of sensitized T cells to stressed EC ; ( 2 ) that part of the atherosclerosis-promoting effect of CyA may be due to its potential as an inducer of Hsp60 expression and its inability to down-regulate adhesion molecule expression on EC ; and ( 3 ) that down-regulation of MCP-1 expression by aspirin may result in decreased recruitment of monocytes into the arterial intima beneath stressed EC .
30,33 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type|58,59 G#protein|65,67 G#protein|69,70 G#cell_type|78,79 G#protein|88,89 G#cell_type|95,96 G#cell_type

In vivo modulation of glucocorticoid receptor mRNA by inhaled fluticasone propionate in bronchial mucosa and blood lymphocytes in subjects with mild asthma .
4,6 G#protein|4,7 G#RNA|15,17 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : In vivo regulation of the glucocorticoid receptor ( GR ) by glucocorticoids provides a means of modulating sensitivity of targeted cells .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

OBJECTIVE : We sought to determine the in vivo modulation of GR mRNA expression by fluticasone propionate ( FP ) in subjects with mild asthma .
11,13 G#RNA

METHODS : Ten atopic asthmatic subjects were treated with FP 250 microg twice daily for 4 weeks .


Before and after treatment , the patients underwent fiberoptic bronchoscopy with endobronchial biopsy and sampling of venous blood for measurements of GR mRNA levels .
21,23 G#RNA

A solution hybridization assay was used for quantitative analysis of GR mRNA .
10,12 G#RNA

In addition , a 24-hour urinary cortisol excretion and an adrenocorticotropic hormone test before and after treatment with FP were performed .


RESULTS : A high interindividual variation in GR mRNA expression was seen .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA

However , we detected a significant reduction of the GR mRNA levels in the endobronchial biopsy specimens after FP treatment ( 36.6 +/- 23.1 and 25.0 +/- 10.9 amol GR mRNA /microg RNA , respectively ; P &lt; .01 ) .
9,11 G#RNA|29,31 G#RNA

In the peripheral blood lymphocytes an even more striking downregulation of the GR by its cognate ligand was documented ( 30.3 +/- 26.5 and 8.8 +/- 5 amol GR mRNA /microg RNA , respectively ; P &lt; .001 ) , possibly reflecting differences in glucocorticoid sensitivity between tissues .
3,5 G#cell_type|28,30 G#RNA

A small but significant reduction of the 24-hour urinary cortisol excretion was observed ( 233 +/- 109 and 157 +/- 66 nmol/L , respectively ; P &lt; .01 ) , whereas the feedback regulation of glucocorticoid synthesis by means of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis as assessed by the adrenocorticotropic hormone test remained normal after treatment with FP .


CONCLUSION : The results in this study confirm the potency of the inhaled corticosteroid FP and provide evidence for a considerable tissue-specific interindividual variation in the expression of the GR .
29,30 G#protein

[ Corticoids and allergy ]


Inflammation is constantly observed in allergic reactions .


Corticosteroids are most effective in preventing the late phase of allergic reaction .


The action of glucocorticosteroids is mediated through glucocorticoid receptors present in the cellular cytoplasm .
7,9 G#protein

When activated , glucocorticoid receptors form a dimer and bind to DNA after migration into the nucleus .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Interaction to DNA induces changes in the transcription rate , leading to either gene induction or gene repression .


Glucocorticoid receptors are also able to interact with transcriptional factors such as AP-1 ( activator protein-1 ) of NF-kappa B ( nuclear factor-kappa B ) .
12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Through these actions glucocorticosteroids are susceptible to modify functions of cells involved in the allergic inflammatory response .


They are in particular able to inhibit most of the pro-inflammatory functions of the eosinophils .
14,15 G#cell_type

Jeg-3 human choriocarcinoma-induced immunosuppression : downregulation of interleukin-2 , interleukin-2 receptor alpha-chain , and its Jak/Stat signaling pathway .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

PROBLEM : The mechanisms of the immunosuppressive and immunosuppression-inducing capacities of Jeg-3 human choriocarcinoma cell line supernatants ( HCSs ) are not yet completely understood .
11,16 G#cell_line

The influence on interleukin ( IL ) -2 , IL-4 and interferon ( IFN ) -gamma production ; IL-2 receptor ( IL-2R ) alpha - , beta - , and gamma-chain ; and the signaling pathway molecules Janus kinase ( Jak ) 1 , Jak3 , signal transducers and activators of transcription ( Stat ) 1 , Stat3 , and Stat5 should be investigated .
3,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,16 G#protein|18,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|39,43 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|49,52 G#protein|52,56 G#protein|57,58 G#protein|60,61 G#protein

METHOD OF STUDY : For assessment of IL production , whole peripheral venous blood from healthy donors was stimulated with phorbol-myristate-acetate and ionomycine .


Secretion of ILs was blocked with monensine .
2,3 G#protein

Intracellular ILs were analyzed by flow cytometry .
1,2 G#protein

For IL-2R and signaling pathway molecule analysis , peripheral blood lymphocytes were stimulated with phytohemagglutinin ( PHA ) .
1,2 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

IL-2R chains were measured by flow cytometry , and Jaks/Stats by sodium dodecyl sulfate polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis ( SDS-PAGE ) and Western blot .
9,10 G#protein

RESULTS : Phorbol-myristate-acetate and ionomycine strongly increase the percent-age of IL-2+ cells ; an additional 50 % HCSs significantly suppresses the percentage to , or below the level of unstimulated cells .
10,12 G#cell_line|29,31 G#cell_type

IFN-gamma production is strongly decreased by HCSs in some cases , but not in others .


PHA stimulates IL-2R alpha- , beta- , and gamma- chain expression and their signaling pathway molecules Jak1 , Jak3 , Stat1 , Stat3 , and Stat5 .
0,1 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

50 % HCS downregulates the alpha-chain and slightly upregulates the beta-chain .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Jak1 , Jak3 , Stat1 , Stat3 , and Stat5 expression is suppressed approximately to , or below the level of unstimulated cells .
21,23 G#cell_type

CONCLUSIONS : HCS forcefully blocks the production of IL-2 ; the IL-2R alpha-chain ; and Jak1 , Jak3 , Stat1 , Stat3 , and Stat5 expression .
8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

The observed phenomena might be caused by downregulation of an IL-2R regulation gene , and might play a key role in the expansion of choriocarcinoma , and possibly in the survival of the fetal allograft .
10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA

Apoptosis -resistant T cells have a deficiency in NF-kappaB -mediated induction of Fas ligand transcription .
0,4 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Apoptosis induced through the TCR in CD4+ T cells is mostly mediated by the inducible expression of Fas ligand ( FasL ) as a primary event leading to the commitment to death .
4,5 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

To gain a better understanding of the transcriptional events that regulate this expression , we took advantage of our previously described mutant Jurkat cells .
21,24 G#cell_line

These cells are deficient in FasL expression and apoptosis induced upon TCR triggering , although their cytokine ( IL-2 and IFN-gamma ) production is normal .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Here we show that both a FasL- and a consensus NF-kappaB- reporter construct are inefficiently induced in these cells compared to wild-type cells .
6,13 G#DNA|21,23 G#cell_type

In addition , we demonstrate that the inducible transcriptional activity of the FasL reporter is abolished by specific inhibitors of NF-kappaB activation .
12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

Thus , we could trace the deficit of the mutant cells to an inefficient NF-kappaB activation , evidencing a relevant role for NF-kappaB in the regulation of FasL expression in activated T cells .
9,11 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_type

Furthermore , our results suggest that the induction of FasL versus cytokine gene expression is differentially sensitive to NF-kappaB deprivation .
9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein

Decreased proteasome -mediated degradation in T cells from the elderly : A role in immune senescence .
1,2 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type

Induction of NFkappaB is a highly regulated process requiring phosphorylation , ubiquitination , and proteasome -mediated degradation of the cytosolic inhibitor IkappaBalpha .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Analyses of the regulation of IkappaBalpha in TNF-alpha -treated T lymphocytes from young and elderly donors revealed severely compromised degradation of IkappaBalpha in T cells from the elderly .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

Examination of activation-induced phosphorylation and ubiquitination of IkappaBalpha did not demonstrate any significant age-related alterations .
7,8 G#protein

However , examination of proteasome activity in these T cells using fluorogenic peptide assays revealed a significant age-related decline in chymotryptic activity .
4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

These results suggest that a decline in proteasome activity results in a failure to fully degrade IkappaBalpha in the elderly .
7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

This failure to degrade IkappaBalpha may underlie both the observed decrease in NFkappaB induction and the IL-2 receptor expression in TNF-treated T cells during aging .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|20,23 G#cell_line

Thus , decreased proteasome -mediated degradation may be central to immune dysfunction that accompanies aging .
3,4 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Inhibition of IL-4 -inducible gene expression in human monocytes by type I and type II interferons .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|10,16 G#protein

The Th2-type cytokines , interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) and interleukin-13 ( IL-13 ) , induce expression of a distinct subset of genes in human monocytes , including FcepsilonRIIb ( CD23 ) , 15-lipoxygenase , IL-1 receptor antagonist ( IL-1ra ) , and type I and type II IL-1 receptors ( IL-1R ) .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|42,49 G#protein|50,51 G#protein

Type I interferons ( IFN-alpha and IFN-beta ) and type II interferon ( IFN-gamma ) inhibit induction of these genes by IL-4 and IL-13 .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

However , the mechanism by which IFNs mediate this inhibition has not been defined .
6,7 G#protein

In this overview , we discuss the role of the transcription factor , STAT6 ( signal transducer and activator of transcription-6 ) in mediating IL-4- and IL-13- induced gene expression in monocytes .
10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|31,32 G#cell_type

We also discuss our recent findings that type I and type II IFNs suppress IL-4 / IL-13 -inducible gene expression by inhibiting tyrosine phosphorylation and nuclear translocation of STAT6 .
7,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The ability of type I and type II IFNs to inhibit IL-4 / IL-13 -induced STAT6 activity is dose- and time-dependent , and is not unique to monocytes because IFNs induce the same effects in fibroblasts .
3,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|35,36 G#cell_type

Inhibition of STAT6 activity is not evident unless cells are preincubated with IFN for at least 1 h before IL-4 stimulation .
2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Furthermore , inhibition can be blocked by actinomycin D , indicating a requirement for de novo transcription .


We propose a model in which stimulation of monocytes by IFN activates de novo synthesis of an inhibitory factor , possibly one or more members of the SOCS/ SSI/CIS gene family , capable of suppressing activation of STAT6 by IL-4 and IL-13 .
8,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|27,31 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

Because STAT6 activation plays an essential role in IL-4 / IL-13 -induced gene expression , the ability of IFN-beta and IFN-gamma to inhibit STAT6 activity provides an explanation for how IFNs can suppress IL-4 / IL-13 -inducible gene expression .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

HLA class I -mediated induction of cell proliferation involves cyclin E -mediated inactivation of Rb function and induction of E2F activity .
0,3 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein

Chronic rejection of transplanted organs is manifested as atherosclerosis of the blood vessels of the allograft .


HLA class I Ags have been implicated to play a major role in this process , since signaling via HLA class I molecules can induce the proliferation of aortic endothelial as well as smooth muscle cells .
0,4 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|33,36 G#cell_type

In this study , we show that HLA class I -mediated induction of cell proliferation correlates with inactivation of the Rb protein in the T cell line Jurkat as well as human aortic endothelial cells .
7,10 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|24,28 G#cell_line|31,35 G#cell_type

HLA class I -mediated inactivation of Rb can be inhibited specifically by neutralizing Abs to basic fibroblast growth factor ( bFGF ) , suggesting a role for FGF receptors in the signaling process .
0,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Signaling through HLA class I molecules induced cyclin E -associated kinase activity within 4 h in quiescent endothelial cells , and appeared to mediate the inactivation of Rb .
2,6 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|16,19 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein

A cdk2 inhibitor , Olomoucine , as well as a dominant-negative cdk2 construct prevented HLA class I -mediated inactivation of Rb ; in contrast , dominant-negative cdk4 and cdk6 constructs had no effect .
10,13 G#DNA|14,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,30 G#DNA

Furthermore , there was no increase in cyclin D-associated kinase activity upon HLA class I ligation , suggesting that cyclin E-dependent kinase activity mediates Rb inactivation , leading to E2F activation and cell proliferation .
7,10 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Immunosuppressant PG490 ( triptolide ) inhibits T-cell interleukin-2 expression at the level of purine-box/nuclear factor of activated T-cells and NF-kappaB transcriptional activation .
6,8 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

PG490 ( triptolide ) is a diterpene triepoxide with potent immunosuppressive and antiinflammatory properties .


PG490 inhibits interleukin ( IL ) -2 expression by normal human peripheral blood lymphocytes stimulated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) and antibody to CD3 ( IC50 of 10 ng/ml ) , and with PMA and ionomycin ( Iono , IC50 of 40 ng/ml ) .
2,7 G#protein|9,14 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

In Jurkat T-cells , PG490 inhibits PMA /Iono-stimulated IL-2 transcription .
1,3 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein

PG490 inhibits the induction of DNA binding activity at the purine-box/antigen receptor response element ( ARRE ) /nuclear factor of activated T-cells ( NF-AT ) target sequence but not at the NF-kappaB site .
10,27 G#DNA|31,33 G#DNA

PG490 can completely inhibit transcriptional activation at the purine-box/ARRE/NF-AT and NF-kappaB target DNA sequences triggered by all stimuli examined ( PMA , PMA /Iono , tumor necrosis factor-alpha ) .
8,14 G#DNA|25,28 G#protein

PG490 also inhibits PMA -stimulated activation of a chimeric transcription factor in which the C-terminal TA1 transactivation domain of NF-kappaB p65 is fused to the DNA binding domain of GAL4 .
8,11 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

In 16HBE human bronchial epithelial cells , IL-8 expression is regulated predominantly by NF-kappaB , and PG490 but not cyclosporin A can completely inhibit expression of IL-8 .
1,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

The mechanism of PG490 inhibition of cytokine gene expression differs from cyclosporin A and involves nuclear inhibition of transcriptional activation of NF-kappaB and the purine-box regulator operating at the ARRE/NF-AT site at a step after specific DNA binding .
6,8 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

Unexpected and coordinated expression of Spi-1 , Fli-1 , and megakaryocytic genes in four Epo-dependent cell lines established from transgenic mice displaying erythroid-specific expression of a thermosensitive SV40 T antigen .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#cell_line|26,30 G#protein

Most erythroleukemic cell lines established in vitro coexpress erythrocytic and megakaryocytic markers that often are associated with expression of Spi-1 and/or Fli-1 transcription factors known as transactivators of megakaryocyte-specific promoters .
1,4 G#cell_line|8,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|26,30 G#protein

In the present study , we examined the possibility of establishing new cell lines keeping strictly erythroid-specific properties in vitro through the targeted and conditional immortalization of erythrocytic progenitors .
11,14 G#cell_line|27,29 G#cell_type

For that purpose , we established several lines of transgenic mice displaying erythroid-specific expression of a thermosensitive SV40 T antigen .
16,20 G#protein

As expected , these transgenic mice developed splenomegaly due to the massive amplification of Ter 119 positive erythroid nucleated cells expressing T antigen .
14,20 G#cell_line|21,23 G#protein

Despite this drastic effect in vivo , the in vitro immortalization of erythropoietin-dependent erythroid progenitors unexpectedly occurred at low frequency , and all four cell lines established expressed both erythrocytic ( globins ) and megakaryocytic markers ( glycoprotein IIb , platelet factor 4 ) as well as Spi-1 and Fli-1 transcripts at permissive temperature .
12,15 G#cell_type|24,26 G#cell_line|29,36 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|40,43 G#protein|47,48 G#protein|49,51 G#protein

Switching the cells to the nonpermissive temperature led to a marked increase in globin gene expression and concomitant decrease in expression of Spi-1 , Fli-1 , and megakaryocytic genes in an erythropoietin -dependent manner .
13,15 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein

Interestingly , enhanced expression of Spi-1 and Fli-1 genes already was detected in the Ter 119 positive cell population of transgenic mice spleen in vivo .
5,9 G#DNA|14,19 G#cell_line

However , like normal Ter 119 erythroid cells , these Ter 119 positive cells from transgenic mice still expressed high levels of beta-globin and very low or undetectable glycoprotein IIb and platelet factor 4 megakaryocytic transcripts .
3,8 G#cell_line|10,14 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|31,36 G#protein

Taken together , these data indicate that the unexpected expression of megakaryocytic genes is a specific property of immortalized cells that can not be explained only by enhanced expression of Spi-1 and/or Fli-1 genes .
11,13 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_line|30,34 G#DNA

Fludarabine -induced immunosuppression is associated with inhibition of STAT1 signaling .
8,9 G#protein

Fludarabine is a nucleoside analog used in the treatment of hematologic malignancies that can induce severe and prolonged immunosuppression .


Although it can be incorporated into the DNA of dividing cells , fludarabine is also a potent inhibitor of cells with a low growth fraction , thus it must have other mechanisms of action .


STAT1 , which is activated in response to many lymphocyte-activating cytokines including the interferons , is essential for cell-mediated immunity , as the absence of this protein is associated with prominent defects in the ability to control viral infections .
0,1 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Here we show that fludarabine , but not the immunosuppressant cyclosporine A , inhibits the cytokine -induced activation of STAT1 and STAT1 -dependent gene transcription in normal resting or activated lymphocytes .
15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|26,31 G#cell_type

Fludarabine caused a specific depletion of STAT1 protein ( and mRNA ) but not of other STATs .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

This loss of STAT1 was also seen in cells from patients treated with fludarabine in vivo .
3,4 G#protein

Brief exposure to fludarabine led to a sustained loss of STAT1 , analogous to the prolonged period of immunosuppression induced by exposure to the drug in vivo .
10,11 G#protein

Thus , STAT1 may be a useful target in the development of new immunosuppressive and antineoplastic agents .
2,3 G#protein

Studies into the effect of tyrosine phosphatase inhibitor phenylarsine oxide on NFkappaB activation in T lymphocytes during aging : evidence for altered IkappaB-alpha phosphorylation and degradation .
5,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein

Nuclear Factor kappa B ( NFkappaB ) is a critical regulator of several genes involved in immune and inflammatory responses .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Treatment of T cells with a variety of stimuli , including TNF-alpha , leads to the translocation of the active p65-50 heterodimer to the nucleus , albeit at a lower level in T cells from the elderly .
2,4 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

We demonstrate here that pretreatment with PAO results in the inhibition of NFkappaB induction in TNF-alpha treated T cells , suggesting a role for PAO -sensitive phosphatase in the activation of the NFkappaB via this pathway in human T cells .
12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type|24,27 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|37,40 G#cell_type

Furthermore , it demonstrates that aging does not influence the sensitivity of this phosphatase .
13,14 G#protein

Treatment with DMP prior to treatment with PAO and TNF abolishes the inhibition induced by PAO , in T cells from both young and old donors , alike .
9,10 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Finally , we demonstrate that a failure to degrade IkappaB-alpha in cytosols of TNF -treated T cells pretreated with PAO is due to its interference with the phosphorylation of IkappaB-alpha and not due to its inhibitory effect on proteasomal degradation .
9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|13,17 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein

These data collectively suggest that PAO interferes with the phosphorylation and the regulated degradation of IkappaB-alpha , induced by TNF , without affecting the chymotryptic activity of the proteasome , independent of age .
15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Spi-C , a novel Ets protein that is temporally regulated during B lymphocyte development .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

A novel Ets protein was isolated by yeast one-hybrid screening of a cDNA library made from lipopolysaccharide-stimulated mouse splenic B cells , using the SP6 kappa promoter kappaY element as a bait .
2,4 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|16,21 G#cell_line|24,29 G#DNA

The novel Ets protein was most closely related to PU.1 and Spi-B within the DNA binding Ets domain and was therefore named Spi-C .
2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein

However , Spi-C may represent a novel subgroup within the Ets protein family , as it differed significantly from Spi-B and PU.1 within helix 1 of the Ets domain .
2,3 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Spi-C was encoded by a single-copy gene that was mapped to chromosome 10 , region C .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA

Spi-C interacted with DNA similarly to PU.1 as judged by methylation interference , band-shift and site selection analysis , and activated transcription of a kappaY element reporter gene upon co-transfection of HeLa cells .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|24,28 G#DNA|31,33 G#cell_line

Spi-C RNA was expressed in mature B lymphocytes and at lower levels in macrophages .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#RNA|5,8 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

Furthermore , pre-B cell and plasma cell lines were Spi-C -negative , suggesting that Spi-C might be a regulatory molecule during a specific phase of B lymphoid development .
2,8 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Glucocorticoid -induced cell death requires autoinduction of glucocorticoid receptor expression in human leukemic T cells .
7,9 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_type

In contrast to the negative autoregulation of glucocorticoid receptor ( GR ) expression seen in most cells and tissues , GR expression is positively autoregulated in human leukemic T cells and in other cells sensitive to glucocorticoid-induced cell death .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,30 G#cell_type

To determine whether positive autoregulation is a necessary component of glucocorticoid-induced cell death , a wild-type GR gene under the control of a tetracycline -regulated promoter was stably transfected into glucocorticoid-resistant cells lacking endogenous functional receptor .
16,17 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA|30,32 G#cell_line

Transfectants grown in the presence of tetracycline contained about 15,000 receptors/cell , a value approximately equal to basal level GR expression in glucocorticoid-sensitive 6TG1.1 cells before steroid treatment .
0,1 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_line

Under these conditions , dexamethasone had a minimal effect on cell growth , elicited little internucleosomal DNA fragmentation , and induced no cell cycle perturbation .


In the absence of tetracycline , GR mRNA and protein expression increased 2-3-fold , and cells expressed 48,000 receptors , a level nearly equivalent to that present in 6TG1.1 cells after 18 h of autoinduction .
6,8 G#RNA|28,30 G#cell_line

Under these conditions , dexamethasone markedly inhibited cell growth , caused G1 arrest , and induced significant internucleosomal DNA fragmentation .


These studies therefore suggest that basal level GR expression is inadequate to mediate glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis in glucocorticoid-sensitive T cells and that positive autoregulation is a necessary component of this process .
7,8 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line

Constitutive activation of NF-kappaB in primary adult T-cell leukemia cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,10 G#cell_type

Human T-cell leukemia virus type I ( HTLV-I ) is an etiologic agent of adult T-cell leukemia ( ATL ) .


The viral protein Tax induces the activation and nuclear translocalization of transcription factor NF-kappaB , which is proposed to play a crucial role in the transformation of T cells by HTLV-I .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

However , the HTLV-I genes including Tax are not expressed significantly in primary leukemic cells from ATL patients .
3,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

In this study , we examined the basis for NF-kappaB activation in freshly isolated leukemic cells from ATL patients .
9,10 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type

We found that leukemic cells from ATL patients , like HTLV-I -infected T-cell lines , display constitutive NF-kappaB DNA binding activity and increased degradation of IkappaBalpha ( an inhibitor of NF-kappaB ) .
3,5 G#cell_type|10,14 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Whereas the NF-kappaB binding activity in Tax -expressing T-cell lines consisted mostly of p50/c-Rel , fresh ATL samples contained p50/p50 and p50/p65 heterodimers .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,10 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

One T-cell line derived from ATL leukemic cells , TL-Om1 , displayed constitutive NF-kappaB activity , as well as enhanced degradation of IkappaBalpha , despite the lack of detectable Tax expression .
1,3 G#cell_line|6,8 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Interestingly , the NF-kappaB in TL-Om1 consists of p50/p50 and p50/p65 like that in fresh primary leukemic cells .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_type

Our results suggest that activation of NF-kappaB occurs through a Tax -independent mechanism in leukemic cells of ATL patients , possibly due to differential NF-kappaB subunit activation .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein

Interferon-alpha induction of STATs 1 , -3 DNA binding and growth arrest is independent of Lck and active mitogen-activated kinase in T cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

Type I interferons ( IFNs ) are a family of cytokines that have antiviral and antiproliferative effects .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Data regarding the processes by which these cytokines transduce signals from the cell membrane to the nucleus are becoming increasingly complex .
7,8 G#protein

The most characterized pathway is via JAK -STAT signaling .
6,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Previous studies established a potential role for the Src-family kinase Lck in JAK -STAT signaling .
8,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Therefore , this study was designed to analyze the role of Lck in IFN-alpha signaling by using the Jurkat , JCam ( an Lck -defective cell line derived from Jurkat ) , and JCam/ Lck ( JCam cells with Lck restored ) .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,27 G#cell_line|29,30 G#cell_line|34,35 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_line|36,38 G#cell_line|39,40 G#protein

The results show that IFN-alpha can induce MAPK activity , but only in cells containing Lck .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Furthermore , STATs 1 and -3 are effectively phosphorylated and activated to bind DNA in the absence of Lck expression in IFN-alpha -treated cells .
2,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_line

Finally , the results demonstrate that IFN-alpha exerts an antiproliferative effect in all three cell lines .
6,7 G#protein

These data indicate that Lck and active MAPK do not affect IFN-alpha -induced growth arrest or induction of STAT1s1 and -3 DNA binding ability .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Selective activation and functional significance of p38alpha mitogen-activated protein kinase in lipopolysaccharide -stimulated neutrophils .
6,10 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_line
