Activation of leukocytes by proinflammatory stimuli selectively initiates intracellular signal transduction via sequential phosphorylation of kinases .
2,3 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

Lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) stimulation of human neutrophils is known to result in activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPk ) ; however , the upstream activator ( s ) of p38 MAPk is unknown , and consequences of p38 MAPk activation remain largely undefined .
6,8 G#cell_type|15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|40,42 G#protein

We investigated the MAPk kinase ( MKK ) that activates p38 MAPk in response to LPS , the p38 MAPk isoforms that are activated as part of this pathway , and the functional responses affected by p38 MAPk activation .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

Although MKK3 , MKK4 , and MKK6 all activated p38 MAPk in experimental models , only MKK3 was found to activate recombinant p38 MAPk in LPS -treated neutrophils .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Of p38 MAPk isoforms studied , only p38alpha and p38delta were detected in neutrophils .
1,3 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

LPS stimulation selectively activated p38alpha .
4,5 G#protein

Specific inhibitors of p38alpha MAPk blocked LPS -induced adhesion , nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappaB ) activation , and synthesis of tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Inhibition of p38alpha MAPk resulted in a transient decrease in TNF-alpha mRNA accumulation but persistent loss of TNF-alpha synthesis .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|10,12 G#RNA|17,18 G#protein

These findings support a pathway by which LPS stimulation of neutrophils results in activation of MKK3 , which in turn activates p38alpha MAPk , ultimately regulating adhesion , NF-kappaB activation , enhanced gene expression of TNF-alpha , and regulation of TNF-alpha synthesis .
10,11 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

The evolutionarily conserved sequence upstream of the human Ig heavy chain S gamma 3 region is an inducible promoter : synergistic activation by CD40 ligand and IL-4 via cooperative NF-kappa B and STAT-6 binding sites .
1,4 G#DNA|7,15 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|23,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|29,35 G#DNA

Germline C gamma gene transcription is a crucial event in the process that leads to switch DNA recombination to IgG , but its regulation in the human is poorly understood .
19,20 G#protein

We took advantage of our monoclonal model of germinal center B cell differentiation , IgM+ IgD+ CL-01 cells , to define the role of the I gamma 3 evolutionarily conserved sequence ( ECS ) in the germline transcriptional activation of the human C gamma 3 gene .
8,12 G#cell_type|14,18 G#cell_line|25,28 G#protein|28,31 G#DNA|32,33 G#DNA|36,37 G#DNA|41,46 G#DNA

The I gamma 3 ECS lies upstream of the major I gamma 3 transcription initiation site and displays more than 90 % identity with the corresponding human I gamma 1 , I gamma 2 , and I gamma 4 regions .
1,4 G#protein|4,5 G#DNA|10,13 G#protein|9,16 G#DNA|26,30 G#DNA|31,34 G#DNA|36,39 G#DNA

Reporter luciferase gene vectors containing the human gamma 3 ECS were used to transfect CL-01 cells , which have been shown to undergo Smu --&gt; S gamma 3 DNA recombination , upon engagement of CD40 by CD40 ligand ( CD40L ) and exposure to IL-4 .
0,4 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|6,10 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_line|34,35 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

In these transfected CL-01 cells , CD40: CD40L engagement and exposure to IL-4 synergistically induced gamma 3 ECS-dependent luciferase reporter gene activation .
3,5 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

Targeted mutational analysis demonstrated that a tandem NF-kappa B /Rel binding motif is critical for the gamma 3 ECS responsiveness to both CD40L and IL-4 , while a STAT-6-binding site is additionally required for IL-4 inducibility .
7,9 G#protein|7,12 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|34,35 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays showed that p50/p65/c-Rel and STAT-6 are effectively induced by CD40L and IL-4 , respectively , and bind to specific DNA motifs within the ECS .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA

These partially overlapping CD40L and IL-4 responsive elements are functionally cooperative as the disruption of one of them prevents synergistic promoter activation .
3,8 G#DNA

Thus , the gamma 3 ECS is an inducible promoter containing cis elements that critically mediate CD40L and IL-4 -triggered transcriptional activation of the human C gamma 3 gene .
3,6 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,29 G#DNA

CIITA -induced occupation of MHC class II promoters is independent of the cooperative stabilization of the promoter-bound multi-protein complexes .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#cell_type|4,8 G#DNA|16,19 G#protein

Precise regulation of MHC class II expression plays a crucial role in the control of the immune response .
3,6 G#cell_type

The transactivator CIITA behaves as a master controller of constitutive and inducible MHC class II gene activation , but its exact mechanism of action is not known .
1,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type|12,16 G#DNA

Activation of MHC class II promoters requires binding of at least three distinct multi-protein complexes ( RFX , X2BP and NF-Y ) .
2,5 G#cell_type|2,6 G#DNA|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

It is known that the stability of this binding results from cooperative interactions between these proteins .


We show here that expression of CIITA in MHC class II -cells triggers occupation of the promoters by these complexes .
6,7 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|8,12 G#cell_line

This observation raised the possibility that the effect of CIITA on promoter occupation is mediated by an effect on the cooperative stabilization of the DNA-bound multi-protein complexes .
9,10 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

We show , however , that the presence of CIITA does not affect the stability of the higher-order protein complex formed on DNA by RFX , X2BP and NF-Y .
9,10 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

This suggests other mechanisms for CIITA -induced promoter occupancy , such as an effect on chromatin structure leading to increased accessibility of MHC class II promoters .
5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA|22,25 G#cell_type|22,26 G#DNA

This ability of CIITA to facilitate promoter occupation is undissociable from its transactivation potential .
3,4 G#protein

Finally , we conclude that this effect of CIITA is cell-type specific , since expression of CIITA is not required for normal occupation of MHC class II promoters in B lymphocytes .
8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_type|24,28 G#DNA|29,31 G#cell_type

GrpL , a Grb2 -related adaptor protein , interacts with SLP-76 to regulate nuclear factor of activated T cell activation .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type|13,19 G#protein

Propagation of signals from the T cell antigen receptor ( TCR ) involves a number of adaptor molecules .
5,7 G#cell_type|5,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

SH2 domain-containing protein 76 ( SLP-76 ) interacts with the guanine nucleotide exchange factor Vav to activate the nuclear factor of activated cells ( NF-AT ) , and its expression is required for normal T cell development .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|34,36 G#cell_type

We report the cloning and characterization of a novel Grb2-like adaptor molecule designated as Grb2-related protein of the lymphoid system ( GrpL ) .
9,12 G#protein|14,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Expression of GrpL is restricted to hematopoietic tissues , and it is distinguished from Grb2 by having a proline -rich region .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

GrpL can be coimmunoprecipitated with SLP-76 but not with Sos1 or Sos2 from Jurkat cell lysates .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_line

In contrast , Grb2 can be coimmunoprecipitated with Sos1 and Sos2 but not with SLP-76 .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Moreover , tyrosine -phosphorylated LAT / pp36 / 38 in detergent lysates prepared from anti-CD3 stimulated T cells associated with Grb2 but not GrpL .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|2,9 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

These data reveal the presence of distinct complexes involving GrpL and Grb2 in T cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

A functional role of the GrpL -SLP-76 complex is suggested by the ability of GrpL to act alone or in concert with SLP-76 to augment NF-AT activation in Jurkat T cells .
5,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_line|29,31 G#cell_type

Differential induction of interferon ( IFN ) -inducible protein 10 following differentiation of a monocyte , macrophage cell lineage is related to the changes of nuclear proteins bound to IFN stimulus response element and kappaB sites .
3,10 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein|29,33 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA|34,36 G#DNA

We examined chemokine gene expression following the differentiation of a monocyte , macrophage cell lineage .
2,3 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_line

The human monoblastic cell line , U937 was differentiated to macrophages by the treatment with either phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) , retinoic acid ( RA ) , or vitamin D3 ( VitD3 ) .
1,5 G#cell_line|6,7 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_type

The gene expression of interferon ( IFN ) -inducible protein 10 ( IP-10 ) ( a CXC chemokine ) was markedly augmented by the IFNgamma treatment in PMA - or RA -differentiated U937 cells , but only marginally in undifferentiated or VitD3 -treated cells .
4,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_line|41,44 G#cell_line

In contrast , another inducible gene expression of monocyte chemotactic protein-1 ( a CC chemokine ) and the activation of the transcriptional factor ( FcRFgamma ) bound to the gamma response region were similarly or less abundantly induced by IFNgamma treatment in PMA - or RA -differentiated U937 cells , indicating that increased IP-10 mRNA induction was not due to the augmented ability of the cells to respond to the presence of IFNgamma .
8,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,32 G#DNA|39,40 G#protein|47,49 G#cell_line|53,54 G#protein|53,55 G#RNA|72,73 G#protein

Increased expression of IFNgamma -induced IP-10 mRNA following the differentiation of U937 cells was mediated largely by augmented transcriptional activity of the gene and was related to differentiation-dependent changes of the proteins bound to IFN stimulus response element ( ISRE ) and kB sites , suggesting that these nuclear proteins may determine the IP-10 mRNA inducibility by IFNgamma .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|11,13 G#cell_line|39,40 G#DNA|34,41 G#DNA|42,44 G#DNA|48,50 G#protein|53,54 G#protein|53,55 G#RNA|57,58 G#protein

Role of cellular tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factors in NF-kappaB activation and lymphocyte transformation by herpesvirus Saimiri STP .
2,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

The STP oncoproteins of the herpesvirus saimiri ( HVS ) subgroup A strain 11 and subgroup C strain 488 are now found to be stably associated with tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor ( TRAF ) 1 , 2 , or 3 .
1,3 G#protein|27,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|27,41 G#protein

Mutational analyses identified residues of PXQXT/S in STP-A11 as critical for TRAF association .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

In addition , a somewhat divergent region of STP-C488 is critical for TRAF association .
8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Mutational analysis also revealed that STP-C488 induced NF-kappaB activation that was correlated with its ability to associate with TRAFs .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The HVS STP-C488 P10 --&gt; R mutant was deficient in human T-lymphocyte transformation to interleukin-2-independent growth but showed wild-type phenotype for marmoset T-lymphocyte transformation in vitro and in vivo .
2,3 G#protein

The STP-C488 P10 --&gt; R mutant was also defective in Rat-1 fibroblast transformation , and fibroblast cell transformation was blocked by a TRAF2 dominant-negative mutant .
1,6 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

These data implicate TRAFs in STP-C488 -mediated transformation of human lymphocytes and rodent fibroblasts .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

Other factors are implicated in immortalization of common marmoset T lymphocytes and may also be critical in the transformation of human lymphocytes and rodent fibroblasts .
7,11 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type|24,25 G#cell_type|23,25 G#cell_type

Cleavage of transcription factor SP1 by caspases during anti-IgM-induced B-cell apoptosis .
2,4 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type

Apoptosis is instrumental in the processes generating the diversity of the B-cell repertoire .


Autoreactive B-cells are eliminated by anti-IgM crosslinking after encountering self-antigens , but precise mechanisms leading to B-cell apoptosis are still not well understood .
0,2 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type

We report here the cleavage of the transcription factor SP1 in the human Burkitt lymphoma cell line BL60 during anti-IgM -induced apoptosis .
7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,18 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein

Western blot analysis revealed two cleavage products of approximately 68 kDa and 45 kDa after induction of apoptosis .
9,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Cleavage could be completely inhibited by zDEVD-fmk , an inhibitor specific for caspase 3-like proteases .
12,15 G#protein

In-vitro cleavage of recombinant SP1 by recombinant caspase 3 ( CPP32 ) or caspase 7 ( Mch 3 ) results in similar cleavage products as those observed in vivo .
4,5 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Recombinant caspase 6 ( Mch 2 ) primarily generates a 68-kDa cleavage product , as observed after calcium ionophore ( CaI ) induced B-cell apoptosis .
0,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type

In contrast , caspase 1 ( ICE ) did not cleave SP1 in vitro .
11,12 G#protein

The time course of SP1 cleavage during anti-IgM-induced apoptosis is paralleled by an increase of caspase activity measured by DEVD-p-nitroanilide ( DEVD-pNA ) cleavage .
4,5 G#protein

DNA band-shift assays revealed a decrease in the intensity of the full length SP1 /DNA complex and an increase in the intensity of a smaller complex due to the binding of one SP1 cleavage product .
13,14 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

By Edman sequencing we could identify a caspase 3 cleavage site after Asp584 ( D584AQPQAGR ) , generating a 22-kDa C-terminal SP1 protein fragment which still contains the DNA binding site .
21,22 G#protein

Our results show the cleavage of the human transcription factor SP1 in vivo and in vitro , underlining the central role of caspase 3-like proteases during the process of anti-IgM-induced apoptosis .
8,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Stimulation of CD40 on immunogenic human malignant melanomas augments their cytotoxic T lymphocyte -mediated lysis and induces apoptosis .
2,3 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

Here , we report the functional expression of CD40 on human malignant melanomas ( MMs ) .
8,9 G#protein

Comparison of tumor specimen from MM precursor lesions , primary tumors , and metastases revealed that CD40 surface expression is down-regulated during tumor progression .
16,17 G#protein

CD40 expression was confirmed in 7 human MM cell lines established from immunogenic primary tumors or metastases , whereas 11 cell lines established from advanced stages were CD40 negative .
0,1 G#protein|6,10 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein

CD40 expression could be enhanced in CD40 -positive MM by stimulation with IFN-gamma and tumor necrosis factor-alpha but not by interleukin ( IL ) -1beta or CD40 triggering .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|20,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

CD40 ligation on MM by CD40L -transfected murine L-cells or by a soluble CD40L fusion protein up-regulated their expression of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 and MHC class I and class II molecules and their secretion of IL-6 , IL-8 , tumor necrosis factor-a , and granulocyte macrophage colony-stimulating factor and also induced a rapid activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor kappaB .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,31 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,42 G#protein|44,48 G#protein|56,58 G#protein|58,61 G#protein

Furthermore , CD40 ligation of a HLA-A2+ , MelanA/MART1+ MM cell line enhanced its susceptibility to specific lysis by a HLA-A2-restricted , MelanA/MART-1-specific CTL clone .
2,3 G#protein|6,12 G#cell_line|20,25 G#cell_line

Finally , CD40 ligation induced growth inhibition and apoptosis in MM .
2,3 G#protein

These results indicate that CD40 -CD40L interactions may play an important role in augmenting antitumor immunity and inducing apoptosis in some CD40 -positive immunogenic human MMs .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Human immunodeficiency virus -associated Hodgkin 's disease derives from post-germinal center B cells .
9,13 G#cell_type

Human immunodeficiency virus -associated Hodgkin 's disease ( HIV-HD ) displays several peculiarities when compared with HD of the general population .


These include overrepresentation of clinically aggressive histologic types and frequent infection of Reed-Sternberg ( RS ) cells by Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) .
12,17 G#cell_line

Recently , we have reported that the histogenesis of HD of the general population may be assessed by monitoring the expression pattern of BCL-6 , a transcription factor expressed in germinal center ( GC ) B cells , and of CD138/syndecan-1 ( syn-1 ) , a proteoglycan associated with post-GC , terminal B-cell differentiation .
23,24 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|30,37 G#cell_line|40,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|52,53 G#cell_type

In this study , we have applied these two markers to the study of HIV- HD histogenesis and correlated their expression status to the virologic features of this disease .


We have found that RS cells of all histologic categories of HIV- HD consistently display the BCL-6 (-)/syn-1(+) phenotype and thus reflect post-GC B cells .
4,6 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_line

Although BCL-6 (-)/syn-1(+) RS cells of HIV-HD express CD40 , they are not surrounded by CD40 ligand -positive ( CD40L + ) reactive T lymphocytes , which , in HD of the general population , are thought to regulate the disease phenotype through CD40 /CD40L interactions .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|15,25 G#cell_type|43,44 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

Conversely , RS cells of virtually all HIV- HD express the EBV -encoded latent membrane protein 1 ( LMP1 ) , which , being functionally homologous to CD40 , may contribute , at least in part , to the modulation of the HIV- HD phenotype .
2,4 G#cell_line|11,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

MDS1/EVI1 enhances TGF-beta1 signaling and strengthens its growth-inhibitory effect but the leukemia-associated fusion protein AML1/MDS1/EVI1 , product of the t(3;21) , abrogates growth-inhibition in response to TGF-beta1 .
0,1 G#DNA|2,3 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

MDS1/EVI1 , located on chromosome 3 band q26 , encodes a zinc-finger DNA-binding transcription activator not detected in normal hematopoietic cells but expressed in several normal tissues .
0,1 G#DNA|4,6 G#DNA|4,8 G#DNA|11,15 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type

MDS1/EVI1 is inappropriately activated in myeloid leukemias following chromosomal rearrangements involving band 3q26 .
0,1 G#DNA|5,7 G#cell_type|11,13 G#protein

The rearrangements lead either to gene truncation , and to expression of the transcription repressor EVI1 , as seen in the t(3;3)(q21;q26) and inv(3)(q21q26) , or to gene fusion , as seen in the t(3;21)(q26;q22) which results in the fusion protein AML1/MDS1/EVI1 .
13,16 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA|41,42 G#protein

This fusion protein contains the DNA-binding domain of the transcription factor AML1 fused in-frame to the entire MDS1/EVI1 with the exclusion of its first 12 amino acids .
5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA

In this report , we have analyzed the response of the hematopoietic precursor cell line 32Dcl3 , expressing either the normal protein MDS1/EVI1 or the fusion protein AML1/MDS1/EVI1 , to factors that control cell differentiation or cell replication .
11,16 G#cell_line|22,23 G#DNA|20,23 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|25,28 G#protein

The 32Dcl3 cells are IL-3 -dependent for growth and they differentiate into granulocytes when exposed to G-CSF .
1,3 G#cell_line|4,5 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

They are growth-inhibited by TGF-beta1 .
4,5 G#protein

We show that whereas the expression of MDS1/EVI1 has no effect on granulocytic differentiation induced by G-CSF , expression of AML1/MDS1/EVI1 blocks differentiation resulting in cell death .
7,8 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

This effect is similar to that previously described by others for 32Dcl3 cells that express transgenic Evil .
11,13 G#cell_line|15,17 G#protein

Furthermore , we show that whereas the expression of the fusion protein AML1/MDS1/EVI1 completely abrogates the growth-inhibitory effect of TGF-beta1 and allows 32Dcl3 cells to proliferate , expression of the normal protein MDS1/EVI1 has the opposite effect , and it strengthens the response of cells to the growth-inhibitory effect of TGF-beta1 .
12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_line|32,33 G#DNA|50,51 G#protein

By using the yeast two-hybrid system , we also show that EVI1 ( contained in its entirety in MDS1/EVI1 and AML1/MDS1/EVI1 ) physically interacts with SMAD3 , which is an intracellular mediator of TGF-beta1 signaling .
11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Finally , we have correlated the response of the cells to G-CSF or TGF-beta1 with the ability of the normal and fusion proteins to activate or repress promoters which they can directly regulate by binding to the promoter site .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|37,39 G#DNA

We propose that mutations of MDS1/EVI1 either by gene truncation resulting in the transcription repressor EVI1 or by gene fusion to AML1 lead to an altered cellular response to growth and differentiation factors that could result in leukemic transformation .
5,6 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

The different response of myeloid cells ectopically expressing the normal or the fusion protein to G-CSF and TGF-beta1 could depend on the different transactivation properties of these proteins resulting in divergent expression of downstream genes regulated by the two proteins .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA

Abnormalities of cyclic adenosine monophosphate signaling in platelets from untreated patients with bipolar disorder .
7,8 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Abnormalities in the cyclic adenosine monophosphate ( cAMP ) -dependent phosphorylation system have been recently reported in patients with bipolar disorder .


We evaluated the immunoreactivity of the regulatory and catalytic subunits of cAMP-dependent protein kinase ( protein kinase A ) and 1 of its substrates , Rap1 , in platelets from untreated euthymic , manic , and depressed patients with bipolar disorder and healthy subjects .
6,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type

METHODS : Platelets were collected from 112 drug-free patients with bipolar disorder ( 52 euthymic , 29 depressed , and 31 manic ) and 62 healthy subjects .
2,3 G#cell_type

The levels of cAMP-dependent protein kinase and Rap1 were assessed by Western blot analysis , immunostaining , and computer-assisted imaging .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

RESULTS : The immunolabeling of the catalytic subunit of cAMP-dependent protein kinase was significantly different among groups ( P &lt; .001 ) , with higher values in untreated depressed and manic patients with bipolar disorder compared with untreated euthymic patients with bipolar disorder and healthy subjects .
6,8 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

No significant differences were found in the immunolabeling of the regulatory subunits ( type I and type II ) of cAMP-dependent protein kinase .
10,12 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

The immunolabeling of Rap1 was significantly higher ( P &lt; .001 ) in untreated euthymic , depressed , and manic patients than in healthy persons .
3,4 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : Levels of Rap1 and the catalytic subunit of cAMP-dependent protein kinase are altered in the platelets of bipolar patients .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

These findings may provide clues toward understanding the involvement of cAMP signaling in the pathogenesis of bipolar disorder .


Molecular regulation of cytokine gene expression during the immune response .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA

Cytokine expression by immune system cells plays an important role in the regulation of the immune response .
0,1 G#protein

On first encounter with antigen , naive CD4+ T helper ( Th ) cells differentiate into cytokine -producing effector cells .
6,14 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|16,20 G#cell_line

Two types of effector cells characterized by their distinct expression of cytokine profiles have been described .
11,12 G#protein

Th1 cells produce IL-2 and IFN-gamma , whereas Th2 cells produce IL-4 , IL-5 , IL-6 , IL-10 , and IL-13 .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

In many pathological situations , the balance between Th1 and Th2 immune responses determines the outcome of diverse immunologically mediated clinical syndromes including infectious , autoimmune , and allergic diseases .


However , the molecular basis for the tissue-specific expression of Th1/Th2-like cytokines has remained elusive .
10,12 G#protein

In this review we evaluate the possible in vivo role of different transcription factors and transcriptional mechanisms in T cell differentiation and the immune response .


Tcf-1 -mediated transcription in T lymphocytes : differential role for glycogen synthase kinase-3 in fibroblasts and T cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type

Beta-catenin is the vertebrate homolog of the Drosophila segment polarity gene Armadillo and plays roles in both cell-cell adhesion and transduction of the Wnt signaling cascade .
7,11 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA

Recently , members of the Lef/Tcf transcription factor family have been identified as protein partners of beta-catenin , explaining how beta-catenin alters gene expression .
5,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Here we report that in T cells , Tcf-1 also becomes transcriptionally active through interaction with beta-catenin , suggesting that the Wnt signal transduction pathway is operational in T lymphocytes as well .
5,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

However , although Wnt signals are known to inhibit the activity of the negative regulatory protein kinase glycogen synthase kinase-3beta ( GSK-3beta ) , resulting in increased levels of beta-catenin , we find no evidence for involvement of GSK-3beta in Tcf-mediated transcription in T cells .
13,17 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|43,45 G#cell_type

That is , a dominant negative GSK-3beta does not specifically activate Tcf transcription and stimuli ( lithium or phytohemagglutinin ) that inhibit GSK-3beta activity also do not activate Tcf reporter genes .
4,7 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,31 G#DNA

Thus , inhibition of GSK-3beta is insufficient to activate Tcf-dependent transcription in T lymphocytes .
4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

In contrast , in C57MG fibroblast cells , lithium inactivates GSK-3beta and induces Tcf-controlled transcription .
4,7 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein

This is the first demonstration that lithium can alter gene expression of Tcf-responsive genes , and points to a difference in regulation of Wnt signaling between fibroblasts and lymphocytes .
12,14 G#DNA|26,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_type

SHP2-interacting transmembrane adaptor protein ( SIT ) , a novel disulfide-linked dimer regulating human T cell activation .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

T lymphocytes express several low molecular weight transmembrane adaptor proteins that recruit src homology ( SH ) 2 domain -containing intracellular molecules to the cell membrane via tyrosine-based signaling motifs .
0,2 G#cell_type|4,10 G#protein|12,19 G#protein|12,22 G#protein

We describe here a novel molecule of this group termed SIT ( SHP2 interacting transmembrane adaptor protein ) .
10,11 G#protein|12,17 G#protein

SIT is a disulfide-linked homodimeric glycoprotein that is expressed in lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type

After tyrosine phosphorylation by src and possibly syk protein tyrosine kinases SIT recruits the SH2 domain -containing tyrosine phosphatase SHP2 via an immunoreceptor tyrosine-based inhibition motif .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|14,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Overexpression of SIT in Jurkat cells downmodulates T cell receptor- and phytohemagglutinin- mediated activation of the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NF-AT ) by interfering with signaling processes that are probably located upstream of activation of phospholipase C .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_type|16,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

However , binding of SHP2 to SIT is not required for inhibition of NF-AT induction , suggesting that SIT not only regulates NF-AT activity but also controls NF-AT unrelated pathways of T cell activation involving SHP2 .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

Extracellular-regulated kinase 1/2 , Jun N-terminal kinase , and c-Jun are involved in NF-kappa B -dependent IL-6 expression in human monocytes .
0,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In the present study we investigated the possible involvement of the mitogen-activated protein kinase family members extracellular-regulated kinase 1/2 ( ERK1/2 ) and c- Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ) in mediating IL-6 gene expression in human monocytes , in particular their role in enhancing NF-kappa B activity .
11,15 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|36,38 G#cell_type|45,47 G#protein

Freshly isolated monocytes treated with the protein phosphatase inhibitor okadaic acid secreted high levels of IL-6 protein , which coincided with enhanced binding activity of NF-kappa B as well as with phosphorylation and activation of the ERK1/2 and JNK proteins .
15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|36,40 G#protein

The ERK pathway-specific inhibitor PD98059 inhibited IL-6 secretion from monocytes .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type

Transient overexpression of inactive mutants of either Raf-1 or JNK1 showed that both pathways were involved in kappa B-dependent IL-6 promoter activity .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

By using PD98059 , we demonstrated that the Raf1/MEK1/ ERK1/2 pathway did not affect the DNA binding of NF-kappa B but , rather , acted at the level of transcriptional activity of NF-kappa B .
9,10 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|32,34 G#protein

Interestingly , it was shown that NF-kappa B -mediated gene transcription , both in the context of the IL-6 promoter as well as on its own , was dependent on both serine kinase activity and interaction with c-Jun protein .
6,8 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

We conclude that okadaic acid -induced IL-6 gene expression is at least partly mediated through the ERK1/2 and JNK pathway-dependent activation of NF-kappa B transcriptional capacity .
6,7 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Our results suggest that the JNK pathway may regulate NF-kappa B -mediated gene transcription through its phosphorylation and activation of c-Jun .
5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

The Epstein-Barr virus nuclear antigen 2 ( EBNA2 ) , a protein required for B lymphocyte immortalization , induces the synthesis of type I interferon in Burkitt 's lymphoma cell lines .
1,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|22,25 G#protein|26,31 G#cell_line

Epstein-Barr virus nuclear antigen 2 ( EBNA2 ) , a protein involved in cell transformation , interferes with the cellular response to type I interferons ( IFN-alpha/beta ) .
0,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

We investigated the function of conditionally expressed EBNA2 in the context of the IFN response in Burkitt 's lymphoma cell lines .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,21 G#cell_line

Expression of EBNA2 led to the transcriptional activation of both endogenous or transfected IFN-stimulated genes ( ISGs ) , genes which contain within their promoters either the interferon-stimulated response element ( ISRE ) or the gamma interferon activation site ( GAS ) .
2,3 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|27,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA|35,39 G#DNA|40,41 G#DNA

In search of a molecular mechanism for the transcriptional induction of ISGs , we observed an EBNA2 -dependent synthesis of IFN-beta mRNA at low levels and the secretion of low amounts of IFN .
11,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

A transfected IFN-beta promoter responded to EBNA2 activation , and a sequence closely resembling a RBP-Jkappa binding site was pinpointed as a potential target of EBNA2 activity .
6,7 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein

EBNA2 -dependent transcriptional induction of the IFN-beta promoter occurred in EBV-negative Burkitt 's lymphoma cells , indicating that other EBV genes were not required for the induction of IFN-beta synthesis .
0,1 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|10,15 G#cell_line|19,21 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein

PGG-glucan , a soluble beta-(1,3)-glucan , enhances the oxidative burst response , microbicidal activity , and activates an NF-kappa B -like factor in human PMN : evidence for a glycosphingolipid beta-(1,3)-glucan receptor .
18,20 G#protein|18,22 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|29,32 G#protein

PGG-Glucan , a soluble beta-(1,6)-branched beta-(1,3)-linked glucose homopolymer derived from the cell wall of the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae , is an immunomodulator which enhances leukocyte anti-infective activity and enhances myeloid and megakaryocyte progenitor proliferation .


Incubation of human whole blood with PGG-Glucan significantly enhanced the oxidative burst response of subsequently isolated blood leukocytes to both soluble and particulate activators in a dose-dependent manner , and increased leukocyte microbicidal activity .
14,18 G#cell_type

No evidence for inflammatory cytokine production was obtained under these conditions .
4,5 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays demonstrated that PGG-Glucan induced the activation of an NF-kappaB -like nuclear transcription factor in purified human neutrophils .
12,13 G#protein|12,17 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type

The binding of 3 H- PGG-Glucan to human leukocyte membranes was specific , concentration-dependent , saturable , and high affinity ( Kd approximately 6 nM ) .


A monoclonal antibody specific to the glycosphingolipid lactosylceramide was able to inhibit activation of the NF-kappaB -like factor by PGG-Glucan , and ligand binding data , including polysaccharide specificity , suggested that the PGG-Glucan binding moiety was lactosylceramide .
1,3 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

These results indicate that PGG-Glucan enhances neutrophil anti-microbial functions and that interaction between this beta-glucan and human neutrophils is mediated by the glycosphingolipid lactosylceramide present at the cell surface .
16,18 G#cell_type

Glucocorticoids promote nonphlogistic phagocytosis of apoptotic leukocytes .
5,7 G#cell_type

Phagocyte recognition , uptake , and nonphlogistic degradation of neutrophils and other leukocytes undergoing apoptosis promote the resolution of inflammation .
9,10 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type

This study assessed the effects of anti-inflammatory glucocorticoids on this leukocyte clearance mechanism .


Pretreatment of " semimature " 5-day human monocyte-derived macrophages ( M phi ) for 24 h with methylprednisolone , dexamethasone , and hydrocortisone , but not the nonglucocorticoid steroids aldosterone , estradiol , and progesterone , potentiated phagocytosis of apoptotic neutrophils .
6,9 G#cell_type|39,41 G#cell_type

These effects were specific in that the potentiated phagocytosis of apoptotic neutrophils was completely blocked by the glucocorticoid receptor antagonist RU38486 , and glucocorticoids did not promote 5-day M phi ingestion of opsonized erythrocytes .
10,12 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

Similar glucocorticoid-mediated potentiation was observed with 5-day M phi uptake of alternative apoptotic " targets " ( eosinophils and Jurkat T cells ) and in uptake of apoptotic neutrophils by alternative phagocytes ( human glomerular mesangial cells and murine M phi elicited into the peritoneum or derived from bone marrow ) .
17,18 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_line|27,29 G#cell_type|31,32 G#cell_type|33,37 G#cell_type|38,41 G#cell_line

Importantly , methylprednisolone -mediated enhancement of the uptake of apoptotic neutrophils did not trigger the release of the chemokines IL-8 and monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 .
9,11 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Furthermore , longer-term potentiation by methylprednisolone was observed in maturing human monocyte-derived M phi , with greater increases in 5-day M phi uptake of apoptotic cells being observed the earlier glucocorticoids were added during monocyte maturation into M phi .
9,14 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_line|24,26 G#cell_type|37,39 G#cell_line

We conclude that potentiation of nonphlogistic clearance of apoptotic leukocytes by phagocytes is a hitherto unrecognized property of glucocorticoids that has potential implications for therapies aimed at promoting the resolution of inflammatory diseases .
8,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#cell_type

1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D3 induces differentiation of a retinoic acid -resistant acute promyelocytic leukemia cell line ( UF-1 ) associated with expression of p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) and p27 ( KIP1 ) .
6,14 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line|21,25 G#protein|26,30 G#protein

Retinoic acid ( RA ) resistance is a serious problem for patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia ( APL ) who are receiving all-trans RA .


However , the mechanisms and strategies to overcome RA resistance by APL cells are still unclear .
11,13 G#cell_type

The biologic effects of RA are mediated by two distinct families of transcriptional factors : RA receptors ( RARs ) and retinoid X receptors ( RXRs ) .
12,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

RXRs heterodimerize with 1,Â 25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 [ 1,25(OH)2D3 ] receptor ( VDR ) , enabling their efficient transcriptional activation .
0,1 G#protein|3,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

The cyclin-dependent kinase ( cdk ) inhibitor p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) has a vitamin D3-responsive element ( VDRE ) in its promoter , and 1,25(OH)2D3 enhances the expression of p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) and induces differentiation of selected myeloid leukemic cell lines .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|1,7 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA|29,33 G#protein|38,42 G#cell_line

We have recently established a novel APL cell line ( UF-1 ) with features of RA resistance .
6,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line

1,25(OH)2D3 can induce growth inhibition and G1 arrest of UF-1 cells , resulting in differentiation of these cells toward granulocytes .
9,11 G#cell_line|19,20 G#cell_type

This 1,Â 25(OH)2D3 -induced G1 arrest is enhanced by all-trans RA .


Also , 1,Â 25(OH)2D3 ( 10(-10) to 10(-7) mol/L ) in combination with RA markedly inhibits cellular proliferation in a dose- and time-dependent manner .


Associated with these findings , the levels of p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) and p27 ( KIP1 ) mRNA and protein increased in these cells .
8,12 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|13,18 G#RNA

Northern blot analysis showed that p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) and p27 ( KIP1 ) mRNA and protein increased in these cells .
5,15 G#RNA

Northern blot analysis showed that p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) and p27 ( KIP1 ) transcripts were induced after 6 hours ' exposure to 1,25(OH)2D3 and then decreased to basal levels over 48 hours .
5,9 G#protein|10,14 G#protein

Western blot experiments showed that p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) protein levels increased and became detectable after 12 hours of 1,25(OH)2D3 treatment and induction of p27 ( KIP1 ) protein was much more gradual and sustained in UF-1 cells .
5,9 G#protein|24,28 G#protein|36,38 G#cell_line

Interestingly , the combination of 1,Â 25(OH)2D3 and RA markedly enhanced the levels of p27 ( KIP1 ) transcript and protein as compared with levels induced by 1,Â 25(OH)2D3 alone .
13,17 G#protein

In addition , exogenous p27 ( KIP1 ) expression can enhance the level of CD11b antigen in myeloid leukemic cells .
4,8 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type

In contrast , RA alone can induce G1 arrest of UF-1 cells ; however , it did not result in an increase of p21 ( WAF1/CIP1 ) and p27 ( KIP1 ) transcript and protein expression in RA -resistant cells .
10,12 G#cell_line|23,27 G#protein|28,32 G#protein

Taken together , we conclude that 1,25(OH)2D3 induces increased expression of cdk inhibitors , which mediates a G1 arrest , and this may be associated with differentiation of RA -resistant UF-1 cells toward mature granulocytes .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line|34,35 G#cell_type

Molecular mechanisms of neutrophil-endothelial cell adhesion induced by redox imbalance .


Previous studies have implicated a role for intracellular thiols in the activation of nuclear factor-kappaB and transcriptional regulation of endothelial cell adhesion molecules .
13,15 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

This study was designed to determine whether changes in endothelial cell glutathione ( GSH ) or oxidized glutathione ( GSSG ) can alter neutrophil adhesivity and to define the molecular mechanism that underlies this GSSG / GSH -induced adhesion response .


Treatment of human umbilical vein endothelial cell ( HUVEC ) monolayers for 6 hours with 0.2 mmol/L diamide and 1 mmol/L buthionine sulfoximine ( BSO ) decreased GSH levels and increased the ratio of GSSG to GSH without cell toxicity .
2,7 G#cell_line|8,9 G#cell_line|2,11 G#cell_line

These redox changes are similar to those observed with anoxia/reoxygenation .


Diamide plus BSO -induced thiol/disulfide imbalance was associated with a biphasic increase in neutrophil adhesion to HUVECs with peak responses observed at 15 minutes ( phase 1 ) and 240 minutes ( phase 2 ) .
13,14 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_line

N-Acetylcysteine treatment attenuated neutrophil adhesion in both phases , which indicated a role for GSH in the adhesion responses .
3,4 G#cell_type

Interestingly , phase 1 adhesion was inversely correlated with GSH levels but not with the GSSG / GSH ratio , whereas phase 2 neutrophil adhesion was positively correlated with GSSG /GSH ratio but not with GSH levels .
23,24 G#cell_type

Intercellular adhesion molecule-1 and P-selectin-specific monoclonal antibodies attenuated the increased neutrophil adhesion during both phases , whereas an anti-E-selectin monoclonal antibody also attenuated the phase 2 response .
0,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Pretreatment with actinomycin D and cycloheximide or with competing ds-oligonucleotides that contained nuclear factor-kappaB or activator protein-1 cognate DNA sequences significantly attenuated the phase 2 response , which implicated a role for de novo protein synthesis .
12,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Surface expression of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 , P- selectin , and E-selectin on HUVECs correlated with the phase 1 and 2 neutrophil adhesion responses .
3,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_type

This study demonstrates that changes in endothelial cell GSSG /GSH cause transcription-independent and transcription-dependent surface expression of different endothelial cell adhesion molecules , which leads to a 2-phase neutrophil -endothelial adhesion response .
18,22 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type

Glucocorticoid hormone suppression of human neutrophil -mediated tumor cell cytostasis .
5,6 G#cell_type

In the present study , we have investigated the effect of glucocorticoid hormones on neutrophil -mediated tumor cell cytostasis and found that hydrocortisone and a synthetic hormone , dexamethasone ( Dex ) , inhibited cytostasis in the presence or absence of tumor necrosis factor-alpha .
14,15 G#cell_type|41,44 G#protein

The effect of Dex was completely reversed by a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist , RU38486 .
9,11 G#protein

To clarify the underlying mechanisms , we examined effects of Dex on the binding avidity of beta2 integrin on the neutrophil surface and how these might in turn affect neutrophil -to-tumor cell binding .
16,18 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|29,30 G#cell_type

Dex was found to inhibit these neutrophil properties , and RU38486 completely suppressed both forms of Dex inhibition .
6,7 G#cell_type

Taken together , our findings suggest that glucocorticoid hormone inhibition of neutrophil -mediated tumor cell cytostasis is at least partially due to a lowering of the ligand binding avidity of beta2 integrin on the neutrophil surface .
11,12 G#cell_type|30,32 G#protein|34,35 G#cell_type

Constitutive activation of an epithelial signal transducer and activator of transcription ( STAT ) pathway in asthma .
12,13 G#protein

Cytokine effects on immunity and inflammation often depend on the transcription factors termed signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STATs ) , so STAT signaling pathways are candidates for influencing inflammatory disease .
0,1 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

We reasoned that selective IFN responsiveness of the first STAT family member ( Stat1 ) and Stat1 -dependent immune-response genes such as intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) , IFN regulatory factor-1 ( IRF-1 ) , and Stat1 itself in airway epithelial cells provides a basis for detecting cytokine signaling abnormalities in inflammatory airway disease .
4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,20 G#DNA|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|40,43 G#cell_type|48,49 G#protein

On the basis of nuclear localization and phosphorylation , we found that epithelial Stat1 ( but not other control transcription factors ) was invariably activated in asthmatic compared with normal control or chronic bronchitis subjects .
13,14 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Furthermore , epithelial levels of activated Stat1 correlated with levels of expression for epithelial ICAM-1 , IRF-1 , and Stat1 , and in turn , ICAM-1 levels correlated with T-cell accumulation in tissue .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

However , only low levels of IFN-gamma or IFN-gamma -producing cells were detected in airway tissue in all subjects .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type

The results therefore provide initial evidence linking abnormal behavior of STAT pathways for cytokine signaling to the development of an inflammatory disease .
10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

In that context , the results also change the current scheme for asthma pathogenesis to one that must include a localized gain in transcriptional signal ordinarily used for a T helper 1-type cytokine ( IFN-gamma ) in combination with allergy-driven overproduction of T helper 2-type cytokines .
29,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|42,46 G#protein

Leukocyte populations , hormone receptors and apoptosis in eutopic and ectopic first trimester human pregnancies .
0,2 G#cell_type|3,5 G#protein

The implantation of trophoblast cells at extrauterine sites still results in decidualization .
3,5 G#cell_type

The objective of the present study was to compare decidualization at eutopic and ectopic implantation sites .


Tissues from women undergoing elective termination of uterine pregnancy and from women with ectopic pregnancy were used to detect the presence of cells important for the maintenance of pregnancy , such as BCL-2+ , CD56+ , CD3+ , CD8+ and CD68+ cells , and the presence of oestrogen ( ER ) and progesterone receptors ( PR ) by immunohistochemistry .
32,42 G#cell_type|47,48 G#protein|49,50 G#protein|52,54 G#protein|47,54 G#protein|55,56 G#protein

In-situ detection of fragmented DNA was performed to identify apoptotic cells .
9,11 G#cell_type

The percentage of CD3+ cells among all immunocompetent cells in the tubal epithelium was 46.6 % ( 39.9 % of CD3+ were also CD8+ ) ; the other 53.4 % were CD68+ cells .
3,5 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type|31,33 G#cell_type

CD56+ cells were undetectable in ectopic decidua at the feto-maternal interface in ectopic tissue .
0,2 G#cell_type

In uterine decidua , we found 29.9 % CD3+ cells ( 2.2 % of CD3+ were CD8+ ) , 51.6 % CD56+ cells and 18.5 % CD68+ cells .
8,10 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type|26,28 G#cell_type

The ratio of BCL2+ to CD3+ cells in ectopic pregnancy was 0.41 .
3,4 G#cell_type|5,7 G#cell_type

In uterine pregnancy , the ratio of BCL-2 to CD3 was 0.44 and 0.39 for CD56 .
7,8 G#protein

Tissues from both ectopic and uterine pregnancies were positive for PR .
10,11 G#protein

Fewer apoptotic cell bodies were present in ectopic pregnancy .
1,4 G#cell_type

The use of tissue obtained from ectopic pregnancy may become an excellent model to identify the mechanism of trophoblast invasion in eutopic pregnancies .


Angiotensin II activates the proinflammatory transcription factor nuclear factor-kappaB in human monocytes .
0,2 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

The renin -angiotensin system may contribute to the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis .
1,2 G#protein

A common feature of all stages of atherosclerosis is inflammation of the vessel wall .


The transcription factor nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) participates in most signaling pathways involved in inflammation .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

This study therefore examined the effect of angiotensin ( ANG ) II on NF-kappaB activation in monocytic cells , a major cellular component of human atheroma , by electrophoretic mobility shift assay .
7,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

ANG II , like TNFalpha , caused rapid activation of NF-kappaB in human mononuclear cells isolated from peripheral blood by Ficoll density gradient .
0,2 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

This ANG II effect was blocked by the angiotensin AT1 receptor antagonist losartan .
1,3 G#protein

Specificity of ANG II -induced NF-kappaB activation was ascertained by supershift and competition experiments .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Moreover , ANG II stimulated NF-kappaB activation in human monocytes , but not in lymphocytes from the same preparation .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type

Together , the data demonstrate the ability of the vasoactive peptide ANG II to activate inflammatory pathways in human monocytes .
11,13 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Signal transduction pathways activated in endothelial cells following infection with Chlamydia pneumoniae .
5,7 G#cell_type

Chlamydia pneumoniae is an important respiratory pathogen .


Recently , its presence has been demonstrated in atherosclerotic lesions .


In this study , we characterized C. pneumoniae-mediated activation of endothelial cells and demonstrated an enhanced expression of endothelial adhesion molecules followed by subsequent rolling , adhesion , and transmigration of leukocytes ( monocytes , granulocytes ) .
10,12 G#cell_type|18,21 G#protein|31,32 G#cell_type|33,34 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type

These effects were blocked by mAbs against endothelial and/or leukocyte adhesion molecules ( beta1 and beta2 integrins ) .
5,6 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|13,17 G#protein

Additionally , activation of different signal transduction pathways in C. pneumoniae -infected endothelial cells was shown : protein tyrosine phosphorylation , up-regulation of phosphorylated p42/p44 mitogen-activated protein kinase , and NF-kappaB activation/translocation occurred within 10-15 min .
12,14 G#cell_type|9,14 G#cell_type|24,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Increased mRNA and surface expression of E-selectin , ICAM-1 , and VCAM-1 were noted within hours .
1,2 G#RNA|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Thus , C. pneumoniae triggers a cascade of events that could lead to endothelial activation , inflammation , and thrombosis , which in turn may result in or may promote atherosclerosis .


Transient pseudo-hypoaldosteronism following resection of the ileum : normal level of lymphocytic aldosterone receptors outside the acute phase .
11,14 G#protein

Pseudo-hypoaldosteronism ( PHA ) is due to mineralocorticoid resistance and manifests as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia with increased plasma aldosterone levels .


It may be familial or secondary to abnormal renal sodium handling .


We report the case of a 54-year-old woman with multifocal cancer of the colon , who developed PHA after subtotal colectomy , ileal resection and jejunostomy .


She was treated with 6 g of salt daily to prevent dehydration , which she stopped herself because of reduced fecal losses .


One month later she was admitted with signs of acute adrenal failure , i.e. fatigue , severe nausea , blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg , extracellular dehydration , hyponatremia ( 118 mmol/l ) ; hyperkalemia ( 7.6 mmol/l ) , increased blood urea nitrogen ( BUN ) ( 200 mg/dl ) and creatininemia ( 2.5 mg/dl ) , and decreased plasma bicarbonates level ( HCO3- : 16 mmol/l ; N : 27-30 ) .


However , the plasma cortisol was high ( 66 microg/100 ml at 10:00 h ; N : 8-15 ) and the ACTH was normal ( 13 pg/ml , N : 10-60 ) ; there was a marked increase in plasma renin activity ( &gt; 37 ng/ml/h ; N supine &lt; 3 ) , active renin ( 869 pg/ml ; N supine : 1.120 ) , aldosterone ( &gt; 2000 pg/ml ; N supine &lt; 150 ) and plasma AVP ( 20 pmol/l ; N : 0.5-2.5 ) .


The plasma ANH level was 38 pmol/l ( N supine : 5-25 ) .


A urinary steroidogram resulted in highly elevated tetrahydrocortisol ( THF : 13.3 mg/24h ; N : 1.4+/-0.8 ) with no increase in tetrahydrocortisone ( THE : 3.16 mg/24h ; N : 2.7+/-2.0 ) excretion , and with low THE/THF ( 0.24 ; N : 1.87+/-0.36 ) and alpha THF/THF ( 0.35 ; N : 0.92+/-0.42 ) ratios .


The number of mineralocorticoid receptors in mononuclear leukocytes was in the lower normal range for age , while the number of glucocorticoid receptors was reduced .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_type|6,8 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein

Small-bowel resection in ileostomized patients causes excessive fecal sodium losses and results in chronic sodium depletion with contraction of the plasma volume and severe secondary hyperaldosteronism .


Nevertheless , this hyperaldosteronism may be associated with hyponatremia and hyperkalemia suggesting PHA related to the major importance of the colon for the absorption of sodium .


In conclusion , this case report emphasizes 1 ) the possibility of a syndrome of acquired PHA with severe hyperkalemia after resection of the ileum and colon responding to oral salt supplementation ; 2 ) the major increase in AVP and the small increase in ANH ; 3 ) the strong increase in urinary THF with low THE/THF and alpha THF/THF ratios ; 4 ) the normal number of lymphocytic mineralocorticoid receptors outside the acute episode .
70,72 G#protein|69,72 G#protein

Modulation of the immune response by progesterone-induced lymphocyte factors .
6,9 G#protein

Rat spleen and peripheral blood lymphocytes express progesterone receptors whose concentration is increased greatly during the early phase of pregnancy .
3,6 G#cell_type|7,9 G#protein

After stimulation of progesterone the expression of receptors was augmented 2-3 times .


When cells were cultured in the presence of progesterone they released a soluble factor that inhibited cellular immunoreactions ( MLR , CRC ) and cellular proliferation as measured by thymidine incorporation by spleen-cell culture .
12,14 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_line

This factor also inhibited the synthesis of anti-DNP antibodies by a mouse hybridoma and diminished the proportion of cells in phase S .
7,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line

However , the percentage of asymmetric molecules produced by the hybridoma remained unaltered .
5,7 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_line

These results support the hypothesis that soluble factors released by rat lymphocytes modulate the immune response of the mother and participate in the mechanism that protects the fetus against antipaternal antibodies .
6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|29,31 G#protein

Differential regulation of 4E-BP1 and 4E-BP2 , two repressors of translation initiation , during human myeloid cell differentiation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Human myeloid differentiation is accompanied by a decrease in cell proliferation .


Because the translation rate is an important determinant of cell proliferation , we have investigated translation initiation during human myeloid cell differentiation using the HL-60 promyelocytic leukemia cell line and the U-937 monoblastic cell line .
18,21 G#cell_type|24,29 G#cell_line|31,35 G#cell_line

A decrease in the translation rate is observed when the cells are induced to differentiate along the monocytic/macrophage pathway or along the granulocytic pathway .


The inhibition in protein synthesis correlates with specific regulation of two repressors of translation initiation , 4E-BP1 and 4E-BP2 .
16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Induction of HL-60 and U-937 cell differentiation into monocytes /macrophages by IFN-gamma or PMA results in a dephosphorylation and consequent activation of 4E-BP1 .
2,3 G#cell_line|4,5 G#cell_line|8,9 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Dephosphorylation of 4E-BP1 was also observed when U-937 cells were induced to differentiate into monocytes /macrophages following treatment with retinoic acid or DMSO .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

In contrast , treatment of HL-60 cells with retinoic acid or DMSO , which results in a granulocytic differentiation of these cells , decreases 4E-BP1 amount without affecting its phosphorylation and strongly increases 4E-BP2 amount .
5,7 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Taken together , these data provide evidence for differential regulation of the translational machinery during human myeloid differentiation , specific to the monocytic/macrophage pathway or to the granulocytic pathway .


Nonimmunoglobulin gene hypermutation in germinal center B cells .
4,8 G#cell_type

Somatic hypermutation is the most critical mechanism underlying the diversification of Ig genes .
11,13 G#DNA

Although mutation occurs specifically in B cells during the germinal center reaction , it remains a matter of debate whether the mutation machinery also targets non- Ig genes .
5,7 G#cell_type|26,28 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA

We have studied mutations in the 5' noncoding region of the Bcl6 gene in different subtypes of lymphomas .
6,9 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA

We found frequent hypermutation in follicular lymphoma ( 25 of 59 = 42 % ) ( germinal center cell origin ) and mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue ( MALT ) lymphoma ( 19 of 45 = 42 % ) ( postgerminal center ) , but only occasionally in mantle cell lymphoma ( 1 of 21 = 4.8 % ) ( pregerminal center ) .


Most mutations were outside the motifs potentially important for transcription , suggesting they were not important in lymphomagenesis but may , like Ig mutation , represent an inherent feature of the lymphoma precursor cells .
31,34 G#cell_type

Therefore , we investigated their normal cell counterparts microdissected from a reactive tonsil .


Bcl6 mutation was found in 13 of 24 ( 54 % ) clones from the germinal centre but only in 1 of 24 ( 4 % ) clones from the naive B cells of the mantle zone .
31,33 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_type

The frequency , distribution , and nature of these mutations were similar to those resulting from the Ig hypermutation process .


The results show unequivocal evidence of non- Ig gene hypermutation in germinal center B cells and provide fresh insights into the process of hypermutation and lymphomagenesis .
7,9 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_type|11,15 G#cell_type

Impaired binding of a DQ2 and DQ8 -binding HSV VP16 peptide to a DQA1*0501/DQB1*0302 trans class II heterodimer .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|13,18 G#protein

DQalpha and DQbeta trans heterodimeric HLA-DQ molecules form in individuals heterozygous for the DQ2 and DQ8 specificities .
5,7 G#protein|0,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Unique functions and disease associations have been postulated for such trans-dimers , which may be different from cis-encoded DQ molecules encoded by the corresponding haplotypes .
10,11 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

We analyzed the ability of the trans-dimer encoded by HLA-DQA1*0501/DQB1*0302 to bind a peptide antigen which interacts with DQ molecules encoded by both parental haplotypes .
9,10 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Markedly impaired binding was observed , consistent with both the use of different anchor residues and with changes in levels of DQ cis- dimer availability for peptide binding interactions .
23,24 G#protein

Detection of intracellular phosphorylated STAT-1 by flow cytometry .
2,5 G#protein

We have applied flow cytometry to the investigation of interferon-gamma activation of human monocytes .
9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

This approach uses monoclonal antibodies that distinguish between the native and phosphorylated forms of STAT-1 .
3,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

It enables rapid and quantitative assessment of STAT-1 phosphorylation on a discrete cell basis and is both more sensitive and less time consuming than immunoblotting .
7,8 G#protein

Furthermore , it allows for discrimination between a mixture of cells that differ in their response to interferon-gamma .
17,18 G#protein

This approach should allow for the evaluation of different intracellular signaling pathways using a combination of monoclonal reagents that are specific for native and activation modified proteins .
24,27 G#protein

Application of this form of testing should prove valuable in screening for signaling defects in selected patients with recurrent infections .


In addition , this technique should permit dissection of a full range of cellular signaling pathways at the protein level .


Activation of nuclear factor-kappaB by lipopolysaccharide in mononuclear leukocytes is prevented by inhibitors of cytosolic phospholipase A2 .
2,4 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|14,17 G#protein

In monocytes , lipopolysaccharide induces synthesis and activity of the 85-kDa cytosolic phospholipase A2 .
1,2 G#cell_type|11,14 G#protein

This enzyme releases arachidonic acid and lyso-phospholipids from membranes which are metabolized to eicosanoids and platelet-activating-factor .


These lipid mediators increase activity of transcription factors and expression of cytokine genes indicating a function for cytosolic phospholipase A2 in signal transduction and inflammation .
6,8 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|17,20 G#protein

We have shown previously that trifluoromethylketone inhibitors of cytosolic phospholipase A2 suppressed interleukin-1beta protein and steady-state mRNA levels in human lipopolysaccharide -stimulated peripheral blood mononuclear leukocytes .
8,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|20,26 G#cell_type

In this study , the subcellular mechanisms were analyzed by which trifluoromethylketones interfere with gene expression .


We found that they reduced the initial interleukin-1beta mRNA transcription rate through prevention of degradation of inhibitor-kappaB alpha .
7,9 G#RNA|16,18 G#protein

Consequently , cytosolic activation , nuclear translocation and DNA-binding of nuclear factor-kappaB were decreased .
10,12 G#protein

Trifluoromethylketones ameliorate chronic inflammation in vivo .


Thus , this therapeutic potency may reside in retention of inactive nuclear factor-kappaB in the cytosol thereby abrogating interleukin-1beta gene transcription .
11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Cellular disposition of sulphamethoxazole and its metabolites : implications for hypersensitivity .


1. Bioactivation of sulphamethoxazole ( SMX ) to chemically-reactive metabolites and subsequent protein conjugation is thought to be involved in SMX hypersensitivity .


We have therefore examined the cellular metabolism , disposition and conjugation of SMX and its metabolites in vitro .


2. Flow cytometry revealed binding of N-hydroxy ( SMX-NHOH ) and nitroso ( SMX-NO ) metabolites of SMX , but not of SMX itself , to the surface of viable white blood cells .
30,33 G#cell_type

Cellular haptenation by SMX -NO was reduced by exogenous glutathione ( GSH ) .


3. SMX -NHOH and SMX -NO were rapidly reduced back to the parent compound by cysteine ( CYS ) , GSH , human peripheral blood cells and plasma , suggesting that this is an important and ubiquitous bioinactivation mechanism .
22,26 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein

4. Fluorescence HPLC showed that SMX -NHOH and SMX -NO depleted CYS and GSH in buffer , and to a lesser extent , in cells and plasma .


5. Neutrophil apoptosis and inhibition of neutrophil function were induced at lower concentrations of SMX -NHOH and SMX -NO than those inducing loss of membrane viability , with SMX having no effect .


Lymphocytes were significantly ( P &lt; 0.05 ) more sensitive to the direct cytotoxic effects of SMX -NO than neutrophils .
0,1 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

6. Partitioning of SMX -NHOH into red blood cells was significantly ( P &lt; 0.05 ) lower than with the hydroxylamine of dapsone .
6,9 G#cell_type

7. Our results suggest that the balance between oxidation of SMX to its toxic metabolites and their reduction is an important protective cellular mechanism .


If an imbalance exists , haptenation of the toxic metabolites to bodily proteins including the surface of viable cells can occur , and may result in drug hypersensitivity .


Bcl-6 expression in reactive follicular hyperplasia , follicular lymphoma , and angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma with hyperplastic germinal centers : heterogeneity of intrafollicular T-cells and their altered distribution in the pathogenesis of angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma .
0,1 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : The Bcl-6 gene product , a nuclear phosphoprotein , is expressed independently of Bcl-6 gene rearrangement .
3,4 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

In lymph nodes , expression of Bcl-6 protein is restricted to germinal center ( GC ) B-cells and 10 % to 15 % of CD3/CD4+ intrafollicular T cells .
6,7 G#protein|11,17 G#cell_type|24,28 G#cell_type

Interfollicular cells are negative for Bcl-6 protein , except for rare CD3+/CD4+ T cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

Recently , we reported cases of angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma ( AITL ) with hyperplastic GCs ( AITL/GC ) , and observed that borders of enlarged GCs were ill defined , with features suggestive of an outward migration of GC cells to surrounding interfollicular zones .
38,40 G#cell_type

This prompted a study of follicular borders with Bcl-6 staining in reactive follicular hyperplasias and follicular lymphomas to compare with AITL /GC .
8,9 G#protein

MATERIALS AND METHODS : Formalin-fixed paraffin sections were used for immunostaining of Bcl-6 .
12,13 G#protein

Six cases of AITL/GC , 12 nonspecific reactive follicular hyperplasia ( FH ) , 7 HIV adenopathy , 10 follicular lymphoma ( FL ) , and 8 typical AITL ( ie , AITL without GC ) were studied .


Double staining for Bcl-6 /CD20 , Bcl-6 /CD3 , and Bcl-6 /CD57 was performed in selected cases .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

RESULTS : In FH and HIV adenopathy , staining for Bcl-6 revealed densely populated GCs with well-defined and regular GC borders , whereas Bcl-6 + cells were rare in the interfollicular areas .
10,11 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,26 G#cell_type

An occasional GC with an ill-defined border was invariably surrounded by a broad mantle zone ; those with indistinct mantle zones had well-defined , regular borders .


In FL , follicles were densely populated , and their borders were irregular , with some Bcl-6 + cells in the interfollicular zones .
16,17 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

In AITL /GC , GCs were less dense , GC borders were ill defined and irregular , and the number of interfollicular Bcl-6 + cells was markedly increased .
22,23 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_type

Double staining revealed that these interfollicular Bcl-6 + cells in AITL /GC were Bcl6+/CD3+/CD20-/CD57- T cells .
6,7 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_type

Moreover , CD3+ intrafollicular T cells were depleted in AITL /GC , whereas they were abundant in FH .
2,6 G#cell_type

Intrafollicular CD57+ cells did not stain for Bcl-6 , and were also depleted in AITL /GC .
1,3 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein

In typical AITL , some neoplastic cells were positive for Bcl-6 , showing variable degrees of staining .
10,11 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : ( 1 ) GCs of AITL/GC differed from those of other reactive follicular hyperplasias and follicular lymphomas , and staining for Bcl-6 was useful to discern them .
23,24 G#protein

( 2 ) Intrafollicular CD3+ T cells , many of which were also positive for Bcl-6 , were markedly depleted in AITL /GC , with increased interfollicular Bcl-6 +/CD3+ cells , suggesting an outward migration of intrafollicular T cells in this condition .
3,7 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#cell_type|36,39 G#cell_type

( 3 ) Interfollicular Bcl-6 +/CD3+ cells in AITL/GC were too numerous to be accounted for by migration alone , suggesting local proliferation .
4,5 G#protein|3,7 G#cell_type

( 4 ) Intrafollicular CD57+ cells were negative for Bcl-6 , indicating heterogeneity of the intrafollicular T-cell population .
3,6 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type

( 5 ) Some neoplastic cells in AITL stained for Bcl-6 , suggesting up-regulation of Bcl-6 expression in this tumor .
10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Human cytomegalovirus binding to human monocytes induces immunoregulatory gene expression .
5,6 G#cell_type|4,6 G#cell_type

To continue our investigation of the cellular events that occur following human CMV ( HCMV ) infection , we focused on the regulation of cellular activation following viral binding to human monocytes .
31,32 G#cell_type|30,32 G#cell_type

First , we showed that viral binding induced a number of immunoregulatory genes ( IL-1beta , A20 , NF-kappaB-p105/p50 , and IkappaBalpha ) in unactivated monocytes and that neutralizing Abs to the major HCMV glycoproteins , gB ( UL55 ) and gH ( UL75 ) , inhibited the induction of these genes .
11,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#cell_type|28,30 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein

Next , we demonstrated that these viral ligands directly up-regulated monocyte gene expression upon their binding to their appropriate cellular receptors .


We then investigated if HCMV binding also resulted in the translation and secretion of cytokines .
14,15 G#protein

Our results showed that HCMV binding to monocytes resulted in the production and release of IL-1beta protein .
7,8 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Because these induced gene products have NF-kappaB sites in their promoter regions , we next examined whether there was an up-regulation of nuclear NF-kappaB levels .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

These experiments showed that , in fact , NF-kappaB was translocated to the nucleus following viral binding or purified viral ligand binding .
8,9 G#protein

Changes in IkappaBalpha levels correlated with the changes in NF-kappaB translocation .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Lastly , we demonstrated that p38 kinase activity played a central role in IL-1beta production and that it was rapidly up-regulated following infection .
5,6 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

These results support our hypothesis that HCMV initiates a signal transduction pathway that leads to monocyte activation and pinpoints a potential mechanism whereby HCMV infection of monocytes can result in profound pathogenesis , especially in chronic inflammatory-type conditions .
26,27 G#cell_type

Regulation of the megakaryocytic glycoprotein IX promoter by the oncogenic Ets transcription factor Fli-1 .
3,7 G#DNA|9,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Glycoprotein ( GP ) IX is a subunit of the von Willebrand receptor , GPIb- V-IX , which mediates adhesion of platelets to the subendothelium of damaged blood vessels .
0,5 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|21,22 G#cell_type

Previous characterization of the GPIX promoter identified a functional Ets site that , when disrupted , reduced promoter activity .
4,6 G#DNA

However , the Ets protein ( s ) that regulated GPIX promoter expression was unknown .
3,5 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

In this study , transient cotransfection of several GPIX promoter /reporter constructs into 293T kidney fibroblasts with a Fli-1 expression vector shows that the oncogenic protein Fli-1 can transactivate the GPIX promoter when an intact GPIX Ets site is present .
8,10 G#DNA|8,12 G#DNA|13,16 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|30,32 G#DNA|35,38 G#DNA

In addition , Fli-1 binding of the GPIX Ets site was identified in antibody supershift experiments in nuclear extracts derived from hematopoietic human erythroleukemia cells .
3,4 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|21,25 G#cell_type

Comparative studies showed that Fli-1 was also able to transactivate the GPIbalpha and , to a lesser extent , the GPIIb promoter .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

Immunoblot analysis identified Fli-1 protein in lysates derived from platelets .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type

In addition , expression of Fli-1 was identified immunohistochemically in megakaryocytes derived from CD34(+) cells treated with the megakaryocyte differentiation and proliferation factor , thrombopoietin .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type|18,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

These results suggest that Fli-1 is likely to regulate lineage-specific genes during megakaryocytopoiesis .
4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA

Expression of IkappaBalpha in the nucleus of human peripheral blood T lymphocytes .
2,3 G#protein|7,12 G#cell_type

According to current models the inhibitory capacity of I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) would be mediated through the retention of Rel/NF-kappaB proteins in the cytosol .
8,16 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type

However , I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) has also been detected in the nucleus of cell lines and when overexpressed by transient transfection .
2,10 G#protein

To gain better insight into the potential role of nuclear I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) in a physiological context we have analysed its presence in the nucleus of human peripheral blood T lymphocytes ( PBL ) .
10,18 G#protein|9,18 G#protein|31,36 G#cell_type|37,38 G#cell_type

We demonstrate the nuclear localization of I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) in PBL by different techniques : Western blot , indirect immunofluorescence and electron microscopy .
6,14 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

Low levels of nuclear I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) were detected in resting cells whereas a superinduction was obtained after PMA activation .
4,12 G#protein

The nuclear pool of I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) showed a higher stability than cytosolic I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) and was partially independent of the resynthesis of the protein .
4,12 G#protein|18,26 G#protein

Unexpectedly , the presence of nuclear I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) did not inhibit NF-kappaB binding to DNA and this phenomenon was not due to the presence of IkappaBbeta at the nuclear level .
6,14 G#protein|5,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Immunoprecipitation experiments failed to demonstrate an association between nuclear I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) and NF-kappaB proteins .
9,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Our results demonstrate that in resting and PMA-activated human PBL , I ( kappa ) B ( alpha ) is present in the nucleus in an apparently inactive form unable to disrupt NF-kappaB binding from DNA .
9,10 G#cell_type|7,10 G#cell_type|11,19 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|35,36 G#DNA

Impaired fetal thymocyte development after efficient adenovirus -mediated inhibition of NF-kappa B activation .
1,3 G#cell_type|10,12 G#protein

We introduce a new experimental system combining adenovirus -mediated gene transfer and fetal thymic organ culture ( FTOC ) .


This system allowed us to efficiently express in developing thymocytes a mutant form of the NF-kappa B inhibitor I kappa B alpha ( mut-I kappa B ) and to study the maturation defects occurring when NF-kappa B activation is inhibited during fetal development .
15,17 G#protein|18,22 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

Fetal thymocytes infected with adenovirus containing mut-I kappa B were found to develop normally until the CD44 -CD25+ , CD4 - CD8 - double-negative stage , while production of more mature double-positive and single-positive populations was strongly decreased .
0,2 G#cell_type|6,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Proliferation , as measured by the percentage of cells in cycle appeared normal , as did rearrangement and expression of the TCR beta-chain .
21,23 G#protein

However , apoptosis was much higher in FTOC infected with adenovirus containing mut-I kappa B than in FTOC infected with a control virus .
12,15 G#protein

Taken together , these results suggest that NF-kappa B plays a crucial role in ensuring the differentiation and survival of thymocytes in the early stages of their development .
7,9 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type

The relationship between Ca2+-ATPase and freely exchangeable Ca2+ in the dense tubules : a study in platelets from women .
3,4 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type

The main aims of this work were to examine in women : the relationship between the freely exchangeable Ca2+ ( FECa2+ ) in the dense tubules and the activity of the sarco ( endo ) plasmic reticulum ( SER ) Ca2+-ATPase ( SERCA ) in platelets , and the relationship of these parameters with blood pressure and serum lipoproteins .
