40,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|31,44 G#protein|45,46 G#cell_type|57,59 G#protein

Platelets from 14 white and 13 black women in good health were studied .


The FECa2+ was measured as the ionomycin-evoked Ca2+ release ( in the presence of thapsigargin ) in Ca2+ - free medium .


SERCA activity was measured as the thapsigargin sensitive , Ca2+ dependent and ouabain resistant , ATP hydrolyses in platelet membranes .
0,1 G#protein

Relative expressions of SERCA 2 and 3 isoforms and Ras-related protein ( Rap ) 1 in platelet membranes were determined by Western immunoblots .
3,4 G#protein|9,15 G#protein

Highly significant correlations were observed for FECa2+ in the dense tubules with : 1 ) the maximal reaction velocity ( Vmax ) of the SERCA ( r = 0.592 , P = .0014 ) , and 2 ) Rapl ( r = 0.551 , P = .0035 ) .
24,25 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

In addition , negative correlations were observed between FECa2+ in the dense tubules and age .


No correlations were observed for these variables with blood pressure or serum lipoproteins .
11,13 G#protein

We conclude the FECa2+ and the Vmax of the SERCA are reliable indicators of Ca2+ load in platelets from women .
9,10 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

However , in women , unlike previous observations in men , these platelet parameters are not correlated with blood pressure and serum lipoproteins .
21,23 G#protein

Cobalt chloride -induced signaling in endothelium leading to the augmented adherence of sickle red blood cells and transendothelial migration of monocyte-like HL-60 cells is blocked by PAF-receptor antagonist .
13,16 G#cell_type|12,16 G#cell_type|20,23 G#cell_line

In response to hypoxia , sickle red blood cells ( SS RBC ) and leukocytes exhibit increased adherence to the vascular endothelium , while diapedesis of leukocytes through the blood vessel increases .
5,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type

However , the cellular signaling pathway ( s ) caused by hypoxia is poorly understood .


We utilized CoCl2 as a mimetic molecule for hypoxia to study cellular signaling pathways .


We found that in human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVEC ) , CoCl2 at 2 mM concentration induced the surface expression of a subset of CAMs ( VCAM-1 ) and activation of transcription factor NF-kappaB in the nuclear extracts of HUVEC .
4,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|41,42 G#cell_type

Furthermore , CoCl2 also caused time-dependent tyrosine phosphorylation of mitogen-activated protein ( MAP ) kinase isoform ERK2 without significantly affecting ERK1 , indicating ERK2 is the preferred substrate for upstream kinase of the MAPK pathway .
9,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Inhibitors of MAP kinase ( PD98059 ) or platelet-activating factor ( PAF ) -Â receptor antagonist ( CV3988 ) inhibited the CoCl2 -induced NF-kappaB activation and VCAM-1 expression .
2,4 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Augmented expression of VCAM-1 led to increased SS RBC adhesion , inhibitable by a VCAM-1 antibody .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Additionally , CoCl2 caused a two- to threefold increase in the rate of transendothelial migration of monocyte-like HL-60 cells and a twentyfold increase in phosphorylation of platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecules ( PECAM-1 ) .
16,19 G#cell_line|27,31 G#protein|26,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

The transendothelial migration of monocytes was inhibited by an antibody to PECAM-1 .
4,5 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein

Both phosphorylation of PECAM-1 and transendothelial migration of monocytes in response to CoCl2 were inhibited by protein kinase inhibitor ( GF109203X ) and augmented by protein phosphatase inhibitor ( Calyculin A ) .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type

Our data suggests that CoCl2 -induced cellular signals directing increased expression of VCAM-1 in HUVEC involve downstream activation of MAP kinase and NF-kappaB , while the phosphorylation of PECAM-1 occurs as a result of activation of PKC .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

We conclude that PAF-receptor antagonist inhibits the CoCl2 - or hypoxia -induced increase in the adhesion of SS RBC , PECAM-1 phosphorylation , and the concomitant transendothelial migration of monocytes .
17,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

Bacterial lipopolysaccharide activates nuclear factor-kappaB through interleukin-1 signaling mediators in cultured human dermal endothelial cells and mononuclear phagocytes .
3,5 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|10,15 G#cell_line|16,18 G#cell_type

Bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) -mediated immune responses , including activation of monocytes , macrophages , and endothelial cells , play an important role in the pathogenesis of Gram-negative bacteria -induced sepsis syndrome .
12,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

Activation of NF-kappaB is thought to be required for cytokine release from LPS-responsive cells , a critical step for endotoxic effects .
2,3 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type

Here we investigated the role and involvement of interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) and tumor necrosis factor ( TNF-alpha ) signal transducer molecules in LPS signaling in human dermal microvessel endothelial cells ( HDMEC ) and THP-1 monocytic cells .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type|26,31 G#cell_type|32,33 G#cell_type|35,38 G#cell_line

LPS stimulation of HDMEC and THP-1 cells initiated an IL-1 receptor -like NF-kappaB signaling cascade .
3,4 G#cell_type|5,7 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In transient cotransfection experiments , dominant negative mutants of the IL-1 signaling pathway , including MyD88 , IRAK , IRAK2 , and TRAF6 inhibited both IL-1 - and LPS -induced NF-kappaB -luciferase activity .
10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

LPS -induced NF-kappaB activation was not inhibited by a dominant negative mutant of TRAF2 that is involved in TNF signaling .
2,3 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

LPS -induced activation of NF-kappaB -responsive reporter gene was not inhibited by IL-1 receptor antagonist .
4,5 G#protein|4,8 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein

TLR2 and TLR4 were expressed on the cell surface of HDMEC and THP-1 cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|12,14 G#cell_line

These findings suggest that a signal transduction molecule in the LPS receptor complex may belong to the IL-1 receptor/toll-like receptor ( TLR ) super family , and the LPS signaling cascade uses an analogous molecular framework for signaling as IL-1 in mononuclear phagocytes and endothelial cells .
5,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|41,43 G#cell_type|44,46 G#cell_type

Signal transduction through interferon-gamma receptor on human eosinophils .
3,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : We reported on the constitutive interferon-gamma receptor ( IFN-gammaR ) expression on eosinophils .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type

But signal transduction through IFN-gammaR on eosinophils remains to be elucidated .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type

In this study , we examined the involvement of the Jak/Stat pathway in the signaling of eosinophils after IFN-gammaR conjugation by the ligand binding .
10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

METHODS : Purified peripheral eosinophils were stimulated with IFN-gamma at 37 degrees C for 1-60 min .
4,5 G#cell_type|2,5 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein

Tyrosine phosphorylation of IFN-gammaR , Jak1 , Jak2 , and Stat1alpha was examined by immunoblotting .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Gel-shift assay was also examined to show the formation of Stat1alpha -DNA complexes .
10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein

RESULTS : We show that binding of IFN-gamma to human eosinophils initiated a series of events that resulted in the rapid tyrosine phosphorylation of not only the IFN-gammaRalpha chain but also Jak1 , Jak2 , and Stat1alpha .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|27,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

In addition , IFN-gamma enhanced the DNA-binding activity of Stat1alpha .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

CONCLUSION : These data indicate that IFN-gamma affects eosinophils through its specific receptor and utilizes the Jak/Stat pathway as its mode of signaling .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

Expression of E2A-HLF chimeric protein induced T-cell apoptosis , B-cell maturation arrest , and development of acute lymphoblastic leukemia .
2,5 G#protein

The E2A-HLF fusion gene , generated by t(17;19)(q22;p13) in acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( ALL ) , encodes a chimeric transcription factor in which the trans-activating domains of E2A are fused to the DNA- binding and dimerization domains of hepatic leukemic factor ( HLF ) .
1,4 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|18,21 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|32,37 G#protein|38,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

To investigate its biological role , we generated transgenic mice expressing E2A-HLF using Ig enhancer and promoter , which direct transgene expression in cells committed to the lymphoid lineage .
11,12 G#protein|13,17 G#DNA

The transgenic mice exhibited abnormal development in the thymus and spleen and were susceptible to infection .


The thymus contained small numbers of thymocytes , and TUNEL staining showed that higher population of thymocytes were undergoing apoptosis .
6,7 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type

The spleen exhibited a marked reduction in splenic lymphocytes and the flow cytometric analyses and the in vitro colony formation assays showed that the B-cell maturation was blocked at a very early developmental stage .
7,9 G#cell_type

These findings indicated that the expression of E2A-HLF induced T-cell apoptosis and B-cell maturation arrest in vivo and that the susceptibility of the transgenic mice to infection was due to immunodeficiency .
7,8 G#protein

Moreover , several transgenic mice developed acute leukemia , classified as T- ALL based on the surface marker analysis and DNA rearrangements , suggesting that an additional event is required for malignant transformation of lymphoid cells expressing E2A-HLF .
34,36 G#cell_type|37,38 G#protein

Our findings provide insight into the biological function of E2A-HLF in lymphoid development and also its role in leukemogenesis .
9,10 G#protein

Retinoid X receptor ( RXR ) agonist-induced activation of dominant-negative RXR -retinoic acid receptor alpha403 heterodimers is developmentally regulated during myeloid differentiation .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

The multiple biologic activities of retinoic acid ( RA ) are mediated through RAR and retinoid X receptor ( RXR ) nuclear receptors that interact with specific DNA target sequences as heterodimers ( RXR-RAR ) or homodimers ( RXR-RXR ) .
13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|15,23 G#protein|27,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

RA receptor activation appears critical to regulating important aspects of hematopoiesis , since transducing a COOH-terminally truncated RARalpha exhibiting dominant-negative activity ( RARalpha403 ) into normal mouse bone marrow generates hematopoietic growth factor-dependent cell lines frozen at the multipotent progenitor ( EML ) or committed promyelocyte ( MPRO ) stages .
15,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,35 G#cell_line

Nevertheless , relatively high , pharmacological concentrations of RA ( 1 to 10 &amp; mgr ; M ) overcome these differentiation blocks and induce terminal granulocytic differentiation of the MPRO promyelocytes while potentiating interleukin-3 ( IL-3 ) -induced commitment of EML cells to the granulocyte/monocyte lineage .
29,31 G#cell_type|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|40,42 G#cell_type

In the present study , we utilized RXR - and RAR -specific agonists and antagonists to determine how RA overcomes the dominant-negative activity of the truncated RARalpha in these different myeloid developmental stages .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Unexpectedly , we observed that an RXR -specific , rather than an RAR -specific , agonist induces terminal granulocytic differentiation of MPRO promyelocytes , and this differentiation is associated with activation of DNA response elements corresponding to RAR-RXR heterodimers rather than RXR-RXR homodimers .
6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|32,35 G#DNA|37,39 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|41,43 G#protein

This RXR agonist activity is blocked by RAR -specific antagonists , suggesting extensive cross-talk between the partners of the RXR -RARalpha403 heterodimer .
1,2 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

In contrast , in the more immature , multipotent EML cells we observed that this RXR -specific agonist is inactive either in potentiating IL-3 -mediated commitment of EML cells to the granulocyte lineage or in transactivating RAR-RXR response elements .
9,11 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|31,33 G#cell_type|36,39 G#DNA

RA -triggered GALdbd- RARalpha hybrid activity in these cells indicates that the multipotent EML cells harbor substantial nuclear hormone receptor coactivator activity .
3,4 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein

However , the histone deacetylase ( HDAC ) inhibitor trichostatin A readily activates an RXR-RAR reporter construct in the multipotent EML cells but not in the committed MPRO promyelocytes , indicating that differences in HDAC-containing repressor complexes in these two closely related but distinct hematopoietic lineages might account for the differential activation of the RXR-RARalpha403 heterodimers that we observed at these different stages of myeloid development .
3,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type|27,29 G#cell_type|34,37 G#protein|44,46 G#cell_type|54,56 G#protein

The functional synergy between IL-12 and IL-2 involves p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and is associated with the augmentation of STAT serine phosphorylation .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,12 G#protein

IL-12 and IL-2 can stimulate mitogen- or CD3- activated T cells to proliferate , produce IFN-gamma , and kill tumor cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,11 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

The magnitude of these functional responses is greatly augmented when T cells are activated by the combination of IL-12 and IL-2 .
10,12 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Although peripheral blood T cells are largely unresponsive to these cytokines without prior activation , a small subset of CD8+ T cells ( CD8+CD18bright ) is strongly activated by the combination of IL-12 and IL-2 .
3,5 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

In this report we show that the functional synergy between IL-12 and IL-2 in CD8+CD18bright T cells correlates with the activation of the stress kinases , p38 mitogen-activated protein ( MAP ) kinase and stress-activated protein kinase ( SAPK ) /Jun N-terminal kinase , but not with the activation of the extracellular signal-regulated kinases .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|23,25 G#protein|26,33 G#protein|34,43 G#protein|51,54 G#protein

The functional synergy between IL-2 and IL-12 is also associated with a prominent increase in STAT1 and STAT3 serine phosphorylation over that observed with IL-12 or IL-2 alone .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

By contrast , STAT tyrosine phosphorylation is not augmented over that seen with either cytokine alone .
3,4 G#protein

A specific inhibitor of p38 MAP kinase completely inhibits the serine phosphorylation of STAT1 and STAT3 induced by IL-12 and IL-2 and abrogates the functional synergy between IL-12 and IL-2 without affecting STAT tyrosine phosphorylation .
13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

This suggests that p38 MAP kinase may play an important role in regulating STAT serine phosphorylation in response to the combination of IL-12 and IL-2 .
22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Furthermore , these findings indicate that the optimal activation of T cells by IL-12 and IL-2 may depend on an interaction between the p38 MAP kinase and Janus kinase/STAT signaling pathways .
10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Activation of NF-kappaB in Mycobacterium tuberculosis -induced interleukin-2 receptor expression in mononuclear phagocytes .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Soluble interleukin-2 receptor -alpha ( IL-2Ralpha ) has been reported to be increased in the sera of patients with advanced tuberculosis , and levels decline after therapy in accordance with improvement of radiologic findings .
1,3 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

We investigated expression of the IL-2Ralpha in bronchoalveolar lavage ( BAL ) cells in active pulmonary tuberculosis , and evaluated the mechanism Mycobacterium tuberculosis induces in the IL-2Ralpha using the THP-1 mononuclear phagocyte cell line .
5,6 G#protein|7,13 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_line|30,35 G#cell_line

We found IL-2Ralpha expression to be increased in BAL cells from involved sites of active pulmonary tuberculosis .
2,3 G#protein

Expression of the alpha-chain of IL-2Ralpha on peripheral blood monocytes ( PBM ) was induced by M. tuberculosis by flow cytometry evaluation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#cell_type

Northern analysis demonstrated increased IL-2Ralpha gene expression after stimulation with M. tuberculosis which was further induced by interferon-gamma ( IFN-gamma ) .
4,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The IL-2Ralpha promoter containing the nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappaB ) site was transcriptionally induced by M. tuberculosis and this NF-kappaB site could confer inducibility to a heterologous herpes thymidine kinase ( TK ) promoter by M. tuberculosis .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|5,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|5,13 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|28,36 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSAs ) revealed specific binding of nuclear protein to the NF-kappaB site upon induction with M. tuberculosis .
15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

Using antibodies against the p50 and p65 subunits of NF-kappaB in EMSAs , the involvement of both p50 and p65 proteins was further demonstrated .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Functional expression of the IL-2Ralpha on mononuclear phagocytes in M. tuberculosis infection may play an important immunomodulatory role in the host response .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

Vitamin D receptor 3'-untranslated region polymorphisms : lack of effect on mRNA stability .
0,3 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA

Allelic variation at the 3'-end of the vitamin D receptor ( VDR ) gene has been associated with a 3-5-fold increased risk of developing prostate cancer and with differences in bone mineralization .
7,14 G#DNA

This genetic diversity does not alter the VDR protein structurally , but instead may be a marker ( s ) of other , nearby polymorphisms that influence message stability or translation .
7,9 G#protein

The work reported here was instigated to identify additional VDR 3'-UTR polymorphisms that may have functional significance and to then test whether these genetic variants alter message stability .
9,10 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA

Initially , four novel , frequently occurring sequence variants were identified that associated with two common haplotypes that were described previously .
7,9 G#DNA

These common sequence variants were not found within three message-destabilizing elements that we mapped within the 3'-UTR of the vitamin D receptor mRNA .
9,11 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|19,23 G#RNA

Furthermore , the two VDR 3'-UTR haplotypes conferred an identical half-life on a heterologous beta-globin reporter gene , in an in vitro assay .
4,6 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA

We therefore conclude that common polymorphisms within the VDR 3'-UTR do not influence message stability .
8,10 G#DNA

IL-2 -mediated cell cycle progression and inhibition of apoptosis does not require NF-kappa B or activating protein-1 activation in primary human T cells .
0,1 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

The IL-2 growth hormone is the major growth factor of activated T lymphocytes during a developing immune response .
1,2 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

IL-2 is required not only for cell cycle progression but also to protect Ag-activated T cells from programmed cell death .
0,1 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_type

In several cell types , activation of NF-kappa B and/or activating protein-1 ( AP-1 ) has been demonstrated to be extremely important in blocking apoptosis .
7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

To determine whether either or both of these transcription factors are involved in cell survival or cell cycle progression in response to IL-2 , primary human T cells responsive to the growth factor were analyzed for NF-kappa B and AP-1 activation .
8,10 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,28 G#cell_type

The current study clearly demonstrates that IL-2 does not induce I kappa B alpha degradation or NF-kappa B activation in primary human T cells that respond to IL-2 by entering the cell cycle and avoiding apoptosis .
6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein

Similarly , IL-2 neither activates JNK nor increases AP-1 binding activity to a consensus o-tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate ( TPA ) response element .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,21 G#DNA

On the other hand , the growth factor does induce the activation of STAT3 and STAT5 in these cells , as has been previously demonstrated .
6,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

These data show that neither NF-kappa B nor AP-1 activation is required for IL-2 -mediated survival or cell cycle progression in activated primary human T cells .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,26 G#cell_type

Estrone potentiates myeloid cell differentiation : a role for 17 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase in modulating hemopoiesis .
9,12 G#protein

Hormones such as 1 alpha,Â 25-dihydroxy vitamin D3 ( D3 ) , all-trans retinoic acid , and 9-cis retinoic acid stimulate differentiation of myeloid progenitor cells via their interaction with specific hormone receptors .
22,25 G#cell_type|30,32 G#protein

However , the sensitivity of cells to these agents is not merely governed by the expression of their receptors and the availability of ligand to bind them .


Recent studies from our group suggested that the actions of D3 and retinoids on myelopoiesis also are influenced by endogenous mechanisms involving other steroid hormones .


In this study we examined the influence of local estrogen metabolism on the differentiation of HL60 cells and normal primitive myeloid progenitor cells .
15,17 G#cell_line|20,23 G#cell_type

Quantitative thin-layer chromatography ( TLC ) analyses showed that HL60 and normal cells are able to generate estrone ( E1 ) from estradiol ( E2 ) .
9,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_type

Neither cell population generated significant amounts of E2 from E1 .


Reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction and Northern analyses confirmed that normal and leukemic myeloid progenitor cells expressed mRNA for the type I and IV isoforms of 17 beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase .
13,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#RNA|26,29 G#protein

Conversion of E2 to E1 was upregulated within 24 hours when HL60 cells were treated with either all-trans retinoic acid or D3 at doses that induce their differentiation toward neutrophils or monocytes , respectively .
11,13 G#cell_line|29,30 G#cell_type|31,32 G#cell_type

Similarly , D3 -induced monocyte differentiation of normal myeloid progenitor cells was associated with increased capacity to generate E1 from E2 .
8,11 G#cell_type

When HL60 cells or normal myeloid progenitor cells were exposed to exogenous E1 they became more sensitive to the differentiation-inducing effects of D3 .
1,3 G#cell_line|5,8 G#cell_type

Data presented provide further evidence for the local modulation of myelopoiesis by intracrine mechanisms .


In particular , our findings suggest that local metabolism of steroids by normal as well as leukemic myeloid cells influences their responsiveness to D3 and retinoids .
16,19 G#cell_type

Phosphorylation of TRAF2 inhibits binding to the CD40 cytoplasmic domain .
2,3 G#protein|7,10 G#protein

TRAF2 is a signal transducing adaptor molecule which binds to the CD40 cytoplasmic domain .
0,1 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

We have found that it is phosphorylated , predominantly on serine residues , when transiently overexpressed in 293 cells .
17,19 G#cell_line

The phosphorylation appears to be related to the signaling events that are activated by TRAF2 under these circumstances , since two nonfunctional mutants were found to be phosphorylated significantly less than the wild-type protein .
14,15 G#protein|32,34 G#protein

Furthermore , the phosphorylation status of TRAF2 had significant effects on the ability of the protein to bind to CD40 , as evidenced by our observations that the CD40 cytoplasmic domain interacted preferentially with underphosphorylated TRAF2 and that phosphatase treatment significantly enhanced the binding of TRAF2 to CD40 .
6,7 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

We conclude from these studies that the phosphorylation of TRAF2 is likely to play an important role in regulating signaling by virtue of its ability to influence the CD40 -TRAF2 interaction .
9,10 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


A direct interaction between the adaptor protein Cbl-b and the kinase zap-70 induces a positive signal in T cells .
5,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type

Engagement of the T-cell receptor ( TCR ) -CD3 complex induces a rapid increase in the activities of Src-family and Syk/Zap-70-family kinases [ 1 ] [ 2 ] .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|3,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

These activated kinases then induce the tyrosine phosphorylation of multiple intracellular proteins , eventually leading to T-cell activation .
1,3 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

One of the prominent substrates for these kinases is the adaptor protein Cbl [ 3 ] and recent studies suggest that Cbl negatively regulates upstream kinases such as Syk and Zap-70 [ 4 ] [ 5 ] .
7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Cbl-b , a homologue of Cbl , is widely expressed in many tissues and cells including hematopoietic cells [ 6 ] [ 7 ] .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

Cbl-b undergoes rapid tyrosine phosphorylation upon stimulation of the TCR and cytokine receptors [ 8 ] [ 9 ] .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

The role of Cbl-b is unclear , however .
3,4 G#protein

Here , we show that overexpression of Cbl-b in T cells induced the constitutive activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) .
7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|17,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

A loss-of-function mutation in Cbl-b disrupted the interaction between Cbl-b and Zap-70 and nearly completely abrogated the Cbl-b -mediated activation of NFAT .
4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Unlike the proposed role of Cbl as a negative regulator , our results suggest that the Cbl homologue Cbl -b has a positive role in T-cell signaling , most likely via a direct interaction with the upstream kinase Zap-70 .
5,6 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Grf40 , A novel Grb2 family member , is involved in T cell signaling through interaction with SLP-76 and LAT .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

We molecularly cloned a new Grb2 family member , named Grf40 , containing the common SH3-SH2-SH3 motif .
5,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Expression of Grf40 is predominant in hematopoietic cells , particularly T cells .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type

Grf40 binds to the SH2 domain -containing leukocyte protein of 76 kD ( SLP-76 ) via its SH3 domain more tightly than Grb2 .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|4,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Incidentally , Grf40 binds to linker for activation of T cells ( LAT ) possibly via its SH2 domain .
2,3 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|5,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Overexpression of wild-type Grf40 in Jurkat cells induced a significant increase of SLP-76 -dependent interleukin ( IL ) -2 promoter and nuclear factor of activated T cell ( NF-AT ) activation upon T cell receptor ( TCR ) stimulation , whereas the COOH-terminal SH3-deleted Grf40 mutant lacked any recognizable increase in IL-2 promoter activity .
3,4 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|12,20 G#DNA|21,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|32,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|42,46 G#protein|51,52 G#protein|51,53 G#DNA

Furthermore , the SH2-deleted Grf40 mutant led to a marked inhibition of these regulatory activities , the effect of which is apparently stronger than that of the SH2-deleted Grb2 mutant .
4,5 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|27,30 G#protein

Our data suggest that Grf40 is an adaptor molecule involved in TCR -mediated signaling through a more efficient interaction than Grb2 with SLP-76 and LAT .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Modulation of the immune response and tumor growth by activated Ras .
10,11 G#protein

As a result of its transforming abilities , activated Ras is expressed in a great number of cancers .
8,10 G#protein

The ras mutation frequency varies between 95 % in pancreatic cancer and 5 % in breast cancer .


In leukemia , the highest frequency ( 30 % ) is found in acute myeloid leukemia .


The presence of ras mutations has been correlated with a poor prognosis and negative clinical outcome .


This suggests that mutated Ras activates mechanisms , which favor tumor growth , enhance the metastatic capacity of tumors or modulate tumor-specific immune responses .
3,5 G#protein

Several new functions of Ras , such as downregulation of major histocompatibility complex molecules , upregulation of certain cytokines , growth factors and degradative enzymes have been uncovered in the last decade .
4,5 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Additionally , mutated Ras can also serve as a primary target for the development of immunotherapy or drug therapy .
2,4 G#protein

This review will discuss the mechanisms by which Ras expressing tumors are able to evade destruction by the immune system and enhance their growth and metastatic potential .
8,9 G#protein

It will further elaborate on the attempts to develop successful immunotherapy and drug therapy targeting Ras expressing tumors .
15,16 G#protein

Modulation of E2F complexes during G0 to S phase transition in human primary B-lymphocytes .
2,4 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

The pocket protein- E2F complexes are convergence points for cell cycle signaling .
3,5 G#protein|1,5 G#protein

In the present report , we identified and monitored the pocket protein- E2F complexes in human primary B-lymphocytes after activation by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate .
12,14 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type

Consistent with previous data from human and mouse fibroblasts and T-lymphocytes , E2F4 and DP1 form the predominant E2F heterodimers both in G0 and G1 phases of the human B-lymphocyte cell cycle , whereas E2F 1 and -3 are first detected in late G1 , and their expression levels increase towards S phase .
5,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|34,38 G#protein

Intriguingly , the major E2F complex that we detected in quiescent human B-lymphocytes is consisted of pRB , E2F4 , and DP1 .
3,6 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Though the levels of DP 1 and -2 increase when cells progress from G0 to S , the proportion of DP1 to DP2 remains relatively constant during the cell cycle .
4,8 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We also observed an increase in electrophoretic mobility of the predominant E2F components , DP1 and E2F4 , as B-lymphocytes progressed from G0 into early G1 .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

This increase in mobility was attributable to dephosphorylation , as lambda phosphatase treatment could convert the slower migrating forms into the corresponding faster mobility forms .
16,19 G#protein|21,25 G#protein

We further demonstrated that this change in phosphorylation status correlates with a decrease in DNA binding activity .


This modulation of DNA binding activity mediated through the dephosphorylation of DP1 and E2F4 could help to explain the lack of in vivo DNA footprinting in late G1 and S phases of gene promoters negatively regulated through E2F sites and suggests a novel mechanism for controlling E2F transcriptional activity during the transition from quiescence to proliferation .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|32,34 G#DNA|37,39 G#DNA|46,47 G#protein

Engagement of natural cytotoxicity programs regulates AP-1 expression in the NKL human NK cell line .
6,7 G#protein|10,15 G#cell_line

NK cell cytotoxicity is a fast and efficient mechanism of target cell lysis .


Using transcription analysis , such as multiplex messenger assays , we show here that natural cytotoxicity exerted by the human NKL cell line correlates with mRNA accumulation of very early activator protein ( AP ) -1 transcription factor genes such as JunB , FosB and c-Fos .
19,23 G#cell_line|28,36 G#protein|36,39 G#DNA|41,42 G#DNA|43,44 G#DNA|45,46 G#DNA

In addition , DNA-binding activities of Jun-Fos heterodimers were observed by electrophoretic mobility shift assays during the course of natural cytotoxicity .
6,8 G#protein

Interaction between immunoglobulin-like transcript-2/leukocyte Ig-like receptor 1 on NKL cells and HLA-B27 on target cells leads to an impairment of NKL natural cytotoxicity , which correlates with an absence of JunB , FosB , and c-Fos transcription , as well as an absence of their DNA-binding activity .
2,7 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|45,47 G#protein

Our studies thus indicate that , despite the rapidity of NK cell-mediated lysis , AP-1 transcription factor is activated during the early stage of NK cell cytolytic programs and that engagement of NK cell inhibitory receptors for MHC class I molecules impairs the very early activation of AP-1 .
14,17 G#protein|32,36 G#protein|37,41 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

Evidence for a polyclonal etiology of palmar fibromatosis .


X chromosome inactivation patterns at the androgen receptor locus were evaluated to determine clonality in microdissected lesional tissue and in leukocytes from 2 women with Dupuytren 's disease .
0,2 G#DNA|20,21 G#cell_type

The tissue from both patients generated a polyclonal pattern of X chromosome inactivation of the human androgen receptor gene .
10,12 G#DNA|15,19 G#DNA

This finding supports a polyclonal reactive process as the underlying etiology for palmar fibromatosis .


Inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2 expression by 4-trifluoromethyl derivatives of salicylate , triflusal , and its deacetylated metabolite , 2-hydroxy-4-trifluoromethylbenzoic acid .
2,3 G#protein

The therapeutic potential of drugs that block the induction of cyclooxygenase-2 has been emphasized .
10,11 G#protein

When two 4-trifluoromethyl salicylate derivatives [ 2-acetoxy-4-trifluoromethyl-benzoic acid ( triflusal ) and its deacetylated metabolite 2-hydroxy-4-trifluoromethylbenzoic acid ( HTB ) ] were compared with aspirin and sodium salicylate as cyclooxygenase-2 ( COX-2 ) inhibitors , we observed that in bacterial lipopolysaccharide-activated human blood , triflusal , aspirin , and HTB , but not sodium salicylate , inhibited COX-2-mediated prostaglandin E2 ( PGE2 ) production ( IC50 = 0.16 , 0.18 , 0.39 , and &gt; 10 mM , respectively ) .
29,30 G#protein

However , only triflusal and aspirin inhibited purified COX-2 enzyme .
7,10 G#protein

To test this apparent discrepancy , we realized that HTB and triflusal ( but neither aspirin nor salicylate ) produced a concentration-dependent inhibition of COX-2 protein expression in peripheral human mononuclear cells .
24,25 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_type

This observation was further confirmed in a rat air pouch model in vivo , in which both aspirin and triflusal inhibited PGE2 production ( ID50 = 18.9 and 11.4 mg/kg p.o. , respectively ) but only triflusal -treated animals showed a decrease in COX-2 expression .
43,44 G#protein

This different behavior may be , at least in part , due to the ability of HTB and triflusal to block the activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor-kappaB to a higher extent than aspirin and sodium salicylate .
27,29 G#protein

Thus , in addition to inhibiting the COX-2 activity at therapeutic concentrations , triflusal is able to block through its metabolite HTB the expression of new enzyme , and hence the resumption of PGE2 synthesis .


Triflusal and HTB may exert beneficial effects in processes in which de novo COX-2 expression is involved and , in a broader sense , in pathological situations in which genes under nuclear factor-kappaB control are up-regulated .
13,14 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

Evidence for distinct intracellular signaling pathways in CD34+ progenitor to dendritic cell differentiation from a human cell line model .
7,9 G#cell_type

Intracellular signals that mediate differentiation of pluripotent hemopoietic progenitors to dendritic cells ( DC ) are largely undefined .
6,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

We have previously shown that protein kinase C ( PKC ) activation ( with phorbol ester ( PMA ) alone ) specifically induces differentiation of primary human CD34+ hemopoietic progenitor cells ( HPC ) to mature DC .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|25,31 G#cell_line|32,33 G#cell_line|35,37 G#cell_type

We now find that cytokine-driven ( granulocyte-macrophage CSF and TNF-alpha ) CD34+ HPC --&gt; DC differentiation is preferentially blocked by inhibitors of PKC activation .
12,13 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein

To further identify intracellular signals and downstream events important in CD34+ HPC --&gt; DC differentiation we have characterized a human leukemic cell line model of this process .
10,12 G#cell_line|13,14 G#cell_type

The CD34+ myelomonocytic cell line KG1 differentiates into dendritic-like cells in response to granulocyte-macrophage CSF plus TNF-alpha , or PMA ( with or without the calcium ionophore ionomycin , or TNF-alpha ) , with different stimuli mediating different aspects of the process .
1,5 G#cell_line|5,6 G#cell_line|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Phenotypic DC characteristics of KG1 dendritic-like cells include morphology ( loosely adherent cells with long neurite processes ) , MHC I+/ MHC IIbright/CD83+/CD86+/ CD14 - surface Ag expression , and RelB and DC -CK1 gene expression .
1,2 G#cell_type|4,7 G#cell_line|10,13 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#cell_type

Functional DC characteristics include fluid phase macromolecule uptake ( FITC-dextran ) and activation of resting T cells .
1,2 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_type

Comparison of KG1 to the PMA -unresponsive subline KG1a reveals differences in expression of TNF receptors 1 and 2 ; PKC isoforms alpha , beta I , beta II , and mu ; and RelB , suggesting that these components/pathways are important for DC differentiation .
2,3 G#cell_line|5,9 G#cell_line|14,19 G#protein|20,32 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|43,44 G#cell_type

Together , these findings demonstrate that cytokine or phorbol ester stimulation of KG1 is a model of human CD34+ HPC to DC differentiation and suggest that specific intracellular signaling pathways mediate specific events in DC lineage commitment .
12,13 G#cell_line|18,20 G#cell_line|17,20 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_type|34,35 G#cell_type

Involvement of adenylate cyclase and p70(S6)-kinase activation in IL-10 up-regulation in human monocytes by gp41 envelope protein of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|14,17 G#protein

Our previous results show that recombinant gp41 ( aa565-647 ) , the extracellular domain of HIV-1 transmembrane glycoprotein , stimulates interleukin-10 ( IL-10 ) production in human monocytes .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type

The signal cascade transducing this effect is not yet clear .


In this study , we examined whether gp41 -induced IL-10 up-regulation is mediated by the previously described synergistic activation of cAMP and NF-kappaB pathways .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

gp41 induced cAMP accumulation in monocytes in a time- and concentration-dependent manner and the adenylate cyclase inhibitor SQ 22536 suppressed gp41 -induced IL-10 production in monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#cell_type

In contrast , gp41 failed to stimulate NF-kappaB binding activity in as much as no NF-kappaB bound to the main NF-kappaB -binding site 2 of the IL-10 promoter after addition of gp41 .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein

We also examined the involvement of other signal transduction pathways .


Specific inhibitors of p70(S6)-kinase ( rapamycin ) , and Gi protein ( pertussis toxin ) , prevented induction of IL-10 production by gp41 in monocytes , while inhibitors of the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase ( PI 3-kinase ) ( wortmannin ) and mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) pathway ( PD 98059 ) did not .
3,4 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type|30,32 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

Thus HIV-1 gp41 -induced IL-10 up-regulation in monocytes may not involve NF-kappaB , MAPK , or PI 3-kinase activation , but rather may operate through activation of adenylate cyclase and pertussis-toxin-sensitive Gi/Go protein to effect p70(S6)-kinase activation .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

Analysis of the modulation of transcriptional activity in myelopoiesis and leukemogenesis .


Acute myeloid leukemia ( AML ) is still associated with a mortality of 60 to 80 % .


AML is characterized by a block in myeloid differentiation .


The transcription factors PU.1 and C/EBPalpha are responsible for normal myeloid differentiation from stem cells to monocytes or granulocytes .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type

In particular , PU.1 induces expression of the macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( M-CSF ) receptor and the development of monocytes , whereas C/EBPalpha increases the expression of the granulocyte colony-stimulating factor ( G-CSF ) receptor and leads to mature granulocytes .
3,4 G#protein|8,15 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|28,35 G#protein|39,40 G#cell_type

In AML , chromosomal aberrations result in oncoproteins such as AML1/ETO , PML/RARalpha , or activated Ras , which can deregulate genes important for normal myelopoiesis .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Thus , AML1/ETO can bind to the transcription factor C/EBPalpha , inhibit C/EBPalpha -dependent transcription , and block granulocytic differentiation .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

However , AML1/ETO can also synergize with the transcription factor AML1 to enhance the activity of the M-CSF receptor promoter .
2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

On the other hand , the PML/RARalpha fusion protein causes transcriptional repression by recruiting the nuclear corepressor ( N-CoR ) histone deacetylase complex to the DNA , which results in decreased histone acetylation and a repressive chromatin organization .
6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|15,23 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|36,37 G#DNA

Here we describe methods to investigate whether and how signaling agonists induce myeloid differentiation and how oncoproteins might cause AML by modulating the activity of transcription factors that are pivotal for normal myeloid development .
16,17 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


NF-ATc isoforms are differentially expressed and regulated in murine T and mast cells .
0,2 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_type

NF of activated T cells ( NF-AT ) denotes a family of transcription factors that regulate the activation-dependent expression of many immunologically important proteins .
0,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

At least four distinct genes encode the various family members , and several isoforms of these have been identified as well .


The overlapping expression patterns and similar in vitro binding and trans-activation activities on various promoter elements of NF-AT -regulated genes suggest some redundancy in the function of these proteins .
14,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

However , the phenotypic analysis of NF-AT -deficient mice supports the idea that there are tissue- and gene- specific functions as well .
6,7 G#protein

In this study we have characterized the expression of NF-AT cDNAs in murine mast cells .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_type

The majority of clones identified correspond to two NF-ATc isoforms that differ only in their amino-terminal sequence .
8,10 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Despite minimal discrepancies in the coding region , there are striking tissue- and cell type-specific differences in isoform expression patterns .
5,7 G#DNA

Detection of NF-ATc.alpha mRNA is strictly dependent on cell activation signals in both T and mast cell lines .
2,4 G#RNA|13,18 G#cell_line

In contrast , the beta isoform is expressed at very low constitutive levels in both cell types but is only up-regulated in response to mast cell activation signals delivered through the FcepsilonRI or via calcium ionophores .
4,6 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

These results demonstrate another level of regulation within the NF-AT family that can contribute to cell type-specific gene expression .
9,11 G#protein

Crossreactive recognition of viral , self , and bacterial peptide ligands by human class I-restricted cytotoxic T lymphocyte clonotypes : implications for molecular mimicry in autoimmune disease .
12,20 G#cell_type

The immunodominant , CD8(+) cytotoxic T lymphocyte ( CTL ) response to the HLA-B8-restricted peptide , RAKFKQLL , located in the Epstein-Barr virus immediate-early antigen , BZLF1 , is characterized by a diverse T cell receptor ( TCR ) repertoire .
3,7 G#cell_type|21,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|33,40 G#protein

Here , we show that this diversity can be partitioned on the basis of crossreactive cytotoxicity patterns involving the recognition of a self peptide - RSKFRQIV - located in a serine /threonine kinase and a bacterial peptide - RRKYKQII - located in Staphylococcus aureus replication initiation protein .
30,33 G#protein|42,47 G#protein

Thus CTL clones that recognized the viral , self , and bacterial peptides expressed a highly restricted alphabeta TCR phenotype .
1,3 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein

The CTL clones that recognized viral and self peptides were more oligoclonal , whereas clones that strictly recognized the viral peptide displayed a diverse TCR profile .
1,3 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein

Interestingly , the self and bacterial peptides equally were substantially less effective than the cognate viral peptide in sensitizing target cell lysis , and also resulted only in a weak reactivation of memory CTLs in limiting dilution assays , whereas the cognate peptide was highly immunogenic .
32,34 G#cell_type

The described crossreactions show that human antiviral , CD8(+) CTL responses can be shaped by peptide ligands derived from autoantigens and environmental bacterial antigens , thereby providing a firm structural basis for molecular mimicry involving class I-restricted CTLs in the pathogenesis of autoimmune disease .
36,38 G#cell_line

RFLAT-1 : a new zinc finger transcription factor that activates RANTES gene expression in T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|4,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type

RANTES ( Regulated upon Activation , Normal T cell Expressed and Secreted ) is a chemoattractant cytokine ( chemokine ) important in the generation of inflammatory infiltrate and human immunodeficiency virus entry into immune cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,12 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type

RANTES is expressed late ( 3-5 days ) after activation in T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Using expression cloning , we identified the first " late " T lymphocyte associated transcription factor and named it " RANTES Factor of Late Activated T Lymphocytes-1 " ( RFLAT-1 ) .
11,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,27 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

RFLAT-1 is a novel , phosphorylated , zinc finger transcription factor that is expressed in T cells 3 days after activation , coincident with RANTES expression .
0,1 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein

While Rel proteins play the dominant role in RANTES gene expression in fibroblasts , RFLAT-1 is a strong transactivator for RANTES in T cells .
1,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type

Fas ligand induction in human NK cells is regulated by redox through a calcineurin-nuclear factors of activated T cell-dependent pathway .
0,2 G#protein|4,7 G#cell_type|13,15 G#protein

Fas ligand ( FasL ) on cytotoxic lymphocytes is important for mediating apoptosis of activated lymphocytes and other target cells .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

We have reported that NK cell functions , such as proliferation , cell death , and killing activity , are subject to regulation by cellular redox status .


Here , we report that expression of FasL protein and mRNA in activated NK cells is also regulated by redox .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#RNA|12,15 G#cell_type

Ligation of CD16 on IL-2- preactivated NK cells resulted in reduction of intracellular peroxide level as well as induction of FasL expression .
2,3 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_type|4,8 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein

This CD16 -induced FasL expression was suppressed by oxidative stress , including thiol deprivation or treatment with hydrogen peroxide ( H2O2 ) .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

Addition of thiol-reducing compounds , such as L-cystine , 2-ME , or N-acetyl cysteine , restored FasL expression .
16,17 G#protein

These data suggest that CD16 stimulation requires cellular reducing status for FasL induction in NK cells .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

Because FasL gene activation following CD16 cross-linking is regulated by the NF of activated T cells ( NFAT ) , we examined the effect of oxidative stresses on NFAT activation .
5,6 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|11,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays revealed that both thiol insufficiency and H2O2 treatment suppressed DNA-binding activity of NFAT and that addition of thiol-reducing compounds reversed or even enhanced it .
16,17 G#protein

Furthermore , these oxidative stresses inhibited activity of calcineurin , a serine / threonine phosphatase that regulates NFAT activation .
13,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

These results suggest that suppression of calcineurin and NFAT activation is a mechanism by which oxidative stress inhibits FasL induction in activated NK cells and further support the hypothesis that thiol-reducing compounds might be required for maintenance of optimal NK functions under physiologic oxidative conditions .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type

Heterogeneity of clonal development in chronic myeloproliferative disorders .
5,8 G#DNA

Recent reports have suggested a previously unexpected variability in the expression of the dominant neoplastic clone in myeloproliferative disorders ( MPD ) .
13,16 G#cell_line

We evaluated 49 female patients with MPD and informative at the X-linked androgen receptor ( AR ) locus to establish the X chromosome inactivation pattern of hemopoietic cells .
11,18 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA|26,28 G#cell_type

Whereas in chronic myelogenous leukemia ( CML ) the granulocytes ( PMN ) were uniformly of monoclonal origin , a striking heterogeneity of clonal development was found in PMN from patients with other MPD , with up to 50 % of them expressing a polyclonal pattern of X inactivation .
9,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_type

CD80 and CD86 are not equivalent in their ability to induce the tyrosine phosphorylation of CD28 .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Ligation of either CD80 ( B7-1 ) or CD86 ( B7-2 ) , two principal ligands for CD28 , is thought to skew the immune response toward Th1 or Th2 differentiation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

We have examined early signal transduction pathways recruited following T cell stimulation with either CD80 or CD86 .
14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Purified human peripheral T cells or Jurkat T cells were stimulated with Chinese hamster ovary ( CHO ) cells expressing either human CD80 ( CHO-CD80 ) or human CD86 ( CHO-CD86 ) or with anti- CD28 monoclonal antibody ( mAb ) .
0,5 G#cell_line|6,9 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|34,38 G#protein

In the presence of phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate , both CHO-CD80 and CHO-CD86 , like anti-CD28 mAb , were capable of stimulating cytokine production from both human peripheral T cells and Jurkat T cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,29 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_line

Both CHO-CD80 and CHO-CD86 , in the presence of anti-CD3 mAb , costimulated NFAT -dependent transcriptional activation .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Several intracellular signaling proteins , such as CBL and VAV , were phosphorylated on tyrosine in response to CD80 , CD86 , and anti-CD28 mAb .
2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Surprisingly , although stimulation of Jurkat T cells with either CHO-CD80 or anti-CD28 mAb resulted in robust tyrosine phosphorylation of CD28 itself , ligation with CHO-CD86 was unable to induce detectable CD28 tyrosyl phosphorylation over a range of stimulation conditions .
5,8 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

In addition , the association of phosphoinositide 3-kinase with CD28 and enhanced tyrosine phosphorylation of phospholipase Cgamma were seen after anti-CD28 mAb and CHO-CD80 stimulation but to a much lesser extent after CHO-CD86 stimulation .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Thus , ligation of CD28 with either CD80 or CD86 leads to shared early signal transduction events such as the tyrosine phosphorylation of CBL and VAV , to NFAT -mediated transcriptional activation , and to the costimulation of interleukin-2 and granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor production .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|40,43 G#protein

However , CD80 and CD86 also induce distinct signal transduction pathways including the tyrosine phosphorylation of CD28 and phospholipase Cgamma1 and the SH2 -dependent association of phosphoinositide 3-kinase with CD28 .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

These quantitative , if not qualitative , differences between signaling initiated by these two ligands for CD28 may contribute to functional differences ( e.g. Th1 or Th2 differentiation ) in T cell responses .
16,17 G#protein

Binding of HMG-I ( Y ) elicits structural changes in a silencer of the human beta-globin gene .
2,6 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA

Proteins involved in repression of the human beta-globin gene may be useful in the treatment of sickle cell anemia , in conjunction with therapy to reactivate fetal globin genes .
6,9 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA

If there is a reciprocal elevation of gamma-globin expression upon repression , this approach could be useful in additional hemoglobinopathies .
7,8 G#protein

We previously showed that repression of the beta-globin gene appears to be mediated through two DNA sequences , silencers I and II , and identified a protein termed BP1 which binds to both silencer sequences .
15,17 G#DNA|18,22 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein

In this study , we cloned two cDNAs encoding proteins which bind to an oligonucleotide in silencer I containing a BP1 binding site .
7,8 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

These cDNAs correspond to HMG-I and HMG-Y , isoforms regarded as architectural proteins .
1,2 G#DNA|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

We demonstrate that binding of HMG-I(Y) to this oligonucleotide causes bending/flexure of the DNA .
5,6 G#protein

HMG-I(Y) also binds to a second oligonucleotide containing a BP1 binding site located in a negative control region upstream of the delta-globin gene , suggesting a role for HMG-I(Y) in repression of adult globin genes .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein

Expression studies revealed that HMG-I(Y) is ubiquitously expressed in human tissues that do not express beta-globin , being present in 48 of 50 tissues and six hematopoietic cell lines examined .
4,5 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_line

Furthermore , HMG-I(Y) expression is down-regulated during differentiation of primary erythroid cells .
2,3 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

We present a model in which HMG-I(Y) alters DNA conformation to allow binding of repressor proteins , and in which the relative amount of HMG-I(Y) helps to determine the repressive state of the beta-globin gene .
6,7 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA

Interactions between the class II transactivator and CREB binding protein increase transcription of major histocompatibility complex class II genes .
3,6 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|13,19 G#DNA

Class II major histocompatibility ( class II ) genes are regulated in a B-cell-specific and gamma interferon-inducible fashion .
0,9 G#DNA

The master switch for the expression of these genes is the class II transactivator ( CIITA ) .
11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

In this report , we demonstrate that one of the functions of CIITA is to recruit the CREB binding protein ( CBP ) to class II promoters .
12,13 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA

Not only functional but also specific binding interactions between CIITA and CBP were demonstrated .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Moreover , a dominant negative form of CBP decreased the activity of class II promoters and levels of class II determinants on the surface of cells .
7,8 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|18,21 G#protein

Finally , the inhibition of class II gene expression by the glucocorticoid hormone could be attributed to the squelching of CBP by the glucocorticoid receptor .
5,8 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

We conclude that CBP , a histone acetyltransferase , plays an important role in the transcription of class II genes .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

Role of cyclic AMP response element-binding protein in cyclic AMP inhibition of NF-kappaB -mediated transcription .
2,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The NF-kappaB family of transcription factors regulates the inducible expression of a variety of genes .
1,2 G#protein

Recently , we showed that elevation of intracellular cyclic AMP inhibits NF-kappaB -mediated transcription in human monocytes and endothelial cells without preventing nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB complexes .
11,12 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

The present study examined the molecular mechanism of this inhibition .


We hypothesized that activation of the protein kinase A signaling pathway may inhibit NF-kappaB -mediated transcription by phosphorylating proteins , such as cAMP response element-binding protein ( CREB ) , which compete for limiting amounts of the coactivator CBP .
6,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Here , we show that the amino-terminal region ( amino acids 1-450 ) of CBP specifically interacts with the carboxyl-terminal region ( amino acids 286-551 ) of NF-kappaB p65 ( RelA ) both in vitro and in vivo .
6,8 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Functional studies using human endothelial cells demonstrated that overexpression of CBP rescued cAMP inhibition of NF-kappaB -mediated transcription and transcription mediated by a chimeric protein , GAL4-p65 ( 286-551 ) , which contained the GAL4 DNA binding domain fused to the carboxyl-terminal region of p65 ( amino acids 286-551 ) .
4,6 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|26,30 G#protein|34,38 G#protein|41,43 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|46,49 G#protein

In contrast , overexpression of CREB inhibited GAL4 -p65(286-551)-mediated transcription .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

These results suggest that activation of the protein kinase A pathway inhibits NF-kappaB transcription by phosphorylating CREB , which competes with p65 for limiting amounts of CBP .
7,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Glucocorticoid receptors in cord blood lymphocytes of healthy neonates and of preterms suffering from respiratory distress syndrome .
0,2 G#protein|3,6 G#cell_type

We measured the number of glucocorticoid receptors ( GR ) in cord blood lymphocytes and the binding affinity ( Kd ) in 15 term and in 20 preterm babies .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

Thirteen preterms of the latter group received prenatal steroid treatment .


Seven preterms developed neonatal respiratory distress syndrome ( NRDS ) .


The number of GR and the Kd were similar in the term and preterm ( with and without NRDS ) babies .
3,4 G#protein

The maximum (3H)-thymidine incorporation into DNA of cord blood lymphocytes from all preterms , with or without NRDS was suppressed when compared to that from term babies or adults .
7,10 G#cell_type

This could partly be explained by the antenatal steroid treatment .


Sensitivity ( ID50 ) of the lymphocytes for the inhibitory effect of dexamethasone was the same in all groups .
6,7 G#cell_type

In this study on the number and function of GR in lymphocytes , we were unable to find a relation between the functionality of the GR and the development of NRDS .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

Inefficient termination of antigen responses in NF-ATp -deficient mice .
6,7 G#protein

In order to elucidate the role of NF-ATp , one of the most prominent members of family of NF-AT transcription factors in peripheral T lymphocytes , in T cell activation and differentiation we created NF-ATp -deficient mice by gene targeting .
7,8 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|22,25 G#cell_type|34,35 G#protein

Such NF-ATp -/- mice are born and appear to develop a normal immune system .
1,2 G#protein

Apart from clear-cut defects in the synthesis of mRNAs for Th2-type lymphokines , such as IL-4 , IL-5 , IL-10 and IL-13 , in primary and secondary stimulations of spleen cells in vitro , of a distinct impaired deletion of V beta 11+/CD4+ T lymphocytes from these mice was detected after superantigen injection .
8,9 G#RNA|10,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type|43,45 G#cell_type|40,45 G#cell_line

Moreover , NF-ATp -/- mice older than 6 weeks show an 2-5 fold increase in number of lymphocytes .
2,3 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

This is correlated with an increased expression of activation markers CD44 and CD69 and decreased expression of CD62 .

AML and Ets proteins regulate the I alpha1 germ-line promoter .
0,4 G#protein|6,10 G#DNA

The immunoglobulin heavy chain ( IgH ) class switch recombination of B lymphocytes preferentially targets unrearranged IgH genes that have already been rendered transcriptionally active .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|16,18 G#DNA

Transcription of the germ-line IgH genes is controlled by intervening ( I ) regions upstream of their switch regions .
4,6 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA|9,14 G#DNA

The I alpha1 promoter activates transcription of the human germ-line C alpha1 gene for IgA1 and mediates the transforming growth factor ( TGF ) -beta1 responsiveness of this locus .
8,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|18,25 G#protein

Here we show that the I alpha1 promoter contains several binding sites for the AML /PEBP2/CBF family of transcription factors and that AML and Ets proteins are major regulators of the basal and TGF-beta-inducible promoter activity .
14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|14,20 G#protein|22,26 G#protein

Our data constitute a starting point for studies to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which TGF-beta regulates IgA production .
15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Daidzein and genistein glucuronides in vitro are weakly estrogenic and activate human natural killer cells at nutritionally relevant concentrations .
11,15 G#cell_type

Daidzein and genistein glucuronides ( DG and GG ) , major isoflavone metabolites , may be partly responsible for biological effects of isoflavones , such as estrogen receptor binding and natural killer cell ( NK ) activation or inhibition .
30,33 G#cell_type

DG and GG were synthesized using 3-methylcholanthrene -induced rat liver microsomes .


The Km and Vmax for daidzein and genistein were 9.0 and 7.7 micromol/L , and 0.7 and 1.6 micromol/ ( mg protein. min ) , respectively .


The absence of ultraviolet absorbance maxima shifts in the presence of sodium acetate confirmed that the synthesized products were 7-O- glucuronides .


DG and GG were further purified by a Sephadex LH-20 column .


DG and GG competed with the binding of 17beta-(3H)Â estradiol to estrogen receptors of B6D2F1 mouse uterine cytosol .
10,12 G#protein

The concentrations required for 50 % displacement of 17beta-(3H)Â estradiol ( CB50 ) were : 17beta-estradiol , 1.34 nmol/L ; diethylstilbestrol , 1.46 nmol/L ; daidzein , 1.6 micromol/L ; DG , 14.7 micromol/L ; genistein , 0.154 micromol/L ; GG , 7.27 micromol/L .


In human peripheral blood NK cells , genistein at &lt; 0.5 micromol/L and DG and GG at 0.1-10 micromol/L enhanced NK cell-mediated K562 cancer cell killing significantly ( P &lt; 0.05 ) .
1,6 G#cell_type|22,25 G#cell_line

At &gt; 0.5 micromol/L , genistein inhibited NK cytotoxicity significantly ( P &lt; 0.05 ) .


The glucuronides only inhibited NK cytotoxicity at 50 micromol/L .


Isoflavones , and especially the isoflavone glucuronides , enhanced activation of NK cells by interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) , additively .
11,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

At physiological concentrations , DG and GG were weakly estrogenic , and they activated human NK cells in nutritionally relevant concentrations in vitro , probably at a site different from IL-2 action .
15,17 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein

Cross-linking of CD44 on rheumatoid synovial cells up-regulates VCAM-1 .
2,3 G#protein|4,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein

CD44 is a ubiquitous molecule also known as hyaluronic acid or homing receptor .


However , the cellular functions and its role in inflammation , for example , rheumatoid synovitis , are currently unknown .


In this study , we propose a novel function for CD44 .


Using synovial cells from rheumatoid arthritis ( RA ) patients , we demonstrated that CD44 cross-linking and binding to hyaluronan augmented VCAM-1 expression and subsequently VCAM-1 -mediated cell adhesion .
21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Briefly , we found that 1 ) rheumatoid synovial cells highly expressed CD44 ; 2 ) cross-linking of CD44 markedly but transiently augmented VCAM-1 expression and its mRNA transcription much more than did IL-1beta and TNF-alpha ; 3 ) hyaluronan , especially when fragmented , also up-regulated VCAM-1 ; 4 ) CD44 activated the transcription factor AP-1 ; and 5 ) the integrin -dependent adhesive function of RA synovial cells to T cells was also amplified by CD44 cross-linking .
7,10 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|47,48 G#protein|51,52 G#protein|62,63 G#protein|67,70 G#cell_type|71,73 G#cell_type|77,78 G#protein

These results indicate that the adhesion of RA synovial cells to matrices such as hyaluronic acid through CD44 could up-regulate VCAM-1 expression and VCAM-1 -mediated adhesion to T cells , which might in turn cause activation of T cells and synovial cells in RA synovitis .
7,10 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|37,39 G#cell_type|40,42 G#cell_type

We therefore propose that such cross-talking among distinct adhesion molecules may be involved in the pathogenesis of inflammation , including RA synovitis .


NF-kappaB activation is a critical regulator of human granulocyte apoptosis in vitro .
0,1 G#protein

During beneficial inflammation , potentially tissue-damaging granulocytes undergo apoptosis before being cleared by phagocytes in a non-phlogistic manner .
5,7 G#cell_type

Here we show that the rate of constitutive apoptosis in human neutrophils and eosinophils is greatly accelerated in both a rapid and concentration-dependent manner by the fungal metabolite gliotoxin , but not by its inactive analog methylthiogliotoxin .
10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

This induction of apoptosis was abolished by the caspase inhibitor zVAD-fmk , correlated with the inhibition of nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappaB ) , and was mimicked by a cell permeable inhibitory peptide of NF-kappaB , SN-50 ; other NF-kappaB inhibitors , curcumin and pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ; and the proteasome inhibitor , MG-132 .
17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Gliotoxin also augmented dramatically the early ( 2-6 h ) pro-apoptotic effects of tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) in neutrophils and unmasked the ability of TNF-alpha to induce eosinophil apoptosis .
13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

In neutrophils , TNF-alpha caused a gliotoxin -inhibitable activation of an inducible form of NF-kappaB , a response that may underlie the ability of TNF-alpha to delay apoptosis at later times ( 12-24 h ) and limit its early killing effect .
1,2 G#cell_type|3,4 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Furthermore , cycloheximide displayed a similar capacity to enhance TNF-alpha induced neutrophil apoptosis even at time points when cycloheximide alone had no pro-apoptotic effect , suggesting that NF-kappaB may regulate the production of protein ( s ) which protect neutrophils from the cytotoxic effects of TNF-alpha .
9,10 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|39,40 G#cell_type|45,46 G#protein

These data shed light on the biochemical and molecular mechanisms regulating human granulocyte apoptosis and , in particular , indicate that the transcription factor NF-kappaB plays a crucial role in regulating the physiological cell death pathway in granulocytes .
22,24 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|37,38 G#cell_type

Role of Egr-2 in up-regulation of Fas ligand in normal T cells and aberrant double-negative lpr and gld T cells .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|13,20 G#cell_type

We previously identified a Fas ligand regulatory element ( FLRE ) in the Fas ligand ( fasL ) promoter that binds Egr family proteins and demonstrated that Egr-3 ( PILOT ) but not Egr-1 ( NGFI-A , Krox-24 , Tis-8 , and Zif-268 ) induces transcription of fasL .
4,8 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|13,19 G#DNA|21,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

The aberrant CD4(-) CD8(-) T cells from lpr/lpr and gld/gld mice , which have mutations in the genes encoding Fas and FasL , respectively , have an activated phenotype and constitutively express high levels of fasL mRNA , prompting us to ask what role if any the FLRE and Egr family proteins have in this aberrant expression of fasL .
1,6 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|35,37 G#RNA|47,48 G#DNA|49,52 G#protein|58,59 G#protein

Unstimulated MRL-lpr/lpr and C3H-gld/gld CD4(-) CD8(-) T cells constitutively contained high levels of two proteins that bound to the FLRE .
1,8 G#cell_line|19,20 G#DNA

Supershift analysis revealed these proteins to be Egr-1 and Egr-2 ( Krox-20 ) ; Egr-3 was not detected .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Activation of normal lymph node cells resulted in increased expression of Egr -1 , -2 , and -3 .
2,6 G#cell_type|11,18 G#protein

As with egr-3 , expression of egr-2 was blocked by cyclosporin A .
2,3 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA

Although overexpressed Egr-1 was ineffective , overexpressed Egr-2 was as potent as Egr-3 in inducing fasL promoter-dependent reporter constructs in T cell hybridomas and HeLa cells , and both up-regulated endogenous fasL mRNA in HeLa cells .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,19 G#DNA|31,33 G#RNA|34,36 G#cell_line

FasL -dependent reporter constructs in MRL-lpr/lpr and C3H-gld/gld CD4(-) CD8(-) T cells were constitutively active , and this activity was largely prevented by mutation of the critical Egr family binding element .
0,1 G#protein|0,4 G#DNA|5,12 G#cell_line|27,31 G#DNA

Thus , Egr-2 , in addition to Egr-3 , regulates FasL expression in activated normal T cells , and Egr-2 is likely to play a direct role in aberrant fasL up-regulation in lpr/lpr and gld/gld CD4(-) CD8(-) T cells .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|32,39 G#cell_line

The activity of the CCAAT-box binding factor NF-Y is modulated through the regulated expression of its A subunit during monocyte to macrophage differentiation : regulation of tissue-specific genes through a ubiquitous transcription factor .
4,5 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|4,8 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|31,33 G#protein

In this study , we analyzed the regulation of NF-Y expression during human monocyte to macrophage maturation .
9,10 G#protein

NF-Y is a ubiquitous and evolutionarily conserved transcription factor that binds specifically to the CCAAT motif present in the 5' promoter region of a wide variety of genes .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA

We show here that in circulating monocytes , NF-Y binding activity is not detected on the CCAAT motif present in the promoters of genes such as major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class II , gp91-phox , mig , and fibronectin , whereas during macrophage differentiation , a progressive increase in NF-Y binding activity is observed on these promoters .
5,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|21,24 G#DNA|26,34 G#DNA|35,36 G#DNA|37,38 G#DNA|51,52 G#protein

Analysis of NF-Y subunit expression indicates that the absence of NF-Y activity in circulating monocytes is caused by a lack of the A subunit .
2,3 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein

Furthermore , addition of the recombinant NF-Y A subunit restores NF-Y binding .
6,7 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

We show that the lack of NF-YA protein is due to posttranscriptional regulation and not to a specific proteolytic activity .
6,8 G#protein

In fact , NF-YA mRNA is present at the same level at all days of monocyte cultivation , whereas the protein is absent in freshly isolated monocytes but is progressively synthesized during the maturation process .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#RNA|24,27 G#cell_type

We thus conclude that the NF-Y A subunit plays a relevant role in activating transcription of genes highly expressed in mature monocytes .
5,6 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

In line with this conclusion , we show that the cut/CDP protein , a transcriptional repressor that inhibits gpc91-phox gene expression by preventing NF-Y binding to the CAAT box , is absent in monocytes .
10,12 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|33,34 G#cell_type

Interdomain B in ZAP-70 regulates but is not required for ZAP-70 signaling function in lymphocytes .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type

The protein tyrosine kinase ZAP-70 plays an important role in T-cell activation and development .
4,5 G#protein

After T-cell receptor stimulation , ZAP-70 associates with the receptor and is phosphorylated on many tyrosines , including Y292 , Y315 , and Y319 within interdomain B .
1,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Previously , we demonstrated that Y292 negatively regulates ZAP-70 function and that Y315 positively regulates ZAP-70 function by interacting with Vav .
8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Recent studies have suggested that Y319 also positively regulate ZAP-70 function .
9,10 G#protein

Paradoxically , removal of interdomain B ( to create the construct designated Delta ) , containing the Y292 , Y315 , and Y319 sites , did not eliminate the ability of ZAP-70 to induce multiple gene reporters in Syk-deficient DT-40 B cells and ZAP-70 /Syk-deficient Jurkat cells .
4,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,37 G#DNA|38,42 G#cell_line|43,44 G#protein|43,47 G#cell_line

Here we show that Delta still utilizes the same pathways as wild-type ZAP-70 to mediate NF-AT induction .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

This is manifested by the ability of Delta to restore induction of calcium fluxes and mitogen-activated protein kinase activation and by the ability of dominant negative Ras and FK506 to block the induction of NF-AT activity mediated by Delta .
7,8 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Biochemically we show that the stimulated tyrosine phosphorylation of Vav , Shc , and ZAP-70 itself is diminished , whereas that of Slp-76 is increased in cells reconstituted with Delta .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Deletion of interdomain B did not affect the ability of ZAP-70 to bind to the receptor .
2,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

The in vitro kinase activity of ZAP-70 lacking interdomain B was markedly reduced , but the kinase activity was still required for the protein 's in vivo activity .
6,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Based on these data , we concluded that interdomain B regulates but is not required for ZAP-70 signaling function leading to cellular responses .
8,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Differential induction of DNA-binding activities following CD19 cross-linking in human B lineage cells .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type

The B cell-specific cell surface molecule CD19 is expressed at all stages of B cell development , including normal plasma cells , and mediates signal transduction via interaction with cytoplasmic effector proteins .
1,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|29,32 G#protein
