Cross-linking CD19 on early human B lineage cells induces the formation of a CD19 /Vav/phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase complex , tyrosine phosphorylation of CD19 and Vav , and activation of the Ras pathway .
1,2 G#protein|4,8 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

To further explore the ramifications of CD19 signaling , the current study examined whether phosphorylation of Elk-1 , activation of activator protein-1 ( AP-1 ) , or activation of nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) transcription factors occurred following CD19 cross-linking .
6,7 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

The cells used were the BLIN-1 pre-B cell line expressing low levels of cell surface mu heavy chain associated with surrogate light chain and the 1E8 immature B cell line expressing cell surface mu/kappa .
5,9 G#cell_line|13,18 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|31,34 G#protein

Lysates from CD19 cross-linked 1E8 cells induced robust phosphorylation of an Elk-1 fusion protein in vitro , whereas no phosphorylation of Elk-1 fusion protein occurred using lysates from CD19 cross-linked BLIN-1 cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_line

An electrophoretic mobility shift assay employing AP-1 and NF-kappaB consensus oligonucleotides was used to demonstrate that AP-1 Â -binding activity increased , while constitutive NF-kappaB -binding activity was not enhanced , following 2 h of CD19 cross-linking in 1E8 cells . Supershift experiments revealed that JunD and c-Fos proteins mediated anti- CD19 induced AP-1 -binding activity in 1E8 cells .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_line|44,45 G#protein|46,48 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|52,53 G#protein|56,58 G#cell_line

In contrast , CD19 cross-linking in BLIN-1 cells resulted in the induction of NF-kappaB , but had no apparent effect on AP-1 -binding activity .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

These data suggest that CD19 -mediated signal transduction activates different transcription factors at juxtaposed stages of B cell development that may culminate in the activation or suppression of distinct sets of genes .
4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|31,32 G#DNA

Oxidants , transcription factors , and intestinal inflammation .
2,4 G#protein

It is now well appreciated that chronic gut inflammation is characterized by enhanced production of reactive metabolites of oxygen and nitrogen .


Some of these oxidants are known to modulate the expression of a variety of genes that are involved in the immune and inflammatory responses .


For example , certain oxidants are known to activate the nuclear transcription factor kappa B , which regulates the expression of a variety of different adhesion molecules , cytokines , and enzymes .
11,13 G#protein|10,15 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Oxidants are also known to activate another transcription factor , activator protein-1 .
7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

This transcription factor is composed of products from the fos and jun proto-oncogene family and is believed to be important in regulating cell growth and proliferation .
1,3 G#protein|9,14 G#protein

Finally , oxidants are believed to promote intestinal epithelial cell apoptosis , and the B-cell lymphoma/leukemia-2 gene product is believed to inhibit this phenomenon in an antioxidant-dependent manner .
7,10 G#cell_type|14,18 G#protein

Taken together , these observations suggest that nontoxic concentrations of reactive metabolites of oxygen and nitrogen play an important role in regulating the expression of genes involved in the inflammatory response and in modulating apoptosis .


Identification of target genes of the lymphoid-specific transcription factor Oct2 .
2,4 G#DNA|7,9 G#protein|6,10 G#protein

The Oct2 transcription factor is expressed predominantly in B lymphocytes and plays an essential role during the terminal phase of B cell differentiation .
1,2 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type

The regulatory regions of several genes specifically expressed in B cells contain functional binding sites for Oct2 .
1,3 G#DNA|9,11 G#cell_type|12,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

Nevertheless , none of the genes originally thought to be regulated by Oct2 were affected in their expression in Oct2 -deficient B cells .
12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|19,23 G#cell_line

In an attempt to find such elusive Oct2 target genes and to understand the molecular function of Oct2 in B cell development , we isolated cDNAs for Oct2 target genes .
7,8 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|25,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA

So far , we have identified five potential targets for Oct2 : the membrane glycoprotein CD36 , the cysteine-rich secreted protein 3 ( CRISP-3 ) , a mouse homolog of the human monocyte/neutrophil elastase inhibitor ( mEI ) and two unknown cDNA sequences Nov1 and Nov2 .
10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|31,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|41,43 G#DNA|43,44 G#DNA|45,46 G#DNA

These target genes show quite distinct expression patterns demonstrating that transcription factors in addition to Oct2 are involved in their regulation .
1,3 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Whereas CD36 and mEI were expressed in all hematopoetic cell lines containing Oct2 , .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein

CRISP-3 is pre-B cell-specific , Nov1 is plasma B cell-specific and Nov2 is B cell-specifically expressed .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA

RFX-B is the gene responsible for the most common cause of the bare lymphocyte syndrome , an MHC class II immunodeficiency [ published erratum appears in Immunity 1999 Mar ; 10 ( 3 ) : 399 ]
0,1 G#DNA|17,20 G#protein

The bare lymphocyte syndrome ( BLS ) is characterized by the absence of MHC class II transcription and humoral- and cellular- mediated immune responses to foreign antigens .
13,16 G#protein

Three of the four BLS genetic complementation groups have defects in the activity of the MHC class II transcription factor RFX .
15,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

We have purified the RFX complex and sequenced its three subunits .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

The sequence of the smallest subunit describes a novel gene , termed RFX-B .
12,13 G#DNA

RFX-B complements the predominant BLS complementation group ( group B ) and was found to be mutant in cell lines from this BLS group .
0,1 G#DNA|4,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line

The protein has no known DNA-binding domain but does contain three ankyrin repeats that are likely to be important in protein-protein interactions .
5,7 G#protein

Binding of c-Rel to STAT5 target sequences in HTLV-I-transformed T cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|8,11 G#cell_type

The type I human T-cell leukemia virus ( HTLV-I ) induces abnormal growth and subsequent transformation of T cells , which is associated with the development of an acute T-cell malignancy termed adult T-cell leukemia .
17,19 G#cell_type

A characteristic of HTLV-I -transformed T cells is the constitutive nuclear expression of NF-kappaB/Rel family of transcription factors , which appears to be essential for the growth of these transformed cells .
3,7 G#cell_type|13,15 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type

Although NF-kappaB/Rel factors are known to induce the expression of T-cell growth factor interleukin ( IL ) -2 , it is unclear how they participate in the IL-2 -independent growth of HTLV-I -transformed cells .
1,3 G#protein|10,18 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_line

In this study , we show that certain NF-kappaB/Rel members , predominantly c-Rel , interact with enhancer sequences for STAT5 , a key transcription factor mediating IL-2 -induced T-cell proliferation .
8,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Reporter gene assays reveal that the binding of c-Rel to the STAT5 site present in the Fc gammaR1 gene leads to potent transactivation of this enhancer .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,19 G#DNA

Binding of c-Rel to the Fc gammaR1 STAT site also occurs in human peripheral blood T cells immortalized with HTLV-I in vitro and is correlated with enhanced levels of proliferation of these cells .
2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|13,17 G#cell_type

These results raise the possibility that NF-kappaB/Rel may participate in the growth control of HTLV-I -transformed T cells by regulating genes driven by both kappaB and certain STAT enhancers .
6,7 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line|24,25 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

Activation-dependent transcriptional regulation of the human Fas promoter requires NF-kappaB p50-p65 recruitment .
5,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#protein

Fas ( CD95 ) and Fas ligand ( CD95L ) are an interacting receptor-ligand pair required for immune homeostasis .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

Lymphocyte activation results in the upregulation of Fas expression and the acquisition of sensitivity to FasL -mediated apoptosis .
7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Although Fas upregulation is central to the preservation of immunologic tolerance , little is known about the molecular machinery underlying this process .


To investigate the events involved in activation-induced Fas upregulation , we have examined mRNA accumulation , fas promoter activity , and protein expression in the Jurkat T-cell line treated with phorbol myristate acetate and ionomycin ( P/I ) , pharmacological mimics of T-cell receptor activation .
7,8 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_line|42,44 G#protein

Although resting Jurkat cells express Fas , Fas mRNA was induced approximately 10-fold in 2 h upon P/I stimulation .
1,4 G#cell_line|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA

Using sequential deletion mutants of the human fas promoter in transient transfection assays , we identified a 47-bp sequence ( positions -306 to -260 relative to the ATG ) required for activation-driven fas upregulation .
1,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|20,24 G#DNA

Sequence analysis revealed the presence of a previously unrecognized composite binding site for both the Sp1 and NF-kappaB transcription factors at positions -295 to -286 .
8,12 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,25 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay ( EMSA ) and supershift analyses of this region documented constitutive binding of Sp1 in unactivated nuclear extracts and inducible binding of p50-p65 NF-kappaB heterodimers after P/I activation .
17,18 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

Sp1 and NF-kappaB transcription factor binding was shown to be mutually exclusive by EMSA displacement studies with purified recombinant Sp1 and recombinant p50 .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

The functional contribution of the kappaB- Sp1 composite site in P/I -inducible fas promoter activation was verified by using kappaB- Sp1 concatamers ( -295 to -286 ) in a thymidine kinase promoter-driven reporter construct and native promoter constructs in Jurkat cells overexpressing IkappaB-alpha .
6,7 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA|29,34 G#DNA|35,38 G#DNA|39,41 G#cell_line|42,43 G#protein

Site-directed mutagenesis of the critical guanine nucleotides in the kappaB- Sp1 element documented the essential role of this site in activation-dependent fas promoter induction .
10,11 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA

Evidence for repression of IL-2 gene activation in anergic T cells .
4,6 G#DNA|8,11 G#cell_type

The induction of clonal anergy in a T cell inhibits IL-2 secretion because of the development of a proximal signal transduction defect .
10,11 G#protein

Fusion of anergic murine T cells to human Jurkat T leukemia cells and formation of heterokaryons failed to result in a complementation of this signaling defect and restoration of murine IL-2 mRNA inducibility .
2,6 G#cell_type|7,12 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_line|29,32 G#RNA

Instead , signal transduction to the human IL-2 gene became disrupted .
7,9 G#DNA

Heterokaryons formed by the fusion of anergic murine T cells to normal murine T cells also failed to accumulate intracellular IL-2 protein in response to stimulation either with the combination of CD3 and CD28 mAbs or with ionomycin plus a protein kinase C -activating phorbol ester .
0,1 G#cell_line|6,10 G#cell_type|11,15 G#cell_type|19,22 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|40,43 G#protein

The results argue against a loss-of-function signaling defect as the sole basis for clonal anergy induction and document the presence of a dominant-acting repressor molecule that inhibits signal transduction to the IL-2 gene within viable anergic T cells .
22,25 G#protein|31,33 G#DNA|35,38 G#cell_type

Comparison of HTLV-I basal transcription and expression of CREB/ATF-1/CREM family members in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and Jurkat T cells .
8,11 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_line

HTLV-I is the etiologic agent of adult T-cell leukemia /lymphoma and is associated with tropical spastic paraparesis/ HTLV-I -associated myelopathy .


Following integration into the host cell genome , HTLV-I replication is regulated by both host and viral mechanisms that control transcription .


Low levels of viral transcription ( basal transcription ) occur before expression of the virally encoded Tax protein ( Tax -mediated transcription ) .
14,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Members of the cyclic adenosine monophosphate ( cAMP ) response element binding ( CREB ) /activating transcription factor 1 ( ATF-1 ) family of transcription factors bind three 21-bp repeats ( Tax-responsive element-1 , or TRE-1 ) within the viral promoter and are important for basal and Tax-mediated transcription .
3,11 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|3,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|31,33 G#DNA|35,36 G#DNA|39,41 G#DNA

Using mitogen stimulated and quiescent peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) and Jurkat cells , we compared differences in basal transcription and amounts and binding of transcription factors with TRE-1 .
5,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_line|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#DNA

We demonstrate that amounts of transcriptionally active phosphorylated CREB protein ( P-CREB ) differ between activated PBMC and Jurkat cells .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_line

Following stimulation , P-CREB levels remain elevated in PBMC for up to 24 hours whereas CREB is dephosphorylated in Jurkat cells within 4 hours following stimulation .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_line

The differences in P-CREB levels between PBMC and Jurkat cells were directly correlated with basal transcription of HTLV-I in the two cell types .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_line

Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays , we determined that the pattern of band migration differed between the two cell types .


These data demonstrate that PBMC differentially regulate basal HTLV-I transcription compared with Jurkat T cells , and this differential regulation is due , in part to differential phosphorylation and binding of CREB/ATF-1 to TRE-1 in the HTLV-I promoter .
4,5 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_line|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#DNA

We demonstrate the utility of using primary lymphocyte models to study HTLV-I transcription in the context of cell signaling and suggest that activated PBMC maintain elevated levels of P-CREB , which promote basal HTLV-I transcription and enhance viral persistence in vivo .
23,24 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

Anoxia/reoxygenation-induced tolerance with respect to polymorphonuclear leukocyte adhesion to cultured endothelial cells .
9,12 G#cell_line

A nuclear factor-kappaB -mediated phenomenon .
1,3 G#protein

Exposing human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVECs ) to anoxia/reoxygenation ( A/R ) results in an increase in polymorphonuclear leukocyte ( PMN ) adhesion to HUVECs .
1,6 G#cell_line|7,8 G#cell_line|22,23 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_line

This A/R -induced hyperadhesion is completely prevented by a previous ( 24 hours earlier ) exposure of HUVECs to A/R .
17,18 G#cell_line

This phenomenon has been termed " A/R tolerance . "


Exposing HUVECs to A/R induces an increase in nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) in HUVEC nuclei within 4 hours .
1,2 G#cell_line|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Interfering with either NF-kappaB activation ( proteasome inhibitor ) or translocation ( double-stranded oligonucleotides containing NF-kappaB binding sequence ) prevents the development of A/R tolerance ( ie , the increase in A/R -induced PMN adhesion to HUVECs is the same after the first and second A/R challenges ) .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|36,37 G#cell_line

NO production by HUVECs is increased after the second A/R challenge , but not after the first A/R challenge .
3,4 G#cell_line

Inhibition of NO synthase ( NOS ) during the second A/R challenge prevents the development of A/R tolerance with respect to PMN adhesion .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

However , while HUVECs contained endothelial NOS protein , no inducible NOS was detected in either tolerant or nontolerant cells .
3,4 G#cell_line|6,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Further studies indicated that inhibition of GTP-cyclohydrolase I ( an enzyme involved in de novo synthesis of an important cofactor for NOS activity , tetrahydrobiopterin ) prevented the generation of NO in A/R -tolerant cells .
6,8 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|32,35 G#cell_line

Extracellular generation of NO ( NO donor ) did not effect the hyperadhesion response induced by the initial A/R challenge .


A/R also induced an oxidant stress in naive HUVECs , but not in A/R -tolerant HUVECs .
8,9 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line|13,16 G#cell_line

Inhibition of NOS during the second A/R insult results in the generation of an oxidant stress similar to that observed after the first A/R challenge .
2,3 G#protein

Taken together , the findings of the present study are consistent with a role for NF-kappaB in the development of A/R tolerance ( with respect to PMN adhesion ) , perhaps by transcriptional regulation of GTP -cyclohydrolase .
15,16 G#protein|26,27 G#cell_type|35,37 G#protein

The increased NO production during the second A/R insult reduces PMN adhesion most likely by reducing the intracellular oxidant stress induced by A/R .


Mildly oxidized low-density lipoproteins decrease early production of interleukin 2 and nuclear factor kappaB binding to DNA in activated T- lymphocytes .
2,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type

Activated T-lymphocytes are found early in atherosclerosis lesions , but little is known about their role .


Oxidized low-density lipoproteins ( oxLDLs ) are considered to be involved in the pathogenesis of the lesions , and we have previously demonstrated that oxLDLs inhibit not only interleukin ( IL ) -2-receptor expression on the surface of in vitro-activated T-lymphocytes but also their proliferation .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,33 G#protein

We have now investigated the effect of oxLDLs on blast differentiation , on IL-2 synthesis and on the activation of the nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) system in activated lymphocytes .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Mildly oxLDLs ( 50 and 100 microgram/ml ) decreased the number of lymphoblasts and the level of IL-2 concentration in the culture supernatants after activation of lymphocytes by phytohaemagglutinin and PMA+ ionomycin .
1,2 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

The inhibition of IL-2 production was observed in the CD3 (+) T-lymphocyte cytoplasm as early as 4 h after activation by PMA+ ionomycin .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

The study of NF-kappaB showed that oxLDLs led to a decrease of activation-induced p65/ p50 NF-kappaB heterodimer binding to DNA , whereas the presence of the constitutive nuclear form of p50 dimer was unchanged .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

This was correlated with an unchanged level of the active form of the cytosolic inhibitor protein IkappaB-alpha .
13,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Taken together , these observations suggest that the immunosuppressive effect of oxLDLs might operate via a dysregulation of the T-lymphocyte activation mechanisms .
11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

The B29 ( immunoglobulin beta-chain ) gene is a genetic target for early B-cell factor .
3,5 G#protein|1,7 G#DNA|12,15 G#protein

Early B-cell factor ( EBF ) is a transcription factor suggested as essential for early B-lymphocyte development by findings in mice where the coding gene has been inactivated by homologous disruption .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

This makes the identification of genetic targets for this transcription factor pertinent for the understanding of early B-cell development .
9,11 G#protein

The lack of B29 transcripts , coding for the beta subunit of the B-cell receptor complex , in pro-B cells from EBF -deficient mice suggested that B29 might be a genetic target for EBF .
3,5 G#RNA|9,11 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

We here present data suggesting that EBF interacts with three independent sites within the mouse B29 promoter .
6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

Furthermore , ectopic expression of EBF in HeLa cells activated a B29 promoter -controlled reporter construct 13-fold and induced a low level of expression from the endogenous B29 gene .
5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|11,12 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|11,16 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA

Finally , mutations in the EBF binding sites diminished B29 promoter activity in pre-B cells while the same mutations did not have as striking an effect on the promoter function in B-cell lines of later differentiation stages .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_type|31,33 G#cell_line

These data suggest that the B29 gene is a genetic target for EBF in early B-cell development .
5,6 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein

Delta-opioid receptors expressed by Jurkat T cells enhance IL-2 secretion by increasing AP-1 complexes and activity of the NF-AT/AP-1-binding promoter element .
4,7 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

Recent molecular evidence points to transient and/or stage-specific expression of delta- and kappa- opioid receptors by thymic and peripheral T lymphocytes .
10,15 G#protein|16,21 G#cell_type

Since medical treatments or stress commonly increase opioid levels , it is important to understand the mechanisms by which opioids affect T lymphocyte functions .


We therefore created and studied a T cell line expressing the cloned delta-opioid receptor ( DOR1 ) .
6,9 G#cell_line|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

DOR1 ligation by a specific DOR1 agonist , deltorphin , augmented IL-2 secretion by synergizing with signals from TCR- CD3 and CD28 .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Reporter gene constructs were used to map this effect of deltorphin to the AP-1- and NF-AT/AP-1- binding sites of the IL-2 promoter .
13,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

Although DOR1 signaling increased [ Ca2+ ]i , deltorphin enhanced transcriptional activity of the NF-AT/AP-1-binding site via a mechanism independent of calcineurin and distinct from the effects of elevated [ Ca2+ ]i .
1,2 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

Deltorphin also increased accumulation of AP-1 transcription factor complexes , suggesting that DOR1 augments IL-2 secretion by increasing the AP-1 component of the NF-AT/AP-1 transcription factor .
6,8 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|23,26 G#protein

These results advance the molecular understanding of opioid effects on lymphocytes , and in addition , demonstrate regulation of IL-2 synthesis and secretion by the novel mechanism of receptor-mediated AP-1 induction .
10,11 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Induction of interleukin-12 p40 transcript by CD40 ligation via activation of nuclear factor-kappaB .
2,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#RNA|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

Interleukin-12 is produced in response to infection with bacteria or parasites or to bacterial constituents such as LPS in monocytes/macrophages and dendritic cells , and also generated by the interaction between activated T cells and antigen-presenting cells via CD40 -CD40 ligand ( CD40L ) .
0,1 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_type|35,37 G#cell_type|38,39 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|38,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

So far , transcriptional analyses of p40 have been carried out only using bacterial constituents such as LPS as stimuli .
6,7 G#protein

In the present study , we have characterized the transcriptional induction of p40 by CD40 ligation in a human B lymphoblastoid cell line , Daudi , and a human acute monocytic leukemia cell line , THP-1 .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,23 G#cell_line|24,25 G#cell_line|28,34 G#cell_line|35,36 G#cell_line

These cells , stimulated by an agonistic monoclonal antibody against CD40 or by transfection with a CD40L expression vector , secreted p40 and showed enhanced p40 mRNA expression .
10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,19 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#RNA

Sequence analysis of the p40 promoter region identified two potential nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappaB binding sites conserved between mouse and human .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|9,18 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay revealed that the potential NF-kappaB binding sequence which is located around 120 bp upstream of the transcription initiation site in murine and human p40 genes formed an NF-kappaB complex with nuclear extract from Daudi cells stimulated by CD40 ligation .
8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|24,29 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_line|41,42 G#protein

Moreover , transfection of Daudi cells with the polymerized NF-kappaB binding sequence ligated to a thymidine kinase /chloramphenicol acetyltransferase ( CAT ) reporter plasmid greatly induced CAT activity , but transfection with the polymerized mutated NF-kappaB binding sequence did not .
4,6 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|15,17 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|15,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|33,38 G#DNA

These results suggest that the NF-kappaB binding site located around 120 bp upstream of the transcription initiation site in murine and human p40 promoter regions could be important for the p40 induction by CD40 ligation via activation of NF-kappaB .
5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|19,25 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

High frequency of germ-line BRCA2 mutations among Hungarian male breast cancer patients without family history .
4,5 G#DNA

To determine the contribution of BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations to the pathogenesis of male breast cancer in Hungary , the country with the highest male breast cancer mortality rates in continental Europe , a series of 18 male breast cancer patients and three patients with gynecomastia was analyzed for germ-line mutations in both BRCA1 and BRCA2 .
5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|53,54 G#DNA|55,56 G#DNA

Although no germ-line BRCA1 mutation was observed , 6 of the 18 male breast cancer cases ( 33 % ) carried truncating mutations in the BRCA2 gene .
3,4 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA

Unexpectedly , none of them reported a family history for breast/ovarian cancer .


Four of six truncating mutations were novel , and two mutations were recurrent .


Four patients ( 22 % ) had a family history of breast/ovarian cancer in at least one first- or second-degree relative ; however , no BRCA2 mutation was identified among them .
25,26 G#DNA

No mutation was identified in either of the genes in the gynecomastias .


These results provide evidence for a strong genetic component of male breast cancer in Hungary .


T-cell expression of the human GATA-3 gene is regulated by a non-lineage-specific silencer .
4,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA

The GATA-3 transcription factor is required for development of the T-cell lineage and Th2 cytokine gene expression in CD4 T-cells .
1,4 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line|13,16 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_type

We have mapped the DNase-I-hypersensitive ( HS ) regions of the human GATA-3 gene in T-cells and non-T-cells and studied their transcriptional activities .
4,9 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|15,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type

HS I-III , located 5' from the transcriptional initiation site , were found in hematopoietic and non-hematopoietic cells , whereas HS IV-VII , located 3' from the transcriptional start site , were exclusively observed in T-cells .
0,2 G#DNA|7,10 G#DNA|14,18 G#cell_type|20,22 G#DNA|27,30 G#DNA|35,36 G#cell_type

Among these hypersensitive sites , two transcriptional control elements were found , one in the first intron of the GATA-3 gene and the other between 8.3 and 5.9 kilobases 5' from the GATA-3 transcriptional initiation site .
2,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|24,29 G#DNA|33,36 G#DNA|32,36 G#DNA

The first intron acted as a strong transcriptional activator in a position-dependent manner and with no cell-type specificity .
1,3 G#DNA

The upstream regulatory element could confer T-cell specificity to the GATA-3 promoter activity , and analysis of this region revealed a 707-base pair silencer that drastically inhibited GATA-3 promoter activity in non- T-cells .
1,4 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|21,24 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA|32,33 G#cell_type|31,33 G#cell_type

Two CAGGTG E-boxes , located at the 5'- and 3'- ends of the silencer , were necessary for this silencer activity .
1,3 G#DNA|7,11 G#DNA

The 3'-CAGGTG E-box could bind USF proteins , the ubiquitous repressor ZEB , or the basic helix-loop-helix proteins E2A and HEB , and we showed that a competition between ZEB and E2A /HEB proteins is involved in the silencer activity .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|31,34 G#protein

Reactive oxygen intermediate-dependent NF-kappaB activation by interleukin-1beta requires 5-lipoxygenase or NADPH oxidase activity .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

We previously reported that the role of reactive oxygen intermediates ( ROIs ) in NF-kappaB activation by proinflammatory cytokines was cell specific .
14,15 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

However , the sources for ROIs in various cell types are yet to be determined and might include 5-lipoxygenase ( 5-LOX ) and NADPH oxidase .
18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

5-LOX and 5-LOX activating protein ( FLAP ) are coexpressed in lymphoid cells but not in monocytic or epithelial cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|16,20 G#cell_type

Stimulation of lymphoid cells with interleukin-1beta ( IL-1beta ) led to ROI production and NF-kappaB activation , which could both be blocked by antioxidants or FLAP inhibitors , confirming that 5-LOX was the source of ROIs and was required for NF-kappaB activation in these cells .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

IL-1beta stimulation of epithelial cells did not generate any ROIs and NF-kappaB induction was not influenced by 5-LOX inhibitors .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

However , reintroduction of a functional 5-LOX system in these cells allowed ROI production and 5-LOX -dependent NF-kappaB activation .
6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

In monocytic cells , IL-1beta treatment led to a production of ROIs which is independent of the 5-LOX enzyme but requires the NADPH oxidase activity .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

This pathway involves the Rac1 and Cdc42 GTPases , two enzymes which are not required for NF-kappaB activation by IL-1beta in epithelial cells .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

In conclusion , three different cell-specific pathways lead to NF-kappaB activation by IL-1beta : a pathway dependent on ROI production by 5-LOX in lymphoid cells , an ROI- and 5-LOX -independent pathway in epithelial cells , and a pathway requiring ROI production by NADPH oxidase in monocytic cells .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type|43,45 G#protein|46,48 G#cell_type

Cutting edge : dominant effect of Ile50Val variant of the human IL-4 receptor alpha-chain in IgE synthesis .
6,8 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Two variants of the IL-4R alpha-chain ( IL-4Ralpha ) gene have been recently identified in association with different atopic disorders .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|4,10 G#DNA

To clarify the etiological relationship between the two variants , we analyzed responsiveness to IL-4 of transfectants with four kinds of IL-4Ralpha carrying either Val or Ile at 50 and either Gln or Arg at 551 .
14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

The substitution of Ile for Val augmented STAT6 activation , proliferation , and transcription activity of the Iepsilon promoter by IL-4 , whereas that of Arg for Gln did not change these IL-4 signals .
7,8 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Arg551 was not associated with atopic asthma in the Japanese population .


CD23 expression and IgE synthesis by IL-4 were augmented in Ile50 -bearing PBMC , compared with those bearing Val50 .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line

Taken together , substitution of Arg551 does not enhance the IL-4 signal for generation of germline epsilon transcript , whereas the substitution of Ile50 contributes to enhancement of IgE synthesis .
10,11 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

A novel growth-factor-dependent myeloid cell line derived from mouse bone marrow cells contains progenitors endowed with high proliferative potential .
2,6 G#cell_line|8,12 G#cell_type

Constitutive expression of human colony-stimulating factor-1 receptor ( CSF-1R ) confers long-lasting CSF-1 -dependent proliferation to mouse myeloid cell lines .
3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,20 G#cell_line

We developed mice transgenic for human CSF-1R because mouse CSF-1 can not activate human CSF-1R .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Then bone marrow cells from transgenic mice were plated onto MS-5 stromal cells expressing the membrane form of human CSF-1 ( 2M-1 cells ) in order to combine the hematopoietic supporting properties of stromal cells and the proliferative effects of CSF-1 .
1,4 G#cell_type|15,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_line|33,35 G#cell_type|40,41 G#protein

Thus , we were able to derive a hematopoietic cell line , called 47.10 , that grew indefinitely under these conditions , whereas no cell line could be developed from nontransgenic mice .
8,11 G#cell_line|13,14 G#cell_line

Proliferation of 47.10 cells is severely affected by neutralizing anti- CSF-1R monoclonal antibodies .
2,4 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|9,13 G#protein

Morphologic and cytofluorometry analysis established that most 47.10 cells are immature myelomonocytic cells .
7,9 G#cell_line|10,13 G#cell_type

Consistent with this phenotype , the myeloid transcription factor PU.1 , but not the erythroid transcription factor GATA-1 , is expressed in 47.10 cells .
9,10 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_line

A few 47.10 cells ( 3-5 % ) do not express lineage specific markers ; they differentiate spontaneously to lineage-positive cells after replating on 2M-1 cells .
2,4 G#cell_line|19,21 G#cell_line|24,26 G#cell_line

In agar cultures , 47.10 cells form 7- and 14-day colonies in response to a cocktail of granulocyte/macrophage colony-stimulating factor ( 2.5 ng/mL ) , interleukin-3 ( 1 ng/mL ) , and mouse CSF-1 ( 10 ng/mL ) .
4,6 G#cell_line|17,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Under these conditions , about 0.5 % of 47.10 cells formed large 14-day colonies ( &gt; 1 mm ) composed of mature monocytes and granulocytes , reflecting the presence of progenitors endowed with high proliferative potential ( HPP- 47.10 cells ) .
8,10 G#cell_line|21,23 G#cell_type|24,25 G#cell_type|38,40 G#cell_line|37,40 G#cell_line

In conclusion , we have characterized a novel continuous myeloid cell line presenting a hierarchical structure similar to that of the bone marrow progenitor cell compartment .
8,12 G#cell_line|21,26 G#cell_line

Regulation of IL-4 expression by the transcription factor JunB during T helper cell differentiation .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

The molecular basis for restricted cytokine expression by T helper 1 ( Th1 ) and T helper 2 ( Th2 ) cells is unclear .
5,6 G#protein|8,22 G#cell_type

Previous studies found that P1 , an element of the interleukin 4 ( IL-4 ) promoter that binds AP-1 , is important for Th2-restricted IL-4 expression .
4,5 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|10,16 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein

Here we show that JunB , but not the other Jun family members , was selectively induced in Th2 cells and not in Th1 cells during differentiation .
4,5 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|23,25 G#cell_type

JunB has previously been considered to be a negative regulator of transcription .
0,1 G#protein

However , we show that JunB binds directly to the P1 site and synergizes with c-Maf to activate an IL-4 luciferase reporter gene .
5,6 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA

JunB -control of IL-4 expression is mediated by the phosphorylation of JunB at Thr 102 and - 104 by JNK MAP kinase .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

The synergy between c-Maf and JunB can be attributed to cooperative DNA binding , which is facilitated by JunB phosphorylation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

In transgenic mice , elevated JunB levels caused increased expression of several Th2 cytokines in developing Th1 cells .
5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

JunB also upregulated IL-4 expression in response to immunization .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

Thus , the early increase of JunB protein in Th2 cells can provide the specificity for c-Maf in IL-4 expression during T cell development and directs thereby Th2 differentiation .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 tax protein abrogates interleukin-2 dependence in a mouse T-cell line .
0,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_line

Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) is the etiologic agent of adult T-cell leukemia .


Tax , the viral protein , is thought to be crucial in the development of the disease , since it transforms healthy T cells in vitro and induces tumors in transgenic animals .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type

We examined the effect of Tax activity on the growth of the interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) -dependent T-cell line CTLL-2 .
5,6 G#protein|12,19 G#cell_line|19,20 G#cell_line

Stable expression of Tax in CTLL-2 transformed cell growth from being IL-2 dependent to IL-2 independent .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Tax stimulated transcription through NF-kappaB and the cyclic AMP -responsive element-like sequence in the HTLV-1 promoter .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,12 G#DNA

The finding of Tax mutants segregating these two pathways suggested that the NF-kappaB pathway was essential for IL-2 -independent growth of CTLL-2 cells while the CRE pathway was unnecessary .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|25,26 G#DNA

However , both pathways were necessary for another transformation-related activity ( colony formation in soft agar ) of CTLL-2/ Tax .
19,20 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Our results show that Tax has at least two distinct activities on T cells , and suggest that Tax plays a crucial role in IL-2 -independent T-cell transformation induced by HTLV-1 , in addition to its well-known IL-2 -dependent cell transformation .
4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

Accessing Epstein-Barr virus -specific T-cell memory with peptide-loaded dendritic cells .
7,10 G#cell_line

The conventional means of studying Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) -induced cytotoxic T-lymphocyte ( CTL ) memory , by in vitro stimulation with the latently infected autologous lymphoblastoid cell line ( LCL ) , has important limitations .
11,13 G#cell_type|27,30 G#cell_line|31,32 G#cell_line

First , it gives no information on memory to lytic cycle antigens ; second , it preferentially amplifies the dominant components of latent antigen-specific memory at the expense of key subdominant reactivities .
9,12 G#protein

Here we describe an alternative approach , based on in vitro stimulation with epitope peptide-loaded dendritic cells ( DCs ) , which allows one to probe the CTL repertoire for any individual reactivity of choice ; this method proved significantly more efficient than stimulation with peptide alone .
14,17 G#cell_line|13,17 G#cell_line|18,19 G#cell_line

Using this approach we first show that reactivities to the immunodominant and subdominant lytic cycle epitopes identified by T cells during primary EBV infection are regularly detectable in the CTL memory of virus carriers ; this implies that in such carriers chronic virus replication remains under direct T-cell control .
13,16 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

We further show that subdominant latent cycle reactivities to epitopes in the latent membrane protein LMP2 , though rarely undetectable in LCL -stimulated populations , can be reactivated by DC stimulation and selectively expanded as polyclonal CTL lines ; the adoptive transfer of such preparations may be of value in targeting certain EBV-positive malignancies .
12,16 G#protein|21,22 G#cell_line|36,38 G#cell_line

Regulation of the human interleukin-2 gene by the alpha and beta isoforms of the glucocorticoid receptor .
3,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

The immunosuppressive effects of glucocorticoids are largely due to transcriptional inhibition of immunologically relevant genes , such as the interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) gene .
12,15 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|19,24 G#DNA

These effects are mediated by the intracellular glucocorticoid receptor ( GR ) .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

In humans , alternative splicing of the GR precursor mRNA gives rise to two receptor isoforms , termed GRalpha and GRbeta .
7,10 G#RNA|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

We previously demonstrated that GRbeta could antagonize GRalpha -mediated transactivation of a glucocorticoid- responsive element ( GRE ) -driven reporter gene in COS-7 cells .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|12,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#cell_line

The present study was designed to analyze the roles of the two GR isoforms on glucocorticoid-mediated transrepression of the IL-2 gene .
12,14 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

Using a recently developed transfection technique , we demonstrate that in primary human lymphocytes , stimulation of a 548 bp IL-2 promoter -luciferase reporter construct by phorbol ester and calcium ionophore is reversed by dexamethasone to a similar extent as in Jurkat T lymphoma cells transfected with a GRalpha expression vector .
11,14 G#cell_type|20,22 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|18,25 G#DNA|48,49 G#protein

Transfection of a GRbeta expression vector alone did not result in IL-2 promoter repression in response to glucocorticoids .
3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA

Furthermore , GRbeta did not antagonize the repressive effects of GRalpha on IL-2 promoter activity .
2,3 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

Surprisingly , overexpression of GRbeta in Jurkat cells did not cause significant inhibition of GRalpha -induced transactivation of a GRE-dependent luciferase reporter gene either .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA

We conclude that the transrepressive effect of glucocorticoids on IL-2 gene transcription is exclusively mediated by GRalpha .
9,11 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

GRbeta can neither antagonize GRalpha -mediated transactivation nor transrepression in Jurkat cells , indicating a cell type-specific pattern of GRbeta -mediated antiglucocorticoid activity .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein

Extinction of immunoglobulin gene expression in B cells upon fusion with HeLa cells is preceded by rapid nuclear depletion of essential transcription factors and is accompanied by widespread inactivation of genes expressed in a B cell-specific manner .
2,4 G#DNA|6,8 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_line|20,23 G#protein

When immunoglobulin ( Ig ) expressing B cells are fused with non-B cells , Ig expression is rapidly suppressed at the level of transcription , a phenomenon termed extinction .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|1,8 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type

Here we demonstrate that fusion of HeLa cells with either diploid or tetraploid B cells ( Daudi ) results in widespread extinction of several other B cell-encoded genes that are expressed in a B cell-specific manner .
6,8 G#cell_line|10,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_line|25,28 G#DNA

In contrast , expression of B cell-expressed genes that are not dependent on cell-specific controls is unaffected .
5,8 G#DNA

We show that the molecular mechanism ( s ) underlying Ig gene extinction can be explained , at least in part , by a lack of transcription factors that are essential for Ig gene transcription .
10,12 G#DNA|26,28 G#protein|32,34 G#DNA

These transcription factors are either not produced due to block of transcription of their respective genes ( Oct-2 , OBF-1 , PU.1 ) , or are rendered inactive posttranslationally ( NF-kappa B , E47 ) .
1,3 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|33,34 G#DNA

By isolating Daudi x HeLa heterokaryons a few hours after fusion , we have studied the initial fate of two B cell-specific transcription factors involved in Ig gene transcription , Oct-2 and NF-kappa B .
2,6 G#cell_line|22,24 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA|32,34 G#protein

This report provides the first demonstration that upon fusion with HeLa cells , the nuclear contents of B cell-expressed transcription factors are depleted within a few hours with kinetics that are as fast or faster than that of Ig gene extinction .
10,12 G#cell_line|19,21 G#protein|17,21 G#protein|38,40 G#DNA

Thus , the extinguishing mechanism is effective very early after fusion .


We suggest that extinction of Ig genes is part of a global mechanism that suppresses the differentiation program foreign to the HeLa phenotype .
5,7 G#DNA|21,23 G#cell_line

Evidence for suppressed activity of the transcription factor NFAT1 at its proximal binding element P0 in the IL-4 promoter associated with enhanced IL-4 gene transcription in T cells of atopic patients .
6,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|26,28 G#cell_type

Allergen-specific T cells in atopic patients are polarized IL-4-producing Th2 cells , promoting IgE synthesis by B cells .
1,3 G#cell_type|8,11 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

The molecular basis for increased IL-4 gene expression in atopy is not fully understood .
5,7 G#DNA

IL-4 gene regulation in general involves the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) family of transcription factors , of which NFAT1 and NFAT2 are most prominent in peripheral T cells .
0,2 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_type|7,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|7,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_type

Recently , a unique inhibitory role of NFAT1 in IL-4 gene control was shown in the mouse .
7,8 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA

In a series of electrophoretic mobility shift assays with protein extracts of highly polarized Th2 clones from atopics and Th1 clones from controls we compared DNA-binding activities at the two NFAT-binding elements P0 and P1 of the crucial proximal human IL-4 promoter .
12,16 G#cell_line|19,21 G#cell_line|30,32 G#DNA|32,33 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA|40,42 G#DNA

At the most proximal P0 site , NFAT-containing complexes devoid of NFAT2 were readily inducible in the Th1 clones , but hardly or not in the Th2 clones .
4,5 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line|26,28 G#cell_line

In contrast , both in Th1 and Th2 clones NFAT-containing complexes were strongly inducible at the P1 site , consisting of NFAT2 and a P0 -compatible NFAT activity , without apparent differences between Th1 and Th2 clones .
5,9 G#cell_line|16,18 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|33,37 G#cell_line

Like in Th2 clones , suppressed NFAT- P0 complex formation was observed also at the polyclonal level in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) of three of five severe atopic dermatitis patients with strongly elevated serum IgE levels , but not in control PBMC .
2,4 G#cell_line|7,8 G#DNA|18,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type|37,38 G#protein|44,45 G#cell_type

These findings suggest that high-level IL-4 production in atopic Th2 cells is associated with selective reduction of suppressive NFAT1 activity at the IL-4 P0 element and that some patients with this multifactorial disease may have a putative systemic disorder at this level .
5,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA

Differential expression and phosphorylation of CTCF , a c-myc transcriptional regulator , during differentiation of human myeloid cells .
5,6 G#protein

CTCF is a transcriptional repressor of the c-myc gene .
0,1 G#protein

Although CTCF has been characterized in some detail , there is very little information about the regulation of CTCF activity .
1,2 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Therefore we investigated CTCF expression and phosphorylation during induced differentiation of human myeloid leukemia cells .
3,4 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_type

We found that : ( i ) both CTCF mRNA and protein are down-regulated during terminal differentiation in most cell lines tested ; ( ii ) CTCF down-regulation is retarded and less pronounced than that of c-myc ; ( iii ) CTCF protein is differentially phosphorylated and the phosphorylation profiles depend on the differentiation pathway .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|26,27 G#protein|36,37 G#DNA|41,42 G#protein|41,43 G#protein

We concluded that CTCF expression and activity is controlled at transcriptional and post-transcriptional levels .
3,4 G#protein

Glucocorticoid resistance in the squirrel monkey is associated with overexpression of the immunophilin FKBP51 .
12,14 G#protein

Squirrel monkeys are neotropical primates that have high circulating cortisol to compensate for expression of glucocorticoid receptors ( GRs ) with reduced affinity .
15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The low binding affinity of squirrel monkey GR does not result from substitutions in the receptor , because squirrel monkey GR expressed in vitro exhibits high affinity .
7,8 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Rather , squirrel monkeys express a soluble factor that , in mixing studies of cytosol from squirrel monkey lymphocytes ( SML ) and mouse L929 cells , reduced GR binding affinity by 11-fold .
16,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type

In an effort to identify this factor , the cellular levels of components of the GR heterocomplex in SML and human lymphocytes ( HL ) were compared .
15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type

The immunophilin FKBP51 was 13-fold higher in SML than in HL cytosol ; FKBP52 in SML was 42 % of that in HL cytosol .
1,3 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type

A role for changes in immunophilins , causing glucocorticoid resistance in neotropical primates , is supported by the following : the changes in FKBP51 and FKBP52 were observed in cells from other neotropical primates with glucocorticoid resistance ; the elevated level of FKBP51 was reflected in an abundance of FKBP51 in heat shock protein 90 complexes in SML ; when cytosols of SML and L929 cells were mixed , the decrease in GR binding was associated with incorporation of FKBP51 into GR heterocomplexes ; the effect of SML cytosol on GR binding was reproduced with cytosol from COS cells expressing squirrel monkey FKBP51 ; and both the effect of SML cytosol on GR binding and the incorporation of FKBP51 into GR heterocomplexes were blocked by FK506 .
5,6 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|49,50 G#protein|51,56 G#protein|57,58 G#cell_type|62,63 G#cell_type|64,66 G#cell_line|79,80 G#protein|81,83 G#protein|87,88 G#cell_type|97,99 G#cell_line|102,103 G#protein|109,110 G#cell_type|118,119 G#protein|120,122 G#protein

Regulation of GR binding by FKBP51 represents a previously unrecognized mechanism for regulating glucocorticoid sensitivity .
5,6 G#protein

High-level replication of human immunodeficiency virus in thymocytes requires NF-kappaB activation through interaction with thymic epithelial cells .
7,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

We have previously demonstrated that interaction of infected thymocytes with autologous thymic epithelial cells ( TEC ) is a prerequisite for a high level of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) replication in thymocytes ( M.Rothe , L.Chene , M.Nugeyre , F.Barre-Sinoussi , and N.Israel , J.Virol.72 : 5852-5861 , 1998 ) .
8,9 G#cell_type|11,14 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type

We report here that this activation of HIV replication takes place at the transcriptional level through activation of the Rel/ NF-kappaB transcription factors .
20,21 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

We first demonstrate that an HIV-1 provirus ( SF-2 strain ) very effectively replicates in thymocytes cocultured with TEC whereas this provirus , with kappaB sites deleted , fails to replicate .
15,16 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|24,26 G#DNA

We provide evidence that several NF-kappaB complexes are constitutively found in the nuclei of thymocytes either freshly isolated from the thymus or maintained in coculture with autologous or heterologous TEC .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|29,30 G#cell_type

The prevalent complex is the heterodimer p50-p65 .
5,7 G#protein

NF-kappaB activity is tightly correlated with the transcriptional activity of a long terminal repeat ( LTR ) of HIV-1 transfected in thymocytes .
0,1 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|21,22 G#cell_type

The cotransfection of this LTR with a mutated IkappaBalpha molecule formally demonstrates that LTR transactivation is regulated by members of the Rel/ NF-kappaB family in thymocytes .
4,5 G#DNA|8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#cell_type

We also showed that tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) and to a lesser extent interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) , secreted within the coculture , induce NF-kappaB activity and a correlative LTR transactivation .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|31,32 G#DNA

However IL-7 , a crucial factor for thymopoiesis that is secreted mainly by TEC , is a necessary cofactor for NF-kappaB activation elicited by TNF or IL-1 .
1,2 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Together , these data indicate that NF-kappaB activation , required for a high level of HIV replication in thymocytes , is regulated in a specific manner in the thymic microenvironment which provides the necessary cytokines : TNF , IL-1 , and IL-7 .
6,7 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

Imbalanced expression of the glucocorticoid receptor isoforms in cultured lymphocytes from a patient with systemic glucocorticoid resistance and chronic lymphocytic leukemia .
4,7 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

The human glucocorticoid receptor ( GR ) is expressed as two alternatively spliced isoforms , GRalpha and GRbeta .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Whereas GRalpha is a hormone-activated transcription factor , GRbeta does not bind glucocorticoids ( GCs ) , is transcriptionally inactive , and is a potential inhibitor of activated GRalpha .
1,2 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Differential expression of GR isoforms may play a role in generalized or tissue-specific GC resistance .
3,5 G#protein

GCs induce apoptosis in neoplastic lymphoid cells ; and , defective apoptosis is implicated in the genesis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia ( CLL ) .
4,7 G#cell_type

We studied a patient with generalized GC resistance and CLL .


GR number in the patient 's transformed lymphocytes was approximately one half that of control cells with a approximately 10-fold reduction in binding affinity for dexamethasone .
6,8 G#cell_line

In vitro apoptosis induction in CLL cells was delayed in response to GCs , but not to other apoptosis inducers .
5,7 G#cell_line

Sequencing of the GR cDNA and gene including the 2.3-kb coding region , the intron/exon junctions , the known 5'-regulatory region , and approximately 300 bp of the 3'-region revealed no alterations .
3,5 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA

Western blot with an N-terminal antibody showed normal levels of immunoreactive GR , but quantitative analysis with isoform-specific C-terminal antibodies revealed a markedly reduced GRalpha expression , and high GRbeta expression .
10,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

These findings indicate that imbalanced expression of the GR isoforms may be a mechanism of GC resistance , and may have implications for tumorigenesis by enhancing cell survival .
8,10 G#protein

Copyright 1999 Academic Press .


Intranuclear targeted delivery of functional NF-kappaB by 70 kDa heat shock protein .
5,6 G#protein|7,12 G#protein

The 70 kDa heat shock protein ( Hsp70 ) is a highly conserved , ubiquitous protein involved in chaperoning proteins to various cellular organelles .
1,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Here we show that when added exogenously to cells , Hsp70 is readily imported into both cytoplasmic and nuclear compartments in a cell-type-specific fashion .
10,11 G#protein

We exploited this ability of Hsp70 to deliver NF-kappaB , a key transcriptional regulator of inflammatory responses .
5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

We demonstrate that a fusion protein composed of a C-terminal Hsp70 peptide and the p50 subunit of NF-kappaB was directed into the nucleus of cells , could bind DNA specifically , and activated Igkappa expression and TNFalpha production .
10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

We therefore propose that Hsp70 can be used as a vehicle for intracytoplasmic and intranuclear delivery of proteins or DNA to modulate gene expression and thereby control immune responses .
4,5 G#protein

Characterization of the human elk-1 promoter .
4,5 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA

Potential role of a downstream intronic sequence for elk-1 gene expression in monocytes .
4,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|12,13 G#cell_type

To characterize the human elk-1 promoter , we mapped the transcriptional start site and isolated elk-1 -specific genomic phage clones that contained extensive upstream and downstream sequences .
4,5 G#DNA|3,6 G#DNA|10,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|15,20 G#cell_line|23,27 G#DNA

A TATA-like motif was identified immediately upstream of the transcriptional start site .
1,3 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA

Functional analyses of DNA fragments containing the TATA element and the identification of a DNase I-hypersensitive chromatin site ( HS 1 ) in close proximity to the TATA box suggest that the identified TATA motif is important for elk-1 transcription in vivo .
3,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA|38,39 G#DNA

Sequences upstream and downstream from the TATA box were found to contribute to elk-1 promoter activity .
6,8 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA

A second hypersensitive site ( HS 2 ) was identified within the first intron in pre-monocytic cells , which express Elk-1 only when differentiating to monocytes .
25,26 G#cell_type

In a variety of other cell types , which display a constitutive Elk-1 expression , HS 2 did not exist , suggesting that inducibility of elk-1 expression is associated with the presence of HS 2 .
12,13 G#protein|25,26 G#DNA

Egr-1 and the serum response factor were found to interact specifically with the intronic sequence at +265 and +448 , respectively .
13,15 G#DNA

Because Egr-1 mRNA and protein levels were observed to increase significantly before induction of elk-1 expression , we propose that Egr-1 is important for the regulation of elk-1 transcription in differentiating monocytes .
1,3 G#RNA|14,15 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|27,28 G#DNA|31,32 G#cell_type

Immunohistochemical study of c-fos-positive lymphocytes infiltrated into human squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck during radiation therapy and its clinical significance .
3,5 G#protein

C-fos has been reported to be one of the immediate early genes in signal transduction systems after many kinds of stresses , including ionizing radiation .
0,1 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA

Changes in c-fos expression induced by radiation therapy in tumor tissues have not yet been reported .
2,3 G#DNA

In this study , we have attempted to determine whether c-fos expression is induced by radiotherapy in human squamous cell carcinomas of the head and neck and to establish a possible correlation between c-fos expression and the therapeutic effects of radiation therapy .
10,11 G#DNA|33,34 G#DNA

Twenty-seven patients with tumors of the oral cavity , oropharynx , and maxillary sinus were examined , all of which were confirmed as squamous cell carcinomas .


After obtaining the patients ' informed consent , biopsies were performed before treatment and at doses of 4 , 10 , and 20 Gy of radiotherapy , and the specimens were preserved in liquid nitrogen for further examination .


Serial sectioning of 6 micrometer was performed using a cryostat , and samples were immunohistochemically stained using the streptoavidin -biotin peroxidase method and a monoclonal antibody against c-fos .
18,19 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Three of the 27 patients with squamous cell carcinoma showed slight expression of c-fos in their tumor cells before and/or at 4 or 10 Gy of radiotherapy .


The tumors showed high radiosensitivity .


Concerning tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes , the rate of moderate or remarkable grades of c-fos-positive lymphocytes before radiotherapy and at radiation doses of 4 , 10 , and 20 Gy was 8.0 , 29.2 , 4.8 , and 0 % , respectively .
1,3 G#cell_type|12,14 G#protein

The relationship between the immunohistochemical findings and the antitumor effect at a radiation dose of 20 Gy was examined on the corresponding H &amp; E-stained sections .


In patients whose infiltration of c-fos-positive lymphocytes into tumor tissues were moderate or remarkable at 4 Gy of radiotherapy , the tumors responded significantly well to radiation therapy ( P &lt; 0.025 , chi2 test ) , and the patients took a significantly favorable clinical course ( P &lt; 0.05 , chi2 test ) .
5,7 G#protein

In a sample from one of the patients , c-fos-positive lymphocytes were identified as CD4 positive and CD8 negative .
9,11 G#protein

Therefore , the high radiosensitivity of squamous cell carcinomas in our samples could be explained by an overexpression of c-fos in the tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes induced by small doses of radiation therapy , and these activated lymphocytes exerted a cytotoxic effect against the cancer cells .
19,20 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type|34,36 G#cell_type|42,44 G#cell_type

Paternal expression of WT1 in human fibroblasts and lymphocytes .
3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#cell_type

The Wilms ' tumor suppressor gene ( WT1 ) was previously identified as being imprinted , with frequent maternal expression in human placentae and fetal brains .
1,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein

We examined the allele-specific expression of WT1 in cultured human fibroblasts from 15 individuals .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Seven of 15 fibroblast lines were heterozygous for polymorphic alleles , and the expression patterns were variable , i.e. , equal , unequal or monoallelic paternal expression in three , two and two cases , respectively .
3,5 G#cell_line|8,10 G#DNA

Exclusive paternal expression of WT1 was also shown in non-cultured peripheral lymphocytes from the latter two individuals .
4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

The allele-specific expression profiles of other imprinted genes , IGF2 and H19 , on human chromosome 11 were constant and consistent with those in other tissues .
6,8 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

Our unexpected observations of paternal or biallelic expression of WT1 in fibroblasts and lymphocytes , together with the previous findings of maternal or biallelic expression in placentae and brains , suggest that the allele-specific regulatory system of WT1 is unique and may be controlled by a putative tissue- and individual-specific modifier .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|37,38 G#protein

T cell reactivity to Sjogren 's syndrome related antigen La ( SSB ) .
9,13 G#protein

OBJECTIVE .


Many patients with primary Sjogren 's syndrome ( SS ) make high titer IgG autoantibodies to the La ( SSB ) antigen , suggesting antigen specific T cell-B cell interactions .
13,15 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

T cell responses to some nuclear antigens , particularly U1RNP , have been detected in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE ) and in healthy subjects .
9,10 G#protein

We investigated T cell reactivity to the autoantigen SSB in patients with SS and healthy controls .
7,9 G#protein

METHODS .


Using the [3H]thymidine proliferation assay , we determined reactivity to purified recombinant SSB ( rSSB ) in 20 patients with SS and 19 controls .
10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Specificity was determined using tetanus toxoid , endotoxin , and 3 other autoantigens ( PBC.M2 , Sc170 , and GAD ) .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Precursor frequency was calculated by limiting dilution analysis .


HLA Class II dependency was investigated using anti-Class II monoclonal antibodies .
7,11 G#protein

HLA-DR typing was by polymerase chain reaction and sequence specific oligonucleotide typing .


RESULTS .


Six of 20 patients with SS and 10/19 controls proliferated to La ( rSSB ) .
13,14 G#protein

Precursor frequency of anti-SSB T cells was 1:77,040 and 1:115,000 in 2 healthy subjects and 1:230,250 and 1:103,034 in two patients with SS .
3,6 G#cell_line

Anti- HLA-DR abrogated proliferation to SSB and tetanus toxoid .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Thirteen of 15 patients with SS and 4/17 controls were HLA-DR3 positive , with no apparent association of HLA-DR3 with SSB reactivity in controls .
10,11 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

CONCLUSION .


Anti- La(SSB) specific T cells occur in a significant proportion of controls and in some patients with SS .
1,2 G#protein|0,5 G#cell_line

The function of SSB T cells in controls remains to be defined .
3,6 G#cell_line

They may represent immunoregulatory cells , and further analysis of these cells , and a comparison to those found in patients with SS , may elucidate normal immunoregulation and the derangements that lead to Sjogren 's syndrome .
3,5 G#cell_type

Anti-rheumatic compound aurothioglucose inhibits tumor necrosis factor-alpha -induced HIV-1 replication in latently infected OM10.1 and Ach2 cells .
4,7 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_line

NF-kappaB is a potent cellular activator of HIV-1 gene expression .
0,1 G#protein

Down-regulation of NF-kappaB activation is known to inhibit HIV replication from the latently infected cells .
2,3 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

Gold compounds have been effectively used for many decades in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis .


We previously reported that gold compounds , especially aurothioglucose ( AuTG ) containing monovalent gold ion , inhibited the DNA-binding of NF-kappaB in vitro .
21,22 G#protein

In this report we have examined the efficacy of the gold compound AuTG as an inhibitor of HIV replication in latently infected OM10.1 and Ach2 cells .
22,26 G#cell_line

Tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) -alpha -induced HIV-1 replication in OM10.1 or Ach2 cells was significantly inhibited by non-cytotoxic doses of AuTG ( &gt; 10 microM in OM10.1 cells and &gt; 25 F.M in Ach2 cells ) , while 25 microM of the counter-anion thioglucose ( TG ) or gold compound containing divalent gold ion , HAuCl3 , had no effect .
0,7 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_line|13,15 G#cell_line|35,37 G#cell_line|44,46 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

The effect of AuTG on NF-kappaB -dependent gene expression was confirmed by a transient CAT assay .
5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Specific staining as well as electron microscopic examinations revealed the accumulation of metal gold in the cells , supporting our previous hypothesis that gold ions could block NF-kappaB -DNA binding by a redox mechanism .
27,28 G#protein

These observations indicate that the monovalent gold compound AuTG is a potentially useful drug for the treatment of patients infected with HIV .


Clonality of isolated eosinophils in the hypereosinophilic syndrome .
2,4 G#cell_type

The idiopathic hypereosinophilic syndrome ( IHES ) is a rare disorder characterized by unexplained , persistent eosinophilia associated with multiple organ dysfunction due to eosinophilic tissue infiltration .


In the absence of karyotypic abnormalities , there is no specific test to detect clonal eosinophilia in IHES .


Analysis of X-chromosome inactivation patterns can be used to determine whether proliferative disorders are clonal in origin .
2,3 G#DNA

Methylation of HpaII and Hha I sites near the polymorphic trinucleotide repeat of the human androgen receptor gene ( HUMARA ) has been shown to correlate with X-inactivation .
2,7 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA

In this study , we have used the polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) with nested primers to analyze X-inactivation patterns of the HUMARA loci in purified eosinophils from female patients with eosinophilia .
23,24 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA|26,28 G#cell_type

Peripheral blood eosinophils were isolated by their autofluoresence using flow cytometric sorting .
0,3 G#cell_type

Eosinophils purified from a female patient presenting with IHES were found to show a clonal pattern of X-inactivation .
0,1 G#cell_type

Eosinophil-depleted leukocytes from this patient were polyclonal by HUMARA analysis , thus excluding skewedness of random X- inactivation .
0,2 G#cell_type|8,9 G#DNA

After corticosteroid suppression of her blood eosinophilia , a clonal population of eosinophils could no longer be detected in purified eosinophils .
12,13 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type

In contrast , eosinophils purified from a patient with Churg-Strauss syndrome and from six patients with reactive eosinophilias attributed to allergy , parasitic infection , or drug reaction showed a polyclonal pattern of X-inactivation by HUMARA analysis .
3,4 G#cell_type|35,36 G#DNA

The finding of clonal eosinophilia in a patient presenting with IHES indicates that such patients may have , in reality , a low-grade clonal disorder that can be distinguished from reactive eosinophilias by HUMARA analysis .
33,34 G#DNA

Further , the method described can be used to monitor disease progression .


GA-binding protein factors , in concert with the coactivator CREB binding protein/p300 , control the induction of the interleukin 16 promoter in T lymphocytes .
0,3 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#cell_type

Interleukin 16 ( IL-16 ) is a chemotactic cytokine that binds to the CD4 receptor and affects the activation of T cells and replication of HIV .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

It is expressed as a large 67-kDa precursor protein ( pro-IL-16 ) in lymphocytes , macrophages , and mast cells , as well as in airway epithelial cells from asthmatics after challenge with allergen .
6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type|25,28 G#cell_type

This pro-IL-16 is subsequently processed to the mature cytokine of 13 kDa .
1,2 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

To study the expression of IL-16 at the transcriptional level , we cloned the human chromosomal IL-16 gene and analyzed its promoter .
5,6 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA

The human IL-16 gene consists of seven exons and six introns .
2,3 G#protein|1,4 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA

The 5' sequences up to nucleotide -120 of the human and murine IL-16 genes share &gt; 84 % sequence homology and harbor promoter elements for constitutive and inducible transcription in T cells .
1,3 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|21,24 G#DNA|30,32 G#cell_type

Although both promoters lack any TATA box , they contain two CAAT box-like motifs and three binding sites of GA-binding protein ( GABP ) transcription factors .
5,7 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|19,26 G#protein

Two of these motifs are part of a highly conserved and inducible dyad symmetry element shown previously to control a remote IL-2 enhancer and the CD18 promoter .
12,15 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA

In concert with the coactivator CREB binding protein/p300 , which interacts with GABPalpha , the binding of GABPalpha and -beta to the dyad symmetry element controls the induction of IL-16 promoter in T cells .
4,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA|32,34 G#cell_type

Supplementing the data on the processing of pro-IL-16 , our results indicate the complexity of IL-16 expression , which is tightly controlled at the transcriptional and posttranslational levels in T lymphocytes .
7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type

Tuberculosis and chronic hepatitis B virus infection in Africans and variation in the vitamin D receptor gene .
13,17 G#DNA

The active metabolite of vitamin D , 1,25 dihydroxyvitamin D3 , is an important immunoregulatory hormone [ 1 ] .


Its effects are exerted by interaction with the vitamin D receptor , which is present on human monocytes and activated T and B lymphocytes .
8,11 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|19,24 G#cell_type

Variation in the vitamin D receptor gene was typed in 2015 subjects from large case-control studies of three major infectious diseases : tuberculosis , malaria , and hepatitis B virus .
3,6 G#protein|3,7 G#DNA

Homozygotes for a polymorphism at codon 352 ( genotype tt ) were significantly underrepresented among those with tuberculosis ( chi2 = 6.22 , 1 df , P = .01 ) and persistent hepatitis B infection ( chi2 = 6.25 , 1 df , P = .01 ) but not in subjects with clinical malaria compared with the other genotypes .
5,7 G#DNA

Therefore , this genetic variant , which predisposes to low bone mineral density in many populations , may confer resistance to certain infectious diseases .


Inhibition of NF-kappa B activation in vitro and in vivo : role of 26S proteasome .
2,4 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

It is becoming increasingly apparent that NF-kappa B plays a critical role in regulating the inflammatory response .
6,8 G#protein

Data obtained from studies in our laboratories demonstrate that the proteasome plays an important role in the inflammatory cascade by regulating the activation of NF-kappa B .
24,26 G#protein

Indeed , the availability of selective and orally active proteasome inhibitors should prove useful in delineating the roles of the proteasome and NF-kappa B in other pathophysiological conditions such as cancer and heart disease .
22,24 G#protein

Tissue factor expression of human monocytes is suppressed by lysophosphatidylcholine .
4,6 G#cell_type

The expression of tissue factor ( TF ) , the principal initiator of coagulation , is increased during inflammation and atherosclerosis .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Both conditions are promoted by lysophosphatidylcholine ( lysoPC ) .


We observed in the present study that lysoPC ( 1 to 10 micromol/L ) dose-dependently reduced TF activity in human monocytes , as elicited by lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) .
16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

Lysophosphatidylethanolamine ( lysoPE ) and other lysophospholipids did not affect LPS -induced TF activity of human monocytes .
15,17 G#cell_type

TF antigen expression as elicited by LPS was also lowered by lysoPC .


Phospholipid analyses indicated a selective increase in the lysoPC content of the monocytes after preincubation with the lysophospholipid .
12,13 G#cell_type

LysoPC inhibited the TF activity of Mono Mac-6 cells to a similar extent as in the monocytes .
6,9 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_type

LPS binding to plasma membrane receptors and internalization of LPS into monocytes were not affected by lysoPC .
11,12 G#cell_type

In contrast , LPS -mediated nuclear binding of nuclear factor-kappaB/Rel to a TF-specific kappaB site was inhibited by lysoPC .
8,10 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA

Induction of TF mRNA expression by LPS tended to be partially reduced by the lysophospholipid .
2,4 G#RNA

Preincubation with lysoPC increased monocytic cAMP levels .


Inhibition of adenylyl cyclase by pretreatment with 2'-deoxy-3'-adenosine monophosphate partially reversed the inhibition of TF activity promoted by lysoPC .
2,4 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

In conclusion , lysoPC markedly decreases LPS -mediated TF expression of human monocytes , the effect probably being mediated by both transcriptional and posttranscriptional mechanisms .
11,13 G#cell_type

LysoPC may thus attenuate activation of coagulation during inflammation and atherosclerosis .


Regulation of fas-ligand expression during activation-induced cell death in T lymphocytes via nuclear factor kappaB .
9,11 G#cell_type|12,15 G#protein

T cell receptor engagement activates transcription factors important for cytokine gene regulation .
5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA

Additionally , this signaling pathway also leads to activation-induced apoptosis in T lymphocytes that is dependent on FasL transcription and expression .
11,13 G#cell_type

Here we demonstrate that nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) , which is involved in the transcriptional regulation of many cytokine genes expressed in activated lymphocytes , also plays a role in T cell activation-induced FasL expression .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein

Inhibition of NF-kappaB activity in a T cell hybridoma leads to decreased FasL expression and apoptosis upon T cell receptor stimulation .
2,3 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

We identified the NF-kappaB site in the FasL promoter that contributes to such regulation .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA

Co-expression of p65 ( Rel A ) with the FasL promoter enhanced its activity , and co-expression of IkappaB dramatically inhibited the inducible promoter activity .
2,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA

In contrast , the transcription factor AP-1 is not required for activation-induced FasL promoter activity .
4,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

These results define a role for NF-kappaB in mediating FasL expression during T cell activation .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Promoter sequence , exon : intron structure , and synteny of genetic location show that a chicken cytokine with T-cell proliferative activity is IL2 and not IL15 .
0,2 G#DNA|3,7 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

The gene encoding a chicken cytokine with T-cell proliferative activity was cloned , sequenced , and mapped .
4,6 G#protein

The results show that this cytokine is chicken IL2 and not IL15 .
5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein
