This induction of C/EBP epsilon mRNA expression is transcriptionally mediated and occurs in the absence of synthesis of additional protein factors .
3,6 G#RNA|19,21 G#protein

We suspect that the C/EBP epsilon promoter/enhancer contains a retinoic acid-response element that is directly stimulated by retinoids .
4,7 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA

Dual effects of LPS antibodies on cellular uptake of LPS and LPS -induced proinflammatory functions .
3,5 G#protein

Human phagocytes recognize bacterial LPS ( endotoxin ) through membrane CD14 ( mCD14 ) , a proinflammatory LPS receptor .
0,2 G#cell_type|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

This study tested the hypothesis that anti- LPS Abs neutralize endotoxin by blocking cellular uptake through mCD14 .
6,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Ab-associated changes in the uptake and cellular distribution of FITC- LPS were assessed by flow cytometry and laser scanning confocal microscopy in human CD14-transfected Chinese hamster ovary fibroblasts ( CHO-CD14 cells ) and human peripheral blood monocytes .
22,28 G#cell_line|29,31 G#cell_line|33,37 G#cell_type

LPS core- and O-side chain- specific mAbs inhibited mCD14 -mediated LPS uptake by both cell types in the presence of serum .
1,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

O-side chain-specific mAb concurrently enhanced complement-dependent LPS uptake by monocytes through complement receptor-1 ( CR1 ) and uptake by CHO-CD14 cells involving another heat-labile serum factor ( s ) and cell-associated recognition molecule ( s ) .
0,3 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_line|23,26 G#protein|30,33 G#protein

Core-specific mAb inhibited mCD14 -mediated uptake of homologous and heterologous LPS , while producing less concurrent enhancement of non- mCD14 -mediated LPS uptake .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The modulation by anti- LPS mAbs of mCD14 -mediated LPS uptake was associated with inhibition of LPS -induced nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) translocation and TNF-alpha secretion in CHO-CD14 cells and monocytes , respectively , while mAb enhancement of non- mCD14 -mediated LPS uptake stimulated these activities .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_line|40,41 G#protein

LPS -specific Abs thus mediate anti-inflammatory and proinflammatory functions , respectively , by preventing target cell uptake of LPS through mCD14 and augmenting uptake through CR1 or other cell receptors .
0,3 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

Four P-like elements are required for optimal transcription of the mouse IL-4 gene : involvement of a distinct set of nuclear factor of activated T cells and activator protein-1 family proteins .
1,3 G#DNA|10,13 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_type|20,26 G#protein|27,31 G#protein

We previously identified the P sequence as a critical regulatory element of the human IL-4 promoter .
4,6 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

In the mouse IL-4 promoter , there are five elements homologous to the human P sequence designated conserved lymphokine element 0 ( CLE0 ) , P , P2 , P3 and P4 .
2,5 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|17,21 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA|29,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA

To characterize the role of these P -like elements and their binding factors in the native promoter , we did transient transfection and electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSA ) .
6,7 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

Transfection of EL-4 cells with the IL-4 promoter-reporter constructs carrying mutated P -like elements showed that four P-like elements , CLE0 , P , P2 and P4 , but not P3 , were required for optimal activation of the IL-4 promoter .
2,4 G#cell_line|6,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA|39,41 G#DNA

EMSA showed that both constitutive and inducible complexes bound to CLE0 , P , P2 and P4 , whereas only a constitutive complex bound to P3 .
10,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA

In competition and antibody supershift assays in EMSA , complexes formed with P or P2 proved to contain nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) family proteins as major components .
12,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|18,29 G#protein

Activator protein ( AP ) -1 family proteins interacted with CLE0 , P , P2 and P4 .
0,8 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA

NFAT/AP-1 complex formed only with P and P2 .
0,2 G#protein|5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA

Cross-competition assays among the P-like elements revealed element-specific and common complexes .
4,6 G#DNA|7,11 G#protein

Six tandem repeats of the P element linked to the SV40 promoter responded to phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate , while that of other elements did not . It would thus appear that components of each P-like element-binding complexes are not identical and may coordinately contribute to transcriptional activity .
5,7 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|34,37 G#protein

Constitutive expression c-fos , c-jun , and NF kappa B mRNA is in nucleated fetal blood cells and up-regulation of c-fos and c-jun with anti-CD3 stimulation .
2,11 G#RNA|13,17 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Fetal and neonatal lymphocytes are relatively resistant to activation and cytokine production when stimulated either via their T-cell antigen receptors or lectins .
0,4 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The molecular mechanism ( s ) responsible for this phenomenon have not been clearly elucidated .
1,3 G#protein

We have hypothesized that such defects in fetal/neonatal T-cell activation may be due to lack of expression of the transcriptional regulatory elements required for T-cell activation .
19,22 G#protein

We used reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction to examine both fetal and term neonatal cord bloods for mRNA expression of three transcription factors implicated in T-cell activation : c-jun , c-fos , and NF kappa B ( p50 subunit ) .
2,4 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

We demonstrate that mRNAs for all three of these regulatory factors are expressed in fetal blood cells by the 27th week of gestation and in term cord bloods .
3,4 G#RNA|14,17 G#cell_type

Activation of term infant cord blood mononuclear cells with anti-CD3 monoclonal antibodies resulted in up-regulation of both c-jun and c-fos mRNAs within 15 min of stimulation .
2,8 G#cell_type|9,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#RNA

However , secretion of IL-2 by anti-CD3-stimulated cord blood mononuclear cells was still blunted compared with control cells from adults .
4,5 G#protein|6,11 G#cell_line|16,18 G#cell_type

We conclude that fetal nucleated blood cells constitutively express important genes for cytokine regulation and are able to increase intracellular accumulation of the mRNAs for these factors in response to anti-CD3 stimulation .
3,7 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|23,24 G#RNA|30,31 G#protein

Thus , qualitative differences in the capacity to regulate these factors could not be shown in fetal blood cells .
16,19 G#cell_type

Quantitative experiments comparing binding of these transcription factors to the IL-2 promoter are currently under investigation .
6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

Nuclear accumulation of NFAT4 opposed by the JNK signal transduction pathway .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

The nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) group of transcription factors is retained in the cytoplasm of quiescent cells .
1,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

NFAT activation is mediated in part by induced nuclear import .
0,1 G#protein

This process requires calcium -dependent dephosphorylation of NFAT caused by the phosphatase calcineurin .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The c-Jun amino-terminal kinase ( JNK ) phosphorylates NFAT4 on two sites .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Mutational removal of the JNK phosphorylation sites caused constitutive nuclear localization of NFAT4 .
4,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In contrast , JNK activation in calcineurin -stimulated cells caused nuclear exclusion of NFAT4 .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein

These findings show that the nuclear accumulation of NFAT4 promoted by calcineurin is opposed by the JNK signal transduction pathway .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Thiol modulation inhibits the interleukin ( IL ) -1 -mediated activation of an IL-1 receptor-associated protein kinase and NF-kappa B .
4,9 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

The interleukin-1 receptor type I ( IL-1RI ) is associated with other proteins thus forming a complex system by which IL-1 exerts its various signals .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

The initiating event is still uncertain , but activation of a recently described receptor-associated protein kinase is one of the earliest events detectable ( Martin et al. , Eur.J.Immunol.1994.24 : 1566 ) .
13,16 G#protein

IL-1 signaling is commonly accompanied by oxidative processes and is thought to be subject to redox regulation .
0,1 G#protein

We therefore investigated whether the activation of the IL-1RI -associated protein kinase could be a target for redox regulation and whether an altered activity of the kinase could influence IL-1 -mediated NF-kappa B activation .
8,9 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

A murine T cell line , EL4 , was stimulated with IL-1 with and without pretreatment with different compounds known to influence the cellular redox status .
1,5 G#cell_line|6,7 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

Thiol modifying agents like diamide , menadione , pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ( PDTC ) , diethyl dithiocarbamate or phenylarsine oxide inhibited the IL-1 -induced activation of the IL-1RI-associated protein kinase .
21,22 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

N-Acetylcysteine , alpha,alpha'-dipyridyl , aminotriazole or nitrofurantoin did not show any effect .


The inhibition by PDTC was reversible unless glutathione synthesis was blocked by buthionine sulfoximine .


The described conditions which inhibited or prevented the activation of the IL-1RI -associated kinase similarly impaired the activation of NF-kappa B in EL4 cells .
11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_line

From these observations we conclude that free thiols in the IL-1RI complex are essential for the activation of the IL-1RI -associated protein kinase and that this process is mandatory for IL-1 signaling leading to NF-kappa B activation .
10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

Switching gears during T-cell maturation : RANTES and late transcription .
6,7 G#protein

Although much is understood about the induction of genes expressed early ( within 24 h ) after T-cell activation , little is known about the regulation of expression of genes expressed ' late ' ( three or more days ) post-stimulation .
8,9 G#DNA|29,30 G#DNA

A better understanding of transcriptional regulation at this important stage of T-cell maturation may yield new insights into T-cell development and new immunotherapeutic targets .


Involvement of different transduction pathways in NF-kappa B activation by several inducers .
6,8 G#protein|11,12 G#DNA

Double-stimulation was used to demonstrate that , in a T lymphocytic cell line ( CEM ) , phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) rapidly induced NF-kappa B through a signaling pathway which did not involve reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) and was different from the activation triggered by either H2O2 or tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) .
9,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|25,27 G#protein|52,55 G#protein|56,57 G#protein

Since these latter compounds were known to activate NF-kappa B translocation in a redox-sensitive way , we have demonstrated that NF-kappa B activation by PMA was resistant to antioxidant N-acetyl-L-cysteine ( NAC ) and sensitive to kinase inhibitors staurosporine and H7 while activation by H2O2 or TNF-alpha were not .
8,10 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

Blockade of T-cell activation by dithiocarbamates involves novel mechanisms of inhibition of nuclear factor of activated T cells .
12,18 G#protein

Dithiocarbamates ( DTCs ) have recently been reported as powerful inhibitors of NF-kappaB activation in a number of cell types .
12,13 G#protein

Given the role of this transcription factor in the regulation of gene expression in the inflammatory response , NF-kappaB inhibitors have been suggested as potential therapeutic drugs for inflammatory diseases .
18,19 G#protein

We show here that DTCs inhibited both interleukin 2 ( IL-2 ) synthesis and membrane expression of antigens which are induced during T-cell activation .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

This inhibition , which occurred with a parallel activation of c-Jun transactivating functions and expression , was reflected by transfection experiments at the IL-2 promoter level , and involved not only the inhibition of NF-kappaB -driven reporter activation but also that of nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) .
10,11 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|34,35 G#protein|42,48 G#protein|49,50 G#protein

Accordingly , electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSAs ) indicated that pyrrolidine DTC ( PDTC ) prevented NF-kappaB , and NFAT DNA-binding activity in T cells stimulated with either phorbol myristate acetate plus ionophore or antibodies against the CD3-T-cell receptor complex and simultaneously activated the binding of AP-1 .
17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|38,41 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

Furthermore , PDTC differentially targeted both NFATp and NFATc family members , inhibiting the transactivation functions of NFATp and mRNA induction of NFATc .
6,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Strikingly , Western blotting and immunocytochemical experiments indicated that PDTC promoted a transient and rapid shuttling of NFATp and NFATc , leading to their accelerated export from the nucleus of activated T cells .
17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_type

We propose that the activation of an NFAT kinase by PDTC could be responsible for the rapid shuttling of the NFAT , therefore transiently converting the sustained transactivation of this transcription factor that occurs during lymphocyte activation , and show that c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase ( JNK ) can act by directly phosphorylating NFATp .
20,21 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|41,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|52,53 G#protein

In addition , the combined inhibitory effects on NFAT and NF-KB support a potential use of DTCs as immunosuppressants .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Activation of a novel gene in 3q21 and identification of intergenic fusion transcripts with ecotropic viral insertion site I in leukemia .
3,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|14,19 G#DNA

We have identified a novel gene , GR6 , located within the leukemia breakpoint region of 3q21 , that is normally expressed in early fetal development but not in adult peripheral blood .
4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA

GR6 is activated in the UCSD-AML1 cell line and in a leukemic sample , both of which carry a t(3;3)(q21;q26) .
0,1 G#DNA|5,8 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_line|19,20 G#DNA

In UCSD-AML1 , we have also identified fusion transcripts between the ecotropic viral insertion site I ( EVI1 ) gene in 3q26 and GR6 and between EVI1 and Ribophorin I that maps 30 kb telomeric to GR6 in 3q21 .
1,2 G#cell_line|7,9 G#RNA|11,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|36,37 G#DNA|38,39 G#DNA

All fusions splice the 5' ends of the 3q21 genes into exon 2 of the EVI1 gene , an event that is similar to the normal intergenic splicing of MDS1- EVI1 and to those previously documented in leukemias with t(3;21) and t(3;12) , in which acute myelogenous leukemia 1- EVI1 fusions and ETV6- EVI1 fusions , respectively , occur .
4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA|39,40 G#DNA|41,42 G#DNA|49,50 G#DNA|46,51 G#DNA|53,54 G#DNA|52,55 G#DNA

The Ribophorin I -EVI1 fusion in particular may be a common occurrence in t(3;3) .
1,3 G#DNA|3,4 G#DNA|1,5 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA

The A-myb transcription factor in neoplastic and normal B cells .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|5,10 G#cell_type

The myb family of transcription factors has been strongly implicated in the regulation of cell growth and differentiation in the haematopoietic system .
1,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

The v-myb oncogene , carried by avian defective retroviruses , causes leukaemias in the chicken and transforms haematopoietic cells in vitro .
1,3 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_type

Its normal cellular equivalent c-myb , has been shown to promote the proliferation and block the differentiation of haematopoietic cells in several experimental models and is required for fetal haematopoiesis .
4,5 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_type

Two other members of the family have been cloned more recently , A-myb and B-myb , which show sequence homology with c-myb in several domains , of which the DNA binding domain as well as other regulatory domains .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA|29,32 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

Both have been shown to be transcription factors .
6,8 G#protein

B-myb is also involved in the control of proliferation and differentiation , but , unlike c-myb , it is expressed in many cell types .
0,1 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA

The third member of the family , A-myb , shows the most restricted pattern of expression , suggesting a very specific role for this transcription factor .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

A-myb is expressed in a subpopulation of normal B lymphocytes activated in vivo and localised in the germinal center of peripheral lymphoid organs and is not detected at significant levels in all other mature or immature haematopoietic populations studied , including bone marrow cells , T lymphocytes , granulocytes , monocytes , either at rest or after in vitro activation .
0,1 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type|35,38 G#cell_type|41,44 G#cell_type|45,47 G#cell_type|48,49 G#cell_type|50,51 G#cell_type

These studies indicate that A-myb plays a role during a narrow window of normal B cell differentiation .
4,5 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_type

A-myb expression has also been studied in a wide range of neoplastic B cells , representing the whole spectrum of B cell differentiation .
0,1 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

A-myb is strongly expressed in Burkitt 's lymphomas ( BL ) and slg+ B-acute lymphoblastic leukaemias ( B-ALL ) and not in all other leukaemias /lymphomas tested , with the exception of a subset of CLL ( about 25 % of cases ) .
0,1 G#protein

It is intriguing that the A-myb genome has been localised relatively close to the c-myc gene on chromosome 8 , suggesting that the c-myc translocation in BL and B-ALL may affect A-myb transcription .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|31,32 G#protein

Studies are in progress to investigate the functional relationship between A-myb and c-myc , particularly in the context of BL cells and to determine whether A-myb is deregulated in these cells .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA|19,21 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

Expression of bcl-6 protein in normal skin and epidermal neoplasms .
2,4 G#protein

Bcl-6 protein is a recently identified novel transcription factor whose deregulated expression is associated with diffuse large B cell lymphomas .
0,2 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

It was recently shown by us that the protein is located in germinal center B cells and their neoplastic counterparts .
12,16 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type

In the present study , the expression of bcl-6 protein on normal epidermis , benign , and malignant tumors originating from epidermal cells , and squamous cell carcinoma ( SCC ) cell lines are investigated .
8,10 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|25,33 G#cell_line

With the use of immunohistochemistry , bcl-6 protein was shown to stain intensely on normal prickle cells , but none to only slightly on epidermal basal cells .
6,8 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_line|24,27 G#cell_type

Papillomas and keratoacanthomas copied their normal counterparts in the mode of expression .


Various levels of expression were found on seborrheic keratoses , while the expression level on basal cell epitheliomas was low .


Peculiarly , eccrine poromas and undifferentiated spindle-shaped basal cell epitheliomas were totally unstained .


Squamous cell carcinomas showed a variety of expression levels , while two undifferentiated spindle-shaped carcinomas and one undifferentiated SCC cell line remained unstained .
18,21 G#cell_line

These results suggest that the expression of bcl-6 protein may be associated with morphological differentiation in normal and neoplastic epidermal cells .
7,9 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|18,21 G#cell_type

Sp3 mediates transcriptional activation of the leukocyte integrin genes CD11C and CD11B and cooperates with c-Jun to activate CD11C .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA

The leukocyte integrin genes CD11c and CD11b are expressed predominately in myelomonocytic cells .
1,4 G#DNA|4,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA

In previous experiments , the -70 to -65 and -121 to -103 regions of the CD11c promoter and the -66 to -59 region of the CD11b promoter were shown to be essential for Sp1- mediated activation of these genes .
5,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|19,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA|33,34 G#protein

In vivo genomic footprinting had also revealed cell-specific binding of protein , presumably Sp1 , to these regions .
13,14 G#protein

In this study , electrophoretic mobility shift analysis showed that the Sp1 -related factor , Sp3 , also binds at or near these same regions .
11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Cotransfection of Sp3 along with CD11c promoter -luciferase constructs into Sp-deficient Drosophila Schneider 2 cells showed that Sp3 could activate the CD11c promoter .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|10,15 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

Deletion of both the -70 to -65 and -121 to -103 regions of the CD11c promoter resulted in the loss of activation by Sp3 .
4,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

Both sites showed activation by Sp3 ; however , the -70 to -65 region was more responsive to Sp3 than to Sp1 .
5,6 G#protein|10,14 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Similar transfection analysis of the -66 to -59 region of the CD11b promoter showed Sp3 -dependent expression .
5,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein

Further , cotransfection analysis in Drosophila cells showed that Sp3 , as was previously shown for Sp1 , also synergizes with c-Jun to activate CD11c .
5,7 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#DNA

Antisense experiments that knocked out endogenous Sp3 expression in the myelomocytic cell line , HL60 , revealed that Sp3 participates in activation of the CD11c and CD11b promoters in vivo .
6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|24,28 G#DNA

The winged-helix transcription factor Trident is expressed in actively dividing lymphocytes .
1,4 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

We recently identified the winged-helix transcription factor Trident and described its expression pattern in synchronized fibroblasts .
4,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

We have now studied Trident expression in cell lines , differentiating thymocytes and in lymphocytes derived from peripheral blood .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line|10,12 G#cell_type

During T cell differentiation , expression peaked in the actively dividing immature single positive cells .
9,15 G#cell_type

In peripheral blood lymphocytes , expression of Trident mRNA was absent , but could be induced upon stimulation with mitogens in vitro .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA

These observations imply a function for Trident in dividing lymphocytes .
6,7 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

Estrogen receptor diminishes DNA-binding activities of chicken GATA-1 and CACCC-binding proteins .
0,2 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

The estrogen receptor ( ER ) repressed erythroid differentiation and erythroid-specific gene expression .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

In this study , we investigated the effect of ER alpha ( referred to throughout as ER ) on DNA-binding activities of transcription factors involved in regulating the expression of erythroid-specific genes , and , in particular , the histone H5 gene .
9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|30,32 G#DNA|39,42 G#DNA

Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays , we found that in the presence of rabbit reticulocyte lysate , human ER reduced the binding activities of chicken immature erythrocyte nuclear extracted proteins to GATA and CACCC sites in the H5 promoter and enhancer .
17,19 G#protein|24,30 G#protein|31,35 G#DNA|37,41 G#DNA

In contrast , the binding activities of NF1 and Sp1 were not affected by ER .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Binding of ER to an estrogen response element was enhanced by addition of rabbit reticulocyte lysate .
2,3 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA

This lysate was also necessary for ER to diminish the DNA-binding activity of GATA-1 .
6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

These results suggest that additional factor ( s ) are necessary for full ER function .
13,14 G#protein

Both GATA-1 and CACCC-binding proteins are critical for the developmentally regulated expression of erythroid-specific genes .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

We hypothesize that interference in DNA-binding activities of GATA-1 and CACCC-binding proteins is the mechanism by which the ER inhibits regulation of these genes .
8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Regulation of Id3 cell cycle function by Cdk-2-dependent phosphorylation .
2,3 G#protein

The functions of basic helix-loop-helix ( bHLH ) transcription factors in activating differentiation-linked gene expression and in inducing G1 cell cycle arrest are negatively regulated by members of the Id family of HLH proteins .
8,10 G#protein|3,10 G#protein|29,34 G#protein

These bHLH antagonists are induced during a mitogenic signalling response , and they function by sequestering their bHLH targets in inactive heterodimers that are unable to bind to specific gene regulatory ( E box ) sequences .
1,3 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|29,36 G#DNA

Recently , cyclin E-Cdk2- and cyclin A-Cdk2- dependent phosphorylation of a single conserved serine residue ( Ser5 ) in Id2 has been shown to occur during late G1-to-S phase transition of the cell cycle , and this neutralizes the function of Id2 in abrogating E-box-dependent bHLH homo - or hetero dimer complex formation in vitro ( E.Hara , M.Hall , and G.Peters , EMBO J.16 : 332-342 , 1997 ) .
19,20 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|44,46 G#protein

We now show that an analogous cell-cycle-regulated phosphorylation of Id3 alters the specificity of Id3 for abrogating both E-box-dependent bHLH homo- or heterodimer complex formation in vitro and E-box-dependent reporter gene function in vivo .
9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA

Furthermore , compared with wild-type Id3 , an Id3 Asp5 mutant ( mimicking phosphorylation ) is unable to promote cell cycle S phase entry in transfected fibroblasts , whereas an Id3 Ala5 mutant ( ablating phosphorylation ) displays an activity significantly greater than that of wild-type Id3 protein .
5,6 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_line|30,31 G#protein|30,33 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|45,48 G#protein

Cdk2-dependent phosphorylation therefore provides a switch during late G1-to-S phase that both nullifies an early G1 cell cycle regulatory function of Id3 and modulates its target bHLH specificity .
21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

These data also demonstrate that the ability of Id3 to promote cell cycle S phase entry is not simply a function of its ability to modulate bHLH heterodimer-dependent gene expression and establish a biologically important mechanism through which Cdk2 and Id-bHLH functions are integrated in the coordination of cell proliferation and differentiation .
8,9 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Molecular cloning and functional characterization of murine cDNA encoding transcription factor NFATc .
6,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Transcription factors of the NFAT ( nuclear factor of activated T cells ) family play important roles in immune and inflammatory responses by regulating the expression of genes encoding cytokines and immunoregulatory proteins .
0,2 G#protein|6,12 G#protein|4,14 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

Here we describe cloning and characterization of full-length cDNA encoding murine ( m ) NFATc which predicts that the protein has all the conserved structural motifs of NFAT family members , including the rel homology domain , the NFAT homology domain and the nuclear translocation signals .
14,15 G#protein|8,15 G#protein|23,26 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|38,41 G#protein

mNFATc complexed with AP-1 bound specifically to the murine IL-2 NFAT recognition sequence and activated transcription from the co-transfected IL-2 promoter in COS-7 cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,13 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#cell_line

Northern blot analysis showed that the cDNA probe hybridized with a 4.5 kb transcript which is highly inducible in murine T cells .
6,8 G#DNA|19,22 G#cell_type

By Northern and in situ hybridization , mNFATc transcript was detected from the early stage of development .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA

In the mouse embryo , mNFATc transcript was strongly expressed in thymus , lung and submandibular gland and weakly in skeletal muscle and heart suggesting that mNFATc may have a role both in embryogenesis and in mature T cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|26,27 G#protein|36,39 G#cell_type

TNFalpha cooperates with the protein kinase A pathway to synergistically increase HIV-1 LTR transcription via downstream TRE-like cAMP response elements .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|16,20 G#DNA

Activating protein-1 ( AP-1 ) binding TPA responsive elements ( TRE ) are located downstream of the transcription initiation site in the U5 region of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|26,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA

These downstream sequence elements , termed DSE , can bind both AP-1 and CREB/ATF transcription factors .
1,4 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Recently , we demonstrated that the DSE are also cAMP-responsive elements ( CRE ) , since they mediated activation signals elicited by cholera toxin ( Ctx ) , a potent activator of the cAMP-dependent protein kinase A ( PKA ) signal transduction pathway .
6,7 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

In the present study , we demonstrate that the HIV-1 DSE can mediate the transcriptional synergy elicited by the combination of Ctx and TNFalpha .
10,11 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Ctx combined with TNFalpha or IL-1beta to produce a synergistic increase in p24 antigen production in U1 promonocytic cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line

Transfection studies of LTR reporter constructs indicated that mutation of the DSE sites abrogated the LTR -mediated synergy induced by Ctx and TNFalpha , whereas the synergy induced by Ctx and IL-1beta was unaffected , suggesting TNFalpha and IL-1beta cooperate differently with the cAMP /PKA activation pathway to induce HIV-1 expression in U1 cells .
3,6 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|52,54 G#cell_line

Because the DSE are also TRE sites , we assessed the effect of the agonist combinations on AP-1 -dependent transcription .
2,3 G#DNA|5,6 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein

TNFalpha as well as IL-1beta cooperated with Ctx to produce a synergistic activation of AP-1 -mediated transcription .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

These data indicate that the TRE -like cAMP-responsive DSE sites within the 5'-untranslated leader can mediate the transcriptional cooperativity between TNFalpha and the cAMP /PKA pathway .
5,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|5,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Since the DSE and TRE sites can not bind CREB/ATF homodimers , we propose a mechanism in which the HIV-1 DSE bind heterodimers composed of both AP-1 and CREB/ATF proteins .
2,3 G#DNA|4,5 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|26,30 G#protein

Copyright 1997 Academic Press .


Association of glucocorticoid insensitivity with increased expression of glucocorticoid receptor beta .
8,11 G#protein

In many chronic inflammatory disorders , glucocorticoid ( GC ) insensitivity is a challenging clinical problem associated with life-threatening disease progression .


The molecular basis of GC insensitivity , however , is unknown .


Alternative splicing of the GC receptor ( R ) pre-messenger RNA generates a second GCR , termed GCR-beta , which does not bind GCs but antagonizes the transactivating activity of the classic GCR , termed GCR-alpha .
4,6 G#protein|4,11 G#RNA|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

In the current study , we demonstrate that GC-insensitive asthma is associated with a significantly higher number of GCR-beta -immunoreactive cells in peripheral blood than GC-sensitive asthmatics or normal controls .
18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type

Furthermore , we show that patients with GC-insensitive asthma have cytokine-induced abnormalities in the DNA binding capability of the GCR .
19,20 G#protein

These abnormalities can be reproduced by transfection of cell lines with the GCR-beta gene resulting in significant reduction of their GCR-alpha DNA binding capacity .
8,10 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

We conclude that increased expression of GCR-beta is cytokine inducible and may account for GC insensitivity in this common inflammatory condition .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Epstein-Barr virus EBNA3C represses Cp , the major promoter for EBNA expression , but has no effect on the promoter of the cell gene CD21 .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA

EBNA3C is a potent repressor of transcription when bound to DNA as a fusion with the DNA binding domain ( DBD ) of GALA .
0,1 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

A survey of promoters has revealed that the wild-type , unfused EBNA3C can specifically repress expression from reporter plasmids containing the Epstein-Barr virus Cp latency-associated promoter .
11,12 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA

Repression of Cp activity required amino acids 207 to 368 , which encompasses a region resembling a basic DBD adjacent to a leucine zipper DNA binding motif and a site which binds to the cellular factor CBF1/RBP-Jkappa .
2,3 G#DNA|5,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|22,27 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|34,37 G#protein

However , amino acids 207 to 368 are dispensable when the protein is bound to DNA as a fusion with the GAL4 DBD , thus implicating this region in DNA binding .
22,23 G#protein

Mutation of the CBF1/RBP-Jkappa binding site in EBNA3C abrogated repression , strongly suggesting that CBF1/RBP-Jkappa is necessary for targeting the viral protein to Cp .
3,4 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,24 G#DNA

Consistent with this result , mutation of the EBNA2 response element ( a CBF1/RBP-Jkappa binding site ) in Cp also prevented significant repression .
8,11 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA

In addition , amino acids 346 to 543 , which were previously defined as important for the repressor activity of the GAL4-EBNA3C fusion proteins , also appear to be necessary for the repression of Cp .
3,8 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|34,35 G#DNA

Since repression by these fusions was not observed in all cell types , it seems likely that EBNA3C either depends on a corepressor which may interact with amino acids 346 to 543 or is modified in a cell-specific manner in order to repress .
17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,32 G#protein

These data are consistent with EBNA3C contributing to the regulation of EBNA expression in latently infected B cells through CBF1/RBP-Jkappa and another factor , but this need not directly involve EBNA2 .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|14,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Finally , although it has been reported that EBNA3C can upregulate CD21 in some B cells , we were unable to demonstrate any effect of EBNA3C on reporter plasmids which contain the CD21 promoter .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|32,34 G#DNA

Relationship between glucocorticoid receptor and response to glucocorticoid therapy in ulcerative colitis .
2,4 G#protein

PURPOSE : To clarify the relationship between the glucocorticoid receptor and the effectiveness of glucocorticoid therapy in patients with ulcerative colitis , we investigated the number and apparent dissociation constant of glucocorticoid receptor in peripheral blood mononuclear leukocytes of patients with ulcerative colitis .
8,10 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|34,38 G#cell_type

MATERIALS AND METHODS : Eleven patients with ulcerative colitis ( 5 who responded to intravenous glucocorticoids and 6 who did not ) and ten control subjects were studied .


The number and apparent dissociation constant of glucocorticoid receptor were measured using a whole-cell binding assay .
7,9 G#protein

Results were expressed as a median ( interquartile range ) .


RESULTS : The number of glucocorticoid receptors from the six nonresponders , five responders , and ten healthy controls were 4922 ( range , 4484-5643 ) , 3413 ( range , 3183-4450 ) , and 3610 ( range , 2594-3979 ) binding sites/cell , respectively .
5,7 G#protein

The apparent dissociation constant of the glucocorticoid receptors from the nonresponders , responders , and healthy controls were 7.03 ( range , 5.66-10 ) , 4.27 ( range , 4-5.13 ) , and 6.18 ( range , 5.86-6.74 ) nM , respectively .
6,8 G#protein

Nonresponders had a significant increase both in the number of binding sites and in the apparent dissociation constant compared with responders ( P = 0.045 ; P = 0.029 ) .
10,12 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : The increased number and apparent dissociation constant of glucocorticoid receptor are closely associated with the effectiveness of glucocorticoid therapy .
10,12 G#protein

The measurement of the number and apparent dissociation constant of glucocorticoid receptor may be useful in predicting response to glucocorticoids .
10,12 G#protein

Cooperation of binding sites for STAT6 and NF kappa B/rel in the IL-4 -induced up-regulation of the human IgE germline promoter .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,21 G#DNA

Ig heavy chain class switching is directed by cytokines inducing transcription from unrearranged CH genes .
0,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

Subsequently , such primed cells can undergo switch recombination to express the selected new isotype .
3,5 G#cell_type

In the case of IgE class switching , IL-4 activates the IgE germline promoter by inducing the interaction of the transcription factor STAT6 ( IL-4STAT ) with a responsive DNA element in the proximal region of the promoter .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,31 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA|37,38 G#DNA

This study describes the characterization of two additional cis-acting elements that interact with members of the NF kappa B/rel transcription factor family in an IL-4 -independent fashion .
8,10 G#DNA|16,19 G#protein|16,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility shift assays show that the nucleoprotein complex formed on the upstream site ( NF kappa B1 ) contains the classical p50/p65 heterodimer .
7,9 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

The complex on the proximal site ( NF kappa B2 ) appears to be composed of p50 and relB .
4,6 G#DNA|7,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

IgE germline promoter reporter gene constructs carrying point mutations in the NF kappa B2 site were largely unresponsive to IL-4 stimulation in transient transfection experiments , while plasmids with similar mutations in the NF kappa B1 site responded to cytokine stimulation better than the wild-type promoter .
0,1 G#protein|0,3 G#DNA|0,6 G#DNA|11,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|44,46 G#DNA

The NF kappa B2 effect was dependent on the presence of the STAT6 binding site , demonstrating that the NF kappa B2 motif is necessary but not sufficient for mediating cytokine up-regulation .
1,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|19,22 G#protein|19,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

In addition , the combination of a NF kappa B/rel binding site and the STAT6 response element conferred IL-4 inducibility to a heterologous minimal promoter , while the individual sites had no effect .
7,10 G#protein|7,12 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA

The available data suggest that the NF kappa B2 nucleoprotein complex may cooperate with DNA-bound STAT6 to achieve IL-4 -dependent activation of the human IgE germline gene .
6,9 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|6,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|23,27 G#DNA

Alcohol-induced regulation of nuclear regulatory factor-kappa beta in human monocytes .
3,7 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

Acute ethanol exposure has the capacity to modulate immune functions , particularly , to down regulate monocyte production of inflammatory cytokines .
20,21 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

However , the intracellular mechanisms for these effects of ethanol are yet to be understood .


Considering that nuclear regulatory factor-kappa beta ( NF-kappa B ) /Rel is a common regulatory element of the promoter region of the inflammatory cytokine genes , herein , we tested the hypothesis that acute ethanol affects NF-kappa B activation in human monocytes .
2,6 G#protein|6,11 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|22,25 G#DNA|36,38 G#protein|40,42 G#cell_type

Adherence-isolated monocytes showed constitutive DNA binding activity of NF-kappa B .
0,2 G#cell_line|8,10 G#protein

A clinically relevant dose ( 25 mM ) of acute ethanol treatment in vitro increased NF-kappa B binding activity in monocytes with a preferential induction of the inhibitory , p50 /p50 , NF-kappa B /Rel homodimer , and resulted in no induction of the p65 /p50 heterodimer .
15,17 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|32,36 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|44,47 G#protein

In contrast , lipopolysaccharide stimulation primarily induced the p65 /p50 heterodimer that has been shown to result in gene activation .
8,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|8,11 G#protein

Thus , such unique activation of the inhibitory p50 /p50 homodimer by acute ethanol treatment may result in inhibition rather than activation of NF-kappa B -regulated inflammatory cytokine genes .
8,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA|23,29 G#DNA

Consequently , these results suggest that physiologically relevant concentrations of ethanol may affect production of inflammatory cytokines , such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha , interleukin-1 beta , and interleukin-6 by disrupting NF-kappa B signaling in monocytes .
16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|35,36 G#cell_type

LPS tolerance in monocytes/macrophages : three 3' cytosins are required in the DNA binding motif for detection of upregulated NF-kappa B p50 homodimers .
3,4 G#cell_type|12,15 G#DNA|19,23 G#protein

When monocytes are stimulated with LPS ( lipopolysaccharide ) repeatedly then the initially high expression of the TNF ( tumor necrosis factor ) gene is only very low , i.e. the cells are tolerant to LPS .
1,2 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|17,24 G#DNA

Tolerant cells still express the CD14 receptor and they can still be activated to mobilize NF-kappa B into nucleus .
5,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Analysis of the binding proteins employing the -605 motif of the human TNF promoter ( GGGGCTGTCCC ) revealed that in tolerant cells of the human monocytic cell line Mono Mac 6 there is a predominance of p50p50 of NF-kappa B .
11,14 G#DNA|24,28 G#cell_line|28,31 G#cell_line|36,37 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

We now show that a mutant motif that exchanges the terminal 3' C for a G fails to bind the p50 homodimer that is upregulated in LPS toler ant human Mono Mac 6 cells .
5,7 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein|29,34 G#cell_line

The same is true for nuclear extracts taken from the murine P388D1 macrophage cell line when tested with the -516 motif of the murine TNF promoter ( GGGGGCTTTCCC ) .
10,15 G#cell_line|19,21 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA

Here the wild type motif gives efficient binding of p50p50 that again is upregulated in tolerant cells whereas a mutant with a 3' G shows hardly any binding of p50p50 .
2,5 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein

Conversely , the murine kappa light chain enhancer motif ( GGGGACTTTCCG ) does not efficiently bind the nuclear p50p50 from tolerant murine P388 macrophages .
3,9 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_line

Binding is , however , readily detected when the 3' G is replaced by a C .


These data show that the detection of upregulated p50 homodimers in LPS tolerant cells is dependent on subtle differences in the sequence of the DNA binding motif .
8,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|24,27 G#DNA

Cyclosporin A inhibits early mRNA expression of G0/G1 switch gene 2 ( G0S2 ) in cultured human blood mononuclear cells .
7,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|15,20 G#cell_line

Cyclosporin A ( CsA ) may achieve its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting the calcium- and calmodulin-dependent phosphatase calcineurin which is required for activation of target genes by members of the NFAT ( nuclear factor of activated T cells ) transcription factor family .
13,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|32,38 G#protein|30,42 G#protein

Among these target genes is the gene encoding interleukin-2 ( IL2 ) , a cytokine facilitating progression through the G1 phase of the cell cycle .
2,4 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

However , IL2 does not reverse CsA inhibition , suggesting that at least one other NFAT-sensitive gene may be involved .
2,3 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

The human G0/G1 switch gene , G0S2 , has potential NFAT-binding sites in the 5' flank and encodes a small basic potential phosphoprotein of unknown function .
1,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|19,23 G#protein

Using a sensitive , reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) assay , G0S2 mRNA levels were assayed in cultured blood mononuclear cells .
13,14 G#DNA|19,23 G#cell_line

Freshly isolated cells contain high levels of G0S2 mRNA which rapidly decline .
7,8 G#DNA|7,9 G#RNA

This " spontaneous stimulation " is also noted with some other G0S genes and has been attributed to some aspect of the isolation procedure .
11,13 G#DNA

In cells that have been preincubated to lower mRNA levels , there is a transient increase in G0S2 mRNA , peaking between 1-2 h , in response to Concanavalin-A ( ConA ) , or to the combination of phorbol ester ( TPA ) , and the calcium ionophore , ionomycin .
17,18 G#DNA|17,19 G#RNA

Both these responses are inhibited by CsA .


Our results suggest that G0S2 expression is required to commit cells to enter the G1 phase of the cell cycle , and that , while not excluding other possible targets , early inhibition of G0S2 expression by CsA may be important in achieving immunosuppression .
4,5 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA

G0S2 may be of value as a reporter gene for analyzing the mechanism of action of CsA and its influence on the positive and negative selection of lymphocytes in response to self and not-self antigens .
0,1 G#DNA|27,28 G#cell_type

c-Rel and p65 subunits bind to an upstream NF-kappaB site in human granulocyte macrophage-colony stimulating factor promoter involved in phorbol ester response in 5637 cells .
0,4 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|11,16 G#protein|11,17 G#DNA|23,25 G#cell_line

To further clarify the complex transcriptional regulation of the human GM-CSF gene , which was extensively investigated in activated T cells , we have studied the role of an upstream NF-kappaB like site in the 5637 non-lymphoid cell line , which derives from a bladder carcinoma and constitutively produces GM-CSF .
9,12 G#DNA|18,21 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein|30,33 G#DNA|35,39 G#cell_line|49,50 G#protein

This sequence , named the A element , has an active role on GM-CSF transcription and is responsive to the tumor promoter PMA in transient transfection experiments .
13,14 G#protein|20,23 G#DNA

We describe here a heterodimeric binding complex of NF-kappaB subunits ( c-Rel and p65 ) which is identical to the one obtained using the HIV-LTR-kappaB site as recognition sequence and different from the one ( c-Rel and p50 ) observed with nuclear extracts from Mo T-lymphoid HTLV-II infected cells .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|44,49 G#cell_line

Repression of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 through the novel cooperation of human factors YY1 and LSF [ published erratum appears in J Virol 1998 Feb ; 72 ( 2 ) : 1709 ]
12,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

A subpopulation of stably infected CD4+ cells capable of producing virus upon stimulation has been identified in human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -positive individuals ( T.-W.Chun , D.Finzi , J.Margolick , K.Chadwick , D.Schwartz , and R.F.Siliciano , Nat.Med.1 : 1284-1290 , 1995 ) .
3,7 G#cell_type

Few host factors that directly limit HIV-1 transcription and could support this state of nonproductive HIV-1 infection have been described .


YY1 , a widely distributed human transcription factor , is known to inhibit HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) transcription and virus production .
0,1 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|13,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA

LSF ( also known as LBP-1 , UBP , and CP-2 ) has been shown to repress LTR transcription in vitro , but transient expression of LSF has no effect on LTR activity in vivo .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|31,32 G#DNA

We report that both YY1 and LSF participate in the formation of a complex that recognizes the initiation region of the HIV-1 LTR .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

Further , we have found that these factors cooperate in the repression of LTR expression and viral replication .
13,14 G#DNA

This cooperative function may account for the divergent effects of LSF previously observed in vitro and in vivo .
10,11 G#protein

Thus , the cooperation of two general cellular transcription factors may allow for the selective downregulation of HIV transcription .


Through this mechanism of gene regulation , YY1 and LSF could contribute to the establishment and maintenance of a population of cells stably but nonproductively infected with HIV-1 .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Analysis of interactions between huGATA-3 transcription factor and three GATA regulatory elements of HIV-1 long terminal repeat , by surface plasmon resonance .
4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA

Relative affinities of transcriptional regulatory elements for their respective factor have been essentially studied by bandshift analysis .
3,6 G#DNA

Here we report a real-time study of factor/DNA interactions using a surface plasmon resonance approach and further characterization of recovered proteins involved in this interaction .
19,21 G#protein

For this purpose , human GATA-3 , either recombinant or in nuclear extracts , and three natural GATA elements of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( sites 1 , 2 , and 3 ) were chosen , in which only site 2 is a noncanonical GATA site .
4,6 G#protein|16,19 G#DNA|21,25 G#DNA|26,33 G#DNA|40,42 G#DNA|45,47 G#DNA

Direct analysis of sensorgrams , with recombinant huGATA-3 , allowed the comparison of association and dissociation profiles of the three DNA regions and their ranking according to their relative affinities .
7,8 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

This result , confirmed by competitions with each GATA site , demonstrated the higher relative affinity ( at least sevenfold ) of site 3 .
8,10 G#DNA

Interactions between the canonical and unique GATA site 3 and nuclear extracts were also studied in real time and provided information on its association and dissociation rates for native huGATA-3 .
6,8 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein

Finally , recovered protein was identified as genuine huGATA-3 by SDS-PAGE , Western blotting , and bandshift assays .
8,9 G#protein
