Stable transfection of U937 cells with sense or antisense RXR-alpha cDNA suggests a role for RXR-alpha in the control of monoblastic differentiation induced by retinoic acid and vitamin D .
3,5 G#cell_line|8,11 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein

Although retinoic acid ( RA ) has been known for many years to be a modulating agent that plays a role in generating both granulocytes and monocytes , the molecular mechanism underlying this role has not been defined in the monoblast lineage .
24,25 G#cell_type|26,27 G#cell_type|40,42 G#cell_type

In particular , the part played by the retinoid X receptors ( RXRs ) , which are members of the steroid/thyroid hormone nuclear receptor family , has not been explored .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|20,25 G#protein

In this study , therefore , the human monoblastic leukemia cell line U937 has been used as a model system to investigate the role of one of the RXRs , RXR-alpha , in monoblast differentiation .
7,13 G#cell_line|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

RXR-alpha mRNA was present in untreated U937 cells , and levels increased after induction of differentiation with phorbol ester .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#RNA|6,8 G#cell_line

The same was found for RXR-beta mRNA .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA

Using plasmids containing sense or antisense RXR-alpha sequences under the control of an inducible promoter , we generated stably transfected cell lines which expressed either increased or decreased levels of RXR-alpha , respectively .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein

The sense cell lines ( U alpha S and its clonal derivative alpha G2S ) showed increased sensitivity to RA , while the antisense cell lines ( U alpha A and its clonal derivative alpha B5A ) showed decreased sensitivity to RA , as demonstrated by growth inhibition and by regulation of an RA -responsive reporter gene .
1,4 G#cell_line|5,8 G#cell_line|13,14 G#cell_line|23,26 G#cell_line|27,30 G#cell_line|35,36 G#cell_line|53,57 G#DNA

Both U alpha A and alpha B5A also failed to respond to another modulating agent , 1 alpha,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol ( DHCC ) , but only U alpha S and not alpha G2S showed an enhanced response to DHCC .
1,4 G#cell_line|6,7 G#cell_line|24,27 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_line|29,31 G#protein

The combination of RA and DHCC together inhibited growth of both sense and antisense cell lines .
13,16 G#cell_line

In addition , alpha G2S exhibited increased expression of CD11b and CD54 , while alpha B5A cells showed increased expression of CD102 , suggesting that RXR-alpha has a role in regulating expression of cell adhesion molecules in U937 cells .
4,5 G#cell_line|3,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_line|14,17 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_line

These results demonstrate that RXR-alpha has a role in mediating growth inhibition and cell adhesion during myelomonocytic differentiation , and suggest that different species of heterodimers involving RXR-alpha may control the acquisition of different features of mature monocyte/macrophage function .
4,5 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Transcriptional activation of the vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 gene in T lymphocytes expressing human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 Tax protein .
4,9 G#DNA|10,12 G#cell_type|13,21 G#protein

Recruitment and extravasation of T cells through the blood-brain barrier are favored by adhesion molecule -mediated interactions of circulating T cells with endothelial cells .
4,6 G#cell_type|13,15 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_type

Since a common pathological finding in human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) -associated diseases is the infiltration of HTLV-1-infected T lymphocytes into various organs , we have looked for the profile of adhesion molecules expressed by HTLV-1-transformed T cells .
22,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type|35,37 G#protein|39,42 G#cell_type

Flow cytometry analysis indicated that these cells were expressing high levels of vascular cell adhesion molecule 1 ( VCAM-1 [ CD106 ] ) , a 110-kDa member of the immunoglobulin gene superfamily , first identified on endothelial cells stimulated with inflammatory cytokines .
12,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|36,38 G#cell_type|40,42 G#protein

This adhesion molecule was also expressed by T cells obtained from one patient with HTLV-1 -associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis but not by activated T cells isolated from one normal blood donor .
7,9 G#cell_type|23,25 G#cell_type|22,25 G#cell_type

The role of the viral trans-activator Tax protein in the induction of VCAM-1 was first indicated by the detection of this adhesion molecule on Jurkat T-cell clones stably expressing the tax gene .
4,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_line

The effect of Tax on VCAM-1 gene transcription was next confirmed in JPX-9 cells , a subclone of Jurkat cells , carrying the tax sequences under the control of an inducible promoter .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|18,20 G#cell_line|23,25 G#DNA|30,32 G#DNA

Furthermore , deletion and mutation analyses of the VCAM-1 promoter performed with chloramphenicol acetyltransferase constructs revealed that Tax was trans activating the VCAM-1 promoter via two NF-kappaB sites present at bp -72 and -57 in the VCAM-1 gene promoter , with both of them being required for the Tax -induced expression of this adhesion molecule .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|36,37 G#protein|36,39 G#DNA|48,49 G#protein|53,55 G#protein

Finally , gel mobility shift assays demonstrated the nuclear translocation of proteins specifically bound to these two NF-kappaB motifs , confirming that VCAM-1 was induced on Tax -expressing cells in a kappaB -dependent manner .
17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_line|31,32 G#protein

Collectively , these results therefore suggest that the exclusive Tax -induced expression of VCAM-1 on T cells may represent a pivotal event in the progression of HTLV-1 -associated diseases .
9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

HIV-1 Vpr suppresses immune activation and apoptosis through regulation of nuclear factor kappa B [ see comments ]
0,2 G#protein|10,14 G#protein

The HIV-1 accessory gene product Vpr can influence viral pathogenesis by affecting viral replication as well as host cell transcription and proliferation .
1,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

We have investigated the effects of Vpr on host cell activation and confirm that it influences cellular proliferation .
6,7 G#protein

However , we have also found that Vpr modulates T-cell receptor ( TCR ) -triggered apoptosis in a manner similar to that of glucocorticoids .
7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In the absence of TCR -mediated activation , Vpr induces apoptosis whereas in its presence , Vpr interrupts the expected induction of apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

This regulation of apoptosis is linked to Vpr suppression of NF-kappa B activity via the induction of I kappa B , an inhibitor of NF-kappa B .
7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

Further , Vpr suppresses expression of IL-2 , IL-10 , IL-12 , TNF alpha and IL-4 , all of which are NF-kappa B -dependent .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

The effects of Vpr could be reversed by RU486 .
3,4 G#protein

Our finding that Vpr can regulate NF-kappa B supports the hypothesis that some aspects of viral pathogenesis are the consequence of cell dysregulation by Vpr .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Tissue transglutaminase-dependent posttranslational modification of the retinoblastoma gene product in promonocytic cells undergoing apoptosis .
6,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line

The retinoblastoma gene product ( pRB ) plays an important role in controlling both cell release from the G1 phase and apoptosis .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

We show here that in the early phases of apoptosis , pRB is posttranslationally modified by a tissue transglutaminase ( tTG ) -catalyzed reaction .
11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

In fact , by employing a novel haptenized lysis synthetic substrate which allows the isolation of glutaminyl-tTG substrates in vivo , we identified pRB as a potential tTG substrate in U937 cells undergoing apoptosis .
23,24 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line

In keeping with this finding , we showed that apoptosis of U937 cells is characterized by the rapid disappearance of the 105,000- to 110,000-molecular-weight pRB forms concomitantly with the appearance of a smear of immunoreactive products with a molecular weight of greater than 250,000 .
11,13 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein

The shift in pRB molecular weight was reproduced by adding exogenous purified tTG to extracts obtained from viable U937 cells and was prevented by dansylcadaverine , a potent enzyme inhibitor .
3,4 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line

The effect of the pRB posttranslational modification during apoptosis was investigated by determining the E2F-1 levels and by isolating and characterizing pRB -null clones from U937 cells .
4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_line|25,27 G#cell_line

Notably , the lack of pRB in these U937-derived clones renders these p53-null cells highly resistant to apoptosis induced by serum withdrawal , calphostin C , and ceramide .
5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_line|12,14 G#cell_line

Taken together , these data suggest that tTG , acting on the pRB protein , might play an important role in the cell progression through the death program .
7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

STAT3 is a serine kinase target in T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Interleukin 2 and T cell antigen receptor signals converge upon serine 727 .
0,2 G#protein|3,7 G#protein

Interleukin 2 ( IL-2 ) induces tyrosine phosphorylation of STATs 3 and 5 ( signal transducer and activator of transcription ) .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|9,13 G#protein

We now show that IL-2 regulation of STAT3 proteins in T cells is a complex response involving activation of two forms of STAT3 : 90-kDa STAT3alpha and an 83-kDa carboxyl-terminal truncated STAT3beta .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|28,32 G#protein

The phosphorylation of STAT proteins on serine residues is also required for competent STAT transcription .
3,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

A critical serine phosphorylation site in STAT3alpha is at position 727 .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

In this study we have produced an antisera specific for STAT3alpha proteins phosphorylated on serine 727 and used this to monitor the phosphorylation of this residue during T lymphocyte activation .
10,12 G#protein

Our results show that phosphorylation of STAT3alpha on serine 727 is not constitutive in quiescent T cells but can be induced by the cytokine IL-2 .
6,7 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Interestingly , triggering of the T cell antigen receptor complex or activation of protein kinase C with phorbol esters also induces phosphorylation of serine 727 but without simultaneously inducing STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation or DNA binding .
5,10 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Hence , the present results show that STAT3 serine phosphorylation can be regulated independently of the tyrosine phosphorylation of this molecule .
7,8 G#protein

IL-2 and T cell antigen receptor complex induction of STAT3alpha serine 727 phosphorylation is dependent on the activity of the MEK /ERK pathway .
0,1 G#protein|2,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Previous studies have identified H-7-sensitive kinase pathways that regulate STAT3 DNA binding .
9,10 G#protein

We show that H-7-sensitive pathways regulate STAT3 DNA binding in T cells .
6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

Nevertheless , we show that H-7-sensitive kinases do not regulate STAT3 tyrosine phosphorylation or phosphorylation of serine 727 .
5,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

These results thus show that STAT3 proteins are targets for multiple kinase pathways in T cells and can integrate signals from both cytokine receptors and antigen receptors .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

NF-kappa B/Rel family members regulating the ICAM-1 promoter in monocytic THP-1 cells .
0,4 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|9,12 G#cell_line

A kappa B-site was identified in the promoter of the intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) gene , which is involved in regulation of ICAM-1 expression by tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) and glucocorticoids .
1,3 G#DNA|10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|10,17 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|27,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

We now report on the transcription factors which bind and transactivate this enhancer sequence .
5,7 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

In vitro , the ICAM-1 kappa B site appeared to bind RelA and c-Rel homodimers as well as heterodimers with NF-kappa B1 , but weakly NF-kappa B1 homodimers .
4,8 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|25,28 G#protein

In addition , both RelA and c-Rel , but not NF-kappa B1 , were shown to transactivate an ICAM-1 kappa B-reporter construct .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,22 G#DNA

In monocytic THP-1 cells TNF-alpha induced two nuclear complexes which in vitro bound to the ICAM-1 kappa B site .
1,4 G#cell_line|4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|15,19 G#DNA

Using antibodies in an electrophoretic mobility supershift assay , one of these complexes was shown to contain NF-kappa B1 and RelA , and to bind with higher affinity to the consensus kappa B site in the HIV long terminal repeat .
17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|30,34 G#DNA|36,40 G#DNA

The second complex contained RelA , and exhibited higher affinity towards the ICAM-1 kappa B than to the HIV kappa B site .
4,5 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|18,22 G#DNA

The glucocorticoid receptor was shown to repress activity of both the RelA homodimer and the NF-kappa B1 /RelA heterodimer .
1,3 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

We argue that in vivo RelA homodimers are likely to play a dominant role in TNF-alpha -induced ICAM-1 transcription in monocytic cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

Competent transcription initiation by RNA polymerase II in cell-free extracts from xeroderma pigmentosum groups B and D in an optimized RNA transcription assay .
4,7 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

The human autosomal recessive disease , xeroderma pigmentosum ( XP ) , can result from mutations in any one of seven genes , designated XPA through XPG .
24,25 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA

Of these , the XPB and XPD genes encode proteins that are subunits of a general transcription factor , TFIIH , involved in both nucleotide excision repair ( NER ) and initiation of mRNA transcription by RNA polymerase II .
4,8 G#DNA|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|36,39 G#protein

In humans , mutation of the XPB or XPD gene impairs NER , resulting in hyper-sensitivity to sunlight and greatly increased skin tumor formation .
6,10 G#DNA

However , no transcription deficiency has been demonstrated in either XP-B or XP-D .


We have employed an optimized cell-free RNA transcription assay to analyze transcription activity of XP-B and XP-D .


Although the growth rate was normal , the XP-B and XP-D cells contained reduced amounts of TFIIH .
8,12 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein

Extracts prepared from XP-B and XP-D lymphoblastoid cells exhibited similar transcription activity from the adenovirus major late promoter when compared to that in extracts from normal cells .
3,8 G#cell_line|14,18 G#DNA

Thus , we conclude that the XP-B and XP-D lymphoblastoid cells do not have impaired RNA transcription activity .
6,11 G#cell_line

We consider the possible consequences of the reduced cellular content of TFIIH for the clinical symptoms in XP-B or XP-D patients , and discuss a ' conditional phenotype ' that may involve an impairment of cellular function only under certain growth conditions .
11,12 G#protein

A novel form of the myeloid-specific zinc finger protein ( MZF-2 ) .
5,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Myeloid cell development is controlled by tissue-specific transcription factors .
9,11 G#protein

Human myeloid zinc finger protein ( MZF-1 ) is a putative transcription factor containing 13 zinc fingers , and has been suggested that it regulates the development of neutrophilic granulocytes .
0,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

RESULTS : Here , we have isolated the murine and human cDNAs which encode a novel form of MZF protein ( MZF-2 ) .
8,12 G#DNA|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Murine and human MZF-2 proteins consisted of 814 and 775 amino acids , respectively , and have identity of 75.3 % between them .
0,5 G#protein

The C-terminal half of human MZF-2 , carrying the zinc finger domains , was completely identical with that of human MZF-1 , whereas the N-terminal half of MZF-2 was different from the corresponding region of human MZF-1 , and was coded by distinct exons .
1,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|43,44 G#DNA

MZF-2 mRNA was expressed in myeloid cells , particularly in the cells committed to the neutrophilic lineage , and down-regulated by G-CSF .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#RNA|15,17 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : MZF-1 and MZF-2 mRNAs seem to be produced by the alternative use of two different transcription initiation sites .
2,6 G#RNA|17,20 G#DNA

The distinct N-terminal half of MZF-2 carries two characteristic domains , a leucine-rich domain called LeR and an acidic domain , which suggests a unique function of MZF-2 in neutrophil development .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Impaired cortisol binding to glucocorticoid receptors in hypertensive patients .
4,6 G#protein

We compared glucocorticoid receptor binding characteristics and glucocorticoid responsiveness of human mononuclear leukocytes ( HML ) from hypertensive patients and matched normotensive volunteers .
10,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type

We also considered associations of these variables with plasma renin activity , aldosterone , cortisol , corticotropin , and electrolyte concentrations .
9,10 G#protein

We calculated binding affinity ( Kd ; nmol/L ) and capacity ( Bmax ; sites/cell ) for dexamethasone and cortisol from homologous and heterologous competition curves for specific [3H]dexamethasone binding sites on HML isolated from the blood of normotensive volunteers and subjects with essential hypertension .
32,33 G#cell_type

Glucocorticoid responsiveness of HML was evaluated as IC50 values ( nmol/L ) for dexamethasone and cortisol for the inhibition of lysozyme release .
3,4 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein

We measured plasma hormones by radioimmunoassay .


Kd values ( mean+/-SE ) for cortisol in HML of hypertensive patients were higher than in control subjects ( 24.6+/-2.4 versus 17.5+/-1.7 nmol/L , P &lt; .04 ) .
8,9 G#cell_type

Binding capacity ( 4978+/-391 versus 4131+/-321 sites/cell ) , Kd values for dexamethasone ( 6.7+/-0.5 versus 5.7+/-0.3 nmol/L ) , and IC50 values for dexamethasone ( 3.4+/-0.3 versus 3.1+/-0.2 nmol/L ) and cortisol ( 12.2+/-1.6 versus 9.5+/-0.3 nmol/L ) were not significantly different .


Patients with renin values less than 0.13 ng angiotensin I/L per second were markedly less sensitive to cortisol than those with higher values .
2,3 G#protein

Both Kd ( 30.3+/-2.5 versus 19.2+/-2.4 nmol/L ) and IC50 values ( 15.5+/-1.8 versus 8.9+/-1.2 nmol/L ) for cortisol were significantly higher in patients with lower renin values ( P &lt; .03 ) .
26,27 G#protein

Other variables , including plasma hormone and electrolyte values and binding characteristics for dexamethasone , were not different .


These data suggest that cortisol binding to glucocorticoid receptor is slightly impaired in patients with essential hypertension .
7,9 G#protein

In vivo , this could lead to inappropriate binding of cortisol to mineralocorticoid receptors .


Hence , decreased sensitivity to cortisol is associated with renin suppression .
9,10 G#protein

This hypothesis is supported by evidence of hypertension and low renin activity , which others have described in patients with primary glucocorticoid resistance due to mutations of the glucocorticoid receptor .
10,11 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

PU.1/Pip and basic helix loop helix zipper transcription factors interact with binding sites in the CD20 promoter to help confer lineage- and stage-specific expression of CD20 in B lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|2,9 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

CD20 is a B-lineage-specific gene expressed at the pre-B-cell stage of B-cell development that disappears on differentiation to plasma cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_type

As such , it serves as an excellent paradigm for the study of lineage and developmental stage-specific gene expression .


Using in vivo footprinting we identified two sites in the promoter at -45 and -160 that were occupied only in CD20 + B cells .
12,15 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

The -45 site is an E box that binds basic helix-loop-helix-zipper proteins whereas the -160 site is a composite PU.1 and Pip binding site .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|9,12 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|18,24 G#DNA

Transfection studies with reporter constructs and various expression vectors verified the importance of these sites .
3,5 G#DNA

The composite PU.1 and Pip site likely accounts for both lineage and stage -specific expression of CD20 whereas the CD20 E box binding proteins enhance overall promoter activity and may link the promoter to a distant enhancer .
1,6 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|19,24 G#protein|35,37 G#DNA

Glucocorticoids and the immune function in the human immunodeficiency virus infection : a study in hypercortisolemic and cortisol-resistant patients .


Immunological studies in human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -positive patients suggest that the disease progression is accompanied by a defective production of type 1 cytokines ( interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) and IL-12 ] , an increased production of type 2 cytokines ( IL-4 , IL-6 , and IL-10 ) , and an increased production of IgE .
24,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|39,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|56,57 G#protein

HIV infection is also associated with activation of the hypothalamo-pituitary-adrenal axis function and increased plasma and urinary cortisol concentrations .


As cortisol is involved in the physiological regulation of cytokines , a study was conducted to examine cytokine patterns in two groups of hypercortisolemic patients , one with normal sensitivity to glucocorticoids and the other with glucocorticoid resistance .
9,10 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Ten HIV-infected patients with normal receptor affinity to glucocorticoids ( AIDS-C ) , 10 HIV-infected patients with low receptor affinity to glucocorticoids ( AIDS-GR ) , and 20 healthy subjects were studied .


Receptor characteristics of peripheral blood mononuclear cells were evaluated by [3H]dexamethasone binding .
3,7 G#cell_type

Serum cortisol and urinary free cortisol were measured by RIA .


Serum ACTH and IgE were measured by immunoradiometric assay , and IL-2 , IL-4 , and IL-10 cytokines and interferon-gamma were measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

AIDS-C patients showed low IL-2 and high IL-4 , IL-10 , and IgE concentratios ; conversely , AIDS-GR patients showed high IL-2 and low IL-4 and IgE concentrations .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Thus , in HIV infection , elevated cortisol levels suppress cell-mediated immunity and stimulate humoral immunity , whereas this response is not detected in cortisol -resistant patients .


These findings indicate that cortisol and its receptors are critically involved in the regulation of immune function in HIV infection .


Monocytic differentiation of HL-60 promyelocytic leukemia cells correlates with the induction of Bcl-xL .
3,7 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein

Treatment of human promyelocytic leukemia HL-60 cells with phorbol esters ultimately induces the differentiation of these cells along the monocyte/macrophage lineage , whereas treatment with retinoic acid or DMSO induces granulocytic/neutrophillic differentiation .
2,7 G#cell_line|19,21 G#cell_type

In this study , we demonstrate the disparate fates of HL-60 cells treated with the phorbol ester 12,13-phorbol dibutyric acid ( PDBu ) or DMSO .
10,12 G#cell_line

After DMSO treatment , HL-60 cells eventually died via apoptosis , whereas the viability of PDBu -treated cells was not affected during the same interval .
4,6 G#cell_line|15,18 G#cell_line

The levels of the apoptosis effector proteins Bak and Bad were enhanced , whereas there was a slight down-regulation of the apoptosis suppressor protein Bcl-2 after treatment of the cells with PDBu and DMSO .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Treatment with DMSO resulted in the elevation of the apoptosis effector Bax , whereas treatment with PDBu did not significantly alter the levels of this protein .
9,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

However , treatment of HL-60 cells with PDBu induced the rapid expression of the apoptosis suppressor protein Bcl-xL , whereas the expression of this protein remained unaltered in DMSO -treated cells .
4,6 G#cell_line|14,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

The generality of this finding was confirmed by the induction of Bcl-xL in human myeloid U-937 cells , human peripheral blood monocytes exposed to phorbol ester , and mouse thioglycollate-activated and resident peritoneal macrophages .
11,12 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_line|18,22 G#cell_type|28,34 G#cell_line

PDBu -treated HL-60 cells remained viable for 7 days and thereafter began to die via apoptosis , with a concomitant down-regulation of Bcl-xL .
2,4 G#cell_line|0,4 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein

In conclusion , we propose that Bcl-xL expression is associated with differentiation and survival of hematopoietic cells along the monocyte/macrophage lineage .
6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type

Monochloramine inhibits phorbol ester -inducible neutrophil respiratory burst activation and T cell interleukin-2 receptor expression by inhibiting inducible protein kinase C activity .
12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Monochloramine derivatives are long lived physiological oxidants produced by neutrophils during the respiratory burst .
9,10 G#cell_type

The effects of chemically prepared monochloramine ( NH2Cl ) on protein kinase C ( PKC ) and PKC -mediated cellular responses were studied in elicited rat peritoneal neutrophils and human Jurkat T cells .
10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type|24,28 G#cell_type|29,33 G#cell_line

Neutrophils pretreated with NH2Cl ( 30-50 microM ) showed a marked decrease in the respiratory burst activity induced by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) , which is a potent PKC activator .
30,31 G#protein

These cells , however , were viable and showed a complete respiratory burst upon arachidonic acid stimulation , which induces the respiratory burst by a PKC -independent mechanism .
25,26 G#protein

The NH2Cl -treated neutrophils showed a decrease in both PKC activity and PMA -induced phosphorylation of a 47-kDa protein , which corresponds to the cytosolic factor of NADPH oxidase , p47 ( phox ) .
1,4 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,34 G#protein

Jurkat T cells pretreated with NH2Cl ( 20-70 microM ) showed a decrease in the expression of the interleukin-2 receptor alpha chain following PMA stimulation .
0,3 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

This was also accompanied by a decrease in both PKC activity and nuclear transcription factor- kappaB activation , also without loss of cell viability .
9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

These results show that NH2Cl inhibits PKC -mediated cellular responses through inhibition of the inducible PKC activity .
6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Evidence that calcineurin is rate-limiting for primary human lymphocyte activation .


Cyclosporine ( CsA ) is both a clinical immunosuppressive drug and a probe to dissect intracellular signaling pathways .


In vitro , CsA inhibits lymphocyte gene activation by inhibiting the phosphatase activity of calcineurin ( CN ) .
5,7 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In clinical use , CsA treatment inhibits 50-75 % of CN activity in circulating leukocytes .
10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

We modeled this degree of CN inhibition in primary human leukocytes in vitro in order to study the effect of partial CN inhibition on the downstream signaling events that lead to gene activation .
5,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein

In CsA -treated leukocytes stimulated by calcium ionophore , the degree of reduction in CN activity was accompanied by a similar degree of inhibition of each event tested : dephosphorylation of nuclear factor of activated T cell proteins , nuclear DNA binding , activation of a transfected reporter gene construct , IFN-gamma and IL-2 mRNA accumulation , and IFN-gamma production .
1,4 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|31,38 G#protein|46,50 G#DNA|58,59 G#protein

Furthermore , the degree of CN inhibition was reflected by a similar degree of reduction in lymphocyte proliferation and IFN-gamma production in the allogeneic mixed lymphocyte cultures .
5,6 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,27 G#cell_line

These data support the conclusion that CN activity is rate-limiting for the activation of primary human T lymphocytes .
6,7 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_type

Thus , the reduction of CN activity observed in CsA -treated patients is accompanied by a similar degree of reduction in lymphocyte gene activation , and accounts for the immunosuppression observed .
5,6 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

Selection of down-regulated sequences along the monocytic differentiation of leukemic HL60 cells .
2,4 G#DNA|9,12 G#cell_line

In order to dissect the molecular mechanisms of monocytic differentiation we have developed a subtractive hybridisation method based on a simplified ' representational difference analysis ' .


We have selected 16 sequences and confirmed their down-regulation along the TPA -induced monocytic differentiation of HL60 cells .
3,5 G#DNA|16,18 G#cell_line

Among these sequences we have identified the alpha-tubulin , the TaxREB protein and two ribosomal protein sequences which had not been previously described as differentially expressed .
7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA

These results add to our knowledge about the molecules implicated along the monocytic differentiation and growth arrest of leukemic cells and provide a first step in the study of their respective roles .
18,20 G#cell_type

Control of NF-kappa B activity by the I kappa B beta inhibitor .
2,4 G#protein|7,12 G#protein

The transcription factor NF-kappa B is maintained in an inactive cytoplasmic state by I kappa B inhibitors .
1,3 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|13,17 G#protein

In mammalian cells , I kappa B alpha and I kappa B beta proteins have been purified and shown to be the inhibitors of NF-kappa B through their association with the p65 or c-Rel subunits .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,8 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|9,14 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|31,35 G#protein

In addition , we have isolated a third NF-kappa B inhibitor , I kappa B epsilon ( 1 ) .
8,10 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,16 G#protein

Upon treatment with a large variety of inducers , I kappa B alpha , I kappa B beta are proteolytically degraded , resulting in NF-kappa B translocation into the nucleus .
9,13 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

Here we show that in E29.1 T cell hybridoma I kappa B alpha and I kappa B beta are equally associated with p65 and that I kappa B beta is degraded in response to TNF alpha in contrast to what has been originally published .
5,9 G#cell_line|9,13 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,29 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

Our data also suggest that , unlike I kappa B alpha , I kappa B beta is constitutively phosphorylated and resynthesized as a hypophosphorylated form .
7,11 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

The absence of slow migrating forms of I kappa B beta following stimulation suggests that the phosphorylation does not necessarily constitute the signal-induced event which targets the molecule for proteolysis .
7,11 G#protein

Agonistic activity of a CD40-specific single-chain Fv constructed from the variable regions of mAb G28-5 .
4,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

A single-chain Fv ( sFv ) was expressed from the variable regions of the CD40-specific mAb G28-5 .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

The molecule bound CD40 with a high affinity ( 2.2 nM ) and was a monomer in solution .
3,4 G#protein

Surprisingly , G28-5 sFv was a potent CD40 agonist that rapidly crosslinked CD40 on the cell surface but did not crosslink CD40 -Ig in solution .
2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

G28-5 sFv was a more potent agonist than G28-5 IgG and was able to stimulate CD40 responses by B cells and monocytes .
0,2 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

G28-5 IgG partially blocked , whereas G28-5 sFv augmented CD40 responses during stimulation with natural ligand ( gp39-CD8 fusion protein ) .
0,2 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

These results indicate that the functional activity of ligands built from the binding site of G28-5 is highly dependent upon the size and physical properties of the molecule both in solution and on the cell surfaces .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

C/EBP activates the human corticotropin-releasing hormone gene promoter .
0,1 G#protein|3,8 G#DNA

The purpose of these studies was to identify whether transcription factors , associated with cytokine signalling , affected promoter activity of the corticotropin releasing hormone ( CRH ) gene .
26,27 G#protein|22,29 G#DNA

Fragments of a 3.6 kb sequence of the human CRH gene promoter were amplified by PCR and ligated upstream of a CAT reporter .
9,10 G#protein|8,12 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

These constructs were transfected into a variety of cell lines , either alone or together , with transcription factor expression vectors .

Basal activity of a 3070 bp CRH promoter fragment was only seen in neuronal and lymphoblastoid cell lines .
6,7 G#protein|4,9 G#DNA|15,18 G#cell_line

Promoter activity was increased by the transcription factors C/EBPbeta ( NF-IL6 ) and more strongly , by C/EBPdelta ( NF-IL6beta ) .
6,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Increased CRH promoter activity following phorbol ester treatment was inhibited by a dominant negative NF-IL6 mutant , showing that the effects of phorbol ester were principally mediated by C/EBP .
1,2 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Moreover , the inverse changes in the expression of CRH in the hypothalamus and spleens of arthritic rats were paralleled by similar inverse changes in NF-IL6beta expression in these organs .
9,10 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

These data show that some transcription factors associated with cytokine signalling can also activate the CRH promoter .
5,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

Aberrant splicing of the TSG101 and FHIT genes occurs frequently in multiple malignancies and in normal tissues and mimics alterations previously described in tumours .
4,8 G#DNA

Intragenic deletions of TSG101 , the human homolog of a mouse gene ( tsg101 ) that acts to suppress malignant cell growth , were reported in human breast tumours .
3,4 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|26,29 G#cell_type

We screened TSG101 for somatic mutations in DNA and RNA samples isolated from a variety of common human malignancies , EBV-immortalised B-cells , and normal lung parenchyma .
2,3 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type

Intragenic TSG101 deletions in RNA transcripts were frequently found in all types of samples .
1,2 G#DNA|4,6 G#RNA

Analysis of DNA failed to show genomic rearrangements corresponding to transcripts containing deletions in the same samples .


The breakpoints of most transcript deletions coincide with genuine or cryptic splice site sequences , suggesting that they result from alternative or aberrant splicing .
11,14 G#DNA

A similar spectrum of transcript deletions has previously been described in the putative tumour suppressor gene FHIT .
12,16 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA

We analysed FHIT in the same series of RNA samples and detected truncated FHIT transcripts frequently in both tumour and normal tissues .
2,3 G#DNA|8,10 G#RNA|13,14 G#DNA|13,15 G#RNA

In addition , transcripts from TSG101 , FHIT and seven other genes were analysed in RNA isolated from normal peripheral blood lymphocytes .
5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|18,22 G#cell_type

Large TSG101 and FHIT intragenic transcript deletions were detected and these appeared to be the predominant transcript in ' aged ' lymphocytes .
1,2 G#DNA|3,4 G#DNA|18,22 G#cell_type

Similar alterations were not detected in transcripts of the other genes which were analysed .


Our findings demonstrate that truncated TSG101 and FHIT transcripts are commonly detected in both normal and malignant tissues and that a significant fraction of these are likely to be the result of aberrant splicing .
4,9 G#RNA

While we can not exclude that alterations in TSG101 and FHIT occur during cancer development , our data indicate that in this context the commonly observed transcript abnormalities are misleading .
8,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA

Inhibition of proliferation and apoptosis of human and rat T lymphocytes by curcumin , a curry pigment .
6,11 G#cell_type

Curcumin ( diferuoylmethane ) , the yellow pigment in the rhizome of tumeric ( Curcuma longa ) , an ingredient of curry spice , is known to exhibit a variety of pharmacological effects including antitumor , antiinflammatory , and antiinfectious activities .


Although its precise mode of action remains elusive , curcumin has been shown to suppress the activity of the AP-1 transcription factor in cells stimulated to proliferate .
19,20 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

In this study , we observed that curcumin ( 50 microM ) inhibited proliferation of rat thymocytes stimulated with concanavalin A ( Con A ) as well as that of human Jurkat lymphoblastoid cells in the logarithmic growth phase .
15,17 G#cell_type|30,34 G#cell_type

The pigment also inhibited apoptosis in dexamethasone-treated rat thymocytes and in UV-irradiated Jurkat cells as judged by DNA ladder formation , cellular morphological changes , and flow cytometry analysis .
7,9 G#cell_type|6,9 G#cell_line|11,14 G#cell_line

The inhibition of apoptosis by curcumin in rat thymocytes was accompanied by partial suppression of AP-1 activity .
7,9 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

Complete suppression of AP-1 activity was observed in Con A -treated , proliferating thymocytes .
3,4 G#protein|8,14 G#cell_line

The capacity of curcumin to inhibit both cell growth and death strongly implies that these two biological processes share a common pathway at some point and that curcumin affects a common step , presumably involving a modulation of the AP-1 transcription factor .
39,40 G#protein|40,42 G#protein

Interleukin-7 upregulates the interleukin-2-gene expression in activated human T lymphocytes at the transcriptional level by enhancing the DNA binding activities of both nuclear factor of activated T cells and activator protein-1 .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#DNA|6,10 G#cell_type|25,28 G#cell_type|29,31 G#protein

In the present report , we studied the role of the stromal-derived cytokine interleukin-7 ( IL-7 ) in the IL-2-gene regulation in activated T lymphocytes .
11,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#DNA|22,25 G#cell_type

Production of IL-2 requires the formation of transcription factors involved in the IL-2 -gene regulation .
2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

T-cell receptor ( TCR ) /CD3 engagement results in the activation of nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) , activator protein-1 ( AP-1 ) , and nuclear factor kappaB ( NFkappaB ) , whereas the CD28 responsive complex ( CD28RC ) is activated in response to the CD28 signal .
0,2 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|38,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|50,51 G#protein

Costimulation of phytohemagglutinin /anti-CD28 activated T lymphocytes with IL-7 induces a fivefold enhanced IL-2 -mRNA accumulation and a 2.5-fold enhanced protein secretion .
2,3 G#protein|4,7 G#cell_type|2,7 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

The IL-2 -gene transcription rate is increased 3.4-fold , indicating that the effect of IL-7 is in part mediated at the transcriptional level .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein

The molecular mechanisms underlying the IL-7 effect involve the upregulation of the DNA binding activity of NFAT ( 60 % ) and AP-1 ( 120 % ) , without affecting the activities of NFkappaB and CD28RC , which was confirmed by transfection assays .
5,6 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

We also show that the IL-7 -induced enhancement of the AP-1 -DNA binding activity is not cyclosporin A-sensitive .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Since AP-1 is part of the NFAT complex , we conclude that the IL-7 -signaling pathway is involved in the activation of the fos and jun proteins of which AP-1 consists .
1,2 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

The spatial distribution of human immunoglobulin genes within the nucleus : evidence for gene topography independent of cell type and transcriptional activity .
4,7 G#DNA

The three-dimensional positioning of immunoglobulin ( Ig ) genes within the nucleus of human cells was investigated using in situ hybridization and confocal microscopy .
4,9 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_type

The visualization of heavy and light chain genes in B-lymphoid cells showed that the three Ig genes are differentially and nonrandomly distributed in different nuclear subvolumes : the kappa genes were found to be preferentially confined to an outer nuclear volume , whereas the gamma and lambda genes consistently occupied more central positions within the nucleus , the lambda genes being more interior when compared with the gamma genes .
3,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#cell_type|15,17 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|44,48 G#DNA|58,60 G#DNA|67,69 G#DNA

The data further show that these overall topographical distributions are independent of gene transcriptional activity and are conserved in different cell types .
19,22 G#cell_type

Although subtle gene movements within those defined topographical regions can not be excluded by this study , the results indicate that tissue specificity of gene expression is not accompanied by drastic changes in gene nuclear topography , rather suggesting that gene organization within the nucleus may be primarily dependent on structural constraints imposed on the respective chromosomes .
56,57 G#DNA

Dominant cytotoxic T lymphocyte response to the immediate-early trans-activator protein , BZLF1 , in persistent type A or B Epstein-Barr virus infection .
1,4 G#cell_type|7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Five healthy human leukocyte antigen-B8 ( HLA-B8 ) -positive virus carriers were studied to investigate the CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocyte ( CTL ) response to an HLA-B8-restricted peptide , RAKFKQLLQ , located in the Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) immediate-early trans-activator protein , BZLF1 .
16,20 G#cell_type|34,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein

Of the 5 virus carriers , 4 were infected with type A and 1 with type B EBV .


Using limiting-dilution analysis of peripheral blood mononuclear cells , a high RAKFKQLLQ -specific CTL precursor frequency was demonstrated after specific peptide or autologous lymphoblastoid cell line stimulation in both type A and type B EBV carriers .
4,8 G#cell_type

The RAKFKQLLQ -specific CTL precursor frequencies in all 5 persons were at least as dominant as those observed with two other EBV-associated , HLA-B8-restricted latent epitopes , FLRGRAYGL and QAKWRLQTL .
21,26 G#protein

These findings show that healthy virus carriers maintain a high frequency of BZLF1 -specific memory T cells , potentially to control virus spread from lytically infected cells .
12,13 G#protein|12,17 G#cell_type|24,27 G#cell_type

The DNA binding domain of the A-MYB transcription factor is responsible for its B cell-specific activity and binds to a B cell 110-kDa nuclear protein .
1,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|20,25 G#protein

Expression studies as well as the use of transgenic animals have demonstrated that the A-MYB transcription factor plays central and specific role in the regulation of mature B cell proliferation and/or differentiation .
14,15 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_type

Furthermore , it is highly expressed in Burkitt 's lymphoma cells and may participate in the pathogenesis of this disease .
7,11 G#cell_line

We have therefore investigated the transcriptional activity of A-MYB and its regulation in several human lymphoid cell lines using co-transfection assays and show that A-MYB is transcriptionally active in all the B cell lines studied , but not in T cells .
8,9 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|31,34 G#cell_line|39,41 G#cell_type

In particular the best responder cell line was the Burkitt 's cell line Namalwa .
4,7 G#cell_line|9,14 G#cell_line

The activity of A-MYB in B and not T cells was observed when either an artificial construct or the c-MYC promoter was used as a reporter .
3,4 G#protein|5,10 G#cell_type|19,21 G#DNA

Furthermore , the functional domains responsible for DNA binding , transactivation , and negative regulation , previously characterized in a fibroblast context , were found to have similar activity in B cells .
3,5 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type

The region of A-MYB responsible for the B cell specific activity was defined to be the N-terminal 218 amino acids containing the DNA binding domain .
3,4 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Finally , a 110-kDa protein has been identified in the nuclei of all the B , but not T , cell lines that specifically binds to this A-MYB N-terminal domain .
3,5 G#protein|14,22 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#protein

We hypothesize that this 110-kDa protein may be a functionally important B cell-specific co-activator of A-MYB .
4,6 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Transcription factor Egr-1 activity down-regulates Fas and CD23 expression in B cells .
2,3 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

Activation of mature B cells via Ag receptor cross-linking induces transient expression of the transcription factor Egr-1 .
3,5 G#cell_type|6,8 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Although the activating signals leading to Egr-1 induction have been studied extensively , little is known about the genes that are placed further downstream within this activation cascade and that are transcriptionally regulated by Egr-1 .
6,7 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

To identify such target genes , we established Egr-1 -overexpressing transfectants from the murine B cell line K46 and from human Ramos B cells .
3,5 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line|13,18 G#cell_line|20,24 G#cell_line

All clones derived from K46 B cells showed increased expression of CD44 .
4,7 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

Most interestingly , expression of CD95 ( Fas /Apo-1 ) and of CD23 was down-regulated in all K46 transfectants .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line

As a consequence , they became resistant to apoptosis induced by anti-CD95 Ab treatment .
11,13 G#protein

Similarly , the Egr-1 -expressing Ramos cells showed reduced levels of CD95 expression .
3,4 G#protein|3,7 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

Thus , Egr-1 seems to control the expression of downstream target genes not only as a transcriptional activator , but also as a repressor molecule .
2,3 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|23,25 G#protein

In B cells , Egr-1 therefore plays a critical role in integrating the short-lived signal delivered by triggering of the Ag receptor into phenotypic changes , including repression of CD95 and CD23 transcription .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Regulation of NF-kappa B activity by I kappa B alpha and I kappa B beta stability .
2,4 G#protein

Transcription factor NF-kappa B must be released from cytoplasmic inhibitory molecules ( I kappa Bs ) in order to move to the nucleus and to activate its target genes .
0,2 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA

Little is known about the mechanisms regulating the maintenance of constitutive nuclear NF-kappa B in some cell-types and of sustained nuclear NF-kappa B activity after stimulation .
12,14 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

Increased turnover has been implicated in the regulation of constitutive NF-kappa B activity in mature B cells .
10,12 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

We therefore compared the turnover of I kappa B alpha and I kappa B beta in mature B cells and HeLa cells .
6,10 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_line

Both proteins display a high turnover in B cells although I kappa B beta is considerably more stable than I kappa B alpha .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,14 G#protein|19,23 G#protein

The half-life of both inhibitors is increased in HeLa cells .
8,10 G#cell_line

In contrast , all other NF-kappa B /I kappa B molecules tested are relatively stable in both cell-types .
5,7 G#protein

The elevated turnover of endogenous I kappa B alpha in Namalwa cells is inhibited by a proteasome inhibitor and thus seems to be driven by the same degradation machinery as the slower turnover in non-B cells .
5,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|34,36 G#cell_type

Furthermore , we investigated the processes involved in persistent activation of NF-kappa B .
11,13 G#protein

TNF-alpha signaling leads to a rapid depletion of cellular I kappa B beta pools .
9,13 G#protein

I kappa B alpha is efficiently resynthesized whereas I kappa B beta levels stay low for a prolonged time .
0,4 G#protein|8,12 G#protein

NF-kappa B binding activity can be detected for several hours after stimulation .
0,2 G#protein

We found that removal of the TNF-alpha containing medium causes a rapid decrease in nuclear NF-kappa B .
6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

A phosphoform of newly synthesized I kappa B alpha is visible when degradation by the proteasome is inhibited and new I kappa B alpha displays the same properties regarding phosphorylation and degradation in response to a second inducer .
5,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,24 G#protein

There is no significant difference in the turnover of pre- and post-inductive I kappa B alpha .
12,16 G#protein

These observations suggest that resynthesis of I kappa B alpha and removal of the stimulus are obligatory steps for the inactivation of nuclear NF kappa B .
6,10 G#protein|22,26 G#protein

Selection of a diverse TCR repertoire in response to an Epstein-Barr virus -encoded transactivator protein BZLF1 by CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes during primary and persistent infection .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|10,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_type

We investigated the CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocyte ( CTL ) repertoire to an HLA B8-restricted peptide , RAKFKQLLQ , located in the Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) immediate-early protein , BZLF1 .
3,7 G#cell_type|3,11 G#protein|22,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Repertoire selection was monitored by determining the TCR beta chain sequences of RAKFKQLLQ -specific CTL established from primary infected and healthy virus carriers .
7,11 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_line

PCR analysis of spontaneous EBV -transformed lymphoblastoid cell lines ( LCL ) from three individuals with primary infection showed that two were infected with type A and one with type B EBV .
3,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line

Polyclonal and clonal CTL that were generated by stimulating peripheral blood mononuclear cells with an HLA B8+ homozygous LCL lysed T cell blasts pulsed with the peptide , RAKFKQLLQ ; lysis of certain HLA B8+ LCL targets was associated with the abundance of BZLF1 transcripts .
0,4 G#cell_line|9,13 G#cell_type|15,23 G#cell_line|43,44 G#protein|43,45 G#RNA

TCR beta analysis showed that while there was loop length restriction in the putative peptide contact site of all responding beta chains , diverse and unique ( non-recurrent ) TCR beta clonotypes were selected in individuals during primary infection and continued to emerge after long-term virus exposure .
0,2 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein|29,32 G#cell_line|25,32 G#cell_line

TCR -contact site heterogeneity was excluded as the selective force in diversity generation since the epitope-encoded sequences were found to be identical within endogenous virus isolates .
0,1 G#protein

In this first study of TCR repertoire selection for an EBV lytic antigen , a BZLF1 -reactive component of diverse clonotypes was identified in primary type A or type B EBV infection which was sustained in the EBV -specific memory response throughout life-long infection .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

This diversity selection is likely to play a critical role in maintaining a balanced viral load throughout EBV persistence .


Molecular mechanisms of anoxia/reoxygenation-induced neutrophil adherence to cultured endothelial cells .
7,10 G#cell_line

The objectives of this study were to ( 1 ) determine the time course of neutrophil adhesion to monolayers of human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVECs ) that were exposed to 60 minutes of anoxia followed by 30 to 600 minutes of reoxygenation and ( 2 ) define the mechanisms responsible for both the early ( minutes ) and late ( hours ) hyperadhesivity of postanoxic HUVECs to human neutrophils .
20,25 G#cell_line|26,27 G#cell_line|67,68 G#cell_line|66,68 G#cell_line|69,71 G#cell_type

The results clearly demonstrate that anoxia /reoxygenation ( A/R ) leads to a biphasic increase in neutrophil adhesion to HUVECs , with peak responses occurring at 30 minutes ( phase 1 ) and 240 minutes ( phase 2 ) after reoxygenation .
19,20 G#cell_line

Oxypurinol and catalase inhibited phase-1 adhesion , suggesting a role for xanthine oxidase and H2O2 .
2,3 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

In comparison , platelet activating factor ( PAF ) contributed to both phases of neutrophil adhesion .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Anti-intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) and anti-P-selectin antibodies ( monoclonal antibodies [ mAbs ] ) attenuated phase-1 neutrophil adhesion , consistent with roles for constitutively expressed ICAM-1 and enhanced surface expression of preformed P-selectin .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

Phase-2 neutrophil adhesion was attenuated by an anti-E-selectin mAb , indicating a dominant role of this adhesion molecule in the late phase response .
7,9 G#protein

Pretreatment with actinomycin D and cycloheximide or with competing ds-oligonucleotides containing the nuclear factor-kappa B or activator protein-1 cognate DNA sequences significantly attenuated phase-2 response , suggesting a role for de novo macromolecule synthesis .
12,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

Surface expression of ICAM-1 , P-selectin , and E-selectin on HUVECs correlated with the phase -1 and -2 neutrophil adhesion responses .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_line

Collectively , these findings indicate that A/R elicits a two-phase neutrophil-endothelial cell adhesion response that involves transcription-independent and transcription-dependent surface expression of different endothelial cell adhesion molecules .
23,27 G#protein

Characterization of CD40 signaling determinants regulating nuclear factor-kappa B activation in B lymphocytes .
2,3 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

CD40 signaling to B cells is important for generating an effective humoral immune response .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type

CD40 ligation leads to B cell activation events such as proliferation , Ig secretion , isotype switching , and up-regulation of cell surface molecules , as well as the generation of memory B cells .
0,1 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|31,34 G#cell_type

Many of these events are dependent upon the ability of CD40 to activate the transcription factor NF-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) .
10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

To define the CD40 signaling components upstream of NF-kappa B activation and the functional consequences downstream of NF-kappa B activation , we examined mouse B cell transfectants expressing wild-type or mutant human CD40 .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|23,27 G#cell_line|28,33 G#protein

Analysis of CD40 cytoplasmic domain truncation and point mutants defined a 10-amino acid CD40 cytoplasmic signaling determinant required for NF-kappa B activation .
2,3 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|11,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

A threonine residue at position 234 , previously shown to be important for CD40 association with TNF receptor-associated factor 2 ( TRAF2 ) , TRAF3 , and TRAF5 , was not required for NF-kappa B activation .
4,6 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|33,35 G#protein

This suggests that in B cells , CD40 -induced NF-kappa B activation can occur independently of TRAF2 and TRAF5 association .
4,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

NF-kappa B activation was independent of the transmembrane domain of CD40 , suggesting that it is independent of p23 , a molecule that associates with CD40 in a region other than the cytoplasmic domain .
0,2 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|32,34 G#protein

Proteasome-dependent inhibitory kappa B alpha ( I kappa B alpha ) and I kappa B beta degradation occurred downstream of CD40 ligation and preceded CD40 -mediated NF-kappa B nuclear translocation .
6,10 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

CD40- or pervanadate- mediated I kappa B tyrosine phosphorylation was not detected .


NF-kappa B activation correlated with the ability of CD40 to induce Ab secretion and the up-regulation of ICAM-1 and LFA-1 .
0,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

However , NF-kappa B activation was insufficient for CD40 -mediated up-regulation of B7-1 , Fas , and CD23 .
2,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

CD30 -dependent degradation of TRAF2 : implications for negative regulation of TRAF signaling and the control of cell survival .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

CD30 is a cell-surface receptor that can augment lymphocyte activation and survival through its ability to induce the transcription factor NF-kappaB .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

CD30 , however , has also been implicated in the induction of apoptotic cell death of lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type

Here we show that one of the effects of CD30 signal transduction is to render cells sensitive to apoptosis induced by the type 1 tumor necrosis factor receptor ( TNFR1 ) .
9,10 G#protein|22,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

This sensitization is dependent on the TRAF-binding sites within the CD30 cytoplasmic domain .
6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

One of the proteins that binds to these sites is TRAF2 , a signal transduction molecule that is also utilized by TNFR1 to mediate the activation of several downstream kinases and transcription factors .
10,11 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

During CD30 signal transduction , we found that binding of TRAF2 to the cytoplasmic domain of CD30 results in the rapid depletion of TRAF2 and the associated protein TRAF1 by proteolysis .
1,2 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

These data suggest a model in which CD30 limits its own ability to transduce cell survival signals through signal-coupled depletion of TRAF2 .
7,8 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Depletion of intracellular TRAF2 and its coassociated proteins also increased the sensitivity of the cell to undergoing apoptosis during activation of death-inducing receptors such as TNFR1 .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Consistent with this hypothesis , expression of a dominant-negative form of TRAF2 was found to potentiate TNFR1 -mediated death .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

These studies provide a potential mechanism through which CD30 , as well as other TRAF-binding members of the TNFR superfamily , can negatively regulate cell survival .
8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Analysis of myeloid-associated genes in human hematopoietic progenitor cells .
2,4 G#DNA|5,9 G#cell_type

The distribution of myeloid lineage-associated cytokine receptors and lysosomal proteins was analyzed in human CD34+ cord blood cell ( CB ) subsets at different stages of myeloid commitment by reverse-transcriptase polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) .
3,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,22 G#cell_line

The highly specific granulomonocyte-associated lysosomal proteins myeloperoxidase ( MPO ) and lysozyme ( LZ ) , as well as the transcription factor PU.1 , were already detectable in the most immature CD34+Thy-1+ subset .
4,6 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_line

Messenger RNA ( mRNA ) levels for the granulocyte-colony stimulating factor ( G-CSF ) receptor , granulocyte-macrophage ( GM ) -CSF receptor alpha subunit and tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) receptors I ( p55 ) and II ( p75 ) were also detected in this subset in addition to c-kit and flt-3 , receptors known to be expressed on progenitor cells .
0,2 G#RNA|3,4 G#RNA|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|8,15 G#protein|16,24 G#protein|25,41 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|52,53 G#protein|60,62 G#cell_type

By contrast , the monocyte-macrophage colony stimulating factor ( M-CSF ) receptor was largely absent at this stage and in the CD34+Thy-1-CD45RA- subsets .
4,12 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_line

The M-CSF receptor was first detectable in the myeloid-committed CD34+Thy-l-CD45RA+ subset .
1,3 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line

All other molecules studied were found to be expressed at this stage of differentiation .


Different cocktails of the identified ligands were added to sorted CD34+Thy-1+ single cells .
9,13 G#cell_line

Low proliferative capacity was observed after 1 week in culture in the presence of stem cell factor ( SCF ) + Flt-3 ligand ( FL ) + G-CSF .
14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Addition of GM-CSF to this basic cocktail consistently increased the clonogenic capacity of single CD34+Thy-1+ cells , and this effect was further enhanced ( up to 72.3 +/- 4.3 % on day 7 ) by the inclusion of TNF-alpha .
2,3 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_line|38,39 G#protein

In conclusion , the presence of myeloid-associated growth factor receptor transcripts in CD34+ CB subsets does not discriminate the various stages of differentiation , with the exception of the M-CSF receptor .
6,10 G#protein|6,11 G#RNA|12,15 G#cell_line|29,31 G#protein

In addition , we show that TNF-alpha is a potent costimulatory factor of the very immature CD34+Thy-1+ CB subset .
6,7 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_line

Induction of endothelial cell surface adhesion molecules by tumor necrosis factor is blocked by protein tyrosine phosphatase inhibitors : role of the nuclear transcription factor NF-kappa B .
2,7 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|22,27 G#protein

Recent studies from our laboratory have indicated that protein tyrosine phosphatase ( PTPase ) inhibitors can down-modulate the tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) -mediated activation of the nuclear transcription factor NF-kappa B in ML-1a , a monocytic cell line ( Singh and Aggarwal , J. Biol. Chem. 1995 : 270 : 10631 ) .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,33 G#protein|34,35 G#cell_line|37,40 G#cell_line

Since TNF is one of the major inducers of various adhesion molecules in human endothelial cells and their expression is known to require the activation of NF-kappa B , we examined the effect of PTPase inhibitors on the TNF -mediated induction of intracellular adhesion molecule ( ICAM ) -1 , vascular cell adhesion molecule ( VCAM ) -1 and endothelial leukocyte adhesion molecule ( ELAM ) -1 .
1,2 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|42,49 G#protein|50,58 G#protein|59,67 G#protein

Like ML-1a , human dermal microvessel endothelial cells ( MVEC ) treated with TNF rapidly activated ( within 30 min ) NF-kappa B ; this effect was completely abolished by co-treatment with phenylarsine oxide ( PAO ) , a specific inhibitor of PTPase .
1,2 G#cell_line|3,8 G#cell_line|9,10 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

The induction of ICAM-1 , VCAM-1 , and ELAM-1 by TNF in MVEC occurred within 6 h and was also completely down-regulated by PAO in a dose-dependent manner .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_line

PAO was found to be effective even when added 3 h after TNF , suggesting a rapid mode of action of this inhibitor .
12,13 G#protein

Besides PAO , other inhibitors of PTPase , including pervanadate and diamide , also blocked TNF -dependent NF-kappa B activation and induction of all the three adhesion proteins .
6,7 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

Consistent with these results , the attachment of monocytes to MVEC was also blocked by the PTPase inhibitors .
10,11 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein

Thus , overall , our results demonstrate that a PTPase is involved either directly or indirectly in the pathway leading to the induction of endothelial cell adhesion molecules by TNF .
9,10 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|24,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Because of their role in cell adhesion , PTPase may provide a novel target of drug development for treatment of inflammation , atherogenesis , and tumor metastasis .
8,9 G#protein

Regulation of nuclear factor-kappa B and its inhibitor I kappa B-alpha/MAD-3 in monocytes by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and during human tuberculosis .
2,5 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type

Blood monocytes from patients with active tuberculosis are activated in vivo , as evidenced by an increase in the stimulated release of proinflammatory cytokines , such as TNF -alpha , and the spontaneous expression of IL-2R .
0,2 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

Further , monocytes from patients demonstrate an augmented susceptibility to a productive infection with HIV-1 in vitro .
2,3 G#cell_type

Mycobacterium tuberculosis and its components are strong signals to activate monocytes to production of cytokines .
10,11 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

In this study we examined the basis of activation of monocytes during active tuberculosis and by M. tuberculosis .
10,11 G#cell_type

We found a constitutive degradation of I kappa B-alpha , the major cytoplasmic inhibitor of nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) , in freshly isolated PBMC and monocytes from patients with tuberculosis .
6,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_type|29,30 G#cell_type

In contrast , I kappa B-alpha levels in PBMC and monocytes from healthy subjects or from patients with nontuberculous pulmonary conditions were intact .
3,6 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type

Further , by electrophoretic mobility shift assay , NF-kappa B was activated in monocytes from tuberculous patients .
8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

The expression of I kappa B-alpha gene , which is responsive to activation by NF-kappa B , was up-regulated in PBMC and monocytes from patients , but not in mononuclear cells from healthy subjects or those with nontuberculous lung diseases .
3,6 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type

By contrast , the expression of other adherence-associated early genes , such as IL-8 and IL-1 beta , was not up-regulated in PBMC of tuberculous patients .
7,10 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|22,23 G#cell_type

Further , M. tuberculosis and its tuberculin , purified protein derivative , induced the degradation of I kappa B-alpha and the expression of I kappa B-alpha mRNA , and purified protein derivative induced the activation of NF-kappa B in monocytes .

Cooperation of Spi-1/ PU.1 with an activated erythropoietin receptor inhibits apoptosis and Epo -dependent differentiation in primary erythroblasts and induces their Kit ligand-dependent proliferation .
3,4 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

Spi-1/ PU.1 is a myeloid- and B-cell specific transcription factor which is also involved in Friend virus -induced murine erythroleukemia .
1,2 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|4,10 G#protein

The pre-leukemic phase of Friend erythroleukemia results from activation of the erythropoietin receptor ( EpoR ) by the spleen focus forming virus ( SFFV ) envelope glycoprotein , followed by the emergence of leukemic clones characterized by overexpression of Spi-1 and mutation of the p53 tumor suppressor gene .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,27 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|44,48 G#DNA

We developed a heterologous system to analyze the contribution of these alterations to the induction of primary erythroblast transformation .


Avian erythroblasts expressing the activated mouse EpoR ( R129C ) differentiated into erythrocytes in response to hEpo .
0,2 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|4,10 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

Expression of Spi-1 in these cells inhibited this ability to differentiate and rescued the cells from the apoptotic cell death program normally induced upon hEpo withdrawal .
2,3 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Although devoid of any effect by itself , a mutant p53 cooperated with Spi-1 and EpoR ( R129C ) to reinforce both phenotypes .
9,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

Analysis of erythroblasts co-expressing Spi-1 and the wild-type mouse EpoR showed that differentiation arrest and inhibition of apoptosis depended on specific cooperation between Spi-1 and EpoR ( R129C ) .
4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,29 G#protein

This cooperation was also required to induce the sustained proliferation of differentiation-blocked erythroblasts in response to ligand activation of the endogenous tyrosine kinase receptor c-Kit .
11,13 G#cell_line|20,24 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

These results show that Spi-1/ PU.1 requires signals emanating from specific cytokine and growth factor receptors to affect the survival , proliferation and differentiation control of primary erythroblasts .
5,6 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type

They also suggest that the function of Spi-1 /PU.1 in the late phase of Friend leukemia requires specific signaling from the gp55 -modified EpoR generated during the early phase of the disease .
7,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

The role of Rel/ NF-kappa B proteins in viral oncogenesis and the regulation of viral transcription .
4,6 G#protein|3,7 G#protein

Rel /NF-kappa B is a ubiquitous transcription factor that consists of multiple polypeptide subunits , and is subject to complex regulatory mechanisms that involve protein-protein interactions , phosphorylation , ubiquitination , proteolytic degradation , and nucleocytoplasmic translocation .
0,1 G#protein|1,3 G#protein|0,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|11,14 G#protein

The sophisticated control of Rel /NF-kappa B activity is not surprising since this transcription factor is involved in a wide array of cellular responses to extracellular cues , associated with growth , development , apoptosis , and pathogen invasion .
4,5 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

Thus , it is not unexpected that this versatile cellular homeostatic switch would be affected by a variety of viral pathogens , which have evolved mechanisms to utilize various aspects of Rel /NF-kappa B activity to facilitate their replication , cell survival and possibly evasion of immune responses .
31,32 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|31,34 G#protein

This review will cover the molecular mechanisms that are utilized by mammalian oncogenic viruses to affect the activity of Rel/ NF-kappa B transcription factors and the role of Rel /NF-kappa B in the regulation of viral gene expression and replication .
20,22 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|28,31 G#protein

Cellular and molecular mechanisms of IL-5 synthesis in atopic diseases : a study with allergen-specific human helper T cells .
5,6 G#protein|14,19 G#cell_line

BACKGROUND : Cytokines produced by helper T cells are intimately involved in chronic allergic diseases associated with eosinophilic inflammation .
2,3 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_type

OBJECTIVE : We investigated the production of IL-5 , a potent growth factor and chemotactic factor for eosinophils , by CD4+ T lymphocytes in patients with asthma .
7,8 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type|20,23 G#cell_type

METHODS : Allergen-specific T cell clones and T cell hybridomas were established from the peripheral blood lymphocytes of patients with asthma , and the responses to various stimuli were determined .
2,6 G#cell_line|7,10 G#cell_line|14,17 G#cell_type

RESULTS : After nonspecific stimulation , IL-5 production by CD4+ T cells from both atopic and nonatopic subjects with asthma was significantly enhanced compared with that by cells from healthy controls .
6,7 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

Peripheral blood mononuclear cells from atopic asthma patients both proliferated and produced IL-5 after incubation with mite allergen , suggesting that mite-specific helper T cells were involved in the eosinophilic inflammation of atopic asthma .
0,4 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_type|21,25 G#cell_type

A human IL-5 promoter/enhancer luciferase gene construct transfected into IL-5 -producing T cell clones was clearly transcribed after stimulation , indicating that the 515 base pair IL-5 gene segment upstream of the coding region was sufficient to respond to activating signals in human helper T cells .
2,3 G#protein|2,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|9,14 G#cell_line|26,27 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA|43,46 G#cell_type

The same gene segment was not transcribed in IL-5 -nonproducing T cell clones , suggesting that human T cell IL-5 synthesis is regulated at the transcriptional level .
8,9 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein

Experiments with T cell hybridomas confirmed these findings and suggested that a unique transcription factor may be essential for human IL-5 gene transcription .
2,5 G#cell_line|12,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

CONCLUSION : Enhanced IL-5 production by helper T cells seems to cause the eosinophilic inflammation of both atopic and nonatopic asthma .
3,4 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_type

Elucidation of IL-5 -specific regulatory mechanisms may facilitate the development of novel treatments for allergic diseases associated with eosinophilic inflammation .
2,3 G#protein

Cyclosporin A inhibits monocyte tissue factor activation in cardiac transplant recipients .
4,6 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Fibrin deposition and thrombosis have been implicated in both allograft rejection and vasculopathy after cardiac transplantation .


Because monocytes play a pivotal role in the pathophysiology of intravascular coagulation activation through their ability to synthesize tissue factor ( TF ) , we asked ( 1 ) whether monocyte TF activation occurs in cardiac transplant recipients and ( 2 ) whether monocyte TF expression is affected by treatment with cyclosporin A ( CsA ) .
1,2 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

METHODS AND RESULTS : We measured levels of TF activity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and highly purified monocytes /macrophages from 10 consecutive cardiac transplant recipients and 10 healthy control subjects .
8,9 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|16,20 G#cell_type

TF activity generated by both unstimulated and endotoxin-stimulated cells was significantly higher in transplant recipients than in control subjects ( P &lt; .05 ) .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_line|7,9 G#cell_line

Increased monocyte TF expression in transplant recipients was shown to be adversely affected by treatment with CsA : TF induction was markedly reduced by CsA serum concentrations reaching peak CsA drug levels .
2,3 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Inhibition of TF induction in the presence of high CsA blood concentrations was also observed when stimulation of cells was performed with interferon-gamma or interleukin-1beta .
2,3 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

As shown by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and electrophoretic mobility shift assay , respectively , treatment with CsA leads to decreased TF mRNA expression and reduced activation of the NF-kappaB transcription factor , which is known to contribute to the induction of the TF promotor in human monocytes .
21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#RNA|29,30 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|43,45 G#DNA|47,48 G#cell_type|46,48 G#cell_type

CONCLUSIONS : This study demonstrates that TF activation , occurring in mononuclear cells of cardiac transplant recipients , is inhibited by treatment with CsA .
6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Inhibition of monocyte TF induction by CsA may contribute to its successful use in cardiac transplant medicine and might be useful in managing further settings of vascular pathology also known to involve TF expression and NF-kappaB activation .
3,4 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

IL-2 and IL-7 induce heterodimerization of STAT5 isoforms in human peripheral blood T lymphoblasts .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,14 G#cell_type

Despite differences in T cell responses induced by interleukin ( IL ) -2 and IL-7 , both cytokines modulate T cell functions by activation of signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STAT ) proteins .
8,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|25,35 G#protein

We examined the contribution of the two isoforms of STAT5 , STAT5A and STAT5B , to IL-2- and IL-7- induced activation of human peripheral blood T lymphoblasts .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,27 G#cell_type

Both cytokines induced assembly of STAT5A and STAT5B containing complexes capable of binding to the interferon-gamma activation sequence ( GAS ) , and these complexes rapidly translocated ( within 1 min ) into the nucleus of IL-2- or IL-7- treated cells .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|36,41 G#cell_line

The kinetics of this translocation were delayed in IL-7 -treated as compared to IL-2 -treated cells .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_line
