IL-2 and IL-7 were equivalent in their ability to induce tyrosine phosphorylation of STAT5A and STAT5B and to facilitate binding of these STATs to an immobilized GAS element .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA

Both IL-2 and IL-7 induced substantial amounts of STAT5A /STAT5B heterodimerization .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Moreover , we observed constitutive association of STAT3 with each STAT5 isomer .
7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

These data suggest that IL-2 and IL-7 induce assembly of STAT heterodimers in a similar manner and that subsequent cellular responses may be driven by induction of similar sets of genes .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|30,31 G#DNA

Transcription factor NF-kappaB regulates inducible Oct-2 gene expression in precursor B lymphocytes .
0,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|9,12 G#cell_type

The POU transcription factors Oct-1 and Oct-2 regulate the activity of octamer-dependent promoters , including those that direct transcription from rearranged immunoglobulin genes .
1,4 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|21,23 G#protein

Unlike Oct-1 , which is constitutively expressed in many cell types , Oct-2 expression is restricted primarily to B lymphocytes and can be induced in precursor B cells by stimulation with bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) .
1,2 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|25,28 G#cell_type

However , the precise factors that mediate this induction mechanism remain unknown .


In the present study , we monitored Oct-2 expression in cells arrested for the activation of NF-kappaB , an LPS -responsive member of the Rel transcription factor family .
7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|24,28 G#protein

Despite stimulation with LPS , disruption of the NF-kappaB signaling pathway in precursor B cells led to the loss of inducible Oct-2 DNA binding activity in vitro and the suppression of Oct-2 -directed transcription in vivo .
8,9 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

This biochemical defect correlated with a specific block to Oct-2 gene expression at the level of transcription , whereas the expression of Oct-1 was unaffected .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein

The finding that Oct-2 is under NF-kappaB control highlights an important cross-talk mechanism involving two distinct transcription factor families that regulate B lymphocyte function .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

Suppression of MHC class II expression by human class II trans-activator constructs lacking the N-terminal domain .
2,5 G#protein|7,12 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein

The class II trans-activator ( CIITA ) is a bi- or multi-functional domain protein which plays a critical role in the expression of MHC class II genes .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,14 G#protein|23,27 G#DNA

We report that removal of the N-terminal 151 amino acids , encompassing all of the acidic domain but leaving intact the proline / serine / threonine -rich domain , results in a mutant protein with potent suppressive properties for MHC class II expression .
6,10 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|21,28 G#protein|39,42 G#protein

HeLa cells stably or transiently transfected with mutant CIITA constructs showed up to 99 % suppression of MHC class II antigen induction by IFN-gamma and marked suppression of HLA-DRA mRNA expression .
0,2 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|17,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,30 G#RNA

Transient transfection of a B lymphoma line resulted in up to 89 % reduction of constitutive MHC class II expression within 5 days and suppression of HLA-DRA mRNA synthesis .
16,19 G#protein|26,28 G#RNA

Helenalin , an anti-inflammatory sesquiterpene lactone from Arnica , selectively inhibits transcription factor NF-kappaB [ see comments ]
11,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Alcoholic extracts prepared form Arnicae flos , the collective name for flowerheads from Arnica montana and A. chamissonis ssp. foliosa , are used therapeutically as anti-inflammatory remedies .


The active ingredients mediating the pharmacological effect are mainly sesquiterpene lactones , such as helenalin , 11alpha,13-dihydrohelenalin , chamissonolid and their ester derivatives .


While these compounds affect various cellular processes , current data do not fully explain how sesquiterpene lactones exert their anti-inflammatory effect .


We show here that helenalin , and , to a much lesser degree , 11alpha,13-dihydrohelenalin and chamissonolid , inhibit activation of transcription factor NF-kappaB .
21,23 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

This difference in efficacy , which correlates with the compounds ' anti-inflammatory potency in vivo , may be explained by differences in structure and conformation .


NF-kappaB , which resides in an inactive , cytoplasmic complex in unstimulated cells , is activated by phosphorylation and degradation of its inhibitory subunit , IkappaB .
0,1 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Helenalin inhibits NF-kappaB activation in response to four different stimuli in T-cells , B-cells and epithelial cells and abrogates kappaB -driven gene expression .
2,3 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

This inhibition is selective , as the activity of four other transcription factors , Oct-1 , TBP , Sp1 and STAT 5 was not affected .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

We show that inhibition is not due to a direct modification of the active NF-kappaB heterodimer .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Rather , helenalin modifies the NF-kappaB/ IkappaB complex , preventing the release of IkappaB .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

These data suggest a molecular mechanism for the anti-inflammatory effect of sesquiterpene lactones , which differs from that of other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs ( NSAIDs ) , indomethacin and acetyl salicylic acid .


The tax protein of human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 mediates the transactivation of the c-sis/platelet-derived growth factor-B promoter through interactions with the zinc finger transcription factors Sp1 and NGFI-A/Egr-1 .
1,3 G#protein|15,19 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Transcriptional up-regulation of the c-sis/platelet-derived growth factor-B ( PDGF-B ) proto-oncogene by the Tax protein of human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 has been implicated as one possible mechanism of cellular transformation by human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|4,11 G#DNA|13,15 G#protein

In previous work , we identified an essential site in the c-sis/PDGF-B promoter , Tax-responsive element 1 ( TRE1 ) , necessary for transactivation by Tax .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein

We also identified Sp1 , Sp3 , and NGFI-A/Egr-1 as the primary nuclear transcription factors binding to TRE1 which mediate Tax responsiveness .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

In the present work , we have investigated the mechanism ( s ) whereby Tax transactivates the c-sis/PDGF-B proto-oncogene .
14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

In vitro transcription assays showed that Tax was able to significantly increase the transcriptional activity of a template containing the -257 to +74 region of the c-sis/PDGF-B promoter .
6,7 G#protein|20,24 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay analysis showed that Tax increased the DNA binding activity of both Sp1 and NGFI-A/Egr-1 using a TRE1 probe .
7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA

Analysis of Tax mutants showed that two mutants , IEXC29S and IEXL320G , were unable to significantly transactivate the c-sis/PDGF-B promoter .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

Finally , co-immunoprecipitation analysis revealed that Tax is able to stably bind to both Sp1 and NGFI-A/Egr-1 .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Interestingly , co-immunoprecipitation analysis also revealed that Tax mutant IEXC29S is unable to interact with NGFI-A/Egr-1 , whereas Tax mutant IEXL320G is able to interact with NGFI-A/Egr-1 .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Nuclear localization of RelB is associated with effective antigen-presenting cell function .
3,4 G#protein

Dendritic cells ( DC ) are potent APCs that enter resting tissues as precursors and , after Ag exposure , differentiate and migrate to draining lymph nodes .
0,2 G#cell_type|3,4 G#cell_type|7,8 G#cell_type

The phenotype of RelB knockout mice implicates this member of the NF kappa B/Rel family in DC differentiation .
3,4 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type

To further elucidate the role of RelB in DC differentiation , mRNA , intracellular protein expression , and DNA binding activity of RelB were examined in immature and differentiated human DC , as well as other PB mononuclear cell populations .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|11,12 G#RNA|22,23 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type|36,40 G#cell_type

RelB protein and mRNA were detected constitutively in lymphocytes and in activated monocytes , differentiated DC , and monocyte-derived DC .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#RNA|8,9 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_line

Immunohistochemical staining demonstrated RelB within the differentiated lymph node interdigitating DC and follicular DC , but not undifferentiated DC in normal skin .
3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|6,11 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|12,14 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

Active nuclear RelB was detected by supershift assay only in differentiated DC derived from either PB precursors or monocytes and in activated B cells .
2,3 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type

These RelB + APC were potent stimulators of the MLR .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein

The data indicate that RelB expression is regulated both transcriptionally and post-translationally in myeloid cells .
4,5 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Within the nucleus , RelB may specifically transactivate genes that are critical for APC function .
4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type

NF-AT activation induced by a CAML -interacting member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,15 G#protein

Activation of the nuclear factor of activated T cells transcription factor ( NF-AT ) is a key event underlying lymphocyte action .
3,9 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The CAML ( calcium-modulator and cyclophilin ligand ) protein is a coinducer of NF-AT activation when overexpressed in Jurkat T cells .
1,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line

A member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily was isolated by virtue of its affinity for CAML .
4,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Cross-linking of this lymphocyte-specific protein , designated TACI ( transmembrane activator and CAML -interactor ) , on the surface of transfected Jurkat cells with TACI -specific antibodies led to activation of the transcription factors NF-AT , AP-1 , and NFkappaB .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|9,14 G#protein|20,23 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

TACI -induced activation of NF-AT was specifically blocked by a dominant-negative CAML mutant , thus implicating CAML as a signaling intermediate .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Rel/NF-kappa B transcription factors and the control of apoptosis .
0,2 G#protein|2,4 G#protein

The process of apoptosis is used to eliminate unwanted cells from a wide variety of organisms .
8,10 G#cell_type

Various extracellular signals , often converging in common intracellular pathways , can induce apoptosis in a cell-type-specific fashion .


Recent work from several laboratories has demonstrated that Rel/NF-kappa B transcription factors regulate apoptosis in many cell types .
8,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

In most cells , Rel/NF-kappa B transcription factors appear to mediate survival signals that protect cells from apoptosis ; however , under some circumstances , activation of these factors may also promote apoptosis .
4,6 G#protein|6,8 G#protein

A thiol antioxidant regulates IgE isotype switching by inhibiting activation of nuclear factor-kappaB .
4,6 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

The binding site for nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) is present at the promoter region of the germline Cepsilon gene , but there is little information on whether this factor is involved in regulating IgE synthesis by human B cells .
1,3 G#DNA|4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|17,20 G#DNA|34,35 G#protein|37,40 G#cell_type

Accordingly , we studied the role of NF-kappaB in germline Cepsilon transcription by using two human Burkitt 's lymphoma B cell lines , DND39 and DG75 .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|15,22 G#cell_line|23,24 G#cell_line|25,26 G#cell_line

In both cell lines , n-acetyl-L-cysteine ( NAC ) , a potent thiol antioxidant , inhibited the triggering of the nuclear expression of NF-kappaB by IL-4 and by anti-CD40 monoclonal antibody .
2,4 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,31 G#protein

Although IL-4 activated signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STAT ) 6 in addition to NF-kappaB , NAC treatment or the transfection of decoy oligodeoxynucleotides for NF-kappaB or STAT6 only partly blocked IL-4 -induced germline Cepsilon transcription .
1,2 G#protein|3,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#DNA

However , these two decoy oligodeoxynucleotides together almost completely abrogated IL-4 -induced germline Cepsilon transcription .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA

Of note , CD40 -mediated enhancement of IL-4 -driven germline Cepsilon transcription was markedly decreased by NAC or by a decoy oligodeoxynucleotide for NF-kappaB .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

The effect of NAC was also examined on deletional switch recombination underlying the isotype switch to IgE .
16,17 G#protein

NAC inhibited the generation of Smu/Sepsilon switch fragments in normal human B cells costimulated with IL-4 and anti-CD40 monoclonal antibody .
5,8 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

It also abolished IL-4 -induced upregulation of CD40 but promoted upregulation of CD23 .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

These results suggest that coordination of NF-kappaB and STAT6 may be required for induction of germline Cepsilon transcription by IL-4 , and that CD40 -mediated NF-kappaB activation may be important in regulating both enhancement of germline Cepsilon transcription and class switching to IgE .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|35,36 G#DNA|42,43 G#protein

Pathogenesis .


There are many hypotheses concerning the pathogenesis of endometriosis , though no single theory can explain all cases .


It is likely that several mechanisms are involved .


Early studies concentrated on the histogenesis of the endometriotic lesion .


Recent evidence has implicated components of the immune system in the pathogenesis of endometriosis .


This review considers the evidence for different theories of the histogenesis of endometriosis and discusses possible immune factors that may be involved in the pathophysiology of the disease .


ATF1 and CREB trans-activate a cell cycle regulated histone H4 gene at a distal nuclear matrix associated promoter element .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|5,11 G#DNA|13,19 G#DNA

Proteins of the ATF/ CREB class of transcription factors stimulate gene expression of several cell growth-related genes through protein kinase A-related cAMP response elements .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|18,24 G#DNA

The promoter activity of cell cycle regulated histone H4 genes is regulated by at least four principal cis-acting elements which mediate G1/S phase control and/or enhancement of transcription during the cell cycle .
4,10 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA

Using protein-DNA interaction assays we show that the H4 promoter contains two ATF/ CREB recognition motifs which interact with CREB , ATF1 , and ATF2 but not with ATF4/CREB2 .
8,10 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

One ATF/CRE motif is located in the distal promoter at the nuclear matrix-associated Site IV , and the second motif is present in the proximal promoter at Site I .
1,3 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|11,15 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

Both ATF/CRE motifs overlap binding sequences for the multifunctional YY1 transcription factor , which has previously been shown to be nuclear matrix associated .
1,3 G#DNA|4,6 G#DNA|8,12 G#protein

Subnuclear fractionation reveals that there are two ATF1 isoforms which appear to differ with respect to DNA binding activity and partition selectively between nuclear matrix and nonmatrix compartments , consistent with the role of the nuclear matrix in regulating gene expression .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

Site-directed mutational studies demonstrate that Site I and Site IV together support ATF1- and CREB- induced trans-activation of the H4 promoter .
5,7 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA

Thus , our data establish that ATF/CREB factors functionally modulate histone H4 gene transcription at distal and proximal promoter elements .
6,8 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|15,20 G#DNA

Is celiac disease due to molecular mimicry between gliadin peptide -HLA class II molecule -T cell interactions and those of some unidentified superantigen ?
10,14 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

This paper presents a new hypothesis for the etiology and pathogenesis of celiac disease ( CD ) .


It is our contention that CD is triggered by the binding of one or more gliadin peptides to CD -associated HLA class II molecules .
18,24 G#protein

Furthermore , we propose that these putative CD peptides bind to oligosaccharide residues on HLA class II molecules distal to the peptide-binding groove invoking recognition and binding by specialized subsets of gamma delta T cell receptor-bearing lymphocytes .
14,18 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|31,37 G#cell_type

The binding of these gamma delta T cells serves as a signal for abrogation of oral tolerance to ingested proteins setting in motion a series of immune responses directed against the small intestinal epithelium of CD patients .
4,8 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein

CD patients are victimized by this self-distructed immune response because of inheritance of certain combinations of HLA-DQ and DR haplotypes .


Dimers encoded by HLA-DR haplotypes may be the primary restriction elements for lectin-like , gliadin peptides while the degree of immune suppression ( or lack thereof ) to ingested gliadins is governed by inherited HLA-DQ haplotypes .
3,4 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA

Finally , we speculate that molecular mimicry between one or more gliadin peptides and some , as yet unidentified , bacterial or viral superantigen plays a role in disease pathogenesis .
20,24 G#protein

Epstein-Barr virus latent membrane protein-1 triggers AP-1 activity via the c-Jun N-terminal kinase cascade .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

The Epstein-Barr virus latent membrane protein-1 ( LMP-1 ) is an integral membrane protein which transforms fibroblasts and is essential for EBV-mediated B-cell immortalization .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type

LMP-1 has been shown to trigger cellular NF-kappa B activity which , however , can not fully explain the oncogenic potential of LMP-1 .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Here we show that LMP-1 induces the activity of the AP-1 transcription factor , a dimer of Jun/Jun or Jun/Fos proteins .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

LMP-1 effects on AP-1 are mediated through activation of the c-Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ) cascade , but not the extracellular signal-regulated kinase ( Erk ) pathway .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Consequently , LMP-1 triggers the activity of the c-Jun N-terminal transactivation domain which is known to be activated upon JNK -mediated phosphorylation .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Deletion analysis indicates that the 55 C-terminal amino acids of the LMP-1 molecule , but not its TRAF interaction domain , are essential for AP-1 activation .
6,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

JNK -mediated transcriptional activation of AP-1 is the direct output of LMP -1-triggered signaling , as shown by an inducible LMP-1 mutant .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Using a tetracycline-regulated LMP-1 allele , we demonstrate that JNK is also an effector of non-cytotoxic LMP-1 signaling in B cells , the physiological target cells of EBV .
3,4 G#protein|2,5 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

In summary , our data reveal a novel effector of LMP-1 , the SEK/ JNK / c-Jun / AP-1 pathway , which contributes to our understanding of the immortalizing and transforming potential of LMP-1 .
10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Abnormal apoptosis and cell cycle progression in humans exposed to methyl tertiary-butyl ether and benzene contaminating water .


1 . In this study we hypothesized that in individuals with certain genetic makeup , MTBE , benzene or their metabolites act as adducts and may induce programmed cell death .


2 . Our study involved a group of 60 male and female subjects who were exposed to MTBE and benzene -contaminated water concentrations up to 76 PPB for MTBE and 14 PPB for benzene , for a period of 5 to 8 years .


For comparison , we recruited a control group consisting of 32 healthy males and females with similar age distribution and without a history of exposure to MTBE or benzene .


3 . Peripheral blood lymphocytes ( PBL ) of both groups were tested for the percentage of apoptotic cells and cell cycle progression using flow cytometry .
2,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

4 . When apoptotic lymphocytes from exposed individuals were compared to apoptotic lymphocytes from the control group , statistically-significant differences between each mean group were detected ( 26.4 +/- 1.8 and 12.1 +/- 1.3 , respectively ) , indicating an increased rate of apoptosis in 80.5 % of exposed individuals ( P &lt; 0.0001 , Mann-Whitney U-Test ) .
3,5 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type

MTBE and benzene -induced apoptosis is attributed to a discrete block within the cell cycle progression .


Because cell cycle analysis showed that in PBL from chemically- exposed individuals , between 20-50 % of cells were accumulated at the S-G2/M boundaries .
7,8 G#cell_type

5 . One of the signaling molecules which mediates programmed cell death is nuclear factor Kappa-B ( NF-kappa B ) .
5,7 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

NF-kappa B was examined as one of the many molecular mechanisms for mediating cell death by MTBE and benzene .
0,2 G#protein

Indeed , addition of inhibitors of NF-kappa B activation pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ( PDTC ) , to the lymphocytes of the chemically-exposed group was capable of inhibiting programmed cell death by 40 % .
6,8 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

This reversal of apoptosis almost to the control level by inhibitor of NF-kappa B activation may indicate involvement of this signaling molecule in MTBE and benzene induction of programmed cell death .
12,14 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Purification and characterization of the human SR 31747A-binding protein .
5,9 G#protein

A nuclear membrane protein related to yeast sterol isomerase .
1,4 G#protein|6,9 G#protein

SR 31747A , defined as a sigma ligand , is a novel immunosuppressive agent that blocks proliferation of human and mouse lymphocytes .
18,22 G#cell_type

Using a radiolabeled chemical probe , we here purified a target of SR 31747A and called it SR 31747A -binding protein ( SR-BP ) .
17,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Purified SR-BP retained its binding properties and migrated on SDS-polyacrylamide gel as a Mr 28,000 protein .
1,2 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

Cloning of the cDNA encoding human SR-BP shows an open reading frame for a 223-amino acid protein , which is homologous to the recently cloned sigma 1 receptor .
3,4 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#protein|25,28 G#protein

Interestingly , the deduced amino acid sequence was found to be related to fungal C8-C7 sterol isomerase , encoded by the ERG2 gene .
4,7 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

The ERG2 gene product has been identified recently as the molecular target of SR 31747A that mediates antiproliferative effects of the drug in yeast .
1,3 G#DNA|1,4 G#protein

Northern blot analysis of SR-BP gene expression revealed a single transcript of 2 kilobases which was widely expressed among organs , with the highest abundance in liver and the lowest abundance in brain .
4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#RNA

Subcellular localization analysis in various cells , using a specific monoclonal antibody raised against SR-BP , demonstrated that this protein was associated with the nuclear envelope .
9,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

When studying the binding of SR 31747A on membranes from yeast expressing SR-BP , we found a pharmacological profile of sigma 1 receptors ; binding was displaced by (+)-pentazocine , haloperidol , and (+)-SKF 10,047 , with (+)-SKF 10,Â 047 being a more potent competitor than (-)-SKF 10,047 .
12,13 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

Scatchard plot analysis revealed Kd values of 7.1 nM and 0.15 nM for (+)-pentazocine and SR 31747A , respectively , indicating an affinity of SR-BP 50-fold higher for SR 31747A than for pentazocine .
24,25 G#protein

Additionally , we showed that pentazocine , a competitive inhibitor of SR 31747A binding , also prevents the immunosuppressive effect of SR 31747A .


Taken together , these findings strongly suggest that SR-BP represents the molecular target for SR 31747A in mammalian tissues , which could be critical for T cell proliferation .
8,9 G#protein

Phospholipase C gamma 1 overexpression and activation induced by interferon beta in human T lymphocytes : an ISGF3 -independent response .
0,4 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

Interferons exert their antiviral , antiproliferative and immunoregulatory activities by stimulating the expression of several genes .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Such genes disclose a common element within their promoters , defined Interferon Stimulated Response Element ( ISRE ) , which binds a nuclear factor ( s ) translocated from the cytoplasm to the nucleus ( ISGF3 ) after the binding of interferon ( IFN ) to the specific receptor .
8,9 G#DNA|11,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein

Here we report the induction of the synthesis and of the hydrolytic activity of phospholipase C gamma 1 ( PLC gamma 1 ) in human T lymphocytes by IFN-beta .
14,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

The increased level of PLC gamma 1 becomes evident after 90 min of IFN-beta treatment and is still detectable after 24 h .
4,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Neither the PLC gamma 1 overexpression induced by IFN nor the increased hydrolytic activity of the enzyme appear to be affected by pretreatment of the cells with the protein tyrosine kinase inhibitor genistein , which is known to prevent the association of ISGF3 components .
2,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

These results suggest that in human T lymphocytes IFN-beta can activate other transcription factor ( s ) distinct from ISGF3 to regulate PLC gamma 1 expression .
5,8 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

In addition , the ability of this enzyme to hydrolyse PIP2 , also in the presence of genistein , implies the possibility that this enzyme can exert its hydrolytic activity independently of protein tyrosine kinase activation .
7,8 G#protein|32,35 G#protein

Negative regulation by HLA-DO of MHC class II -restricted antigen processing .
3,4 G#protein|5,8 G#protein

HLA-DM is a major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class II-like molecule that facilitates antigen processing by catalyzing the exchange of invariant chain-derived peptides ( CLIP ) from class II molecules for antigenic peptides .
0,1 G#protein|3,12 G#protein|28,31 G#protein

HLA-DO is a second class II-like molecule that physically associates with HLA-DM in B cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

HLA-DO was shown to block HLA-DM function .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Purified HLA-DM -DO complexes could not promote peptide exchange in vitro .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#protein

Expression of HLA-DO in a class II+ and DM+ , DO- human T cell line caused the accumulation of class II- CLIP complexes , indicating that HLA-DO blocked DM function in vivo and suggesting that HLA-DO is an important modulator of class II-restricted antigen processing .
2,3 G#protein|5,15 G#cell_line|19,23 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

Vitamin D receptor : no evidence for allele-specific mRNA stability in cells which are heterozygous for the Taq I restriction enzyme polymorphism .
0,3 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

Allelic variations of the vitamin D receptor ( VDR ) gene have been associated with the risk of developing prostate cancer in men and osteoporosis in postmenopausal women .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|4,11 G#DNA

Three RFLPs ( TaqI , ApaI , BsmI ) define two common haplotypes : BAt and baT .
1,2 G#DNA|3,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA

None of these polymorphisms change the translated protein .
3,4 G#DNA|6,8 G#protein

Since sequence variations in the 3' UTR of VDR have been linked to the different haplotypes , investigators have proposed that the stability of VDR mRNA is influenced by allelic variations .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#RNA

Indirect evidence suggested that allele T is less stable than allele t .
4,6 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA

In this study , we used a RT-PCR based approach to compare the stability of the big T and small t allele in normal heterozygous lymphocytes and the heterozygous cell lines NB4 ( myeloid leukemia ) and PC-3 and DU 145 ( prostate cancers ) .
16,22 G#DNA|23,26 G#cell_type|28,31 G#cell_line|31,32 G#cell_line|37,38 G#cell_line|39,41 G#cell_line

In all three cases , we did not find a significant difference in stability .


Interestingly , we consistently observed 30 % less RT-PCR product derived from the small t allele mRNA in steady state , a finding which also speaks against a higher stability of the small t allele mRNA .
8,10 G#DNA|13,17 G#RNA|32,36 G#RNA

These results indicate a variation in transcriptional regulation rather than mRNA stability between the alleles .
14,15 G#DNA

We hypothesize that an unknown gene or genes in linkage with the polymorphisms is ( are ) responsible for the relationship between risk of prostate cancer and VDR polymorphisms .
12,13 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|28,29 G#DNA

Replication of human immunodeficiency virus-1 in primary human T cells is dependent on the autocrine secretion of tumor necrosis factor through the control of nuclear factor-kappa B activation .
6,10 G#cell_type|17,20 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

Tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) -alpha controls T-cell activation and is a major inducer of human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -1 replication in chronically infected cells .
0,7 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_type

Therefore , we have investigated its role in primary cultures of HIV-infected human T lymphocytes by using neutralizing anti-TNF-alpha antibodies or TNF-alpha .
11,15 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Primary resting T lymphocytes produced TNF-alpha and supported HIV replication after T-cell receptor activation .
5,6 G#protein

Addition of neutralizing anti- TNF-alpha antibodies drastically reduced p24 antigen release and prevented CD4+ cell depletion associated with infection .
4,5 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Anti- TNF-alpha also prevented nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) activation , and a good correlation between this inhibition and inhibition of HIV replication was observed .
1,2 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Moreover , supplementing the cultures with high doses of IL-2 reverted anti- TNF-alpha inhibition of cell proliferation but did not affect the inhibition of HIV p24 antigen release or NF-kappa B activation in the same cultures .
12,13 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

Moreover , anti- TNF-alpha inhibited HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) -driven transcription of a reporter gene in primary T cells in response to activation , either in the presence or the absence of HIV-1 Tat .
3,4 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|19,22 G#cell_type|35,37 G#protein

Our results support an important role for autocrine TNF-alpha secretion in controlling HIV replication in primary T cells because of its ability to maintain NF-kappa B elevated in the nucleus of T cells .
8,9 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|24,26 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

Hypoxia enhances induction of endothelial ICAM-1 : role for metabolic acidosis and proteasomes .
4,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Intercellular adhesion molecule 1 ( ICAM-1 ) is an important molecule in promotion of polymorphonuclear neutrophil transendothelial migration during inflammation .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Coincident with many inflammatory diseases is tissue hypoxia .


Thus we hypothesized that combinations of hypoxia and inflammatory stimuli may differentially regulate expression of endothelial ICAM-1 .
16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Human endothelial cells were exposed to hypoxia in the presence or absence of added lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) and examined for expression of functional ICAM-1 .
0,3 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein

Although hypoxia alone did not induce ICAM-1 , the combination of LPS and hypoxia enhanced ( 3 +/- 0.4-fold over normoxia ) ICAM-1 expression .
6,7 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Combinations of hypoxia and LPS significantly increased lymphocyte binding , and such increases were inhibited by addition of anti- ICAM-1 antibodies or antisense oligonucleotides .
19,20 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Hypoxic endothelia showed a &gt; 10-fold increase in sensitivity to inhibitors of proteasome activation , and combinations of hypoxia and LPS enhanced proteasome -dependent cytoplasmic-to-nuclear localization of the nuclear transcription factor-kappa B p65 ( Rel A ) subunit .
12,13 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,38 G#protein

Such proteasome activation correlated with hypoxia -evoked decreases in both extracellular and intracellular pH .
1,2 G#protein

We conclude from these studies that endothelial hypoxia provides a novel , proteasome -dependent stimulus for ICAM-1 induction .
12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Differanisole A , a novel antitumor antibiotic , enhances growth inhibition and differentiation of human myeloid leukemia cells induced by 9-cis retinoic acid .
14,18 G#cell_type

Differanisole A , 3,5-dichloro-2-hydroxy-4-methoxy-6-n-propylbenzoic acid , inhibited growth of human myeloid leukemia cells .
9,13 G#cell_type

The compound induced G1 arrest and granulocytic differentiation of HL-60 cells , although the differentiation-inducing effect was modest .
9,11 G#cell_line

Differanisole A and 9-cis retinoic acid ( 9cisRA ) synergistically inhibited the growth and induced functional and morphologic differentiation of HL-60 and NB4 cells , whereas the combined treatment with differanisole A and all-trans retinoic acid or 1alpha,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3 was less effective .
20,24 G#cell_line

Similar results were obtained in primary culture of leukemia cells from a patient with acute promyelocytic leukemia .
8,10 G#cell_type

The synergistic effect on growth inhibition and induction of differentiation required simultaneous treatment with differanisole A and 9cisRA .


Differanisole A and an RXR-specific ligand ( Ro47-5944 ) cooperatively inhibited the cell growth , while the combined effect of differanisole A and an RAR-specific ligand Am80 was just additive .


Differanisole A in combination with 9cisRA may have implications for therapy of acute promyelocytic leukemia patients .


The activation of the JAK2 /STAT5 pathway is commonly involved in signaling through the human IL-5 receptor .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

The JAK ( Janus kinase ) family of protein tyrosine kinases and the STATs ( signal transducers and activators of transcription ) have been shown to be activated in response to a number of cytokines and growth factors .
3,5 G#protein|1,7 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,38 G#protein

In this study , we evaluated the activation of JAK /STAT pathway upon human interleukin-5 ( hIL-5 ) stimulation of two different hIL-5 -responsive cell lines , hIL-5 receptor alpha-subunit ( hIL-5R alpha ) cDNA-transfected TF-1 ( TF-h5R alpha ) and butyric-acid -treated YY-1 ( YY-Bu ) , and peripheral eosinophils .
9,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,26 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|27,36 G#cell_line|37,39 G#cell_line|41,44 G#cell_line|45,46 G#cell_line|49,51 G#cell_line

Immunoprecipitation and electrophoretic mobility shift analysis revealed that tyrosine phosphorylation of JAK2 and activation of STAT5 were induced upon stimulation with hIL-5 in all three cell types , while STAT1 activation was only observed in eosinophils .
11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|35,36 G#cell_type

These results indicate that JAK2 /STAT5 activation is a common JAK /STAT pathway for hIL-5 -mediated signal in these cells .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Dysregulation of monocytic nuclear factor-kappa B by oxidized low-density lipoprotein .
3,6 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

Nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) /Rel transcription factors may be involved in atherosclerosis , as is suggested by the presence of activated NF-kappa B in human atherosclerotic lesions .
4,6 G#protein|0,10 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

The aim of the present study was to investigate the effects of oxidized LDL ( oxLDL ) on the NF-kappa B system in human THP-1 monocytic cells as well as adherent monocytes .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_line|30,32 G#cell_type

Our results demonstrate that short-term incubation of these cells with oxLDL activated p50/p65 containing NF-kappa B dimers and induced the expression of the target gene IL-8 .
10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA

This activation of NF-kappa B was inhibited by the antioxidant and H2O2 scavenger pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate and the proteasome inhibitor PSI .
3,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

The oxLDL -induced NF-kappa B activation was accompanied by an initial depletion of I kappa B-alpha followed by a slight transient increase in the level of this inhibitor protein .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

In contrast , long-term treatment with oxLDL prevented the lipopolysaccharide -induced depletion of I kappa B-alpha , accompanied by an inhibition of both NF-kappa B activation and the expression of tumor necrosis factor-alpha and interleukin-1 beta genes .
6,7 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|30,37 G#DNA

These observations provide additional evidence that oxLDL is a potent modulator of gene expression and suggest that ( dys ) regulation of NF-kappa B /Rel is likely to play an important role in atherogenesis .
6,7 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Suppression of nuclear factor kappa B and CD18 -mediated leukocyte adhesion to the corneal endothelium by dexamethasone .
2,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

PURPOSE : To demonstrate that leukocyte adhesion to cultured corneal endothelial cells is mediated by the CD18 antigen , and to determine whether dexamethasone directly suppresses adhesion by inhibiting activation of nuclear factor kappa B ( NFkappaB ) .
8,12 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|31,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

METHODS : Cultured bovine corneal endothelium was stimulated for 6 hours by 40 micron/ml tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNFalpha ) .
14,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Dexamethasone was added 1 hour before TNFalpha stimulation in the dexamethasone group .
6,7 G#protein

After stimulation , neutrophils separated from a healthy human volunteer were added with or without anti- CD18 antibody .
16,17 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

The culture plate was settled for 15 minutes at 37 degrees C , and then neutrophils were activated by N-formyl-methionyl-leucyl-phenylalanine for 5 minutes .
15,16 G#cell_type

Nonadherent neutrophils were removed by sealing and inverting the culture well .
1,2 G#cell_type

The intracellular localization of NFkappaB after TNFalpha simulation was determined by confocal immunocytochemistry using an anti-p65 antibody .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

RESULTS : Neutrophil adhesion to cultured corneal endothelial cells increased significantly on exposure to TNFalpha ( 451.4+/-45.4 cells/mm2 , n = 16 ) compared to control ( 156.7+/-27.3 cells/mm2 , n = 16 , P &lt; 0.01 ) .
5,9 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein

This increased adhesion was suppressed by the addition of anti- CD18 antibody ( 157.6+/-25.1 cells/mm2 , n = 8 , P &lt; 0.01 ) and by pretreatment with 10(-7) M dexamethasone ( 207.9+/-31.5 cells/mm2 , n = 10 , P &lt; 0.01 ) .
10,11 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

Immunocytochemistry 60 minutes after stimulation revealed that NFkappaB was located in the cytoplasm in unstimulated cells ; however , the addition of TNFalpha caused NFkappaB to translocate into the nucleus .
7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Pretreatment with dexamethasone tapered NFkappaB translocation into the nucleus .
4,5 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : Leukocyte adhesion to the corneal endothelium was shown to be mediated by CD18 expressed on activated leukocytes .
14,15 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type

Pretreatment of the endothelium with dexamethasone inhibited leukocyte adhesion ; this may be due in part to the suppression of NFkappaB entry into the nucleus .
20,21 G#protein

Molecular characterization and pattern of tissue expression of the gene for neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin from humans .
11,14 G#protein

Neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin ( NGAL ) is a 25-kDa lipocalin first identified as a protein stored in specific granules of the human neutrophil .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

The protein is believed to bind small lipophilic substances such as bacterial derived formylpeptides and lipopolysaccharides ( LPS ) and might function as a modulator of inflammation .


To characterize the regulation of NGAL further , we have cloned and sequenced a 5869-bp region of the NGAL gene including 1695 bp of the 5' nontranscribed region and a 3696-bp coding region encompassing seven exons and six introns .
5,6 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|30,33 G#DNA|34,39 G#DNA

The transcriptional start sites were identified by an RNase protection assay .
1,4 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein

The NGAL gene is highly homologous to the mouse gene 24p3 .
1,2 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA

NGAL was expressed in bone marrow and in tissues that are prone to exposure to microorganisms .
0,1 G#protein

Potential cis-acting elements were identified in the promoter region of the NGAL gene by computer analysis and include binding sites for CTF/CBP , the hematopoietic transcription factors GATA-1 and PU.1 , and the LPS -inducible factor NF-kappa B .
1,3 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|33,38 G#protein

Human neutrophils express GH-N gene transcripts and the pituitary transcription factor Pit-1b .
1,2 G#cell_type|0,2 G#cell_type|3,5 G#DNA|3,6 G#RNA|8,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Since GH stimulates the development and function of granulocytes , we investigated the expression of GH in granulocyte subsets .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type

By immunocytochemistry , 25 +/- 7 % of the human neutrophils were shown to express immunoreactive GH , whereas eosinophils were negative .
10,11 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type

Reversed transcription ( RT ) -PCR analysis demonstrated GH mRNA in neutrophils .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|11,12 G#cell_type

Restriction analysis revealed that neutrophils express the GH-N gene but not the GH-V gene .
4,5 G#cell_type|7,9 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

Furthermore , we demonstrated by western blot analysis that neutrophils express an alternatively spliced variant of the pituitary transcription factor Pit-1 , designated Pit-1b .
9,10 G#cell_type|17,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

The ability of BHRF1 to inhibit apoptosis is dependent on stimulus and cell type .
3,4 G#protein

The development of resistance to host defense mechanisms such as tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) - and Fas- mediated apoptosis of transformed or virus-infected cells may be a critical component in the development of disease .
22,23 G#cell_type|24,26 G#cell_type

To find genes that protect cells from apoptosis , we used an expression cloning strategy and identified BHRF1 , an Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) early-lytic-cycle protein with distant homology to Bcl-2 , as an anti- apoptosis protein .
17,18 G#protein|20,27 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|35,38 G#protein

Expression of BHRF1 in MCF-Fas cells conferred nearly complete resistance against both anti-Fas antibody and TNF-mediated apoptosis .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_line|12,14 G#protein

In addition , BHRF1 protected these cells from monocyte-mediated killing but failed to protect them from killing mediated by lymphokine-activated killer cells .
3,4 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type

The ability of BHRF1 to protect MCF-Fas cells from apoptosis induced by various stimuli was identical to that of Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Moreover , the mechanism of action of BHRF1 resembled that of Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL as it inhibited TNF- and anti-Fas- induced activation of two enzymes participating in the apoptosis pathway , cytosolic phospholipase A2 and caspase-3/CPP32 , but did not interfere with the activation of NF-kappaB -like transcription factors .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|45,49 G#protein

A putative function of BHRF1 in EBV -infected epithelial cells may be to protect virus-infected cells from TNF- and/or anti-Fas- induced cell death in order to maximize virus production .
4,5 G#protein|6,10 G#cell_type

Surprisingly , expression of neither BHRF1 nor Bcl-2 in a B-cell line , BJAB , protected the cells from anti-Fas-mediated apoptosis even though they increased the survival of serum-starved cells .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line|13,14 G#cell_line|28,30 G#cell_type

Thus , the protective role of BHRF1 against apoptosis resembles that of Bcl-2 in being cell type specific and dependent on the apoptotic stimulus .
6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Genomic organization , sequence , and transcriptional regulation of the human eotaxin gene .
10,13 G#DNA

Eotaxin is an eosinophil specific beta-chemokine assumed to be involved in eosinophilic inflammatory diseases such as atopic dermatitis , allergic rhinitis , asthma and parasitic infections .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein

Its expression is stimulus- and cell-specific .


We here describe the genomic organisation ( 3 exons of 132 , 112 and 542 bp and 2 introns of 1211 and 378 bp ) and sequence including 3 kb of DNA from the immediate 5' upstream region of the human eotaxin gene .
8,9 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA|35,38 G#DNA|40,43 G#DNA

Among the regulatory promoter elements potentially regulating eotaxin gene expression and/or mediating the effects of anti-inflammatory drugs we identified consensus sequences known to interact with nuclear factors like NF-IL6 , AP-1 , a NF-kappa-B like consensus sequence and gamma-interferon- as well as glucocorticoid response elements .
2,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,37 G#DNA|38,45 G#DNA

Differential interaction of nuclear factors with the leukocyte-specific pp52 promoter in B and T cells .
3,5 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|11,15 G#cell_type

The leukocyte-specific , cytoskeleton-binding pp52 ( LSP-1 , WP-34 ) protein is widely expressed in multiple leukocyte lineages , including B and T lymphocytes , granulocytes , and macrophages .
20,24 G#cell_type|25,26 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_type

We previously detected a tissue-specific promoter preceding the exon encoding the N terminus of the pp52 leukocyte protein .
4,6 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

Here we describe the functional characterization of this promoter and identification of the factors in B and T cells that regulate its activity .
15,19 G#cell_type

The pp52 promoter contains an initiator specifying the unique 5' terminus of pp52 mRNA , tandem pairs of Ets and SP1 motifs , and a lone C/EBP motif .
1,3 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|12,14 G#RNA|18,22 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA

All these motifs are essential and collectively control transcriptional activity .


DNA binding studies and Ab supershift assays revealed that different combinations of factors interact with these motifs in B cells vs T cells .
18,20 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

The Ets motifs are preferentially bound by PU-1 in B cell extracts from all stages of development , whereas a different Ets family member reacts with these motifs in T cell extracts .
1,3 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

The C/EBP motif is bound by Ig/EBP-1 in pre-B cell and T cell extracts , but is replaced by nuclear factor-IL-6beta or a nuclear factor-IL-6beta -Ig/EBP-1 heterodimer in plasmacytoma cell extracts .
1,3 G#DNA|6,7 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|23,27 G#protein

Despite its reported role as a negative regulator of transcription , Ig/EBP-1 appears to exert a stimulatory effect on this promoter .
11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA

These findings reveal the features controlling the pp52 promoter in B and T cells and provide the foundation for determining the regulation of this promoter in other leukocyte lineages .
7,9 G#DNA|10,14 G#cell_type|24,25 G#DNA|27,29 G#cell_type

Regulation of B-cell commitment to plasma cells or to memory B cells .
5,7 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|9,12 G#cell_type

During humoral immune responses , B-lymphocyte activation is followed by differentiation along either the plasma cell pathway or the memory B-cell pathway .


Recent studies suggest that CD40-CD40 ligand , OX-OX40 ligand , a group of cytokines and intracellular transcriptional factors may all contribute to B-lymphocyte differentiation control .
4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Transcription factor binding sites downstream of the human immunodeficiency virus type 1 transcription start site are important for virus infectivity .
0,2 G#protein|7,15 G#DNA

When transcriptionally active , the human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) promoter contains a nucleosome-free region encompassing both the promoter /enhancer region and a large region ( 255 nucleotides [ nt ] ) downstream of the transcription start site .
11,12 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA|36,39 G#DNA

We have previously identified new binding sites for transcription factors downstream of the transcription start site ( nt 465 to 720 ) : three AP-1 sites ( I , II , and III ) , an AP3-like motif ( AP3-L ) , a downstream binding factor ( DBF ) site , and juxtaposed Sp1 sites .
8,10 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|17,21 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA|36,38 G#DNA|39,40 G#DNA|43,50 G#DNA|52,55 G#DNA

Here , we show that the DBF site is an interferon-responsive factor ( IRF ) binding site and that the AP3-L motif binds the T-cell-specific factor NF-AT .
6,8 G#DNA|10,17 G#DNA|20,21 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Mutations that abolish the binding of each factor to its cognate site are introduced in an infectious HIV-1 molecular clone to study their effect on HIV-1 transcription and replication .


Individual mutation of the DBF or AP3-L site as well as the double mutation AP-1(III)/ AP3-L did not affect HIV-1 replication compared to that of the wild-type virus .
6,7 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

In contrast , proviruses carrying mutations in the Sp1 sites were totally defective in terms of replication .
8,10 G#DNA

Virus production occurred with slightly delayed kinetics for viruses containing combined mutations in the AP-1(III) , AP3-L , and DBF sites and in the AP3-L and DBF-sites , whereas viruses mutated in the AP-1(I,II,III) and AP3-L sites and in the AP-1(I,II,III) , AP3-L , and DBF sites exhibited a severely defective replicative phenotype .
14,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|33,34 G#DNA|35,37 G#DNA|42,43 G#DNA|45,47 G#DNA

No RNA-packaging defect could be measured for any of the mutant viruses as determined by quantification of their HIV genomic RNA .
18,21 G#RNA

Measurement of the transcriptional activity of the HIV-1 promoter after transient transfection of the HIV-1 provirus DNA or of long terminal repeat-luciferase constructs showed a positive correlation between the transcriptional and the replication defects for most mutants .
7,9 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|19,23 G#DNA

Glucocorticoid receptor regulates expression of L-selectin and CD11/CD18 on human neutrophils [ see comments ]
0,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Recent studies have raised the hypothesis that glucocorticoids could diminish the ability of endothelial cells to direct leukocyte traffic into inflamed tissues by inhibiting expression of the adhesion molecules endothelial-leukocyte adhesion molecule-1 and intercellular adhesion molecule-1 .
15,17 G#cell_type|29,31 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|35,38 G#protein

The aim of the present study was to investigate whether glucocorticoids also regulate the expression of L-selectin and CD11/CD18 integrins on human neutrophil granulocytes .
16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type

METHODS AND RESULTS : Incubation of human whole blood with platelet-activating factor ( PAF , 1 mumol/L ) evoked downregulation of L-selectin and upregulation of CD11/CD18 adhesion receptors on neutrophils as measured by flow cytometry .
10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

While dexamethasone ( 0.1 nmol/L to 100 mumol/L ) did not affect expression of adhesion molecules on resting neutrophils , it attenuated the PAF -induced changes in L-selectin and CD18 expression in a time- and concentration-dependent fashion with IC50 values of 31 and 13 nmol/L , respectively .
14,16 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

These effects of dexamethasone were completely aborted by RU-486 ( 10 mumol/L ) , which blocks transcriptional activation of the glucocorticoid receptor , and by the protein synthesis inhibitor cycloheximide ( 35.5 mumol/L ) .
20,22 G#protein

Dexamethasone , up to a concentration of 1 mumol/L , neither affected significantly the release of granule enzymes nor interfered with PAF binding to its membrane receptors .
16,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : Our results show that glucocorticoids at clinically relevant concentrations exert specific actions on expression of adhesion molecules on activated neutrophils , which are mediated through ligation of glucocorticoid receptors and induction of protein synthesis , and suggest a novel mechanism by which anti-inflammatory corticosteroids may inhibit leukocyte accumulation .
17,19 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type|29,31 G#protein

The immediate-early gene product Egr-1 regulates the human interleukin-2 receptor beta-chain promoter through noncanonical Egr and Sp1 binding sites .
4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|7,12 G#DNA|13,19 G#DNA

The interleukin-2 IL-2 receptor beta-chain ( IL-2Rbeta ) is an essential component of the receptors for IL-2 and IL-15 .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Although IL-2Rbeta is constitutively expressed by lymphocytes , its expression can be further induced by a number of stimuli , including phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) .
1,2 G#protein

We have now characterized factors that bind to an enhancer region located between nucleotides -170 and -139 of the human IL-2Rbeta promoter .
13,17 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

Both Sp1 and Sp3 bound to the 5' portion of this region , whereas a PMA -inducible factor ( PIF ) mainly bound to its 3' portion and bound to the Sp binding motifs as well .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA|31,34 G#DNA

In Jurkat T cells , induction of PIF DNA binding activity was rapidly induced , required de novo protein synthesis , and was sustained at a high level for at least 23 h .
2,4 G#cell_type|1,4 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein

Interestingly , PIF was constitutively activated in human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 -transformed MT-2 cells .
2,3 G#protein|7,16 G#cell_line

In this paper , we demonstrate that PIF is Egr-1 based on its recognition by anti- Egr-1 antisera in gel mobility shift assays , even though the IL-2Rbeta DNA binding motif differed substantially from the canonical Egr-1 binding site .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,31 G#DNA|36,37 G#protein|36,39 G#DNA

In addition , Egr-1 bound to the Sp binding site .
3,4 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA

In Jurkat cells , both sites were required for maximal IL-2Rbeta promoter activity , and in HeLaS3 cells , transfection of Egr-1 could drive activity of a reporter construct containing both sites .
1,3 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Moreover , Sp1 and Egr-1 could form a complex with kinetics that correlated with the production of Egr-1 in Jurkat cells upon PMA stimulation .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_line

Thus , Sp1 and Egr-1 physically and functionally cooperate to mediate maximal IL-2Rbeta promoter activity .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

Overexpression of HSF2-beta inhibits hemin -induced heat shock gene expression and erythroid differentiation in K562 cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line

Acquisition of heat shock factor 2 ( HSF2 ) DNA binding activity is accompanied by induced transcription of heat shock genes in hemin-treated K562 cells undergoing erythroid differentiation .
18,21 G#DNA|23,25 G#cell_line

Previous studies revealed that HSF2 consists of two alternatively spliced isoforms , HSF2-alpha and HSF2-beta , whose relative abundance is developmentally regulated and varies between different tissues .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

To investigate whether the molar ratio of HSF2-alpha and HSF2-beta isoforms is crucial for the activation of HSF2 and whether the HSF2 isoforms play functionally distinct roles during the hemin-mediated erythroid differentiation , we generated cell clones expressing different levels of HSF2-alpha and HSF2-beta .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein

We show that in parental K562 cells , the HSF2-alpha isoform is predominantly expressed and HSF2 can be activated upon hemin treatment .
5,7 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

In contrast , when HSF2-beta is expressed at levels exceeding those of endogenous HSF2-alpha , the hemin-induced DNA binding activity and transcription of heat shock genes are repressed , whereas overexpression of HSF2-alpha results in an enhanced hemin response .
4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

Furthermore , the hemin -induced accumulation of globin , known as a marker of erythroid differentiation , is decreased in cells overexpressing HSF2-beta .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We suggest that HSF2-beta acts as a negative regulator of HSF2 activity during hemin-mediated erythroid differentiation of K562 cells .
3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_line

Sequential development of structural and functional alterations in T cells from tumor-bearing mice .
8,10 G#cell_type

The TCR alpha beta or -gamma delta chains bind the peptide ligand , whereas the associated CD3 delta epsilon gamma and TCR zeta subunits couple the TCR to intracellular signal transduction components .
1,8 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Recently , several groups have described marked alterations in signal transduction elements in T cells from cancer patients or in mice bearing tumor for a few weeks ( &gt; 26 days ) .
13,15 G#cell_type

The sequence in which these alterations develop is unknown .


The aim of this study was to explore the kinetics of the development of alterations in signal transduction molecules ( TCR zeta chain , NF kappaB family proteins , and tyrosine kinase p56 ( lck ) ) in mice bearing MC38 colon adenocarcinoma .
20,23 G#protein|24,28 G#protein|30,36 G#protein

The results demonstrate that alterations in NF kappaB family proteins , specifically the failure of p65 translocation to the nucleus , occur earlier and more frequently than the decrease in zeta-chain .
6,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

These defects are paralleled by an impaired ability to produce Th1 cytokines ( IL-2 and IFN-gamma ) .
11,12 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

These initial changes are followed by the eventual loss of TCR zeta chain and p56 ( lck ) and a marked decrease in cytotoxic function .
10,13 G#protein|14,18 G#protein

An increased rate of lysosomal degradation is one of the mechanisms responsible for the loss of zeta-chain .
16,17 G#protein

HLA-DMA and HLA-DMB gene expression functions through the conserved S-X-Y region .
9,11 G#DNA

The MHC class II homologous proteins HLA-DMA and HLA-DMB function in the loading of peptides onto class II molecules .
1,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

Like the class II genes , the HLA-DM genes contain upstream regulatory sequences similar to the S-X-Y regulatory region as well as additional putative regulatory sites .
2,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA

To determine whether the DM genes are regulated in a similar manner as class II genes , a series of in vivo and in vitro analyses was performed .
4,6 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

Deletion analysis showed that expression from the DM promoters is dependent on the conserved S-X-Y region .
7,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA

The class II-specific transcription factors RFX and CIITA are also required for expression , as cell lines deficient in these factors failed to allow transcription from the DM promoters .
3,5 G#protein|1,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA

In addition , in vivo footprint analysis showed the putative X and Y boxes to be occupied by transcription factors in wild-type B cells , but not in RFX -deficient B cells .
10,14 G#DNA|18,20 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|28,32 G#cell_line

In astrocytes , IFN-gamma treatment induced increased occupancy of these sites .
1,2 G#cell_type|3,4 G#protein

None of the other putative regulatory sites was occupied in vivo , indicating that they may not be functional .


Finally , gel shift analysis showed synergistic complex formation between proteins that bind to the putative X boxes of the DM genes , as is found for the DRA gene .
16,18 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA

Therefore , the DM genes share a common mechanism of regulation with the class II genes .
3,5 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

Effect of adenovirus 2 on cellular gene activation in blood-derived monocytes and macrophages .
9,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type

We have investigated the effect of adenovirus 2 ( Ad2 ) infection on human monocytes and monocyte-derived macrophages with regard to expression of TNF-alpha and IL-1 beta .
13,15 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

In monocytes , the virus was bound to the surface without being internalized .


On the other hand , Ad2 was internalized by macrophages .
9,10 G#cell_type

No virus replication and no transcription of the Ad2 early genes was observed in either of the cells .
8,11 G#DNA

Ad2 infection induced transient increase in the mRNA levels for TNF-alpha and IL-1 beta in both monocytes and in macrophages , although the kinetics of the transcription was slightly different .
7,8 G#RNA|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

The production of both cytokines , measured by ELISA tests , was enhanced in monocytes .
4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type

In macrophages , a slight enhancement of TNF-alpha production was seen , whereas IL-1 beta was not detected .
1,2 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

The data indicate that cellular genes might be activated by Ad2 virus infection in nonpermissive cells where no viral gene products could be detected .
4,6 G#DNA|18,21 G#protein

Structure and function analysis of the human myeloid cell nuclear differentiation antigen promoter : evidence for the role of Sp1 and not of c-Myb or PU.1 in myelomonocytic lineage-specific expression .
6,13 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

The human myeloid nuclear differentiation antigen ( MNDA ) is expressed specifically in maturing cells of the myelomonocytic lineage and in monocytes and granulocytes .
1,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type

Epitope enhancement was used to confirm the strict lineage- and stage-specific expression of MNDA in bone marrow as well as in other paraffin-embedded fixed tissues .
13,14 G#protein

A 1-kb region of the gene that includes 5' flanking sequence was reported earlier to contain functional promoter activity and was specifically demethylated in expressing cells in contrast to null cells .
1,3 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type

Further analysis has revealed that this 1-kb fragment promotes higher reporter gene activity in MNDA -expressing cells than non-expressing cells , indicating cell-specific differences in transactivation .
6,8 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type

This sequence contains consensus elements consistent with myeloid-specific gene expression , including a PU.1 consensus site near the major transcription start site and a cluster of c-Myb sites located several hundred bases upstream of this region .
3,5 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA

However , analysis of deletion mutants localized nearly all of the promoter activity to a short region ( -73 to -16 ) that did not include the cluster of c-Myb sites .
4,6 G#DNA|18,21 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

A 4-bp mutation of the core Sp1 consensus element ( GC box ) ( -20 ) reduced overall promoter activity of the 1-kb fragment .
5,9 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA

Mutation of the PU.1 site did not significantly affect promoter activity .
3,5 G#DNA

Only a small region ( -35 to +22 ) including the Sp1 element and transcription start site , but not the PU.1 site was footprinted .
11,13 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|21,23 G#DNA

The 4-bp mutation of the core Sp1 consensus element abolished footprinting at the site and an antibody super-shift reaction showed that Sp1 is one of the factors binding the consensus site .
6,9 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA

The Sp1 site also co-localizes with a DNase I hypersensitive site .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|7,11 G#DNA

The results indicate that DNA methylation , chromatin structure , and transactivation at an Sp1 site contribute to the highly restricted expression of this myelomonocytic lineage specific gene .
7,8 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|24,28 G#DNA

Critical cytoplasmic domains of human interleukin-9 receptor alpha chain in interleukin -9-mediated cell proliferation and signal transduction .
1,3 G#protein|4,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Interleukin-9 receptor ( IL-9R ) complex consists of a ligand-specific alpha chain and IL-2R gamma chain .
0,6 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

In this study , two regions in the cytoplasmic domain of human IL-9Ralpha were found to be important for IL-9 -mediated cell growth .
8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

A membrane-proximal region that contains the BOX1 consensus sequence is required for IL-9 -induced cell proliferation and tyrosine phosphorylation of Janus kinases ( JAKs ) .
1,3 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Deletion of this region or internal deletion of the BOX1 motif abrogated IL-9 -induced cell proliferation and signal transduction .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

However , substitution of the Pro-X-Pro in the BOX1 motif with Ala-X-Ala failed to abolish IL-9 -induced cell proliferation but decreased IL-9 -mediated tyrosine phosphorylation of JAK kinases , insulin receptor substrate-2 , and signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 ( STAT3 ) and expression of c-myc and junB .
5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|26,28 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|34,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|47,48 G#DNA|49,50 G#DNA

Another important region is downstream of the BOX1 motif and contains a STAT3 binding motif YLPQ .
7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA

Deletion of this region significantly impaired IL-9 -induced cell growth , activation of JAK kinases , insulin receptor substrate-2 , and STAT3 and expression of early response genes .
6,7 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA

A point mutation changing YLPQ into YLPA greatly reduced IL-9 -induced activation of STAT3 and expression of c-myc but did not affect cell proliferation .
4,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA

These results suggest that cooperation or cross-talk of signaling molecules associated with different domains of IL-9Ralpha other than STAT3 is essential for IL-9 -mediated cell growth .
15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Bcl-2 protein inhibits bufalin -induced apoptosis through inhibition of mitogen-activated protein kinase activation in human leukemia U937 cells .
0,2 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line

In a previous study , we demonstrated that bufalin , which is an active principle of Chinese medicine , chan'su , caused apoptosis in human leukemia U937 cells by anomalous activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) via the signaling pathway of Ras , Raf-1 , and MAPK kinase-1 .
24,28 G#cell_line|32,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|48,50 G#protein

Here , we report the effect of overexpression of bcl-2 in U937 cells on the signaling pathway of apoptosis that is induced by bufalin .
9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line

The results indicated that the apoptosis induced by bufalin in U937 cells was significantly inhibited by overexpression of the Bcl-2 protein .
10,12 G#cell_line|19,21 G#protein

No significant difference was detected in the activation of MAPK kinase-1 that is induced by bufalin in wild-type or Bcl-2-overexpressed U937 cells ; however , the activation of MAPK by bufalin was significantly attenuated in the cells overexpressing Bcl-2 .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_line|19,22 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Bufalin treatment activated activator protein-1 transcriptional activity ; however , this activation was decreased to 40 % in bcl-2 -overexpressed U937 cells .
2,5 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_line

These results indicate that Bcl-2 acts downstream of MAPK kinase-1 but upstream of MAPK and suggest that , in the signaling pathway of the apoptotic process induced by bufalin , the transcriptional activity of activator protein-1 may be down-regulated through the inhibition of MAPK activity by Bcl-2 .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

Pancreatic islet expression studies and polymorphic DNA markers in the genes encoding hepatocyte nuclear factor -3alpha , -3beta , -3gamma , -4gamma , and -6 .
12,25 G#protein

The genes encoding the functionally related hepatocyte nuclear factors HNF-1alpha and HNF-4alpha play a critical role in normal pancreatic beta-cell function .
6,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Mutations in these liver -enriched transcription factors result in two forms of early-onset type 2 diabetes ( maturity-onset diabetes of the young [ MODY ] ) , MODY3 and MODY1 , which are characterized by impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion , early disease onset , and autosomal dominant inheritance .
3,7 G#protein

The transcriptional hierarchy of HNFs suggests that other proteins of the regulatory cascade might be responsible for other forms of MODY and/or late-onset type 2 diabetes .


In this study , we show that HNF -3alpha , -3beta , -3gamma , -4gamma , and -6 are expressed in pancreatic beta-cells .
7,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

We report the identification and characterization of simple tandem repeat DNA polymorphisms in the genes encoding HNF-3alpha , -3beta , -3gamma , -4gamma , and -6 and the mapping of HNF-6 to chromosome bands 15q21.1-21.2 by fluorescence in situ hybridization .
7,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,34 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA

These markers will be useful to study the role of genetic variation in these genes in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes .


Induction of nuclear factor kappa B/Rel nuclear activity in human peripheral blood T lymphocytes by anti-HLA class I monoclonal antibodies .
2,6 G#protein|9,14 G#cell_type|15,20 G#protein

Monoclonal antibodies against either monomorphic or polymorphic determinants of class I antigen induced in PBMC and highly purified T lymphocytes the nuclear activity of NF-kappa B/Rel complexes .
9,12 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type|24,27 G#protein

These included both p50/p50 and p50/p65 dimers , recognized by specific antibodies in EMSA .
3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

The induced complexes were detectable in extracts of cells incubated with anti-class I monoclonal antibody ( mAb ) for 1.5 h ; the induction was maximal at 5 h , persistent at 16 h and no longer observed at 40 h .
2,3 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

The mAb failed to induce NF-kappa B/Rel nuclear activity in cells incubated in the presence of 3,4-dichloroisocoumarin , an inhibitor of I kappa B-alpha degradation .
1,2 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Together , these results suggest that class I triggering can induce the activity of NF-kappa B/Rel nuclear activity in peripheral blood T lymphocytes , thereby modulating the expression of genes regulated by these transcription factors .

Anti-Ehrlichia chaffeensis antibody complexed with E. chaffeensis induces potent proinflammatory cytokine mRNA expression in human monocytes through sustained reduction of IkappaB-alpha and activation of NF-kappaB .
0,3 G#protein|9,12 G#RNA|14,16 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Ehrlichia chaffeensis is an obligatory intracellular bacterium that infects monocytes and macrophages and is the etiologic agent of human ehrlichiosis in the United States .
9,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#cell_type

Our previous studies showed that the exposure of human monocytes to E. chaffeensis induces the expression of interleukin-1beta ( IL-1beta ) , IL-8 , and IL-10 genes in vitro but not the expression of tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) and IL-6 mRNAs .
9,10 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA|34,44 G#RNA

In this study , the effect of anti- E. chaffeensis antibody complexed with E. chaffeensis on the expression of major proinflammatory cytokines in human monocytes was examined .
7,11 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

Human monocytic cell line THP-1 was treated with E. chaffeensis which had been preincubated with human anti- E. chaffeensis serum for 2 h , and the levels of cytokine mRNAs were evaluated by competitive reverse transcription-PCR .
0,5 G#cell_line|28,30 G#RNA

Anti- E. chaffeensis antibody complexed with E. chaffeensis significantly enhanced mRNA expression of IL-1beta in THP-1 cells .
0,4 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_line

The expression of TNF-alpha and IL-6 mRNAs was also induced .
3,7 G#RNA

The levels of secreted IL-1beta , TNF-alpha , and IL-6 during 24 h of stimulation were comparable to those induced by Escherichia coli lipopolysaccharide at 1 microg/ml .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Fab fragment of anti- E. chaffeensis immunoglobulin G complexed with E. chaffeensis did not induce any of these three cytokines , indicating that ehrlichial binding is required for IL-1beta mRNA expression and that binding of the immune complex to the Fc gamma receptor is required for TNF-alpha and IL-6 mRNA expression and enhanced IL-1beta mRNA expression .
3,8 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#RNA|36,38 G#protein|40,43 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|48,50 G#RNA|53,54 G#protein|53,55 G#RNA

Furthermore , prolonged degradation of IkappaB-alpha and activation of NF-kappaB were demonstrated in THP-1 cells exposed to anti- E. chaffeensis serum and E. chaffeensis .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_line

This result implies that development of anti- E. chaffeensis antibody in patients can result in the production of major proinflammatory cytokines , which may play an important role in the pathophysiology of ehrlichiosis and immune responses to it .
6,10 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

The class II trans-activator CIITA interacts with the TBP-associated factor TAFII32 .
4,5 G#protein|1,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein

The class II trans-Â activator ( CIITA ) is the main transcriptional co-activator for the expression of MHC class II proteins .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|16,20 G#protein

Its N-terminal 125 amino acids function as an independent transcriptional activation domain .
1,5 G#protein|8,12 G#protein

Analyses of the primary amino acid sequence of the activation domain predict the presence of three alpha-helices , each with a high proportion of acidic residues .
3,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Using site-directed mutagenesis , we found that two of these predicted alpha-helices are required for full transcriptional activation by CIITA .
11,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Moreover , a CIITA protein in which both functional alpha-helices have been deleted displays a dominant negative phenotype .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

This activation domain of CIITA interacts with the 32 kDa subunit of the general transcription complex TFIID , TAFII32 .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Decreased transcriptional activation by N-terminal deletions of CIITA is correlated directly with their reduced binding to TAFII32 .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein
