Glucocorticoid therapy resolves clinical symptoms within hours to days , but therapy has to be continued over several years to prevent disease relapses .


It is not known whether and how glucocorticoids affect the function of the inflammatory infiltrate or why the disease persists subclinically despite chronic treatment .


GCA is self-sustained in temporal arteries engrafted into SCID mice , providing a model in which the mechanisms of action and limitations of glucocorticoid therapy can be examined in vivo .


Administration of dexamethasone to temporal artery-SCID chimeras for 1 wk induced a partial suppression of T cell and macrophage function as indicated by the reduced tissue concentrations of IL-2 , IL-1beta , and IL-6 mRNA , and by the diminished expression of inducible NO synthase .
4,7 G#cell_line|28,35 G#RNA|43,45 G#protein

In contrast , synthesis of IFN-gamma mRNA was only slightly decreased , and expression of TGF-beta1 was unaffected .
5,7 G#RNA|15,16 G#protein

These findings correlated with activation of the IkappaBalpha gene and blockade of the nuclear translocation of NFkappaB in the xenotransplanted tissue .
7,9 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

Dose-response experiments suggested that steroid doses currently used in clinical medicine are suboptimal in repressing NFkappaB -mediated cytokine production in the inflammatory lesions .
15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Chronic steroid therapy was able to deplete the T cell products IL-2 and IFN-gamma , whereas the activation of tissue-infiltrating macrophages was only partially affected .
8,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

IL-1beta transcription was abrogated ; in contrast , TGF-beta1 mRNA synthesis was steroid resistant .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA

The persistence of TGF-beta1-transcribing macrophages , despite paralysis of T cell function , may provide an explanation for the chronicity of the disease , and may identify a novel therapeutic target in this inflammatory vasculopathy .
3,5 G#cell_type

Defective survival and activation of thymocytes in transgenic mice expressing a catalytically inactive form of Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IV .
5,6 G#cell_type|11,14 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

We have generated transgenic mice that express a catalytically inactive form of Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IV ( CaMKIV ) specifically in thymic T cells .
8,11 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type

The presence of this protein results in a markedly reduced thymic cellularity , although the distribution of the remaining cells is normal based on evaluation of the CD4 and CD8 cell surface antigens that are used to gauge T cell development .
27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|30,33 G#protein

Isolated thymic T cells from the transgenic mice also show a dramatically decreased survival rate when evaluated in culture under conditions that do not favor activation .
1,4 G#cell_type

When challenged with an activating stimulus such as alpha- CD3 or a combination of phorbol ester plus ionophore , the cells are severely compromised in their ability to produce the cytokine interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) .
9,10 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Reduction of IL-2 production is secondary to the inability to phosphorylate the cAMP response element binding protein , CREB , and induce expression of the immediate early genes such as Fos B that are required to transactivate the IL-2 promoter .
2,3 G#protein|12,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA|30,32 G#DNA|38,39 G#protein|38,40 G#DNA

Because transgene expression was regulated by the proximal promoter of the murine lck gene and this promoter is inactivated in T cells that exit the thymus , the mutant hCaMKIV is not present in peripheral T cells .
7,9 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type|28,30 G#protein|34,37 G#cell_type

Consequently , T lymphocytes present in the spleen can be activated normally in response to either stimulus mentioned above , demonstrating that the effects of the inactive CaMKIV on activation are reversible .
2,4 G#cell_type|26,28 G#protein

Our results suggest that CaMKIV may represent a physiologically relevant CREB kinase in T cells and that the enzyme is also required to ensure normal expansion of T cells in the thymus .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|27,29 G#cell_type

Whereas the pathway responsible for this latter role is yet to be elucidated , it is unlikely to include CREB phosphorylation .
19,20 G#protein

A new mouse gene , SRG3 , related to the SWI3 of Saccharomyces cerevisiae , is required for apoptosis induced by glucocorticoids in a thymoma cell line .
2,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|24,27 G#cell_line

We isolated a new mouse gene that is highly expressed in thymocytes , testis , and brain .
4,6 G#DNA|11,12 G#cell_type

This gene , SRG3 , showed a significant sequence homology to SWI3 , a yeast transcriptional activator , and its human homolog BAF155 .
3,4 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA

SRG3 encodes 1,100 amino acids and has 33-47 % identity with SWI3 protein over three regions .
0,1 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein

The SRG3 protein contains an acidic NH2 terminus , a myb-like DNA binding domain , a leucine-zipper motif , and a proline- and glutamine-rich region at its COOH terminus .
1,2 G#DNA|1,3 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|21,25 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Rabbit antiserum raised against a COOH-terminal polypeptide of the SRG3 recognized a protein with an apparent molecular mass of 155 kD .
9,10 G#DNA

The serum also detected a 170-kD protein that seems to be a mouse homologue of human BAF170 .
5,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Immunoprecipitation of cell extract with the antiserum against the mouse SRG3 also brought down a 195-kD protein that could be recognized by an antiserum raised against human SWI2 protein .
10,11 G#DNA|9,11 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|26,29 G#protein

The results suggest that the SRG3 protein associates with a mouse SWI2 .
5,6 G#DNA|5,7 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

The SRG3 protein is expressed about three times higher in thymocytes than in peripheral lymphocytes .
1,2 G#DNA|1,3 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type

The expression of anti-sense RNA to SRG3 mRNA in a thymoma cell line , S49.1 , reduced the expression level of the SRG3 protein , and decreased the apoptotic cell death induced by glucocorticoids .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#DNA|6,8 G#RNA|10,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line|22,23 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein

These results suggest that the SRG3 protein is involved in the glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis in the thymoma cell line .
5,6 G#DNA|5,7 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_line

This implicates that the SRG3 may play an important regulatory role during T cell development in thymus .
4,5 G#DNA

Transcriptional induction of collagenase-1 in differentiated monocyte-like ( U937 ) cells is regulated by AP-1 and an upstream C/EBP-beta site .
3,4 G#protein|5,11 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA

In this report , we demonstrate that the AP-1 site and a distal promoter element regulate transcriptional induction of collagenase-1 during monocytic differentiation .
8,9 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein

Chloramphenicol acetyltransferase expression constructs containing regions of the human collagenase-1 promoter were stably or transiently transfected into U937 cells , and reporter activity was assessed at various times after the onset of phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) -mediated differentiation .
0,2 G#protein|0,4 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_line

Rapid and strong induction of promoter activity was lost in constructs with a mutant AP-1 element ; however , at 16-96 h post-PMA , the mutant collagenase-1 promoter displayed AP-1 independent PMA-mediated transactivation .
13,16 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein

The AP-1 mutant constructs also showed delayed transcriptional activation in PMA-treated fibroblasts .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#DNA|10,12 G#cell_line

Western and supershift analyses indicated that functional Jun and Fos proteins were present in nuclear extracts of PMA-differentiated U937 cells .
6,11 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line|17,20 G#cell_line

Promoter deletion constructs demonstrated the potential role of distal promoter sequences in regulating collagenase-1 transcription .
8,11 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein

In particular , Western , supershift , and promoter deletion analyses suggested a role for CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein-beta ( C/EBP-beta ) binding site between -2010 and -1954 in regulating transcription of collagenase-1 in monocytic cells .
15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|15,22 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA|30,31 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

Our findings suggest that distinct regulatory elements , acting somewhat independently of each other , control expression of collagenase-1 .
5,7 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein

In addition , our data suggests that the rapid PMA-mediated induction of collagenase-1 transcription is controlled by a mechanism distinct from that regulating the sustained expression of this proteinase in activated macrophages .
12,13 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type

Quantification of vitamin D receptor mRNA by competitive polymerase chain reaction in PBMC : lack of correspondence with common allelic variants .
2,5 G#protein|2,6 G#RNA|12,13 G#cell_type|18,21 G#DNA

It has been recently claimed that polymorphism for the vitamin D receptor ( VDR ) influences several aspects of calcium and bone metabolism .
9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

To evaluate the physiologic plausibility of these claims , we compared the abundance of the VDR mRNA in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMCs ) between different VDR genotypes using a quantitative reverse transcribed polymerase chain reaction-based method .
15,17 G#RNA|18,22 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

The method is based on the coamplification of VDR cDNA and an internal standard consisting of known concentrations of a human VDR CDNA mutated at a BglII restriction site ; the interassay coefficient of variation is 11 % .
8,10 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA

To validate the method , we made use of earlier receptor binding studies indicating that normal human monocytes and activated , but not resting , lymphocytes expressed the VDR .
15,18 G#cell_type|25,26 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

The concentration of the VDR mRNA was 10(-8) to 10(-7) g/g of total RNA in cell-sorted monocytes and in in vitro activated lymphocytes , but only 10(-12) g/g of total mRNA in resting lymphocytes , establishing that the VDR mRNA determined by our method in PBMCs is due to constitutive expression in monocytes .
4,6 G#RNA|13,14 G#RNA|15,17 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type|19,23 G#cell_type|29,31 G#RNA|33,34 G#cell_type|38,40 G#RNA|45,46 G#cell_type|52,53 G#cell_type

Following an initial genotype screening of 85 normal volunteers by polymerase chain reaction or restriction fragment length polymorphism analysis , 14 individuals with the Bb genotype , 12 with the bb genotype , and 12 with the BB genotype were selected .
14,18 G#DNA

The concentration of the VDR mRNA , corrected for the number of monocytes , was similar among the three genotype groups , as were the other variables examined : serum calcitriol , serum osteocalcin , and vertebral and hip bone density .
4,6 G#RNA|12,13 G#cell_type|29,31 G#protein|32,34 G#protein

We conclude that VDR polymorphism does not affect the abundance of the VDR mRNA .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,13 G#RNA|12,14 G#RNA

Oncogenic forms of NOTCH1 lacking either the primary binding site for RBP-Jkappa or nuclear localization sequences retain the ability to associate with RBP-Jkappa and activate transcription .
3,4 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Truncated forms of the NOTCH1 transmembrane receptor engineered to resemble mutant forms of NOTCH1 found in certain cases of human T cell leukemia/lymphoma ( T-ALL ) efficiently induce T-ALL when expressed in the bone marrow of mice .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Unlike full-sized NOTCH1 , two such truncated forms of the protein either lacking a major portion of the extracellular domain ( DeltaE ) or consisting only of the intracellular domain ( ICN ) were found to activate transcription in cultured cells , presumably through RBP-Jkappa response elements within DNA .
2,3 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

Both truncated forms also bound to the transcription factor RBP-Jkappa in extracts prepared from human and murine T-ALL cell lines .
9,10 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|14,20 G#cell_line

Transcriptional activation required the presence of a weak RBP-Jkappa -binding site within the NOTCH1 ankyrin repeat region of the intracellular domain .
8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Unexpectedly , a second , stronger RBP-Jkappa -binding site , which lies within the intracellular domain close to the transmembrane region and significantly augments association with RBP-Jkappa , was not needed for oncogenesis or for transcriptional activation .
6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

While ICN appeared primarily in the nucleus , DeltaE localized to cytoplasmic and nuclear membranes , suggesting that intranuclear localization is not essential for oncogenesis or transcriptional activation .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

In support of this interpretation , mutation of putative nuclear localization sequences decreased nuclear localization and increased transcriptional activation by membrane-bound DeltaE .
9,12 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Transcriptional activation by this mutant form of membrane-bound DeltaE was approximately equivalent to that produced by intranuclear ICN .
8,9 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

These data are most consistent with NOTCH1 oncogenesis and transcriptional activation being independent of association with RBP-Jkappa at promoter sites .
6,7 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

Sp family members preferentially interact with the promoter proximal repeat within the HTLV-I enhancer .
0,3 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA

Human T cell lymphotropic virus type I ( HTLV-I ) encodes the transactivator protein , Tax , which facilitates viral transcription from three 21 bp repeated elements within the U3 region of the long terminal repeat ( LTR ) .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|23,27 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA|33,36 G#DNA|37,38 G#DNA

Examination of the basal factors interacting with the 21 bp repeat elements through electrophoretic mobility shift ( EMS ) analyses has demonstrated the formation of DNA-protein complexes common to each of the 21 bp repeats ( C1-C3 ) as well as three DNA-protein complexes specific to the promoter proximal ( pp ) repeat ( U1 ( U1A/U1B ) and U2 ; 1-4 ) .
3,5 G#protein|8,12 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA|36,37 G#DNA|42,44 G#protein|47,53 G#DNA|54,55 G#DNA|56,57 G#DNA|59,60 G#DNA

These studies have indicated that the individual repeats are not identical with respect to the cellular factors with which they interact .
15,17 G#protein

EMS analyses utilizing a series of mutated pp repeat elements demonstrate that the nucleotide sequence requirements for U1 ( U1A/U1B ) and U2 formation are separable from those required for C1-C3 formation .
6,10 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA

Competition EMS analyses utilizing Sp1 and CREB binding site oligonucleotides demonstrate that Sp family members are critical components of U1 ( U1A/U1B ) and U2 and that ATF/CREB family members are critical components of C1-C3 .
12,15 G#protein|19,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA|27,30 G#protein|34,35 G#DNA

EMS supershift analyses have demonstrated that Sp1 is involved in U1A formation while Sp3 is involved in U1B and U2 formation .
6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

EMS analyses performed with nuclear extracts from Tax -expressing Jurkat cells and HTLV-I -transformed peripheral blood mononuclear cells demonstrate that Tax prevents the formation of U1 ( U1A/U1B ) and U2 DNA-protein complexes .
7,8 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_line|12,18 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA|31,33 G#protein

Therefore , Tax appears to inhibit the interaction of Sp family members with the pp repeat .
2,3 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA

Based on these observations , it is possible that the interaction of Sp and ATF/CREB family members with the pp repeat during basal and Tax -mediated transcription may play a critical role in viral gene expression during the initial stages of virus infection or during activation of a latent infection .
12,13 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein

Lineage- and stage- specific expression of runt box polypeptides in primitive and definitive hematopoiesis .
6,9 G#protein

Translocations involving the human CBFA2 locus have been associated with leukemia .
3,6 G#DNA

This gene , originally named AML1 , is a human homologue of the Drosophila gene runt that controls early events in fly embryogenesis .
5,6 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA

To clarify the role of mammalian runt products in normal and leukemic hematopoiesis , we have studied their pattern of expression in mouse hematopoietic tissues in the adult and during ontogeny using an anti-runt box antiserum .
5,8 G#protein

In the adult bone marrow , we found expression of runt polypeptides in differentiating myeloid cells and in B lymphocytes .
13,16 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type

Within the erythroid lineage , runt expression is biphasic , clearly present in the erythroblasts of early blood islands and of the fetal liver , but absent in the adult .
2,4 G#cell_type|14,15 G#cell_type

Biochemical analysis by Western blotting of fetal and adult hematopoietic populations shows several runt isoforms .
6,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#protein

At least one of them appears to be myeloid specific .


Signal transducer and activator of transcription-3 ( STAT3 ) is constitutively activated in normal , self-renewing B-1 cells but only inducibly expressed in conventional B lymphocytes [ see comments ]
0,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|24,26 G#cell_type

Cytokine and growth factor receptor engagement leads to the rapid phosphorylation and activation of latent , cytosolic signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STAT ) proteins , which then translocate to the nucleus where they regulate transcriptional events from specific promoter sequences .
0,1 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|16,27 G#protein|40,43 G#DNA

STAT3 expression in particular has been associated with Abl , Src , and HTLV-1 transformation of normal cells .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

B-1 lymphocytes are self-renewing , CD5+ B cells that display a propensity for malignant transformation and are the normal counterpart to human chronic lymphocytic leukemias .
0,2 G#cell_type|5,8 G#cell_type

Further , B-1 cells are characterized by aberrant intracellular signaling , including hyperresponsiveness to phorbol ester PKC agonists .
2,4 G#cell_type

Here we demonstrate that B-1 lymphocytes constitutively express nuclear activated STAT3 , which is not expressed by unmanipulated conventional ( B-2 ) lymphocytes .
4,6 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|17,23 G#cell_type

In contrast , STAT3 activation is induced in B-2 cells after antigen receptor engagement in a delayed fashion ( after 3 h ) .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

Induction of STAT3 is inhibited by both the serine/threonine protein kinase inhibitor H-7 and the immunosuppressive drug rapamycin and requires de novo protein synthesis , demonstrating novel coupling between sIg and STAT proteins that differs from the classical paradigm for STAT induction by cytokine receptors .
2,3 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|43,45 G#protein

The inability of prolonged stimulation of conventional B-2 cells with anti-Ig , a treatment sufficient to induce CD5 expression , to result in sustained STAT3 activation suggests that STAT3 is a specific nuclear marker for B-1 cells .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|35,37 G#cell_type

Thus , STAT3 may play a role in B cell antigen-specific signaling responses , and its constitutive activation is associated with a normal cell population exhibiting intrinsic proliferative behavior .
2,3 G#protein

Significance of quantitative analysis of AML1 /ETO transcripts in peripheral blood stem cells from t(8;21) acute myelogenous leukemia .
5,6 G#DNA|5,8 G#RNA|9,13 G#cell_type

Autologous peripheral blood stem cell transplantation ( PBSCT ) is replacing autologous bone marrow transplantation ( BMT ) in the treatment of leukemia .
1,5 G#cell_type

One of the potential advantages of autologous PBSCT is the possibility that peripheral blood stem cells ( PBSC ) are less likely to be contaminated by leukemic cells than bone marrow grafts .
12,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type|26,28 G#cell_type

However , the major problem still remains the high incidence of leukemic relapse following autologous PBSCT , which may be caused by the reinfusion of PBSC contaminated by leukemic cells .
25,26 G#cell_type|28,30 G#cell_type

Recently , we have developed a quantitative assay using competitive reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction that estimates the number of AML1 /ETO transcripts in t(8;21) acute myelogenous leukemia ( AML ) , in order to determine the degree of leukemic cell contamination in PBSC harvests , and to monitor minimal residual disease ( MRD ) quantitatively in patients with t(8;21) AML .
10,13 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA|20,23 G#RNA|43,44 G#cell_type

Our data indicate that although PBSC harvests collected after consolidation chemotherapy are contaminated by leukemic cells , the degree of leukemic cell contamination decreases with repeated cycles of chemotherapy .
5,6 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

Furthermore , the MRD in PBSC harvests is less than in the corresponding bone marrow obtained on the day of the PBSC collection .
5,6 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type

There appears to be no relationship between the number of AML1 /ETO transcripts found in the infused PBSC harvests and the incidence of leukemic relapse following autologous PBSCT in our study .
10,11 G#DNA|10,13 G#RNA|17,18 G#cell_type

However , a substantial decrease of AML1 /ETO transcripts was seen following autologous PBSCT .
6,7 G#DNA|6,9 G#RNA

Thus , the quantitative analysis of AML1 /ETO transcripts may be clinically useful in patients with t(8;21) AML .
6,7 G#DNA|6,9 G#RNA

Upregulation of c-Fos in activated T lymphoid and monocytic cells by human immunodeficiency virus-1 Tat protein .
2,3 G#protein|4,10 G#cell_type|11,16 G#protein

The regulatory Tat protein of the human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV-1 ) is essential for viral replication and also shows pleiotropic activities on various cell functions .
1,4 G#protein

To get further insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying the biological activity of Tat , we investigated the effect of endogenous and exogenous Tat protein on c-fos gene expression in T lymphoblastoid ( Jurkat ) and monocytic ( U937 ) cell lines , as well as in primary peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) .
13,14 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|30,42 G#cell_line|47,52 G#cell_type|53,54 G#cell_type

Transient cotransfection of tat cDNA in sense orientation ( tat/S ) , together with a plasmid containing the c-fos promoter ( FC3 , from - 711 to +42 ) in front of the bacterial chloramphenicol acetyltransferase ( CAT ) gene significantly enhanced CAT activity in Jurkat cells activated by the addition of 15 % fetal calf serum ( FCS ) or 5 micrograms/mL phytohemagglutinin plus 10(-7) mol/L phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) and U937 cells activated by 15 % FCS or 10(-7) mol/L PMA .
3,5 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|34,36 G#protein|33,40 G#DNA|42,43 G#protein|45,47 G#cell_line|63,64 G#protein|74,76 G#cell_line

This effect was specifically due to Tat , since Jurkat and U937 cells cotransfected either with tat cDNA in antisense orientation ( tat/AS ) , tat carrying a mutation in the aminoacid cys22-gly22 ( tat 22/S ) or with the backbone vector alone ( pRPneo-SL3 ) did not show any significant difference in c-fos promoter activity as compared to cells transfected with FC3 plasmid alone .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_line|16,18 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|31,33 G#protein|34,36 G#DNA|40,43 G#DNA|44,45 G#DNA|53,55 G#DNA|62,64 G#DNA

By using deletion mutants of the c-fos promoter , we found that the minimal DNA sequence required for Tat activity was located between nucleotides -404/-220 and that the serum responsive element ( SRE , -317/-288 ) , present within this region , was still responsive to Tat .
6,8 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|28,31 G#DNA|32,33 G#DNA|34,35 G#DNA|46,47 G#protein

A single point mutation in the SRE completely abrogated the responsiveness to tat/S .
1,4 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA

Exogenous recombinant Tat protein was also able to upregulate c-fos promoter activity in serum-activated Jurkat and U937 cells , as well as endogenous c-fos mRNA expression and c-Fos protein synthesis in both serum-activated cell lines and primary PBMC .
2,3 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|16,18 G#cell_line|23,25 G#RNA|27,28 G#protein|32,35 G#cell_line|37,38 G#cell_type|36,38 G#cell_type

c-Fos protein was shown essential for an optimal transactivation of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) by Tat : incubation of Jurkat cells with antisense , but not sense , c-fos oligonucleotides significantly reduced either the Tat -enhanced expression of an LTR-CAT reporter construct or the levels of gag p24 in the culture supernatants of Jurkat cells and PBMC acutely infected with HIV-1 .
0,1 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_line|38,39 G#protein|43,46 G#DNA|50,52 G#protein|57,59 G#cell_line|60,61 G#cell_type

Our data suggest that the c-fos upregulation mediated by Tat might play a significant role in the control of viral gene transactivation .
5,6 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein

Cytokine signal networks and a new era in biomedical research .
0,3 G#protein

Elucidation of the biochemical nature of the signal transduction pathway that regulate transcription and replication is the focus of attention in molecular biology .


This research may make feasible manipulation of growth and differentiation of mammalian cells , which in turn would have profound implication in biomedical research on cell and gene therapy , and development of pharmaceutical products .
11,13 G#cell_type

Cytokines control growth , differentiation , death , and function of cells of lymphocytic , hemopoietic systems , and together with nerve cells provide a pertinent model to study intercellular communications and intercellular signal networks .
0,1 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

This review outlines general features of signal transduction and several aspects of cytokine networks are discussed with emphasis on : transcriptional regulation of Th1 and Th2-specific cytokine genes in T cells , the roles of cytokines and their receptors in growth and differentiation of hemopoietic cells , and the manipulation of cytokine networks .
12,14 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|29,31 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein|44,46 G#cell_type|51,53 G#protein

Regulation of the tissue factor gene in human monocytic cells .
3,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_type|7,10 G#cell_type

Role of AP-1 , NF-kappa B/Rel , and Sp1 proteins in uninduced and lipopolysaccharide -induced expression .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Tissue factor ( TF ) expression by peripheral blood monocytes during sepsis initiates intravascular thrombosis .
0,2 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type

Bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) rapidly induces TF gene transcription in monocytes .
7,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#cell_type

The human TF promoter contains binding sites for the transcription factors AP-1 , c-Rel/p65 , Egr-1 , and Sp1 .
1,4 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

NF-kappa B/Rel proteins have been shown to physically interact with both AP-1 and Sp1 proteins .
0,2 G#protein|0,3 G#protein|11,15 G#protein

In this study , we investigated the role of these transcription factors in uninduced and LPS -induced TF gene expression in human monocytic THP-1 cells .
10,12 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|21,25 G#cell_type

Deletional analysis indicated that five Sp1 sites mediated basal expression in uninduced cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_type

The two AP-1 sites bound c-Fos /c-Jun heterodimers in both unstimulated and LPS-stimulated cells .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|10,14 G#cell_type

Maximal LPS induction of the TF promoter required the two AP-1 sites and the kappa B site within the LPS response element .
5,7 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA

Disruption of the conserved spacing between the proximal AP-1 site and the kappa B site abolished LPS induction .
8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA

Replacement of the two AP-1 sites with intrinsically bent DNA partially restored LPS induction , suggesting an additional structural role for the AP-1 sites .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#DNA

Synergistic transactivation of the LPS response element in Drosophila Schneider cells by coexpression of c-Fos , c-Jun , c-Rel , and p65 or c-Jun and p65 required the transactivation domains of c-Jun and p65 .
4,7 G#DNA|8,11 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

These data indicated that c-Fos /c-Jun , c-Rel /p65 , and Sp1 regulate TF gene expression in human monocytic cells .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type

Inhibitory effect of growth hormone on TNF-alpha secretion and nuclear factor-kappaB translocation in lipopolysaccharide -stimulated human monocytes .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type

Several studies have pointed to a link between immune and endocrine systems , including a regulatory function of GH on monocyte activation .


The present study demonstrates that human THP-1 promonocytic cells , engineered by gene transfer to constitutively produce human growth hormone ( hGH ) , secreted depressed amounts of TNF-alpha in response to challenge by LPS .
6,9 G#cell_line|28,29 G#protein

The effect of GH appears to occur in an autocrine fashion , since the inhibitory effect on TNF-alpha secretion by constitutive GH production could be abolished in the presence of anti-hGH mAb .
17,18 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

The GH -induced inhibitory effect was also observed using normal human monocytes and monocyte-derived macrophages .
9,12 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type

Inhibition of TNF-alpha production by THP-1-hGH-transfected cells cultured in the presence of LPS is dependent on a selective pathway , since no inhibition of TNF-alpha production was observed when cells were cultured in the presence of PMA .
2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein

Inhibition of TNF-alpha secretion by LPS -stimulated THP-1-hGH cells was associated with a decrease in nuclear translocation of nuclear factor-kappaB .
2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_line|18,20 G#protein

The capacity of GH to inhibit LPS -induced TNF-alpha production by monocytes without altering other pathways leading to TNF-alpha production may be of potential relevance in septic shock , since GH is available for clinical use .
8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Nuclear factor-kappaB activation in human monocytes stimulated with lipopolysaccharide is inhibited by fibroblast conditioned medium and exogenous PGE2 .
0,2 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type

The nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) is thought to be crucially involved in the gene activation of several cytokines , including tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF ) .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Previously , we showed that fibroblast conditioned medium ( FCM ) is able to inhibit both TNF mRNA accumulation and protein release in peripheral blood-derived human monocytes ( PBM ) stimulated with lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) .
16,18 G#RNA|25,27 G#cell_type|23,27 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_line

In this study we have investigated the effect of FCM on the LPS -induced DNA-binding activity of NF-kappaB , by means of electrophoretic shift assay ( EMSA ) .
17,18 G#protein

We provide evidence that FCM strongly inhibits the LPS -induced NF-kappaB activation in PBM .
10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_line

Furthermore , we show that exogenous PGE2 mimics the NF-kappaB inhibitory effect of FCM .
9,10 G#protein

On the other hand , FCM produced in the presence of indomethacin does not inhibit NF-kappaB activation by LPS .
15,16 G#protein

Our results lend further support to the hypothesis that inflammatory and immune responses of monocytes/macrophages may be modulated at the molecular level by signals originating from tissue structural cells such as fibroblasts .
14,15 G#cell_type|26,29 G#cell_type|31,32 G#cell_type

Human neutrophil elastase proteolytically activates the platelet integrin alphaIIbbeta3 through cleavage of the carboxyl terminus of the alphaIIb subunit heavy chain .
0,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

Involvement in the potentiation of platelet aggregation .


Neutrophil elastase ( NE ) and cathepsin G are two serine proteinases released concomitantly by stimulated polymorphonuclear neutrophils .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

We previously demonstrated that while NE by itself does not activate human platelets , it strongly enhances the weak aggregation induced by a threshold concentration of cathepsin G ( threshold of cathepsin G ) ( Renesto , P. , and Chignard , M. ( 1993 ) Blood 82 , 139-144 ) .
5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|26,28 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

The aim of this study was to delineate the molecular mechanisms involved in this potentiation process .


Two main pieces of data prompted us to focus on the activation of the platelet fibrinogen receptor , the alphaIIbbeta3 integrin .
14,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

First , previous studies have shown this integrin to be particularly prone to proteolytic regulation of its function .
7,8 G#protein

Second , we found that the potentiating activity of NE on the threshold of cathepsin G -induced platelet aggregation was strictly dependent on the presence of exogenous fibrinogen .
9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

Using flow cytometry analysis , NE was shown to trigger a time-dependent binding of PAC-1 and AP-5 , two monoclonal antibodies specific for the activated and ligand-occupied conformers of alphaIIbbeta3 .
5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Furthermore , the potentiated aggregation was shown to result from an increased capacity of platelets to bind fibrinogen .


Indeed , the combination of NE and threshold of cathepsin G increased the binding of PAC-1 approximately 5.5-fold over basal values measured on nontreated platelets , whereas this binding raised only by approximately 3-fold in threshold of cathepsin G -stimulated platelets ( p &lt; 0.05 ) .
5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|37,39 G#protein|37,41 G#cell_type

By contrast , phosphatidic acid accumulation , pleckstrin phosphorylation , and calcium mobilization produced by the combination of NE and threshold of cathepsin G were not significantly different from those measured with threshold of cathepsin G alone ( p &gt; 0.05 ) , indicating that the phospholipase C /protein kinase C pathway is not involved in the potentiation of aggregation .
18,19 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|46,48 G#protein|48,51 G#protein

The foregoing data , as well as the requirement of catalytically active NE to trigger alphaIIbbeta3 activation and potentiate threshold of cathepsin G -initiated platelet aggregation , led us to examine whether the structure of this integrin was affected by NE .
12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

Immunoblot and flow cytometry analysis revealed a limited proteolysis of the carboxyl terminus of the alphaIIb subunit heavy chain ( alphaIIbH ) , as judged by the disappearance of the epitope for the monoclonal antibody PMI-1 .
11,13 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|33,36 G#protein

Mass spectrometry studies performed on a synthetic peptide mapping over the cleavage domain of alphaIIbH predicted the site of proteolysis as located between Val837 and Asp838 .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Treatment by NE of ATP-depleted platelets or Chinese hamster ovary cells expressing human recombinant alphaIIbbeta3 clearly established that activation of the integrin was independent of signal transduction events and was concomitant with the proteolysis of alphaIIbH .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|7,11 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|35,36 G#protein

AP-1 derived from mature monocytes and astrocytes preferentially interacts with the HTLV-I promoter central 21 bp repeat .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#cell_type|11,13 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

Characterization of the cellular transcription factors interacting with the human T cell lymphotropic virus type I ( HTLV-I ) long terminal repeat ( LTR ) is essential to dissecting the mechanisms involved in viral transcription that may be pertinent to the oncogenic and neuropathogenic processes associated with HTLV-I infection in both the immune and nervous systems .
4,6 G#protein|9,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA

Electrophoretic mobility shift ( EMS ) analyses utilizing oligonucleotides homologous to each of the 21 bp repeat elements reacted with nuclear extracts derived from cell lines of lymphocytic , monocytic , neuronal , and glial cell origin have demonstrated differential binding of cellular factors to the three 21 bp repeats ( 1-4 ) .
14,17 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_line|27,37 G#cell_type|42,44 G#protein|47,50 G#DNA

ATF/CREB and Sp family members interacted with the 21 bp repeats to form DNA-protein complexes common to all cell types examined .
0,1 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|13,15 G#protein

However , a unique DNA-protein complex was detected when the promoter central 21 bp repeat was reacted with nuclear extracts derived from either the U-373 MG glioblastoma cell line or the THP-1 mature monocytic cell line .
4,6 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|24,29 G#cell_line|31,36 G#cell_line

Based on nucleotide sequence requirements and immunoreactivity , we demonstrate that this DNA-protein complex is comprised of the AP-1 components , Fos and Jun .
12,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

HIV does not replicate in naive CD4 T cells stimulated with CD3/CD28 .
5,9 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein

In this report , we demonstrate that the T cell tropic strain of HIV , LAI , does not replicate in naive CD4 T cells stimulated by cross-linking CD3 and CD28 .
21,25 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

In contrast , LAI replicates well in memory CD4 T cells stimulated in the same way .
7,11 G#cell_type

Unlike this physiologically relevant stimulation , PHA stimulates productive LAI replication in both naive and memory T cells .
6,7 G#protein|13,18 G#cell_type

These studies were conducted with highly purified ( FACS-isolated ) subsets of CD4 T cells identified by expression of both CD45RA and CD62L .
12,15 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Remixing of purified T cells showed that naive T cells do not suppress LAI replication in memory T cells and that memory T cells do not restore LAI expression in naive T cells .
2,5 G#cell_type|7,10 G#cell_type|16,19 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_type

The suppression of productive LAI replication in naive T cells is not due to differential expression of viral coreceptors , nor is it due to inhibition of activation of the important HIV transcription factors , nuclear factor-kappaB and activator protein-1 .
7,10 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|35,37 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

The inherent resistance of naive T cells to productive HIV infection , coupled with their proliferative advantage as demonstrated here , provides a sound basis for proposed clinical therapies using ex vivo expansion and reinfusion of CD4 T cells from HIV -infected adults .
4,7 G#cell_type|36,39 G#cell_type

A PMLRARalpha transgene initiates murine acute promyelocytic leukemia .
1,3 G#DNA

The malignant cells of acute promyelocytic leukemia ( APL ) contain a reciprocal chromosomal translocation that fuses the promyelocytic leukemia gene ( PML ) with the retinoic acid receptor alpha gene ( RAR alpha ) .
1,3 G#cell_type|18,21 G#DNA|26,31 G#DNA|32,34 G#protein

To test the hypothesis that the chimera PMLRAR alpha plays a role in leukemogenesis , we expressed a PMLRAR alpha cDNA in myeloid cells of transgenic mice .
6,9 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#cell_type

PMLRAR alpha transgenic mice exhibited impaired neutrophil maturation early in life , which progressed at a low frequency over the course of several months to overt APL .


Both the preleukemic state and the leukemia could be transplanted to nontransgenic mice , and the transplanted preleukemia could progress to APL .


The APL recapitulated features of the human disease , including a response to retinoic acid .


Retinoic acid caused the leukemic cells to differentiate in vitro and in vivo , eliciting remissions of both the preleukemic state and APL in mice .
4,6 G#cell_type

Our results demonstrate that PMLRAR alpha impairs neutrophil differentiation and initiates the development of APL .
4,6 G#protein

The transgenic mice described here provide an apparently accurate model for human APL that includes clear evidence of tumor progression .


The model should be useful for exploring the molecular pathogenesis of APL and the mechanisms of the therapeutic response to retinoic acid , as well as for preclinical studies of therapeutic regimens .


DNA methylation changes in hematologic malignancies : biologic and clinical implications .


DNA methylation changes are among the most common detectable abnormalities in human neoplasia .


Hypermethylation within the promoters of selected genes appears to be especially common in all types of human hematopoietic neoplasms , and is usually associated with inactivation of the involved gene ( s ) .
3,4 G#DNA|16,19 G#cell_type

Such hypermethylation-associated silencing of gene expression has been shown for several genes regulating the growth and differentiation of hematopoietic cells , including the estrogen receptor ( ER ) gene , P15 , P16 and others .
18,20 G#cell_type|23,29 G#DNA

Hypermethylation within the promoters of some genes appear to be an early event in the pathogenesis of neoplasia ( ER , P15 ) , while other genes seem to become methylated during the progression of leukemias ( HIC1 , c-abl ) .
3,4 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA

The high prevalence of promoter methylation suggests that this molecular abnormality can be used to monitor disease activity during therapy .


In addition , new technology allows the sensitive identification of gene hypermethylation in a background of normal cells , suggesting possible new strategies for the detection of minimal residual disease .
16,18 G#cell_type

Finally , reactivation of tumor-suppressor gene expression through pharmacologic inhibition of DNA methyltransferase and resultant DNA demethylation appears to be a promising new avenue of therapy in acute leukemia .
11,13 G#protein

Redox regulation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway during lymphocyte activation .
4,7 G#protein

We have previously demonstrated an obligatory requirement for intracellular reactive oxygen species generation during T lymphocyte activation , and have proposed that intracellular reactive oxygen species may act as signalling agents in the regulation of certain cellular processes , for example , during cell cycle entry .


To test this hypothesis , we have been interested to determine which , if any , cell cycle entry events are affected by oxidative signalling .


In earlier studies , we have identified the transcription factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 as molecular targets for oxidative signalling processes during cell cycle entry , and have shown that oxidative signalling is involved in the regulation of early changes in gene expression during the G0 to G1 phase transition .
8,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

To extend these initial observations , we have examined the effect of antioxidant treatment on the activity of the mitogen-activated protein kinases erk1 and erk2 , as members of a signal transduction pathway known to directly regulate transcription factor function .
19,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Using as a probe cysteamine , an aminothiol compound with both antioxidant and antiproliferative activity , we have identified erk2 , a key element of the MAP kinase pathway , as being responsive to oxidative signalling during lymphocyte activation .
19,20 G#protein

These observations provide further evidence to suggest a role for intracellular oxidant generation as a regulatory mechanism during cell cycle entry , and establish a link between oxidative signalling and other aspects of the intracellular signalling network that is activated in response to mitogenic stimulation .


Physical and functional interaction between the human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 Tax1 protein and the CCAAT binding protein NF-Y .
6,14 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Tax1 , a potent activator of human T-cell lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) transcription , has been shown to modulate expression of many cellular genes .
0,1 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA

Tax1 does not bind DNA directly but regulates transcription through protein-protein interactions with sequence-specific transcription factors .
0,1 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

Using the yeast two-hybrid system to screen for proteins which interact with Tax1 , we isolated the B subunit of the CCAAT binding protein NF-Y from a HeLa cDNA library .
12,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,30 G#DNA

The interaction of Tax1 with NF-YB was specific in that NF-YB did not interact with a variety of other transcription factors , including human immunodeficiency virus Tat , human papillomavirus E6 , and Bicoid , or with the M7 ( amino acids 29CP-AS ) Tax1 mutant .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|38,46 G#protein

However , NF-YB did interact with the C-terminal Tax1 mutants M22 ( 130TL-AS ) and M47 ( 319LL-RS ) .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

We also show that in vitro-translated NF-YB specifically bound to a glutathione S-transferase- Tax1 fusion protein .
6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|11,16 G#protein

Further , Tax1 coimmunoprecipitated with NF-Y from nuclear extracts of HTLV-1-transformed cells , providing evidence for in vivo interaction of Tax1 and NF-YB .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We further demonstrate that Tax1 specifically activated the NF-Y -responsive DQbeta promoter , as well as a minimal promoter which contains only the Y-box element .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,12 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA

In addition , mutation of the Y-box element alone abrogated Tax1 -mediated activation .
6,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein

Taken together , these data indicate that Tax1 interacts with NF-Y through the B subunit and that this interaction results in activation of the major histocompatibility complex class II promoter .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|24,30 G#DNA

Through activation of this and other NF-Y driven promoters , the Tax1 -NF-Y interaction may play a critical role in causing cellular transformation and HTLV-1 pathogenesis .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

High levels of the DNA-binding activity of E2F in adult T-cell leukemia and human T-cell leukemia virus type I -infected cells : possible enhancement of DNA-binding of E2F by the human T-cell leukemia virus I transactivating protein , Tax .
7,8 G#protein|13,21 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|30,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Transcription factor E2F binds to cellular promoters of certain growth- and cell cycle- controlling genes and forms distinct heteromeric complexes with other nuclear proteins .
0,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|9,15 G#DNA|18,20 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

It has therefore been proposed that E2F is involved in cellular proliferation control .
6,7 G#protein

Human T-cell leukemia virus type I ( HTLV-I ) is an etiological agent of adult T-cell leukemia ( ATL ) .


We show here by mobility-shift assay that E2F -containing DNA-binding complexes were detected in HTLV-I -infected T-cell lines and leukemic cells obtained from ATL patients but not in an uninfected T-cell line , Jurkat , and normal peripheral blood mononuclear cells .
7,8 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line|19,21 G#cell_type|29,32 G#cell_line|33,34 G#cell_line|36,41 G#cell_type

The Tax protein , encoded by HTLV-I , is a potent transcription activator of viral and several cellular genes .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

We demonstrate that expression of Tax can induce the E2F -containing DNA-binding complexes in Jurkat T cells .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_line

Thus , Tax , through enhancement of the DNA-binding activity of E2F , may be capable of regulating cellular gene expression implicated in the proliferation and transformation of T cells in ATL .
2,3 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

This activity may be relevant to the mechanisms whereby HTLV-I which does not contain oncogenes induces neoplasia .
14,15 G#DNA

Dissociation of the Jak kinase pathway from G-CSF receptor signaling in neutrophils .
3,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

Activation of the granulocyte colony-stimulating factor receptor ( G-CSFR ) induces rapid tyrosine phosphorylation of multiple intracellular substrates in proliferating cells and nonproliferating , terminally differentiated neutrophils .
3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|22,27 G#cell_type

The kinases that couple ligand binding to tyrosine phosphorylation of cellular substrates by the G-CSFR with activation of specific functional programs are largely unknown .
10,12 G#protein

In this study , we examined early signaling events in proliferating and terminally differentiated cells following G-CSF stimulation to determine whether identical signaling cascades are activated .
10,11 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

In murine Ba/F3 cells transfected with the human G-CSFR and NFS-60 cells constitutively expressing the murine G-CSFR , G-CSF induced tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of Jak1 , Jak2 , and Tyk2 .
1,4 G#cell_line|7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Tyrosine phosphorylation of Stat3 and , to a lesser extent , Stat1 was also detected following G-CSF stimulation .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Using a mitogenically incompetent human G-CSFR mutant in which Pro639 and Pro641 were substituted by alanine , the box 1 PDP motif was found to be required for activation of Jak kinases , tyrosine phosphorylation of the G-CSFR , and recruitment of Stat proteins .
4,6 G#protein|2,7 G#protein|18,22 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|42,44 G#protein

Notably , no activation of Jak1 , Jak2 , Tyk2 , Stat1 , or Stat3 was observed in neutrophils following G-CSF stimulation .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein

In addition , there was no detectable activation in neutrophils of the recently cloned Jak3 kinase , which has been reported to be expressed at high levels as myeloid cells undergo terminal neutrophilic maturation .
9,10 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

These results indicate a lack of involvement of Jak kinases in signaling by the G-CSFR in neutrophils , and suggest utilization of alternative signal transduction pathways distinct from those in proliferating cells .
8,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type|30,32 G#cell_type

Activation of the Jak -Stat pathway correlates with proliferative signaling by the G-CSFR and requires the membrane-proximal box 1 PXP motif , which is conserved in members of the cytokine receptor superfamily .
3,4 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,21 G#protein|29,32 G#protein

Impaired induction of c-fos/c-jun genes and of transcriptional regulatory proteins binding distinct c-fos/c-jun promoter elements in activated human T cells during aging .
3,5 G#DNA|7,10 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|16,20 G#cell_type

The activation of transcriptional factor c-Fos/c-Jun AP-1 is essential for normal T cell responsiveness and is often impaired in T cells during aging .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type

In the present study , we investigated whether aberrancies in the regulation of c-fos/c-jun at the mRNA or protein level might underlie the age-associated impairments of AP-1 in human T cells .
13,14 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|28,31 G#cell_type

Whereas T cells from young subjects stimulated with cross-linked anti-CD3epsilon mAb OKT3 plus PMA or with the lectin PHA plus PMA demonstrated considerable increases in c-Fos protein expression , the expression of c-Fos but not c-Jun was markedly reduced in stimulated T cells from certain elderly subjects .
1,3 G#cell_type|8,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|41,43 G#cell_type

In addition , RNase protection assays revealed that anti-CD3/ PMA -stimulated T cells from a substantial proportion of elderly subjects exhibited decreased levels of c-fos and/or c-jun mRNA compared to T cells from young subjects .
3,4 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type|24,28 G#RNA|30,32 G#cell_type

Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays , the levels of nuclear regulatory proteins recognizing the AP-1 consensus TRE motif , the proximal c-jun TRE-like promoter element , and the c-fos serum response element ( SRE ) were determined in resting and stimulated T cells .
9,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|20,25 G#DNA|28,32 G#DNA|33,34 G#DNA|38,43 G#cell_type

Although the stimulation of T cells from young subjects resulted in coordinated increases of nuclear protein complexes binding the AP-1 TRE , c-jun TRE , and c-fos SRE DNA sequence motifs , age-related reductions in the activation of AP-1 were accompanied by decreased levels of c-jun TRE and c-fos SRE binding complexes .
4,6 G#cell_type|14,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA|26,31 G#DNA|38,39 G#protein|45,52 G#protein

Furthermore , the nuclear protein complexes binding the SRE motif induced in activated T cells of young and elderly subjects contained serum response factor and Elk-1 pointing toward age-related defects in the activation of transcriptional regulatory proteins distinct from c-jun/ AP-1 .
3,6 G#protein|8,9 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#cell_type|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|39,41 G#protein

These results suggest that underlying aberrancies in the induction of c-fos/c-jun as well as their nuclear regulatory proteins may contribute to the age-related impairments of AP-1 activation in human T cells .
10,11 G#DNA|15,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,31 G#cell_type

Retinoic acid -induced modulation of IL-2 mRNA production and IL-2 receptor expression on T cells .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|9,10 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Retinoic acid ( RA ) has important immune-modulating effects on both T and B cell function .


Our laboratory has shown that RA can enhance in vitro polyclonal B cell immunoglobulin ( Ig ) response .
13,14 G#protein

Investigating cytokines known to affect B cell differentiation , we have recently shown that IL-6 production is augmented by RA .
1,2 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

In the present study we have examined the immune modulating effects of RA on IL-2 mRNA , another important cytokine for B cell immunoglobulin production , the expression of IL-2 receptors on T cells , and the RA nuclear receptors .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|37,40 G#protein

METHODS : Purified T cells were obtained from adenoidal tissues , and incubated with RA ( 10(-7) M ) or DMSO solvent/media control for 0 , 6-8 , and 24 h .
3,5 G#cell_type

Total mRNA was extracted from T cells , and using RT-PCR , changes in the production of IL-2 and RA receptors ( RAR ) - alpha , beta , gamma mRNA were determined .
1,2 G#RNA|5,7 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#RNA|27,28 G#RNA|29,31 G#RNA

The effects of RA on IL-2-alpha receptor expression was determined by flow cytometry on T cells .
14,16 G#cell_type

CONCLUSION : These studies suggest that RA can augment IL-2 mRNA production by T cells with a possible paracrine effect on IL-2R-alpha expression .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#RNA|13,15 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein

These changes appear to be mediated by RAR-alpha .
7,8 G#protein

Thus , IL-2 may be another important cytokine modulated by RA in the immune response .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Involvement of an SAF-like transcription factor in the activation of serum amyloid A gene in monocyte/macrophage cells by lipopolysaccharide .
3,6 G#protein|10,14 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type

Serum amyloid A ( SAA ) has been linked to atherosclerosis because of its ability to remodel high-density lipoprotein by the depletion of apolipoprotein A1 , its ability to bind cholesterol , and its presence in the atherosclerotic plaques of coronary and carotid arteries .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

In the present study , we investigated the induction mechanism of SAA gene in THP-1 monocyte/macrophage cells which play a critical role in the development of atherosclerotic fatty streak and plaque formation .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_line

We and others have shown that SAA gene is induced in monocyte/macrophage cells by lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) .
6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

By promoter function analysis , we show that the SAA promoter sequence between -280 and -226 can confer LPS responsiveness .
9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA

Gel electrophoretic mobility shift assay detected an induced DNA-binding activity in these cells in response to LPS .


Characterization of the DNA-binding protein by UV cross-linking , Southwestern blot , and antibody ablation/supershift assays revealed that it is similar to a recently reported nuclear factor designated SAF .
3,5 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

These results demonstrated that LPS -mediated SAA gene induction in monocyte/macrophage cells is primarily due to the induction of SAF activity .
6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

Cytomegalovirus immediate early genes upregulate interleukin-6 gene expression .
0,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein

BACKGROUND : The immediate early genes ( IE ) of human cytomegalovirus ( CMV ) can be expressed in monocytic cells and are known to regulate viral and cellular genes .
3,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|19,21 G#cell_type|26,30 G#DNA

Interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) plays a central role in numerous inflammatory and immune processes .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein

Interleukin-6 levels are increased in lung transplant patients clinically diagnosed with CMV pneumonitis .
0,1 G#protein

The regulation of IL-6 is dependent on various stimuli that include lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) , viruses , and other cytokines .
3,4 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

These studies examined the ability of CMV IE gene products to modulate IL-6 production .
12,13 G#protein

METHODS : THP-1 cells , a monocytic cell line , were transfected with the CMV IE genes .
2,4 G#cell_line|6,9 G#cell_line|14,17 G#DNA

Interleukin-6 protein and IL-6 mRNA were measured in control and CMV immediate early transfected cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#RNA|10,15 G#cell_type

Cotransfection of CMV IE genes and IL-6 chloramphenicol acetyl transferase ( CAT ) or IL-6 luciferase constructs were used to study IL-6 promoter activity .
2,5 G#DNA|6,17 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

RESULTS : Interleukin-6 protein and mRNA production were significantly increased in cells transfected with the CMV IE genes and stimulated with LPS compared to LPS -stimulated control cells .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|24,28 G#cell_line

Cytomegalovirus IE gene products significantly enhanced LPS stimulation of IL-6 promoter activity in both IL-6 CAT and IL-6 luciferase assays .
0,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein

A deletion construct that contains a NF-kappa B site but is missing the multiple response region demonstrated a continued increase in IL-6 luciferase activity in LPS -stimulated CMV transfected cells .
6,8 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,30 G#cell_line

CONCLUSION : Cytomegalovirus immediate early gene products significantly enhanced expression of IL-6 in LPS -stimulated cells .
2,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

The increase in IL-6 luciferase activity occurs in the absence of the multiple response region , the area of the IL-6 promoter responsive to IL-1 , TNF alpha , cyclic amp , and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate .
3,4 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

The ability of CMV IE gene products to enhance IL-6 production may play an important role in immune inflammatory states associated with CMV infection .
3,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Induction of relA ( p65 ) and I kappa B alpha subunit expression during differentiation of human peripheral blood monocytes to macrophages .
2,6 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|16,20 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type

We evaluated the expression and DNA binding activity of nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappa B subunits in human peripheral blood monocytes and in monocyte-derived macrophages ( MDMs ) .
9,17 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_type|25,26 G#cell_type|24,26 G#cell_type|27,28 G#cell_type

Constitutive DNA binding activity consisting of p50 homodimers was detected in nuclear extracts from both cell types .
6,8 G#protein

An additional complex composed of p50/RelA ( p65 ) heterodimers appeared only in nuclear extracts from 7-day MDMs .
5,10 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

Immunoblot analysis showed that the p50 subunit was constitutively expressed in monocytes and MDMs .
11,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type

In contrast , the RelA ( p65 ) subunit was barely detectable in monocytes , but its level increased markedly in MDMs .
4,9 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type

Analysis of RelA ( p65 ) mRNA revealed that the stability of RelA ( p65 ) mRNA was significantly higher in MDMs , compared with monocytes .
2,7 G#RNA|12,17 G#RNA|21,22 G#cell_type|25,26 G#cell_type

In MDMs , an upregulation of I kappa B alpha synthesis as well as the appearance of a novel M(r) 40,000 form of I kappa B alpha were also observed .
1,2 G#cell_type|6,10 G#protein|23,27 G#protein

These results suggest that macrophage differentiation results in the expression of active p50/RelA ( p65 ) heterodimers with the capacity to activate target gene expression .
12,17 G#protein

The parallel induction of I kappa B alpha synthesis may allow for the continuous presence of a cytoplasmic reservoir of p50/RelA ( p65 ) complexes that are readily available for inducer-mediated stimulation .
4,8 G#protein|20,25 G#protein

Nuclear Rel-A and c-Rel protein complexes are differentially distributed within human thymocytes .
0,6 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

Nuclear factor-kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) /Rel proteins are inducible transcriptional regulators of numerous cellular genes .
4,6 G#protein|0,9 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

They are particularly abundant in lymphoid tissues and are thought to be critical for the transcription of genes involved in immune and inflammatory responses .


We have reported previously that a nuclear NF-kappa B activity was present in freshly extracted human thymocytes in the absence of in vitro treatment of these cells .
7,9 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

In the present report , we identified NF-kappa B proteins extracted from human thymocyte nuclei as being p50/p65 and p50/c-Rel complexes .
7,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|17,21 G#protein

Immunochemical and immunofluorescent staining of thymus sections using specific Abs allowed visualization of nuclear NF-kappa B proteins in both thymocytes and nonthymocyte cells .
8,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|19,20 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

This detection suggested a preferential activation of p50/c-Rel in medullary thymocytes , whereas p50/p65 was present in both cortical and medullary regions of human thymus lobules .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

However , the intensity of p65 labeling was much higher in several thymocytes from the medulla .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type

p65 , p50 , and c-Rel activities were found in both CD4- and CD8- positive thymocytes .
11,16 G#cell_type

These observations suggest that p65 and c-Rel complexes play distinct roles in gene expression and that both forms of NF-kappa B play critical roles during late stages of the intrathymic maturation of T cells .
4,8 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

ALY , a context-dependent coactivator of LEF-1 and AML-1 , is required for TCRalpha enhancer function .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

LEF-1 is a transcription factor that participates in the regulation of the T-cell receptor alpha ( TCR alpha ) enhancer by facilitating the assembly of multiple proteins into a higher order nucleoprotein complex .
0,1 G#protein|12,20 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

The function of LEF-1 is dependent , in part , on the HMG domain that induces a sharp bend in the DNA helix , and on an activation domain that stimulates transcription only in a specific context of other enhancer-binding proteins .
3,4 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|39,41 G#protein

With the aim of gaining insight into the function of context-dependent activation domains , we cloned ALY , a novel LEF-1 -interacting protein .
10,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

ALY is a ubiquitously expressed , nuclear protein that specifically associates with the activation domains of LEF-1 and AML-1 ( CBF alpha2 , PEBP2 alpha ( B ) , which is another protein component of the TCR alpha enhancer complex .
0,1 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|36,40 G#protein

In addition , ALY can increase DNA binding by both LEF-1 and AML proteins .
3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

Overexpression of ALY stimulates the activity of the TCR alpha enhancer complex reconstituted in transfected nonlymphoid HeLa cells , whereas down-regulation of ALY by anti-sense oligonucleotides virtually eliminates TCR alpha enhancer activity in T cells .
2,3 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|14,18 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein|28,31 G#DNA|33,35 G#cell_type

Similar to LEF-1 , ALY can stimulate transcription in the context of the TCR alpha enhancer but apparently not when tethered to DNA through an heterologous DNA-binding domain .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|25,28 G#protein

We propose that ALY mediates context-dependent transcriptional activation by facilitating the functional collaboration of multiple proteins in the TCR alpha enhancer complex .
3,4 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|18,22 G#protein

AML1a but not AML1b inhibits erythroid differentiation induced by sodium butyrate and enhances the megakaryocytic differentiation of K562 leukemia cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type

AML1 may play a role in growth and differentiation of cells along erythroid and/or megakaryocytic lineages , because a significant level of the AML1 gene is expressed in these cells .
0,1 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein

We overexpressed AML1a ( without the transcription-activating domain ) and AML1b ( with the domain ) proteins in K562 leukemia cells , which can be induced to differentiate into hemoglobin-producing cells and megakaryocytes .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type|32,33 G#cell_type

The AML1a -transfected K562 cells had a reduced capacity to differentiate in the presence of sodium n-butyrate but not in the presence of other inducers , such as hemin , 1-beta-D-arabinofuranosylcytosine , and herbimycin A .
1,2 G#protein|1,5 G#cell_line

The AML1 antisense oligodeoxynucleotide but not the sense oligomer recovered its differentiation-inducing capacity in the presence of butyrate .
1,2 G#protein

On the other hand , AML1b conferred a similar differentiation-inducing capacity upon K562 cells transfected with vector alone .
5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line

AML1a expression was associated with enhanced sensitivity to megakaryocytic differentiation induced by phorbol ester .
0,1 G#protein

These results provide evidence that AML1 proteins play a role in erythroid and megakaryocytic differentiation .

Suppression by azelastine hydrochloride of NF-kappa B activation involved in generation of cytokines and nitric oxide .
5,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

The influence of the anti-allergy agent azelastine hydrochloride ( Azeptin ) on NF-kappa B activation associated with the generation of cytokines and nitric oxide ( NO ) was investigated in various kinds of human and mouse cells .
12,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|33,37 G#cell_type

Azeptin dose-dependently suppressed both DNA and protein synthesis in human gingival fibroblasts ( HF ) and also suppressed blastogenesis of human peripheral blood lymphocytes ( PBL ) . Generation of tumor necrosis factor-alpha , interleukin 1-beta , granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor and interleukin-6 from 10(-5) M Azeptin -treated PBL and human monocytes ( HM ) was decreased to approximately 1/3 to 2/3 of the control levels .
9,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|20,24 G#cell_type|25,26 G#cell_type|30,33 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|37,40 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|47,48 G#cell_type|49,51 G#cell_type|52,53 G#cell_type

In parallel with the decreased cytokine generation , each cytokine mRNA was less expressed in the presence of 10(-5) M Azeptin .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#RNA

In addition , both inducible nitric oxide synthase -mRNA level and NO generation in mouse peritoneal macrophages were suppressed by 10(-5) M Azeptin .
5,8 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Being compatible with those results , Azeptin ( 10(-5) M ) suppressed activation of NF-kappa B in PBL , HM and HF .
14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type

These results appear to indicate that suppression of cytokine and NO generation by Azeptin results at least partially from the inhibition of NF-kappa B activation .

Differential interaction of nuclear factors with the PRE-I enhancer element of the human IL-4 promoter in different T cell subsets .
7,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|17,20 G#cell_type

The immunomodulatory cytokine IL-4 affects cells of most hemopoietic lineages .
2,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

IL-4 is secreted by activated Th2 but not Th1 cells and plays a major role in the immune response by modulating the differentiation of naive Th cells toward the Th2 phenotype .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|24,27 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type

We have previously identified an enhancer element , PRE-I , that is essential for the function of the human IL-4 promoter .
5,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

To investigate the mechanisms responsible for tissue-specific expression of the IL-4 gene , we analyzed nuclear factors binding to the PRE-I site and compared the binding activities of these factors to the IL-4 promoter of Th1 and Th2 cells .
10,11 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|35,39 G#cell_type

We show that PRE-I interacts with PMA - and PMA / ionomycin -inducible , cyclosporin A -sensitive nuclear factors .
3,4 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein

Using anti-C/EBPbeta ( NF-IL6 ) , anti-C/EBPdelta ( NF-IL6beta ) , anti-NF-ATc , anti-NF-ATp , anti-Fos , and anti-Jun Abs we demonstrate that the previously identified PRE-I binding factor POS-1 is composed of different transcription factors in different Th cell subsets .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|26,27 G#DNA|26,29 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

In the IL-4 -producing Th0-like human Jurkat and mouse EL-4 cells , POS-1 ( designated POS-1a ) contains NF-IL6beta and Jun .
2,3 G#protein|2,7 G#cell_line|8,11 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

In the mouse Th2 D10 cells and in the human Th2 clones , POS-1 ( designated POS-1b ) contains NF-IL6beta , Jun , and NF-ATc/p .
2,6 G#cell_line|9,12 G#cell_line|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

In contrast , POS-1 was not found in nuclear extracts of human Th1 clones .
3,4 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_line

These findings suggest that PRE-I may play a role in the differential regulation of IL-4 gene expression levels .
