The capacity of Syk to reconstitute the MAPK response required the catalytic activity of Syk , an intact autophosphorylation site ( Y518 and Y519 ) , both Src homology 2 domains and it was blocked by the inhibitory N17-mutated dominant-negative Ras construct .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|27,31 G#protein|37,42 G#protein

A Y341 --&gt; F mutant of Syk , which is deficient in its interaction with phospholipase Cy1 and Vav , was less efficient than wild-type Syk .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

Our results suggest that Syk , in contrast to Zap , can transduce signals from the T cell antigen receptor independently of Lck .
4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Activation of the transcription factor MEF2C by the MAP kinase p38 in inflammation .
3,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein

For cells of the innate immune system to mount a host defence response to infection , they must recognize products of microbial pathogens such as lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) , the endotoxin secreted by Gram-negative bacteria .


These cellular responses require intracellular signalling pathways , such as the four MAP kinase ( MAPK ) pathways .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

In mammalian cells the MAPK p38 is thought to play an important role in the regulation of cellular responses during infection through its effects on the expression of proinflammatory molecules .
4,6 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

One means of understanding the role of p38 in these responses is to identify proteins with functions regulated by p38 -catalysed phosphorylation .
7,8 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Here we demonstrate a link between the p38 pathway and a member of the myocyte-enhancer factor 2 ( MEF2 ) group of transcription factors .
7,8 G#protein|14,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

We found that in monocytic cells , LPS increases the transactivation activity of MEF2C through p38 -catalysed phosphorylation .
4,6 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

One consequence of MEF2C activation is increased c-jun gene transcription .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA

Our results show that p38 may influence host defence and inflammation by maintaining the balance of c-Jun protein consumed during infection .
4,5 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Cellular redox status influences both cytotoxic and NF-kappa B activation in natural killer cells .
11,14 G#cell_type

The role of cellular redox status in both cytotoxic activity and NF-kappa B activation in natural killer ( NK ) cells was investigated .
11,13 G#protein|15,21 G#cell_type

The results indicate that stimulation of NK cells , either freshly isolated from peripheral blood lymphocytes ( PBL ) or long-term cultured NK clones , with specific cell targets results in an increased binding activity of NF-kappa B and AP-1 transcription factors measured by gel retardation .
6,8 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type|20,24 G#cell_line|36,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|40,42 G#protein

Pretreatment of NK cells with the antioxidant pyrrolidine dithiocarbarmate ( PDTC ) leads to the inhibition of NF-kappa B activation but the AP-1 binding to DNA was superinduced .
2,4 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

The inhibition of NF-kappa B by PDTC paralleled with an inhibition of spontaneous cytotoxicity mediated by NK cells .
3,5 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

Moreover , the inhibitors of serine proteases , N-alpha-tosyl-L-lysine chloromethyl ketone and N-alpha-tosyl-L-phenylalanine chloromethyl ketone , also blocked the cytolytic activity of NK cells against the sensitive target K562 .
5,7 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_line

In contrast , NK activity was not affected by pretreatment of the effector cells with the proteasome inhibitor N-acetyl-leu-leu-norleucinal which selectively inhibits NF-kappa B activation .
16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Altogether , these results support the hypothesis that the activation of NK cells involved transcriptional and post-transcriptional events , and that reactive intermediates may play an important role in the molecular processes related with the generation of a cytotoxic response by NK cells .
11,13 G#cell_type|41,43 G#cell_type

The predominant E2F complex in human primary haemopoietic cells and in AML blasts contains E2F-4 , DP-1 and p130 .
2,4 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The E2F family of transcription factors are thought to play an important role in the control of cell cycle progression .
1,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

There is now also increasing evidence that some family members may act as oncogenes or tumour suppressor genes .
13,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA

The characterization of these proteins in human primary haemopoietic cells and acute myeloid leukaemia ( AML ) blasts may thus give an insight to the molecular mechanisms governing proliferation and leukaemogenesis in these cells .
6,10 G#cell_type|11,18 G#cell_type

Therefore we analysed the expression of E2F -DNA binding activity and the constituent proteins found in the complexes in human primary haemopoietic cells of various lineages .
6,7 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_type

We also studied blasts from 18 patients with acute myeloid leukaemia ( AML ) .


On electromobility shift assays ( EMSA ) a single E2F-DNA binding complex was detected in T cells , B cells and monocytes which was shown to contain E2F-4 , DP-1 and p130 , indicating that all quiescent haemopoietic cells have the same complex .
9,12 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type|21,22 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|36,39 G#cell_type

Examination of 18 AML samples by EMSA revealed the presence of E2F binding and no gross abnormalities were detected .
11,12 G#protein

An E2F-4 /p130 complex was detected in representative samples of all FAB types analysed .
1,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Thus abnormalities of E2F function are unlikely to play a primary pathogenic role in AML .
3,4 G#protein

Characterization of a mutant cell line that does not activate NF-kappaB in response to multiple stimuli .
3,6 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein

Numerous genes required during the immune or inflammation response as well as the adhesion process are regulated by nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) .
18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Associated with its inhibitor , I kappaB , NF-kappaB resides as an inactive form in the cytoplasm .
5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Upon stimulation by various agents , I kappaB is proteolyzed and NF-kappaB translocates to the nucleus , where it activates its target genes .
6,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

The transduction pathways that lead to I kappaB inactivation remain poorly understood .
6,8 G#protein

In this study , we have characterized a cellular mutant , the 70/Z3-derived 1.3E2 murine pre-B cell line , that does not activate NF-kappaB in response to several stimuli .
12,18 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein

We demonstrate that upon stimulation by lipopolysaccharide , Taxol , phorbol myristate acetate , interleukin-1 , or double-stranded RNA , I kappaB alpha is not degraded , as a result of an absence of induced phosphorylation on serines 32 and 36 .
14,15 G#protein|17,19 G#RNA|20,22 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

Neither a mutation in I kappaB alpha nor a mutation in p50 or relA , the two major subunits of NF-kappaB in this cell line , accounts for this phosphorylation defect .
4,6 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

As well as culminating in the inducible phosphorylation of I kappaB alpha on serines 32 and 36 , all the stimuli that are inactive on 1.3E2 cells exhibit a sensitivity to the antioxidant pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ( PDTC ) .
9,11 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_line

In contrast , stimuli such as hyperosmotic shock or phosphatase inhibitors , which use PDTC -insensitive pathways , induce I kappaB alpha degradation in 1.3E2 .
19,21 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_line

Analysis of the redox status of 1.3E2 does not reveal any difference from wild-type 70Z/3 .
6,7 G#cell_line|13,15 G#cell_line

We also report that the human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) -derived Tax trans-activator induces NF-kappaB activity in 1.3E2 , suggesting that this viral protein does not operate via the defective pathway .
15,16 G#protein|5,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#cell_line

Finally , we show that two other I kappaB molecules , I kappaB beta and the recently identified I kappaB epsilon , are not degraded in the 1.3E2 cell line following stimulation .
7,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_line

Our results demonstrate that 1.3E2 is a cellular transduction mutant exhibiting a defect in a step that is required by several different stimuli to activate NF-kappaB .
4,5 G#cell_line|7,10 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

In addition , this analysis suggests a common step in the signaling pathways that trigger I kappaB alpha , I kappaB beta , and I kappaB epsilon degradation .
15,17 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

Involvement of Egr-1 /RelA synergy in distinguishing T cell activation from tumor necrosis factor-alpha -induced NF-kappa B1 transcription .
2,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

NF-kappa B is an important transcription factor required for T cell proliferation and other immunological functions .
0,2 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

The NF-kappa B1 gene encodes a 105-kD protein that is the precursor of the p50 component of NF-kappa B .
1,4 G#DNA|6,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Previously , we and others have demonstrated that NF-kappa B regulates the NF-kappa B1 gene .
8,10 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA

In this manuscript we have investigated the molecular mechanisms by which T cell lines stimulated with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) and phytohemagglutin ( PHA ) display significantly higher levels of NF-kappa B1 encoding transcripts than cells stimulated with tumor necrosis factor-alpha , despite the fact that both stimuli activate NF-kappa B .
11,14 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|35,36 G#RNA|40,43 G#protein|51,53 G#protein

Characterization of the NF-kappa B1 promoter identified an Egr-1 site which was found to be essential for both the PMA / PHA -mediated induction as well as the synergistic activation observed after the expression of the RelA subunit of NF-kappa B and Egr-1 .
3,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|39,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein

Furthermore , Egr-1 induction was required for endogenous NF-kappa B1 gene expression , since PMA / PHA -stimulated T cell lines expressing antisense Egr-1 RNA were inhibited in their ability to upregulate NF-kappa B1 transcription .
2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line|18,21 G#cell_line|16,21 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#RNA

Our studies indicate that transcriptional synergy mediated by activation of both Egr-1 and NF-kappa B may have important ramifications in T cell development by upregulating NF-kappa B1 gene expression .
11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA

The synthesis and immunogenicity of varicella-zoster virus glycoprotein E and immediate-early protein ( IE62 ) expressed in recombinant herpes simplex virus-1 .
5,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

In order to evaluate the conditions for optimal expression and immunogenicity of varicella-zoster virus ( VZV ) proteins in a herpes simplex virus-1 ( HSV-1 ) vector , we selected the VZV glycoprotein E ( gE ) , encoded by ORF 68 and the VZV product of ORF 62 , an immediate-early major tegument protein ( IE62 ) .
12,18 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|40,42 G#DNA|44,46 G#protein|47,49 G#DNA|51,55 G#protein|56,57 G#protein

Three HSV/VZV recombinants were generated : ( 1 ) VZV gE protein coding sequences along with the promoter region were inserted into the thymidine kinase ( TK ) gene of HSV-1 strain KOS ; ( 2 ) VZV gE expressed from the HSV-1 ICP4 promoter was inserted into the glycoprotein C ( gC ) gene of HSV-1 strain F ; and ( 3 ) VZV IE62 protein coding sequences under the control of the HSV-1 ICP4 promoter were inserted into the gC gene of HSV-1 strain F .
1,3 G#DNA|9,12 G#protein|9,14 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|23,29 G#DNA|37,39 G#protein|42,45 G#DNA|49,55 G#DNA|65,66 G#protein|64,69 G#DNA|74,77 G#DNA|81,83 G#DNA

Immunoblot analysis and immunoperoxidase staining of infected cell monolayers demonstrated vector expression of VZV proteins .
13,15 G#protein

Following intracranial inoculation in mice , both VZV gE-HSV ( TK ) and VZV IE62-HSV ( gC ) induced an IgG response against VZV gE or VZV IE62 .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

When tested in cytotoxicity assays using T-lymphocytes from VZV immune human donors , the range of precursor frequencies for T-lymphocytes that recognized VZV gE or VZV IE62 was similar whether these proteins were expressed by HSV-1 or a vaccinia vector .
6,7 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

These experiments demonstrate that HSV-1 is a competent vector for expression of these VZV proteins and support the feasibility of engineering a combined vaccine for these closely related alpha-herpesviruses .
13,15 G#protein

Constitutive dephosphorylation and activation of a member of the nuclear factor of activated T cells , NF-AT1 , in Tax-expressing and type I human T-cell leukemia virus-infected human T cells .
9,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,30 G#cell_type

The tax gene product of the type I human T-cell leukemia virus ( HTLV-I ) transactivates interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) gene through activation of an enhancer termed CD28 responsive element ( CD28RE ) .
18,19 G#protein|16,21 G#DNA|27,30 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA

Tax activation of the CD28RE is partially mediated by a member of the nuclear factor of activated T cells , NF-AT1 .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#DNA|13,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

We have previously shown that NF-AT1 is constitutively active in Jurkat T cells stably transfected with the Tax cDNA , although the underlying molecular mechanism and physiological relevance of this finding remain unclear .
5,6 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

In this report , we demonstrate that the active form of NF-AT1 is also present in the nuclei of HTLV-I -transformed T cells that express the Tax protein .
11,12 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

Interestingly , the constitutive activation of NF-AT1 in these T cells is associated with its dephosphorylation .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Furthermore , the dephosphorylated NF-AT1 can be rapidly rephosphorylated when the cells are incubated with cyclosporin A , an immunosuppressant inhibiting the serine /threonine phosphatase calcineurin .
4,5 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

These results suggest that activation of NF-AT1 in Tax-expressing and HTLV-I-transformed T cells results from its dephosphorylation , which in turn may be due to deregulation of calcineurin
6,7 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein

Expression of NFAT-family proteins in normal human T cells .
2,4 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_type

NFAT proteins constitute a family of transcription factors involved in mediating signal transduction .
0,2 G#protein|6,8 G#protein

Using a panel of specific antisera in immunoprecipitation assays , we found that NFATp ( 135 kDa ) is constitutively expressed in normal human T cells , while synthesis of NFATc ( predominant form of 86 kDa ) is induced by ionomycin treatment .
13,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|22,26 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

NFAT4/x was very weakly expressed in unstimulated cells , and its level did not increase upon treatment with activating agents .
0,1 G#protein

NFAT3 protein was not observed under any conditions .
0,2 G#protein

Higher-molecular-weight species of NFATc ( of 110 and 140 kDa ) were also detected .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

In addition , translation of NFATc mRNA apparently initiates at two different AUG codons , giving rise to proteins that differ in size by 36 amino acids .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|12,14 G#DNA

Additional size heterogeneity of both NFATc and NFATp results from phosphorylation .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

In contrast to ionomycin treatment , exposure of cells to phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) plus anti-CD28 did not induce NFATc , indicating that under these conditions , interleukin-2 synthesis by these cells is apparently independent of NFATc .
17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

In DNA binding assays , both PMA plus anti-CD28 and PMA plus ionomycin resulted in nuclear NFAT .
8,9 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Surprisingly , the PMA - ionomycin -induced synthesis of NFATc that was detected by immunoprecipitation was not mirrored in the DNA binding assays : nearly all of the activity was due to NFATp .
9,10 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

This is the first study of expression of all family members at the protein level in normal human T cells .
16,20 G#cell_type

Of the GATA-binding proteins , only GATA-4 selectively regulates the human IL-5 gene promoter in IL-5 producing cells which express multiple GATA-binding proteins .
2,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,14 G#DNA|15,18 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein|20,23 G#protein

Interleukin-5 ( IL-5 ) is produced by T lymphocytes and known to support B cell growth and eosinophilic differentiation of the progenitor cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

Using ATL-16T cells which express IL-5 mRNA , we have identified a region , within the human IL-5 gene promoter , that regulates IL-5 gene transcription .
1,3 G#cell_line|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#RNA|17,18 G#protein|16,20 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA

This cis-acting sequence contains the core binding motif , (A/T)GATA(A/G) , for GATA-binding family proteins and thus suggests the involvement of these family members .
1,3 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|12,15 G#protein

In this report , we describe the cloning of human GATA-4 ( hGATA-4 ) and show that hGATA-4 selectively interacts with the -70 GATA site within the IL-5 proximal promoter region .
10,11 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|27,31 G#DNA

By promoter deletion and mutation analyses , we established this region as a positive regulatory element .
13,16 G#DNA

Cotransfection experiments revealed that both hGATA-4 and PMA /A23187 stimulation are necessary for the IL-5 promoter activation .
5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA

The requirement of another regulatory element called CLE0 , which lies downstream of the -70 GATA site , was also demonstrated .
4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

ATL-16T cells express mRNA of three GATA-binding proteins , hGATA-2 , hGATA-3 and hGATA-4 , and each of them has a potential to bind to the consensus (A/T)GATA(G/Â A) motif .
0,2 G#cell_line|3,4 G#RNA|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA

However , using ATL-16T nuclear extract , we demonstrated that GATA-4 is the only GATA-binding protein that forms specific DNA-protein complex with the -70 GATA site .
10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA

The electrophoretic mobility shift assay with extracts of COS cells expressing GATA-binding proteins showed that GATA-4 has the highest binding affinity to the -70 GATA site among the three GATA-binding proteins .
8,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein

When the transactivation ability was compared among the three , GATA-4 showed the highest activity .
10,11 G#protein

These results demonstrate the selective role of GATA-4 in the transcriptional regulation of the IL-5 gene in a circumstance where multiple members of the GATA-binding proteins are expressed .
7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein

Control of NFATx1 nuclear translocation by a calcineurin -regulated inhibitory domain .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,11 G#protein

The nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) regulates cytokine gene expression in T cells through cis-acting elements located in the promoters of several cytokine genes .
1,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA

NFATx1 , which is preferentially expressed in the thymus and peripheral blood leukocytes , is one of four members of the NFAT family of transcription factors .
0,1 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

We have performed domain analysis of NFATx1 by examining the effects of deletion mutations .
6,7 G#protein

We found that NFATx1 DNA binding activity and interaction with AP-1 polypeptides were dependent on its central Rel similarity region and that transcriptional activation was reduced by deletions of either its N-terminal domain or its C-terminal domain , suggesting the presence of intrinsic transcriptional activation motifs in both regions .
3,4 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|35,37 G#protein|42,46 G#protein

We also identified a potent inhibitory sequence within its N-terminal domain .
5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

We show that the inactivation of the inhibition was dependent on the activity of calcineurin , a calcium-calmodulin-dependent phosphatase .
14,15 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

We also show that calcineurin associated with the N-terminal domain of NFATx1 at multiple docking sites and caused a reduction of size , indicative of dephosphorylation , in NFATx1 .
4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

We have mapped the inhibitory activity to less than 60 residues , containing motifs that are conserved in all NFAT proteins .
9,11 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Finally , we demonstrate that deletion in NFATx1 of the mapped 60 residues leads to its nuclear translocation independent of calcium signaling .
7,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

Our results support the model proposing that the N-terminal domain confers calcium -signaling dependence on NFATx1 transactivation activity by regulating its intracellular localization through a protein module that associates with calcineurin and is a target of its phosphatase activity .
8,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

Neuronal ( type I ) nitric oxide synthase regulates nuclear factor kappaB activity and immunologic ( type II ) nitric oxide synthase expression .
0,8 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,22 G#protein

Nitric oxide subserves diverse physiologic roles in the nervous system .


NO is produced from at least three different NO synthase ( NOS ) isoforms : neuronal NOS ( nNOS ) , endothelial NOS , and immunologic NOS ( iNOS ) .
8,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

We show that nNOS is the predominant isoform constitutively expressed in glia .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type

NO derived from nNOS in glia inhibits the transcription factor nuclear factor kappaB ( NF kappaB ) as NOS inhibitors enhance basal NF kappaB activation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|8,10 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate ( PDTC ) is an inhibitor of NF kappaB in most cells ; however , we show that PDTC is also a potent scavenger of NO through formation of mononitrosyl iron complexes with PDTC .
9,11 G#protein

In Jurkat cells , a human T-cell lymphoma cell line , tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) induces NF kappaB activation that is inhibited by PDTC .
1,3 G#cell_line|6,10 G#cell_line|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Contrary to the results in Jurkat cells , PDTC did not inhibit tumor necrosis factor-alpha -induced NF kappaB activation in astrocytes ; instead PDTC itself induces NF kappaB activation in astrocytes , and this may be related to scavenging of endogenously produced NO by the PDTC iron complex .
5,7 G#cell_line|12,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|26,28 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_type

In astrocytes PDTC also dramatically induces the NF kappaB - dependent enzyme , iNOS , supporting the physiologic relevance of endogenous NO regulation of NF kappaB .
1,2 G#cell_type|7,9 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

NF kappaB activation in glia from mice lacking nNOS responds more rapidly to PDTC compared with astrocytes from wild-type mice .
0,2 G#protein|4,5 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#cell_type

Our data suggest that nNOS in astrocytes regulates NF kappaB activity and iNOS expression , and indicate a novel regulatory role for nNOS in tonically suppressing central nervous system , NF kappaB -regulated genes .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|8,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|30,34 G#DNA

Involvement of Stat3 in interleukin-6 -induced IgM production in a human B-cell line .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_line

Interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) is an important B-cell growth and differentiation factor .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|7,12 G#protein

IL-6 treatment of the human lymphoblastoid cell line , SKW6.4 , leads to increased IgM production .
0,1 G#protein|4,8 G#cell_line|9,10 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein

We have previously shown that IL-6 induces activation of JAK1 and JAK2 in human B cell lines .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_line

A chimeric IL-6 receptor , comprised of the intracellular tail of the IL-6 receptor subunit gp130 fused to the extracellular domain of the epidermal growth factor ( EGF ) receptor , was stably transfected into SKW6.4 cells .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,30 G#protein|35,37 G#cell_line

EGF treatment induced IgM production in cells transfected with an intact gp130 cytoplasmic tail , but not in untransfected cells or cells transfected with a cytoplasmic tail lacking all four signal transducers and activators of transcription ( Stat ) binding sites .
3,4 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line|25,27 G#protein|30,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|30,41 G#protein

Moreover , EGF treatment induced Stat3 phosphorylation in cells transfected with the intact chimeric EGF-gp130 receptor along with induction of DNA-mobility shift of a classical interferon-gamma-activated site .
5,6 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA

To define further the relation between Stat3 activation and enhanced IgM production , we determined the effect of chimeric gp130 on the transcriptional activation of a genetic element linked to immunoglobulin production , namely the immunoglobulin heavy chain enhancer ( IgH-enhancer ) .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|35,39 G#DNA|40,41 G#DNA

Parental as well as transfected SKW6.4 cells were transiently transfected with an IgH-enhancer -luciferase construct .
5,7 G#cell_line|12,13 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA

The transcriptional activity of the IgH-luciferase construct was induced upon ligation of the full-length chimeric receptor but not by truncated gp130 receptors .
5,7 G#DNA|13,16 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

Moreover , the gp130 -induced activity of this reporter gene was abrogated by Stat3EE , a mutant Stat3 incapable of binding DNA .
3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

These results indicate that IL-6 -induced B-cell differentiation , as measured by IgM production , may be controlled by Stat3 proteins .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

T-lymphocytes from individuals with filarial inflammatory disease have increased transendothelial migration in vitro .
0,1 G#cell_type

The in vitro transendothelial migration of circulating filarial antigen-specific T-cells was examined in Wuchereria banerofti infection .
6,10 G#cell_type

Circulating T-cells from individuals with filaria-induced lymphatic pathology ( LP ) had significantly greater migration through unstimulated HUVEC monolayers than did T-cells from asymptomatic infected ( MF ) individuals ( P = 0.04 ) .
0,2 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

In contrast to the MF individuals where no effect was seen , transendothelial migration of 48-hr filarial antigen stimulated T-cells from LP individuals was significantly ( P = 0.01 ) greater than migration of 48-hr media-stimulated T-cells .
16,20 G#cell_type|35,37 G#cell_type

In six of seven patients examined , inhibition of the VLA-4/ VCAM-1 pathway resulted in greater than 50 % inhibition of transendothelial migration of T-cells .
11,12 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type

Transcriptional regulation of the ferritin heavy-chain gene : the activity of the CCAAT binding factor NF-Y is modulated in heme-treated Friend leukemia cells and during monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation .
4,7 G#DNA|12,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_line

The ferritin H-chain gene promoter regulation was analyzed in heme-treated Friend leukemia cells ( FLCs ) and during monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation .
1,5 G#DNA|9,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_line

In the majority of cell lines studied , the regulation of ferritin expression was exerted mostly at the translational level .
4,6 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein

However , in differentiating erythroid cells , which must incorporate high levels of iron to sustain hemoglobin synthesis , and in macrophages , which are involved in iron storage , transcriptional regulation seemed to be a relevant mechanism .
3,6 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#cell_type

We show here that the minimum region of the ferritin H-gene promoter that is able to confer transcriptional regulation by heme in FLCs to a reporter gene is 77 nucleotides upstream of the TATA box .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|22,23 G#cell_line|25,27 G#DNA|28,31 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA

This cis element binds a protein complex referred to as HRF ( heme-responsive factor ) , which is greatly enhanced both in heme-treated FLCs and during monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation .
1,3 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_line

The CCAAT element present in reverse orientation in this promoter region of the ferritin H-chain gene is necessary for binding and for gene activity , since a single point mutation is able to abolish the binding of HRF and the transcriptional activity in transfected cells .
1,3 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|43,45 G#cell_line

By competition experiments and supershift assays , we identified the induced HRF as containing at least the ubiquitous transcription factor NF-Y .
11,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

NF-Y is formed by three subunits , A , B , and C , all of which are necessary for DNA binding .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Cotransfection with a transdominant negative mutant of the NF-YA subunit abolishes the transcriptional activation by heme , indicating that NF-Y plays an essential role in this activation .
3,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

We have also observed a differential expression of the NF-YA subunit in heme-treated and control FLCs and during monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation .
9,11 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_line

Concomitant downregulation of IgH 3' enhancer activity and c-myc expression in a plasmacytoma x fibroblast environment : implications for dysregulation of translocated c-myc .
3,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA

Regulation of immunoglobulin heavy chain ( IgH ) gene expression is controlled by a B cell-specific promoter , intronic enhancer and additional B cell-specific enhancer elements identified recently in the 3' end of the IgH locus .
2,9 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|22,26 G#DNA|34,36 G#DNA

One of the latter elements , the IgH 3' enhancer , is of particular interest : ( 1 ) it is B cell-specific and active only in late B cell development ; ( 2 ) in rodent plasmacytomas and in some human Burkitt 's lymphomas it is part of a locus control region ( LCR ) that is involved in deregulation of the c-myc oncogene as a result of translocation into the IgH locus ; and ( 3 ) it has been implicated in the mechanisms that control Ig gene class switch recombination .
7,10 G#DNA|50,53 G#DNA|54,55 G#DNA|63,64 G#DNA|63,65 G#DNA|72,74 G#DNA|88,91 G#DNA

We have used a somatic cell hybridization approach to genetically analyse regulation of the activity of the IgH 3' enhancer .
17,20 G#DNA

When mouse MPC11 plasmacytoma cells , in which the IgH 3' enhancer is active , are fused with fibroblasts , Ig expression is extinguished at the level of transcription .
1,5 G#cell_line|9,12 G#DNA|18,19 G#cell_type

Here we show that in a MPC11 plasmacytoma x fibroblast environment , the IgH 3' enhancer is transcriptionally inactive .
6,11 G#cell_line|13,16 G#DNA

Furthermore , we demonstrate that binding of several B cell-specific transcription factors , essential for IgH 3' enhancer activity , is lacking , which may explain 3' enhancer inactivity , although the binding of repressors can not be excluded .
10,12 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA

Moreover , the high expression level of c-myc , characteristic of the parental MPC11 cells carrying the t(12;15) translocation , is down-regulated in the hybrids to that in unfused fibroblasts .
7,8 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_line|17,19 G#DNA|29,30 G#cell_type

Therefore , inactivation of the IgH 3' enhancer is a multifactorial process affecting several transcription factors that control the cell-specific and developmental activity of the enhancer .
5,8 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein|25,26 G#DNA

Activation of the NF-kappaB transcription factor in a T-lymphocytic cell line by hypochlorous acid .
3,4 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_line

Reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) such as hydrogen peroxide serve as second messengers in the induction of the transcription factor NF-kappaB , and hence in the activation and replication of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) in human cells .
19,21 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|40,42 G#cell_type

During inflammatory reactions , many oxidative species are produced , one of which is hypochlorous acid ( HOCl ) , which is responsible for the microbicidal effects of activated human polymorphonuclear leukocytes .
29,32 G#cell_type

Treatment of a T-lymphocytic cell line with micromolar concentrations of HOCl promoted the appearance of transcription factor NF-kappaB ( the heterodimer p50/p65 ) in the nucleus of the cells , even in the absence of de novo protein synthesis .
3,6 G#cell_line|15,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Western blot analysis of the NF-kappaB inhibitory subunits ( IkappaB ) demonstrated that both IkappaB -alpha proteolysis and p105 processing were induced by the treatment .
5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

NF-kappaB activation was very effective when cells were subjected to hyperthermia before being treated with HOCl .
0,1 G#protein

Various antioxidants , such as pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate , p-bromophenacyl-bromide and nordihydroguaiaretic acid could strongly reduce NF-kappaB translocation , demonstrating the importance of oxidative species in the transduction mechanism .
15,16 G#protein

Moreover , ACH-2 cells treated with HOCl or H2O2 released tumour necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) in the supernatants .
2,4 G#cell_line|10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The importance of TNF-alpha release in NF-kappaB induction by HOCl or H2O2 was demonstrated by the fact that : ( 1 ) the nuclear appearance of NF-kappaB was promoted in untreated cells ; and ( 2 ) synergism between TNF-alpha and HOCl was detected .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line|39,40 G#protein

Collectively , these results suggest that HOCl should be considered as an oxidative species capable of inducing NF-kappaB in a T-lymphocytic cell line through a transduction mechanism involving ROS , and having a long-distance effect through subsequent TNF-alpha release .
17,18 G#protein|20,23 G#cell_line|37,38 G#protein

Rapid Ca2+-mediated activation of Rap1 in human platelets .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

Rap1 is a small , Ras-like GTPase whose function and regulation are still largely unknown .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

We have developed a novel assay to monitor the active , GTP-bound form of Rap1 based on the differential affinity of Rap1GTP and Rap1GDP for the Rap binding domain of RalGDS ( RBD ) .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Stimulation of blood platelets with alpha-thrombin or other platelet activators caused a rapid and strong induction of Rap1 that associated with RBD in vitro .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Binding to RBD increased from undetectable levels in resting platelets to &gt; 50 % of total Rap1 within 30 s after stimulation .
2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

An increase in the intracellular Ca2+ concentration is both necessary and sufficient for Rap1 activation since it was induced by agents that increase intracellular Ca2+ and inhibited by a Ca2+ -chelating agent .
13,14 G#protein

Neither inhibition of translocation of Rap1 to the cytoskeleton nor inhibition of platelet aggregation affected thrombin -induced activation of Rap1 .
5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

In contrast , prostaglandin I2 ( PGI2 ) , a strong negative regulator of platelet function , inhibited agonist-induced as well as Ca2+ -induced activation of Rap1 .
14,15 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein

From our results , we conclude that Rap1 activation in platelets is an important common event in early agonist-induced signalling , and that this activation is mediated by an increased intracellular Ca2+ concentration
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type

Physical interactions between Ets and NF-kappaB/NFAT proteins play an important role in their cooperative activation of the human immunodeficiency virus enhancer in T cells .
3,7 G#protein|17,21 G#DNA|22,24 G#cell_type

The transcriptional regulatory elements of many inducible T-cell genes contain adjacent or overlapping binding sites for the Ets and NF-kappaB/NFAT families of transcription factors .
1,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|17,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Similar arrays of functionally important NF-kappaB/NFAT and Ets binding sites are present in the transcriptional enhancers of human immunodeficiency viruses types 1 and 2 ( HIV-1 and HIV-2 ) , suggesting that this pattern of nuclear protein binding sites reflects an evolutionarily conserved mechanism for regulating inducible T-cell gene expression that has been co-opted during HIV evolution .
5,10 G#DNA|14,16 G#DNA|35,39 G#DNA

Despite these findings , the molecular mechanisms by which Ets and NF-kappaB/NFAT proteins cooperatively regulate inducible T-cell gene expression remained unknown .
9,13 G#protein

In the studies described in this report , we demonstrated a physical interaction between multiple Ets and NF-kappaB/NFAT proteins both in vitro and in activated normal human T cells .
15,19 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|24,29 G#cell_type

This interaction is mediated by the Ets domain of Ets proteins and the C-terminal region of the Rel homology domains of NF-kappaB/NFAT proteins .
6,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

In addition , the Ets - NF-kappaB / NFAT interaction requires the presence of DNA binding sites for both proteins , as it is abolished by the DNA intercalating agents propidium iodide and ethidium bromide and enhanced by the presence of synthetic oligonucleotides containing binding sites for Ets and NF-kappaB proteins .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|44,46 G#DNA|47,48 G#protein|49,51 G#protein

A dominant-negative mutant of NF-kappaB p50 that binds DNA but fails to interact with Ets proteins inhibits the synergistic activation of the HIV-1 and HIV-2 enhancers by NF-kappaB ( p50 + p65 ) and Ets-1 , suggesting that physical interaction between Ets and NF-kappaB proteins is required for the transcriptional activity of the HIV-1 and HIV-2 enhancers .
4,6 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|41,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|43,45 G#protein|53,57 G#DNA

Taken together , these findings suggest that evolutionarily conserved physical interactions between Ets and NF-kappaB/NFAT proteins are important in regulating the inducible expression of T-cell genes and viruses .
12,16 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA

These interactions represent a potential target for the development of novel immunosuppressive and antiviral therapies .


An acute myeloid leukemia gene , AML1 , regulates transcriptional activation and hemopoietic myeloid cell differentiation antagonistically by two alternative spliced forms .
1,5 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA

The AML1 gene on chromosome 21 is disrupted in the (8;21)(q22;q22) and (3;21)(q26;q22) translocations associated with myelogenous leukemias and encodes a DNA-binding protein .
1,3 G#DNA|4,6 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA|21,23 G#protein

From AML1 gene , two representative forms of proteins , AML1a and AML1b , are produced by an alternative splicing .
1,3 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Both forms have DNA-binding domain , but AML1a lacks a putative transcriptional activation domain which AML1b has .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Here we demonstrate that AML1a , which solely has no effects as a transcriptional regulator , dominantly suppresses transcriptional activation by AML1b , and that AML1a exhibits the higher affinity for DNA-binding than AML1b .
4,5 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Furthermore a dominant negative form of AML1 , AML1a , totally suppressed granulocytic differentiation otherwise induced by granulocyte colony-stimulating factor when AML1a was overexpressed in 32Dc13 murine myeloid cells .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,29 G#cell_type

Such differentiation block by AML1a was canceled by the concomitant overexpression of AML1b .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

These data strongly suggest that a transcriptionally active form of AML1 is essential for the myeloid cell differentiation .
10,11 G#protein

In addition , we observed an altered expression level of AML1 along with the myeloid differentiation in several hemopoietic cell lines .
10,11 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line

In these cases , at least , the AML1 expression level is a potential regulator for myeloid cell differentiation .
8,9 G#protein

Nuclear factor-kappa B potently up-regulates the promoter activity of RANTES , a chemokine that blocks HIV infection .
0,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

The complex network of cytokines that are involved in inflammatory and immunoregulatory responses plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of HIV infection .
4,5 G#protein

RANTES ( regulated upon activation , normal T cell expressed and secreted ) is a cytokine that belongs to the beta-chemokine family ; it is chemoattractant for CD4+/CD45RO T cells , it is produced by various cell types including CD8+ and CD4+ T cells as well as monocytes/macrophages , and has recently been shown to suppress replication of macrophage-tropic strains of HIV in CD4+ T cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|27,30 G#cell_type|39,44 G#cell_type|47,48 G#cell_type|63,66 G#cell_type

To investigate the molecular mechanisms of RANTES expression , the RANTES promoter region was analyzed by transient expression and gel-mobility shift assays .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA

We demonstrate that : 1 ) RANTES promoter activity is up-regulated by PMA plus ionomycin , coexpression of the p65 subunit of nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappa B , the proinflammatory cytokines TNF-alpha and IL-1 beta , and the CD28 costimulatory pathway ; 2 ) the RANTES promoter region contains four NF-kappa B binding sites at positions -30 , -44 , -213 , and -579 relative to the transcription start site ; 3 ) one site ( -213 ) is an NF-AT ( nuclear factor of activated T cells ) binding site that also has weak affinity to NF-kappa B , and the most distal site ( -579 ) also serves as a CD28-responsive element ; and 4 ) mutation on any of those NF-kappa B sites or coexpression of I kappa B alpha ( cytoplasmic inhibitor of NF-kappa B ) markedly reduced the promoter activity .
6,7 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|22,29 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,37 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|47,48 G#protein|47,50 G#DNA|52,54 G#protein|54,56 G#DNA|52,56 G#DNA|57,66 G#DNA|69,72 G#DNA|82,83 G#protein|84,90 G#protein|82,93 G#DNA|99,101 G#protein|114,116 G#DNA|125,127 G#protein|125,128 G#DNA|131,135 G#protein|139,141 G#protein|136,141 G#protein

Thus , NF-kappa B , a potent transcriptional activator of HIV expression , is also involved in the expression of RANTES , a chemokine that blocks infection by macrophage-tropic strains of HIV .
2,4 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Pivotal role for the NFIL3/E4BP4 transcription factor in interleukin 3 -mediated survival of pro-B lymphocytes .
4,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

The E2A-HLF ( hepatic leukemia factor ) oncoprotein , generated in pro-B lymphocytes by fusion of the trans-activation domain of E2A to the basic region/leucine zipper ( bZIP ) domain of HLF , functions as an anti-apoptotic transcription factor in leukemic cell transformation .
1,8 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|23,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|36,39 G#protein

When introduced into interleukin 3 ( IL-3 ) -dependent mouse pro-B lymphocytes , E2A-HLF prevents apoptosis induced by growth factor deprivation , suggesting that IL-3 mediates cell survival through activation of a transcription factor whose activity can be constitutively replaced by the chimeric oncoprotein .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|42,44 G#protein

We considered four bZIP transcription factors as candidates for this putative IL-3 -regulated factor , each of which binds avidly to the DNA consensus sequence recognized by E2A-HLF and is related to the Caenorhabditis elegans CES-2 ( cell death specification protein ) neuron-specific mediator of cell death .
4,6 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|37,41 G#protein|42,47 G#protein

The expression and binding activity of the Nfil3 protein ( also called E4bp4 ) , but not of Hlf , Dbp , or Tef , was found to be regulated by IL-3 in mouse pro-B cell lines ( Baf-3 and FL5.12 ) .
7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,37 G#cell_line|38,39 G#cell_line|40,41 G#cell_line

Northern blot analysis showed that Nfil3/ E4bp4 is regulated as a " delayed-early " IL-3 -responsive gene , requiring de novo protein synthesis .
6,7 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|11,17 G#DNA

In the absence of IL-3 , enforced expression of the human NFIL3/E4BP4 cDNA promoted the survival but not the growth of IL-3 -dependent pro-B cells .
4,5 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_type

Our results implicate NFIL3/E4BP4 ( nuclear factor regulated by IL-3 /adenovirus E4 promoter binding protein ) in a distinct growth factor-regulated signaling pathway that is responsible for the survival of early B-cell progenitors , and whose alteration by E2A-HLF leads to childhood B lineage leukemia .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|5,15 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_type|38,39 G#protein

Detection of adenovirus DNA in peripheral blood mononuclear cells by polymerase chain reaction assay .
5,9 G#cell_type

Adenovirus can establish persistent infections which may reactivate and cause disease in immunocompromised hosts .


Lymphocytes have been postulated to serve as a site of adenoviral persistence based upon the ability to isolate adenovirus from tonsils and to detect adenovirus DNA by Southern blot hybridization in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) .
0,1 G#cell_type|31,35 G#cell_type|36,37 G#cell_type

To test this hypothesis , a more sensitive and specific polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) assay was developed to detect adenovirus DNA .


Two sets of nested primers were designed to conserved sequences in the adenovirus E1A and hexon genes .
12,17 G#DNA

The E1A and hexon primers amplified DNA from representative adenoviral serotypes in all six adenoviral groups ( A-F ) .
1,5 G#DNA

Both primers detected a single copy of the adenovirus type 2 genome but were less sensitive for the group B type 35 .
8,12 G#DNA

None of 33 PBMC specimens from healthy adults and only one of 40 pediatric samples was positive ( at a low level ) for adenovirus DNA by nested PCR assay .
3,4 G#cell_type|3,5 G#cell_type

In comparison , PBMC from two children with fatal adenoviral infection were both strongly positive for adenovirus DNA .
3,4 G#cell_type

It is concluded that , in contrast to a previous study , PBMC are not a common site of persistent group C adenoviral infection .
12,13 G#cell_type

In addition , assay of PBMC by the adenovirus -specific PCR may help detect early invasive disease and warrants further evaluation .
5,6 G#cell_type

Common and distinct intracellular signaling pathways in human neutrophils utilized by platelet activating factor and FMLP .
7,9 G#cell_type|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Stimulation of human neutrophils with chemoattractants FMLP or platelet activating factor ( PAF ) results in different but overlapping functional responses .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

We questioned whether these differences might reflect patterns of intracellular signal transduction .


Stimulation with either PAF or FMLP resulted in equivalent phosphorylation and activation of the mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPk ) homologue 38-kD murine MAP kinase homologous to HOG-1 ( p38 ) MAPk .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|14,21 G#protein|21,25 G#protein|27,32 G#protein

Neither FMLP nor PAF activated c-jun NH2-terminal MAPk ( JNKs ) .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Under identical conditions , FMLP but not PAF , resulted in significant p42/44 ( ERK ) MAPk activation .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,17 G#protein

Both FMLP and PAF activated MAP kinase kinase-3 ( MKK3 ) , a known activator of p38 MAPk .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|3,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Both MAP ERK kinase kinase-1 ( MEKK1 ) and Raf are activated strongly by FMLP , but minimally by PAF .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Pertussis toxin blocked FMLP -induced activation of the p42/44 ( ERK ) MAPk cascade , but not that of p38 MAPk .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,13 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

A specific p38 MAPk inhibitor ( SK&amp;F 86002 ) blocked superoxide anion production in response to FMLP and reduced adhesion and chemotaxis in response to PAF or FMLP .
2,4 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

These results demonstrate distinct patterns of intracellular signaling for two chemoattractants and suggest that selective activation of intracellular signaling cascades may underlie different patterns of functional responses .
10,11 G#protein

Cloning of the novel human myeloid-cell-specific C/EBP-epsilon transcription factor .
3,9 G#protein

Chicken NF-M transcription factor , in cooperation with either c-Myb or v-Myb , is active in the combinatorial activation of myeloid-cell-specific genes in heterologous cell types , such as embryonic fibroblasts .
0,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|23,26 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_type

In humans , similar effects were observed with homologous members of the CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein ( C/EBP ) family of transcriptional regulators , especially the human homolog of chicken NF-M , C/EBP-beta ( NF-IL6 ) .
12,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

However , the NF-IL6 gene is expressed in a variety of nonmyeloid cell types and is strongly inducible in response to inflammatory stimuli , making it an unlikely candidate to have an exclusive role as a combinatorial differentiation switch during myelopoiesis in human cells .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|42,44 G#cell_type

By using a reverse transcription-PCR-based approach and a set of primers specific for the DNA-binding domains of highly homologous members of the C/EBP family of transcriptional regulators , we have cloned a novel human gene encoding a member of the C/EBP gene family , identified as the human homolog of CRP1 , C/EBP-epsilon .
14,16 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA|40,43 G#DNA|50,51 G#protein|52,53 G#protein

A 1.2-kb cDNA encoding full-length human C/EBP-epsilon was cloned from a promyelocyte-late myeloblast-derived lambda gt11 library .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|11,16 G#DNA

Molecular analysis of the cDNA and genomic clones indicated the presence of two exons encoding a protein with an apparent molecular mass of 32 kDa and a pI of 9.5 .
13,14 G#DNA

Primer extension analysis of C/EBP-epsilon mRNA detected a single major transcription start site approximately 200 bp upstream of the start codon .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#RNA|10,13 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA

The putative promoter area is similar to those of several other myeloid-cell-specific genes in that it contains no TATAAA box but has a number of purine-rich stretches with multiple sites for the factors of the Ets family of transcriptional regulators .
18,20 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA|35,37 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

Northern blot analyses indicated a highly restricted mRNA expression pattern , with the strongest expression occurring in promyelocyte and late-myeloblast-like cell lines .
17,22 G#cell_line

Western blot and immunoprecipitation studies using rabbit anti-C/EBP-epsilon antibodies raised against the N-terminal portion of C/EBP-epsilon ( amino acids 1 to 115 ) showed that C/EBP-epsilon is a 32-kDa nuclear phosphoprotein .
6,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,31 G#protein

The human C/EBP-epsilon protein exhibited strong and specific binding to double-stranded DNA containing consensus C/EBP sites .
2,3 G#protein|10,16 G#DNA

Cotransfection of the C/EBP-epsilon sense and antisense expression constructs together with chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter vectors containing myeloid-cell-specific c-mim and human myeloperoxidase promoters suggested a role for C/EBP-epsilon transcription factor in the regulation of a subset of myeloid-cell-specific genes .
3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|16,22 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|36,38 G#DNA

Transient tranfection of a promyelocyte cell line ( NB4 ) with a C/EBP-epsilon expression plasmid increased cell growth by sevenfold , while antisense C/EBP-epsilon caused a fivefold decrease in clonal growth of these cells .
4,7 G#cell_line|8,9 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

The tumour associated cell surface antigen A6H is costimulatory for human CD4+ but not CD8+ T cells .
1,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,17 G#cell_type

The A6H monoclonal antibody ( mAb ) recognizes a 120,000-140,000 MW antigen that is expressed at similar densities on 85-90 % of human CD4+ and CD8+ T cells and on renal cell carcinomas .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|23,28 G#cell_type

The binding of the A6H mAb induced a costimulatory signal in anti-CD3 activated T cells .
4,6 G#protein|11,15 G#cell_line

In the present report , we show that A6H costimulated cell proliferation and cytokine production in purified CD4+ T cells .
8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type

Unexpectedly , the CD8+ T-cell subpopulation failed to respond .
3,6 G#cell_type

CD4+ T cells costimulated with the A6H mAb upregulated CD80 , CD86 , CD71 , interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) R alpha , IL-2R beta and IL-2R gamma , while no corresponding up-regulation of these cell surface molecules was seen in CD8+ T cells .
0,3 G#cell_type|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|40,43 G#cell_type

In order to investigate the nature of the A6H mAb costimulus at the transcriptional level we have examined induction of the transcription factors OCT-1 , AP-1 and NF-kappa B which are known to be transcriptional regulators of several cytokine and cytokine receptor genes , including the IL-2 and IL-2R genes .
8,10 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|46,50 G#DNA

Co-ligation of the A6H antigen and the CD3 complex induced expression of the transcription factor AP-1 in CD4+ T cells , whereas no increase in NF-kappa B and octamer-binding ( Oct ) proteins was seen compared to T cells stimulated with anti-CD3 alone .
3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein|28,33 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type|41,42 G#protein

Furthermore , no induction of AP-1 was seen in A6H costimulated CD8+ T cells .
5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

These results suggests that both proximal steps in CD8+ T-cell activation as well as the later phases are unresponsive to A6H ligation .
20,21 G#protein

Molecular differences of the A6H molecule or distinct regulation of the A6H transduced AP-1 activation pathway may exist in CD4+ and CD8+ T cell subpopulations .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|19,25 G#cell_type

Cloning and expression of the glucocorticoid receptor from the squirrel monkey ( Saimiri boliviensis boliviensis ) , a glucocorticoid-resistant primate .
5,7 G#protein

New World primates such as the squirrel monkey have elevated cortisol levels and glucocorticoid resistance .


We have shown that the apparent binding affinity of the glucocorticoid receptor in squirrel monkey lymphocytes is 5-fold lower than that in human lymphocytes ( apparent Kd , 20.9 +/- 1.8 and 4.3 +/- 0.2 nmol/L , respectively ; n = 3 ) , consistent with previous studies in mononuclear leukocytes isolated from the two species .
10,12 G#protein|13,16 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_type|49,51 G#cell_type

As a first step in understanding the mechanism of decreased binding affinity in New World primates , we used reverse transcription-PCR to clone the glucocorticoid receptor from squirrel monkey liver and have compared the sequence to receptor sequences obtained from owl monkey liver , cotton-top tamarin B95-8 cells , and human lymphocytes .
24,26 G#protein|44,48 G#cell_line|50,52 G#cell_type

The squirrel monkey glucocorticoid receptor is approximately 97 % identical in nucleotide and amino acid sequence to the human receptor .
3,5 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

The ligand-binding domain ( amino acids 528-777 ) of the squirrel monkey glucocorticoid receptor contains four amino acid differences ( Ser551 to Thr , Ser616 to Ala , Ala618 to Ser , and Ile761 to Leu ) , all of which are present in owl monkey and cotton-top tamarin receptors .
1,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|44,50 G#protein

The DNA-binding domain ( amino acids 421-486 ) is completely conserved among human , squirrel monkey , owl monkey , and cotton-top tamarin receptors .
1,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|12,24 G#protein

Twenty-two differences from the human sequence were found in the N-terminal region ( amino acids 1-421 ) of the squirrel monkey receptor .
10,12 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

None of the substitutions in the ligand-binding domain matched mutations known to influence binding affinity in other species .
6,8 G#protein

To determine whether the substitutions per se were responsible for decreased affinity , squirrel monkey and human glucocorticoid receptors were expressed in the TNT Coupled Reticulocyte Lysate System .
16,19 G#protein

Expressions of human and squirrel monkey glucocorticoid receptors and a squirrel monkey receptor in which Phe774 was mutated to Leu ( F774L ) were similar .
6,8 G#protein|10,13 G#protein

When expressed in the TNT System , squirrel monkey and human glucocorticoid receptors had similar , high affinity binding for dexamethasone ( apparent Kd , 5.9 +/- 1.2 and 4.3 +/- 0.5 nmol/L , respectively ; n = 3 ) , whereas the squirrel monkey F774L receptor had lower affinity binding ( apparent Kd , 20.4 +/- 2.0 nmol/L ; n = 3 ) .
11,13 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|43,47 G#protein

Thus , substitutions within the ligand-binding domain of the squirrel monkey glucocorticoid receptor can not account for the decreased binding affinity of these receptors in squirrel monkey cells .
5,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_type

Rather , the binding affinity is probably influenced by the expression of cytosolic factors that affect glucocorticoid receptor function .
12,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Shared gamma(c) subunit within the human interleukin-7 receptor complex .
1,3 G#protein|5,9 G#protein

A molecular basis for the pathogenesis of X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency .


Genetic evidence suggests that mutations in the gamma(c) receptor subunit cause X-linked severe combined immunodeficiency ( X-SCID ) .
7,10 G#protein

The gamma(c) subunit can be employed in receptor complexes for IL -2 , -4 , -7 , -9 , and -15 , and the multiple signaling defects that would result from a defective gamma(c) chain in these receptors are proposed to cause the severe phenotype of X-SCID patients .
1,3 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,21 G#protein|33,35 G#protein

Interestingly , gene disruption of either IL-7 or the IL-7 receptor ( IL-7R ) alpha subunit in mice leads to immunological defects that are similar to human X-SCID .
6,7 G#protein|9,16 G#protein

These observations suggest the functional importance of gamma(c) in the IL-7R complex .
7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

In the present study , structure/function analyses of the IL-7R complex using a chimeric receptor system demonstrated that gamma(c) is indeed critical for IL-7R function .
9,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Nonetheless , only a limited portion of the cytoplasmic domain of gamma(c) is necessary for IL-7R signal transduction .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Furthermore , replacement of the gamma(c) cytoplasmic domain by a severely truncated erythropoeitin receptor does not affect measured IL-7R signaling events .
5,6 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

These findings support a model in which gamma(c) serves primarily to activate signal transduction by the IL-7R complex , while IL-7R alpha determines specific signaling events through its association with cytoplasmic signaling molecules .
7,8 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|30,33 G#protein

Finally , these studies are consistent with the hypothesis that the molecular pathogenesis of X-SCID is due primarily to gamma(c) -mediated defects in the IL-7 /IL-7R system
19,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

S-allyl cysteine inhibits activation of nuclear factor kappa B in human T cells .
5,9 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

Reactive oxygen species are involved in signal transduction pathways leading to nuclear factor kappa B ( NF-kappa B ) activation which has been implicated in the regulation of gene transcription .
11,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

We recently reported that a garlic compound , S-allyl cysteine ( SAC ) , protects bovine pulmonary artery endothelial cells from oxidant injury induced by hydrogen peroxide ( H2O2 ) .
15,20 G#cell_type

In this study we determined the effects of SAC on NF-kappa B activation in human T lymphocytes ( Jurkat cells ) induced by tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-Â alpha ) and H2O2 .
10,12 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_line|23,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Activated NF-kappa B in nuclear extracts was measured by an electrophoretic mobility shift assay using 32P-labeled probe .
1,3 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

SAC consistently exhibited a dose-dependent inhibition of NF-kappa B activation induced by both TNF-alpha and H2O2 .
7,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Supershift with specific antibodies to NF-kappa B subunits confirmed that the inducible retarded bands observed in the EMSA and p65-p50 heterodimer of the NF-kappa B /Rel protein .
5,8 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|23,27 G#protein

Our data suggest that SAC may act via antioxidant mechanisms to block NF-kappa B activation in Jurkat cells .
12,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_line

Elf-2 , a rhombotin-2 binding ets transcription factor : discovery and potential role in T cell leukemia .
0,1 G#protein|3,8 G#protein

Rhombotin-2 ( RBTN-2 ) is a proto-oncogene only in the context of T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#DNA|2,3 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_type

We postulated that the oncogenic effect of RBTN-2 in T cells is likely mediated by binding protein ( s ) with T cell-specific expression .
7,8 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

By screening a T cell cDNA library , we identified a novel ets transcription factor that binds RBTN-2 .
5,7 G#DNA|11,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

This protein was named elf-2 because its DNA-binding domain is virtually identical to that of ets family member elf-1 .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Northern analyses showed similar levels of two elf-2 transcripts ( 3.5 kb and 3.8 kb ) in all tissues except thymus .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA

Thymocytes expressed four- to 10-fold greater amounts of the 3.5 kb transcript than other tissues .
0,1 G#cell_type|9,12 G#RNA

Sequence analyses of cDNA clones indicated that these transcripts encode proteins differing only at their amino termini , and likely represent alternatively spliced isoforms .
3,5 G#DNA|15,17 G#protein

These isoforms ( elf-2a and elf-2b ) contain identical RBTN-2 binding regions and DNA-binding domains .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

Elf-2b lacks a putative transactivation domain .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein

The expression patterns suggest that RBTN-2 normally interacts equally with elf-2a and elf-2b .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In contrast , when RBTN-2 is inappropriately expressed in T cells , RBTN-2 would interact predominantly with elf-2b ; this interaction may lead to T cell proliferation .
4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Transcription factor effects on chromosome constitution of cell hybrids .
0,2 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line

When immunoglobulin ( Ig ) -secreting plasmacytomas are fused to a T-cell lymphoma , Ig gene expression ceases in greater than 95 % of the resulting hybrids .
1,7 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_type|14,16 G#DNA

In the rare hybrids that continue to express Ig , all other tested B lymphocyte-specific genes also remain active .
13,16 G#DNA

The low frequency with which these Ig-expressing hybrids are recovered , along with the fact that cell fusions can lead to chromosome loss , led us to propose that this rare phenotype was due to loss of a T-cell-derived chromosome encoding a factor or factors with gene silencing activity .
6,8 G#cell_line|38,43 G#protein

To identify the relevant chromosome , we have used a polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) -assisted method of chromosome mapping to analyze both Ig-silenced ( common ) and Ig-expressing ( rare ) hybrids .
24,34 G#cell_line

Although no single chromosome was found to correlate with Ig gene silencing , we discovered that the two types of hybrids had undergone distinct patterns of chromosome loss .
9,11 G#DNA

Moreover , we found that ectopic expression of a B-cell-specific transcription factor ( Oct-2 ) dramatically altered both the phenotype and chromosome constitution of hybrids arising in these cell fusions .
9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Reactivation of Kaposi 's sarcoma -associated herpesvirus infection from latency by expression of the ORF 50 transactivator , a homolog of the EBV R protein .
14,17 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Kaposi 's sarcoma ( KS ) -associated herpesvirus ( KSHV ) , or human herpesvirus 8 , is a lymphotropic virus strongly linked to several AIDS-related neoplasms .


The primary reservoir of infection consists of latently infected B lymphocytes and possibly other mononuclear cells .
9,11 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

Viral reactivation from latency and spread from this lymphoid reservoir is presumably required for development of nonlymphoid tumors like KS .


Here we show that deregulated expression of a single viral gene , ORF 50 , which encodes a transactivator able to selectively upregulate delayed-early viral genes , suffices to disrupt latency and induce the lytic gene cascade in latently infected B cells .
9,11 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA|38,42 G#cell_type

The identification of this gene opens the way to studies of the physiologic mechanisms controlling reactvation of KSHV from latency .

Nuclear factor of activated T cells and AP-1 are insufficient for IL-2 promoter activation : requirement for CD28 up-regulation of RE/AP .
4,6 G#cell_type|0,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

IL-2 gene transcription in T cells requires both TCR and costimulatory signals .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type

IL-2 promoter activation in Jurkat T cells stimulated with superantigen presented by Raji B cells requires CD28 activation .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#DNA|4,7 G#cell_line|12,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein

The addition of rCTLA4Ig , which blocks CD28 binding to its ligand , to the cultures decreased IL-2 promoter activation by &gt; 80 % .
7,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

Interestingly , CTLA4Ig did not significantly inhibit the activation of either NF of activated T cells ( NFAT ) or AP-1 reporters .
11,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

Therefore , activation of NFAT and AP-1 is insufficient for IL-2 promoter activation .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

In contrast , an RE/AP reporter was blocked by CTLA4Ig by &gt; 90 % .
4,5 G#protein

Thus , the requirement for CD28 in IL-2 promoter activation appears to be due to RE/AP and not the NFAT or AP-1 sites .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA

In addition , these data suggest that transcriptional activation of RE/AP is not mediated by NFAT , because activation of a NFAT reporter is not affected by the addition of CTLA4Ig .
10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The control of lytic replication of Epstein-Barr virus in B lymphocytes ( Review ) .
9,11 G#cell_type

Uncontrolled replication of a virus , which is harmful to the host is also disadvantageous to the virus .


Most viruses can not compete with the various immune mechanisms and become eliminated in the course of infection .


Therefore , only the time between infection and eradication remains for these viruses to proliferate .


A few viruses , like the Herpesviruses or the papillomaviruses , however , have developed a sophisticated strategy for persisting lifelong , usually asymptomatically in the host , hiding from the immune system and producing infectious progeny at the same time .


This strategy depends on a separation of latency and the lytic replication , either by time due to differentiation-dependent mechanisms or by spatial separation as the result of different host cell types .


Both are true for the Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) .


B cells and epithelial cells have a pivotal role in the life cycle of the virus .
0,2 G#cell_type|3,5 G#cell_type

The former can become latently infected and are thought to be the virus reservoir in vivo , whereas the latter were shown to be permissive for lytic replication .


However , replication of EBV in vivo is controlled primarily by host immune mechanisms selecting for cells that are not permissive for viral replication as the result of a particular set of transcription factors .
32,34 G#protein

These factors control the activity of the regulatory immediate-early genes and , in addition , lytic and latent cycle regulatory genes negatively interfere with each other and thus link cellular and viral gene regulatory mechanisms .
7,10 G#DNA|31,33 G#DNA

Disturbance of both the immune surveillance as well as viral gene regulation may result in EBV -associated disease .
9,11 G#DNA

Adaptor function for the Syk kinases-interacting protein 3BP2 in IL-2 gene activation .
4,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Syk-family tyrosine kinases are essential for lymphocyte development and activation .
0,3 G#protein

Using a yeast two-hybrid screen to identify Syk kinases-interacting proteins ( SKIPs ) , we isolated 3BP2 , an Abl SH3-interacting protein of unknown function .
7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

3BP2 was selectively expressed in hematopoietic/lymphoid tissues and bound via its SH2 domain activated Syk-family kinases in mammalian cells , including in antigen receptor-stimulated T cells .
0,1 G#protein|11,16 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type|22,26 G#cell_type

In addition to Zap-70 , the 3BP2 SH2 domain associated in vitro with LAT , Grb2 , PLCgamma1 , and Cbl from activated T cell lysates .
3,4 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Transient 3BP2 overexpression induced transcriptional activation of the IL-2 promoter and its NFAT or AP-1 elements .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|12,16 G#DNA

This activity was dependent on the SH2 and pleckstrin-homology domains of 3BP2 , and required functional Syk kinases , Ras , and calcineurin .
6,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Thus , 3BP2 is an important adaptor that may couple activated Zap-70 /Syk to a LAT -containing signaling complex involved in TCR-mediated gene transcription .
2,3 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,19 G#protein

In vitro suppression of programmed cell death of B cells by tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases-1 .
8,10 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

Cellular pathways for induction of programmed cell death ( PCD ) have been identified , but little is known about specific extracellular matrix processes that may affect apoptosis along those pathways .


In this study , a series of Burkitt 's lymphoma ( BL ) cell lines were assayed for their expression of tissue inhibitor of metalloproteinases ( TIMP ) -1 .
7,15 G#cell_line|21,29 G#protein

Results indicate that TIMP-1 -positive BL lines show resistance to cold-shock-induced apoptosis .
3,4 G#protein|3,7 G#cell_line

Furthermore , recombinant TIMP-1 , but not TIMP-2 or a synthetic metalloproteinase inhibitor ( BB-94 ) , confers resistance to apoptosis induced by both CD95-dependent and -independent ( cold shock , serum deprivation , and gamma-radiation ) pathways in TIMP-1 -negative BL lines .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|39,43 G#cell_line

TIMP-1 suppression of PCD is not due to metalloproteinase inhibition , as reduction and alkylation of the TIMP-1 did not abolish this activity .
0,1 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Retroviral induction of TIMP-1 not only resulted in cell survival but also in continued DNA synthesis for up to 5 d in the absence of serum , while controls underwent apoptosis .
3,4 G#protein

This resistance to apoptosis is reversed by anti- TIMP-1 antibodies , demonstrating that secreted TIMP-1 is active in blocking apoptosis .
8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Furthermore , TIMP-1 upregulation induced expression of Bcl-XL but not Bcl-2 as well as decreased NF-kappaB activity as compared with controls .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

These results demonstrate that TIMP-1 suppresses apoptosis in B cells and suggests a novel activity for TIMP-1 in tissue homeostasis .
4,5 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

Spi-1/PU.1 proto-oncogene induces opposite effects on monocytic and erythroid differentiation of K562 cells .
0,1 G#DNA|1,2 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_line

Spi-1/PU.1 is a hematopoietic transcription factor of the Ets family .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

To analyze the effects of ectopic expression of spi-1 on the proliferation/differentiation of human myeloid leukemia cells , K562 cells were stably transfected with a spi-1 expression vector .
8,9 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|25,28 G#DNA

The transfected cell lines expressed elevated levels of spi-1 mRNA and protein and high Spi-1 -DNA binding activity .
1,4 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|14,15 G#protein

The spi-1 transfected cells showed reduced growth rates and reduced clonogenic cell growth .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#cell_line

When the erythroid and monocytic differentiation markers were analyzed , spi-1 overexpression resulted in opposite effects : erythroid differentiation was significantly inhibited in spi-1 transfectants , while spi-1 overexpression increased the monocytic differentiation of cells .
10,11 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein

These results indicate a differential role of Spi-1 on the differentiation of human myeloid leukemia cells .
7,8 G#DNA|12,16 G#cell_line
