In vivo function of an interleukin 2 receptor beta chain ( IL-2Rbeta ) / IL-4Ralpha cytokine receptor chimera potentiates allergic airway disease .
5,10 G#protein|10,18 G#protein

Strength of T cell receptor ( TCR ) signaling , coreceptors , costimulation , antigen-presenting cell type , and cytokines all play crucial roles in determining the efficiency with which type 2 T lymphocytes ( Th2 , Tc2 ) develop from uncommitted precursors .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type|32,34 G#cell_type|30,34 G#cell_type|35,36 G#cell_type|37,38 G#cell_type|41,43 G#protein

To investigate in vivo regulatory mechanisms that control the population of type 2 T cells and disease susceptibility , we have created lines of transgenic mice in which expression of a chimeric cytokine receptor ( the mouse interleukin 2 receptor beta chain [ IL-2Rbeta ] extracellular domain fused to the cytoplasmic tail of IL-4Ralpha ) is targeted to the T lymphoid lineage using the proximal lck promoter .
11,15 G#cell_type|31,34 G#protein|37,42 G#protein|36,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|36,47 G#protein|50,52 G#protein|53,54 G#protein|59,62 G#cell_type|64,67 G#DNA

This chimera transduced IL-4 -specific signals in response to IL-2 binding and dramatically enhanced type 2 responses ( IL-4 , IL-5 , and immunoglobulin E production ) upon in vitro TCR stimulation or in vivo antigen challenge .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Thus , type 2 effector function was augmented by IL-4 signals transduced through a chimeric receptor expressed in a T cell-specific manner .
9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

This influence was sufficient for establishment of antigen-induced allergic airway hyperresponsiveness on a disease-resistant background


Differentiation-dependent expression of a human carboxylesterase in monocytic cells and transcription factor binding to the promoter .
4,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA

Carboxylesterases play an important role in defense and clearance mechanisms of the monocyte/macrophage system .
0,1 G#protein

During the differentiation process of cells from the monocytic cell line THP-1 we observed a transient transcriptional upregulation of a human carboxylesterase analyzed by means of Northern blots .
8,12 G#cell_line|20,22 G#protein

In PMA-treated THP-1 cells we could detect three major transcription initiation sites as revealed by Nuclease Protection Assay carried out with two overlapping antisense RNA probes .
1,4 G#cell_line|9,12 G#DNA|22,26 G#RNA

We have recently cloned the carboxylesterase upstream sequence and showed its basal promoter activity in CHO cells .
5,8 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_line

Using electrophoretic mobility shift analysis we demonstrated that the promoter region spanning base pairs -1 to -275 , which contains several putative binding sites for transcription factors , is bound by nuclear factors Sp1 and IRBP but not by C/EBPs .
9,11 G#DNA|12,17 G#DNA|25,27 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Taken together these data indicate that carboxylesterase gene transcription in THP-1 cells starts at multiple initiation sites and that Sp1 and IRBP may be critical factors for modulating the differentiation-dependent transcription of this human carboxylesterase gene .
10,12 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|33,36 G#DNA

The role of the Ikaros gene in lymphocyte development and homeostasis .
4,6 G#DNA

The Ikaros gene , which encodes a family of hemopoietic-specific zinc finger proteins , is described as a central regulator of lymphocyte differentiation .
1,3 G#DNA|9,13 G#protein

During fetal development , it is required at the earliest stage of T cell and B cell specification .


In the adult , however , lymphoid lineages rely on Ikaros at distinct phases of their development .
6,8 G#cell_type|10,11 G#DNA

Its activity is essential for the generation of B cell but not of T cell precursors , although the differentiation of the latter is not normal .
8,10 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_type

A significant increase in CD4 thymocytes and their immediate precursors is detected , and because these cells lack markers that correlate with positive selection , a deregulation in their maturation process is suggested .
4,6 G#cell_type

Furthermore , Ikaros-null thymocytes hyperproliferate in response to T cell receptor ( TCR ) signaling ; within days after their appearance in the thymus , clonally expanding populations are detected .
2,4 G#cell_type|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Deregulated TCR -mediated responses and the fast kinetics of tumor development in these mutant thymocytes implicate Ikaros as a central tumor suppressor gene for the T cell lineage .
1,2 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|19,23 G#DNA|25,28 G#cell_type

In addition , lack of natural killer cells and selective defects in gamma delta T cells and dendritic antigen-presenting cells point to Ikaros as an essential factor for the establishment of early branchpoints of the T cell pathway .
5,8 G#cell_type|12,16 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein

The dominant interference activity of Ikaros isoforms unable to bind DNA and their effects in lymphocyte development suggest that Ikaros works in concert with other factors .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The role of Aiolos , a lymphoid-restricted and structurally related gene , in lymphoid differentiation is discussed .
3,4 G#DNA|6,11 G#DNA

A model is proposed that defines Ikaros as the backbone of a complex regulatory protein network that controls cell fate decisions and regulates homeostasis in the hemo-lymphoid system .
6,7 G#protein|12,16 G#protein

Changes in this regulatory network may reflect differentiation and proliferation adjustments made in hemo-lymphoid progenitors and precursors as they give rise to the cells of our immune system .
13,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type

STAT1 pathway is involved in activation of caprine arthritis-encephalitis virus long terminal repeat in monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|8,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#cell_type

The caprine arthritis-encephalitis virus ( CAEV ) long terminal repeat ( LTR ) is activated by gamma interferon ( IFN-gamma ) in promonocytic cells .
1,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type

We have previously shown that a 70-bp element is necessary and sufficient for the response of the CAEV LTR to this cytokine .
6,8 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

At the 5' end , this 70-bp IFN-gamma response element contains sequence similarity to the gamma activated site ( GAS ) .
2,4 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|6,10 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA

Here we demonstrate that the putative GAS element in the CAEV LTR binds specifically to a cellular factor induced by IFN-gamma in promonocytic cells .
6,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|16,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type

Substitution mutations in this consensus sequence eliminate binding of the inducible factor .
4,6 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein

The GAS element from the 70-bp motif is sufficient to confer responsiveness to IFN-gamma using a heterologous minimal promoter .
1,3 G#DNA|5,7 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein

Consistent with the binding data , the same mutations in the GAS element eliminate responsiveness to IFN-gamma in the context of both a functional CAEV LTR and a heterologous promoter .
11,13 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA

The cellular factor that binds to the GAS element is present from 5 min to 14 h after stimulation with IFN-gamma .
7,9 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

Binding of the nuclear factor to the GAS element in the CAEV LTR is inhibited by antibody directed against STAT1 ( p91/84 ) .
7,9 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Thus , the GAS sequence in the CAEV LTR is essential for the response to IFN-gamma and a STAT1 -like factor binds to this site .
7,9 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

The STAT-1 signaling pathway provides at least one mechanism for activation of the CAEV LTR by IFN-gamma in monocytes .
13,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type

These data are the first demonstration of a role for a STAT family member in the regulation of a viral promoter .
11,14 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

1,25-Dihydroxyvitamin D3 receptors in peripheral blood mononuclear cells from patients with renal insufficiency .
0,3 G#DNA|4,8 G#cell_type

A reduced expression of the vitamin D receptor ( VDR ) in parathyroid glands of uremic animals and humans has been observed .
5,8 G#protein

Similar results have been obtained by our own group in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) from patients with secondary hyperparathyroidism to chronic renal failure .
10,14 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type

However , the reasons for these changes are not clear .


In the present study , we have investigated the specific uptake of [3H]1,25(OH)2D3 by PBMC of 11 women with advanced chronic renal failure ( A-CRF ) , 6 women with mild-moderate renal insufficiency ( M-CRF ) , and 23 healthy women .
14,15 G#cell_type

The mean dissociation constant ( KD ) was similar in both groups of patients and in healthy women ( A-CRF : 0.7 +/- 0.5 x 10(-10) M ; M-CRF : 1.1 +/- 0.9 x 10(-10) M ; controls : 1.0 +/- 0.6 x 10(-10) M ) .


However , VDR concentration was significantly decreased in A-CRF ( 0.8 +/- 0.5 fmol/10(7) cells vs. 2.3 +/- 0.9 fmol/10(7) cells in controls , p &lt; 0.001 ) , whereas no changes were seen in M-CRF ( 1.7 +/- 0.7 fmol/10(7) cells vs. 2.3 +/- 0.9 fmol/10(7) cells in controls ) .
2,3 G#protein

No correlation was seen between VDR and serum calcitriol or PTH levels , when considering both groups of patients together or separately .
5,6 G#protein

Conversely , a significant negative correlation was found between VDR and serum creatinine values when A-CRF and M-CRF were considered altogether ( r = -0.63 ; p &lt; 0.01 ) .
9,10 G#protein

Treatment with two different schedules of oral calcitriol ( five patients with 0.5 microgram/day for 1 month and four patients with 2 micrograms/day for 7 days ) did not change VDR concentrations .
30,31 G#protein

We conclude that the low levels of serum 1,25(OH)2D3 of uremia are not responsible for the decrease in VDR concentration found in these patients .
18,19 G#protein

Transcription factor binding to the core promoter of the human monoamine oxidase B gene in the cerebral cortex and in blood cells .
0,2 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|9,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type

Many studies show that monoamine oxidase B in blood cells is a biological marker for personality characteristics such as sensation seeking .
4,7 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

The mechanism underlying this association is so far not explored .


In the present study we have performed electrophoretic mobility-shift assays to investigate the pattern of protein binding to a 150 bp fragment of the proximal 5'-flanking region of the human monoamine oxidase B gene .
19,22 G#DNA|24,27 G#DNA|30,33 G#protein|29,34 G#DNA

We compared the pattern using nuclear extracts from human brain and lymphocytes .
11,12 G#cell_type

Interestingly , a correlation was observed between monoamine oxidase B enzyme activity in blood cells ( platelets ) and the binding pattern of two uncharacterized transcription factors .
7,10 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein

These data are well in line with the long-standing notion that interindividual differences in platelet monoamine oxidase may represent differences in expression of the enzyme rather than genotypic variation .
14,17 G#protein

Enhanced differentiation of HL-60 leukemia cells to macrophages induced by ciprofibrate .
3,6 G#cell_line|7,8 G#cell_type

Ciprofibrate , an hypolipidaemic peroxisome proliferator , induced differentiation of HL-60 cells .
10,12 G#cell_line

The effect was greatly potentiated by phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate at a concentration where neither phorbol ester nor ciprofibrate alone had any effect on these cells .


As occurs for HL-60 cell differentiation induced by high phorbol ester concentration , the ciprofibrate -induced phorbol ester -dependent differentiation of HL-60 cells proceeded through the monocytic/macrophage pathway and induced the phosphorylation of proteins with similar molecular weights suggesting that increased protein kinase C activity may be involved in the effect .
21,23 G#cell_line|41,44 G#protein

The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor ( PPARalpha ) transcription factor is expressed in HL-60 cells , but no changes were observed in its expression upon HL-60 cell differentiation .
7,9 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line

The involvement of multiple tumor necrosis factor receptor ( TNFR ) -associated factors in the signaling mechanisms of receptor activator of NF-kappaB , a member of the TNFR superfamily .
4,13 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Receptor activator of NF-kappaB ( RANK ) is a recently identified member of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily and is expressed on activated T cells and dendritic cells .
3,4 G#protein|0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,19 G#protein|23,26 G#cell_type|27,29 G#cell_type

Its cognate ligand ( RANKL ) plays significant roles in the activation of dendritic cell function and osteoclast differentiation .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

We demonstrate here the interaction of RANK with tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factors ( TRAFs ) 1 , 2 , 3 , 5 , and 6 both in vitro and in cells .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|8,26 G#protein

Mapping of the structural requirements for TRAF /RANK interaction revealed multiple TRAF binding sites clustered in two distinct domains in the RANK cytoplasmic tail .
6,7 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

These TRAF binding domains were shown to be functionally important for the RANK -dependent induction of NF-kappaB and c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase activities .
1,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Site-directed mutagenesis demonstrated that these TRAF binding sites exhibited selective binding for different TRAF proteins .
5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

In particular , TRAF6 interacted with membrane-proximal determinants distinct from those binding TRAFs 1 , 2 , 3 , and 5 .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|12,21 G#protein

When this membrane-proximal TRAF6 interaction domain was deleted , RANK -mediated NF-kappaB signaling was completely inhibited while c-Jun NH2-terminal kinase activation was partially inhibited .
3,4 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

An NH2-terminal truncation mutant of TRAF6 inhibited RANKL -mediated NF-kappaB activation , but failed to affect constitutive signaling induced by receptor overexpression , revealing a selective role for TRAF6 in ligand-induced activation events .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Stat6 inhibits human interleukin-4 promoter activity in T cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#cell_type

The differentiation of naive T-helper ( Th ) cells into cytokine -secreting effector Th cells requires exposure to multiple signals , including exogenous cytokines .
3,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|10,15 G#cell_type|22,24 G#protein

Interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) plays a major role in this process by promoting the differentiation of IL-4 -secreting Th2 cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In Th2 cells , IL-4 gene expression is tightly controlled at the level of transcription by the coordinated binding of multiple transcription factors to regulatory elements in the proximal promoter region .
4,5 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|29,31 G#DNA

Nuclear factor of activated T cell ( NFAT ) family members play a critical role in regulating IL-4 transcription and interact with up to five sequences ( termed P0 through P4 ) in the IL-4 promoter .
0,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|34,36 G#DNA

The molecular mechanisms by which IL-4 induces expression of the IL-4 gene are not known , although the IL-4 -activated transcription factor signal transducer and activator of transcription 6 ( Stat6 ) is required for this effect .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|18,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

We report here that Stat6 interacts with three binding sites in the human IL-4 promoter by electrophoretic mobility shift assays .
4,5 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA

These sites overlap the P1 , P2 , and P4 NFAT elements .
4,12 G#DNA

To investigate the role of Stat6 in regulating IL-4 transcription , we used Stat6 -deficient Jurkat T cells with different intact IL-4 promoter constructs in cotransfection assays .
5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|21,23 G#DNA|21,24 G#DNA

We show that , whereas a multimerized response element from the germline IgE promoter was highly induced by IL-4 in Stat6 -expressing Jurkat cells , the intact human IL-4 promoter was repressed under similar conditions .
6,9 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_type|28,30 G#DNA|27,30 G#DNA

We conclude that the function of Stat6 is highly dependent on promoter context and that this factor promotes IL-4 gene expression in an indirect manner .
6,7 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Epithelial cell-initiated inflammation plays a crucial role in early tissue damage in amebic infection of human intestine .


BACKGROUND &amp; AIMS : Entamoeba histolytica infection of the intestine can induce severe gut inflammation .


The aims of this study were to assess the role of the host inflammatory response in the tissue damage observed with amebiasis and the role of the intestinal epithelial cell in initiating that response .
27,30 G#cell_type

METHODS : E. histolytica infection was established in human intestinal xenografts in severe combined immunodeficient ( SCID-HU-INT ) mice .


Human intestinal epithelial cell inflammatory responses to amebic infection were inhibited by the intraluminal administration of an antisense oligonucleotide to the human p65 subunit of nuclear factor kappaB , and the role of neutrophils in tissue damage observed with amebiasis was studied by depleting neutrophils from SCID-HU-INT mice .
1,4 G#cell_type|21,24 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|44,45 G#cell_type

RESULTS : Administration of the antisense oligonucleotide blocked the production of human interleukin 1beta and interleukin 8 by intestinal epithelial cells and inhibited neutrophil influx into the E. histolytica -infected intestinal xenografts .
11,14 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type

Inhibition of the gut inflammatory response by the antisense oligonucleotide or the depletion of neutrophils from SCID-HU-Â INT mice blocked the increase in intestinal permeability observed with amebic infection .
14,15 G#cell_type

CONCLUSIONS : Intestinal epithelial cells initiate an inflammatory response with resulting neutrophil-mediated tissue damage in response to E. histolytica infection ; this inflammatory cascade can be blocked by inhibiting the transcription of genes regulated by nuclear factor kappaB .
2,5 G#cell_type|35,38 G#protein

Triptolide induces apoptotic death of T lymphocyte .
5,7 G#cell_type

Extract of Tripterygium wilfordii Hook . f ( TWHf ) has immunosuppressive activity and has been used as anti-inflammatory agent in traditional Chinese medicine for centuries .


Recent studies have demonstrated that triptolide is the major active component in the extract that inhibits antigen or mitogen -induced T cell proliferation .
18,19 G#protein

In attempting to investigate its effect on activation of T lymphocytes , we found triptolide induces apoptotic death of T cell hybridomas and peripheral T cells but not that of thymocytes .
9,11 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_line|23,26 G#cell_type|30,31 G#cell_type

The triptolide -induced apoptosis is accompanied by increase of DEVD-cleavable caspases activity and degradation of caspase substrate poly ( ADP-ribose ) polymerase ( PARP ) .
10,11 G#protein|15,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

A specific inhibitor of caspases , zVAD-FMK , prevents triptolide -induced PARP degradation and DNA fragmentation but not growth arrest .
4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Furthermore , enforced expression of Bcl-2 inhibited triptolide -induced degradation of PARP and apoptosis .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

These results indicate that triptolide induces T cell apoptosis through activating caspases , and suggest the growth arrest and apoptotic effect of triptolide may contribute to the immunosuppressive activity of TWHf extract
11,12 G#protein

A novel transcription factor regulates expression of the vacuolar H+-ATPase B2 subunit through AP-2 sites during monocytic differentiation .
2,4 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA

During monocyte-to-macrophage differentiation , the cellular content of vacuolar H+-ATPase ( V-ATPase ) increases more than 4-fold .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

We have shown previously that amplified expression of the B2 subunit of the V-ATPase occurs solely by increased transcription , and that the 5'-untranslated region of the B2 gene , containing multiple consensus binding sites for the transcription factors AP-2 and Sp1 , is required for this expression .
9,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA|32,35 G#DNA|37,39 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

The present study demonstrates that AP-2 binding sequences are essential for increased transcription from the B2 promoter during monocyte-macrophage differentiation and that AP-2 , expressed exogenously in THP-1 and other cells , activates transcription from the B2 promoter .
5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#cell_line|36,38 G#DNA

In mobility shift assays , a nuclear factor from THP-1 and U-937 cells was identified that binds to several AP-2 response elements within the B2 promoter , but does not react with AP-2 antibodies , and has a DNA sequence binding affinity profile that differs from AP-2 .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_line|11,13 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|38,40 G#DNA|46,47 G#protein

These findings suggest that a novel AP-2 -like transcription factor is responsible for V-ATPase B subunit amplification during monocyte differentiation .
6,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

c-Jun and GST-pi expression in human plasma cells .
5,8 G#cell_type

Bone marrow samples from 33 patients affected by MM and MGUS , and 8 patients not affected by lymphoproliferative diseases were studied for expression of c-Jun ( a component of the transcription factor AP-1 ) and glutathione-S-transferase pi ( GST-pi ) using immunocytochemical methods .
25,26 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

A high and frequent expression of these two proteins was found both in MM and MGUS patients ( 31/33 patients positive for c-Jun and 29/33 patients positive for GST-pi ) and in controls not affected by monoclonal gammopathy ( 7/8 patients positive for both c-Jun and GST-pi ) .
22,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

No statistically significant correlation was found between c-Jun- and GST-pi- positive plasma cells .
7,13 G#cell_line

The expression of these two proteins was not related to clinical or laboratory data .


Our results seem to confirm a possible role of the transcriptional complex AP-1 in activating GST-pi promoter in human plasma cells .
10,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|18,21 G#cell_type

Activation of signaling pathways and prevention of apoptosis by cytokines in eosinophils .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type

Inhibition of apoptosis in eosinophils by cytokines such as IL-5 and GM-CSF may play an important role in the pathogenesis of allergic and parasitic disorders .
4,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Recently , there has been some progress in the understanding of the signal transduction pathways activated by these cytokines in eosinophils .
18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type

The IL-3 , IL-5 and GM-CSF receptors share a common signal transducer that possesses no intrinsic kinase domain .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

It has been shown that eosinophil stimulation by these cytokines is associated with increases in tyrosine phosphorylation of several cellular substrates .
9,10 G#protein

In the past few years , there has been some progress in defining the tyrosine kinases that are activated by the IL-3 / IL-5 / GM-CSF receptor beta-subunit in eosinophils .
21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|21,28 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

This review will concentrate on this topic and on its role for the regulation of eosinophil apoptosis .


Requirement of GATA-1 and p45 NF-E2 expression in butyric acid -induced erythroid differentiation .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein

Butyric acid ( BA ) is known to induce overexpression of fetal hemoglobin and then erythroid differentiation .
11,13 G#protein

Therefore , BA is currently under clinical investigation as a potential therapy for the treatment of sickle cell disease and cancer .


Nevertheless , the molecular mechanisms involved in BA -induced differentiation remain largely unknown .


Previous reports have shown that BA -induced overexpression of erythroid genes occurred at the transcriptional level , suggesting the involvement of erythroid transcription factors .
9,11 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Here , we intend to demonstrate the requirement of GATA-1 and NF-E2 transcription factors in the BA -induced erythroid differentiation of human leukemic K562 cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_line

Time-course experiments showed that nuclear levels of GATA-1 and p45 NF-E2 proteins increased during BA treatment .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

Moreover , antisense oligodeoxynucleotides targeting either GATA-1 or p45 NF-E2 proteins inhibited both protein expression and BA -induced differentiation .
6,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

In contrast , BA -induced cell growth inhibition was not affected .


These results provide the first direct evidence for the requirement of GATA-1 and NF-E2 in BA -induced differentiation process .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Characterisation of regulatory sequences at the Epstein-Barr virus BamHI W promoter .
6,11 G#DNA

Epstein-Barr virus , a human gammaherpesvirus , possesses a unique set of latent genes whose constitutive expression in B cells leads to cell growth transformation .
12,14 G#DNA|18,20 G#cell_type

The initiation of this growth transforming infection depends on a viral promoter in BamHI W ( Wp ) whose regulation is poorly understood .
10,12 G#DNA

Using Wp reporter constructs in in vitro transfection assays , we found that Wp was 11- to 190-fold more active in B cell than in non-B cell lines and that three regions of the promoter ( termed UAS1 , UAS2 , and UAS3 ) contributed to transcriptional activation .
1,4 G#DNA|21,23 G#cell_line|25,28 G#cell_line|34,35 G#DNA|37,38 G#DNA|39,40 G#DNA|42,43 G#DNA

The upstream regions UAS3 ( -1168 to -440 ) and UAS2 ( -352 to -264 ) both functioned in a cell lineage-independent manner and were together responsible for the bulk of Wp activity in non-B cells ; mutational analysis indicated the importance of a YY1 binding site in UAS2 in that context .
3,4 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|34,36 G#cell_type|44,47 G#DNA|48,49 G#DNA

By contrast , UAS1 ( -140 to -87 ) was B cell specific and was the key determinant of the promoter 's increased activity in B cell lines .
3,4 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|25,28 G#cell_line

Mutational analysis of UAS1 sequences combined with in vitro bandshift assays revealed the presence of three binding sites for cellular factors in this region .
3,4 G#DNA|3,5 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein

When mutations that abolished factor binding in bandshift assays were introduced into a Wp reporter construct , the loss of any one of the three UAS1 binding sites was sufficient to reduce promoter activity by 10- to 30-fold in B cells .
13,16 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|39,41 G#cell_type

From sequence analysis , two of these appear to be novel transcription factor binding sites , whereas the third was identified as a cyclic AMP response element ( CRE ) .
11,13 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|23,27 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA

Our data indicate that this CRE interacts with CREB and ATF1 proteins present in B cell nuclear extracts and that this interaction is important for Wp activity .
5,6 G#DNA|8,12 G#protein

In situ RT-PCR detection of Epstein-Barr virus immediate-early transcripts in CD4+ and CD8+ T lymphocytes .
5,9 G#RNA|10,15 G#cell_type

AIDS -related Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) -associated T cell lymphomas are emerging as a new , distinct histopathological entity .


The pathway whereby EBV infects T cells as well as the initial EBV transcriptional program in T cells has not been established .
5,7 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type

In order to shed light on the early events of the EBV infection of T cells , we have used in situ reverse transcription based polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) to study the initial EBV transcriptional program in homogeneous CD4+ and CD8+ lymphocytes .
14,16 G#cell_type|39,44 G#cell_type

Following EBV infection , Epstein-Barr nuclear antigen ( EBNA ) expression could be detected in T rosetting CD4+ and CD8+ T lymphocytes .
8,9 G#protein|15,22 G#cell_type

Only a few cells showed viral capsid antigen ( VCA ) .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

EBV immediate-early gene transcripts ( BZLF1 , BRLF1 , and BMLF1 ) encoded in the BamHI Z , R , and M fragments could be detected by in situ RT-PCR in the EBV producer cell line B95.8 .
0,4 G#RNA|5,6 G#RNA|7,8 G#RNA|10,11 G#RNA

Both BZLF1 and BRLF1 immediate-early transcripts , but not BMLF1 transcript , could be detected in individual CD4+ and CD8+ T cells infected with EBV .
1,6 G#RNA|9,10 G#RNA|9,11 G#RNA|17,22 G#cell_type

Demonstration of EBV mRNA transcripts encoding immediate-early transcriptional transactivators in EBV -infected T cells provides the first evidence for a possible mechanism whereby EBV could contribute to T cell proliferation and EBV -associated T cell malignancies .
2,5 G#RNA|6,9 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|10,14 G#cell_type

The linkage between T-cell and dendritic cell development in the mouse thymus .


Thymic dendritic cells ( DC ) mediate negative selection at a relatively late stage of the T-cell developmental pathway .
0,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#cell_type

We present evidence that the development of thymic DC and of T-lineage cells is linked via a common precursor at an early stage of thymocyte development .
7,9 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type

T-lineage precursor populations from the adult mouse thymus , prior to T-cell receptor gene rearrangement , display a capacity to produce DC as well as T cells in the thymus , and are very efficient precursors of DC in culture .
21,22 G#cell_type|25,27 G#cell_type|37,38 G#cell_type

These lymphoid/ DC precursors have little capacity to form myeloid cells , indicating that thymic DC are a lymphoid-related rather than myeloid-related lineage .
2,3 G#cell_type|1,4 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

In contrast to myeloid-related DC , granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor is not required for the development of these lymphoid-related DC in vivo or in vitro .
4,5 G#cell_type|3,5 G#cell_type|6,9 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

DC can develop in mutant mice lacking mature T cells , provided the common precursors are present .
0,1 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|7,10 G#cell_type

However , in mutant mice lacking functional Ikaros transcription factors , there are deficiencies in lymphoid precursor cells , in mature lymphoid cells and in DC .
7,8 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|15,18 G#cell_type|20,23 G#cell_type|25,26 G#cell_type

Host control of HIV-1 parasitism in T cells by the nuclear factor of activated T cells .
6,8 G#cell_type|10,16 G#protein

Post HIV-1 entry , productive HIV-1 infection of primary T cells requires overcoming several cellular blocks to provirus establishment and replication .
9,11 G#cell_type|8,11 G#cell_type

Activation of unknown host intracellular events overcomes such inhibitory steps and is concomitant with HIV-1 replication .


We show that the transcription factor NFATc was sufficient as a cellular factor to induce a highly permissive state for HIV-1 replication in primary CD4+ T cells .
4,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|23,27 G#cell_type

NFATc overcame a blockade at reverse transcription and permitted active HIV-1 replication .
0,1 G#protein

Pharmacologic blockade of endogenous NFAT activity by FK506 or CsA inhibited synthesis of reverse transcription and also potently blocked HIV-1 replication .
3,5 G#protein

T cells therefore can become competent for HIV-1 replication by control of regulated host factors such as the NFATc transcription factor .
0,2 G#cell_type|12,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

The host mechanisms regulated by such permissivity factors are potential targets for anti- HIV-1 therapy .


Regulation of NF-kappa B , AP-1 , NFAT , and STAT1 nuclear import in T lymphocytes by noninvasive delivery of peptide carrying the nuclear localization sequence of NF-kappa B p50 .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|23,26 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|27,30 G#protein

Activation of T lymphocytes by Ags or cytokines results in translocation of the transcription factors NF-kappa B , AP-1 , NFAT , and STAT from the cytoplasm into the nucleus .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

The first step in the nuclear import process is recognition of a nuclear localization sequence ( NLS ) within the karyophilic protein by a cytoplasmic receptor such as the importin ( karyopherin ) -alpha subunit .
12,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|29,35 G#protein

The NLSs of NF-kappa B , AP-1 , and NFAT differ and the NLS of STAT1 has not yet been identified .
1,2 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Herein we demonstrate that the inducible nuclear import of NF-kappa B , AP-1 , NFAT , and STAT1 in Jurkat T lymphocytes is significantly inhibited by a cell-permeable peptide carrying the NLS of the NF-kappa B p50 subunit .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_line|31,32 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|34,38 G#protein

NLS peptide-mediated disruption of the nuclear import of these transcription factors results in inhibition of I kappa B alpha and IL-2 gene expression , processes dependent on NF-kappa B or the combination of NF-kappa B , AP-1 , and NFAT .
0,1 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Further , we show that inhibitory NLS peptide interacts in vitro with a cytoplasmic NLS receptor complex comprised of the Rch1/importin ( karyopherin ) -beta heterodimer expressed in Jurkat T cells .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|20,26 G#protein|28,31 G#cell_line

Taken together , these data indicate that the inducible nuclear import of NF-kappa B , AP-1 , NFAT , and STAT1 in Jurkat T cells can be regulated by NLS peptide delivered noninvasively to the cytoplasm of Jurkat T cells to target members of the importin ( karyopherin ) -alpha beta NLS receptor complex .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_line|29,30 G#protein|37,40 G#cell_line|45,51 G#protein|51,52 G#protein|51,54 G#protein

Membrane-associated lymphotoxin on natural killer cells activates endothelial cells via an NF-kappaB -dependent pathway .
0,2 G#protein|3,6 G#cell_type|7,9 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Inhibition of complement in small animal models of xenotransplantation has demonstrated graft infiltration with natural killer ( NK ) cells and monocytes associated with endothelial cell ( EC ) activation .
16,22 G#cell_type|26,28 G#cell_type|29,30 G#cell_type

We have previously demonstrated that human NK cells activate porcine EC in vitro , which results in adhesion molecule expression and cytokine secretion .
5,8 G#cell_type|10,11 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

In this study , we used the NK cell line NK92 to define the molecular and cellular basis of NK cell-mediated EC activation .
7,11 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_type

METHODS : EC were transfected with either reporter constructs containing the luciferase gene driven either by E-selectin or interleukin ( IL ) -8 promoters or a synthetic NF-kappaB -dependent promoter .
2,3 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|16,24 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#DNA

In addition , a dominant-negative mutant tumor necrosis factor receptor I ( TNFRI ) expression vector was co-transfected in inhibition studies .
4,16 G#DNA

Forty-eight hours after transfection , EC were stimulated with NK cells or NK cell membrane extracts for 7 hr and activation was measured by a luciferase assay .
5,6 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|12,16 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

RESULTS : Co-culture of NK cells with transfected EC enhanced E-selectin , IL-8 , and NF-kappaB -dependent promoter activity .
4,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

NK cell membrane extracts retained the capacity to activate EC and induced nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB ( p50 and p65 ) .
9,10 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Western blotting of NK cell and membrane extracts detected the presence of Lymphotoxin-alpha ( LTalpha ) but not tumor necrosis factor-alpha .
3,5 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

Furthermore , LTalpha was secreted in NK: EC co- cultures .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_type|6,10 G#cell_line

Co-transfection with dominant-negative mutant TNFRI inhibited EC activation by NK cell membrane extracts and by NK cells by 80 % and 47 % , respectively .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type

The same pattern of inhibition was observed using anti-human LT sera .


CONCLUSIONS : Human NK cell membrane-bound LT signals across species via TNFRI , leading to NF-kappaB nuclear translocation and transcription of E-selectin and IL-8 , which results in EC activation .
11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type

The discrepancy in the degree of inhibition by membrane extracts and NK cells with mutant TNFRI suggests that additional pathways are utilized by NK cells to activate EC
11,13 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|27,28 G#cell_type

Ras -dependent , Ca2+ -stimulated activation of nuclear factor of activated T cells by a constitutively active Cbl mutant in T cells .
0,1 G#protein|7,13 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,22 G#cell_type

T cell receptor ( TCR ) stimulation induces rapid tyrosine phosphorylation of cellular proteins , including Cbl , a protooncogene product whose function remains unclear .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

As a first step toward elucidating the function of Cbl in TCR -initiated signaling , we evaluated the ability of wild-type Cbl or a transforming Cbl mutant ( 70Z/3 ) to induce transcriptional activation of a nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) element derived from the interleukin 2 ( IL2 ) promoter in transiently cotransfected Jurkat-TAg T cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|40,42 G#cell_type|36,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|36,46 G#DNA|49,51 G#protein|52,53 G#protein|49,55 G#DNA|59,61 G#cell_type|58,61 G#cell_line

70Z/3 , but not Cbl , caused NFAT activation which was significantly enhanced by stimulation with calcium ionophore , and was drastically reduced by cyclosporin A pretreatment .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

A point mutation of a potential phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase ( PI3-K ) binding site ( Y731EAM to Y731EAC ) in 70Z/3 disrupted the association of PI3-K with 70Z/3 , but did not reduce the induction of NFAT activity , suggesting that the interaction between Cbl and PI3-K is not required in the 70Z/3 -mediated induction of NFAT .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|6,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|51,52 G#protein|55,56 G#protein

Additional mapping studies indicated that defined deletions of C-terminal 70Z/3 sequences affected to a variable degree its ability to stimulate NFAT activity .
9,10 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Strikingly , deletion of 346 C-terminal residues augmented this activity , whereas removal of 20 additional residues abolished it .
4,7 G#protein

Coexpression of dominant negative Ras abrogated the basal or ionomycin-stimulated , 70Z/3 -mediated NFAT activation , suggesting a functional Ras is required for this activation .
2,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

These results implicate Cbl in Ras -dependent signaling pathways which lead to NFAT activation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Requirement of prestimulated THP-1 monocytic cells for endothelial cell activation .
2,6 G#cell_line|7,9 G#cell_type

Involvement of TNF alpha .


Blood monocytes spontaneously activate endothelial cells in culture , leading to adhesion of monocytic cells onto the endothelial surface and overproduction of endothelial proteins such as von Willebrand factor ( vWf ) and plasminogen activator inhibitor type 1 ( PAI-1 ) .
0,2 G#cell_type|4,6 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type|26,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

To overcome the difficulty in obtaining quiescent monocytes , we studied the ability of promonocytic THP-1 cells to activate endothelial cells .
6,8 G#cell_type|14,17 G#cell_line|19,21 G#cell_type

Lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) -prestimulated and untreated THP-1 cells were cocultured with resting human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVEC ) for 3 and 24 h in the presence of colimycin to neutralize LPS traces .
7,9 G#cell_line|16,18 G#cell_type|12,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

Addition of untreated THP-1 cells had little effect on HUVEC adhesiveness .
3,5 G#cell_line|9,10 G#cell_type

Addition of prestimulated THP-1 cells was followed by a noticeable adhesion after 3 h which reversed to basal values within 24 h .
3,5 G#cell_line

Under these conditions HUVEC adhesion molecules , E-selectin , VCAM-1 and ICAM-1 , were increased at 3 h with only ICAM-1 remaining overexpressed at 24 h .
3,4 G#cell_type|3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Diffusible endothelial proteins such as soluble E-selectin , PAI-1 and vWf to a minimal extent , increased in supernatants from HUVEC cocultured for 24 h with prestimulated THP-1 cells .
1,3 G#protein|0,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|27,29 G#cell_line

In those cocultures , TNF alpha concentrations peaked at 3 h whereas IL-1 beta levels progressively rose until 24 h .
4,6 G#protein

Addition of an anti- TNF alpha antibody decreased by 40 % E-selectin and ICAM-1 induction and suppressed PAI-1 overproduction with a weak effect on vWf .
4,6 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

An anti-IL-1 beta antibody had negligible effects on HUVEC adhesion molecules , PAI-1 or vWf production .
1,4 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

These results provide evidence that promonocytic THP-1 cells require prestimulation in order to activate HUVEC and that TNF alpha contributes to this phenomenon .
5,8 G#cell_line|14,15 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein

Engagement of the Lewis X antigen ( CD15 ) results in monocyte activation .


We previously reported that monocyte adhesion to tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) -treated endothelial cells increased expression of tissue factor and CD36 on monocytes .
11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|7,16 G#cell_line|22,23 G#protein

Using immunological cross-linking to mimic receptor engagement by natural ligands , we now show that CD15 ( Lewis X ) , a monocyte counter-receptor for endothelial selectins may participate in this response .
22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

We used cytokine production as a readout for monocyte activation and found that CD15 cross-linking induced TNF-alpha release from peripheral blood monocytes and cells from the monocytic cell line MM6 .
16,17 G#protein|19,22 G#cell_type|26,30 G#cell_line

Quantitative reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) showed an increase in steady-state TNF-alpha mRNA after 3 to 4 hours of cross-linking .
1,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA

CD15 cross-linking also concomitantly increased interleukin-1 beta ( IL-1 beta ) mRNA , while no apparent change was observed in the levels of beta-actin mRNA , indicating specificity .
5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|5,12 G#RNA|23,25 G#RNA

To examine transcriptional regulation of cytokine genes by CD15 engagement , a CAT plasmid reporter construct containing IL-1 beta promoter/enhancer sequences was introduced into MM6 .
5,7 G#DNA|17,19 G#protein|17,21 G#DNA|24,25 G#cell_line

Subsequent cross-linking of CD15 increased CAT activity .
5,6 G#protein

CD15 engagement by monoclonal antibody also attenuated IL-1 beta transcript degradation , demonstrating that signaling via CD15 also had posttranscriptional effects .
3,5 G#protein|7,9 G#protein

Nuclear extracts of anti- CD15 cross-linked cells demonstrated enhanced levels of the transcriptional factor activator protein-1 , minimally changed nuclear factor-kappa B , and did not affect SV40 promoter specific protein-1 .
4,7 G#cell_type|12,16 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|27,31 G#protein

We conclude that engagement of CD15 on monocytes results in monocyte activation .


In addition to its well-recognized adhesive role , CD15 may function as an important signaling molecule capable of initiating proinflammatory events in monocytes that come into contact with activated endothelium .
22,23 G#cell_type

CD2 signalling induces phosphorylation of CREB in primary lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Promoter sequences responsive to cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) are found in a number of cellular genes , and bind transcription factors of the cAMP response element binding protein ( CREB ) / activating transcription factor-1 ( ATF-1 ) family .
15,17 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein|24,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|30,40 G#protein

We have used a human T-lymphotropic virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) model of cAMP response element ( CRE ) transcription to investigate the influence of lymphocyte activation on transcription from homologous regions in the viral promoter .
14,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA|35,37 G#DNA

We previously demonstrated increased HTLV-1 transcription following CD2 but not CD3 receptor cross-linking .


We hypothesized that this increased viral transcription was mediated , in part , through the phosphorylation of CREB .
17,18 G#protein

Therefore , we investigated CD2 and CD3 receptor -mediated signalling in primary human peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,17 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type

CD2 , but not CD3 , cross-linking increased cAMP detected by competitive enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay ( ELISA ) approximately fourfold .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

CD2 cross-linking concurrently increased phosphorylation of CREB detected by immunoblot assay eightfold .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Consistent with post-translational regulation , no change in total level of CREB protein was observed .
11,12 G#protein

Phosphorylation of CREB occurred through a herbimycin A and Rp-cAMP- sensitive pathway , suggesting phosphorylation required antecedent activation of both protein tyrosine kinases ( PTK ) and protein kinase A ( PKA ) .
2,3 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Both CD2 and CD3 cross-linking increased binding of nuclear proteins to a radiolabelled CRE oligonucleotide probe in electrophoretic mobility shift assays suggesting that lymphocyte activation enhances binding independently of phosphorylation of CREB at serine 133 .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

These data indicate specific modulation of the CREB /ATF-1 family of transcription factors by the CD2 signalling pathway and suggest CD2 receptor modulation of CRE -mediated transcription following ligand engagement ( e.g. cell-to-cell contact ) .
7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#DNA

X-rays -induced secretion of cellular factor ( s ) that enhance ( s ) HIV-1 promoter transcription in various non-irradiated transfected cell lines .
4,6 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|19,23 G#cell_line

Various cellular stress agents like ionizing radiation exposure could activate human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-Â 1 ) replication or reporter gene expression .
20,22 G#DNA

In addition , extracellular factor ( s ) released by X-ray-treated human colonic carcinoma cell line ( HT29 ) might activate the long terminal repeat ( LTR ) of HIV-1 in non-irradiated HT29 cells .
3,5 G#protein|10,16 G#cell_line|17,18 G#cell_line|22,25 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|31,34 G#cell_line

In the present report we show that in various transiently or stably transfected cell lines , X-ray irradiation up-regulates HIV-1 LTR transcription through the kappaB regulatory elements .
11,15 G#cell_line|19,21 G#DNA|24,27 G#protein

A factor ( s ) , which is processed by and acts upon a variety of cell types , was detected by addition to non-irradiated cells of either X-ray -treated cells or a conditioned medium taken from irradiated cultures .
24,26 G#cell_type|28,31 G#cell_line|37,39 G#cell_line

The magnitude of responsiveness is cell type dependent .


In addition , X-ray activation of HIV-1 LTR in transiently or stably transfected cell lines is inhibited by a potent antioxidant drug , pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate and by another drug , known for its role in the trapping of growth factors , suramin .
6,8 G#DNA|13,15 G#cell_line|38,40 G#protein

The importance of these observations in the pathophysiology of patients with AIDS-related cancers treated by radiotherapy remains to be established .


Activation of the human delta-globin gene promoter in primary adult erythroid cells .
3,7 G#DNA|8,12 G#cell_type

Restoration of the CCAAT box or insertion of an erythroid Kruppel-like factor ( EKLF ) binding site in the delta promoter activates its expression in several erythroid cell lines .
3,5 G#DNA|9,17 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|26,29 G#cell_line

We extended these studies using a novel primary human adult erythroid cell ( hAEC ) system to investigate these effects at the late erythroblast stage .
7,12 G#cell_line|13,14 G#cell_line|7,16 G#cell_line|22,25 G#cell_type

Restoration of the CCAAT box at -70 bp , or insertion of an EKLF binding site at -85 bp or -95 bp in the promoter significantly increased delta globin gene expression in hAEC .
3,5 G#DNA|6,8 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|24,25 G#DNA

Our results demonstrate that the altered CCAAT box ( CCAAC ) and the lack of an EKLF binding site in delta-globin contribute to its low level of expression in the hAEC model as well .
6,8 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_line

Constitutive association of JAK1 and STAT5 in pro-B cells is dissolved by interleukin-4 -induced tyrosine phosphorylation of both proteins .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein

The bipartite human interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) receptor was functionally expressed in murine pro-B cells and activated by human IL-4 to evoke intracellular signaling .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|1,8 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|12,15 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Mutual association of signal transducing proteins within the receptor complex was then studied in dependence of ligand stimulation .
3,6 G#protein

Besides ligand-induced receptor heterodimerization and contacts of the two IL-4 receptor subunits alpha and gamma with Janus kinases JAK1 and JAK3 a prominent constitutive binding between JAK1 and signal transducer and activator of transcription STAT5 was detected .
9,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,34 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

Since both these proteins become phosphorylated in response to IL-4 receptor stimulation , the influence of tyrosine phosphorylation on their mutual contact was analyzed .
9,11 G#protein

Association of JAK1 and STAT5 was found to occur exclusively between unphosphorylated proteins .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

Activation of human macrophages by mechanical ventilation in vitro .
2,4 G#cell_type

Positive-pressure mechanical ventilation supports gas exchange in patients with respiratory failure but is also responsible for significant lung injury .


In this study , we have developed an in vitro model in which isolated lung cells can be submitted to a prolonged cyclic pressure-stretching strain resembling that of conventional mechanical ventilation .
14,16 G#cell_type|21,25 G#cell_line

In this model , cells cultured on a Silastic membrane were elongated up to 7 % of their initial diameter , corresponding to a 12 % increase in cell surface .


The lung macrophage was identified as the main cellular source for critical inflammatory mediators such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha , the chemokines interleukin ( IL ) -8 and -6 , and matrix metalloproteinase-9 in this model system of mechanical ventilation .
1,3 G#cell_type|12,14 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|22,29 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

These mediators were measured in supernatants from ventilated alveolar macrophages , monocyte-derived macrophages , and promonocytic THP-1 cells .
7,10 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_line

Nuclear factor-kappaB was found to be activated in ventilated macrophages .
0,2 G#protein|8,10 G#cell_type

Synergistic proinflammatory effects of mechanical stress and molecules such as bacterial endotoxin were observed , suggesting that mechanical ventilation might be particularly deleterious in preinjured or infected lungs .
10,12 G#protein

Dexamethasone prevented IL-8 and tumor necrosis factor-alpha secretion in ventilated macrophages .
2,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

Mechanical ventilation induced low levels of IL-8 secretion by alveolar type II-like cells .
6,7 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type

Other lung cell types such as endothelial cells , bronchial cells , and fibroblasts failed to produce IL-8 in response to a prolonged cyclic pressure-stretching load .
6,8 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

This model is of particular value for exploring physical stress-induced signaling pathways , as well as for testing the effects of novel ventilatory strategies or adjunctive substances aimed at modulating cell activation induced by mechanical ventilation .


Signaling pathways mediated by the TNF- and cytokine- receptor families target a common cis-element of the IFN regulatory factor 1 promoter .
5,9 G#protein|13,14 G#DNA|16,21 G#DNA

CD40 activation of B cells is strongly influenced by the presence of cytokines .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein

However , the molecular basis for the interplay between these distinct stimuli is not clearly delineated .


IFN regulatory factor 1 ( IRF-1 ) is a transcription factor activated by either CD40 or cytokines .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

We have found that these different sets of signals target a common cis-acting element in the promoter of this gene , the IRF-1 gamma -activated site ( GAS ) .
22,23 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|22,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA

Targeting of the IRF-1 GAS is not confined to activation via CD40 but extends to other stimuli that mimic the CD40 signaling cascade , like TNF-alpha and EBV .
3,5 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

In contrast to induction of STATs by cytokines , the IRF-1 GAS -binding complex activated by CD40 , TNF-alpha , or EBV contains Rel proteins , specifically p50 and p65 .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

In this system , simultaneous exposure to CD40L together with either IL-4 or IFN-gamma does not lead to the activation of novel Rel/STAT complexes .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Given the importance of IRF-1 in a variety of biologic functions from proliferation to apoptosis , our findings support the notion that modulation of IRF-1 levels may be a critical control point in B cell activation .
4,5 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Differential effects of protein kinase C inhibitors on fibronectin -induced interleukin-beta gene transcription , protein synthesis and secretion in human monocytic cells .
3,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type|19,22 G#cell_type

Human monocytic cells express interleukin-1beta ( IL-1beta ) when stimulated with the extracellular matrix glycoprotein , fibronectin ( FN ) .
0,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Protein kinase C ( PKC ) activation is considered important for this process ; however , the metabolic steps at which PKC acts upon to mediate the FN -induced IL-1beta response remain unclear .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

We performed an analysis of the mechanisms by which two PKC inhibitors , Calphostin C and Staurosporine , prevent the FN -induced IL-1beta response .
10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Both inhibitors blocked the secretion of IL-1beta protein into the media of peripheral blood mononuclear cells exposed to FN .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Immunoprecipitation analysis revealed that unde3r these circumstances , Calphostin C inhibited the production of IL-1beta protein , whereas Staurosporine allowed protein production , but inhibited its secretion .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

To determine the mechanisms responsible for these differences , we turned to human U937 promonocytic cells .
12,16 G#cell_line

U937 cells transfected with the human full-length IL-1beta promoter connected to a luciferase reporter gene were submitted to transcription assays , Northern blotting , and DNA electrophoresis mobility gel shift assays .
7,8 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|12,15 G#DNA

These studies revealed that Calphostin C inhibited the nuclear translocation of the transcription factor activator protein-1 ( AP-1 ) which is considered necessary for FN induction of IL-1beta gene transcription , and prevented the transcription of the IL-1beta gene .
12,14 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#DNA

In contrast , Staurosporine alone induced AP-1 translocation and stimulation of the gene .
6,7 G#protein

Overall , our data indicate that Calphostin C prevents the transcription of the IL-1beta gene thereby inhibiting protein synthesis .
13,15 G#DNA

Based on the high specificity of this compound for PKC , we conclude that PKC is necessary for FN -induced IL-1beta protein production .
9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

In contrast , Staurosporine prevented secretion of IL-1beta by unknown mechanisms
7,8 G#protein

The carboxyl-terminal cytoplasmic domain of CD36 is required for oxidized low-density lipoprotein modulation of NF-kappaB activity by tumor necrosis factor-alpha .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

The binding of oxidized low-density lipoprotein ( Ox LDL ) by monocyte -macrophages causes pleiotropic effects , including changes in gene expression , and is thought to represent an early event in atherogenesis .
11,12 G#cell_type|12,13 G#cell_type

The integral membrane glycoprotein CD36 appears to play a physiological role in binding and uptake of Ox LDL by monocyte- macrophages , although the molecular events associated with CD36 -Ox LDL interaction are unknown .
4,5 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

To approach this issue , we used CD36 transfected Chinese hampster ovary ( CHO ) cells , exposed them to Ox LDL , and determined changes in the activity of the transcription factor NF-kappaB .
7,8 G#protein|9,16 G#cell_type|31,33 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

We report here that Ox LDL enhanced DNA binding activity of nuclear extracts to an NF-kappaB sequence following activation of CD36 -producing CHO cells with the proinflammatory cytokine tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) .
15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,24 G#cell_line|26,28 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

This enhanced DNA binding activity was inhibited by coincubation of CD36 transfected cells with the human CD36 -specific antibody OKM5 .
10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|15,19 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

We also determined that activation of NF-kappaB DNA binding activity required an intact carboxyl-terminal cytoplasmic segment on CD36 .
6,7 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Our results support the idea that human CD36 mediates signal transduction events in response to Ox LDL .

TRAMP , a novel apoptosis-mediating receptor with sequence homology to tumor necrosis factor receptor 1 and Fas ( Apo-1/CD95 ) .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|10,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

A novel member of the tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) receptor family , designated TRAMP , has been identified .
5,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

The structural organization of the 393 amino acid long human TRAMP is most homologous to TNF receptor 1 .
10,11 G#protein|5,11 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

TRAMP is abundantly expressed on thymocytes and lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#cell_type

Its extracellular domain is composed of four cysteine-rich domains , and the cytoplasmic region contains a death domain known to signal apoptosis .
7,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein

Overexpression of TRAMP leads to two major responses , NF-kappaB activation and apoptosis .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

TRAMP -induced cell death is inhibited by an inhibitor of ICE-like proteases , but not by Bcl-2 .
0,1 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In addition , TRAMP does not appear to interact with any of the known apoptosis -inducing ligands of the TNF family .
3,4 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

The state of maturation of monocytes into macrophages determines the effects of IL-4 and IL-13 on HIV replication .
5,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

The molecular mechanisms of the effects of IL-4 and IL-13 on HIV infection in human monocytes as they matured into monocyte-derived macrophages over 7 days were investigated using HIV-1 ( BaL ) , and low passage clinical strains .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type

IL-4 and IL-13 up-regulated the expression of both genomic and spliced HIV mRNA in monocytes cultured on Teflon , as determined by Northern analysis and p24 Ag assay .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|11,13 G#RNA|14,15 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein

Using a nuclear run-on assay , IL-4 stimulation was shown to enhance transcription by two- to threefold .
6,7 G#protein

IL-4 stimulated nuclear factor-kappaB nuclear translocation and binding before enhancement of HIV RNA expression .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|11,13 G#RNA

Conversely , IL-4 and IL-13 markedly and significantly inhibited HIV replication at the transcriptional level in monocyte-derived macrophages , and this occurred whether these cytokines were added before or after HIV infection .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein

The reversal from stimulation to inhibition occurred after 3 to 5 days of adherence to plastic .


IL-4 had no significant effect on HIV reverse transcription .
0,1 G#protein

The effect of both cytokines on the monocyte maturation/differentiation ( CD11b , CD13 , and CD26 ) and other macrophage markers ( CD14 and CD68 ) was examined .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

IL-4 enhanced CD11b , but inhibited CD26 expression and delayed CD13 loss .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

IL-13 had similar effects on CD11b and CD13 , but no effect on CD26 .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Hence , these cytokines do not simply enhance monocyte differentiation , but have complex and slightly divergent effects that impact on HIV replication probably through cell signaling pathways and nuclear factor-kappaB translocation .

Mice lacking the transcription factor CIITA -- a second look .
3,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

We have generated a second line of mice lacking a transcription factor thought to be a critical regulator of MHC class II gene expression , CIITA ( for class II transactivator ) .
10,12 G#protein|19,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Our and the previously published lines differ in the deletion that was engineered and by the fact that we removed the neomycin-resistance promoter and structural gene via the cre-loxP recombination system .
21,23 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA

Characterization of our line led to two new findings .


First , a substantial number of cells can express class II molecules in the absence of CIITA , albeit at 5-fold reduced levels , most notably dendritic cells in s.c. lymph nodes ; therefore , the CIITA gene can not be an absolute ' master gene ' controlling the expression of class II molecules , as had been thought .
9,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein|36,38 G#DNA|44,46 G#DNA|51,54 G#protein

Second , in contrast to recent results on human cell lines , CIITA is not critically involved in the IFN-gamma -induced up-regulation of MHC class I genes .
8,11 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,27 G#DNA

Interleukin-10 stabilizes inhibitory kappaB-alpha in human monocytes .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type

Interleukin-10 ( IL-10 ) protects animals from lethal endotoxemia .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein

This beneficial effect is mediated , in part , by inhibition of inflammatory cytokine production , including tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) .
12,14 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Evidence suggests that IL-10 may inhibit activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) through an unknown mechanism .
3,4 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

NF-kappaB activation in response to inflammatory signals is dependent upon degradation of its associated inhibitory peptide , inhibitory kappaB-alpha ( IkappaB-alpha ) .
0,1 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

We hypothesized that IL-10 prevents human monocyte NF-kappaB activation and resultant TNF-alpha production by stabilization of IkappaB-alpha .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

The purpose of this study was to determine the effect of IL-10 on lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) -induced human monocyte TNF-alpha production , NF-kappaB activation , and IkappaB-alpha degradation .
11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Monocytes were isolated from human donors .


Cells were stimulated with endotoxin ( LPS , 100 ng/mL ) with and without human IL-10 ( 10 ng/mL ) .
4,5 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Following stimulation , TNF-alpha was measured in cell supernatants by ELISA , NF-kappaB activity by electrophoretic mobility shift assay , and IkappaB-alpha levels by Western blot .
3,4 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

We observed that after LPS stimulation of human monocytes , TNF-alpha increased to 798+/-67 pg/mL ( p &lt; .001 versus control ) .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,11 G#protein

IL-10 attenuated LPS -stimulated TNF-alpha production ( 297+/-54 ; p &lt; .001 versus LPS alone ) .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

After LPS stimulation in human monocytes , IkappaB-alpha protein levels decreased , and NF-kappaB DNA binding increased .
4,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

IL-10 pretreatment prevented LPS -induced decreases in IkappaB-alpha protein levels and attenuated NF-kappaB DNA binding .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

IL-10 appears to prevent activation of NF-kappaB by preserving IkappaB-alpha protein levels , leading to a reduction in TNF-alpha release .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Down-regulation of human granzyme B expression by glucocorticoids .
3,5 G#protein

Dexamethasone inhibits binding to the Ikaros and AP-1 regulatory elements of the granzyme B promoter .
5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA

The serine protease granzyme B is an essential component of the granule exocytosis pathway , a major apoptotic mechanism used by cytotoxic T lymphocytes and natural killer cells to induce target cell apoptosis .
1,5 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type|21,24 G#cell_type|25,28 G#cell_type

Granzyme B gene transcription is induced in activated lymphocytes upon antigenic stimulation , and several regulatory regions including CBF , AP-1 , and Ikaros binding sites have been shown to be essential in the control of granzyme B promoter activation .
8,9 G#cell_type|15,17 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,26 G#DNA|36,39 G#DNA

Dexamethasone , a glucocorticoid that is widely used as an immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory agent , inhibits granzyme B mRNA transcript in phytohemagglutinin -activated peripheral blood mononuclear cells .
16,20 G#RNA|21,22 G#protein|21,27 G#cell_type

Transfection of a reporter construct containing the -148 to +60 region of the human granzyme B promoter demonstrated that this region was the target for dexamethasone repression .
7,11 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA

Mutation of Ikaros or AP-1 binding sites in the context of the granzyme B promoter demonstrated that both sites participate in dexamethasone -mediated inhibition of the granzyme B promoter activity .
2,3 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA

Electromobility shift assay revealed that dexamethasone abolished the binding of nuclear transcription factors to the Ikaros binding site and reduced AP-1 binding activity .
10,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein

These results indicate that dexamethasone is able to abrogate the transcriptional activity of the human granzyme B gene promoter by inhibiting the binding of nuclear factors at the AP-1 and Ikaros sites .
14,19 G#DNA|24,26 G#protein|28,32 G#DNA

Glucocorticoid receptors on mononuclear leukocytes in polycystic ovary syndrome .
0,2 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type

OBJECTIVE : Many studies have suggested that there is a possible hormonal dysregulation of hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal ( HPA ) axis and an increased cortisol clearance in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome ( PCOS ) .


Therefore in this study , we have examined the role of glucocorticoid receptor/s ( GR ) characteristics in the developing of these abnormalities in patients with PCOS .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

METHOD : For this purpose , the number and affinity of GR in peripheral mononuclear leukocytes ( MNL ) of 10 patients with PCOS and 10 healthy women ( controls ) were determined .
11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

RESULTS : There were no significant differences in the number ( 6500+/-1001 sites/cell and 6352+/-1697 sites/cell , respectively ; P &gt; 0.05 ) and affinity ( 3.93+/-0.89 nM and 4.49+/-0.71 nM , respectively ; P &gt; 0.05 ) of GR between the PCOS patients and the controls .
39,40 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : These results suggest that the alterations in the HPA axis and in the cortisol metabolism observed in PCOS are not related to GR deficiency .
24,25 G#protein

Heterogeneous expression of the lipocalin NGAL in primary breast cancers .
4,6 G#protein

We have previously shown that neu oncogene-initiated rat mammary carcinomas uniquely over-express neu-related lipocalin ( NRL ) , a member of the calycin protein superfamily .
12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

Here , we characterize the putative human homolog of NRL , neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin ( NGAL ) .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

ngal gene expression was found at moderate levels in only 2 of 17 human tissues examined , breast and lung .


When breast cancers were examined for NGAL mRNA and protein levels , they were found to exhibit heterogeneous expression .


NGAL levels varied in these tumors from undetectable to exceeding those in normal breast parenchyma .
0,1 G#protein

Immuno-histochemical analysis confirmed the presence of NGAL within breast carcinoma cells but detected only low levels of this protein in normal ductal epithelium .
6,7 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type

In contrast , large amounts of the protein were localized to the lumen of normal breast ducts in the vicinity of NGAL -expressing tumors .
21,22 G#protein

Interestingly , unlike NRL in rat mammary carcinomas , no significant association between NGAL expression and HER-2/neu activation was found in human breast tumors .
3,4 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In contrast , a significant correlation between NGAL expression in breast cancer was found with several other markers of poor prognosis , including estrogen and progesterone receptor -negative status and high proliferation ( S-phase fraction ) .
7,8 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

NGAL levels were stratified as high or low in breast cancers from a cohort of node-positive patients with known outcome .
0,1 G#protein

No significant association between NGAL expression and disease-free or overall survival was observed .
4,5 G#protein

BASH , a novel signaling molecule preferentially expressed in B cells of the bursa of Fabricius .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

The bursa of Fabricius is a gut-associated lymphoid organ that is essential for the generation of a diversified B cell repertoire in the chicken .
18,21 G#cell_type

We describe here a novel gene preferentially expressed in bursal B cells .
10,12 G#cell_type|9,12 G#cell_type

The gene encodes an 85-kDa protein , designated BASH ( B cell adaptor containing SH2 domain ) , that contains N-terminal acidic domains with SH2 domain-binding phosphotyrosine-based motifs , a proline -rich domain , and a C-terminal SH2 domain .
4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,16 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,28 G#protein|30,33 G#protein|36,39 G#protein

BASH shows a substantial sequence similarity to SLP-76 , an adaptor protein functioning in TCR -signal transduction .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

BASH becomes tyrosine -phosphorylated with the B cell Ag receptor ( BCR ) cross-link or by coexpression with Syk and Lyn and associates with signaling molecules including Syk and a putative chicken Shc homologue .
0,1 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,34 G#protein

Overexpression of BASH results in suppression of the NF-AT activation induced by BCR -cross-linking .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

These findings suggest that BASH is involved in BCR -mediated signal transduction and could play a critical role in B cell development in the bursa .
