CD27 /CD70 interaction augments IgE secretion by promoting the differentiation of memory B cells into plasma cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type

The induction of IgE switching in B cells requires several signals given by cytokines and cell contact-delivered signals .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

Here , we investigated the role of CD27 /CD70 interaction in B cell IgE synthesis .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

The addition of CD27 ligand ( CD70 ) transfectants to B cell cultures increased the IgE synthesis synergistically in the presence of IL-4 plus anti-CD40 mAb ( anti-CD40 ) .
10,13 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The effect of CD70 transfectants was dose dependent and was completely blocked by anti-CD70 mAb .
3,5 G#cell_line|13,16 G#protein

CD27+ B cells had the ability to produce IgE , which was increased by contact with CD70 transfectants , whereas CD27-Â B cells did not produce IgE .
0,3 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

CD27 /CD70 interaction enhanced B cell proliferation in the presence of IL-4 or IL-4 plus anti-CD40 .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

The augmentation of B cell proliferation by CD70 transfectants was apparent in CD27+ B cells , but was mild in CD27-Â B cells .
12,15 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type

The helper activity for IgE synthesis by the CD27 /CD70 interaction did not contribute to the enhancement of germline epsilon transcripts .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|18,21 G#RNA

Flow cytometric and morphological analyses demonstrated that the addition of CD70 transfectants to B cell cultures remarkably promoted differentiation into plasma cells in the presence of IL-4 and CD40 signaling .
13,16 G#cell_line|20,22 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Finally , CD27 cross-linking resulted in the up-regulation of positive regulatory domain I-binding factor-1 .
2,3 G#protein|9,14 G#protein

Taken together , our findings indicate that signaling via CD27 on B cells induces IgE synthesis , in cooperation with IL-4 and CD40 signaling , by promoting the generation of plasma cells through up-regulation of positive regulatory domain I-binding factor-1 .
9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type|35,40 G#protein

Human immunodeficiency virus type-1 transcription : role of the 5'-untranslated leader region ( review ) .


Human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV-1 ) transcription is dependent on the interaction of host-cell transcription factors with cis-regulatory DNA elements within the viral long terminal repeat ( LTR ) .
15,17 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|23,27 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA

Much attention has focused on the series of sequence elements upstream of the transcriptional initiation site in the U3 region of the LTR including the Sp1 and NF-kappaB binding sites .
13,16 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA

Recent studies , however , demonstrate that the transcribed 5'-untranslated leader region ( 5'-UTR ) also contains important transcriptional elements .
9,12 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA

These regulatory elements situated downstream of transcription interact with constitutive and inducible transcription factors , mediate transmission of cellular activation signals , and are important for efficient HIV-1 transcription and replication .
1,3 G#DNA|12,14 G#protein

The 5'-UTR contains binding sites for the transcription factors AP-1 , NF-kappaB , NF-AT , IRF , and Sp1 .
1,2 G#DNA|3,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Mutations in these binding sites can interfere with the viral response to cell activation signals , decrease LTR transcription , and inhibit viral replication .
3,5 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA

The 5'-UTR also interacts with a specific nucleosome that is rapidly displaced during transcriptional activation of the latent provirus .
1,2 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein

We propose that the inducible transcription factor binding sites in the 5'-UTR comprise a downstream enhancer domain that can function independent of , or in concert with , the LTR promoter to rapidly increase latent proviral transcription in response to cell activation signals .
7,9 G#DNA|4,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|14,17 G#DNA|29,30 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

In this review , we describe the host-cell transcription factors that interact with the 5'-UTR and discuss their role in the transcriptional regulation of HIV-1 gene expression .
8,10 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA

Regulation of PAK activation and the T cell cytoskeleton by the linker protein SLP-76 .
11,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Tyrosine phosphorylation of linker proteins enables the T cell antigen receptor ( TCR ) -associated protein tyrosine kinases to phosphorylate and regulate effector molecules that generate second messengers .
3,5 G#protein|7,18 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

We demonstrate here that the SLP-76 linker protein interacts with both nck , an adaptor protein , and Vav , a guanine nucleotide exchange factor for Rho-family GTPases .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

The assembly of this tri-molecular complex permits the activated Rho-family GTPases to regulate target effectors that interact through nck .
4,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

In turn , assembly of this complex mediates the enzymatic activation of the p21-activated protein kinase 1 and facilitates actin polymerization .
13,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Hence , phosphorylation of linker proteins not only bridges the TCR-associated PTK , ZAP-70 , with downstream effector proteins , but also provides a scaffold to integrate distinct signaling complexes to regulate T cell function .
4,6 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

Interleukin-12 expression in B cells by transformation with Epstein-Barr virus .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#cell_type

Although interleukin ( IL ) -12 was originally purified from an Epstein-Barr ( EBV ) -transformed B cell line and the high correlation of EBV infection and IL-12 expression has been suggested , no study has reported whether EBV infection is directly linked to IL-12 expression .
1,6 G#protein|11,19 G#cell_line|27,28 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

To address this issue , we have investigated IL-12 expression in B cells during in vitro transformation with EBV .
8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Human peripheral B cells became capable of constitutively producing p40 by in vitro transformation with EBV , coincident with the expression of latent membrane protein 1 ( LMP1 ) of EBV .
0,4 G#cell_type|22,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

These B cells expressed p40 and p35 mRNA , and phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) stimulation strongly enhanced p40 and p70 production .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,8 G#RNA

Furthermore , transfection with LMP1 expression vector into a human B lymphoma cell line , Daudi , led to p40 production with nuclear factor ( NF ) -kappaB activation .
4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#DNA|9,14 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein|22,28 G#protein

These results suggest that transformation of primary B cells with EBV induces IL-12 expression potentially through LMP1 expression .
6,9 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Copyright 1998 Academic Press .


The human gene encoding the lectin-type oxidized LDL receptor ( OLR1 ) is a novel member of the natural killer gene complex with a unique expression profile .
1,3 G#DNA|5,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|18,22 G#protein

LOX-1 is an endothelial receptor for oxidized low-density lipoprotein that plays essential roles in atherogenesis .
0,1 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|6,9 G#protein

LOX-1 has the highest homology with C-type lectin receptors expressed on natural killer cells .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

In the present study , we cloned and characterized the human LOX-1 gene ( HGMW-approved symbol OLR1 ) .
10,13 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|14,17 G#protein

The gene structure of LOX-1 resembles that of the natural killer cell receptors .
4,5 G#protein|9,13 G#protein

Fluorescence in situ hybridization and analyses of a yeast artificial chromosome contig revealed that the human LOX-1 gene is located in the natural killer gene complex on chromosome 12p12-p13 , where the genes of the natural killer cell receptors cluster .
16,17 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|22,26 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|35,39 G#protein

In contrast , the expression pattern of LOX-1 is different from that of the natural killer cell receptors ; LOX-1 is expressed in vascular-rich organs , but not in lymphocytes .
7,8 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

A 1753-bp fragment of the 5' flanking region of the LOX-1 gene had a functional promoter activity .
1,3 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

This region contains binding sites for several transcription factors , including the STAT family and NF-IL6 , and the expression of LOX-1 was upregulated by several cytokines .
3,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

These results demonstrate that the human LOX-1 gene is a new member of the natural killer gene complex with a unique expression profile .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|14,18 G#protein

Copyright 1998 Academic Press .


Transcriptional regulation of the beta-casein gene by cytokines : cross-talk between STAT5 and other signaling molecules .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

The beta-casein promoter has been widely used to monitor the activation of STAT ( signal transducer and activator of transcription ) 5 since STAT5 was originally found as a mediator of PRL-inducible beta-casein expression .
1,2 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|12,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

However , not only is expression of the beta-casein gene regulated by STAT5 but it is also affected by other molecules such as glucocorticoid and Ras .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

In this report , we describe the transcriptional regulation of the beta-casein gene by cytokines in T cells .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

We have found that the beta-casein gene is expressed in a cytotoxic T cell line , CTLL-2 , in response to interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) , which activates STAT5 .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|11,15 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

While IL-4 does not activate STAT5 , it induces expression of STAT5 -regulated genes in CTLL-2 , i.e. beta-casein , a cytokine-inducible SH2-containing protein ( CIS ) , and oncostatin M ( OSM ) , suggesting that STAT6 activated by IL-4 substitutes for the function of STAT5 in T cells .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|15,16 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|29,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|48,50 G#cell_type

IL-2 -induced beta-casein expression was enhanced by dexamethasone , and this synergistic effect of Dexamethasone requires the sequence between -155 and -193 in the beta-casein promoter .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA

Coincidentally , a deletion of this region enhanced the IL-2 -induced expression of beta-casein .
9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Expression of an active form of Ras , Ras(G12V) , suppressed the IL-2 -induced beta-casein and OSM gene expression , and the negative effect of Ras is mediated by the region between -105 and -193 in the beta-casein promoter .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA|37,38 G#protein|37,39 G#DNA

In apparent contradiction , expression of a dominant negative form of Ras , RasN17 , also inhibited IL-2 -induced activation of the promoter containing the minimal beta-casein STAT5 element as well as the promoters of CIS and OSM .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|26,29 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

In addition , Ras(G12V) complemented signaling by an erythropoietin receptor mutant defective in Ras activation and augmented the activation of the beta-casein promoter by the mutant erythropoietin receptor signaling , suggesting a possible role of Ras in Stat5 -mediated gene expression .
3,4 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA|25,28 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

These results collectively reveal a complex interaction of STAT5 with other signaling pathways and illustrate that regulation of gene expression requires integration of opposing signals
8,9 G#protein

GATA-3 represses gp91phox gene expression in eosinophil-committed HL-60-C15 cells .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|6,9 G#cell_line

To study the regulatory mechanism of gp91phox gene expression in eosinophils , we transiently transfected eosinophil-committed HL-60-C15 cells with gp91phox promoter constructs , and identified a negative element from bp -267 to -246 of the gp91phox gene , the deletion of which caused an 83 % increase in promoter activity .
6,8 G#DNA|15,18 G#cell_line|19,22 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|30,33 G#DNA|35,37 G#DNA

Electrophoresis mobility shift assays demonstrated GATA-3 binds to the GATA consensus site from bp -256 to -250 .
5,6 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA

An 81 % increment in promoter activity was obtained when a mutation was introduced in the GATA-3 binding site of the bp -267 to +12 construct , which is comparable to that of the bp -245 to +12 construct .
16,17 G#protein|16,19 G#DNA|21,26 G#DNA|34,39 G#DNA

We therefore conclude that GATA-3 specifically binding to the GATA site negatively regulates the expression of the gene in HL-60-C15 cells .
4,5 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|19,21 G#cell_line

Uncoupling activation-dependent HS1 phosphorylation from nuclear factor of activated T cells transcriptional activation in Jurkat T cells : differential signaling through CD3 and the costimulatory receptors CD2 and CD28 .
2,3 G#protein|5,11 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

CD3 , CD2 , and CD28 are functionally distinct receptors on T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Engagement of any of these receptors induces the rapid tyrosine phosphorylation of a shared group of intracellular signaling proteins , including Vav , Cbl , p85 phosphoinositide 3-kinase , and the Src family kinases Lck and Fyn .
16,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Ligation of CD3 also induces the tyrosine phosphorylation of HS1 , a 75-kDa hematopoietic cell-specific intracellular signaling protein of unknown function .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,18 G#protein

We have examined changes in HS1 phosphorylation after differential stimulation of CD3 , CD2 , and CD28 to elucidate its role in T cells and to further delineate the signaling pathways recruited by these receptors .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#cell_type

Unlike ligation of CD3 , stimulation with anti- CD28 mAb or CHO cells expressing the CD28 ligands CD80 or CD86 did not lead to tyrosine phosphorylation of HS1 in Jurkat T cells .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|7,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,32 G#cell_line

Additionally , no tyrosine phosphorylation of HS1 was induced by mitogenic pairs of anti- CD2 mAbs capable of activating the transcription factor NFAT ( nuclear factor of activated T cells ) .
6,7 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,30 G#protein

Costimulation through CD28 and/or CD2 did not modulate the CD3 -dependent phosphorylation of HS1 .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

In vivo studies indicated that CD3 -induced HSI phosphorylation was dependent upon both the Src family tyrosine kinase Lck and the tyrosine phosphatase CD45 , did not require MEK1 kinase activity , and was regulated by protein kinase C activation .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|36,39 G#protein

Thus , although CD3 , CD28 , and CD2 activate many of the same signaling molecules , they differed in their capacity to induce the tyrosine phosphorylation of HSI .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Furthermore , activation-dependent tyrosine phosphorylation of HS1 was not required for NFAT transcriptional activation .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

c-fos and c-jun mRNA expression in activated cord and adult lymphocytes : an analysis by Northern hybridization .
6,11 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND AND OBJECTIVES : To further analyze the neonatal immune response to an antigenic challenge such as blood transfusion , c-fos and c-jun mRNA expression were analyzed in twelve in-vitro-stimulated normal cord blood and ten in-vitro-stimulated normal adult peripheral blood lymphocyte samples .
35,42 G#cell_type

MATERIALS AND METHODS : Lymphocyte samples were stimulated by either the mitogen phytohemagglutinin ( PHA ) or the monoclonal antibody alphaCD3 .
4,6 G#cell_type|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Proliferation rate and Northern blot hybridization were employed .


RESULTS : Cord lymphocytes revealed a greater proliferation rate with PHA and alphaCD3 than adult lymphocytes ( p = 0.0081 and 0.0023 , respectively ) .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In addition , Northern blot analysis of cord and adult samples revealed similar maximal increases in c-fos ( 99+/-15 and 126+/-11 % , p = 0.0126 ) and c-jun ( 123+/-9 and 185+/-38 % , p = 0.0291 ) mRNA expression , respectively , as early as 15 min post- alphaCD3 stimulation .
16,17 G#RNA|28,40 G#RNA|50,51 G#protein

Adult lymphocytes showed an equivalent increase in mRNA expression of c-fos and c-jun ( 140+/-25 and 155+/-31 % ) at 30 min post- PHA stimulation , while cord lymphocyte maximum c-fos and c-jun expression ( 82+/-6 and 142+/-12 % ) occurred at 15 min post- PHA stimulation ( c-fos , p = 0.0354 ; c-jun , p = 0.0112 ) .
10,11 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#DNA|54,55 G#DNA

CONCLUSION : Although cord lymphocyte proliferation rates were significantly greater than those of adult lymphocytes following stimulation , lymphocyte activation , as analyzed by c-fos and c-jun mRNA expression , appears similar in both cord and adult samples .
3,5 G#cell_type

We conclude that cord lymphocyte activation exhibits an adult-type profile .


Fcgamma receptor -mediated mitogen-activated protein kinase activation in monocytes is independent of Ras .
0,2 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein

Receptors for the Fc portion of immunoglobulin molecules ( FcR ) present on leukocyte cell membranes mediate a large number of cellular responses that are very important in host defense , including phagocytosis , cell cytotoxicity , production and secretion of inflammatory mediators , and modulation of the immune response .
3,5 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|41,43 G#protein

Cross-linking of FcR with immune complexes leads , first to activation of protein- tyrosine kinases .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

The molecular events that follow and that transduce signals from these receptors to the nucleus are still poorly defined .


We have investigated the signal transduction pathway from Fc receptors that leads to gene activation and production of cytokines in monocytes .
8,10 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type

Cross-linking of FcR , on the THP-1 monocytic cell line , by immune complexes resulted in both activation of the transcription factor NF-kappaB and interleukin 1 production .
2,3 G#protein|6,10 G#cell_line|12,14 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

These responses were completely blocked by tyrosine kinase inhibitors .
6,8 G#protein

In contrast , expression of dominant negative mutants of Ras and Raf-1 , in these cells , did not have any effect on FcR -mediated nuclear factor activation , suggesting that the mitogen-activated protein kinase ( MAPK ) signaling pathway was not used by these receptors .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|32,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

However , MAPK activation was easily detected by in vitro kinase assays , after FcR cross-linking with immune complexes .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Using the specific MAPK /extracellular signal-regulated kinase kinase ( MAPK kinase ) inhibitor PD98059 , we found that MAPK activation is necessary for FcR -dependent activation of the nuclear factor NF-kappaB .
3,4 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

These results strongly suggest that the signaling pathway from Fc receptors leading to expression of different genes important to leukocyte biology , initiates with tyrosine kinases and requires MAPK activation ; but in contrast to other tyrosine kinase receptors , FcR -mediated MAPK activation does not involve Ras and Raf .
9,11 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|36,39 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|47,48 G#protein|49,50 G#protein

BCL-6 mutations in normal germinal center B cells : evidence of somatic hypermutation acting outside Ig loci .
0,1 G#protein|3,8 G#cell_type|15,17 G#DNA

The molecular mechanism involved in the process of antigen-driven somatic hypermutation of Ig genes is unknown , but it is commonly believed that this mechanism is restricted to the Ig loci .
12,14 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

B cell lymphomas commonly display multiple somatic mutations clustering in the 5'-regulatory region of BCL-6 , a proto-oncogene encoding for a POZ/Zinc finger transcriptional repressor expressed in germinal center ( GC ) B cells and required for GC formation .
0,3 G#cell_type|11,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#DNA|21,25 G#protein|27,34 G#cell_type

To determine whether BCL-6 mutations represent a tumor-associated phenomenon or reflect a physiologic mechanism , we screened single human tonsillar GC B cells for mutations occurring in the BCL-6 5'-noncoding region and in the Ig variable heavy chain sequences .
3,4 G#protein|18,23 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|28,31 G#DNA|34,39 G#DNA

Thirty percent of GC B cells , but not naive B cells , displayed mutations in the 742 bp region analyzed within the first intron of BCL-6 ( overall frequency : 5 x 10(-4)/bp ) .
3,6 G#cell_type|9,12 G#cell_type|17,20 G#DNA|26,27 G#protein

Accordingly , an expanded survey in lymphoid malignancies showed that BCL-6 mutations are restricted to B cell tumors displaying GC or post-GC phenotype and carrying mutated Ig variable heavy chain sequences .
10,11 G#protein|25,31 G#DNA

These results indicate that the somatic hypermutation mechanism active in GC B cells physiologically targets non-Ig sequences .
10,13 G#cell_type|15,17 G#DNA

The AD1 and AD2 transactivation domains of E2A are essential for the antiapoptotic activity of the chimeric oncoprotein E2A-HLF .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The chimeric oncoprotein E2A-HLF , generated by the t(17;19) chromosomal translocation in pro-B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia , incorporates the transactivation domains of E2A and the basic leucine zipper ( bZIP ) DNA-binding and protein dimerization domain of HLF ( hepatic leukemic factor ) .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|39,42 G#protein

The ability of E2A-HLF to prolong the survival of interleukin-3 ( IL-3 ) -dependent murine pro-B cells after IL-3 withdrawal suggests that it disrupts signaling pathways normally responsible for cell suicide , allowing the cells to accumulate as transformed lymphoblasts .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|9,17 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|38,40 G#cell_type

To determine the structural motifs that contribute to this antiapoptotic effect , we constructed a panel of E2A-HLF mutants and programmed their expression in IL-3 -dependent murine pro-B cells ( FL5.12 line ) , using a zinc-inducible vector .
17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|24,29 G#cell_line|30,32 G#cell_line

Neither the E12 nor the E47 product of the E2A gene nor the wild-type HLF protein was able to protect the cells from apoptosis induced by IL-3 deprivation .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|13,16 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Surprisingly , different combinations of disabling mutations within the HLF bZIP domain had little effect on the antiapoptotic property of the chimeric protein , so long as the amino-terminal portion of E2A remained intact .
9,12 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

In the context of a bZIP domain defective in DNA binding , mutants retaining either of the two transactivation domains of E2A were able to extend cell survival after growth factor deprivation .
5,7 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

Thus , the block of apoptosis imposed by E2A-HLF in pro-B lymphocytes depends critically on the transactivating regions of E2A .
8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Since neither DNA binding nor protein dimerization through the bZIP domain of HLF is required for this effect , we propose mechanisms whereby protein-protein interactions with the amino-terminal region of E2A allow the chimera to act as a transcriptional cofactor to alter the expression of genes regulating the apoptotic machinery in pro-B cells .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|51,53 G#cell_type

Induction of Mn SOD in human monocytes without inflammatory cytokine production by a mutant endotoxin .
2,4 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type|8,10 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

Endotoxin selectively induces monocyte Mn superoxide dismutase ( SOD ) without affecting levels of Cu , Zn SOD , catalase , or glutathione peroxidase .
0,1 G#protein|3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

However , little is known about the structure-activity relationship and the mechanism by which endotoxin induces Mn SOD .
16,18 G#protein

In this study we demonstrated that a mutant Escherichia coli endotoxin lacking myristoyl fatty acid at the 3' R-3-hydroxymyristate position of the lipid A moiety retained its full capacity to coagulate Limulus amoebocyte lysate compared with the wild-type E . coli endotoxin and markedly stimulated the activation of human monocyte nuclear factor-kappaB and the induction of Mn SOD mRNA and enzyme activity .
48,52 G#protein|56,58 G#protein|56,59 G#RNA

However , in contrast to the wild-type endotoxin , it failed to induce significant production of tumor necrosis factor-alpha and macrophage inflammatory protein-1alpha by monocytes and did not induce the phosphorylation and nuclear translocation of mitogen-activated protein kinase .
16,19 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type|35,38 G#protein

These results suggest that 1 ) lipid A myristoyl fatty acid , although it is important for the induction of inflammatory cytokine production by human monocytes , is not necessary for the induction of Mn SOD , 2 ) endotoxin -mediated induction of Mn SOD and inflammatory cytokines are regulated , at least in part , through different signal transduction pathways , and 3 ) failure of the mutant endotoxin to induce tumor necrosis factor-alpha production is , at least in part , due to its inability to activate mitogen-activated protein kinase .
20,22 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|34,36 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|43,45 G#protein|47,48 G#protein|68,70 G#protein|72,75 G#protein|89,92 G#protein

Regulation of the vitellogenin gene B1 promoter after transfer into hepatocytes in primary cultures .
3,7 G#DNA|10,11 G#cell_type

The estrogen-dependent and tissue-specific regulation of the Xenopus laevis vitellogenin gene B1 promoter has been studied by lipid-mediated DNA transfer into Xenopus hepatocytes in primary culture .
9,13 G#DNA|22,23 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

Hepatocytes achieve an efficient hormonal control of this promoter through a functional interaction between the estrogen responsive elements and a promoter proximal region upstream of the TATA box , which is characterized by a high density of binding sites for the transcription factors CTF/NF-1 , C/EBP and HNF3 .
15,18 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|41,43 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

DNA accessibility to restriction enzymes within the chromosomal copy of the vitellogenin gene B1 promoter shows that the estrogen responsive unit and the promoter proximal region are sensitive to digestion in uninduced and estrogen -induced hepatocytes but not in erythrocyte nuclei .
3,5 G#protein|11,15 G#DNA|18,21 G#DNA|23,26 G#DNA|35,36 G#cell_type|33,36 G#cell_type

Together , these findings support the notion that chromatin configuration as well as the interplay of promoter elements mediate proper hormone-dependent and tissue-specific expression of the B1 vitellogenin gene .
8,9 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA

Characterization of cytokine differential induction of STAT complexes in primary human T and NK cells .
2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|9,15 G#cell_type

Cytokines , IL-2 , IL-4 , IL-6 , IL-7 , IL-12 , and IL-15 are key regulators of human peripheral blood T and NK cell activation and differentiation but the precise mechanisms that give rise to their differential activities within these cells are not clear .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Recent studies reveal that a family of transcription factors , signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STATs ) directly mediate many cytokine signals .
7,9 G#protein|10,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We analyzed the activation of STATs in primary human T and NK cells by a variety of specific cytokines .
5,6 G#protein|7,13 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

We demonstrate that IL-12 induces STAT4 only in freshly isolated primary NK cells , but not in primary T cells , consistent with the lack of the IL-12 receptor in resting T cells .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|10,13 G#cell_type|17,20 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#protein|30,33 G#cell_type

In contrast , IL-4 induces different C epsilon GAS DNA-protein binding complexes in both T and NK cells .
3,4 G#protein|6,12 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

Moreover , IL-4 costimulation with IL-2 or IL-12 does not alter their own preferential GAS -like DNA binding patterns when C epsilon- , Fc gamma RI- , and SIE GAS motif containing oligonucleotide probes are compared , suggesting that induction of GAS-like DNA-protein binding complexes by IL-2 , IL-4 , and IL-12 is highly selective and represents one important factor in determining specific gene activation .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA|20,31 G#DNA|41,45 G#protein|46,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|51,52 G#protein

In addition , IL-6 and IL-2 synergistically induce homo- and heterodimerized STAT1 alpha and STAT3 in both NK and T cells , consistent with their reported synergism in modulating perforin gene expression .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_type|29,31 G#DNA

We further demonstrated that IL -2 , -7 , and -15 induce multiple STAT proteins , including STAT5a , STAT5b , STAT1 alpha , STAT3 , and another unidentified Fc gamma RI GAS DNA-binding protein .
4,11 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,35 G#protein

Finally , we observed that activated STAT5a and STAT5b proteins form distinct Fc gamma RI GAS binding patterns in T and NK cells , suggesting that they might have different roles in gene regulation .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|19,23 G#cell_type

Our data provide evidence that the differential responses in gene expression and cell activation seen in primary NK and T cells on direct stimulation with different cytokines may be a direct result of distinct activation of STAT transcription factors .
17,21 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|36,39 G#protein

A regulatory element in the CD95 ( APO-1/Fas ) ligand promoter is essential for responsiveness to TCR -mediated activation .
1,3 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|5,11 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

Expression of the CD95 ( APO-1/Fas ) ligand ( CD95L ) in activated T cells is a major cause of T cell activation-induced apoptosis .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|3,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

To study the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional control of CD95L expression in T cells , we investigated the human CD95L promoter in Jurkat T cells .
9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|22,25 G#cell_line

Deletion studies revealed that the CD95L proximal promoter sequence from -220 to the transcription start site is essential for T cell stimulation-induced expression of CD95L .
5,6 G#protein|5,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein

In this study , we discovered a novel regulatory element located at -120 of the CD95L promoter which contains DNA binding sites for SP-1 and a yet unknown inducible factor .
8,10 G#DNA|12,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA|19,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

Mutation analysis demonstrated that binding of the inducible factor to the -120 region is crucial for the biological function of the CD95L promoter upon T cell stimulation .
11,13 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

The DNA sequence at -120 also contains two DNA motifs homologous to the binding site for NF-AT .
4,5 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

NF-AT does not directly bind to this element .
0,1 G#protein

However , cotransfection studies with an NF-AT expression vector showed that NF-AT may confer a strong inducible activity to the CD95L promoter at this regulatory region .
6,7 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA

Our data also show that the immunosuppressive agent cyclosporin A down-regulates CD95L transcription by inhibiting the function of this positive regulatory element
11,12 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA

A nongenomic mechanism for progesterone-mediated immunosuppression : inhibition of K+ channels , Ca2+ signaling , and gene expression in T lymphocytes .
9,11 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

The mechanism by which progesterone causes localized suppression of the immune response during pregnancy has remained elusive .


Using human T lymphocytes and T cell lines , we show that progesterone , at concentrations found in the placenta , rapidly and reversibly blocks voltage-gated and calcium-activated K+ channels ( KV and KCa , respectively ) , resulting in depolarization of the membrane potential .
2,4 G#cell_type|1,4 G#cell_type|5,8 G#cell_line|25,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

As a result , Ca2+ signaling and nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NF-AT ) -driven gene expression are inhibited .
7,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Progesterone acts distally to the initial steps of T cell receptor ( TCR ) -mediated signal transduction , since it blocks sustained Ca2+ signals after thapsigargin stimulation , as well as oscillatory Ca2+ signals , but not the Ca2+ transient after TCR stimulation .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

K+ channel blockade by progesterone is specific ; other steroid hormones had little or no effect , although the progesterone antagonist RU 486 also blocked KV and KCa channels .
25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Progesterone effectively blocked a broad spectrum of K+ channels , reducing both Kv1.3 and charybdotoxin-resistant components of KV current and KCa current in T cells , as well as blocking several cloned KV channels expressed in cell lines .
7,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|32,33 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|36,38 G#cell_line

Progesterone had little or no effect on a cloned voltage-gated Na+ channel , an inward rectifier K+ channel , or on lymphocyte Ca2+ and Cl- channels .
8,12 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|21,26 G#protein

We propose that direct inhibition of K+ channels in T cells by progesterone contributes to progesterone -induced immunosuppression .
6,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

A mouse carrying genetic defect in the choice between T and B lymphocytes .
9,13 G#cell_type

Transgenic mice with human CD3epsilon gene have been shown to exhibit early arrest of T cell development in the thymus .
3,6 G#DNA

The present study shows that , instead of T cells , B cells are generated in the thymus of a line , tg epsilon26 , of the human CD3epsilon transgenic mice .
8,10 G#cell_type|11,13 G#cell_type

The accumulation of mature B cells in the thymus was found only in tg epsilon26 mice , not in other human CD3epsilon transgenic mouse lines or other T cell-deficient mice , including CD3-epsilon knockout mice and TCR-beta/TCR-delta double knockout mice .
3,6 G#cell_type|20,25 G#cell_line

Hanging drop-mediated transfer into 2-deoxyguanosine-treated thymus lobes showed that lymphoid progenitor cells rather than thymus stromal cells were responsible for abnormal B cell development in tg epsilon26 thymus , and that tg epsilon26 fetal liver cells were destined to become B cells in normal thymus even in the presence of normal progenitor cells undergoing T cell development .
9,12 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|31,36 G#cell_type|40,42 G#cell_type|50,53 G#cell_type

These results indicate that lymphoid progenitor cells in tg epsilon26 mice are genetically defective in thymic choice between T cells and B cells , generating B cells even in normal thymus environment .
4,7 G#cell_type|8,10 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type|25,27 G#cell_type

Interestingly , tg epsilon26 thymocytes expressed GATA-3 and TCF-1 , but not LEF-1 and PEBP-2alpha , among T cell-specific transcription factors that are involved in early T cell development , indicating that GATA-3 and TCF-1 expressed during thymocyte development do not necessarily determine the cell fate into T cell lineage .
2,4 G#protein|2,5 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,21 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|47,50 G#cell_type

Thus , tg epsilon26 mice provide a novel mouse model in that lineage choice between T and B lymphocytes is genetically defective .
2,4 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_type

Downstream activation of a TATA-less promoter by Oct-2 , Bob1 , and NF-kappaB directs expression of the homing receptor BLR1 to mature B cells .
4,6 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type

The chemokine receptor , BLR1 , is a major regulator of the microenvironmental homing of B cells in lymphoid organs .
1,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

In vitro studies identify three essential elements of the TATA-less blr1 core promoter that confer cell type- and differentiation- specific expression in the B cells of both humans and mice , a functional promoter region ( -36 with respect to the transcription start site ) , a NF-kappaB motif ( +44 ) , and a noncanonical octamer motif ( +157 ) .
9,13 G#DNA|23,25 G#cell_type|32,35 G#DNA|41,44 G#DNA|47,48 G#protein|47,49 G#DNA|55,58 G#DNA

The importance of these sites was confirmed by in vivo studies in gene-targeted mice deficient of either Oct-2 , Bob1 , or both NF-kappaB subunits p50 and p52 .
17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

In all of these animals , the expression of BLR1 was reduced or absent .
9,10 G#protein

In mice deficient only of p52/ NF-kappaB , BLR1 expression was unaffected .
6,7 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Thus our data demonstrate that BLR1 is a target gene for Oct-2 , Bob1 , and members of the NF-kappaB /Rel family and provides a link to the impaired B cell functions in mice deficient for these factors .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#protein

CD4 promoter transactivation by human herpesvirus 6 .
0,2 G#DNA

The observation that human herpesvirus 6 ( HHV-6 ) can induce CD4 gene transcription and expression in CD4(-) cells was reported several years ago ( P.Lusso , A.De Maria , M.Malnati , F.Lori , S.E.DeRocco , M. Baseler , and R.C.Gallo , Nature 349 : 533-535 , 1991 ) and subsequently confirmed ( P.Lusso , M.S.Malnati , A.Garzino-Demo , R.W.Crowley , E. O.Long , and R.C.Gallo , Nature 362 : 458-462 , 1993 ; G.Furlini , M. Vignoli , E.Ramazzotti , M.C.Re , G.Visani , and M.LaPlaca , Blood 87 : 4737-4745 , 1996 ) .
11,13 G#DNA|17,19 G#cell_line

Our objective was to identify the mechanisms underlying such phenomena .


Using reporter gene constructs driven by the CD4 promoter , we report that HHV-6 can efficiently transactivate such genetic elements .
1,4 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|18,20 G#DNA

Activation of the CD4 promoter occurs in the presence of the viral DNA polymerase inhibitor phosphonoformic acid , which limits expression to the immediate-early and early classes of viral genes .
3,5 G#DNA|23,30 G#DNA

Using deletion mutants and specific CD4 promoter mutants , we identified an ATF/CRE binding site located at nucleotides -67 to -60 upstream of the CD4 gene transcription start site that is important for HHV-6 transactivation .
5,7 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|17,22 G#DNA|24,26 G#DNA|24,29 G#DNA

The ATF/CRE site is also essential for CD4 promoter activation by forskolin , an activator of adenylate cyclase .
1,3 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA

Using electrophoretic mobility shift assays and specific antibodies , we showed that CREB-1 binds specifically to the -79 to -52 region of the CD4 promoter .
12,13 G#protein|17,21 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA

Last , we have identified two open reading frames ( ORFs ) of HHV-6 , U86 and U89 from the immediate-early locus A , that can transactivate the CD4 promoter in HeLa cells .
6,9 G#DNA|10,11 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|28,30 G#DNA|31,33 G#cell_line

However , transactivation of the CD4 promoter by ORFs U86 and U89 is independent of the CRE element , suggesting that additional HHV-6 ORFs are likely to contribute to CD4 gene activation .
5,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA|9,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|29,31 G#DNA

Taken together , our results will help to understand the complex interactions occurring between HHV-6 and the CD4 promoter and provide additional information regarding the class of transcription factors involved in the control of CD4 gene expression .
17,19 G#DNA|27,29 G#protein|34,36 G#DNA

The PEBP2betaMYH11 fusion created by Inv(16)(p13;q22) in myeloid leukemia impairs neutrophil maturation and contributes to granulocytic dysplasia .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#DNA

Chromosomal translocations involving the genes encoding the alpha and beta subunits of the Pebp2/Cbf transcription factor have been associated with human acute myeloid leukemia and the preleukemic condition , myelodysplasia .
7,11 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

Inv(16)(p13;q22) fuses the gene encoding the beta subunit of Pebp2 to the MYH11 gene encoding a smooth muscle myosin heavy chain ( Smmhc ) .
0,1 G#DNA|6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|16,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

To examine the effect of the inv(16)(p13;q22) on myelopoiesis , we used the hMRP8 promoter element to generate transgenic mice expressing the Pebp2beta Smmhc chimeric fusion protein in myeloid cells .
6,7 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type

Neutrophil maturation was impaired in PEBP2betaMYH11 transgenic mice .
5,6 G#protein

Although the transgenic mice had normal numbers of circulating neutrophils , their bone marrow contained increased numbers of immature neutrophilic cells , which exhibited abnormal characteristics .
8,10 G#cell_type|18,21 G#cell_type

In addition , PEBP2betaMYH11 inhibited neutrophilic differentiation in colonies derived from hematopoietic progenitors .
3,4 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

Coexpression of both PEBP2betaMYH11 and activated NRAS induced a more severe phenotype characterized by abnormal nuclear morphology indicative of granulocytic dysplasia .
3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein

These results show that PEBP2betaMYH11 can impair neutrophil development and provide evidence that alterations of Pebp2 can contribute to the genesis of myelodysplasia .
4,5 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Human T cell leukemia virus-I ( HTLV-I ) Tax -mediated apoptosis in activated T cells requires an enhanced intracellular prooxidant state .
8,9 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

We have shown that an estradiol-dependent activation of human T cell leukemia virus-I Tax leads to the inhibition of cell proliferation and to the induction of apoptosis .
13,14 G#protein

The present study demonstrates that a hormone-dependent activation of Tax promotes an enhanced prooxidant state in stably transfected Jurkat cells as measured by changes in the intracellular levels of glutathione and H2O2 ; these changes are followed by apoptotic cell death .
9,10 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_line|16,20 G#cell_line

Additional stimulation of the CD3 /TCR pathway enhances the oxidative and apoptotic effects .
4,5 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

Both Tax -mediated apoptosis and oxidative stress can be potently suppressed by antioxidants , as is seen with the administration of recombinant thioredoxin ( adult T cell leukemia-derived factor ) or pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate .
1,2 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|24,29 G#protein

Hormone-induced Tax activation induces a long-lasting activation of NF-kappaB , which is a major target of reactive oxygen intermediates .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

The long-term exposure of Jurkat cells to hormone eventually results in a selection of cell clones that have lost Tax activity .
4,6 G#cell_line|14,16 G#cell_line|19,20 G#protein

A subsequent transfection of these apparently " nonresponsive " clones allows the recovery of Tax responses in these cells .
6,10 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein

Our observations indicate that changes in the intracellular redox status may be a determining factor in Tax -mediated DNA damage , apoptosis , and selection against the long-term expression of Tax function .
16,17 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

An allosteric drug , o,o'-bismyristoyl thiamine disulfide , suppresses HIV-1 replication through prevention of nuclear translocation of both HIV-1 Tat and NF-kappa B .
18,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

The efficacy of o , o'-bismyristoyl thiamine disulfide ( BMT ) was examined in detail against HIV-1 laboratory isolates ( HTLV-IIIB , JRFL , and MN ) , primary isolates ( KMT and KMO ) , and simian immunodeficiency virus ( SIVmac251 ) in vitro .


BMT inhibited the replication of HIV-1 in both laboratory and primary isolates in vitro .


In addition , BMT exhibited antiviral activity against SIVmac251 .


Minimizing energy studies of BMT structure reveal that a trans-disulfide of thiamine ( holo drug ) disulfide ( TDS , protodrug ) is allosterically transited to the reactive twisted disulfide of BMT ( allo drug ) by o , o'-bismyristoyl esterification of TDS .


BMT inhibits nuclear translocation of both HIV-1 transactivator ( TAT ) and the cellular transcriptional nuclear factor-KB ( NF-kappa B ) , resulting in the suppression of HIV-1 replication .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Glucocorticoid -induced apoptosis and regulation of NF-kappaB activity in human leukemic T cells .
6,7 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type

Glucocorticoid -induced apoptosis was investigated in glucocorticoid-sensitive 6TG1.1 and resistant ICR27TK.3 human leukemic T cells .
6,8 G#cell_line|9,11 G#cell_line|11,15 G#cell_type

Following glucocorticoid treatment of 6TG1.1 cells , chromatin fragmentation was observed after a delay of 24 h .
4,6 G#cell_line|7,8 G#DNA

Fragmentation was not observed in ICR27TK.3 cells containing mutant glucocorticoid receptors ( L753F ) that are activation-deficient but retain the ability to repress AP-1 activity .
5,7 G#cell_line|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_line|23,24 G#protein

Nor was fragmentation observed after treatment with RU38486 , indicating that repression of AP-1 activity is not involved .
13,14 G#protein

As described in other systems , fragmentation required ongoing protein synthesis .


However , inhibition of protein synthesis with cycloheximide anytime during the first 18 h of steroid treatment was as effective in blocking chromatin fragmentation as inhibition for the entire period , suggesting that synthesis of a component with a rapid turnover rate is required .


Dexamethasone treatment completely blocked 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol 13-acetate induction of nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) activity and elicited an increase in the amount of immunoreactive IkappaB alpha in sensitive 6TG1.1 cells but not in resistant ICR27TK.3 cells .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_line|33,35 G#cell_line

In addition , mild detergent treatment of cell extracts indicated that a substantial amount of cytoplasmic NF-kappaB is complexed with IkappaB alpha or some other inhibitory factor . These results suggest that induction of a labile inhibitory factor such as IkappaB alpha may contribute to glucocorticoid-induced apoptosis .
16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|35,38 G#protein|40,42 G#protein

Inhibition of HIV-1 replication by combination of a novel inhibitor of TNF-alpha with AZT .
11,12 G#protein

The small molecule S9a was derived from an established tumor necrosis factor-alpha ( TNF-alpha ) inhibitor ( Canventol ) by replacement of the isopropylidine group with a phenyl ring .
9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

S9a at 10 to 100 nM inhibited HIV production as potently as 3'-azido-3'-deoxythymidine ( AZT ) , an inhibitor of viral reverse transcriptase .
20,23 G#protein

Furthermore , S9a and AZT in combination , at noncytoxic concentrations strongly inhibited HIV-1 replication that was more than additive and substantially prolonged the appearance of virus both in acutely infected CD4+ lymphocytes ( SupT ) in culture and in peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMCs ) infected with a primary HIV-1 isolate .
29,33 G#cell_type|34,35 G#cell_line|40,44 G#cell_type|45,46 G#cell_type

S9a inhibited TNF-alpha promoter-driven reporter gene activity .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#DNA

It was proposed that the mechanism of antiviral action of S9a was on the host cell , by blocking TNF-alpha transcription via a Tat -induced tar-independent loop , which decreases downstream NF-kappaB activation of HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) .
19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,38 G#DNA|39,40 G#DNA

S9a was superior to the first generation compound Canventol , which was superior to the natural compound sarcophytol A , demonstrating that further structure-based enhancement of potency of these compounds is feasible .


This study suggests a therapeutic approach against AIDS by application of two drugs , one against a cellular and the other a viral target , which may provide an approach to the problem of frequent emergence of resistant variants to combinations of drugs that target only HIV genes .
46,48 G#DNA

Highly polarized HLA class II antigen processing and presentation by human intestinal epithelial cells .
2,6 G#protein|10,14 G#cell_type

The high concentration of foreign antigen in the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract is separated from the underlying lymphocytes by a single cell layer of polarized epithelium .
4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#cell_type|18,19 G#cell_type

Intestinal epithelial cells can express HLA class II antigens and may function as antigen-presenting cells to CD4(+) T cells within the intestinal mucosa .
0,3 G#cell_type|5,9 G#protein|13,19 G#cell_type

Using tetanus toxoid specific and HLA-DR-restricted T lymphocytes , we show that polarized intestinal epithelial cells directed to express HLA-DR molecules are able to initiate class II processing only after internalization of antigen from their apical surface .
1,8 G#cell_type|12,16 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein

Coexpression of the class II transactivator CIITA in these cells , which stimulates highly efficient class II processing without the characteristic decline in barrier function seen in polarized monolayers treated with the proinflammatory cytokine gamma-IFN , facilitates antigen processing from the basolateral surface .
3,7 G#protein|32,35 G#protein

In both cases , peptide presentation to T cells via class II molecules was restricted to the basolateral surface .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,13 G#protein

These data indicate a highly polarized functional architecture for antigen processing and presentation by intestinal epithelial cells , and suggest that the functional outcome of antigen processing by the intestinal epithelium is both dependent on the cellular surface at which the foreign antigen is internalized and by the underlying degree of mucosal inflammation
14,17 G#cell_type

Tobacco smoke induces coordinate activation of HSF and inhibition of NFkappaB in human monocytes : effects on TNFalpha release .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

Tobacco smoke ( TS ) exposure is a major risk factor for human disease , and macrophages of healthy smokers have a depressed capacity to release cytokines , including tumor necrosis factor ( TNF ) alpha .
16,17 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|29,36 G#protein

TS induces the synthesis of heat shock ( HS ) /stress proteins ( HSP ) , and , in particular , of Hsp70 .
5,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

We determined whether Hsp70 induction by TS was mediated by the activation of the HS transcription factor , HSF .
3,4 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

HSF activation has been shown to inhibit NFkappaB .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Thus , we also determined the effects of TS on NFkappaB .
10,11 G#protein

U937 cells and human peripheral blood monocytes were exposed to TS , binding activities of the respective transcription factors were analyzed , and Hsp70 expression and TNFalpha release were determined in parallel .
0,2 G#cell_line|3,7 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

TS activated HSF , which was associated with Hsp70 overexpression and inhibition of NFkappaB binding activity and TNFalpha release .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

The altered cytokine profile observed in smokers may relate to an HSF / Hsp70 -mediated inhibition of NFkappaB activity .
2,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

Copyright 1998 Academic Press .


[ Molecular mechanism of cytokine gene expression in Th1 and Th2 ]
4,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line

Upon activation by antigens , helper T cells differentiate into one of several subsets , characterized by their distinct cytokine -production patterns .
3,4 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

Among these subsets , Th1 cells are known to activate cellular immunity resulting in inflammatory response , whereas Th2 cells induce humoral and allergic responses and suppress inflammation .
4,6 G#cell_line|18,20 G#cell_line

Th1 and Th2 effector functions and their development are attributable to their distinct cytokine expression patterns .
13,14 G#protein

Recent reports have demonstrated that differential expression of cell surface molecules , such as adhesion molecule and chemokine receptor , is involved in their recruitment into target tissues .
14,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

It is , therefore , suggested that clarification of the mechanisms of differential gene expression in Th1/Th2 should lead to rational strategies for manipulating pathological immune responses .
16,17 G#cell_line

Activation of helper T cells mediated by the T cell receptor induces a series of biochemical events .
2,5 G#cell_type

Among them , both the activation of PKC/Ras- and CaM/CN- mediated pathways play a central role in the signal transduction of cytokine gene expression .
21,23 G#DNA

Closer examination using non-transformed murine Th1 and Th2 clones suggested that a balance between the activities of the two signaling pathways contributes to cytokine gene expression .
3,9 G#cell_line|23,25 G#DNA

We propose that one of the targets of PGE2 , whose effect distinguishes Th1 from Th2 , resides in the downstream PKC/Ras -mediated pathway .
13,14 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

Signalling into the T-cell nucleus : NFAT regulation .
6,7 G#protein

The nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) plays an important role in T-cell biology .
1,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein

Activation of T cells results in the rapid calcineurin -dependent translocation of NFAT transcription factors from the cytoplasm to the nucleus .
8,9 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|13,15 G#protein

This translocation process coupled to the subsequent active maintenance of NFAT in the nucleus compartment is critical for the induction of expression of several genes encoding cytokines and membrane proteins that modulate immune responses .
10,11 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

The molecular cloning of the NFAT family of transcription factors has facilitated rapid progress in the understanding of the signalling mechanisms that control the activity of NFAT .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Differential RNA display identifies novel genes associated with decreased vitamin D receptor expression .
4,6 G#DNA|9,12 G#protein

To characterize further the function of the intracellular vitamin D receptor ( VDR ) , we have developed stable transfectant variants of a vitamin D-responsive cell line ( U937 ) which express either decreased or increased numbers of VDR .
8,11 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line|23,27 G#cell_line|28,29 G#cell_line|38,39 G#protein

In this study we have analyzed changes in gene expression associated with this variable VDR expression .
14,15 G#protein

Initial experiments indicated that a 50 % decrease in VDR levels was associated with a 2-fold increase in cell proliferation and a similar rise in c-myc mRNA expression .
9,10 G#protein|25,27 G#RNA

Further studies were carried out using differential RNA display ( DD ) .


Sequence analysis of DD products revealed two cDNAs with identity to known gene products : the catalytic sub-unit of DNA-protein kinase ( DNA-PK(CS) ) , and the peroxisomal enzyme 17beta-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type IV ( 17beta-HSD IV ) .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#DNA|11,14 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|16,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,33 G#protein|34,36 G#protein

Northern analysis confirmed that expression of both mRNAs was reduced in cells with decreased numbers of VDR .
7,8 G#RNA|16,17 G#protein

Down-regulation of 17beta-HSD IV mRNA expression was associated with enhanced estradiol inactivation by U937 cells , suggesting a link between estrogenic pathways and cell proliferation .
2,4 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_line

Further Northern analyses indicated that there was no significant change in 17beta-HSD IV or DNA-PK(CS) mRNA levels following treatment with 1,25(OH)2D3 , although expression of both genes varied with changes in cell proliferation .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA

These data suggest that , in addition to its established role as a hormone-dependent trans-activator , VDR may influence gene expression by ligand-independent mechanisms .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Prostaglandin E2 Up-regulates HIV-1 long terminal repeat -driven gene activity in T cells via NF-kappaB -dependent and -independent signaling pathways .
3,7 G#DNA|11,13 G#cell_type

Replication of human immunodeficiency virus type-1 ( HIV-1 ) is highly dependent on the state of activation of the infected cells and is modulated by interactions between viral and host cellular factors .
19,21 G#cell_type|27,32 G#protein

Prostaglandin E2 ( PGE2 ) , a pleiotropic immunomodulatory molecule , is observed at elevated levels during HIV-1 infection as well as during the course of other pathogenic infections .
7,10 G#protein

In 1G5 , a Jurkat-derived T cell line stably transfected with a luciferase gene driven by HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) , we found that PGE2 markedly enhanced HIV-1 LTR -mediated reporter gene activity .
1,2 G#cell_line|4,8 G#cell_line|12,14 G#DNA|16,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA|30,32 G#DNA|33,35 G#DNA

Experiments have been conducted to identify second messengers involved in this PGE2 -dependent up-regulating effect on the regulatory element of HIV-1 .
6,8 G#protein

In this study , we present evidence indicating that signal transduction pathways induced by PGE2 necessitate the participation of cyclic AMP , protein kinase A , and Ca2+ .
22,25 G#protein

Experiments conducted with different HIV-1 LTR -based vectors suggested that PGE2 -mediated activation effect on HIV-1 transcription was transduced via both NF-kappaB -dependent and -independent signaling pathways .
4,6 G#DNA|4,8 G#DNA

The involvement of NF-kappaB in the PGE2 -dependent activating effect on HIV-1 transcription was further confirmed using a kappaB-regulated luciferase encoding vector and by electrophoretic mobility shift assays .
3,4 G#protein|18,22 G#DNA

Results from Northern blot and flow cytometric analyses , as well as the use of a selective antagonist indicated that PGE2 modulation of HIV-1 LTR -driven reporter gene activity in studied T lymphoid cells is transduced via the EP4 receptor subtype .
23,25 G#DNA|26,28 G#DNA|31,34 G#cell_type|38,41 G#protein

These results suggest that secretion of PGE2 by macrophages in response to infection or inflammatory activators could induce signaling events resulting in activation of proviral DNA present into T cells latently infected with HIV-1 .
8,9 G#cell_type|28,30 G#cell_type

Activation of distinct transcription factors in neutrophils by bacterial LPS , interferon-gamma , and GM-CSF and the necessity to overcome the action of endogenous proteases .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

Human neutrophils can be induced to actively transcribe a number of early-response genes , in particular those encoding cytokines , chemokines , and the high-affinity surface receptor for IgG , FcgammaRI .
1,2 G#cell_type|11,13 G#DNA|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Although little is known to date about the regulation of gene transcription in neutrophils , several indications point to a role for distinct transcription factors , such as members of the NF-kappaB and STAT families .
13,14 G#cell_type|23,25 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|33,35 G#protein

In this study , we investigated whether these transcription factors become activated under stimulatory conditions which are known to induce gene transcription in neutrophils .
8,10 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type

Unexpectedly , we found that conventional procedures employed to prepare cellular extracts cause the release of proteolytic activities that are normally stored in intracellular granules , resulting in the degradation of various NF-kappaB /Rel and STAT proteins .
32,33 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

To circumvent this problem , we developed an alternative procedure which allowed us to show that in neutrophils , LPS and TNFalpha induce a NF-kappaB DNA-binding activity which essentially consists of p50/RelA dimers , and that IFNgamma promotes the binding of STAT1 homodimers to the IFNgamma response region of the FcgammaRI promoter .
17,18 G#cell_type|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|41,43 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|45,48 G#DNA|50,51 G#protein|50,52 G#DNA

Moreover , we report that neutrophil stimulation with GM-CSF results in the formation of a STAT5 -containing DNA-binding activity .
8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Collectively , the current findings open new perspectives about mechanisms that are likely to regulate gene transcription in neutrophils .
18,19 G#cell_type

In addition , the procedure described herein could prove useful in other cell types that express high levels of endogenous proteases .
19,21 G#protein

Low CD3+CD28-induced interleukin-2 production correlates with decreased reactive oxygen intermediate formation in neonatal T cells .
2,3 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

The capacity of neonatal T cells to secrete interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) has been reported to be variable .
3,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

We analysed IL-2 production in purified neonatal and adult T cells using polyclonal activator phorbol ester + calcium ionophore ( PDBu + iono ) or receptor-mediated anti-CD3 /anti-CD3+ anti-CD28 stimulation .
2,3 G#protein|6,11 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

PDBu + iono induced equally high IL-2 levels in both groups and , when stimulated with plate-bound anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody ( mAb ) , the IL-2 secretion by neonatal cells was undetectable and adult cells produced low amounts of IL-2 ( mean 331 +/- 86 pg/ml ) .
6,7 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|33,35 G#cell_type|39,40 G#protein

The addition of anti-CD28 mAb to anti-CD3-stimulated cells markedly increased IL-2 production in both cell types , but levels of IL-2 in neonatal T cells remained clearly lower than those of adult T cells ( respective mean values : 385 +/- 109 pg/ml and 4494 +/- 1199 pg/ml ) .
3,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_type|31,34 G#cell_type

As NF-kappa B is a critical transcription factor in the control of IL-2 expression , we next analysed its nuclear translocation in neonatal and adult T cells using the electrophoretic mobility shift assay and , because induction of reactive oxygen intermediates ( ROI ) is required for the activation of NF-kappa B , we also analysed levels of intracellular ROI in these cells using the ROI -reactive fluorochrome DCFH-DA and flow cytometry .
1,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|22,27 G#cell_type|50,52 G#protein

In neonatal T cells NF-kappa B activation and ROI formation after anti-CD3 stimulation were low compared with adult T cells and , although addition of anti-CD28 mAb increased induction of NF-kappa B and ROI formation , levels similar to those of adults were not achieved .
1,4 G#cell_type|4,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_type|25,27 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

After PDBu + iono stimulation , the cells showed similar ROI formation and IL-2 secretion .
13,14 G#protein

Our results suggest that reduced IL-2 production by neonatal T cells is specific for anti-CD3 and anti-CD3 + anti-CD28 -mediated stimulation and that these activators can not effectively activate the ROI -NF-kappa B signalling pathway in neonatal T cells .
5,6 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|36,39 G#cell_type

CD30 is a CD40 -inducible molecule that negatively regulates CD40 -mediated immunoglobulin class switching in non-antigen-selected human B cells .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_line

We used our monoclonal model of germinal center maturation , CL-01 B cells , to investigate the role of CD30 in human B cell differentiation .
10,13 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

CL-01 cells are IgM + IgD + CD30 + and switch to IgG , IgA , and IgE when exposed to CD40L and IL-4 .
0,2 G#cell_line|3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Switching is hampered by CD30 coengagement , possibly through interference with the CD40 -mediated NF-kappaB -dependent transcriptional activation of downstream C(H) genes .
4,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA

The physiological relevance of this phenomenon is emphasized by similar CD30 -mediated effects in naive B cells .
10,11 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Expression of CD30 by these cells is induced by CD40L but is inhibited by B cell receptor coengagement and/or exposure to IL-6 and IL-12 .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Our data suggest that CD30 critically regulates the CD40 -mediated differentiation of non-antigen-selected human B cells .
