Calcineurin and the biological effect of cyclosporine and tacrolimus .
0,1 G#protein

The mechanism of the immunosuppressive effect of CyA and FK 506 can be monitored in vivo in humans .


The picture emerging is of a close relationship between drug concentrations and CN inhibition .


But many puzzles of the drugs remain .


What is the role of CyA in the activation of transforming growth factor-beta ( TGF-beta ) , particularly in relationship to nephrotoxicity and fibrogenesis ?
10,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

How important are the anti-inflammatory ( non T ) effects of CyA , and which cells do they operate in ?


Are there effects of CyA and FK 506 all attributable to CN inhibition , and how much of them are mediated through the NFATC family of transcription factors ?
23,25 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

Finally , it would be useful to know what the inhibitory effects of CyA are on tolerance and negative regulatory events .


Stimulation of B and T cells activates expression of transcription and differentiation factors .
2,6 G#cell_type|9,13 G#protein

During B and T cell differentiation and proliferation many genes are induced or repressed while certain genes are constitutively expressed .


To investigate processes related to B and T cell activation , the gene expression of stimulated and nonstimulated Ramos and Jurkat cells was studied using cDNA microarray technology .
17,22 G#cell_line

Simultaneous analysis of close to 600 genes indicated highest increase in the expression of certain transcription , differentiation and proliferation factors .
5,7 G#DNA|15,21 G#protein

Many of these genes have not previously been shown to funcion in the stimulated lymphocytes .
13,15 G#cell_type

Also genes encoding proteins involved in DNA replication , binding , transcription and translation were induced .


Large part of the activated genes were under very stringent regulation being expressed only after stimulation .
4,6 G#DNA

The mechanism and function of the expressed genes during lymphocyte differentiation and in disorders is discussed .
6,8 G#DNA

Interleukin 2 and 15 activate Stat3alpha in human T lymphocytes .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type

Signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 ( Stat3 ) has recently been shown to exist in two alternatively spliced isoforms , a short form , Stat3beta , and a longer form , Stat3alpha , displaying differences in transcriptional activity .
0,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

It is unknown which Stat3 isoform ( s ) is activated in response to interleukin ( IL ) -2 and IL-15 .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|14,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Here , cytokine -induced activation of Stat3 in previously activated CD4(+) human T cells was examined using Stat3 antibodies directed against different regions of Stat3 .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,14 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

As determined by tyrosine phosphorylation , nuclear translocation and binding to an hSIE-oligonucleotide probe , IL-2 and IL-15 activated the slowly migrating isoform , Stat3alpha .
15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

In contrast , minimal or no activation of Stat3beta was observed , suggesting that IL-2 and IL-15 predominantly activate Stat3alpha in human CD4(+) T cells .
8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_type

In this way , diversity in the expression and activation of Stat3 proteins may provide additional means of regulating cytokine -induced T cell responses .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Copyright 1998 Academic Press .


Transcriptional regulation of lysosomal acid lipase in differentiating monocytes is mediated by transcription factors Sp1 and AP-2 .
3,6 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Human lysosomal acid lipase ( LAL ) is a hydrolase required for the cleavage of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides derived from plasma lipoproteins .
1,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

It is shown here that during monocyte to macrophage differentiation , the expression of LAL -mRNA is induced .
14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#RNA

This induction is dependent on protein kinase C activity and protein synthesis .
5,8 G#protein

The cell type-specific increase in LAL expression is further investigated in the THP-1 cell line with respect to transcriptional regulation .
5,6 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_line

The human monocytic leukemia cell line THP-1 differentiates into macrophage-like cells when treated with phorbol esters .
1,6 G#cell_line|6,7 G#cell_line|9,11 G#cell_type

In order to determine the cis-acting elements necessary for both basal and phorbol 12-myristate-13 acetate ( PMA ) -enhanced promoter activity , we performed deletion analysis and reporter gene assays .
5,7 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA

A PMA responsive element has been identified between -182 bp and -107 bp upstream of the major transcription start site .
1,4 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|16,20 G#DNA

Gel mobility shift assays demonstrated that binding of Sp1 and AP-2 to the LAL promoter is increased by PMA in THP-1 cells .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_line

Co-transfections with expression plasmids for Sp1 and AP-2 further emphasized the important role of these transcription factors in both basal and PMA -enhanced LAL expression .
2,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Our data suggest that differentiation dependent increase of lysosomal acid lipase ( LAL ) expression in THP-1 cells is mediated by a concerted action of Sp1 and AP-2 .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Relationship between IkappaBalpha constitutive expression , TNFalpha synthesis , and apoptosis in EBV-infected lymphoblastoid cells .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

In order to understand the role of NF-kappaB in EBV transformation we have established stably transfected IkappaBalpha into lymphoblastoid cells .
7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Two clones were obtained in which the loss of NF-kappaB binding activity correlated with the constitutive expression of the transgenic IkappaBalpha .
9,10 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Protein latency expression was determined by immunocytochemistry .


Expression of surface markers , intracytoplasmic content of cytokines cell cycle analysis after BrdU incorporation and DNA staining with propidium iodide were studied by flow cytometry .
8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Percentage of apoptotic cells was determined by in-situ labelling of DNA strand breaks .
2,4 G#cell_type

No significative changes in EBV latency nor in cell surface marker expression was found .


In contrast , intracytoplasmic TNFalpha levels were strongly reduced in transfected clones .
4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line

Furthermore , 30 % of IkappaBalpha transfected cells were apoptotic after 8 h of TNFalpha treatment .
5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein

This correlated with a strong reduction of BrdU incorporation after 24 h of TNFalpha treatment .
13,14 G#protein

No effect was seen with non transfected cells or with cells transfected with a control plasmid .
6,8 G#cell_line

Our results suggest that the TNFalpha gene could be one of the targets of NF-kappaB in EBV infected cells and that NF-kappaB protects EBV -infected cells from apoptosis induced by TNFalpha , which may favour the proliferative effect of this cytokine .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,26 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

Seminoma in a postmenopausal woman with a Y;15 translocation in peripheral blood lymphocytes and a t(Y;15)/45,X Turner mosaic pattern in skin fibroblasts .
7,9 G#DNA|10,13 G#cell_type|20,22 G#cell_type

We report an unusual case of a 55 year old Japanese woman with a seminoma but relatively normal menses .


The patient was a phenotypic female with late onset menarche ( 18 years of age ) , who was amenorrhoeic for the first year , followed by menses of one to three days ' slight flow with dysmenorrhoea , but an otherwise normal menstrual history .


A typical seminoma was removed from the left adnexal region and an immature testis was identified separately as an associated right adnexal mass .


Repeated karyotypic studies on peripheral blood lymphocyte cultures showed only 46,X,-Y,t(Y;15)(q12;p13) .
4,8 G#cell_type

Cytogenetic examination of the patient 's younger brother , who had fathered three healthy children , showed an identical karyotype .


Mosaicism of 46,X,-Y,t(Y;15)(q12;p13)/45,X cell lines was found in skin samples from the patient 's elbow and genital regions , although there were no clinical stigmata of Turner syndrome .
2,5 G#cell_line

An androgen receptor binding assay of cultured genital skin fibroblasts was negative .
8,10 G#cell_type|6,10 G#cell_line

Molecular analysis using Southern blot hybridisation , PCR , and direct DNA sequencing showed that neither the patient nor her brother had a detectable deletion or other abnormalities of Y chromosome sequences , including the SRY ( sex determining region of the Y chromosome ) gene sequence .
35,47 G#DNA

These findings suggest that Turner mosaicism of the 45,X cell line may have contributed to this atypical presentation in an XY female , although we can not exclude abnormalities of other genes related to sex differentiation .
8,11 G#cell_line

Potent inhibition of HIV type 1 replication by an antiinflammatory alkaloid , cepharanthine , in chronically infected monocytic cells .
15,19 G#cell_type

Cepharanthine is a biscoclaurine alkaloid isolated from Stephania cepharantha Hayata and has been shown to have antiinflammatory , antiallergic , and immunomodulatory activities in vivo .


As several inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stresses are involved in the pathogenesis of HIV-1 infection , we investigated the inhibitory effects of cepharanthine on tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) - and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) - induced HIV-1 replication in chronically infected cell lines .
3,4 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|44,48 G#cell_line

Two chronically HIV-1 -infected cell lines , U1 ( monocytic ) and ACH-2 ( T lymphocytic ) , were stimulated with TNF-alpha or PMA and cultured in the presence of various concentrations of the compound .
1,6 G#cell_line|7,8 G#cell_line|12,13 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein

HIV-1 replication was determined by p24 antigen level .
5,7 G#protein

The inhibitory effects of cepharanthine on HIV-1 long terminal repeat ( LTR ) -driven gene expression and nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) activation were also examined .
6,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|17,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Cepharanthine dose dependently inhibited HIV-1 replication in TNF-alpha- and PMA- stimulated U1 cells but not in ACH-2 cells .
7,13 G#cell_line|16,18 G#cell_line

Its 50 % effective and cytotoxic concentrations were 0.016 and 2.2 microg/ml in PMA -stimulated U1 cells , respectively .
13,17 G#cell_line

Cepharanthine was found to suppress HIV-1 LTR -driven gene expression through the inhibition of NF-kappaB activation .
5,7 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein

These results indicate that cepharanthine is a highly potent inhibitor of HIV-1 replication in a chronically infected monocytic cell line .
15,20 G#cell_line

Since biscoclaurine alkaloids , containing cepharanthine as a major component , are widely used for the treatment of patients with various inflammatory diseases in Japan , cepharanthine should be further pursued for its chemotherapeutic potential in HIV-1 -infected patients .


NF-kappaB only partially mediates Epstein-Barr virus latent membrane protein 1 activation of B cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,10 G#protein

The latent membrane protein 1 ( LMP1 ) of Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) is required for EBV -induced immortalization of human B cells and causes tumorigenic transformation of cell lines .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type|29,31 G#cell_line

LMP1 expression induces phenotypic changes resembling B cell activation , such as cell size increase and up-regulation of cell surface activation markers .
0,1 G#protein|18,22 G#protein

LMP1 contains two domains that activate the transcription factor NF-kappaB , one through interactions with TRAF proteins and the other with the TRADD protein .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

The purpose of the present study was to investigate the importance of NF-kappaB induction in the up-regulation of the B cell activation markers ICAM-1 and CD71 by LMP1 .
12,13 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

This study shows that expression of LMP1 activates transcription from p50/p65- and c-Rel- responsive promoters , and that this activity can be completely inhibited by expression of a dominant inhibitory IkappaB mutant .
6,7 G#protein|10,15 G#DNA|29,32 G#protein

ICAM-1 and CD71 are nevertheless up-regulated by LMP1 in primary B cells and cell lines expressing the dominant IkappaB .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type|17,19 G#protein

Furthermore , LMP1 -induced cell size increase of primary B cells was unaffected by IkappaB expression .
2,3 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

It was concluded that even when LMP1 is unable to activate NF-kappaB , it is still capable of inducing certain characteristics of activated B cells , strongly suggesting that LMP1 can also activate cells independently of NF-kappaB .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|22,25 G#cell_type|29,30 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Models of lineage switching in hematopoietic development : a new myeloid-committed eosinophil cell line ( YJ ) demonstrates trilineage potential .
10,14 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_line

A new human leukemia cell line with an eosinophilic phenotype , designated YJ , was established from the peripheral blood cells of a patient with chronic myelomonocytic leukemia ( CMMoL ) with eosinophilia .
2,6 G#cell_line|12,13 G#cell_line|18,21 G#cell_type

When cultured in RPMI 1640 medium containing 10 % fetal bovine serum , most YJ cells were myeloblastoid with a small number of the cells having eosinophilic granules .
14,16 G#cell_line

Cell surface markers in the YJ cells were positive for CD33 and were negative for CD34 , CD16 and CD23 .
0,3 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The eosinophilic characteristics of YJ cells were confirmed by histochemical staining with Fast-Green/Neutral-Red and by the expression of mRNAs for eosinophil-associated granule proteins , eosinophil cationic protein ( ECP ) , eosinophil-derived neurotoxin ( EDN ) , eosinophil peroxidase ( EPO ) , and major basic protein ( MBP ) , and for the Charcot-Leyden crystal ( CLC ) protein .
4,6 G#cell_line|18,19 G#RNA|20,23 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|44,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|54,60 G#protein

The YJ cells could be induced towards monocytic differentiation by stimulation with phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) .
1,3 G#cell_line

The monocytic characteristics of YJ cells treated with PMA were confirmed by morphological analysis with alpha-naphthyl butyrate esterase staining , by CD14 expression , and by increased expression of Egr-1 mRNA .
4,6 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|29,31 G#RNA

Furthermore , YJ cells could be differentiated towards the neutrophil lineage by stimulation with all-trans retinoic acid ( RA ) .
2,4 G#cell_line|9,11 G#cell_type

YJ cells treated in vitro with 2 microM RA differentiated into metamyelocytes and band neutrophils , and increased the number of nitroblue tetrazolium ( NBT ) -positive cells and increased gp91phox mRNA expression .
0,2 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type|21,28 G#cell_line|30,32 G#RNA

Thus , the YJ cell line exhibited eosinophilic characteristics , but was able to differentiate to the monocytic or neutrophilic lineages in response to PMA or RA , respectively .
3,6 G#cell_line|17,21 G#cell_type

The expression of genes for transcription factors involved in myeloid differentiation was evaluated by Northern blot analysis .
5,7 G#protein

Increased expression of Egr-1 was observed with macrophage differentiation .
3,4 G#protein

In contrast , increased expressions of C/EBPbeta and MZF-1 mRNA occurred with neutrophilic differentiation .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA

The YJ cell line should be useful for elucidating the molecular mechanisms governing lineage switching from the eosinophil to monocytic or neutrophil lineages .
1,4 G#cell_line|17,18 G#cell_type|19,23 G#cell_type

Interleukin-6 production in hemorrhagic shock is accompanied by neutrophil recruitment and lung injury .
0,1 G#protein

Hemorrhagic shock ( HS ) initiates an inflammatory cascade that includes the production of cytokines and recruitment of neutrophils ( PMN ) and may progress to organ failure , inducing acute respiratory distress syndrome ( ARDS ) .
14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#cell_type

To examine the hypothesis that interleukin-6 ( IL-6 ) contributes to PMN infiltration and lung damage in HS , we examined the lungs of rats subjected to unresuscitated and resuscitated HS for the production of IL-6 and activation of Stat3 .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Using semiquantitative RT- PCR , we found a striking increase in IL-6 mRNA levels only in resuscitated HS , with peak levels observed 1 h after initiation of resuscitation .
11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#RNA

Increased IL-6 protein expression was localized to bronchial and alveolar cells .
1,2 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_type

Electrophoretic mobility shift assay of protein extracts from shock lungs exhibited an increase in Stat3 activation with kinetics similar to IL-6 mRNA .
14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#RNA

In situ DNA binding assay determined Stat3 activation predominantly within alveoli .
6,7 G#protein

Intratracheal instillation of IL-6 alone into normal rats resulted in PMN infiltration into lung interstitium and alveoli , marked elevation of bronchoalveolar lavage cellularity , and increased wet-to-dry ratio .
3,4 G#protein

These findings indicate that IL-6 production and Stat3 activation occur early in HS and may contribute to PMN-mediated lung injury , including ARDS after HS .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

The MHC class II transactivator ( CIITA ) requires conserved leucine charged domains for interactions with the conserved W box promoter element .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|18,22 G#DNA

The class II transactivator CIITA is required for transcriptional activation of the major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class II genes .
1,4 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|12,21 G#DNA

Aside from an N-terminal acidic transcriptional activation domain , little is known about how this factor functions .
3,8 G#DNA

Extensive mutagenesis of CIITA was undertaken to identify structural motifs required for function .
3,4 G#protein

The ability of mutants to activate a reporter gene under the control of MHC class II conserved W-X-Y or X-Y regulatory elements was determined .
13,16 G#protein|17,22 G#DNA

Two mutants displayed differential activity between the two promoters , activating transcription with the W-X-Y but not the X-Y elements .
8,9 G#DNA|14,20 G#DNA

All mutants were tested for their ability to interfere with wild-type CIITA activity .
11,12 G#protein

Five CIITA mutant constructions were able to down-regulate wild-type CIITA activity .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein

Three of these mutants contained targeted disruptions of potential functional motifs : the acidic activation domain , a putative GTP -binding motif and two leucine charged domains ( LCD motifs ) .
13,16 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

The other two contained mutations in regions that do not have homology to described proteins .


The characterization of CIITA mutants that are able to discriminate between promoters with or without the W box strongly suggests that CIITA requires such interactions for function .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#protein|16,18 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

The identification of LCD motifs required for CIITA function brings to light a previously undefined role of these motifs in CIITA function .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

The peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha ( PPARalpha ) ligand WY 14,643 does not interfere with leukotriene B4 induced adhesion of neutrophils to endothelial cells .
1,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type|22,24 G#cell_type

Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptors ( PPAR ) control discrete genes involved in fatty acid and lipid metabolism .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

Recently , it was suggested that activation of the alpha isoform of PPAR by the potent proinflammatory mediator leukotriene B4 ( LTB4 ) enhanced degradation of this eicosanoid , offersuggesting a new aspect of down-regulation of inflammation .
9,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

Here , we studied whether PPARalpha activation ( by means of the selective agonist WY 14,643 ) of endothelial cells , pivotal in the regulation of inflammatory responses , interfered with LTB4 induced adhesion of PMN neutrophil granulocytes in vitro .
5,6 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|35,38 G#cell_type

When endothelial cells were treated with WY 14,643 prior to activation with LTB4 ( or fMLP , IL-1beta or TNFalpha , as controls ) we could not document any effect on the number of adhering PMN or duration of the response .
1,3 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|34,36 G#cell_type

Thus , this study provides no evidence indicating a regulatory function of PPARalpha in LTB4 induced adhesive interactions between endothelial cells and neutrophils
12,13 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type

Interaction of sickle erythrocytes with endothelial cells in the presence of endothelial cell conditioned medium induces oxidant stress leading to transendothelial migration of monocytes .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,7 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type

The abnormal adherence of sickle red blood cells ( SS RBC ) to endothelial cells has been thought to contribute to vascular occlusion , a major cause of morbidity in sickle cell disease ( SCD ) .
4,8 G#cell_type|9,11 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type

We determined whether the interaction of SS RBC with cultured endothelial cells induced cellular oxidant stress that would culminate in expression of cell adhesion molecules ( CAMs ) involved in the adhesion and diapedesis of monocytes and the adherence of SS reticulocytes .
6,8 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|35,36 G#cell_type|40,42 G#cell_type

We showed that the interaction of SS RBC at 2 % concentration in the presence of multimers of von Willebrand factor ( vWf ) , derived from endothelial cell-derived conditioned medium ( E-CM ) with cultured human umbilical vein endothelial cells ( HUVEC ) , resulted in a fivefold increased formation of thiobarbituric acid-reactive substances ( TBARS ) and activation of the transcription factor NF-kB , both indicators of cellular oxidant stress .
6,8 G#cell_type|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|39,41 G#cell_type|35,41 G#cell_line|42,43 G#cell_line|62,64 G#protein|64,65 G#protein

Normal RBC show none of these phenomena .
0,2 G#cell_type

The oxidant stress-induced signaling resulted in an increased surface expression of a subset of CAMs , ICAM-1 , E-selectin , and VCAM-1 in HUVEC .
14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_line

The addition of oxygen radical scavenger enzymes ( catalase , superoxide dismutase ) and antioxidant ( probucol ) inhibited these events .
3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Additionally , preincubation of HUVEC with a synthetic peptide Arg-Gly-Asp ( RGD ) that prevents vWf -mediated adhesion of SS RBC reduced the surface expression of VCAM-1 and NF-kB activation .
4,5 G#cell_line|15,16 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

Furthermore , SS RBC -induced oxidant stress resulted in a twofold increase in the transendothelial migration of both monocyte-like HL-60 cells and human peripheral blood monocytes , and approximately a sixfold increase in platelet-endothelial cell adhesion molecule-1 ( PECAM-1 ) phosphorylation , each of which was blocked by protein kinase C inhibitor and antioxidants .
2,4 G#cell_type|18,21 G#cell_line|25,26 G#cell_type|22,26 G#cell_type|33,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|48,51 G#protein

These results suggest that the adherence/contact of SS RBC to endothelial cells in large vessel can generate enhanced oxidant stress leading to increased adhesion and diapedesis of monocytes , as well as heightened adherence of SS reticulocytes , indicating that injury/activation of endothelium can contribute to vaso-occlusion in SCD .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|27,28 G#cell_type|35,37 G#cell_type

Signal transduction abnormalities in T lymphocytes from patients with advanced renal carcinoma : clinical relevance and effects of cytokine therapy .
4,6 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Studies have demonstrated abnormalities of the CD3/T-cell antigen receptor ( TCR ) and pathways of signal transduction in T lymphocytes from animals and patients with advanced malignancy .
6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type

Diminished expression of TCRzeta and p56(lck) that are associated with the TCR and reduced nuclear localization of RelA containing nuclear factor kappaB ( NFkappaB ) complexes have been noted .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|17,26 G#protein

These defects have been described in T cells from patients with malignant melanoma , renal cell carcinoma ( RCC ) , ovarian cancer , and colorectal cancer .
6,8 G#cell_type

Preliminary observations also indicate possible correlation with clinical variables such as stage in selected instances .


To further characterize altered expression of TCRzeta , p56(lck) , and impaired activation of NFkappaB , T lymphocytes were obtained from 65 patients with RCC , the majority of whom were receiving combination cytokine therapy [ interleukin ( IL ) -2 , IFN alpha -containing regimens ] and 37 control individuals .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|33,34 G#protein|36,41 G#protein|42,44 G#protein

In 29 of these patients , levels of TCRzeta and p56(lck) were determined by Western blots of T-cell lysates and semiquantitated using densitometry .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Relative levels were then correlated with a series of clinical variables including response to therapy , performance status , survival , disease sites , age , and others .


In another group of 28 patients ( three individuals from the first group ) , the frequency of abnormal NFkappaB activation was studied using electrophoretic mobility shift assays after activation of T cells with phorbol myristate acetate/ionomycin or anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody .
19,20 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type|38,41 G#protein

Changes in these signaling molecules during cytokine treatment were also investigated .
6,7 G#protein

TCRzeta and p56(lck) were detected in the peripheral blood T cells in 27 of 29 patients , and overall , reduced levels were noted visually in 12 of 29 ( 41 % ) and 13 of 29 ( 45 % ) individuals , respectively .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|7,11 G#cell_type

When levels were semiquantitated using densitometry , significant decreases of TCRzeta ( P = 0.029 ) and p56(lck) ( P = 0.029 ) but not CD3epsilon ( P = 0.131 ) , compared with control levels , were found .
10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

In patients treated with IL-2/ IFN alpha -based therapy , relative levels of TCRzeta increased significantly ( P = 0.002 ) on day 15 of cycle one compared with the baseline .
5,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Correlations of TCRzeta or p56(lck) levels with response or disease variables , except for lower TCRzeta levels ( P &lt; 0.001 ) in the presence of bone metastases , were not found .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Abnormal NFkappaB activation after stimulation with phorbol myristate acetate/ionomycin and/or anti-CD3 monoclonal antibody was found in 59 % of patients ( 17 of 28 ) and was not accounted for by the advanced age of the study cohort .
1,2 G#protein|10,13 G#protein

Activation of NFkappaB in peripheral blood T cells was inducible during cytokine therapy in four of six individuals who displayed impaired NFkappaB activity prior to therapy .
2,3 G#protein|4,8 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Moreover , impaired activation of NFkappaB does not appear linked to a reduction of TCRzeta expression , because in five patients , normal TCRzeta levels were present although kappaB binding was not inducible .
5,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

In the majority of patients with advanced RCC , peripheral blood T cells express TCRzeta and p56(lck) , and in a subset , reduced levels of these TCRzeta associated molecules are seen that may increase during cytokine -based therapy .
9,13 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Abnormal activation of NFkappaB is also present in &gt; 50 % of patients and may also revert to normal during IL-2/ IFN alpha -based treatment .
3,4 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

This alteration in NFkappaB activation occurred in the presence of normal expression of TCRzeta -associated signaling elements .
3,4 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,17 G#DNA

The clinical significance of these findings remains unclear .


Identification of transcription factors expressed during ATRA-induced neutrophil differentiation of HL60 cells .
2,4 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line

A recent clinical therapeutic initiative has been the use of chemical agents which induce the leukaemic cells to overcome their block in differentiation .
15,17 G#cell_type

In order to understand this block the cascade of molecular events needs to be characterized .


Haemopoietic differentiation is ultimately controlled at the level of gene transcription which is mediated by an array of transcription factors .
18,20 G#protein

Many transcription factors contain similar structural protein sequences , and we have used an RT-PCR -based approach to isolate sequences , from transcription factor gene families which share similar domains .
1,3 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Degenerate primers corresponding to the TFIIIA zinc-finger consensus amino acid sequences and to the POU-homeodomain and POU-specific domain were used to amplify genes on the basis that they contained similarities in structural motifs shared within these families of transcription factors .
5,7 G#protein|5,11 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

A serum-independent HL60 cell line was induced towards the neutrophil lineage by treatment with all-trans retinoic acid ( ATRA ) for 24 h .
2,5 G#cell_line|1,5 G#cell_line

CD38+ cells committed towards this lineage were enriched and a population of these cells treated with dihydroxyvitamin D3 to induce neutrophil maturation .
0,2 G#cell_type

RNA extracted from uninduced , ATRA -induced CD38+ cells , and vitamin D3 treated maturing cell cultures were amplified using the degenerate primers .
7,9 G#cell_type|5,9 G#cell_line|11,17 G#cell_line

PCR fragments were cloned , sequenced , clustered into homologous groups , and the group sequences searched on the GenBank database .
0,2 G#DNA

The Oct 1 transcription factor , and a very close homologue , KIAA0144 , was identified using the POU family primers .
3,5 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA

The zinc-finger primers identified three zinc-finger genes .


The pattern of gene expression was suggested from the number of clones in each group at neutrophil commitment and maturation .


The differential expression of the genes in the zinc finger and POU families will lead to a better understanding of the cascade of gene expression which occurs following ATRA -induced differentiation .
8,13 G#protein

GATA-3 -dependent enhancer activity in IL-4 gene regulation .
0,1 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA

Previously , we analyzed the proximal IL-4 promoter in directing Th2-specific activity .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA

An 800-base pair proximal promoter conferred some Th2-selective expression in transgenic mice .
1,5 G#DNA

However , this region directed extremely low reporter mRNA levels relative to endogenous IL-4 mRNA , suggesting that full gene activity requires additional enhancer elements .
13,14 G#protein|13,15 G#RNA|23,25 G#DNA

Here , we analyzed large genomic IL-4 regions for enhancer activity and interaction with transcription factors .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein

The proximal IL-4 promoter is only moderately augmented by GATA-3 , but certain genomic regions significantly enhanced GATA-3 promoter transactivation .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|9,10 G#protein|13,15 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA

Some enhancing regions contained consensus , GATA sites that bound Th2-specific complexes .
6,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#protein

However , retroviral transduction of GATA-3 into developing T cells induced IL-5 to full Th2 levels , but only partially restored IL-4 production .
5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Thus , we propose that GATA-3 is permissive , but not sufficient , for full IL-4 enhancement and may act through GATA elements surrounding the IL-13 / IL-4 gene locus .
5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#DNA|25,30 G#DNA

Position effect of translocations involving the inactive X chromosome : physical linkage to XIC/XIST does not lead to long-range de novo inactivation in human differentiated cells .
6,9 G#DNA|13,14 G#DNA|23,26 G#cell_type

Given the reported long-range cis-inactivating effect of the XIST gene in early embryonic development and the lack of requirement of X- chromosome-specific elements for propagating the inactive state , there exists the possibility of cis inactivation of autosomal material after de novo translocation to an inactive X chromosome ( Xi ) in differentiated cells .
8,10 G#DNA|20,23 G#DNA|45,48 G#DNA|49,50 G#DNA|52,54 G#cell_type

We have analyzed de novo radiation-induced translocations between the Xi and autosomes to study the maintenance and spreading of X-chromosome inactivation ( X inactivation ) in relation to the position of the X-inactivation center ( XIC ) /XIST in differentiated cells .
9,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|34,38 G#DNA|39,41 G#cell_type

Autosome/ Xi translocations were detected by fluorescence in situ hybridization ( FISH ) .
1,2 G#DNA

The activation status of the chromosomes involved in the translocation was determined by simultaneous immunocytogenetic studies using antibodies against either BrdU incorporated at late S phase or acetylated histone H4 .
5,6 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|27,30 G#protein

The position of XIC/XIST in the reciprocal products of the translocation was determined by XIST-specific FISH and computer enhancement .
3,4 G#DNA

In other experiments , the Xq13 region carrying XIC/XIST was localized by computer enhancement of the DAPI banding pattern .
5,7 G#DNA|8,9 G#DNA

Our study in differentiated cells provides a visual demonstration that physical separation from XIC/XIST does not result in reactivation of inactive X-chromosome material and that X inactivation is not spread to the translocated autosomes irrespective of the position of XIC/XIST .
3,5 G#cell_type|13,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|32,34 G#DNA|39,40 G#DNA

This observation suggests that physical linkage to XIC/XIST does not lead to de novo inactivation of autosomal material .
7,8 G#DNA

Interleukin -4 and -13 induce upregulation of the murine macrophage 12/15-lipoxygenase activity : evidence for the involvement of transcription factor STAT6 .
0,4 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

When human monocytes or alveolar macrophages are cultured in the presence of interleukin ( IL ) -4 or IL-13 , the expression of the reticulocyte-type 15-lipoxygenase is induced .
2,3 G#cell_type|4,6 G#cell_type|12,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

In mice a 15-lipoxygenase is not expressed , but a leukocyte-type 12-lipoxygenase is present in peritoneal macrophages .
3,4 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

To investigate whether both lipoxygenase isoforms exhibit a similar regulatory response toward cytokine stimulation , we studied the regulation of the leukocyte-type 12-lipoxygenase of murine peritoneal macrophages by interleukins and found that the activity of this enzyme is upregulated in a dose-dependent manner when the cells were cultured in the presence of the IL-4 or IL-13 but not by IL-10 .
4,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type|24,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|53,54 G#protein|55,56 G#protein|59,60 G#protein

When peripheral murine monocytes that do not express the lipoxygenase were treated with IL-4 expression of 12/15-lipoxygenase mRNA was induced , suggesting pretranslational control mechanisms .
3,4 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,18 G#RNA

In contrast , no upregulation of the lipoxygenase activity was observed when the macrophages were prepared from homozygous STAT6 -deficient mice .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

Peritoneal macrophages of transgenic mice that systemically overexpress IL-4 exhibited a threefold to fourfold higher 12-lipoxygenase activity than cells prepared from control animals .
1,2 G#cell_type|0,2 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

A similar upregulation of 12-lipoxygenase activity was detected in heart , spleen , and lung of the transgenic animals .
4,5 G#protein

Moreover , a strong induction of the enzyme was observed in red cells during experimental anemia in mice .
11,13 G#cell_type

The data presented here indicate that ( 1 ) the 12-lipoxygenase activity of murine macrophages is upregulated in vitro and in vivo by IL-4 and/or IL-13 , ( 2 ) this upregulation requires expression of the transcription factor STAT6 , and ( 3 ) the constitutive expression of the enzyme appears to be STAT6 independent .
10,11 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|53,54 G#protein

The cytokine -dependent upregulation of the murine macrophage 12-lipoxygenase and its induction during experimental anemia suggests its close relatedness with the human reticulocyte-type 15-lipoxygenase despite their differences in the positional specificity of arachidonic acid oxygenation .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|21,24 G#protein

Interferon-gamma-induced factor binding to the interleukin-4 -responsive element of CD23b promoter in human tonsillar mononuclear cells : role in transient up-regulation of the interleukin-4 -induced CD23b mRNA .
0,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|12,16 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|25,27 G#RNA|23,27 G#RNA

Stimulation of human tonsillar mononuclear cells with interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) and interferon-gamma ( IFN-gamma ) rapidly induced the activation of distinct nuclear factors with different mobilities , both of which bind the IL-4 response element ( IL-4RE ) of CD23b promoter as examined by electrophoretic mobility shift assays ( EMSA ) .
2,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|33,36 G#DNA|37,38 G#DNA|40,42 G#DNA

Co-treatment of IL-4 and IFN-gamma induced , in addition to the two distinct complexes , a new complex with an intermediate mobility .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

The IL-4 -induced complex reacted with anti- STAT ( signal transducers and activators of transcription ) 6 , resulting in a supershift whereas the formation of the IFN-gamma -induced complex was inhibited by anti- STAT 1 .
1,2 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|7,17 G#protein|6,17 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|34,36 G#protein|33,36 G#protein

The intermediate complex appeared to react with both anti- STAT 6 and anti- STAT 1 .
9,11 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|12,15 G#protein

Although IFN-gamma alone did not induce CD23 mRNA transcription , Northern blot analysis revealed a transient up-regulation of the IL-4 -induced CD23 mRNA by IFN-gamma within 2 h of IFN-gamma treatment in these tonsillar cells .
1,2 G#protein|6,8 G#RNA|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#RNA|19,23 G#RNA|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,35 G#cell_type

The results suggest that the IL-4RE of the IL-4 -inducible gene can accommodate both IL-4- and IFN-gamma- activated factors , such as STAT 6 and STAT 1 , either in homodimeric or heterodimeric forms and the binding of these different proteins to the respective promoter may play a potential regulatory role in the IL-4 - inducible gene expression .
5,6 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|14,19 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|30,34 G#protein|53,54 G#protein

A p56lck -independent pathway of CD2 signaling involves Jun kinase .
1,2 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,10 G#protein

The p56 Src family non-receptor tyrosine kinase has been shown to be critical for T lymphocyte differentiation and activation .
1,7 G#protein

Hence in the absence of p56 , T cell receptor triggered activation does not occur .
5,6 G#protein|7,10 G#protein

We now provide evidence for a CD2 -based signaling pathway which , in contrast to that of the T cell receptor , is independent of p56 .
6,7 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

CD2 -mediated interleukin-2 production occurs via activation of Jun kinase in cell lines lacking p56 .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Jun kinase then facilitates the binding of c-Jun/c-Fos heterodimers to the AP-1 consensus site and the subsequent transcriptional activity of the interleukin-2 promoter .
0,2 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

These data elucidate differences between TCR and CD2 signaling pathways in the same T cells .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Activation of E2F -mediated transcription by human T-cell leukemia virus type I Tax protein in a p16 ( INK4A ) -negative T-cell line .
2,3 G#protein|6,14 G#protein|16,23 G#cell_line

The human T-cell leukemia virus type I ( HTLV-I ) is a causative agent of adult T-cell leukemia .


Although the exact mechanism by which HTLV-I contributes to leukemogenesis is still unclear , the Tax protein is thought to play a major role in this process .
15,17 G#protein

This 40-kDa polypeptide is able to interact with the tumor suppressor p16 ( INK4A ) .
9,11 G#protein|11,15 G#protein

Consequently , Tax can activate the signaling pathway that lead to the release of E2F that in turn induces expression of factors required for cell cycle progression .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

In this paper , we demonstrate that Tax can also activate E2F -mediated transcription independently of p16 ( INK4A ) .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,20 G#protein

Indeed , when Tax is coexpressed with the E2F-1 transcription factor in CEM T-cells , which lack expression of p16 ( INK4A ) , it strongly potentiates the E2F -dependent activation of a reporter construct driven by a promoter containing E2F binding sites .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|19,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|40,43 G#DNA

This stimulation is abrogated by mutations affecting the E2F -binding sites .
8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA

In addition , Tax also stimulates the transcription of the E2F-1 gene itself .
3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

Using Tax mutants that fail to activate either ATF - or NF-kappaB-dependent promoters and different 5' truncation mutants of the E2F-1 promoter , we show that the Tax -dependent transcriptional control of the E2F1 gene involves , at least in part , the ATF binding site located in the E2F-1 promoter .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA|15,18 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|33,35 G#DNA|43,46 G#DNA|49,50 G#protein|49,51 G#DNA

Inducible nitric oxide : an autoregulatory feedback inhibitor of vascular inflammation .


Inducible nitric oxide ( iNO ) is produced at sites of vascular inflammation by resident and nonresident vascular wall cells , but its role in the inflammatory process is not known .
17,20 G#cell_type

In this study , we show that a novel function of iNO is to terminate inflammatory processes .


We find that iNO produced by murine macrophage-like cells , RAW264.7 , can inhibit cytokine -induced endothelial cell activation in a separated and mixed endothelial-RAW264.7 coculture system .
6,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_line|24,27 G#cell_line

Both iNO production and endothelial VCAM-1 expression were induced simultaneously with bacterial LPS and murine-specific IFN-gamma .
5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Inhibition of iNO synthase ( iNOS ) activity with N omega-monomethyl-L-arginine in endothelial-RAW264.7 cocultures , stimulated with murine-specific IFN-gamma and LPS , decreased iNO production by 86 % , augmented VCAM-1 and iNOS expression in endothelial and RAW264.7 cells , respectively , and increased monocyte adhesion to the endothelial cell surface .
2,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_line

Transient transfection studies using various VCAM-1 promoter constructs demonstrated that inhibitory effects of iNO on VCAM-1 gene transcription were mediated , in part , by inhibitory effects of iNO on kappa B cis-acting elements .
5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|30,34 G#DNA

Immunofluorescence studies using an Ab to the RelA ( p65 ) subunit of nuclear factor-kappa B revealed that iNO inhibited the activation of nuclear factor-kappa B .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|23,26 G#protein

These studies indicate that iNO attenuates iNOS expression in macrophages and inhibits monocyte adhesion to endothelial cells , and suggest that endogenously derived iNO may be an important autoregulatory inhibitor of vascular inflammation
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type

Detection of oestrogen receptor variants in endometrium , myometrium , leiomyoma and peripheral blood mononuclear cells : comparison to variants present in breast cancer .
2,5 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type

Oestradiol has mitogenic and regulatory effects on various organs and cells , mediated mainly by its nuclear receptor ( ER ) .
16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The presence of aberrant ER forms in Oestrogen-dependent tumours has been discussed in correlation with tumour progression .
4,5 G#protein

ER variants , generated by alternative splicing , have been detected in human breast cancer , but also in normal mammary glands , therefore their role in tumorigenesis has been questioned .
0,1 G#protein

We have investigated , by the use of the reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction amplification technique , the possible existence of ER variants in other normal oestrogen target organs and cells , such as uterus ( myometrium and endometrium ) , in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and in a benign uterus tumour ( leiomyoma ) .
21,22 G#protein|42,46 G#cell_type

We have detected variant ER in these samples and have compared the variant profile to that observed in breast cancer .
4,5 G#protein

All tissues and cells studied expressed both wild-type ER and variant species .
8,9 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Variant forms encompassed ER with deletions of exons 2 , 5 and 7 .
3,4 G#protein|7,13 G#DNA

Variants with exon 5 deleted were detected only in peripheral blood mononuclear cells and in breast cancer .
2,4 G#DNA|9,13 G#cell_type

Variants with exons 2 and 7 deleted were present in all specimens tested .
2,6 G#DNA

These results corroborate previous findings that the presence of ER variants is not a characteristic of breast cancer .
9,10 G#protein

The physiological significance and possible clinical relevance of the variant ER forms remain to be elucidated .
10,11 G#protein

p21ras initiates Rac-1 but not phosphatidyl inositol 3 kinase /PKB , mediated signaling pathways in T lymphocytes .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|5,10 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

p21ras is activated by the T cell antigen receptor ( TCR ) and then co-ordinates important signaling pathways for T lymphocyte activation .
0,1 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|19,21 G#protein

Effector pathways for this guanine nucleotide binding protein in T cells are mediated by the serine/threonine kinase Raf-1 and the Ras-related GTPase Rac-1 .
4,8 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|15,17 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

In fibroblasts , an important effector for the Ras oncogene is Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase ( PtdIns 3-kinase ) .
1,2 G#cell_type|8,10 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Activation of this lipid kinase is able to induce critical Rac-1 signaling pathways and can couple p21ras to cell survival mechanisms via the serine /threonine kinase Akt/PKB .
3,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,27 G#protein

The role of PtdIns 3-kinase in Ras signaling in T cells has not been explored .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

In the present study , we examined the ability of PtdIns 3-kinase to initiate the Rac-1 signaling pathways important for T cell activation .
10,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

We also examined the possibility that Akt/PKB is regulated by Ras signaling pathways in T lymphocytes .
6,7 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type

The results show that Ras can initiate a Rac-1 mediated pathway that regulates the transcriptional function of AP-1 complexes .
4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

PtdIns 3-kinase signals can not mimic p21ras and induce the Rac mediated responses of AP-1 transcriptional activation .
0,2 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Moreover , neither TCR or Ras activation of AP-1 is dependent on PtdIns 3-kinase .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,14 G#protein

PKB is activated in response to triggering of the T cell antigen receptor ; PtdIns 3-kinase activity is both required and sufficient for this TCR response .
0,1 G#protein|9,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

In contrast , p21ras signals are unable to induce Akt/PKB activity in T cell nor is Ras function required for Akt/PKB activation in response to the TCR .
3,4 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

The present data thus highlight that PtdIns 3-kinase and Akt/PKB are not universal Ras effector molecules .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#protein

Ras can initiate Rac-1 regulated signaling pathways in the context of T cell antigen receptor function independently of PtdIns 3-kinase activity .
0,1 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Interleukin 1beta mediates the modulatory effects of monocytes on LNCaP human prostate cancer cells .
0,2 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_type|9,14 G#cell_type

Proliferative and secretory responses in androgen-sensitive prostate cancer LNCaP cells are regulated by steroid and peptide hormones and by differentiation-promoting substances .
5,10 G#cell_type

In the present study , we evaluated whether peripheral blood monocytes that exhibit anti-tumour activity in haematopoietic and solid tumours influence growth and secretion in the LNCaP cell line .
10,11 G#cell_type|8,11 G#cell_type|26,29 G#cell_line

For this purpose , LNCaP cells were incubated with monocyte-conditioned medium ( MCM ) , and proliferation as well as expression of androgen receptor ( AR ) and secretion of prostate-specific antigen ( PSA ) were assessed .
4,6 G#cell_line|22,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

Conditioned medium from monocytes reduced proliferation in a dose-dependent manner .
3,4 G#cell_type

Incubation with 40 % MCM caused a 50 % reduction in cell proliferation .


AR protein decreased by 70 % and PSA levels in supernatants from LNCaP cells were reduced by approximately 80 % following treatment with MCM .
0,1 G#protein|0,2 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line

We focused on the contribution of two major products of activated monocytes , prostaglandin E2 and interleukin 1beta ( IL-1beta ) , to the MCM modulatory action .
11,12 G#cell_type|16,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

LNCaP cells treated with prostaglandin E2 showed neither a reduction in proliferation nor a down-regulation of AR and PSA levels .
0,2 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

The effects of MCM on cellular proliferation , AR protein and PSA secretion were abolished by pretreatment of MCM with a neutralizing anti- IL-1beta antibody .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

In addition , recombinant IL-1beta was able to replace MCM for the inhibition of proliferation and down-regulation of AR and PSA proteins .
4,5 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

LNCaP cells were shown to express the IL-1beta receptor type 1 , which transduces IL-1beta signal .
0,2 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Our findings reveal that monocyte-derived IL-1beta inhibits the proliferation of androgen-responsive prostate tumour cells and reduces AR and PSA levels .

Differential responsiveness of the IL-5 and IL-4 genes to transcription factor GATA-3 .
4,8 G#DNA|9,12 G#protein

The cytokines IL-4 and IL-5 are often coordinately produced by Th2 cells as in asthma .
1,2 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line

However , it is unclear whether similar molecular mechanisms underlie transcription of the two genes .
14,15 G#DNA

We have previously shown that the transcription factor GATA-3 is expressed in Th2 but not Th1 cells and is crucial for activation of the IL-5 promoter by different stimuli .
6,9 G#protein|12,17 G#cell_line|24,25 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA

In a different study , GATA-3 was shown to be sufficient for the expression of IL-4 and other Th2 cytokine genes .
5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

Here , we show that ectopic expression of GATA-3 is sufficient to drive IL-5 but not IL-4 gene expression .
8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Also , in Th2 cells , antisense GATA-3 RNA inhibits IL-5 but not IL-4 promoter activation .
3,5 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

The induction of IL-5 gene expression by GATA-3 involves high affinity binding of GATA-3 to an inverted GATA repeat in the IL-5 promoter .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein|21,23 G#DNA

The interleukin 2 receptor alpha chain /CD25 promoter is a target for nuclear factor of activated T cells .
1,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|1,8 G#DNA|12,18 G#protein

The expression of the murine interleukin ( IL ) -2 receptor alpha chain /CD25 is strongly induced at the transcriptional level after T cell activation .
4,13 G#protein|4,14 G#protein

We show here that nuclear factor of activated T cell ( NF-AT ) factors are involved in the control of CD25 promoter induction in T cells .
4,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|24,26 G#cell_type

NF-ATp and NF-ATc bind to two sites around positions -585 and -650 located upstream of the proximal CD25 promoter .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|8,12 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA

Immediately 3' from these NF-AT motifs , nonconsensus sites are located for the binding of AP-1 -like factors .
4,6 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

Mutations of sites that suppress NF-AT binding impair the induction and strong NF-ATp -mediated transactivation of the CD25 promoter in T cells .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_type

In T lymphocytes from NF-ATp -deficient mice , the expression of CD25 is severely impaired , leading to a delayed IL-2 receptor expression after T cell receptor ( TCR ) / CD3 stimulation .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

Our data indicate an important role for NF-AT in the faithful expression of high affinity IL-2 receptors and a close link between the TCR -mediated induction of IL-2 and IL-2 receptor alpha chain promoters , both of which are regulated by NF-AT factors .
7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#DNA|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|29,33 G#protein|29,34 G#DNA|41,42 G#protein|41,43 G#protein

A novel mutation in the coding sequence of the FY*B allele of the Duffy chemokine receptor gene is associated with an altered erythrocyte phenotype .
9,11 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA

The Duffy blood group system is of clinical and biological significance .


Antibodies to Duffy antigens are responsible for some cases of transfusion incompatibility and newborn hemolytic disease .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#protein

The Duffy protein is a receptor for the Plasmodium vivax erythrocyte-binding protein and is also a receptor for various chemokines ( thus renamed Duffy Antigen Receptor for Chemokines [ DARC ] ) .
1,3 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

The two Duffy polymorphic antigens , Fya and Fyb ( coded by the FY*A and FY*B alleles ) , are present on erythrocyte membranes .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,17 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein

The Fy(a-b-) phenotype is the predominant one in populations of black people and also occurs in other populations , including some non-Ashkenazi Jewish groups .


The Fy(a-b-) phenotype has been associated with a mutation in the FY*B promoter at the GATA box that abolishes the expression of erythrocyte Duffy protein .
11,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|23,25 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

We describe here a novel mutation , present in the FY*B coding sequence ( 271C --&gt; T ) , that is associated with some Fy(b-) phenotypes among non-Ashkenazi Jews and among Brazilian blacks .
10,13 G#DNA

The mutation is present in Fy(b-) individuals , who have wild-type FY*B GATA and carry the previously described 304G --&gt; A substitution .
10,13 G#DNA

The 271C --&gt; T and 304G --&gt; A can be identified by restriction enzyme-generated restriction fragment length polymorphisms .
12,18 G#DNA

The 271C --&gt; T substitution represents a considerable change in chemical nature ( Arg91 --&gt; Cys ) , one which may affect the antigenic determinants of DARC , and thus be of clinical significance .
26,27 G#protein

The mutation may have implications for some physiological roles of DARC and be of interest in malaria research and in studies of population genetics .
10,11 G#protein

Establishment and characterization of EBV-positive and EBV-negative primary effusion lymphoma cell lines harbouring human herpesvirus type-8 .
4,12 G#cell_line

In this study we report on the establishment and characterization of two novel lymphoma cell lines ( CRO-AP/3 and CRO-AP/5 ) which carry infection by human herpesvirus type-8 ( HHV-8 ) and have derived from AIDS-related primary effusion lymphoma ( PEL ) .
13,16 G#cell_line|17,18 G#cell_line|19,20 G#cell_line|40,41 G#cell_line

These two cell lines are representative of different virologic subtypes of PEL , i.e. HHV-8 +/EBV- PEL in the case of CRO-AP/3 and HHV-8 +/EBV+ PEL in the case of CRO-AP/5 .
2,4 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_line|14,17 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_line|21,26 G#cell_line|30,31 G#cell_line

Consistent with the diagnosis of PEL , both CRO-AP/3 and CRO-AP/5 expressed indeterminate ( i.e. non-B , non-T ) phenotypes although immunogenotypic studies documented their B-cell origin .
5,6 G#cell_line|8,9 G#cell_line|10,11 G#cell_line|25,27 G#cell_type

Both cell lines are devoid of genetic lesions of c-MYC , BCL-2 and p53 as well as gross rearrangements of BCL-6 .
1,3 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Detailed histogenetic characterization of these novel PEL cell lines suggests that PEL may derive from a post-germinal centre B cell which has undergone pre-terminal differentiation .
6,9 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_line|16,20 G#cell_line

The CRO-AP/3 and CRO-AP/5 cell lines may provide a valuable model for clarifying the pathogenesis of PEL .
1,2 G#cell_line|3,6 G#cell_line|16,17 G#cell_line

In particular , these cell lines may help understand the relative contribution of HHV-8 and EBV to PEL growth and development and may facilitate the identification of recurrent cytogenetic abnormalities highlighting putative novel cancer related loci relevant to PEL .
