Two-site interaction of nuclear factor of activated T cells with activated calcineurin .
7,9 G#cell_type|3,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Transcription factors belonging to the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NFAT ) family regulate the expression of cytokine genes and other inducible genes during the immune response .
0,2 G#protein|5,11 G#protein|5,15 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA

The functions of NFAT proteins are directly controlled by the calcium- and calmodulin- dependent phosphatase calcineurin .
3,5 G#protein|10,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Here we show that the binding of calcineurin to NFAT is substantially increased when calcineurin is activated with calmodulin and calcium .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

FK506.FKBP12 drug-immunophilin complexes inhibited the interaction of NFAT with activated calcineurin much more effectively than they inhibited the interaction with inactive calcineurin , suggesting that part of the interaction with activated calcineurin involved the enzyme active site .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,37 G#DNA

We have previously shown that NFAT is targeted to inactive calcineurin at a region distinct from the calcineurin active site ( Aramburu , J. , Garcia-Cozar , F. J. , Raghavan , A. , Okamura , H. , Rao , A. , and Hogan , P. G. ( 1998 ) Mol. Cell 1 , 627-637 ) ; this region is also involved in NFAT binding to activated calcineurin , since binding is inhibited by an NFAT peptide spanning the calcineurin docking site on NFAT .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,20 G#DNA|63,64 G#protein|67,68 G#protein|79,80 G#protein|83,84 G#protein

The interacting surfaces are located on the catalytic domain of the calcineurin A chain and on an 86-amino acid fragment of the NFAT regulatory domain .
7,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|17,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

NFAT binding to the calcineurin catalytic domain was inhibited by the calcineurin autoinhibitory domain and the RII substrate peptide , which bind in the calcineurin active site , as well as by the NFAT docking site peptide , which binds to a region of calcineurin distinct from the active site .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|48,50 G#protein

We propose that , in resting cells , NFAT is targeted to a region of the calcineurin catalytic domain that does not overlap the calcineurin active site .
5,7 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

Upon cell activation , displacement of the autoinhibitory domain by calmodulin binding allows NFAT to bind additionally to the calcineurin active site , thus positioning NFAT for immediate dephosphorylation at functional phosphoserine residues .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Nuclear factor-kappaB induction in CD45RO+ and CD45RA+ T cell subsets during aging .
0,2 G#protein|4,10 G#cell_type

An increase in the ratio of memory to naive T cells has been postulated to underlie immune hyporesponsiveness accompanying aging .
6,11 G#cell_type

Our analyses of the induction of nuclear factor-kappaB ( NFkappaB ) in activated memory ( CD45RO+ ) and naive ( CD45RA+ ) T cell subsets from young and elderly donors has demonstrated that , regardless of donor age , memory T cells are not significantly altered in their responsiveness to TNF-alpha -mediated induction of NFkappaB .
6,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|13,25 G#cell_type|39,42 G#cell_type|50,51 G#protein|54,55 G#protein

Although treatment with TNF-alpha induced nuclear localization of NFkappaB in both memory and naive T cell subsets , irrespective of the age of the donor , the levels of induced NFkappaB were significantly lower in both subsets of T cells obtained from the elderly , when compared to those in young .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,17 G#cell_type|30,31 G#protein|38,40 G#cell_type

Examination of IkappaB alpha regulation revealed that TNF-alpha -mediated degradation of IkappaB alpha in both memory and naive T cells from the elderly was severely impaired , thus contributing to the lowered induction of the observed NFkappaB .
2,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,20 G#cell_type|36,37 G#protein

In addition , this age-related decrease in induction of nuclear NFkappaB correlated with decrease in intracellular IL-2 receptor expression and anti-CD3 -induced proliferation of both memory and naive T cells subsets .
10,11 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,31 G#cell_type

Taken together , our results suggest that the age-related hyporesponsiveness can not be attributed to a skewing of the T cell population towards a memory phenotype in the elderly .


Cyclosporin A -resistant transactivation of the IL-2 promoter requires activity of okadaic acid-sensitive serine /threonine phosphatases .
6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|11,16 G#protein

Expression of the IL-2 gene requires activation of T cells through stimulation of the TCR and costimulation through accessory receptors .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|8,10 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

We have found recently that okadaic acid-sensitive Ser /Thr phosphatases are involved in a cyclosporin A -insensitive pathway that selectively transmits costimulatory signals .
5,10 G#protein

In this study , we analyzed whether activities of these phosphatases are necessary for the expression of the IL-2 gene .
18,19 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA

In both activated peripheral blood T lymphocytes and activated tumorigenic T cell lines , IL-2 gene expression was blocked at the transcriptional level by okadaic acid .
5,7 G#cell_type|2,7 G#cell_type|8,13 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein

The transcription factors active at the IL-2 promoter were differentially influenced : upon down-modulation of okadaic acid -sensitive phosphatases , transactivation by octamer , NF-kappa B , and NF of activated T cells proteins was abrogated , while transactivation by AP-1 proteins was even enhanced .
1,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|6,8 G#DNA|15,19 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|28,34 G#protein|40,41 G#protein|40,46 G#protein

YM268 increases the glucose uptake , cell differentiation , and mRNA expression of glucose transporter in 3T3-L1 adipocytes .
13,15 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type

The purpose of this study was to examine the effects of bis[4-[2,4-dioxo-5-thiazolidinyl)methyl]phenyl] methane ( YM-268 ) , a thiazolidinedione derivative , on glucose uptake , adipocyte differentiation through peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma ( PPARgamma ) , and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase ( PI 3-kinase ) activity in cultured cells .
25,26 G#cell_type|28,32 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|37,39 G#protein|40,42 G#protein|45,47 G#cell_line

YM268 and pioglitazone dose-dependently increased the 2-deoxyglucose uptake in 3T3-L1 cells .
9,11 G#cell_line

YM268 facilitated the insulin-stimulated triglyceride accumulation in 3T3-L1 adipocytes and increased the mRNA expression of fatty acid-binding protein .
7,9 G#cell_type|15,18 G#protein

YM268 , with and without insulin , increased the mRNA expression of glucose transporter isoforms such as GLUT1 and GLUT4 , indicating enhancement of adipocyte differentiation .
12,14 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|24,25 G#cell_type

Additionally , YM268 and pioglitazone showed activity of the PPARgamma ligand , a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily responsible for adipogenesis .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|16,19 G#protein

To examine the possible involvement of the increased activity of PI 3-kinase in YM268 -stimulated glucose uptake , the enzyme activity was estimated by measuring the phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-trisphosphate ( PI-3,4,5-P3 ) concentration in human monocytic cells .
10,12 G#protein|32,35 G#cell_type

Insulin dose-dependently increased the PI-3,4,5-P3 production but YM268 had no significant effect on the insulin -dependent and -independent PI 3-kinase activation .


These results indicate that the mechanism by which YM268 increased glucose uptake , may be accounted for in part by the enhancement of GLUT1 and GLUT4 expression through PPARgamma activation .
23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The nuclear receptor PPARgamma - bigger than fat .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

Work reported over the past year has provided insights into the mechanisms whereby ligand activation of the nuclear receptor peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma ( PPARgamma ) regulates systemic glucose and lipid homeostasis .
17,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

PPARgamma has also been implicated recently in the biology of monocytes and in cell-cycle regulation and cancer .
0,1 G#protein

Polyunsaturated fatty acids and eicosanoids bind and activate PPARgamma , suggesting that these lipids may serve as hormonal regulators of a variety of biological processes .
8,9 G#protein

The role of caspases in T cell development and the control of immune responses .


Apoptosis is responsible for the removal of potentially autoreactive or useless T cells during thymic selection and activated T cells in the periphery .
17,20 G#cell_type

Specific families of receptors , kinases , transcription factors , and cysteine proteases , termed caspases , are involved in the apoptotic cascade leading to proteolysis of specific substrates and to morphological changes associated with programmed cell death .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Although common members of the apoptotic cascade are shared between different cell types , it appears that cell-specific factors can influence the response to a given apoptotic stimuli .
17,19 G#protein

Characterization and understanding of the basic mechanisms involved in the different pathways protecting or leading to cell death may provide novel ways to control inappropriate apoptosis involved in several diseases .


Cross-priming of CTL responses in vivo does not require antigenic peptides in the endoplasmic reticulum of immunizing cells .
16,18 G#cell_type

It has been proposed that the cross-priming of CTL responses in vivo involves the transfer to host APCs of heat shock protein glycoprotein 96 -chaperoned antigenic peptides released from the endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) of dying or infected cells .
17,18 G#cell_type|19,24 G#protein|36,40 G#cell_type

We have tested this possibility directly using TAP-deficient cell lines lacking antigenic ER peptides derived from two model Ags , the human adenovirus type 5 early regions E1A and E1B .
7,10 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|21,30 G#protein

Although both proteins were well expressed , the cells were not recognized by E1A- or E1B- specific CTLs unless the relevant epitope was either provided exogenously as a synthetic peptide or targeted to the ER in a TAP-independent fashion .
13,18 G#cell_type

Despite the absence of these ER peptides , the TAP1-/- cells were able to efficiently cross-prime E1A- and E1B- specific CTLs following immunization of syngeneic mice .
9,11 G#cell_type|15,21 G#cell_type

These results indicate that , although purified peptide/glycoprotein 96 complexes are potent immunogens , the mechanism of CTL cross-priming in vivo does not depend upon antigenic peptides in the ER of immunizing cells .
7,10 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

A critical role of the p75 tumor necrosis factor receptor ( p75TNF-R ) in organ inflammation independent of TNF , lymphotoxin alpha , or the p55TNF-R .
5,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Despite overwhelming evidence that enhanced production of the p75 tumor necrosis factor receptor ( p75TNF-R ) accompanies development of specific human inflammatory pathologies such as multi-organ failure during sepsis , inflammatory liver disease , pancreatitis , respiratory distress syndrome , or AIDS , the function of this receptor remains poorly defined in vivo .
8,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

We show here that at levels relevant to human disease , production of the human p75TNF-R in transgenic mice results in a severe inflammatory syndrome involving mainly the pancreas , liver , kidney , and lung , and characterized by constitutively increased NF-kappaB activity in the peripheral blood mononuclear cell compartment .
15,16 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|46,50 G#cell_type

This process is shown to evolve independently of the presence of TNF , lymphotoxin alpha , or the p55TNF-R , although coexpression of a human TNF transgene accelerated pathology .
11,12 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA

These results establish an independent role for enhanced p75TNF-R production in the pathogenesis of inflammatory disease and implicate the direct involvement of this receptor in a wide range of human inflammatory pathologies .
8,9 G#protein

Expression status of BCL-6 and syndecan-1 identifies distinct histogenetic subtypes of Hodgkin 's disease .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

The tumor cells in most cases of Hodgkin 's disease ( HD ) have been recently recognized to originate from the B-cell lineage , but their precise differentiation stage is not fully clarified .
1,3 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

Recently , we have reported that the histogenesis of B-cell lymphomas may be assessed by monitoring the expression pattern of BCL-6 , a transcription factor expressed in germinal center ( GC ) B cells , and CD138/ syndecan-1 ( syn-1 ) , a proteoglycan associated with post-GC , terminal B-cell differentiation .
9,11 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,34 G#cell_type|37,38 G#protein|36,38 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

In this study , we have applied these two markers to the study of HD histogenesis .


We have found that in nodular lymphocyte predominance HD ( NLPHD ) tumor cells consistently display the BCL-6 (+)/ syn-1 (-) phenotype , indicating their derivation from GC B cells .
12,14 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|27,30 G#cell_type

Conversely , classic HD ( CHD ) is heterogeneous because the tumor cells of a fraction of CHD display the BCL-6 (-)/ syn-1 (+) phenotype of post-GC B-cells , whereas another fraction of CHD is constituted by a mixture of tumor cells reflecting the GC ( BCL-6 (+)/ syn-1 (-) ) or post-GC ( BCL-6 (-)/ syn-1 (+) ) phenotypes .
11,13 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|40,42 G#cell_type|46,47 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|54,55 G#protein|56,57 G#protein

BCL-6 (-)/ syn-1 (+) tumor cells of CHD are mostly found surrounded by T cells expressing CD40L , consistent with the observation that CD40 signaling downregulates BCL-6 expression .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#cell_type|0,6 G#cell_line|13,15 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

These data indicate that tumor cells of NLPHD uniformly display a GC B-cell phenotype , whereas the phenotype of tumor cells of CHD appears to be modulated by the surrounding cellular background , particularly CD40L + reactive T cells .
4,6 G#cell_type|19,21 G#cell_type|34,35 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type|34,39 G#cell_type

Molecular and cellular analysis of human immunodeficiency virus -induced apoptosis in lymphoblastoid T-cell-line-expressing wild-type and mutated CD4 receptors .
17,18 G#protein|11,18 G#protein

We have previously shown that the presence of the CD4 cytoplasmic tail is critical for human immunodeficiency virus ( HIV ) -induced apoptosis ( J.Corbeil , M.Tremblay , and D.D.Richman , J.Exp.Med.183 : 39-48 , 1996 ) .
9,12 G#protein

We have pursued our investigation of the role of the CD4 transduction pathway in HIV-induced apoptosis .
10,11 G#protein

To do this , wild-type and mutant forms of the CD4 cytoplasmic tail were stably expressed in the lymphoblastoid T-cell line A2.01 .
10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_line|21,22 G#cell_line

Apoptosis was prevented when CD4 truncated at residue 402 was expressed ; however , cells expressing mutated receptors that do not associate with p56(lck) ( mutated at the dicysteine motif and truncated at residue 418 ) but which conserved proximal domains of the cytoplasmic tail underwent apoptosis like wild-Â type CD4 .
4,5 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|43,45 G#protein|49,50 G#protein|48,50 G#protein

The differences between wild-type and mutated receptors in the induction of apoptosis were not related to levels of p56(lck) or NF-Â kappaB activation .
3,7 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

Initial signaling through the CD4 receptor played a major role in the sensitization of HIV-infected T cells to undergo apoptosis .
4,5 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_type

Incubation of HIV-infected cells with monoclonal antibody ( MAb ) 13B8-2 , which binds to CD4 in a region critical for dimerization of the receptor , prevented apoptosis without inhibiting HIV replication .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Moreover , the apoptotic process was not related to Fas -Fas ligand interaction ; however , an antagonistic anti-Fas MAb ( ZB-4 ) enhanced apoptosis in HIV-infected cells without inducing apoptosis in uninfected cells .
9,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type|32,34 G#cell_type

These observations demonstrate that CD4 signaling mediates HIV-induced apoptosis by a mechanism independent of Fas -Fas ligand interaction , does not require p56(lck) signaling , and may involve a critical region for CD4 dimerization .
4,5 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

p130 , p107 , and pRb are differentially regulated in proliferating cells and during cell cycle arrest by alpha-interferon .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

We have determined how the phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma family ( pRb , p107 , and p130 ) is governed in individual cell cycle phases of Daudi B-cells during cell cycle exit triggered by alpha-interferon ( alpha-IFN ) .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_line|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

alpha-IFN causes dephosphorylation of pRb and loss of p130 phosphorylated Form 3 .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,12 G#protein

However , the change in p130 phosphorylation in response to alpha-IFN occurs before dephosphorylation of pRb is complete because loss of p130 Form 3 occurs throughout the cell cycle prior to complete arrest in G1 , whereas pRb is dephosphorylated only in G1 .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

In contrast , p107 is dephosphorylated and is then depleted from cells as they exit the cell cycle .
3,4 G#protein

p130 , predominantly in Form 1 , and hypophosphorylated pRb bind an E2F DNA binding site ; p130 complexes E2F-4 , whereas pRb binds both E2F-4 and E2F-1 .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|12,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The phosphorylated forms of E2F-4 that bind to the E2F DNA site are different from hyperphosphorylated E2F-4 , which predominates in primary hemopoietic cells in G0 .
4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_type

We conclude that although cell cycle arrest induced by alpha-IFN may be mediated in part by formation of a complex containing p130 and E2F-4 , alpha-IFN does not induce hyperphosphorylation of E2F-4 , which characterizes primary hemopoietic cells in G0 .
9,10 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|35,38 G#cell_type

The transcription factors c-myb and C/EBP alpha regulate the monocytic/myeloic gene MRP14 .
1,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,7 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA

The entry of microorganisms into the body induces inflammatory processes .


During this process a sequence of cellular , humoral , non-specific and specific actions are evoked to combat the infection .


Macrophages and granulocytes , which are developed from a common progenitor cell , are the cellular components of the specific and non-specific immunoreaction .
0,1 G#cell_type|2,3 G#cell_type

MRP14 ( Macrophage migration inhibitory related protein ) and MRP8 , two S-100 proteins contained in high concentrations in these cells are obviously essential for adhesion and migration of monocytes and granulocytes .
0,1 G#DNA|2,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type|31,32 G#cell_type

To investigate the transcriptional regulation of these genes we cotransfected constructs expressing CAT under control of the MRP14 promoter and expression constructs of C/EBP alpha and v-myb , two transcription factors involved in myeloid/monocytic differentiation .
12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|23,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

Transfection with C/EBP alpha revealed a massive enhancement of the MRP14 promoter in both , HL 60 cells ( granulocytic differentiated ) and L132 fibroblasts .
2,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA|15,18 G#cell_type|23,25 G#cell_type

In contrast , v-myb reduces MRP14 promoter activity .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|5,7 G#DNA

Northern blot analysis of L132 cells transfected with the C/EBP alpha expression vector demonstrate that C/EBP alpha is sufficient to enhance MRP14 expression in the context of the whole genome .
4,6 G#cell_type|9,11 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

A CD28 -associated signaling pathway leading to cytokine gene transcription and T cell proliferation without TCR engagement .
1,2 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|15,16 G#protein

Stimulation of resting human T cells with the CD28 -specific mAb BW 828 induces proliferation and cytokine synthesis without further requirement for TCR coengagement .
2,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|8,13 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

This observation prompted us to postulate that signal 2 ( costimulatory signal ) alone without signal 1 ( TCR signal ) can activate T cells .
18,19 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

To test whether this putative function of CD28 is mediated via a particular signaling pathway , we compared early signaling events initiated in resting T cells by the stimulatory mAb BW 828 with signals triggered by the nonstimulating CD28 mAb 9.3 .
7,8 G#protein|24,26 G#cell_type|28,32 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|37,41 G#protein

Stimulation of T cells with BW 828 induced an increase in intracellular Ca2+ , but did not lead to detectable activation of the protein kinases p56(lck) and c-Raf-1 .
2,4 G#cell_type|5,7 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

This pathway resulted in the induction of the transcription factors NF-kappa B , NF-AT , and proteins binding to the CD28 response element of the IL-2 promoter .
8,10 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA

On the other hand , stimulation of T cells with mAb 9.3 increased the level of intracellular Ca2+ and triggered the activation of p56(lck) and c-Raf-1 , but was unable to induce the binding of transcription factors to the IL-2 promoter .
7,9 G#cell_type|10,12 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|35,37 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|39,41 G#DNA

In contrast to the differential signaling of BW 828 and 9.3 in resting T cells , the two mAbs exhibited a similar pattern of early signaling events in activated T cells and Jurkat cells ( p56(lck) activation , association of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase with CD28 ) , indicating that the signaling capacity of CD28 changes with activation .
7,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|28,31 G#cell_type|32,34 G#cell_type|35,36 G#protein|40,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|52,53 G#protein

These data support the view that stimulation through CD28 can induce some effector functions in T cells and suggest that this capacity is associated with a particular pattern of early signaling events
8,9 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_type

Decreased IL-12 production and Th1 cell development by acetyl salicylic acid -mediated inhibition of NF-kappaB .
1,2 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

IL-12 is a 75-kDa heterodimeric cytokine composed of two covalently linked p35 and p40 chains .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|11,15 G#protein

This pro-inflammatory cytokine plays a prominent role in the development of Th1 cell-mediated immune responses .
1,3 G#protein

Th1 cell-mediated immune responses have been implicated in the pathogenesis of chronic inflammatory autoimmune diseases .


Thus , IL-12 appears to be a critical factor in the generation and maintenance of chronic inflammatory conditions .
2,3 G#protein

In this study , we investigated the effects of a commonly prescribed anti-inflammatory drug , acetyl salicylic acid ( ASA ) , on IL-12 production and Th1 cell development .
23,24 G#protein

ASA was found to inhibit secretion of the IL-12 heterodimer as well as p40 monomer by human monocytic cells .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

This was associated with the down-regulation of IL-12p40 mRNA expression .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#RNA

Analysis of the regulation of the p40 gene promoter revealed that ASA inhibited NF-kappaB activation and binding to the p40-kappaB site in the p40 promoter , leading to transcriptional repression of the p40 gene .
6,9 G#DNA|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein|32,34 G#DNA

Addition of ASA to an in vitro T helper cell differentiation system , at concentrations compatible with plasma levels reached during anti-inflammatory therapy , resulted in reduced development of Th1 cells .
29,31 G#cell_type

These results suggest that the inhibition of NF-kappaB activation by ASA leads to down-regulation of IL-12 production and inhibition of Th1 cell development .
7,8 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Attenuation of HLA-DR expression by mononuclear phagocytes infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis is related to intracellular sequestration of immature class II heterodimers .
2,3 G#protein|5,7 G#cell_type|17,21 G#protein

MHC class II expression was examined in macrophages infected with Mycobacterium tuberculosis .
0,3 G#protein|7,8 G#cell_type

IFN-gamma increased the surface expression of class II molecules in THP-1 cells and this was markedly reduced in cells infected with M. tuberculosis .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_line

Despite this effect , steady state levels of HLA-DRalpha , HLA-DRbeta , and invariant ( Ii ) chains were equivalent in control and infected cells .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,18 G#protein|21,25 G#cell_type

Metabolic labeling combined with pulse-chase experiments and biochemical analysis showed that the majority of class II molecules in infected cells became resistant to endoglycosidase H , consistent with normal Golgi processing .
14,17 G#protein|23,25 G#protein

However , results of intracellular staining and dual color confocal microscopy revealed a significant defect in transport of newly synthesized class II molecules through the endocytic compartment .
20,23 G#protein

Thus , compared with findings in control cells , class II molecules in infected cells colocalized to a minimal extent with a lysosomal-associated membrane protein-1 + endosomal compartment .
9,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|22,25 G#protein

In addition , in contrast to control cells , class II molecules in infected cells failed to colocalize with endocytosed BSA under conditions where this marker is known to label late endosomes , lysosomes , and the MHC class II compartment .
6,8 G#cell_type|9,12 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein|37,40 G#protein

Consistent with defective transport along the endocytic pathway , the maturation of SDS-stable class II alphabeta dimers -- dependent upon removal of Ii chain and peptide loading of class II dimers in the MHC class II compartment -- was markedly impaired in M. tuberculosis -infected cells .
12,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|28,31 G#protein|33,36 G#protein|44,46 G#cell_type

These findings indicate that defective transport and processing of class II molecules through the endosomal/lysosomal system is responsible for diminished cell surface expression of MHC class II molecules in cells infected with M. tuberculosis .
9,12 G#protein|24,28 G#protein

Identification of upstream regulatory elements that repress expression of adult beta-like globin genes in a primitive erythroid environment .
2,5 G#DNA|9,13 G#DNA

Our investigations have focused on localizing cis-elements responsible for the down regulation of the adult beta-like globin genes ( delta and beta ) in immature , or primitive erythroid tissues .
6,7 G#DNA|14,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#DNA

We studied their activity after transfection into K562 cells , an erythroleukemia cell line with an embryonic-fetal phenotype .
7,9 G#cell_line|11,14 G#cell_line

Analyzed DNA sequences included delta and beta 5' flanking regions extending from approximately -500 to +50bp ( promoter regions ) , truncated delta and beta 5' flanking regions extending from approximately -250 to +50 bp , and chimeric promoter constructions , which consisted of a distal delta or beta fragment fused to a proximal beta or delta sequence .
1,3 G#DNA|4,10 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|17,19 G#DNA|24,28 G#DNA|31,35 G#DNA|37,40 G#DNA|46,50 G#DNA|53,58 G#DNA

In CAT reporter constructions no appreciable level of CAT activity was supported by the beta globin promoter , and only low level activity by the delta promoter .
1,4 G#DNA|8,9 G#protein|14,17 G#DNA|25,27 G#DNA

Truncation of the beta globin promoter led to a 2-3 fold increase in promoter activity .
3,6 G#DNA

In contrast , deletion of the upstream portion of the delta promoter led to a 10 fold decrease in expression .
6,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA

Coupling of the upstream beta globin sequence from approximately -500 to -250 bp to the truncated delta promoter fragment led to complete extinction of transcription activity , consistent with a negative regulatory effect of the beta globin gene upstream element ( s ) .
3,7 G#DNA|16,18 G#DNA|35,40 G#DNA

Fusion of the upstream portion of the delta promoter to the truncated beta globin promoter yielded a modest increase in promoter strength relative to the truncated beta gene promoter , indicating the presence of a positive transcriptional element ( s ) in the upstream delta globin regulatory region .
3,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|12,15 G#DNA|25,29 G#DNA|35,38 G#DNA|43,48 G#DNA

Site-directed mutagenesis of binding sites for the repressor proteins BP1 and BP2 in the upstream portion of the beta globin gene flanking region led to a 4-6 fold increase in promoter activity .
7,12 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|18,23 G#DNA

DNase I footprinting of the upstream delta-globin region revealed protected sequences corresponding to consensus binding sites for GATA-1 and BP2 .
0,2 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|9,11 G#DNA|13,16 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

These results confirm that sequences in the upstream promoter region of the adult beta globin gene contribute to its factor-mediated suppression early in development and then may modulate its expression at a later stage .
7,10 G#DNA|12,16 G#DNA

Analysis of cytokine signaling in patients with extrinsic asthma and hyperimmunoglobulin E .
2,3 G#protein

BACKGROUND : Recent data suggest that the regulation of class switching to IgE by cytokines is mediated by STAT transcription factors .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|18,21 G#protein

The induction of IgE by IL-4 and IL-13 occurs through the activation of the intracellular signal-transducing protein Stat6 , whereas the inhibition of IgE class switching by interferon-y ( IFN-gamma ) occurs through the activation of Statl .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,18 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

OBJECTIVE : We hypothesized that in extrinsic asthma or in cases of markedly elevated IgE ( ie , hyperimmunoglobulin E [ HIE ] ) increased levels of IgE may be associated with alterations in the cytokine levels or the activation of Stat6 .
14,15 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|41,42 G#protein

METHODS : PBMCs and sera from 8 patients with extrinsic asthma ( mean IgE , 285+/-100 IU/mL ) , 3 patients with HIE ( mean IgE , 7050+/-1122 IU/mL ) , and 14 nonatopic control subjects ( mean IgE , 112+/-28 IU/mL ) were analyzed .
2,3 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

RESULTS : The mean IL-4 level detected by ELISA was much greater in patients with HIE than control subjects ( 88.6+/-11.5 pg/mL vs 11.5+/-7.1 pg/mL , P = .005 ) , and increased IL-4 levels among patients with both asthma and HIE correlated with the increased IgE levels .
4,5 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|46,47 G#protein

In contrast , IL-13 levels were not elevated .
3,4 G#protein

Levels of Stat6 protein present in PBMCs did not differ in the patients and control subjects .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type

Examination of Stat6 DNA-binding activity demonstrated no activation of IL-4 signaling in patients with either HIE or acute asthma .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Interestingly , evidence for the presence of B cells that have already switched to IgE was seen in PBMCs of several patients with asthma or HIE .
7,9 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type

CONCLUSION : These results indicate that ( 1 ) IgE production in asthma and HIE usually is associated with elevated levels of IL-4 , but not IL-13 , in the peripheral blood ; ( 2 ) the increased sera IL-4 levels in asthma and HIE are not sufficient to induce Stat6 activation in PBMCs ; and ( 3 ) evidence of switch recombination to epsilon may be detected in isolated cases of elevated IgE .
9,10 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|50,51 G#protein|53,54 G#cell_type|73,74 G#protein

This implies that high levels of IgE in these patients either results from B cells that have already undergone class switching , from Ig class switching that is localized to target tissues , or both .
6,7 G#protein|13,15 G#cell_type

Carboxyl-terminal 15-amino acid sequence of NFATx1 is possibly created by tissue-specific splicing and is essential for transactivation activity in T cells .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

NFAT regulates transcription of a number of cytokine and other immunoregulatory genes .
0,1 G#protein|10,12 G#DNA

We have isolated NFATx , which is one of four members of the NFAT family of transcription factors and is preferentially expressed in the thymus and peripheral blood leukocytes , and an isoform of NFATx , NFATx1 .
3,4 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|26,29 G#cell_type|34,35 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

Here we provide evidence showing that 15 amino acids in the carboxyl-terminal end of NFATx1 are required for its maximum transactivation activity in Jurkat T cells .
11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,26 G#cell_line

A fusion between these 15 amino acids and the GAL4 DNA binding domain was capable of transactivating reporters driven by the GAL4 DNA binding site .
9,13 G#protein|21,25 G#DNA

Interestingly , this 15-amino acid transactivation sequence is well conserved in NFAT family proteins , although the sequences contiguous to the carboxyl-terminal regions of the NFAT family are much less conserved .
3,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

We also report three additional isoforms of NFATx , designated NFATx2 , NFATx3 , and NFATx4 .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

This transactivation sequence is altered by tissue-specific alternative splicing in newly isolated NFATx isoforms , resulting in lower transactivation activity in Jurkat T cells .
12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_line

NFATx1 is expressed predominantly in the thymus and peripheral blood leukocyte , while the skeletal muscle expressed primarily NFATx2 .
0,1 G#protein|8,11 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

In Jurkat cells , transcription from the NFAT site of the IL-2 promoter is activated strongly by NFATx1 but only weakly by NFATx2 .
1,3 G#cell_line|7,9 G#DNA|11,13 G#DNA|17,18 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

These data demonstrate that the 15-amino acid sequence of NFATx1 is a major transactivation sequence required for induction of genes by NFATx1 in T cells and possibly regulates NFAT activity through tissue-specific alternative splicing .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

Altered DNA-binding specificity mutants of EKLF and Sp1 show that EKLF is an activator of the beta-globin locus control region in vivo .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,20 G#DNA

The locus control region of the beta-globin cluster contains five DNase I hypersensitive sites ( 5'HS1-5 ) required for locus activation .
1,4 G#DNA|6,8 G#DNA|10,14 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA

5'HS3 contains six G-rich motifs that are essential for its activity .
0,1 G#DNA|3,5 G#DNA

Members of a protein family , characterized by three zinc fingers highly homologous to those found in transcription factor Sp1 , interact with these motifs .
9,11 G#protein|17,20 G#protein

Because point mutagenesis can not distinguish between family members , it is not known which protein activates 5'HS3 .
17,18 G#DNA

We show that the function of such closely related proteins can be distinguished in vivo by matching point mutations in 5'HS3 with amino acid changes in the zinc fingers of Sp1 and EKLF .
20,21 G#DNA|27,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

Testing their activity in transgenic mice shows that EKLF is a direct activator of 5'HS3 .
8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA

The Epstein-Barr virus Rta protein activates lytic cycle genes and can disrupt latency in B lymphocytes .
1,5 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#cell_type

The transition of Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) from latency into the lytic cycle is associated with the expression of two immediate-early viral genes , BZLF1 and BRLF1 .
21,24 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA|27,28 G#DNA

Overexpression of ZEBRA , the product of BZLF1 , is sufficient to disrupt latency in B lymphocytes and epithelial cells by stimulating expression of lytic cycle genes , including BRLF1 .
7,8 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type|24,27 G#DNA|29,30 G#DNA

The BRLF1 product Rta functions as a transcriptional activator in both B lymphocytes and epithelial cells .
1,2 G#DNA|3,4 G#protein|1,4 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

However , Rta has recently been reported to disrupt latency in an epithelial specific manner ( S. Zalani , E. Holley-Guthrie , and S. Kenney , Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 93 : 9194-9199 , 1996 ) .
2,3 G#protein

Here we demonstrate that expression of Rta is also sufficient for disruption of latency in a permissive B-cell line .
6,7 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_line

In HH514-16 cells , transfection of Rta leads to synthesis of ZEBRA , viral DNA replication , and late gene expression .
1,3 G#cell_line|6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

However , Rta by itself is less potent than ZEBRA in the ability to activate most early and late lytic cycle genes .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|19,22 G#DNA

In light of previous work implicating ZEBRA in the activation of Rta , we suggest a cooperative model for EBV entry into the lytic cycle .
6,7 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Expression of either BZLF1 or BRLF1 triggers expression of the other immediate-early factor , and together these activators act individually or in synergy on downstream targets to activate the viral lytic cycle .
3,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#DNA|11,13 G#protein|24,26 G#DNA

Transcription of a minimal promoter from the NF-IL6 gene is regulated by CREB/ATF and SP1 proteins in U937 promonocytic cells .
3,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|12,13 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_line

NF-IL6 is an important transcriptional regulator of genes induced in activated monocytes/ macrophages , and NF-IL6 is the only CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein ( C/EBP ) family member whose steady-state mRNA levels increase upon activation of monocytes ( 1 ) .
0,1 G#protein|12,13 G#cell_type|10,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|19,25 G#protein|34,35 G#cell_type

We show that increased transcription of the NF-IL6 gene is responsible , at least in part , for induction of NF-IL6 mRNA following activation of U937 promonocytic cells .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#RNA|25,28 G#cell_line

We have identified a 104-bp minimal promoter region of the NF-IL6 gene that is sufficient for basal and activation-dependent induction of transcription in U937 cells .
4,8 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|23,25 G#cell_line

This region contains binding sites for the cAMP response element-binding protein/activation transcription factor ( CREB/ATF ) and Sp1 families of transcription factors .
7,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,22 G#protein

Each site is functionally important and contributes independently to transcription of the NF-IL6 gene in U937 cells .
12,13 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA|15,17 G#cell_line

CIITA B-cell-specific promoter suppression in MHC class II -silenced cell hybrids .
0,1 G#protein|1,3 G#DNA|5,8 G#protein|5,11 G#cell_line

In this study , various sets of somatic cell hybrids , generated by the fusion of epithelial cell lines with B-lymphoblastoid cell lines , were analyzed for the expression of major histocompatibility complex ( MHC ) class II antigens .
7,10 G#cell_line|16,19 G#cell_line|20,23 G#cell_line|30,39 G#protein

We first demonstrate , in human and mouse intraspecies hybrids , the coordinate suppression of MHC class II , Ii ( invariant chain ) and HLA-DM gene transcription , and the release of the silencing by the addition of interferon gamma .
5,10 G#cell_line|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,23 G#protein|25,27 G#DNA|39,41 G#protein

Using interspecies hybrids , the segregation of human chromosomes allowed us to establish that MHC class II extinction is linked to the presence in the hybrids of the chromosomes from the epithelial fusion partner .
7,9 G#DNA|14,17 G#protein|28,29 G#DNA|31,34 G#cell_type

Moreover , our data provide evidence that the expression pattern of MHC class II mRNA is correlated with that of the class II transactivator ( CIITA ) , suggesting that CIITA is the actual target of the silencing .
11,14 G#protein|11,15 G#RNA|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

To gain further insight into the suppression phenomenon we performed luciferase assays which show that silencing affects the activity of the B-cell-specific promoter of CIITA .
21,23 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein

These results therefore demonstrate that the MHC class II gene silencing in somatic cell hybrids is due to an active suppression of one of the promoters of the CIITA gene , mediated by the epithelial cell fusion partner .
6,9 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_line|25,26 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|34,38 G#cell_type

Class II transactivator-independent endothelial cell MHC class II gene activation induced by lymphocyte adhesion .
5,8 G#protein

NK cells induce MHC class II molecules on the surface of allogeneic endothelial cells in an adhesion-dependent , IFN-gamma -independent manner .
3,6 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Here , we demonstrate that NK cells induce HLA-DR on the surface of a mutant cell line that is defective in IFN-gamma -induced MHC class II expression .
5,7 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|14,17 G#cell_line|21,22 G#protein|23,26 G#protein

RNA analysis in these cells and in a cell line that is defective in class II transactivator ( CIITA ) demonstrates that NK cell-induced HLA-DR alpha mRNA expression is also CIITA -independent .
14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|24,26 G#protein|24,27 G#RNA|30,31 G#protein

The Janus kinase-1-deficient cell line U4A expresses HLA-DR alpha mRNA in response to NK cell activation , and HLA-DR alpha promoter constructs transfected into these cells are induced by NK cells but not IFN-gamma .
1,6 G#cell_line|7,9 G#protein|7,10 G#RNA|18,20 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|18,22 G#DNA|29,31 G#cell_line|33,34 G#protein

These data indicate that the IFN-gamma -independent component of the target cell HLA-DR expression induced by lymphocyte adhesion uses a signaling pathway that is distinct from the IFN-gamma -dependent mechanism and also suggest that CIITA is not required .
5,6 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

Effects of overexpression of IL-1 receptor-associated kinase on NFkappaB activation , IL-2 production and stress-activated protein kinases in the murine T cell line EL4 .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,24 G#cell_line

The association and activation of the IL-1 receptor-associated protein kinase ( IRAK ) to the IL-1 receptor complex is one of the earliest events detectable in IL-1 signal transduction .
6,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

We generated permanent clones of the murine T cell line EL4 6.1 overexpressing human ( h ) IRAK to evaluate the role of this kinase in IL-1 signaling .
6,12 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|13,18 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Overexpression of hIRAK enhanced IL-1 -stimulated activation of the transcription factor NFkappaB , whereas a truncated form ( N-IRAK ) specifically inhibited IL-1 -dependent NFkappaB activity .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

In clones stably overexpressing hIRAK a weak constitutive activation of NFkappaB correlated with a low basal IL-2 production which was enhanced in an IL-1 -dependent manner .
4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Compared to the parental cell line the dose-response curve of IL-1 -induced IL-2 production was shifted in both potency and efficacy .
3,6 G#cell_line|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

These results demonstrate that IRAK directly triggers NFkappaB -mediated gene expression in EL4 cells .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_line

Qualitatively different effects were observed for the IL-1 -induced activation of stress-activated protein ( SAP ) kinases : permanent overexpression of IRAK did not affect the dose dependence but prolonged the kinetics of IL-1 -induced activation of SAP kinases , suggesting that this signaling branch may be regulated by distinct mechanisms .
7,8 G#protein|11,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|37,39 G#protein

The role of protein kinase C signaling in activated DRA transcription .
3,6 G#protein|9,10 G#DNA

Expression of human MHC HLA-DRA class II gene can be up-regulated in B cells by Ig cross-linking as well as by phorbol esters such as 12-O-tetradecanoyl phorbol 13-acetate ( TPA ) .
2,8 G#DNA|12,14 G#cell_type

Induced DRA expression involves activation of restricted protein kinase C ( PKC ) isoforms , resulting in activated activator protein-1 -dependent transcription .
1,2 G#DNA|7,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|6,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

In this report expression profiles and activation of PKC were analyzed in human Raji B lymphoblastoid cells .
8,9 G#protein|12,17 G#cell_line

Transient transfection analysis with target plasmids containing either DRA promoter ( wild-type or mutated ) or TPA response elements demonstrated that pretreatment with the selective PKC inhibitor GF 109203X repressed TPA -mediated activation .
4,6 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|16,19 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein

Western analysis performed on cellular fractions of resting cells and of TPA -activated cells revealed abundant expression of classical PKC-alpha ( cPKC-alpha ) , cPKC-betaII , and atypical PKC-zeta isoforms and identified a sustained translocation of cPKC-alpha and cPKC-betaII from the cytosolic compartment to membranes .
7,9 G#cell_type|11,14 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|27,30 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

As expected , the distribution of atypical PKC-zeta was unaffected by TPA treatment and displayed an even distribution between cytosol and membranes .
6,8 G#protein

This finding was confirmed by immunofluorescence microscopy .


The TPA -mediated translocation of cPKC-alpha and cPKC-betaII was not influenced by pretreatment with GF 109203X .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Finally , functional activation and translocation of PKC were investigated with a selective in vitro kinase assay .
7,8 G#protein

Together , these results show that activated HLA-DRA expression in response to TPA treatment is strictly dependent on PKC activation acting on the X2 box of the DRA promoter and that selective inhibition of PKC enzymatic activity does not influence subcellular localization of expressed PKC isoenzymes .
7,8 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA|34,35 G#protein|44,45 G#protein|44,46 G#protein

Thus , the translocation event per se occurs independently of PKC activation in these cells .
10,11 G#protein

Inhibition of RNA polymerase II transcription in human cells by synthetic DNA-binding ligands [ see comments ]
2,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Sequence-specific DNA-binding small molecules that can permeate human cells potentially could regulate transcription of specific genes .
7,9 G#cell_type

Multiple cellular DNA-binding transcription factors are required by HIV type 1 for RNA synthesis .
1,5 G#protein

Two pyrrole-imidazole polyamides were designed to bind DNA sequences immediately adjacent to binding sites for the transcription factors Ets-1 , lymphoid-enhancer binding factor 1 , and TATA-box binding protein .
16,18 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|26,27 G#DNA|26,29 G#protein

These synthetic ligands specifically inhibit DNA-binding of each transcription factor and HIV type 1 transcription in cell-free assays .
8,10 G#protein

When used in combination , the polyamides inhibit virus replication by &gt; 99 % in isolated human peripheral blood lymphocytes , with no detectable cell toxicity .
15,20 G#cell_type

The ability of small molecules to target predetermined DNA sequences located within RNA polymerase II promoters suggests a general approach for regulation of gene expression , as well as a mechanism for the inhibition of viral replication .
8,10 G#DNA|12,16 G#DNA

musculin : a murine basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor gene expressed in embryonic skeletal muscle .
0,1 G#DNA|3,9 G#DNA

We describe the embryonic expression of musculin , a new murine member of the bHLH family of transcription factors .
6,7 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Musculin protein is closely related to human ABF-1 , which is expressed in activated B cells , and to epicardin/capsulin/Pod-1 , which is expressed in branchial myoblasts , visceral and urogenital mesoderm and epicardium .
6,8 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein|25,27 G#cell_type

In situ hybridisation revealed musculin expression in embryos was largely restricted to the embryonic skeletal muscle lineage .
4,5 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type

While all skeletal muscles expressed the gene , only a subset of myocytes within each muscle were positive , indicating molecular heterogeneity within fetal muscle .

Induction of T cell anergy by high concentrations of immunodominant native peptide is accompanied by IL-10 production and a block in JNK activity .
15,16 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The ability to induce anergy in antigen-specific T cells has potential therapeutic value for altering pathologic immune responses .
6,9 G#cell_type

This study was undertaken to further analyze changes in cytokine production and intracellular signaling during anergy induction using high concentrations of native peptide ligand of tetanus toxoid ( TT ) - and myelin basic protein ( MBP ) - specific human T cell lines .
9,10 G#protein|25,44 G#cell_line

The TT -selected T cell line could be rendered unresponsive to its dominant epitope in a dose-dependent manner ( IC50 = 0.03 microg/ml ) .
1,6 G#cell_line

The TT -selected line , as well as three T cell clones established from this line , continued to produce IFN-gamma and significantly increased IL-4 and IL-10 production when anergy was induced with high concentrations of the immunodominant epitope .
1,4 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

JNK enzymatic activity was blocked in anergized T cells .
0,1 G#protein|6,9 G#cell_line

The MBP -selected line could likewise be rendered unresponsive by incubation with supraoptimal concentrations of immunodominant peptide and anergy induction was accompanied by IL-10 release .
1,2 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Both T cell lines could be anergized by the autopresentation of native peptide since anergy was induced in cultures lacking fresh antigen-presenting cells .
1,4 G#cell_line|21,23 G#cell_type

This study shows that the mitogen-activated protein kinase cascade is blocked when anergy is induced to high concentrations of soluble peptide .
5,8 G#protein

Upregulation of interleukin 6 and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor receptors by transcription factor CCAAT enhancer binding protein alpha ( C/EBP alpha ) is critical for granulopoiesis .
2,4 G#protein|5,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein|12,16 G#protein|12,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein

Cytokines stimulate granulopoiesis through signaling via receptors whose expression is controlled by lineage-specific transcription factors .
13,15 G#protein

Previously , we demonstrated that granulocyte colony-stimulating factor ( G-CSF ) receptor mRNA was undetectable and granulocyte maturation blocked in CCAAT enhancer binding protein alpha ( C/EBPalpha ) -deficient mice .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|5,13 G#RNA|20,24 G#protein|20,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

This phenotype is distinct from that of G-CSF receptor-/- mice , suggesting that other genes are likely to be adversely affected by loss of C/EBPalpha .
24,25 G#protein

Here we demonstrate loss of interleukin 6 ( IL-6 ) receptor and IL-6-responsive colony-forming units ( CFU-IL6 ) in C/EBPalpha -/- mice .
5,7 G#protein|5,11 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

The observed failure of granulopoiesis could be rescued by the addition of soluble IL-6 receptor and IL-6 or by retroviral transduction of G-CSF receptors , demonstrating that loss of both of these receptors contributes to the absolute block in granulocyte maturation observed in C/EBPalpha -deficient hematopoietic cells .
13,14 G#protein|13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|43,47 G#cell_type

The results of these and other studies suggest that additional C/EBPalpha target genes , possibly other cytokine receptors , are also important for the block in granulocyte differentiation observed in vivo in C/EBPalpha -deficient mice .
10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein

Phosphatidylinositides bind to plasma membrane CD14 and can prevent monocyte activation by bacterial lipopolysaccharide .
5,6 G#protein|3,6 G#protein

Although bacterial lipopolysaccharides ( LPS ) and several other microbial agonists can bind to mCD14 ( membrane CD14 ) , a cell-surface receptor found principally on monocytes and neutrophils , host-derived mCD14 ligands are poorly defined .
14,15 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|26,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_type|31,32 G#protein

We report here that phosphatidylinositol ( PtdIns ) , phosphatidylinositol -4-phosphate , and other phosphatidylinositides can bind to mCD14 .
18,19 G#protein

Phosphatidylserine ( PS ) , another anionic glycerophospholipid , binds to mCD14 with lower apparent affinity than does PtdIns .
11,12 G#protein

LPS -binding protein , a lipid transfer protein found in serum , facilitates both PS - and PtdIns - mCD14 binding .
0,3 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

PtdIns binding to mCD14 can be blocked by anti-CD14 monoclonal antibodies that inhibit LPS -mCD14 binding , and PtdIns can inhibit both LPS -mCD14 binding and LPS -induced responses in monocytes .
3,4 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_type

Serum-equilibrated PtdIns also binds to mCD14 -expressing cells , raising the possibility that endogenous PtdIns may modulate cellular responses to LPS and other mCD14 ligands in vivo .
5,6 G#protein|0,8 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein

Protein kinase C regulates Fas ( CD95/APO-1 ) expression .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Fas ( CD95/APO-1 ) is a transmembrane protein of the TNF/neuron growth factor receptor family .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|10,15 G#protein

Ligation of Fas by specific Abs or Fas ligand ( FasL/CD95 ligand ) induces rapid apoptotic cell death in a variety of cell types .
2,3 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|10,12 G#protein

Despite progress in understanding the death signals transduced from Fas , very little is known with regard to the mechanisms by which Fas expression is regulated .
9,10 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Using our previously established murine T cell hybridoma model A1.1 , we show that specific protein kinase C ( PKC ) inhibitors could block activation-induced Fas expression and apoptosis .
4,9 G#cell_line|9,10 G#cell_line|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

The activation of PKC with PMA or 1-oleoyl-2-acetyl-sn-glycerol could mimic the TCR signal by inducing the expression of Fas but not FasL .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

PKC -dependent Fas expression was also observed in several murine and human tumor cell lines .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|9,15 G#cell_line

Since the inhibition of Ca2+ redistribution by an inhibitor of intracellular Ca2+ mobilization , 8-(diethylamino)-octyl-3,4,5-trimethoxybenzoate hydrochloride , inhibited TCR-induced FasL but not Fas , the expression of Fas appears to be independent of Ca2+ mobilization .
18,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Significantly , expression of the newly identified Fas -regulatory gene , TDAG51 , was found to be dependent upon the activity of PKC .
7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|22,23 G#protein

PKC activation only induced Fas expression in cells expressing wild-type TDAG51 .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA

Thus , Fas expression is likely mediated by PKC through TDAG51 .
2,3 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#DNA

Retinoic acid inhibits CD40 + interleukin-4 -mediated IgE production in vitro .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

To elucidate the role of retinoic acid ( RA ) in anti- CD40 + interleukin-4 ( IL-4 ) -mediated B-cell activation , the effect of 10(-12) to 10(-6) mol/L RA was studied in anti-CD40 ( 1 microgram/mL ) + IL-4 ( 5 ng/mL ) -mediated proliferation and Ig synthesis by human peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) and B cells in healthy donors .
12,13 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|39,40 G#protein|50,55 G#cell_type|56,57 G#cell_type|59,61 G#cell_type

Anti-CD40 + IL-4 -mediated proliferation of PBMC and B cells was inhibited by RA in a dose-dependent manner , with maximal inhibition of 62 % +/- 5 % in PBMC and 55 % +/- 4.4 % in B cells by all-trans RA , and 58 % +/- 6.7 % and 51 % +/- 4.7 % , respectively by 13-cis RA .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|29,30 G#cell_type|37,39 G#cell_type

IgE synthesis was even more markedly inhibited by RA starting at concentrations of &gt; 10(-14) mol/L for B cells and &gt; 10(-10) mol/L for PBMC .
0,1 G#protein|17,19 G#cell_type|24,25 G#cell_type

Maximal inhibition of IgE production for B cells was at 10(-8) mol/L for all-trans RA ( 94 % +/- 1.8 % ) and 96 % +/- 3.2 % for 13-cis RA .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

Low concentrations of RA inhibiting IgE synthesis ( 10(-10) mol/L ) affected neither B-cell proliferation nor the production of IgA , IgG , and IgM .
5,6 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Elucidation of the mechanism involved in this inhibition of IgE production shows that epsilon germline transcription is decreased by RA , whereas production of interferon-gamma ( IFN-gamma ) was not enhanced in the presence of RA .
9,10 G#protein|14,15 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

To differentiate whether the RA effect was mediated by RA receptors alpha , beta , and gamma , the expression of the retinoic acid receptors ( RAR ) was examined by reverse transcriptase -polymerase chain reaction ( RT-PCR ) .
9,17 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|31,33 G#protein

The data show that unstimulated human peripheral B cells express mRNA of the RA receptor alpha , beta , and gamma .
4,9 G#cell_type|13,21 G#protein

Using retinoids with different receptor binding specificity ( CD336 , CD437 , CD2019 , CD367 ) , dose-dependent inhibition of IgE synthesis was shown by all four derivates , but was most marked by an RA binding the alpha receptor with high specificity .
20,21 G#protein|38,40 G#protein

Taken together , this study shows that RA inhibits IgE production of anti-CD40 + IL-4 -stimulated B cells in vitro .
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|12,18 G#cell_line

Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 Tax induction of NF-kappaB involves activation of the IkappaB kinase alpha ( IKKalpha ) and IKKbeta cellular kinases .
6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|22,24 G#protein

Tax corresponds to a 40-kDa transforming protein from the pathogenic retrovirus human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 ( HTLV-1 ) that activates nuclear expression of the NF-kappaB /Rel family of transcription factors by an unknown mechanism .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|26,29 G#protein|30,32 G#protein

Tax expression promotes N-terminal phosphorylation and degradation of IkappaB alpha , a principal cytoplasmic inhibitor of NF-kappaB .
0,1 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Our studies now demonstrate that HTLV-1 Tax activates the recently identified cellular kinases IkappaB kinase alpha ( IKKalpha ) and IKKbeta , which normally phosphorylate IkappaB alpha on both of its N-terminal regulatory serines in response to tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNF-alpha ) and interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) stimulation .
6,7 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|37,41 G#protein|42,43 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|47,48 G#protein

In contrast , a mutant of Tax termed M22 , which does not induce NF-kappaB , fails to activate either IKKalpha or IKKbeta .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Furthermore , endogenous IKK enzymatic activity was significantly elevated in HTLV-1-infected and Tax-expressing T-cell lines .
10,15 G#cell_line

Transfection of kinase-deficient mutants of IKKalpha and IKKbeta into either human Jurkat T or 293 cells also inhibits NF-kappaB -dependent reporter gene expression induced by Tax .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,16 G#cell_line|18,19 G#protein|20,22 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein

Similarly , a kinase-deficient mutant of NIK ( NF-kappaB -inducing kinase ) , which represents an upstream kinase in the TNF-alpha and IL-1 signaling pathways leading to IKKalpha and IKKbeta activation , blocks Tax induction of NF-kappaB .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein

However , plasma membrane-proximal elements in these proinflammatory cytokine pathways are apparently not involved since dominant negative mutants of the TRAF2 and TRAF6 adaptors , which effectively block signaling through the cytoplasmic tails of the TNF-alpha and IL-1 receptors , respectively , do not inhibit Tax induction of NF-kappaB .
2,5 G#DNA|7,9 G#protein|20,24 G#protein|31,33 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#protein

Together , these studies demonstrate that HTLV-1 Tax exploits a distal part of the proinflammatory cytokine signaling cascade leading to induction of NF-kappaB .
7,8 G#protein|14,16 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

The pathological alteration of this cytokine pathway leading to NF-kappaB activation by Tax may play a central role in HTLV-1 -mediated transformation of human T cells , clinically manifested as the adult T-cell leukemia
9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|23,26 G#cell_type

Role of IKK1 and IKK2 in lipopolysaccharide signaling in human monocytic cells .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type

Mononuclear phagocytes play a major role in immune and inflammatory responses .
0,2 G#cell_type

Bacterial lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ) induces monocytes to express a variety of genes by activating the NF-kappaB/Rel transcription factor family .
6,7 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|16,20 G#protein

Recently , we have reported that the tumor necrosis factor and interleukin 1 signaling pathways activate two kinases , IKK1 and IKK2 .
7,10 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Phosphorylation of the IkappaB cytoplasmic inhibitors , IkappaBalpha , IkappaBbeta , and IkappaBepsilon , by these kinases triggers proteolytic degradation and the release of NF-kappaB/Rel proteins into the nucleus .
3,4 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

At present , the role of the IKKs in LPS signaling has not been investigated .


Here , we report that LPS induces IKK activity in human monocytes and THP-1 monocytic cells .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type|13,16 G#cell_line

The kinetics of activation of kinase activity in monocytic cells are relatively slow with maximal activity observed at 60 min , which coincides with the degradation of IkappaBs and the nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB .
8,10 G#cell_type|27,28 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

In transfection experiments , overexpression of wild type IKK1 , a dominant negative mutant IKK1 ( K44M ) , or wild type IKK2 did not affect LPS -induced kappaB -dependent transcription in monocytic cells .
8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|11,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|20,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type

In contrast , a dominant negative mutant of IKK2 inhibited LPS induction of kappaB -dependent transcription in a dose-dependent manner .
8,9 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

These results indicate that LPS induction of kappaB-dependent gene expression in human monocytic cells requires activation of IKK2 .
12,14 G#cell_type|11,14 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

IL-7 reconstitutes multiple aspects of v-Abl -mediated signaling .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein

The mechanism by which early lymphoid cells are selectively transformed by v-Abl is currently unknown .
4,7 G#cell_type|11,12 G#protein

Previous studies have shown constitutive activation of IL-4 and IL-7 signaling pathways , as measured by activation of Janus protein kinase ( JAK ) 1 , JAK3 , STAT5 , and STAT6 , in pre-B cells transformed by v-Abl .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|18,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,36 G#cell_type|38,39 G#protein

To determine whether activation of these cytokine signaling pathways by v-Abl is important in the cellular events induced by the Abelson murine leukemia virus , the effects of IL-4 and IL-7 on pre-B cells transformed with a temperature-sensitive v-Abl mutant were examined .
10,11 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|32,34 G#cell_type|38,40 G#protein|37,40 G#protein

Whereas IL-4 had little or no effect , IL-7 delayed both the apoptosis and cell cycle arrest that occur upon v-Abl kinase inactivation .
1,2 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

IL-7 also delayed the decreases in the levels of c-Myc , Bcl-2 , and Bcl-xL that occur upon loss of v-Abl kinase activity .
0,1 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

IL-7 did not maintain v-Abl -mediated differentiation arrest of the pre-B cells , as activation of NF-kappaB and RAG gene transcription was unaffected by IL-7 .
0,1 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein

These results identify a potential role for IL-7 signaling pathways in transformation by v-Abl while demonstrating that a combination of IL-4 and IL-7 signaling can not substitute for an active v-Abl kinase in transformed pre-B cells .
7,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|34,36 G#cell_type|33,36 G#cell_type

Differential regulation of coproporphyrinogen oxidase gene between erythroid and nonerythroid cells .
3,6 G#DNA|7,11 G#cell_type

Coproporphyrinogen oxidase ( CPO ) catalyzes the sixth step of the heme biosynthetic pathway .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

To assess the tissue-specific regulation of the CPO gene promoter , mouse genomic DNA clones for CPO were isolated .
7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA|11,15 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

Structural analysis demonstrated that the mouse CPO gene spans approximately 11 kb and consists of seven exons , just like its human counterpart .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA

Functional analysis of the promoter by transient transfection assays indicated that synergistic action between an SP-1 -like element at -21/-12 , a GATA site at -59/-54 , and a novel regulatory element , CPRE ( GGACTACAG - ) at -49/-41 , is essential for the promoter activity in murine erythroleukemia ( MEL ) cells .
15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|22,24 G#DNA|29,32 G#DNA|33,34 G#DNA|35,36 G#DNA|48,54 G#cell_type

In nonerythroid NIH3T3 cells , however , the GATA site is not required .
1,4 G#cell_line|8,10 G#DNA

Gel mobility shift assays demonstrated that specific DNA-protein complexes can be formed with each element , and that there are cell-specific differences in factors , which bind to the SP-1 -like element between MEL and NIH3T3 cells .
7,9 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|29,32 G#DNA|33,37 G#cell_line

These results provide evidence for differential regulation of the promoter function of CPO gene between erythroid and nonerythroid cells .
12,13 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_type

Copyright 1998 by The American Society of Hematology


Tumor suppressor proteins as regulators of cell differentiation .
0,3 G#protein

The products of the tumor suppressor genes are considered to function as specific inhibitors of tumor cell growth .
4,7 G#DNA

In this communication , we present evidence to show that these proteins inhibit tumor cell proliferation by participating in the activation of tumor cell differentiation .


The ML-1 human myeloblastic leukemia cells used in this study proliferate when treated with insulin-like growth factor I and transferrin but differentiate to monocytes when exposed to tumor necrosis factor alpha or transforming growth factor beta1 , or to macrophage-like cells when treated with both these cytokines .
1,6 G#cell_line|14,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|23,24 G#cell_type|27,31 G#protein|32,36 G#protein|39,41 G#cell_type|46,47 G#protein

Initiation of proliferation but not of differentiation was followed by a 20- to 25-fold increase in the nuclear level of the DNA polymerase-associated processivity factor PCNA and of the proliferation-specific transcription factor E2F1 .
25,26 G#protein|21,26 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|29,33 G#protein

In contrast , induction of differentiation but not of proliferation was followed by a 25- to 30-fold increase in the nuclear level of the tumor suppressor proteins p53 ( wild type ) , pRb , and p130/Rb2 and of the p53-dependent cyclin kinase inhibitor p21/Cip1 .
24,28 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|40,44 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

p53 and p21/Cip1 , respectively , inhibit the expression and activation of PCNA , whereas p130 and pRb , respectively , inhibit the expression and activation of E2F1 .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

As a result , G1-S-associated DNA and mRNA synthesis is inhibited , growth uncoupled from differentiation , and maturation enabled to proceed .
4,6 G#DNA

Where this function of the tumor suppressor proteins is impaired , the capacity for differentiation is lost , which leads to the sustained proliferation that is characteristic of the cancer cell .
5,8 G#protein|29,31 G#cell_type

Transcription factor activation in lymphokine activated killer cells and lymphocytes from patients receiving IL-2 immunotherapy .
0,2 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

Administration of the cytokine interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) can result in therapeutic benefits for individuals with renal cell carcinoma and melanoma .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Here we report an analysis of the transcription factor families AP-1 , Sp1 , NF-kappaB , and signal transducers and activators of transcription ( STAT ) in cancer patients ' lymphocytes before and after IL-2 immunotherapy , as assessed by a gel-shift assay .
14,15 G#protein|17,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|30,31 G#cell_type|27,31 G#cell_type|34,35 G#protein

An in vitro surrogate of IL-2 immunotherapy is the incubation of fresh peripheral blood mononuclear cells ( PBMC ) from healthy individuals in IL-2 for several days , resulting in the production of lymphokine -activated killer ( LAK ) activity in these cultures .
5,6 G#protein|11,16 G#cell_type|17,18 G#cell_type|23,24 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

One purpose of this study was to describe the profile of transcription factor activation in these different populations , and assess whether the patterns observed correlated with functional differences in these cells .


Prior to in vivo IL-2 administration , the typical binding pattern of transcription factors in PBMC from patients resembled that seen in fresh PBMC from healthy individuals .
4,5 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|15,16 G#cell_type|23,24 G#cell_type

Over a 3-week course of IL-2 therapy , in most patients the binding patterns of AP-1 , Sp1 , and NF-kappaB proteins changed to resemble those seen in PBMC activated by IL-2 in vitro .
5,6 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|28,29 G#cell_type|31,32 G#protein

However , the cells obtained from IL-2 -treated patients did not have low-level constitutive expression of STAT binding factors as did LAK cells .
6,7 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

When these patient cells were further stimulated by IL-2 in vitro , additional differences in STAT induction patterns were noted .
8,9 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

These data provide further information on the molecular events occurring in immune cells generated through in vivo and in vitro administration of IL-2 , and further document that there is not a precise congruence between PBMC activated in vivo and in vitro by IL-2 .
11,13 G#cell_type|22,23 G#protein|35,36 G#cell_type|43,44 G#protein

Activated platelets induce monocyte chemotactic protein-1 secretion and surface expression of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 on endothelial cells [ see comments ]
0,2 G#cell_type|3,6 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type|15,17 G#cell_type

BACKGROUND : Platelet/endothelium interaction plays an important role in the pathophysiology of inflammation and atherosclerosis .


The role of platelets for monocyte chemotactic protein-1 ( MCP-1 ) secretion and surface expression of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ( ICAM-1 ) on endothelial cells has been assessed .
5,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

METHODS AND RESULTS : Monolayers of human umbilical vein endothelial cells were incubated with nonstimulated or ADP-activated platelets for 6 hours , and secretion of MCP-1 and surface expression of ICAM-1 were determined by ELISA and flow cytometry , respectively .
9,11 G#cell_type|6,11 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

In the presence of ADP-activated platelets , both MCP-1 secretion and ICAM-1 surface expression were significantly increased compared with nonstimulated platelets ( P &lt; 0.02 ) .
4,6 G#cell_type|8,9 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

Activation of the transcription factor nuclear factor-kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) determined by electrophoretic mobility shift assay and kappaB -dependent transcriptional activity was enhanced in the presence of activated platelets .
3,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

In addition , ADP- activated platelets induced MCP-1 and ICAM-1 promoter-dependent transcription .
4,6 G#cell_type|3,6 G#cell_type

Liposomal transfection of a double-stranded kappaB phosphorothioate oligonucleotide , but not of the mutated form , inhibited MCP-1 secretion and surface expression of ICAM-1 on activated endothelium ( P &lt; 0.05 ) .
17,18 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

CONCLUSIONS : The present study indicates that activated platelets modulate chemotactic ( MCP-1 ) and adhesive ( ICAM-1 ) properties of endothelial cells via an NF-kappaB -dependent mechanism .
7,9 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

Platelet-induced activation of the NF-kappaB system might contribute to early inflammatory events in atherogenesis .
4,5 G#protein

Retinoid X receptor and c-cerbA/thyroid hormone receptor regulate erythroid cell growth and differentiation .
0,3 G#protein|4,7 G#protein

Nuclear receptors are important regulators of erythroid cell development .
0,2 G#protein

Here we investigated the impact of retinoid X receptor ( RXR ) , retinoic acid receptor ( RAR ) , and of the c-erbA/thyroid hormone ( T3 ) receptor ( c-erbA/TR ) on growth and differentiation of erythroid cells using an in vitro culture system of stem cell factor-dependent erythroid progenitors .
6,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|23,29 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type|46,51 G#cell_type

RXR , RAR , and c-erbA/TR -specific ligands were found to induce erythroid-specific gene expression and to accelerate erythroid differentiation in culture , with T3 being most effective .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#DNA

Furthermore , while ligand-activated c-erbA/TR accelerated differentiation , unliganded c-erbA/TR effectively blocked differentiation and supported sustained progenitor growth in culture .
4,5 G#protein|9,10 G#protein

Thus , c-erbA/TR appears to act as a binary switch affecting erythroid cell fate : unliganded c-erbA/TR supports growth while ligand-activated c-erbA/TR induces differentiation .
2,3 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Additionally , to determine the impact of RXR for erythroid cell development , dominant interfering mutant RXRs , lacking the transcriptional activator functions AF-1 and AF-2 , or AF-2 only , or the entire DNA-binding domain , were introduced into erythroid progenitor cells via recombinant retrovirus vectors and analyzed for RXR -specific effects .
7,8 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|33,36 G#DNA|40,43 G#cell_type|50,51 G#protein

It was found that expression of wild-type RXR and of the RXR mutants devoid of AF-1 and/or AF-2 supported a transient outgrowth of erythroid cells .
7,8 G#protein|6,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

In marked contrast , expression of the dominant interfering deltaDNA-binding domain RXR , containing a deletion of the entire DNA-binding domain , was incompatible with erythroid cell growth in vitro , suggesting a pivotal role of RXR for erythroid cell development .
7,11 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA|36,37 G#protein

Peripheral T lymphocytes from women with breast cancer exhibit abnormal protein expression of several signaling molecules .
2,3 G#cell_type|0,3 G#cell_type|13,16 G#protein

We examined signaling molecules of peripheral blood T lymphocytes obtained from women with breast cancer .
5,9 G#cell_type

In 6 of 14 patients , T lymphocytes displayed an impaired ability to translocate NFeB p65 ( Rel-A ) following activation by anti-CD3 and IL-2 .
6,8 G#cell_type|14,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

This observation was made despite normal cytoplasmic levels of the Rel-A protein .
10,12 G#protein

We also detected abnormally low levels of the signaling molecules T-cell receptor ( TCR ) -zeta , ZAP-70 and p56lck in 4 of 14 breast cancer patients , i.e. , defects in T-cell signaling molecules .
8,10 G#protein|10,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|33,35 G#protein|32,35 G#protein
