T lymphocytes from 6 of the 14 patients also exhibited an increased expression of the dual specificity phosphatase , map kinase phosphatase-1 ( MKP-1 ) .
0,2 G#cell_type|16,18 G#protein|19,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

MKP-1 inactivates MAP kinase and therefore may interfere with the activation of c-jun and c-fos .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|12,13 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA

Abnormalities of I or more signaling molecules were found in 9 of 14 patients ; however , only 3 patients had T cells that exhibited all 5 defects .
5,7 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_type

Our data have implications for the detection of potentially dysfunctional T cells in patients with cancer .
10,12 G#cell_type

For example , the analysis of only 1 signaling molecule may allow patients with significant defects in T-cell signaling to go unnoticed .
8,10 G#protein

Finally , despite impaired Rel-A translocation , T cells were capable of transcribing IL-2 .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

Impairments in the translocation of Rel-B and c-Rel further suggest that the NFKB family members Rel-A , Rel-B and c-Rel are not required for the transcription of IL-2 in the peripheral T lymphocytes of patients with breast cancer .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type|30,33 G#cell_type

Specific glucocorticoid binding at different levels of human motor activity .


We studied the number of glucocorticoid receptors and dissociation constant in isolated human lymphocytes as well as blood concentrations of hormones produced by the hypothalamic-hypophyseal-adrenocortical system in three experimental series : at normal ( 17 subjects ) , decreased ( 10 subjects , a 360-d head-down bed rest ) and increased ( 8 subjects , physical exercise on bicycle ergometer ) levels of motor activity .
5,7 G#protein|11,14 G#cell_type

In the first series we found that the number of glucocorticoid receptors and dissociation constant did not depend on the season , on the age of subjects nor on cortisol concentrations in blood .
10,12 G#protein

In the second series we observed the following : at the end of the first month of bed rest the number of glucocorticoid receptors and receptor affinity significantly increased ; at the beginning of the third month of bed rest specific glucocorticoid binding significantly decreased and circadian rhythms of adrenocorticotropin and cortisol in blood varied markedly ; at the end of the sixth month of bed rest the number of glucocorticoid receptors returned to prebed rest levels and dissociation constant decreased .
22,24 G#protein|70,72 G#protein

In the third series physical exercises that induced an activation of the hypothalamic-hypophyseal-adrenocortical system ( maximal physical exercises and prolonged submaximal exercises at 70 % of maximal oxygen uptake ) led to a significant increase in the number of glucocorticoid receptors without changes of dissociation constant .
39,41 G#protein

These results indicate that both a decrease and an increase of human motor activity resulted in significant changes of specific glucocorticoid binding which were not influenced by changes of circulating hormone concentrations in blood but by some other factors affected by physical activity .


The small GTP -binding protein Rho potentiates AP-1 transcription in T cells .
5,6 G#protein|1,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

The Rho family of small GTP -binding proteins is involved in the regulation of cytoskeletal structure , gene transcription , specific cell fate development , and transformation .
1,2 G#protein|4,8 G#protein

We demonstrate in this report that overexpression of an activated form of Rho enhances AP-1 activity in Jurkat T cells in the presence of phorbol myristate acetate ( PMA ) , but activated Rho ( V14Rho ) has little or no effect on NFAT , Oct-1 , and NF-kappaB enhancer element activities under similar conditions .
12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,20 G#cell_line|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|45,46 G#protein|48,49 G#protein|48,51 G#DNA

Overexpression of a V14Rho construct incapable of membrane localization ( CAAX deleted ) abolishes PMA -induced AP-1 transcriptional activation .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|10,12 G#DNA|16,17 G#protein

The effect of Rho on AP-1 is independent of the mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway , as a dominant-negative MEK and a MEK inhibitor ( PD98059 ) did not affect Rho -induced AP-1 activity .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|31,32 G#protein

V14Rho binds strongly to protein kinase Calpha ( PKCalpha ) in vivo ; however , deletion of the CAAX site on V14Rho severely diminished this association .
0,1 G#protein|4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|18,20 G#DNA|21,22 G#protein

Evidence for a role for PKCalpha as an effector of Rho was obtained by the observation that coexpression of the N-terminal domain of PKCalpha blocked the effects of activated Rho plus PMA on AP-1 transcriptional activity .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|33,34 G#protein

These data suggest that Rho potentiates AP-1 transcription during T-cell activation
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Changes in PKC isoforms in human alveolar macrophages compared with blood monocytes .
2,4 G#protein|5,8 G#cell_type|10,12 G#cell_type

Alveolar macrophages play an important role in host defense and in other types of inflammatory processes in the lung .


These cells exhibit many alterations in function compared with their precursor cells , blood monocytes .
10,12 G#cell_type|13,15 G#cell_type

To evaluate a potential mechanism for these differences in function , we evaluated expression of protein kinase C ( PKC ) isoforms .
15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|15,22 G#protein

We found an increase in Ca2+ -dependent PKC isoforms in monocytes compared with alveolar macrophages .
7,8 G#protein|7,9 G#protein|5,9 G#protein

We also found differential expression of the Ca2+ -independent isoforms in alveolar macrophages compared with monocytes .
7,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type

One consequence of the activation of PKC can be increased expression of mitogen-activated protein ( MAP ) kinase pathways .
6,7 G#protein|12,18 G#protein

Therefore , we also evaluated activation of the MAP kinase extracellular signal-regulated kinase ( ERK ) 2 by the phorbol ester phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate ( PMA ) .
8,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|8,17 G#protein

PMA activated ERK2 kinase in both alveolar macrophages and monocytes ; however , monocytes consistently showed a significantly greater activation of ERK2 kinase by PMA compared with alveolar macrophages .
2,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#cell_type|13,14 G#cell_type|21,23 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

Another known consequence of the activation of PKC and subsequent activation of ERK kinase is activation of the transcription factor activator protein-1 ( AP-1 ) .
7,8 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|18,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

We evaluated the activation of AP-1 by PMA in both monocytes and macrophages .
5,6 G#protein|10,11 G#cell_type

We found very little detectable activation of AP-1 , as assessed in a gel shift assay , in alveolar macrophages , whereas monocytes showed a substantial activation of AP-1 by PMA .
7,8 G#protein|18,20 G#cell_type|22,23 G#cell_type|28,29 G#protein

These studies show that the differential expression of PKC isoforms in alveolar macrophages and blood monocytes is associated with important functional alterations in the cells .
8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type|15,16 G#cell_type|14,16 G#cell_type

Expression of gamma-IFN responsive genes in scavenger receptor over-expressing monocytes is associated with xanthomatosis .
2,5 G#DNA|9,10 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type

We have recently described an inherited over-expression of the macrophage scavenger receptor ( SR ) in blood monocytes from members of a kindred , only two of whom displayed extensive xanthomatosis .
9,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type

Using mRNA differential display we demonstrated abnormally high expression of the signal transducer and activator of transcription ( STAT1alpha ) in monocytes from the proband II-2 .
11,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#cell_type|24,26 G#cell_line

Expression of gamma-interferon inducible protein 10 ( IP-10 ) , a STAT1alpha -responsive gene and mediator of inflammatory response , was also abnormally expressed in the monocytes from II-2 .
2,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#DNA|26,27 G#cell_type|28,29 G#cell_line

Over-expression of both genes was restricted to monocytes from II-2 and was not observed in monocytes from the clinically unaffected family members , unlike that of SR .
7,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#cell_line|15,16 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein

Gel retardation assays with THP-1 cell extracts identified gamma-IFN inducible DNA binding activity to three potential STATI DNA binding elements in the human IP-10 promoter region from nucleotides -Â 245 to -Â 188 .
4,6 G#cell_line|8,9 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|16,20 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|22,26 G#DNA|27,31 G#DNA

Taken together these results suggest that gamma-interferon mediated cell activation is responsible for STAT1alpha -induced transcription of the IP-10 gene in THP-1 macrophages as well as in monocytes from II-2 .
13,14 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,23 G#cell_line|27,28 G#cell_type|29,30 G#cell_line

Analysis of monocytes from familial hypercholesterolemic ( FH ) subjects , who frequently develop xanthomatosis , revealed a significant number of subjects with elevated STAT1alpha and IP-10 expression .
2,3 G#cell_type

Our data suggest that the inflammatory effects of gamma-IFN signaling could play a role in foam cell formation and xanthomatosis .
8,9 G#protein

Redox signals and NF-kappaB activation in T cells .
3,4 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type

Accumulating data from a number of laboratories have recently indicated that the response of transcription factor NF-kappaB to alterations in the redox homeostasis of cells may play an important role in modulating immune function .
14,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

The activation of NF-kappaB has been recognized to regulate a number of genes necessary for normal T cell responses including IL-2 , IL-6 , IL-8 , and several T cell surface receptors .
3,4 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|28,32 G#protein

Diminished NF-kappaB activity has been shown to occur in T cells with aging , suggesting that impaired activation of NF-kappaB might occur during cellular senescence .
1,2 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type|19,20 G#protein

In addition , aberrancies in NF-kappaB activity have been implicated in the immunopathogenesis of diseases involving immune or inflammatory processes such as atherosclerosis and HIV-1 infection .
5,6 G#protein

The role of H2O2 and other reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) as an integratory secondary messenger for divergent T cell signals has been complicated by the fact that various T cell lines and peripheral blood T cells differ markedly in the levels of NF-kappaB activation induced by oxidant stress .
30,33 G#cell_line|36,38 G#cell_type|34,38 G#cell_type|44,45 G#protein

Additionally , proposed pathways of NF-kappaB activation have been based on indirect evidence provided by experiments which used antioxidants to inhibit active NF-kappaB formation .
5,6 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Further , complete activation of T cells requires at least two signals , one that stimulates an increase in intracellular calcium and one that stimulates enzymatic processes including kinases .
5,7 G#cell_type

Similarly , substantial evidence indicates that full activation of NF-kappaB requires dual signals .
9,10 G#protein

The ability of H2O2 or other ROS to induce T cell signals and functional responses by these two mechanisms is reviewed and the specific response of NF-kappaB to redox changes in T cells is examined .
26,27 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

Data are also presented to suggest that the redox regulation in NF-kappaB activation may be relevant to immune-related diseases and to aging .
11,12 G#protein

Uncoupling of nonreceptor tyrosine kinases from PLC-gamma1 in an SLP-76-deficient T cell .
3,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Activation of nonreceptor protein tyrosine kinases ( PTKs ) is essential for T cell receptor ( TCR ) responsiveness ; however , the function of individual PTK substrates is often uncertain .
4,6 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

A mutant T cell line was isolated that lacked expression of SLP-76 ( SH2 domain-containing leukocyte protein of 76 kilodaltons ) , a hematopoietically expressed adaptor protein and PTK substrate .
1,5 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|13,17 G#protein|23,27 G#protein|28,30 G#protein

SLP-76 was not required for TCR -induced tyrosine phosphorylation of most proteins , but was required for optimal tyrosine phosphorylation and activation of phospholipase C-gamma1 ( PLC-gamma1 ) , as well as Ras pathway activation .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|32,33 G#protein

TCR -inducible gene expression was dependent on SLP-76 .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

Thus , coupling of TCR-regulated PTKs to downstream signaling pathways requires SLP-76 .
5,6 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

A novel function of Stat1 and Stat3 proteins in erythropoietin -induced erythroid differentiation of a human leukemia cell line .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_line

We recently determined that erythropoietin ( EPO ) activates 3 members of the signal transducer and activator of transcription ( STAT ) family , Stat1alpha , Stat3 , and Stat5 , in the human EPO -dependent cell lines , UT-7 and UT-7/ EPO ( Kirito et al , J Biol Chem 272 : 16507 , 1997 ) .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|33,38 G#cell_line|39,40 G#cell_line|42,43 G#protein|41,43 G#cell_line

In addition , we have shown that Stat1alpha , but not Stat3 , is involved in EPO -induced cellular proliferation .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In this study , we examined the roles of Stat1alpha and Stat3 in EPO -induced erythroid differentiation .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

UT-7/GM was used as a model system , because this cell line can differentiate into erythroid-lineage cells with EPO treatment ( Komatsu et al , Blood 89 : 4021 , 1997 ) .
0,1 G#cell_line|15,17 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

We found that EPO did not activate Stat1alpha or Stat3 in UT-7/GM cells .
3,4 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_line

Transfection experiments showed that both Stat1alpha and Stat3 inhibited the induction by EPO of gamma-globin and erythroid-specific 5-aminolevulinate synthetase transcripts , resulting in a reduction of the percentage of hemoglobin-positive cells .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,20 G#RNA|29,31 G#cell_type

Dominant negative forms of Stat1alpha or Stat3 promoted the EPO -induced erythroid differentiation of UT-7/GM cells , even in the presence of granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor , although this cytokine never induced erythroid differentiation of the parent UT-7/GM cells with or without EPO .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|14,16 G#cell_line|22,25 G#protein|35,38 G#cell_line|41,42 G#protein

A cell cycle analysis showed that the constitutive activation of Stat1alpha , but not Stat3 , shortened the period of G0/G1 prolongation caused by EPO stimulation .
10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

Taken together , our data suggest that Stat1alpha and Stat3 act as negative regulators in EPO -induced erythroid differentiation .
7,8 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein

Specifically , Stat1alpha may activate a cell cycle-associated gene ( s ) , leading to the entry of cells into the cell cycle .
2,3 G#protein|6,9 G#DNA

Ro 09-2210 exhibits potent anti-proliferative effects on activated T cells by selectively blocking MKK activity .
8,10 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

By using high throughput screening of microbial broths , we have identified a compound , designated Ro 09-2210 , which is able to block anti-CD3 induced peripheral blood T cell activation with an IC50 = 40 nM .
24,25 G#protein

Ro 09-2210 was also able to block antigen-induced IL-2 secretion with an IC50 = 30 nM , but was considerably less potent at blocking Ca2+ flux stimulated by anti-CD3 treatment .
8,9 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

To determine the mechanism of action of Ro 09-2210 , we set up a transient expression system in Jurkat T cells using a variety of reporter gene constructs and showed effective inhibition of phorbol ester / ionomycin -induced NF-AT activation and anti-CD3 induced NF-AT with IC50 = 7.7 and 10 nM , respectively .
18,21 G#cell_line|38,39 G#protein|43,44 G#protein

Ro 09-2210 was also able to inhibit phorbol ester / ionomycin -induced activation of AP1 with IC50 = &lt; 10 nM .
14,15 G#protein

We further showed that Ro 09-2210 was unable to inhibit c-jun induced expression of AP1 -dependent reporter constructs ( IC50 &gt; 500 nM ) , but was able to potently inhibit ras-induced AP1 activation ( IC50 = 20 nM ) .
10,11 G#DNA|14,15 G#protein|14,18 G#DNA|32,33 G#protein

This suggested that Ro 09-2210 was inhibiting an activator of AP-1 which was upstream of c-jun and downstream of ras signaling .
10,11 G#protein|15,16 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein

To investigate further , we then purified a number of different kinases , including PKC , PhK , ZAP-70 , ERK , and MEK 1 ( a MKK ) , and showed that Ro 09-2210 was a selective inhibitor of MEK1 in vitro ( IC50 = 59 nM ) .
14,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|40,41 G#protein

Coactivation by OCA-B : definition of critical regions and synergism with general cofactors .
2,3 G#protein

Molecular dissection of the B-cell-specific transcription coactivator OCA-B has revealed distinct regions important , respectively , for recruitment to immunoglobulin promoters through interaction with octamer-bound Oct-1 and for subsequent coactivator function .
7,8 G#protein|19,21 G#DNA|25,26 G#protein|24,26 G#protein

Further analysis of general coactivator requirements showed that selective removal of PC4 from the essential USA fraction severely impairs Oct-1 and OCA-B function in a cell-free system reconstituted with partially purified factors .
11,12 G#protein

Full activity can be restored by the combined action of recombinant PC4 and the PC4 -depleted USA fraction , thus suggesting a joint requirement for PC4 and another , USA-derived component ( s ) for optimal function of Oct-1 /OCA-B in the reconstituted system .
11,12 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|38,39 G#protein|39,40 G#protein

Indeed , USA-derived PC2 was found to act synergistically with PC4 in reproducing the function of intact USA in the assay system .
2,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Consistent with the requirement for PC4 in the reconstituted system , OCA-B was found to interact directly with PC4 .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Surprisingly , however , removal of PC4 from the unfractionated nuclear extract has no detrimental effect on OCA-B / Oct-1 -dependent transcription .
6,7 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

These results lead to a general model for the synergistic function of activation domains in Oct-1 and OCA-B ( mediated by the combined action of the multiple USA components ) and , further , suggest a functional redundancy in general coactivators .
15,16 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|39,41 G#protein

Activation of Stat-3 is involved in the induction of apoptosis after ligation of major histocompatibility complex class I molecules on human Jurkat T cells .
2,3 G#protein|13,19 G#protein|21,24 G#cell_line|20,24 G#cell_line

Activation of Janus tyrosine kinases ( Jak ) and Signal transducers and activators of transcription ( Stat ) after ligation of major histocompatibility complex class I ( MHC-I ) was explored in Jurkat T cells .
3,5 G#protein|2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|32,35 G#cell_line

Cross-linking of MHC-I mediated tyrosine phosphorylation of Tyk2 , but not Jak1 , Jak2 , and Jak3 .
2,3 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

In addition , the transcription factor Stat-3 was tyrosine phosphorylated in the cytoplasm and subsequently translocated to the cell nucleus .
4,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Data obtained by electrophoretic mobility shift assay suggested that the activated Stat-3 protein associates with the human serum-inducible element ( hSIE ) DNA-probe derived from the interferon-gamma activated site ( GAS ) in the c-fos promoter , a common DNA sequence for Stat protein binding .
10,13 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA|16,23 G#DNA|26,29 G#DNA|30,31 G#DNA|34,36 G#DNA|42,44 G#protein

An association between hSIE and Stat-3 after MHC-I ligation was directly demonstrated by precipitating Stat-3 from nuclear extracts with biotinylated hSIE probe and avidin -coupled agarose .
3,4 G#DNA|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#DNA|20,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein

To investigate the function of the activated Stat-3 , Jurkat T cells were transiently transfected with a Stat-3 isoform lacking the transactivating domain .
7,8 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

This dominant-negative acting Stat-3 isoform significantly inhibited apoptosis induced by ligation of MHC-I .
3,4 G#protein|1,5 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In conclusion , our data suggest the involvement of the Jak/Stat signal pathway in MHC-I -induced signal transduction in T cells .
10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|19,21 G#cell_type

IL-2 -induced growth of CD8+ T cell prolymphocytic leukemia cells mediated by NF-kappaB induction and IL-2 receptor alpha expression .
0,1 G#protein|4,10 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,18 G#protein

The binding of interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) to its receptor on normal T cells induces nuclear expression of nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) , activation of the IL-2 receptor ( IL-2R ) alpha chain gene , and cell proliferation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|18,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|28,29 G#protein|28,30 G#protein|28,35 G#protein|28,36 G#DNA

In the present study , the role of IL-2R signaling in the growth of CD8+ T cell prolymphocytic leukemia ( T-PLL ) cells has been investigated .
8,9 G#protein|14,23 G#cell_line

Flow cytometry revealed that primary leukemia cells from a patient with CD8+ T-PLL expressed IL-2R alpha and beta chains , and the cells showed a proliferative response and an increase in IL-2Ralpha expression on culture with exogeneous IL-2 .
4,7 G#cell_type|14,19 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

Northern blot analysis failed to detect IL-2 mRNA , suggesting that IL-2 may act in a paracrine manner in vivo .
6,8 G#RNA|11,12 G#protein

Electrophoretic mobility-shift assays revealed that recombinant IL-2 increased NF-kappaB binding activity in nuclear extracts of the leukemia cells , and Northern blot analysis showed that IL-2 increased the abundance of mRNAs encoding the NF-kappaB components c-Rel and KBF1 in these cells .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein|33,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein

IL-2 binding analysis demonstrated that IL-2 markedly increased the number of low affinity IL-2Rs on the leukemia cells , without an effect on the number of high-affinity IL-2Rs .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|26,28 G#protein

These results show that IL-2 is capable of inducing the nuclear expression of NF-kappaB in primary CD8+ T-PLL cells , and that this effect is mediated , at least in part , at a pretranslational level
4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,19 G#cell_line

Dimethyldithiocarbamate inhibits in vitro activation of primary human CD4+ T lymphocytes .
6,11 G#cell_type

Dithiocarbamates ( DTC ) , a diverse group of industrial and therapeutic chemicals , have been reported to inhibit , enhance or have no effect on the immune system .


These apparent inconsistencies reflect the complexity of the DTCs biological activities and are probably due in part to differences in dose , route of exposure , animal species used and/or specific compound tested .


The studies described herein were undertaken to investigate the immunotoxicity of one member of this family , dimethyldithiocarbamate ( DMDTC ) .


We demonstrate that 0.1-0.5 microM DMDTC inhibits TNF-alpha -induced activation of NF-kappaB in primary human CD4+ T cells .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,18 G#cell_type

This inhibition is not accompanied by a loss in viability , and DMDTC -treated T cells retain other active signaling pathways throughout the exposure duration .
12,16 G#cell_type

The inhibition of NF-kappaB is apparently permanent as DMDTC -treated T cells did not regain normal TNF-alpha activation , even after 72 h in culture .
3,4 G#protein|8,12 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein

DMDTC does not appear to alter NF-kappaB directly as pre-incubation of nuclear extracts with DMDTC does not diminish binding activity of this protein .
6,7 G#protein

We further demonstrate that 0.1-0.5 microM DMDTC inhibits intracellular IL-2 production and decreases surface expression of CD25 ( the alpha subunit of the IL-2 receptor ) in T cells stimulated with phorbol ester .
9,10 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

These data demonstrate that DMDTC is a potent immunosuppressive compound in vitro .


Human 15-lipoxygenase gene promoter : analysis and identification of DNA binding sites for IL-13-induced regulatory factors in monocytes .
0,4 G#DNA|9,12 G#DNA|13,16 G#protein|17,18 G#cell_type

In order to study the transcriptional control of 15-LO expression , we have cloned and sequenced the human 15-LO promoter region .
8,9 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|17,21 G#DNA

The 15-LO promoter is associated with a CpG island at the 5'-end of the gene , and sequence analysis reveals putative Sp1 and Ap2 binding site/s and absence of TATA or CAAT motifs .
1,2 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|21,26 G#DNA|29,33 G#DNA

Transcription is initiated at one major site .


Using deletion constructs , we have defined an active promoter region of 1056 bp .
1,3 G#DNA|8,11 G#DNA

Gel-shift assays revealed that transcriptional factor ( s ) induced only in response to IL-13 treatment of human peripheral blood monocytes bind to the 15-LO promoter DNA .
4,6 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_type|24,25 G#protein|24,27 G#DNA

Two regions , DP1 ( -140 to -92 bp ) and DP2 ( -353 to -304 bp ) of the promoter were essential for transcription in HeLa cells and human peripheral monocytes .
3,4 G#DNA|5,9 G#DNA|11,12 G#DNA|13,17 G#DNA|26,28 G#cell_line|29,32 G#cell_type

Hela nuclear extracts contained a specific nuclear factor ( s ) binding to 15-LO promoter DNA which are distinct from those derived from IL-13 -treated human peripheral monocyte nuclear extracts .
5,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,16 G#DNA|23,24 G#protein|23,28 G#cell_line

In addition , fluorescent in situ hybridization ( FISH ) results refined the previous localization of 15-LO to human chromosome 17p13.3 .
16,17 G#protein|18,21 G#DNA

Ex vivo activation of tumor-draining lymph node T cells reverses defects in signal transduction molecules .
7,9 G#cell_type|4,9 G#cell_type|12,15 G#protein

The adoptive transfer of tumor-draining lymph node ( LN ) T cells activated ex vivo with anti-CD3 and interleukin 2 ( IL-2 ) mediates the regression of the poorly immunogenic murine melanoma D5 .
10,12 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

The efficacy of the activated LN cells is augmented when the sensitizing tumor is a genetically modified variant ( designated D5G6 ) that secretes granulocyte/macrophage-colony-stimulating factor .
5,7 G#cell_type|4,7 G#cell_type|15,18 G#cell_line|20,21 G#cell_line|24,26 G#protein

In contrast to anti-CD3/ IL-2 - activated LN cells , adoptive transfer of freshly isolated tumor-draining LN T cells has no therapeutic activity .
4,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type|6,9 G#cell_type|3,9 G#cell_line|15,19 G#cell_type

To determine whether the acquisition of antitumor function during ex vivo activation is associated with modifications in signal transduction capacity , the protein tyrosine kinases p56lck and p59fyn and proteins of the NF-kappaB family were analyzed in tumor-draining LN T cells .
23,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|32,34 G#protein|37,41 G#cell_type

The levels of p56lck and p59fyn were lower in tumor-draining than in normal LN T cells and production of tyrosine -phosphorylated substrates was markedly depressed following anti-CD3 stimulation .
3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|12,16 G#cell_type|19,22 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

After 5-day anti-CD3 /IL-2 activation , levels of p56lck and p59fyn and protein tyrosine kinase activity increased .
2,3 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Interestingly , the levels of p56lck , p59fyn , and tyrosine kinase activity were higher in activated T cells derived from LN that drained D5G6 than they were in those from D5 tumors .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,19 G#cell_type

In contrast , the cytoplasmic levels of c-Rel and Rel A were normal in freshly isolated tumor-draining LN , as was nuclear kappaB DNA-binding activity induced by anti-CD3 mAb or phorbol myristate acetate .
7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,29 G#protein

Stimulation of activated LN cells with D5 tumor cells induced the nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB .
3,5 G#cell_type|2,5 G#cell_type|6,9 G#cell_type|14,15 G#protein

These findings indicate that the recovery of proteins mediating signal transduction through the T cell receptor/CD3 complex in LN T cells activated ex vivo was associated with the acquisition of antitumor function .
13,17 G#protein|18,21 G#cell_type

Suppression of human anti-porcine T-cell immune responses by major histocompatibility complex class II transactivator constructs lacking the amino terminal domain .
8,15 G#DNA

BACKGROUND : The class II transactivator ( CIITA ) is a bi- or multifunctional domain protein that acts as a transcriptional activator and plays a critical role in the expression of MHC class II genes .
3,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,16 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|31,35 G#DNA

We have previously demonstrated that a mutated form of the human CIITA gene , coding for a protein lacking the amino terminal 151 amino acids , acts as a potent dominant-negative suppressor of HLA class II expression .
11,12 G#protein|10,13 G#DNA|20,25 G#protein|33,36 G#protein

Porcine MHC class II antigens are potent stimulators of direct T-cell recognition by human CD4+ T cells and are , therefore , likely to play an important role in the rejection responses to transgenic pig donors in clinical xenotransplantation .
0,5 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type

We were , therefore , interested in examining mutated CIITA constructs for their effect on porcine MHC class II expression .
9,10 G#protein|9,11 G#DNA|16,19 G#protein

METHODS : Stable transfectants of the porcine vascular endothelial cell line PIEC with mutated CIITA constructs were tested for SLA-DR and SLA-DQ induction by recombinant porcine interferon-gamma .
6,11 G#cell_line|11,12 G#cell_line|14,15 G#protein|14,16 G#DNA|19,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|24,27 G#protein

Transient transfectants of the porcine B-cell line L23 with the mutated CIITA constructs were tested for the suppression of constitutive SLA-DR and SLA-DQ expression .
4,8 G#cell_line|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#DNA

T-cell proliferation studies were performed using highly purified human CD4+ T cells .
8,12 G#cell_type

RESULTS : In preliminary studies , we demonstrated that transfection of the PIEC line with full-length human CIITA constructs resulted in strong expression of SLA-DR and SLA-DQ antigens , thus establishing the cross-species effectiveness of human CIITA in the pig .
12,14 G#cell_line|17,18 G#protein|17,19 G#DNA|24,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|36,37 G#protein|35,37 G#protein

The mutated human CIITA constructs were , therefore , tested in the pig .
3,4 G#protein|1,5 G#DNA

PIEC clones stably transfected with one of these constructs showed up to 99 % suppression of SLA-DR and SLA-DQ antigen induction and marked suppression of SLA-DRA mRNA induction .
0,2 G#cell_line|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#RNA

Moreover , transient transfection of the porcine B-cell line L23 showed up to 90 % suppression of constitutive SLA-DR and SLA-DQ antigen expression in 5-8 days .
6,10 G#cell_line

In functional studies , interferon-gamma -stimulated PIEC clones transfected with this mutated CIITA construct failed to stimulate purified human CD4+ T lymphocytes .
4,5 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_line|4,8 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein|11,13 G#protein|18,22 G#cell_type

CONCLUSION : Mutated human CIITA constructs are potent suppressors of porcine MHC class II expression .
4,5 G#protein|2,6 G#DNA|11,14 G#protein

Macrophages in human atheroma contain PPARgamma : differentiation-dependent peroxisomal proliferator-activated receptor gamma ( PPARgamma ) expression and reduction of MMP-9 activity through PPARgamma activation in mononuclear phagocytes in vitro .
0,1 G#cell_type|5,6 G#protein|7,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

Mononuclear phagocytes play an important role in atherosclerosis and its sequela plaque rupture in part by their secretion of matrix metalloproteinases ( MMPs ) , including MMP-9 .
0,2 G#cell_type|19,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

Peroxisomal proliferator-activated receptor gamma ( PPARgamma ) , a transcription factor in the nuclear receptor superfamily , regulates gene expression in response to various activators , including 15-deoxy-delta12,14-prostaglandin J2 and the antidiabetic agent troglitazone .
0,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

The role of PPARgamma in human atherosclerosis is unexplored .
3,4 G#protein

We report here that monocytes/macrophages in human atherosclerotic lesions ( n = 12 ) express immunostainable PPARgamma .
4,5 G#cell_type|16,17 G#protein|15,17 G#protein

Normal artery specimens ( n = 6 ) reveal minimal immunoreactive PPARgamma .
11,12 G#protein|9,12 G#protein

Human monocytes and monocyte-derived macrophages cultured for 6 days in 5 % human serum expressed PPARgamma mRNA and protein by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and Western blotting , respectively .
0,2 G#cell_type|3,5 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#RNA

In addition , PPARgamma mRNA expression in U937 cells increased during phorbol 12-myristate 13 acetate -induced differentiation .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#RNA|7,9 G#cell_line

Stimulation of PPARgamma with troglitazone or 15-deoxy-delta12,14-prostaglandin J2 in human monocyte-derived macrophages inhibited MMP-9 gelatinolytic activity in a concentration-dependent fashion as revealed by zymography .
2,3 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

This inhibition correlates with decreased MMP-9 secretion as determined by Western blotting .
5,6 G#protein

Thus , PPARgamma is present in macrophages in human atherosclerotic lesions and may regulate expression and activity of MMP-9 , an enzyme implicated in plaque rupture .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein

PPARgamma is likely to be an important regulator of monocyte/macrophage function with relevance for human atherosclerotic disease .
0,1 G#protein

Erythropoietin induces tyrosine phosphorylation of Jak2 , STAT5A , and STAT5B in primary cultured human erythroid precursors .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,17 G#cell_type

We examined signaling by erythropoietin in highly purified human colony forming unit-erythroid cells , generated in vitro from CD34(+) cells .
4,5 G#protein|6,13 G#cell_type|18,20 G#cell_type

We found that erythropoietin induces tyrosine phosphorylation of Jak2 , STAT5A , and STAT5B .
3,4 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Tyrosine phosphorylation of Jak2 reaches a peak around 10 minutes after stimulation and is maximum at 5 U/mL of erythropoietin .
3,4 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

Tyrosine phosphorylation of STAT5 is accompanied by the translocation of activated STAT5 to the nucleus as shown by electrophoretic mobility shift assay ( EMSA ) using 32Pi-labeled STAT5 binding site in the beta-casein promoter .
3,4 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|27,30 G#DNA|32,34 G#DNA

Tyrosine phosphorylation STAT1 or STAT3 was not detected in human erythroid precursors after stimulation with erythropoietin .
2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|9,12 G#cell_type|15,16 G#protein

Crkl , an SH2/SH3 adapter protein , becomes coimmunoprecipitated specifically with STAT5 from erythropoietin -stimulated erythroid cells ; although it was shown to become associated with c-Cbl in the studies using cell lines .
0,1 G#protein|3,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_line

Thus , human erythroid precursors can be expanded in vitro in sufficient numbers and purity to allow its usage in signal transduction studies .
2,5 G#cell_type

This report sets a basis for further studies on signaling in primary cultured human erythroid precursors , which in turn contribute to our better understanding in the differentiation processes of erythrocytes and their precursors .
13,16 G#cell_type|11,16 G#cell_type|30,31 G#cell_type

Oxidative stress suppresses transcription factor activities in stimulated lymphocytes .
3,5 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Effects of oxidative stress on stimulation-dependent signal transduction , leading to IL-2 expression , were studied .
11,12 G#protein

Purified quiescent human blood T lymphocytes were subjected to : ( i ) acute exposure to hydrogen peroxide ; ( ii ) chronic exposure to hydrogen peroxide ; and ( iii ) acute exposure to ionizing radiation .
0,6 G#cell_type

The cells were then stimulated for 6 h .


DNA-binding activities ( determined by the electrophoretic mobility shift assay ) of three transcription factors : NFkappaB , AP-1 and NFAT , were abolished in the lymphocytes by all three modes of oxidative stress .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,27 G#cell_type

The lymphocytes exhibited lipid peroxidation only upon exposure to the lowest level of hydrogen peroxide used ( 20 microM ) .
1,2 G#cell_type

All three modes of oxidative stress induced catalase activity in the lymphocytes .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#cell_type

The only exception was hydrogen peroxide at 20 microM , which did not induce catalase activity .
14,15 G#protein

We conclude that : ( i ) suppression of specific transcription factor functions can potentially serve as a marker of exposure to oxidative stress and its effects on human lymphocytes ; ( ii ) lipid peroxidation is only detectable in human lymphocytes upon exposure to weak oxidative stress which does not induce catalase activity ; ( iii ) therefore , transcription factor DNA-binding activities are more sensitive to oxidative stress than lipid peroxidation .
10,12 G#protein|28,30 G#cell_type|40,42 G#cell_type|52,53 G#protein|60,62 G#protein

IL-4 -dependent regulation of TGF-alpha and TGF-beta1 expression in human eosinophils .
0,1 G#protein|9,11 G#cell_type

TGFs play important roles in wound healing and carcinogenesis .
0,1 G#protein

We have previously demonstrated that eosinophils infiltrating into different pathologic processes elaborate TGF-alpha and TGF-beta1 .
5,6 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Eosinophils infiltrating hamster cutaneous wounds were found to express TGFs sequentially .
0,1 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein

In this study , we examined the biologic mediators that may regulate the expression of TGF -alpha and -beta1 by eosinophils .
15,19 G#protein|20,21 G#cell_type

Eosinophils were isolated from the peripheral blood of healthy donors and cultured in the absence or presence of IL-3 , IL-4 , and IL-5 .
0,1 G#cell_type|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Cells were analyzed by in situ hybridization and immunohistochemistry .


Supernatants from these cultures were assayed for secreted TGF-alpha and TGF-beta1 using TGF -specific ELISAs .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

IL-3 , IL-4 , and IL-5 independently up-regulated TGF-beta1 mRNA and product expression by eosinophils in all donors .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|8,10 G#RNA|14,15 G#cell_type

Interestingly , TGF-alpha production by eosinophils was up-regulated by IL-3 and IL-5 but was down-regulated by IL-4 .
2,3 G#protein|5,6 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

Consistent with the ability of IL-4 to regulate eosinophil responses , IL-4 signaling molecules are present in human eosinophils .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|18,19 G#cell_type|17,19 G#cell_type

The observation that IL-4 can differentially regulate the expression of TGF-alpha and TGF-beta1 suggests that IL-4 may serve as a physiologic molecular switch of TGF expression by the infiltrating eosinophils in wound healing and carcinogenesis .
3,4 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#cell_type

MLL and CALM are fused to AF10 in morphologically distinct subsets of acute leukemia with translocation t(10;11) : both rearrangements are associated with a poor prognosis .
2,3 G#DNA|6,7 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA

The translocation t(10;11) (p13;q14) has been observed in acute lymphoblastic leukemia ( ALL ) as well as acute myeloid leukemia ( AML ) .
1,3 G#DNA|1,4 G#DNA

A recent study showed a MLL/ AF10 fusion in all cases of AML with t(10;11) and various breakpoints on chromosome 11 ranging from q13 to q23 .
6,7 G#DNA|5,8 G#DNA|14,15 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|25,26 G#DNA

We recently cloned CALM ( Clathrin Assembly Lymphoid Myeloid leukemia gene ) , the fusion partner of AF10 at 11q14 in the monocytic cell line U937 .
3,4 G#DNA|5,11 G#DNA|17,18 G#DNA|19,20 G#DNA|22,26 G#cell_line

To further define the role of these genes in acute leukemias , 10 cases ( 9 AML and 1 ALL ) with cytogenetically proven t(10;11)(p12-14;q13-21) and well-characterized morphology , immunophenotype , and clinical course were analyzed .
24,25 G#DNA

Interphase fluorescence in situ hybridization ( FISH ) was performed with 2 YACs flanking the CALM region , a YAC contig of the MLL region , and a YAC spanning the AF10 breakpoint .
12,13 G#DNA|15,16 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|19,21 G#DNA|23,25 G#DNA|28,29 G#DNA|31,32 G#DNA

Rearrangement of at least one of these genes was detected in all cases with balanced t(10;11) .
15,16 G#DNA

In 4 cases , including 3 AML with immature morphology ( 1 AML -M0 and 2 AML -M1 ) and 1 ALL , the signals of the CALM YACS were separated in interphase cells , indicating a translocation breakpoint within the CALM region .
27,28 G#DNA|27,29 G#DNA|41,42 G#DNA|41,43 G#DNA

MLL was rearranged in 3 AML with myelomonocytic differentiation ( 2 AML-M2 and 1 AML-M5 ) , including 1 secondary AML .


In all 3 cases , a characteristic immunophenotype was identified ( CD4+ , CD13 - , CD33+ , CD65s+ ) .
11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

AF-10 was involved in 5 of 6 evaluable cases , including 1 case without detectable CALM or MLL rearrangement .
15,16 G#DNA

In 2 complex translocations , none of the three genes was rearranged .


All cases had a remarkably poor prognosis , with a mean survival of 9.6 +/- 6.6 months .


For the 7 AML cases that were uniformly treated according to the AMLCG86/92 protocols , disease-free and overall survival was significantly worse than for the overall study group ( P = .03 and P = .01 , respectively ) .


We conclude that the t(10;11)(p13;q14) indicates CALM and MLL rearrangements in morphologically distinct subsets of acute leukemia and may be associated with a poor prognosis .
4,5 G#DNA|6,10 G#DNA

The role of E-proteins in B- and T- lymphocyte development .
3,4 G#protein

Department of lymphocytes from hematopoietic stem cells is controlled , in part , by the activity of transcriptional regulatory proteins .
2,3 G#cell_type|4,7 G#cell_type|17,20 G#protein

In particular , one class of helix-loop-helix proteins , termed E-proteins , have been implicated in the regulation of gene expression during B-cell development .
6,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

Recent analysis of gene-targeted mice has allowed a direct assessment of the functional roles of several E-protein family members in hematopoiesis .
15,19 G#protein

In this review we describe the defects in B- and T- lymphocyte development in mice carrying targeted mutations in the E-protein genes and discuss our current understanding of the role of these proteins in lymphoid development
20,22 G#DNA

Epstein-Barr virus-transforming protein latent infection membrane protein 1 activates transcription factor NF-kappaB through a pathway that includes the NF-kappaB -inducing kinase and the IkappaB kinases IKKalpha and IKKbeta .
0,3 G#protein|3,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|18,21 G#protein|23,25 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

The Epstein-Barr virus oncoprotein latent infection membrane protein 1 ( LMP1 ) is a constitutively aggregated pseudo-tumor necrosis factor receptor ( TNFR ) that activates transcription factor NF-kappaB through two sites in its C-terminal cytoplasmic domain .
1,4 G#protein|4,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|33,36 G#protein

One site is similar to activated TNFRII in associating with TNFR -associated factors TRAF1 and TRAF2 , and the second site is similar to TNFRI in associating with the TNFRI death domain interacting protein TRADD .
6,7 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|24,25 G#protein|29,30 G#protein|29,32 G#protein|29,34 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

TNFRI has been recently shown to activate NF-kappaB through association with TRADD , RIP , and TRAF2 ; activation of the NF-kappaB -inducing kinase ( NIK ) ; activation of the IkappaB alpha kinases ( IKKalpha and IKKbeta ) ; and phosphorylation of IkappaB alpha .
0,1 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,34 G#protein|35,36 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|43,45 G#protein

IkappaB alpha phosphorylation on Ser-32 and Ser-36 is followed by its degradation and NF-kappaB activation .
0,2 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

In this report , we show that NF-kappaB activation by LMP1 or by each of its effector sites is mediated by a pathway that includes NIK , IKKalpha , and IKKbeta .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|16,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|30,31 G#protein

Dominant negative mutants of NIK , IKKalpha , or IKKbeta substantially inhibited NF-kappaB activation by LMP1 or by each of its effector sites .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|21,23 G#protein

Targeted disruption of the MyD88 gene results in loss of IL-1- and IL-18- mediated function .
4,6 G#DNA

MyD88 , originally isolated as a myeloid differentiation primary response gene , is shown to act as an adaptor in interleukin-1 ( IL-1 ) signaling by interacting with both the IL-1 receptor complex and IL-1 receptor-associated kinase ( IRAK ) .
0,1 G#protein|8,11 G#DNA|20,21 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|30,31 G#protein|30,33 G#protein|34,35 G#protein|34,37 G#protein|38,39 G#protein

Mice generated by gene targeting to lack MyD88 have defects in T cell proliferation as well as induction of acute phase proteins and cytokines in response to IL-1 .
7,8 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|27,28 G#protein

Increases in interferon-gamma production and natural killer cell activity in response to IL-18 are abrogated .
2,3 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In vivo Th1 response is also impaired .


Furthermore , IL-18 -induced activation of NF-kappaB and c-Jun N-terminal kinase ( JNK ) is blocked in MyD88 -/- Th1-developing cells .
2,3 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|17,21 G#cell_line

Taken together , these results demonstrate that MyD88 is a critical component in the signaling cascade that is mediated by IL-1 receptor as well as IL-18 receptor .
7,8 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|20,22 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|25,27 G#protein

Ciprofloxacin induces an immunomodulatory stress response in human T lymphocytes .
7,10 G#cell_type

Exposure of cells to adverse environmental conditions invokes a genetically programmed series of events resulting in the induction of specific genes .
19,21 G#DNA

The fluoroquinolone antibiotic ciprofloxacin has recently been reported to upregulate interleukin-2 ( IL-2 ) gene induction .
10,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein

In the present investigation , the effect of ciprofloxacin at supratherapeutic concentrations on immediate-early ( &lt; 2 h ) gene expression in primary human peripheral blood lymphocytes was studied with Northern blots .
22,27 G#cell_type

In addition , transcriptional activity of IL-2 and metallothionein enhancer and promoter regions and transcription factors AP-1 , NF-kappaB , and NF-AT were analyzed by chloramphenicol acetyltransferase ( CAT ) and electrophoretic mobility shift assays , respectively .
6,7 G#protein|8,13 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein|16,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|21,22 G#protein|25,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The concentration of c-fos , c-jun , c-myc , junB , and fra-1 mRNAs was increased in activated peripheral blood lymphocytes incubated with ciprofloxacin compared to that in untreated controls .
3,14 G#RNA|18,21 G#cell_type

Ciprofloxacin increased CAT activity in stimulated lymphocytes transfected with plasmids containing either the IL-2 or metallothionein enhancer .
2,3 G#protein|9,10 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|15,17 G#DNA

Furthermore , among the transcription factors tested , AP-1 activity was increased in stimulated purified T helper lymphocytes incubated with ciprofloxacin compared to drug-free controls .
4,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|13,18 G#cell_type|23,25 G#cell_type

Taken together , ciprofloxacin increased the levels of immediate-early transcripts , enhanced IL-2 and metallothionein promoter induction , and upregulated AP-1 concentrations in primary lymphocytes , reflecting a program commonly observed in mammalian stress responses .
8,10 G#RNA|12,13 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|23,25 G#cell_type

A novel retinoic acid receptor ( RAR ) -selective antagonist inhibits differentiation and apoptosis of HL-60 cells : implications of RARalpha -mediated signals in myeloid leukemic cells .
2,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|15,17 G#cell_line|20,21 G#protein|24,27 G#cell_type

Retinoic acid ( RA ) induces HL-60 cells to differentiate terminally into mature granulocytes , which subsequently die by apoptosis .
6,8 G#cell_line|12,14 G#cell_type

The biological effects of RA are mediated by two distinct families of transcription factors : retinoic acid receptors ( RARs ) and retinoid X receptors ( RXRs ) .
12,14 G#protein|15,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,25 G#protein|26,27 G#protein

RARs and RXRs form heterodimers and regulate retinoid-mediated gene expression .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein

We have recently developed a novel RAR -selective antagonist ( ER27191 ) which prevents RAR activation by retinoids .
6,7 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

Using this RAR-selective antagonist , and RXR and RAR agonist , we demonstrate the RAR -mediated signaling pathway is important for differentiation and apoptosis of myeloid leukemic cells .
6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|25,28 G#cell_type

Simple activation of RXRs is not sufficient to induce apoptosis of the cells .
3,4 G#protein

Interestingly , the combination of the RAR-selective antagonist and 9-cis RA resulted in partial differentiation and apoptosis of HL-60 and NB4 cells , whereas the RAR antagonist completely blocked all-trans RA -induced differentiation and apoptosis of the cells .
18,22 G#cell_line|25,26 G#protein

Additional experiments showed that levels of BCL-2 protein decreased during differentiation of myeloid leukemic cells .
6,8 G#protein|12,15 G#cell_type

Furthermore , HL-60 cells transduced with a bcl-2 expression vector showed the same differentiation response to retinoids as did parental HL-60 cells even though apoptosis was inhibited in these bcl-2-transduced cells , suggesting that differentiation and apoptosis are regulated independently in myeloid leukemic cells .
2,4 G#cell_line|7,10 G#DNA|20,22 G#cell_line|19,22 G#cell_line|29,31 G#cell_line|41,44 G#cell_type

Thrombopoietin supports in vitro erythroid differentiation via its specific receptor c-Mpl in a human leukemia cell line .
0,1 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,17 G#cell_line

Thrombopoietin ( TPO ) acts on megakaryopoiesis and erythropoiesis in vitro and in vivo .
0,1 G#protein|2,3 G#protein

We isolated a novel subline , UT-7/GMT , from the human leukemia cell line UT-7/GM ( N. Komatsu , et al. , Blood , 89 : 4021-4033 , 1997 ) .
6,7 G#cell_line|10,14 G#cell_line|10,15 G#cell_line

A small population of UT-7/GM cells positively stained for hemoglobin ( Hb ) after a 7-day exposure to TPO .
4,6 G#cell_line|9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

More than 50 % of TPO -treated UT-7/GMT cells positively stained for Hb .
5,6 G#protein|5,9 G#cell_line|12,13 G#protein

Using UT-7/GMT cells , we examined how TPO promotes hemoglobinization .
1,3 G#cell_line|7,8 G#protein

TPO induced tyrosine phosphorylation of the TPO receptor but not the erythropoietin ( EPO ) receptor .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|11,16 G#protein

There was no competition between TPO and EPO for binding to EPO receptor .
5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|11,13 G#protein

These findings suggest that TPO has a direct effect on hemoglobinization via a specific receptor on UT-7/GMT cells .
4,5 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_line

Isoelectric focusing demonstrated that TPO induced fetal and adult Hb synthesis , whereas EPO induced embryonic , fetal , and adult Hb synthesis .
4,5 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Thus , our data suggest that TPO has a distinct action on erythropoiesis .
6,7 G#protein

Role of GATA-1 in proliferation and differentiation of definitive erythroid and megakaryocytic cells in vivo .
2,3 G#protein|9,13 G#cell_type

To elucidate the contributions of GATA-1 to definitive hematopoiesis in vivo , we have examined adult mice that were rendered genetically defective in GATA-1 synthesis ( Takahashi et al , J Biol Chem 272 : 12611 , 1997 ) .
5,6 G#protein|23,24 G#protein

Because the GATA-1 gene is located on the X chromosome , which is randomly inactivated in every cell , heterozygous females can bear either an active wild-type or mutant ( referred to as GATA-1.05 ) GATA-1 allele , consequently leading to variable anemic severity .
2,3 G#protein|2,4 G#DNA|8,10 G#DNA|33,34 G#DNA|35,36 G#protein

These heterozygous mutant mice usually developed normally , but they began to die after 5 months .


These affected animals displayed marked splenomegaly , anemia , and thrombocytopenia .


Proerythroblasts and megakaryocytes massively accumulated in the spleens of the heterozygotes , and we showed that the neomycin resistance gene ( which is the positive selection marker in ES cells ) was expressed profusely in the abnormally abundant cells generated in the GATA-1.05 mutant females .
0,1 G#cell_type|2,3 G#cell_type|17,20 G#DNA|28,30 G#cell_type|42,43 G#protein

We also observed hematopoiesis outside of the bone marrow in the affected mutant mice .


These data suggest that a small number of GATA-1.05 mutant hematopoietic progenitor cells begin to proliferate vigorously during early adulthood , but because the cells are unable to terminally differentiate , this leads to progenitor proliferation in the spleen and consequently death .
8,9 G#protein|8,13 G#cell_line

Thus , GATA-1 plays important in vivo roles for directing definitive hematopoietic progenitors to differentiate along both the erythroid and megakaryocytic pathways .
2,3 G#protein|11,13 G#cell_type

The GATA-1 heterozygous mutant mouse shows a phenotype that is analogous to human myelodysplastic syndrome and thus may serve as a useful model for this disorder .
1,2 G#protein

Differential regulation of the Janus kinase -STAT pathway and biologic function of IL-13 in primary human NK and T cells : a comparative study with IL-4 .
4,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|14,20 G#cell_type|25,26 G#protein

IL-13 , a cytokine similar to IL-4 , is a regulator of human B cell and monocyte functions .
0,1 G#protein|6,7 G#protein

Biologic effects of IL-13 on primary human NK and T cells have not been well defined .
3,4 G#protein|5,11 G#cell_type

We demonstrate that , in primary NK cells , IL-13 , but not IL-4 , may induce low levels of IFN-gamma secretion .
5,8 G#cell_type|9,10 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein

When NK cells were costimulated with IL-13 and IL-2 , IL-13 generally resulted in two types of reactivity : IL-13 synergized with IL-2 to stimulate IFN-gamma production or it modestly inhibited IL-2 - mediated IFN-gamma production .
1,3 G#cell_type|6,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|31,32 G#protein|34,35 G#protein

In both types of donors , the effect of IL-13 on IL-2 -induced IFN-gamma production was in marked contrast to the strong inhibition seen with IL-4 in NK cells .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|27,29 G#cell_type

Additionally , IL-13 suppresses IL-2-induced NK cytolytic and proliferative activities although less efficiently than IL-4 .
2,3 G#protein|14,15 G#protein

In T cells , IL-13 inhibits anti-CD3 mAb/IL-2- or PHA- mediated IFN-gamma production and enhances cytolytic potential .
1,3 G#cell_type|4,5 G#protein

Furthermore , we demonstrate that IL-13 , like IL-4 , induces distinct STAT6-DNA binding complexes and tyrosine phosphorylation of STAT6 and Janus kinase 3 ( JAK3 ) in NK and T cells .
5,6 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|12,15 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|21,24 G#protein|25,26 G#protein|30,32 G#cell_type

We observed that Abs directed against unique domains of STAT6 have differential effects on complexes in T cells but not in NK cells , suggesting different STAT6 isoforms .
9,10 G#protein|16,18 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type|26,27 G#protein|26,28 G#protein

These findings show that IL-13 and IL-4 have the ability to regulate NK and T cell activation and that IL- 13 is a potent regulator of STAT6 and JAK3 in these cell types .
4,5 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|19,21 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|28,29 G#protein

The human toll signaling pathway : divergence of nuclear factor kappaB and JNK /SAPK activation upstream of tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor 6 ( TRAF6 ) .
8,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|17,23 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

The human homologue of Drosophila Toll ( hToll ) is a recently cloned receptor of the interleukin 1 receptor ( IL-1R ) superfamily , and has been implicated in the activation of adaptive immunity .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|16,23 G#protein

Signaling by hToll is shown to occur through sequential recruitment of the adapter molecule MyD88 and the IL-1R-associated kinase .
2,3 G#protein|12,14 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,19 G#protein

Tumor necrosis factor receptor-activated factor 6 ( TRAF6 ) and the nuclear factor kappaB ( NF-kappaB ) -inducing kinase ( NIK ) are both involved in subsequent steps of NF-kappaB activation .
0,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|11,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|11,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

Conversely , a dominant negative version of TRAF6 failed to block hToll -induced activation of stress-activated protein kinase/c-Jun NH2-terminal kinases , thus suggesting an early divergence of the two pathways .
7,8 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,20 G#protein

Inhibition of nuclear factor kappaB activation attenuates apoptosis resistance in lymphoid cells .
2,5 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type

Death-inducing ligands ( DILs ) such as tumor necrosis factor alpha ( TNFalpha ) or the cytotoxic drug doxorubicin have been shown to activate a nuclear factor kappaB ( NFkappaB ) -dependent program that may rescue cells from apoptosis induction .
0,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,11 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|25,28 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

We demonstrate here that TRAIL ( TNF-related apoptosis -inducing ligand ) , a recently identified DIL , also activates NFkappaB in lymphoid cell lines in a kinetic similar to TNFalpha .
4,5 G#protein|6,10 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|29,30 G#protein

NFkappaB activity is independent from FADD , caspases , and apoptosis induction .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein

To study the influence of NFkappaB activity on apoptosis mediated by TRAIL , CD95 , TNFalpha , or doxorubicin , NFkappaB activation was inhibited using the proteasome inhibitor N-acetyl-L-leucinyl-L-leucinyl-L-norleucinal or transient overexpression of mutant IkappaBalpha .
5,6 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|26,27 G#protein|33,35 G#protein

Sensitivity for induction of apoptosis was markedly increased by these treatments in apoptosis sensitive cell lines .
14,16 G#cell_line

Moreover , both in cell lines and in primary leukemia cells that are resistant towards induction of apoptosis by DILs and doxorubicin , antagonization of NFkappaB activity partially restored apoptosis sensitivity .
19,20 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

These data suggest that inhibition of NFkappaB activation may provide a molecular approach to increase apoptosis sensitivity in anticancer treatment .
6,7 G#protein

Loss- and gain-of-function mutations reveal an important role of BSAP ( Pax-5 ) at the start and end of B cell differentiation .
9,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein

Pax-5 codes for the transcription factor BSAP which is expressed throughout B cell development except in terminally differentiated plasma cells .
0,1 G#protein|4,6 G#protein|6,7 G#protein|16,20 G#cell_type

Gene targeting experiments in the mouse revealed a differential dependency of fetal and adult B-lymphopoiesis on this transcription factor .
17,19 G#protein

BSAP is required for B-lineage commitment in the fetal liver and for progression beyond an early pro-B cell stage in adult bone marrow .
0,1 G#protein

The characterization of Pax-5 -deficient pro-B cells demonstrated an important role of BSAP in the regulation of the CD19 , mb-1 ( Ig alpha ) and N-myc genes as well as in the developmental pathway controlling VH-to-DHJH recombination at the immunoglobulin heavy-chain ( IgH ) locus .
3,4 G#protein|3,7 G#cell_type|12,13 G#protein|18,19 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|22,24 G#protein|26,28 G#DNA|40,42 G#protein|43,44 G#protein|40,46 G#protein

The human PAX-5 gene was recently shown to participate together with the IgH locus in the chromosomal translocation t(9;14)(p13;q32) .
1,4 G#DNA|12,14 G#DNA|18,19 G#DNA

This translocation is characteristic of a small subset of non-Hodgkin lymphomas exhibiting plasmacytoid differentiation .


The translocated PAX-5 gene is deregulated by the insertion of IgH regulatory elements into its 5' region , which may contribute to tumorigenesis by interfering with the shut-down of PAX-5 transcription and thus with the completion of plasma cell differentiation
1,4 G#DNA|10,13 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|29,30 G#protein|37,39 G#cell_type

Acetylation and modulation of erythroid Kruppel-like factor ( EKLF ) activity by interaction with histone acetyltransferases .
4,7 G#protein|8,9 G#protein|14,16 G#protein

Erythroid Kruppel-like factor ( EKLF ) is a red cell-specific transcriptional activator that is crucial for consolidating the switch to high levels of adult beta-globin expression during erythroid ontogeny .
0,3 G#protein|4,5 G#protein|8,12 G#protein|24,25 G#protein

EKLF is required for integrity of the chromatin structure at the beta-like globin locus , and it interacts with a positive-acting factor in vivo .
0,1 G#protein|7,9 G#DNA|11,14 G#DNA|20,22 G#protein

We find that EKLF is an acetylated transcription factor , and that it interacts in vivo with CBP , p300 , and P/CAF .
3,4 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein

However , its interactions with these histone acetyltransferases are not equivalent , as CBP and p300 , but not P/CAF , utilize EKLF as a substrate for in vitro acetylation within its trans- activation region .
6,8 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|15,16 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|22,23 G#protein|33,35 G#protein

The functional effects of these interactions are that CBP and p300 , but not P/CAF , enhance EKLF 's transcriptional activation of the beta-globin promoter in erythroid cells .
8,9 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|23,25 G#DNA|26,28 G#cell_type

These results establish EKLF as a tissue-specific transcription factor that undergoes post-translational acetylation and suggest a mechanism by which EKLF is able to alter chromatin structure and induce beta-globin expression within the beta-like globin cluster .
3,4 G#protein|6,9 G#protein|19,20 G#protein|24,25 G#DNA|28,29 G#protein|32,35 G#DNA

Recognition of herpes simplex virus type 2 tegument proteins by CD4 T cells infiltrating human genital herpes lesions .
2,9 G#protein|10,13 G#cell_type

The local cellular immune response to herpes simplex virus ( HSV ) is important in the control of recurrent HSV infection .


The antiviral functions of infiltrating CD4-bearing T cells may include cytotoxicity , inhibition of viral growth , lymphokine secretion , and support of humoral and CD8 responses .
4,8 G#cell_type|17,18 G#protein

The antigens recognized by many HSV -specific CD4 T cells localizing to genital HSV -2 lesions are unknown .
7,10 G#cell_type|5,10 G#cell_type

T cells recognizing antigens encoded within map units 0 . 67 to 0.73 of HSV DNA are frequently recovered from herpetic lesions .
0,2 G#cell_type|14,16 G#DNA

Expression cloning with this region of DNA now shows that tegument protein VP22 and the viral dUTPase , encoded by genes UL49 and UL50 , respectively , are T-cell antigens .
10,12 G#protein|12,13 G#protein|15,17 G#protein|21,22 G#DNA|23,24 G#DNA|20,24 G#DNA|28,30 G#protein

Separate epitopes in VP22 were defined for T-cell clones from each of three patients .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_line

Reactivity with the tegument protein encoded by UL21 was identified for an additional patient .
3,5 G#protein|7,8 G#DNA

Three new epitopes were identified in VP16 , a tegument protein associated with VP22 .
6,7 G#protein|9,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein

Some tegument-specific CD4 T-cell clones exhibited cytotoxic activity against HSV -infected cells .
3,5 G#cell_line|1,5 G#cell_line|9,12 G#cell_type

These results suggest that herpes simplex tegument proteins are processed for antigen presentation in vivo and are possible candidate compounds for herpes simplex vaccines .
4,8 G#protein

Fibrinogen activates NF-kappa B transcription factors in mononuclear phagocytes .
0,1 G#protein|2,4 G#protein|2,6 G#protein|7,9 G#cell_type

Adhesion to extracellular matrices is known to modulate leukocyte activation , although the mechanisms are not fully understood .


Mononuclear phagocytes are exposed to fibrinous provisional matrix throughout migration into inflammatory foci , so this study was undertaken to determine whether fibrinogen triggers activation of NF-kappa B transcription factors .
0,2 G#cell_type|26,30 G#protein

U937 cells differentiated with PMA in nonadherent culture were shown to express two fibrinogen-binding integrins , predominately CD11b/CD18 , and to a lesser extent , CD11c/CD18 .
0,2 G#cell_line|6,8 G#cell_line|13,15 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|25,26 G#protein

Cells stimulated with fibrinogen ( 10-100 microg/ml ) /Mn2+ ( 50 microM ) for 2 h were examined by electrophoretic mobility shift assay .
3,4 G#protein

NF-kappa B activation , minimal in unstimulated cells , was substantially up-regulated by fibrinogen .
0,2 G#protein|6,8 G#cell_type|13,14 G#protein

Fibrinogen also caused activation of AP-1 , but not SP1 or cAMP response element-binding protein ( CREB ) factors .
0,1 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|11,19 G#protein

Blocking mAbs against CD18 and CD11b abrogated fibrinogen -induced NF-kappa B activation .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein|5,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|9,11 G#protein

To determine the effects on transcriptional regulation , U937 cells were transfected with a plasmid containing the HIV-1 enhancer ( bearing two NF-kappa B sites ) coupled to a chloramphenicol acetyltransferase ( CAT ) reporter .
8,10 G#cell_line|17,19 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein|22,25 G#DNA|29,31 G#protein|32,33 G#protein|29,35 G#DNA

Cells were subsequently stimulated with 1 ) PMA for 24 h , inducing CAT activity by 2.6-fold , 2 ) fibrinogen /Mn2+ for 2 h , inducing CAT activity by 3.2-fold , or 3 ) costimulation with fibrinogen and PMA , inducing 5.7-fold the CAT activity induced by PMA alone .
13,14 G#protein|20,21 G#protein|27,28 G#protein|37,38 G#protein|44,45 G#protein

We conclude that contact with fibrinogen -derived proteins may contribute to mononuclear phagocyte activation by signaling through CD11b/CD18 , resulting in selective activation of transcriptional regulatory factors , including NF-kappa B .
5,6 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|17,18 G#protein|24,27 G#protein|29,31 G#protein

Peripheral blood T cells and monocytes and B cell lines derived from patients with lupus express estrogen receptor transcripts similar to those of normal cells .
2,4 G#cell_type|0,4 G#cell_type|5,6 G#cell_type|7,10 G#cell_line|23,25 G#cell_type

OBJECTIVE : To identify and characterize estrogen receptor ( ER ) transcripts expressed in immune cells of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE ) and healthy donors .
6,12 G#RNA|14,16 G#cell_type

METHODS : Peripheral blood monocytes and T cells were prepared from patients with SLE ( n = 6 ) and healthy donors ( n = 8 ) .
2,5 G#cell_type|6,8 G#cell_type

T cells were separated into CD4 and CD8 .
0,2 G#cell_type|5,6 G#cell_type|7,8 G#cell_type

Some monocytes and T cells were stimulated with estradiol , PMA , and ionomycin .
1,2 G#cell_type|3,5 G#cell_type

Epstein-Barr virus-transformed B cell lines ( n = 7 ) and B cell hybridomas ( n = 2 ) established from patients with SLE and a healthy individual were used as a B cell source .
2,5 G#cell_line|11,14 G#cell_line

These cells were examined for ER mRNA by reverse transcription nested polymerase chain reaction .
5,7 G#RNA

Amplified cDNA were sequenced by standard methods .
1,2 G#DNA

RESULTS : In all cells tested , ER mRNA was expressed without prior in vitro stimulation .
7,9 G#RNA

Partial sequences from exons 1-8 were nearly identical to the published sequence of the human ER mRNA .
3,5 G#DNA|15,17 G#RNA|14,17 G#RNA

There were no notable differences in the ER transcripts between patients and healthy controls .
7,9 G#RNA

Variant receptor transcripts lacking exon 5 or exon 7 , which encodes the hormone binding domain , were identified in the majority of the cells .
4,6 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA

Precise deletion of the exons suggests that they are alternatively spliced transcripts .


Whether the detected transcripts are translated into functional receptor proteins remains to be determined .


In vitro stimulation did not affect ER mRNA expression .
6,8 G#RNA

The presence of variants did not correlate with disease activity or medication .


CONCLUSION : Monocytes , T cells , and B cells in patients express transcripts of the normal wild type ER and the hormone binding domain variants in vivo .
2,3 G#cell_type|4,6 G#cell_type|8,10 G#cell_type|17,20 G#protein|22,26 G#protein

DNA damaging agents induce expression of Fas ligand and subsequent apoptosis in T lymphocytes via the activation of NF-kappa B and AP-1 .
6,8 G#protein|12,14 G#cell_type|18,20 G#protein|21,22 G#protein

Apoptosis induced by DNA damage and other stresses can proceed via expression of Fas ligand ( FasL ) and ligation of its receptor , Fas ( CD95 ) .
13,15 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

We report that activation of the two transcription factors NF-kappa B and AP-1 is crucially involved in FasL expression induced by etoposide , teniposide , and UV irradiation .
12,13 G#protein|17,18 G#protein

A nondegradable mutant of I kappa B blocked both FasL expression and apoptosis induced by DNA damage but not Fas ligation .
4,7 G#protein|9,10 G#protein|19,20 G#protein

These stimuli also induced the stress-activated kinase pathway ( SAPK /JNK ) , which was required for the maximal induction of apoptosis .
9,10 G#protein|10,11 G#protein

A 1.2 kb FasL promoter responded to DNA damage , as well as coexpression with p65 Rel or Fos/Jun .
3,4 G#protein|3,5 G#DNA|15,17 G#protein|18,19 G#protein

Mutations in the relevant NF-kappa B and AP-1 binding sites eliminated these responses .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|7,10 G#DNA

Thus , activation of NF-kappa B and AP-1 contributes to stress-induced apoptosis via the expression of FasL .
4,6 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|16,17 G#protein

A small , nonpeptidyl mimic of granulocyte-colony-stimulating factor [ see commetns ]
6,8 G#protein

A nonpeptidyl small molecule SB 247464 , capable of activating granulocyte-colony-stimulating factor ( G-CSF ) signal transduction pathways , was identified in a high-throughput assay in cultured cells .
10,12 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|26,28 G#cell_type

Like G-CSF , SB 247464 induced tyrosine phosphorylation of multiple signaling proteins and stimulated primary murine bone marrow cells to form granulocytic colonies in vitro .
1,2 G#protein|9,12 G#protein|14,19 G#cell_type|21,23 G#cell_type

It also elevated peripheral blood neutrophil counts in mice .
3,6 G#cell_type

The extracellular domain of the murine G-CSF receptor was required for the activity of SB 247464 , suggesting that the compound acts by oligomerizing receptor chains .
6,7 G#protein|5,8 G#protein|23,26 G#protein

The results indicate that a small molecule can activate a receptor that normally binds a relatively large protein ligand .


Minimal residual disease in acute myelogenous leukemia with PML/RAR alpha or AML1/ETO mRNA and phenotypic analysis of possible T and natural killer cells in bone marrow .
8,10 G#protein|11,12 G#protein|8,13 G#RNA|17,23 G#cell_type

Here we studied minimal residual disease ( MRD ) of patients with acute myeloid leukemia ( AML ) who have PML/RAR alpha or AML1/ETO as well as the phenotypic analysis of lymphocyte subsets involved in antitumor immunity .
20,22 G#protein|23,24 G#protein|31,33 G#cell_type

Eight patients in long-term ( LT ; 3 to 15 years ) and 15 patients in short-term ( ST ; up to 3 years ) remission were studied .


Using the reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction ( RT ) assay , the limit of detection was 10(-5) to 10(-6) for PML/RAR alpha transcript and 10(-4) to 10(-5) for the AML1/ETO transcript .
20,22 G#protein|20,23 G#RNA|29,30 G#protein|29,31 G#RNA

Simultaneously , T lymphocyte subsets and NK cells from the peripheral blood ( PB ) and bone marrow ( BM ) were investigated by flow cytometric analysis .
2,5 G#cell_type|6,8 G#cell_type

Four of the eight patients in LT and 7 of the 15 patients in ST remission were MRD -positive .


Although all MRD -positive patients in LT remission are still until now event-free , 3 of the 7 MRD -positive ( MRD + ) patients in ST remission soon relapsed .


The total populations of CD4 + , CD8 + and CD56 + [ possible T-cell and natural killer ( T/NK ) populations ] in the BM of ST patients and MRD +/LT patients were significantly ( p &lt; .01 ) low .
4,5 G#protein|7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|14,15 G#cell_type|16,18 G#cell_type|19,20 G#cell_type

The CD8 + CD28 + population showed the same tendency ( p &lt; .01-.02 ) .
1,2 G#protein|3,4 G#protein

The T/NK subsets in the BM of MRD -negative ( MRD - ) LT ( MRD -/LT ) patients showed similar numbers of cells as normal volunteers .
1,3 G#cell_type

Basically , the total percentage of the CD4 + , CD8 + and CD56 + cell populations in the BM was increased and in the following order : MRD -/LT patients , normal volunteers , MRD +/LT patients and MRD + or -/ST patients .
7,8 G#protein|10,11 G#protein|13,14 G#protein|7,17 G#cell_type

The percentages of the T/NK-cell subsets in the PB were not significantly different among these groups .
4,6 G#cell_type

Thus , the difference of the possible T/NK-cell phenotype in the BM may strongly influence clinical and molecular remission .
7,8 G#cell_type

These results still remain to be confirmed by further studies of the functional anti-tumor immunity of T/NK cells of AML in remission .
16,18 G#cell_type

Mycobacterium tuberculosis mannose-capped lipoarabinomannan can induce NF-kappaB -dependent activation of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 long terminal repeat in T cells .
6,7 G#protein|15,18 G#DNA|19,21 G#cell_type

Tuberculosis has emerged as an epidemic , extended by the large number of individuals infected with human immunodeficiency virus type 1 ( HIV-1 ) .


The major goal of this study was to determine whether the mycobacterial cell wall component mannose-capped lipoarabinomannan ( ManLAM ) of Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( M. tuberculosis ) could activate transcription of HIV-1 in T cells with the use of an in vitro cell culture system .
11,13 G#cell_type|33,35 G#cell_type

These experiments are of prime importance considering that CD4 -expressing T lymphocytes represent the major virus reservoir in the peripheral blood of infected individuals .
8,9 G#protein|10,12 G#cell_type|8,12 G#cell_type

Using the 1G5 cell line harbouring the luciferase reporter gene under the control of the HIV-1 LTR , it was first found that culture protein filtrates ( CFP ) from M. tuberculosis or purified ManLAM could activate HIV-1 LTR -dependent gene expression unlike similarly prepared CFP extracts devoid of ManLAM .
2,5 G#cell_line|7,10 G#DNA|15,17 G#DNA|37,39 G#DNA|37,41 G#DNA

The implication of protein tyrosine kinase ( s ) , protein kinase A and/or protein kinase C was highlighted by the abrogation of the ManLAM -mediated activation of HIV-1 LTR -driven gene expression using herbimycin A and H7 .
3,9 G#protein|10,13 G#protein|14,17 G#protein|28,30 G#DNA|28,32 G#DNA

It was also determined , using electrophoresis mobility shift assays , that M. tuberculosis ManLAM led to the nuclear translocation of the transcription factor NF-kappaB .
24,25 G#protein|22,25 G#protein

M. tuberculosis ManLAM resulted in clear induction of the luciferase gene placed under the control of the wild-type , but not the kappaB -mutated , HIV-1 LTR region .
9,11 G#DNA|22,23 G#DNA|26,27 G#DNA|25,28 G#DNA|17,28 G#DNA

Finally , the ManLAM -mediated activation of HIV-1 LTR transcription was found to be independent of the autocrine or paracrine action of endogenous TNF-alpha .
8,9 G#DNA|7,9 G#DNA|22,24 G#protein

The results suggest that M. tuberculosis can upregulate HIV-1 expression in T cells and could thus have the potential to influence the pathogenesis of HIV-1 infection .
11,13 G#cell_type

Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 long terminal repeat quasispecies differ in basal transcription and nuclear factor recruitment in human glial cells and lymphocytes .
5,8 G#DNA|0,8 G#DNA|0,9 G#DNA|14,16 G#protein|18,23 G#cell_type

The generation of genomic diversity during the course of infection has the potential to affect all aspects of HIV-1 replication , including expression of the proviral genome .
25,27 G#DNA
